At the apical surface, duct epithelial cells possess microvilli and other specialized structures that increase their surface area and allow for more efficient secretion and absorption of fluids and solutes. They also produce and secrete specific proteins and lipids that are important for the function of the gland. At the basal surface, duct epithelial cells are anchored to the basement membrane through various adhesion molecules, which provide structural support and help to maintain the integrity of the glandular duct.

In addition to their secretory and transport functions, duct epithelial cells are also important regulators of glandular homeostasis and tissue remodeling. They play a key role in responding to various stimuli, including hormones, growth factors, and inflammatory signals, and can differentiate into other cell types in response to specific environmental cues. Dysregulation of duct epithelial cell function has been implicated in the pathogenesis of various glandular disorders, including cancer, cystic fibrosis, and pancreatitis.
CL:0000102:
Polymodal neurons are a type of sensory neuron found in the dorsal root ganglia of the spinal cord and cranial nerve ganglia. These neurons play a vital role in the transmission of sensory information from various modalities such as temperature, pressure, pain, and touch. Polymodal neurons have a unique ability to respond to multiple types of stimuli due to their diverse range of sensory receptors present on their dendritic endings.

Under normal conditions, these neurons respond to stimuli within their respective physiological ranges. However, when exposed to noxious stimuli, polymodal neurons become sensitized leading to an increase in their response magnitude and prolonged activation. This phenomenon, termed peripheral sensitization, leads to an enhanced pain response as seen in chronic pain disorders such as neuropathic pain.

Polymodal neurons’ unique ability to respond to multiple sensory stimuli makes them a crucial component of the nervous system's sensory pathway. Their ability to become sensitized plays a critical role in the development of chronic pain. By better understanding the neuronal mechanisms underlying peripheral sensitization, the development of new therapies targeting these cells could lead to more effective pain management strategies.
CL:0000116:
Pioneer neurons, also known as guidepost neurons, are a type of neuron that play a crucial role in the development of the nervous system. During the early stages of embryonic development, pioneer neurons migrate to specific regions and establish pathways that guide other neurons to their final destinations. They do this by extending axons and producing chemotropic factors that attract or repel other cells.

In addition to guiding other neurons, pioneer neurons also play a role in establishing neural circuits. They form connections with other neurons and provide the basis for the subsequent development of more complex neural networks. In some cases, pioneer neurons may also be involved in synaptic transmission, although their precise function in this capacity is not yet fully understood.

One of the most intriguing aspects of pioneer neurons is their ability to regenerate. In certain circumstances, such as after a spinal cord injury, pioneer neurons have been observed to grow new axons and reestablish connections with other neurons. This has led to considerable interest in the potential therapeutic applications of pioneer neurons, particularly for the treatment of spinal cord injuries and other neurological disorders.
CL:0000223:
Endodermal cells are a type of epithelial cell that arises from the innermost layer of the three primary germ layers during embryonic development. Endodermal cells have a diverse range of functions throughout the body, and are primarily found in organs such as the liver, pancreas, lungs, gut, and bladder. They are responsible for many important functions, such as nutrient absorption, waste elimination, and hormone secretion, to name a few.

In the gastrointestinal tract, for example, endodermal cells in the lining of the small intestine help to absorb nutrients from the digested food, while those in the large intestine help to eliminate waste products. Similarly, in the liver, endodermal cells called hepatocytes play a critical role in detoxification and metabolism of drugs and other substances. Endodermal cells in the pancreas produce and secrete important hormones, such as insulin and glucagon, which help regulate glucose and energy metabolism.

Overall, endodermal cells are an essential part of many diverse organ systems and play a critical role in maintaining homeostasis and overall health and well-being. Research into the molecular mechanisms underlying endodermal cell function has the potential to lead to new treatments and therapies for a wide range of diseases and disorders.
CL:0000831:
Mast cell progenitors are a type of stem cell that give rise to mast cells, a cell type involved in various immune and inflammatory responses. These progenitor cells can be found in the bone marrow, and upon activation, they differentiate and migrate to different tissues in the body where they mature into fully functional mast cells. 

Mast cells play a vital role in allergic reactions and host defense against parasites. Upon activation, mast cells release a variety of granules containing histamine, cytokines, and chemokines, which can recruit other immune cells to the site of activation and initiate various inflammatory processes. Histamine release from mast cells is responsible for many allergy symptoms such as itching, swelling, and sneezing. Additionally, mast cells are involved in wound healing and tissue remodeling.

The development and differentiation of mast cell progenitors are influenced by various factors such as cytokines and growth factors. Understanding the regulation of mast cell progenitor biology can potentially lead to the development of therapies for a wide range of diseases, including allergies, asthma, and certain cancers. Overall, mast cell progenitors are a critical component of the body's immune system and play essential roles in both health and disease.
CL:0000064:
Ciliated cells are specialized epithelial cells that play an important role in moving fluids and particles across the surface of tissues. These cells are characterized by the presence of hair-like projections known as cilia, which extend from their surface and beat in coordinated waves to create a directional flow. Ciliated cells are found in many different tissues throughout the body, including the respiratory tract, the reproductive system, and the sensory organs.

One of the most well-known functions of ciliated cells is to help clear mucus and debris from the respiratory tract. In this context, the coordinated beating of cilia helps to move particles trapped in mucus up and out of the lungs, where they can be coughed out or swallowed. Ciliated cells also play a role in protecting the reproductive system, where they help to move sperm and eggs through the reproductive tract. In addition, certain types of sensory cells in the inner ear are ciliated, where they help detect motion and changes in position.

Despite the importance of ciliated cells in many different tissues, their function can be disrupted by a variety of factors, including disease, environmental pollutants, and genetic mutations. For example, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and cystic fibrosis are both associated with impaired ciliary function in the respiratory tract, which can lead to chronic infections and other complications. Understanding the structure and function of ciliated cells is therefore an important area of research with implications for human health and disease.
CL:0000084:
T cells, also known as T lymphocytes, are a type of white blood cell that play a major role in the adaptive immune system. They are produced in the bone marrow and mature in the thymus gland. T cells are known for their ability to recognize and respond to specific antigens, which can include molecules from viruses, bacteria, and cancer cells.

There are several types of T cells, each with their own unique functions. Helper T cells, also known as CD4+ T cells, play a critical role in the immune response by activating and coordinating other cells in the immune system. Killer T cells, also known as CD8+ T cells, directly target and kill infected or cancerous cells. Regulatory T cells help to prevent autoimmune responses by suppressing the activity of other T cells.

T cells are activated when their T cell receptor binds to a specific antigen presented by an antigen-presenting cell. Once activated, they undergo clonal expansion, meaning they produce copies of themselves to mount a more robust immune response. T cells are capable of forming memory, which allows them to quickly respond to a previously encountered antigen in the future.

Overall, T cells are crucial in the body's defense against infection and disease. Dysfunction of T cells can lead to a variety of immune disorders and diseases, including autoimmune diseases and immunodeficiencies.
CL:0000060:
Odontoblasts are a type of specialized cell that forms dentin, a hard mineralized tissue found in teeth. These cells are located in the pulp of teeth and are responsible for maintaining the integrity of the tooth structure. When a tooth is damaged or worn down, odontoblasts can generate new dentin to replace the lost tissue.

Odontoblasts are characterized by their long, slender processes, which extend into the dentin and form microscopic tubules that communicate with the external environment. These processes secrete a variety of substances, including collagen and non-collagenous proteins, which make up the extracellular matrix of dentin. The odontoblasts themselves are also capable of mineralizing their own matrix, making them a key player in the development and repair of teeth.

In addition to their role in dentin formation, odontoblasts are also involved in transmitting sensory information from the pulp to the brain. These cells have been shown to express sensory receptors that respond to a variety of stimuli, including temperature and pressure. This allows them to detect changes in the internal environment of the tooth and initiate appropriate physiological responses. Overall, odontoblasts play a critical role in maintaining the structural and functional integrity of teeth, making them a vital cell type in the body.
CL:0007002:
Precementoblast is a type of primitive mesenchymal cell that gives rise to cementoblasts, which are responsible for forming cementum on the root surface of teeth. It is a unique cell type that is only found in specific regions of the periodontal ligament, which connects the root of a tooth to the surrounding alveolar bone. Precementoblasts are thought to arise from the dental follicle, which is a specialized connective tissue that surrounds the developing tooth germ.

As immature cementoblasts, precementoblasts have the ability to differentiate into a range of cell types, depending on the stimuli they receive from their microenvironment. They are responsible for producing the extracellular matrix of cementum, which consists primarily of collagen, non-collagenous proteins, and hydroxyapatite. This matrix provides a durable surface for the attachment of the periodontal ligament fibers that help anchor the tooth to the surrounding bone.

During tooth development, precementoblasts migrate to the root surface of the tooth and differentiate into cementoblasts. These cells then begin secreting a layer of acellular cementum, which serves to protect the root surface and anchor the connective tissue fibers of the periodontal ligament. The formation and maintenance of cementum is critical for proper tooth function and periodontal health. Any disruption of this process can lead to a range of dental problems, including root resorption, tooth mobility, and periodontal disease.
CL:0000081:
Blood cells, also known as hematopoietic cells, are a diverse group of cells that make up the cellular component of blood. These cells are continuously produced in the bone marrow and play critical roles in maintaining homeostasis in the body. They are primarily responsible for transporting oxygen and nutrients to tissues, removing metabolic waste, and defending against pathogens.

There are three main types of blood cells: erythrocytes, leukocytes, and thrombocytes. Erythrocytes, also known as red blood cells, are responsible for transporting oxygen to tissues throughout the body. They contain hemoglobin, a protein that binds oxygen and enables its delivery to the body's tissues. Leukocytes, commonly referred to as white blood cells, are crucial for the immune system's function. They defend against bacterial and viral infections and other foreign substances. Thrombocytes, also known as platelets, play a critical role in the blood clotting process that stops bleeding after an injury.

Overall, blood cells are essential for the body's homeostasis, and any abnormalities in their number or function can lead to severe health consequences. Blood transfusions and bone marrow transplants are common therapies used to treat a variety of diseases that affect blood cell production. Understanding the functions of different blood cell types is critical for the development of new therapies to treat conditions such as anemia, leukemia, and other blood diseases.
CL:0000103:
A bipolar neuron is a type of neuron found in the sensory organs, including the retina, cochlea, and olfactory epithelium. It consists of a single axon and a single dendrite extending from opposite poles of the cell body. The dendrite receives signals from other neurons and transmits them towards the cell body, while the axon transmits signals away from the cell body to other neurons or effector cells.

In the retina, bipolar neurons play a crucial role in transmitting visual information from the photoreceptor cells to the ganglion cells. There are two types of bipolar neurons in the retina: ON and OFF. ON bipolar cells depolarize in response to light stimuli, while OFF bipolar cells hyperpolarize. These distinct responses to light allow for the discrimination of changes in the brightness of a visual scene. Bipolar neurons also play a role in the processing of auditory and olfactory information.

Bipolar neurons are essential for sensory perception and crucial for understanding how the nervous system processes incoming information. Dysfunctions of bipolar neurons can lead to sensory impairments, such as color blindness and hearing loss. Therefore, understanding the function and properties of bipolar neurons is crucial for developing treatments for these sensory disorders.
CL:0002077:
Ecto-epithelial cells are a type of epithelial cell that originates from the ectoderm layer of the developing embryo. They are responsible for providing a protective barrier between the external environment and the underlying tissues. These cells can be found in various organs such as the skin, oral cavity, and respiratory tract. Ecto-epithelial cells are essential in maintaining the integrity of these organs, preventing the invasion of pathogens and regulating the exchange of molecules between the external environment and the underlying tissue.

In the skin, ecto-epithelial cells are organized into layers and are responsible for providing protection against environmental factors such as UV radiation, chemicals, and pathogens. These cells also play a role in regulating body temperature by controlling the release of sweat and sebum. In the oral cavity, ecto-epithelial cells line the mouth and protect the underlying tissues from physical and chemical damage. They also play a role in the digestion of food by secreting enzymes and mucus.

In the respiratory tract, ecto-epithelial cells form a barrier that protects the underlying tissue from inhaled pathogens, pollutants, and allergens. These cells also secrete mucus that traps foreign particles and cilia that move the mucus out of the respiratory system. Overall, ecto-epithelial cells are vital in maintaining the integrity of the body's surfaces and protecting the underlying tissue from harmful external factors.
CL:0000075:
Columnar/cuboidal epithelial cells are a type of epithelial cell found in various organs of the body. These cells are characterized by their rectangular or cube-like shape and function to provide a protective barrier between the internal and external environment. Columnar epithelial cells are tall and narrow, while cuboidal epithelial cells are approximately as tall as they are wide.

Columnar/cuboidal epithelial cells can be found in various tissues throughout the body, including the lining of the digestive tract, respiratory tract, and ducts of the kidneys and salivary glands. These cells are responsible for the absorption of nutrients and secretion of mucus and other substances in the body. They also provide a barrier against invading microorganisms and toxins.

Columnar/cuboidal epithelial cells are polarized, meaning that they have distinct apical and basal surfaces. The apical surface faces outward and is in contact with the external environment, while the basal surface is in contact with the basal lamina and underlying connective tissue. This polarization allows for the selective transport of substances across the cell membrane and aids in the maintenance of a concentration gradient necessary for various cellular functions. Overall, columnar/cuboidal epithelial cells play a critical role in maintaining the integrity of tissues and organs within the body.
CL:0000077:
Mesothelial cells are a specialized type of epithelial cell that line the serous cavities of the body, such as the pleura, peritoneum, and pericardium. These cells play a crucial role in maintaining the integrity and function of these cavities by producing a lubricating fluid that helps to reduce friction between the membranes during movement. The mesothelial cells also act as a barrier, helping to prevent the invasion of pathogens and other foreign materials into these closed cavities.

Mesothelial cells have been shown to have diverse functions beyond their role in lubrication and barrier formation. For example, mesothelial cells have been found to secrete cytokines and chemokines that regulate immune cell function and promote tissue repair. Additionally, mesothelial cells have been implicated in the progression of various diseases, including cancer and fibrosis. In these contexts, mesothelial cells can undergo significant changes in their phenotype and function, contributing to disease pathogenesis.

Overall, the mesothelial cell is a highly specialized and important cell type that plays a critical role in maintaining the health and function of serous cavities in the body. While they are most commonly associated with their role in lubrication and barrier formation, recent research has highlighted the diverse functions of these cells in both health and disease.
CL:0002546:
Embryonic blood vessel endothelial progenitor cells (EBVEPCs) are a specialized subset of cells that play a vital role in the development of the circulatory system during embryonic development. These cells are derived from the mesoderm layer of the embryo and are responsible for forming the inner lining of blood vessels, known as the endothelium. EBVEPCs are characterized by their ability to self-renew and differentiate into mature endothelial cells, which form the basis of the vascular network throughout the body.

EBVEPCs have been shown to be critical for the proper development of the fetal circulatory system through angiogenesis, or the growth of new blood vessels. These cells are involved in the formation of the primitive vascular plexus, and are responsible for the sprouting and extension of new blood vessels to supply developing organs and tissues. In addition, EBVEPCs have been shown to be involved in the regulation of blood flow and blood pressure, as well as the repair and maintenance of the endothelium throughout life.

Research on EBVEPCs has focused on their potential therapeutic applications in the treatment of cardiovascular disease, as well as their use in tissue engineering and regenerative medicine. Importantly, EBVEPCs represent a unique and valuable cell type with the ability to differentiate into specialized cell types, and hold great promise for the development of novel treatments for a wide range of medical conditions, both now and in the future.
CL:0000357:
A stratified epithelial stem cell is a type of stem cell that is located in the basal layer of stratified epithelial tissues, including skin, esophagus, oral cavity, and cervix. These cells are responsible for tissue homeostasis, repair, and regeneration. Stratified epithelial stem cells have the capacity to differentiate into specialized cells and to self-renew, maintaining the stem cell niche. 

Stratified epithelial stem cells have been shown to differentiate into different cell types, depending on their location. For example, in the skin, stratified epithelial stem cells can differentiate into keratinocytes, which are responsible for creating the outermost layer of the skin. Stratified epithelial stem cells in the esophagus can differentiate into squamous cells, while those in the cervix differentiate into columnar cells. 

The ability of stratified epithelial stem cells to differentiate into specialized cells is crucial for tissue repair and regeneration. When the skin is injured, for example, stratified epithelial stem cells become activated, migrate to the site of damage, and differentiate into keratinocytes, which replace the damaged skin cells. This process is essential for wound healing and restoring tissue integrity. Understanding the role of stratified epithelial stem cells in tissue repair and regeneration is important for developing new therapies for a variety of diseases, including cancer and autoimmune disorders.
CL:0000710:
A neurecto-epithelial cell is a type of stem cell that is found in the developing nervous system of embryos. These cells are part of the early neural plate, which later gives rise to the neural tube and ultimately the brain and spinal cord. Neurecto-epithelial cells are highly proliferative and have the capacity to differentiate into many different cell types, including neurons, glia, and epithelial cells.

During embryonic development, neurecto-epithelial cells take part in a process called neurulation, which is the formation of the neural tube. Neurecto-epithelial cells undergo a process of mesenchymal-to-epithelial transition (MET) and delamination before they differentiate into more specialized cell types. This process is tightly regulated by various signalling pathways and transcription factors.

Neurecto-epithelial cells are important in the early stages of nervous system development. They provide a source of neural stem cells that can differentiate into all the cell types required for the formation of the brain and spinal cord. These cells also play a crucial role in the regulation of the size and shape of the neural tube, which is essential for proper development of the nervous system. Research into the properties and behaviour of neurecto-epithelial cells has the potential to contribute to the development of new treatments for nervous system disorders.
CL:0000864:
Tissue-resident macrophages are a type of immune cell that reside in specific tissues throughout the body such as the liver, lungs, and brain. Unlike circulating immune cells, tissue-resident macrophages are not derived from bone marrow stem cells but instead arise from embryonic precursors and self-renew during adulthood. These cells play an essential role in maintaining tissue homeostasis by monitoring their environment and swiftly responding to invading pathogens or tissue damage. 

Tissue-resident macrophages phagocytose and digest cellular debris, harmful microorganisms, and dying cells. They also produce cytokines and chemokines that recruit other immune cells to the site of infection or injury. In addition to their role in immunity, tissue-resident macrophages also have critical non-immunological functions such as remodeling tissue during development and aiding in tissue repair. Studies have shown that tissue-resident macrophages play a crucial role in the pathogenesis of several diseases such as cancer, fibrosis, and autoimmune disorders. 

Overall, the maintenance of a healthy tissue microenvironment largely depends on the proper functioning of tissue-resident macrophages. Dysregulation of these cells can result in an imbalance in the immune response contributing to the development of inflammatory and autoimmune diseases. The study of tissue-resident macrophages is of great importance in understanding immunity, tissue development, and disease pathology.
CL:0000078:
Peridermal cells are a type of specialized plant cell that form the outermost layer of the epidermis. These cells are typically flat and thin, and are characterized by their unique band-like shape. The periderm is the outermost layer of the plant stem, and the peridermal cells play a crucial role in protecting the plant from water loss, mechanical injury, and pathogen invasion.

One of the main functions of the peridermal cells is to form the plant's outermost protective barrier. This barrier helps to prevent water loss from the plant, and also protects the plant from mechanical injury and pathogen invasion. The periderm is especially important in woody plants, where the outermost layers of the stem are constantly expanding and contracting as the plant grows. The peridermal cells help to maintain the integrity of this outer layer, and provide a durable barrier that can withstand the stresses of the environment.

In addition to their protective role, peridermal cells are also important for regulating gas exchange in the plant. Like other epidermal cells, the peridermal cells are covered in pores called stomata. These pores allow gases such as oxygen and carbon dioxide to pass in and out of the plant, and are essential for photosynthesis and respiration. However, the peridermal cells also have a specialized role in regulating the opening and closing of the stomata, which helps to control the plant's water balance and prevent excessive water loss.
CL:0000062:
Osteoblasts are a type of bone cells that are responsible for producing new bone tissue during the process of bone formation or bone remodeling that takes place throughout life. These cells synthesize and secrete the organic matrix of bone tissue, which includes collagen and other proteins that provide the structural framework of the bone. Once the organic matrix is laid down, osteoblasts become embedded in it, where they differentiate into osteocytes, specialized cells that maintain the integrity of the bone tissue and regulate its metabolism.

The function of osteoblasts is crucial for bone health and physiology. Without them, bones would not be able to grow or repair themselves, and they would become weak and brittle. Osteoblasts work in concert with another type of bone cell, called osteoclasts, which are responsible for breaking down and resorbing bone tissue. Together, these two cell types regulate the delicate balance between bone formation and bone resorption that is necessary for skeletal homeostasis.

Several factors control the activity of osteoblasts, including hormones, growth factors, and mechanical stimuli. Hormones such as parathyroid hormone and calcitonin regulate the rate of bone turnover by affecting the differentiation and activity of osteoblasts and osteoclasts. Growth factors such as bone morphogenetic proteins and insulin-like growth factor stimulate the proliferation and differentiation of osteoblasts. Mechanical stimuli, such as weight-bearing exercise, also stimulate bone formation by increasing the number and activity of osteoblasts.
CL:0007010:
Preosteoblasts are a type of bone cell that are derived from mesenchymal stem cells. They play a crucial role in bone formation and remodeling by differentiating into mature osteoblasts, which produce the bone matrix. Preosteoblasts are characterized by their cuboidal shape and abundant rough endoplasmic reticulum.

The primary function of preosteoblasts is to secrete collagen and other proteins that form the extracellular matrix of bone tissue. As preosteoblasts mature, they deposit calcium and other minerals onto this matrix, creating a mineralized structure that gives bone its strength and rigidity. Preosteoblasts also stimulate the activity of osteoclasts, a type of bone cell that breaks down existing bone tissue and releases calcium and other minerals into the blood.

In addition to their role in bone formation, preosteoblasts are involved in the regulation of bone remodeling. They respond to signals from hormones such as parathyroid hormone and vitamin D to control the balance between bone formation and resorption. Dysregulation of preosteoblasts can lead to a number of bone disorders, such as osteoporosis and osteopetrosis. Overall, preosteoblasts are a critical component of the bone tissue, ensuring skeletal integrity and proper mineral homeostasis.
CL:0000067:
Ciliated epithelial cells are specialized cells that line the surfaces of many organs and tissues, such as the respiratory tract, the inner ear, and the female reproductive system. These cells are characterized by the presence of hair-like projections called cilia that extend from their apical surface. The cilia are capable of coordinated, rhythmic beating, which facilitates the movement of fluid and other substances across the surface of the tissue.

In the respiratory tract, ciliated epithelial cells play a critical role in clearing mucus and debris from the airways. The coordinated beating of their cilia creates a wave-like motion that helps to move the mucus and any trapped particles upwards and out of the lungs. Without ciliated epithelial cells, the airways would be more vulnerable to infections and other potentially harmful substances.

Ciliated epithelial cells are also important in the female reproductive system, where they help to move the egg from the ovary through the fallopian tube towards the uterus. In the inner ear, ciliated epithelial cells are involved in hearing and balance, helping to detect sound waves and changes in head position. In addition to their roles in these specific tissues, ciliated epithelial cells have also been implicated in other physiological processes, such as the regulation of fluid balance in the brain and the maintenance of the mucosal barrier in the gastrointestinal tract.
CL:0000097:
Mast cells are important players in the immune system, particularly in the defense against parasites, but also in allergic responses and inflammation. They are found throughout the body, but are concentrated in tissues that are in contact with the outside environment, such as the skin, lungs, and digestive tract. Mast cells are best known for their role in anaphylaxis, a severe and potentially life-threatening allergic reaction. 

Mast cells are uniquely equipped to detect and respond to a wide variety of stimuli. They are equipped with an arsenal of receptors that allow them to recognize different pathogens and respond accordingly. When they detect an invader, they release a variety of molecules, such as histamine and cytokines, that can promote an immune response or inflammation. This can help to recruit other immune cells to the site of infection and increase the efficiency of the immune response. 

In addition to their role in the immune system, mast cells are also involved in homeostasis, or maintaining a balance within the body. They play a role in wound healing, for example, by releasing growth factors that can help to regenerate tissue. They are also involved in the body's response to stress, including the release of adrenaline and other stress hormones. While mast cells are important for normal immune function, dysfunction of mast cells can contribute to a variety of diseases, including asthma, inflammatory bowel disease, and various autoimmune disorders.
CL:0000988:
Hematopoietic cells are a type of blood cell that are responsible for the production and regulation of other blood cells. They are multipotent cells that differentiate into various types of specialized cells, including white blood cells (leukocytes), red blood cells (erythrocytes), and platelets (thrombocytes). Hematopoietic stem cells are found in the bone marrow and have the ability to self-renew, meaning they can continuously reproduce themselves to maintain a renewable source of blood cells.

Hematopoietic cells play a crucial role in the body’s immune system by producing white blood cells that help fight off infections, diseases, and foreign invaders. They also produce red blood cells, which are responsible for carrying oxygen and nutrients to tissues throughout the body, as well as platelets, which play a role in clotting blood to prevent excessive bleeding. The differentiation of hematopoietic cells into these specialized cell types is tightly regulated by a complex network of signaling pathways and transcription factors.

Abnormalities in hematopoietic cells can lead to a variety of blood disorders, including leukemia, lymphoma, and myeloma. In addition, certain genetic disorders can affect the production and function of these cells, leading to conditions such as sickle cell disease and hemophilia. Despite these challenges, ongoing research into the mechanisms governing hematopoietic cell development and differentiation holds great promise for the development of new treatments for these and other blood-related disorders.
CL:0000107:
Autonomic neurons are a type of neuron that primarily control the involuntary functions of the body such as digestion, breathing, heart rate, and blood pressure. These neurons are divided into two main categories - sympathetic and parasympathetic neurons. The sympathetic neurons are responsible for the "fight or flight" response, while parasympathetic neurons activate the "rest and digest" response. 

Autonomic neurons are located in the autonomic nervous system and have unique structures compared to other types of neurons. They have two branches that extend from their cell body - the axon and the dendrite. The axon transmits signals away from the cell body, while the dendrite receives signals from other neurons. Unlike somatic neurons (which control voluntary movements), the axons of autonomic neurons don't directly connect to muscle fibers. Instead, they connect to intermediate neurons, or ganglia, which innervate the target organs.

The autonomic nervous system is essential for the regulation of many physiological processes, making autonomic neurons and their function critical for overall health. Dysregulation of autonomic neurons can lead to multiple health problems such as hypertension, gastrointestinal disorders, and respiratory diseases. Therefore, understanding the function of autonomic neurons can lead to better treatments for conditions related to the autonomic nervous system.
CL:0000518:
Phagocytes are a type of white blood cell that plays a crucial role in the body's immune system. They are responsible for engulfing and ingesting foreign particles, such as bacteria, viruses, and cellular debris. This process, known as phagocytosis, helps to protect the body from harmful invaders and also plays a role in tissue repair and removal of dead cells.

Phagocytes are found throughout the body, including in the bloodstream, lymphatic system, and various tissues such as the liver and spleen. In the bloodstream, they are primarily known as neutrophils, while in other tissues they are known as macrophages. Both neutrophils and macrophages play important roles in the immune system, with neutrophils being the first line of defense against infections and macrophages providing a more sustained immune response.

Phagocytes also play a role in the development of inflammation, which is a natural response to infection and injury. They release inflammatory mediators that help to recruit other immune cells to the site of infection or injury, creating a localized immune response. However, in some cases, this response can become excessive and lead to chronic inflammation, which can contribute to the development of a range of diseases.
CL:0000073:
Barrier epithelial cells are a specialized type of cells that form a tight barrier between two different environments or spaces within the body. These cells are present in various tissues of the body including the skin, lining of the gastrointestinal tract and the respiratory system. The primary function of barrier epithelial cells is to regulate the exchange of substances between these two environments.

One of the critical functions of barrier epithelial cells is to prevent foreign substances such as microbes and harmful pollutants from entering the body. These cells operate through the production of a dense layer of proteins and lipids that is known as the extracellular matrix. The extracellular matrix provides a tough physical barrier that prevents the entry of foreign substances and invaders into the body. Furthermore, barrier epithelial cells also secrete mucus, a slippery substance that acts as a natural defense mechanism against foreign substances.

Barrier epithelial cells also play an essential role in regulating the exchange of substances between two different compartments of the body, such as the lumen of the gut and the bloodstream. These cells are equipped with tight junctions, which are protein complexes that seal the gaps between adjacent cells, thereby preventing the entry of unwanted substances in and out of the body. The selective nature of these junctions allows for the controlled passage of specific substances such as nutrients and electrolytes, while preventing the entry of harmful substances that can cause inflammation or injury to the body. Overall, barrier epithelial cells are essential for maintaining the integrity of various tissues and organs in the body while also protecting the body from external threats.
CL:0000108:
Cholinergic neurons are a type of nerve cell that use the neurotransmitter acetylcholine to communicate with other cells in the nervous system. These neurons are found throughout the central and peripheral nervous systems and play important roles in regulating various bodily functions including movement, memory, and arousal.

In the central nervous system, cholinergic neurons are often found in areas associated with learning and memory, such as the hippocampus and cerebral cortex. These neurons are thought to be involved in the formation and retrieval of memories, and disruptions in their function have been linked to cognitive decline and neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's.

In the peripheral nervous system, cholinergic neurons are involved in controlling various bodily functions such as heart rate, digestion, and breathing. For example, parasympathetic cholinergic neurons help regulate heart rate and respiration, while motor neurons that release acetylcholine help regulate movement and coordination.

Overall, cholinergic neurons play essential roles in many aspects of physiology and are a valuable target for the treatment of a range of disorders affecting the nervous system.
CL:0000766:
Myeloid leukocytes, also known as myeloid cells, are a type of white blood cell that is involved in the body's immune system. They are derived from hematopoietic stem cells found in the bone marrow and can differentiate into a range of cell types, including red blood cells, platelets, and immune cells. Myeloid leukocytes are an important component of the innate immune system, which provides rapid and non-specific defense against invading pathogens.

One of the primary functions of myeloid leukocytes is phagocytosis, which involves engulfing and destroying foreign particles such as bacteria, viruses, and debris. This process is facilitated by the presence of receptors on the cell surface that recognize and bind to specific targets. Myeloid leukocytes are also capable of producing a variety of antimicrobial substances such as lysozyme, defensins, and complement proteins that help to clear infections.

In addition to their role in innate immunity, myeloid leukocytes also play a role in adaptive immunity. They can act as antigen-presenting cells, which involves capturing and displaying antigens on their surface to activate other immune cells such as T cells. Myeloid leukocytes also release chemical signals called cytokines that help to coordinate the immune response. Dysregulation of myeloid leukocytes has been implicated in a range of diseases, including infections, autoimmune disorders, and cancer.
CL:0000098:
Sensory epithelial cells are specialized epithelial cells responsible for transducing a range of sensory modalities, including vision, hearing, smell, and taste. Sensory epithelial cells play an important role in the body's ability to perceive and respond to stimuli from the external environment, and in maintaining homeostasis within the body.

One example of a sensory epithelial cell is the photoreceptor cell found in the retina of the eye. These specialized cells are responsible for detecting light and converting it into electrical signals that can be interpreted by the brain. Another example of a sensory epithelial cell is the hair cell found in the inner ear. These cells are responsible for detecting sound waves and converting them into neural signals that the brain can interpret as sound.

In addition to their sensory functions, sensory epithelial cells also play a critical role in maintaining the health and balance of their respective sensory systems. For example, the olfactory sensory epithelium in the nose contains specialized cells called olfactory stem cells that are capable of regenerating lost or damaged neurons. Similarly, the sensory epithelium in the cochlea of the ear contains specialized supporting cells that are critical for maintaining the health and function of the hair cells. Overall, sensory epithelial cells serve as important mediators between the external environment and the body's internal systems, enabling the body to sense and respond to changes in the environment.
CL:0000576:
Monocytes are a type of white blood cell that are part of the innate immune system and are produced in the bone marrow. These cells circulate in the blood for about a day before migrating out of the bloodstream and into tissues, where they differentiate into macrophages or dendritic cells. Monocytes are phagocytic, meaning that they are able to engulf and digest foreign particles, such as bacteria and viruses, and dead or damaged cells.

Monocytes play a crucial role in the body's immune response to infection and injury. They are among the first cells to respond to an infection, and they recruit other immune cells to the site of infection, where they work together to clear the infection. Monocytes are also involved in the resolution phase of inflammation, where they help to clear away dead cells and debris that accumulate during an inflammatory response. In addition, monocytes are important for the development of an adaptive immune response, as they can present antigens to T cells and activate them.

Abnormalities in monocyte function or number can lead to a variety of diseases. For example, an increase in the number of monocytes, known as monocytosis, can occur in chronic infections, autoimmune diseases, and certain types of cancer. Decreased monocyte counts, on the other hand, can be seen in immunosuppression, such as HIV infection and certain types of chemotherapy. Overall, the study of monocytes is important for understanding how the innate and adaptive immune systems work together to protect the body from disease.
CL:0000226:
Single nucleate cells, also known as mononucleate cells, are a type of cell that contain only one nucleus. These cells are found in a variety of tissues throughout the body, including muscle, nerve, and glandular tissue. Unlike multinucleate cells, which have multiple nuclei within a single cytoplasmic mass, single nucleate cells have a singular, centralized nucleus that regulates genetic expression.

Single nucleate cells, like all cells, perform a variety of functions necessary for proper organismal function. Muscle tissue, for example, is composed of bundles of single nucleate cells that contract in unison to generate movement. Nerve tissue contains single nucleate cells known as neurons, which transmit electrical signals between each other and between other tissues and organs in the body. Glandular tissue contains single nucleate cells known as secretory cells, which produce and secrete substances such as hormones, enzymes, and mucus.

Despite their relatively simplistic structure, single nucleate cells are essential building blocks of the human body and play a crucial role in maintaining homeostasis and supporting life. Their diverse functions in different tissues highlight the importance of understanding not only the basic molecular mechanisms that underlie cellular function, but also the complex interactions between cells that allow for the proper function of the organs and systems they make up.
CL:0000076:
Squamous epithelial cells are flattened, scale-like cells that form the outermost layer of skin and line the inner surfaces of hollow organs such as the lungs, blood vessels, and heart. The epithelial layer acts as a barrier protecting the body from external threats and regulating the exchange of materials between the body and the environment. Squamous epithelial cells are particularly well suited for this role due to their flat, elongated shape and tight packing, which creates a smooth, continuous layer.

Squamous epithelial cells are also involved in the process of diffusion, which is the movement of molecules from areas of high concentration to areas of low concentration. This process is vital for the exchange of gases, nutrients, and waste products in the body. For example, in the lungs, squamous epithelial cells form a barrier between the air in the lungs and the bloodstream. Oxygen from the air diffuses across this barrier and into the bloodstream, while carbon dioxide produced by the body's cells diffuses from the bloodstream into the air in the lungs to be exhaled.

In addition to their protective and diffusion functions, squamous epithelial cells are also involved in the secretion of various substances. For example, squamous epithelial cells in the skin produce a variety of lipids and other substances that help to waterproof and protect the skin from dehydration. Squamous epithelial cells in the lungs also secrete mucus, which helps to trap dust and other particles that are breathed in, preventing them from reaching deeper into the lungs. Overall, squamous epithelial cells are an essential component of many organs and play a vital role in maintaining the overall health and functionality of the body.
CL:0002078:
Meso-epithelial cells are a rare type of cell that are found in the surface epithelium lining organs throughout the body, including the respiratory, reproductive, and digestive systems. These cells play a critical role in regulating cellular turnover and maintaining the structural integrity of the epithelium. Meso-epithelial cells are characterized by their unique morphology, which includes a large, irregularly shaped nucleus and a prominent cytoplasmic volume. In addition, these cells are capable of differentiating into a variety of specialized epithelial cell types based on different environmental cues.

One important function of meso-epithelial cells is the formation and maintenance of epithelial barriers in the body. These cells form tight junctions with adjacent epithelial cells, effectively sealing the spaces between the cells and preventing the diffusion of substances across the epithelial layer. This barrier function serves to protect the underlying tissue from harmful toxins and pathogens, as well as maintain homeostasis by regulating the transport of nutrients and waste products. Meso-epithelial cells also play a role in tissue repair and regeneration by promoting the proliferation and differentiation of stem cells that give rise to new epithelial cells.

Overall, meso-epithelial cells are a crucial component of the epithelial layer that covers the surfaces of organs in the body. These cells provide structural support, regulate cellular turnover, and play a critical role in maintaining the integrity of epithelial barriers. By better understanding the physiology and function of these cells, we can gain insight into mechanisms underlying normal tissue homeostasis and pathological responses to injury and disease.
CL:0000092:
Osteoclasts are a type of bone cell that are primarily responsible for the resorption of bone tissue. These cells are derived from the monocyte-macrophage lineage and are multinucleated, meaning they have several nuclei in a single cell. Osteoclasts are characterized by their ability to dissolve mineralized bone and break down organic bone matrix, which is essential for bone remodeling and maintenance.

The primary function of osteoclasts is to maintain bone integrity and facilitate bone repair. Osteoclasts generate a localized acidic environment through the secretion of protons and acid hydrolases, which creates an optimal environment for bone resorption. Additionally, osteoclasts secrete collagenases and other enzymes that can break down organic bone matrix. As bone is resorbed, calcium and other minerals are released into the bloodstream and can be utilized elsewhere in the body.

Osteoclast activity is regulated by a variety of factors, including hormones and growth factors. For example, parathyroid hormone (PTH) stimulates osteoclast activity, leading to increased bone resorption. On the other hand, calcitonin inhibits osteoclast activity and promotes bone formation. Dysfunction of osteoclasts can lead to an array of bone disorders, including osteoporosis, osteopetrosis, and Paget disease. Overall, osteoclasts are a critically important cell type for bone maintenance and repair, and their proper functioning is essential for maintaining skeletal health.
CL:0000099:
Interneurons are specialized cells that function primarily in the central nervous system (CNS). These cells act as bridges between sensory and motor neurons, forming complex neural circuits that are responsible for information processing and integration. Interneurons are highly diverse and exhibit a wide range of morphological and functional characteristics. They are classified based on their location, shape, and neurotransmitter phenotype.

The primary function of interneurons is to integrate and process information received from sensory neurons and to transmit this information to motor neurons. They play a crucial role in the regulation of movement, sensory perception, learning, and memory. Interneurons are also involved in the modulation of neural activity and in the maintenance of the excitatory and inhibitory balance within the CNS.

Interneurons are essential for the proper functioning of the nervous system and their dysfunction or degeneration is associated with a wide range of neurological disorders. For example, studies have shown that abnormalities in GABAergic interneurons contribute to the pathogenesis of epilepsy, schizophrenia, and autism spectrum disorders. In contrast, interneuron transplantation has emerged as a potential therapeutic strategy for the treatment of these disorders. Understanding the function and characteristics of interneurons is therefore crucial for the development of effective therapies for CNS disorders.
CL:0000104:
A multipolar neuron, also known as a multipolar ganglion cell, is a type of neuron that has multiple processes that extend from the cell body, known as dendrites. These dendrites receive signals from other neurons or from sensory receptors, which are then transmitted to the cell body. The cell body also contains the nucleus and other organelles necessary for the neuron's function. Additionally, multipolar neurons have a single axon that transmits signals away from the cell body to other neurons or to effectors such as muscles or glands.

The function of multipolar neurons varies depending on their location in the nervous system. In the central nervous system, multipolar neurons are predominantly interneurons, which means they serve to integrate and process information from other neurons to ultimately transmit a response. In contrast, in the peripheral nervous system, multipolar neurons can be found as the principal neurons in sensory ganglia. In this context, their dendrites receive signals from sensory receptors and transmit this information to the central nervous system for processing and integration.

To facilitate their function, multipolar neurons often have many dendrites that branch extensively, allowing them to receive input from a large number of sources. The axon of the multipolar neuron can also branch multiple times, allowing it to communicate with many different neurons or effectors. Overall, the multipolar neuron is a highly versatile type of neuron that plays a critical role in the complex functioning of the nervous system.
CL:0000118:
Basket cells are a type of inhibitory neuron found predominantly in the cerebellum, cortex, and hippocampus of the mammalian brain. These cells play a crucial role in regulating brain activity by suppressing the firing of other neurons. Basket cells receive input from excitatory neurons and, in turn, release gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) to inhibit the firing of these neurons.

Basket cells are named for their distinctive morphology, which resembles a woven basket that envelops the target neuron. They have a unique axonal arborization pattern that forms a dense mesh around the cell bodies and dendrites of their target neurons. This allows them to effectively control the output of target neurons within a specific area and play a critical role in maintaining the balance between excitation and inhibition in the brain.

In addition to their role in regulating neuronal activity, basket cells are also thought to be involved in the formation of memory and learning. Studies have shown that the number and activity of basket cells are altered in response to learning and experience, suggesting that they may play an important role in mediating dynamic changes in neural circuits. Dysfunction of these cells has been implicated in neurological disorders such as epilepsy, schizophrenia, and Alzheimer's disease, highlighting the critical role that basket cells play in maintaining the proper function of the brain.
CL:0000065:
Ependymal cells are specialized cells that line the ventricles of the brain and the central canal of the spinal cord. They are typically classified as epithelial cells due to their polarized structure, being ciliated on the apical surface and having a basal surface that interacts with underlying tissue. Ependymal cells have important functions in the brain, including the production and secretion of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and regulation of its flow. Additionally, they are thought to play a role in neurogenesis and in promoting the repair of damaged neural tissue.

One of the primary functions of ependymal cells is to produce and regulate the flow of CSF, which cushions and protects the brain and spinal cord. Ependymal cells are responsible for the production of approximately two-thirds of CSF, with the remainder being produced by the choroid plexus. The apical surface of ependymal cells is covered with cilia, which move in a coordinated fashion to circulate the CSF and maintain proper fluid dynamics. Dysfunction of ependymal cells can lead to impaired CSF flow and accumulation of fluid in the brain, which can cause hydrocephalus.

In addition to CSF production, ependymal cells have been shown to play a role in neurogenesis and neural repair. Ependymal cells have the ability to differentiate into neural stem cells, which can give rise to neurons and glial cells. It has also been observed that ependymal cells can migrate to damaged neural tissue and promote repair through the secretion of various growth factors and cytokines. However, the extent to which ependymal cells contribute to neurogenesis and neural repair in vivo remains an active area of research.
CL:0000213:
Lining cells are specialized cells that form the innermost layer of several organs and cavities within our body. These cells exist in three main types: endothelial cells, mesothelial cells, and epithelial cells. Endothelial cells are found in the lining of blood vessels and play a crucial role in controlling the exchange of material between the bloodstream and surrounding tissues. On the other hand, mesothelial cells line the body cavity and organs such as the lungs and heart, providing lubrication and a barrier against infection. Epithelial cells are found in the lining of various organs, including the digestive tract, respiratory system, and reproductive system. They protect organs by serving as a physical and chemical barrier against external factors.

The structure of lining cells varies according to their location and function. Endothelial cells, for example, are flat and thin, making them effective at regulating the passage of nutrients and gases in and out of the bloodstream. The structure of mesothelial cells is more complex, with numerous folds and surface protrusions that help reduce friction between organs. Epithelial cells also vary depending on their location and function. In the small intestine, for example, they contain numerous finger-like projections called microvilli, which increase the surface area for absorption of nutrients.

Lining cells play a crucial role in maintaining the proper function of various organs and systems within our body. They provide a physical barrier against pathogens and injury and selectively control the passage of nutrients, gases, and other materials. Dysfunction of lining cells can contribute to various diseases, including cancer, cardiovascular disease, and autoimmune disorders. Understanding the structure and function of these specialized cells is crucial to develop effective treatments for these diseases.
CL:0000122:
Stellate neurons, also known as granule cells, are a type of inhibitory neuron found in the cerebellum of the brain. These cells have a characteristic star-shaped appearance, with dendrites projecting radially in all directions from the cell body. Stellate neurons receive input from parallel fibers of granule cells and serve to modulate the activity of Purkinje cells, the output neurons of the cerebellar cortex. 

Stellate neurons play a critical role in the control of motor coordination and learning. They are involved in the processing of sensory information, particularly from movement receptors, and the integration of this information with motor output. Stellate neurons also contribute to the modulation of synaptic plasticity, which is the ability of synapses to undergo long-term changes in strength, a fundamental process underlying learning and memory. 

Dysfunction of stellate neurons is implicated in a range of neurological disorders, including ataxia, essential tremor, and dystonia. Research into stellate neurons is therefore of great interest in the development of therapies for these conditions. By understanding the function of stellate neurons and their role in disease, it may be possible to develop targeted treatments to restore normal function and improve the quality of life for affected individuals.
CL:4023057:
Cerebellar inhibitory GABAergic interneurons refer to the type of cells present in the cerebellum that have an inhibitory effect on neural activity. These cells are responsible for controlling the activity of Purkinje cells, which are instrumental in the cerebellar circuit. The GABAergic interneurons are vital in maintaining the balance of excitation and inhibition in the cerebellum, making them essential for the proper functioning of the motor system.

These cells are characterized by the release of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), the primary inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain, which binds to GABA receptors on neighboring cells. The GABAergic interneurons have distinct electrophysiological properties, allowing them to regulate the activity of Purkinje cells and maintain precise timing in cerebellar activity. Cerebellar inhibitory GABAergic interneurons are classified into different groups, each with unique functions.

The proper functioning of cerebellar inhibitory GABAergic interneurons is essential for movement control. Dysfunctions in these cells have been implicated in several neurological disorders, including ataxia and dystonia. Therefore, understanding the properties and mechanisms of the GABAergic interneurons is crucial for developing effective treatments for these conditions.
CL:0000106:
A unipolar neuron, also known as a sensory neuron, is a type of neuron that is responsible for relaying sensory information from the peripheral nervous system to the central nervous system. Unipolar neurons have a single process that divides into two branches, one of which receives sensory information from the body, while the other transmits it to the spinal cord or brain. 

These neurons are found in ganglia clusters outside the brain and spinal cord and are critical for the transmission of sensory information, including touch, temperature, and pain. Because the body has such a diverse range of sensory receptors, unipolar neurons come in many subtypes that are specific to the type of sensation they receive and transmit. For example, tactile unipolar neurons are responsible for responding to mechanical changes, such as pressure, while nociceptive unipolar neurons respond to painful stimuli.

In addition to their role in sensory transmission, unipolar neurons are also important in reflex arcs, which allow for quick responses to stimuli, such as pulling your hand away from a hot surface. These neurons have a rapid conduction speed, allowing them to transmit information quickly and efficiently. Overall, unipolar neurons play a crucial role in our ability to sense and respond to the environment around us.
CL:0000095:
Neuron-associated cells, also known as glial cells, are a heterogeneous group of non-neuronal cells in the nervous system that support and modulate the activity of neurons. These cells vastly outnumber neurons and are critical for proper brain development and function. There are several subtypes of glial cells, including astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, and microglia.

Astrocytes are the most abundant glial cells and form a network throughout the brain. They play a crucial role in maintaining the correct chemical environment for neuronal function by regulating neurotransmitter levels and providing nutrients to neurons. Astrocytes also contribute to the formation and maintenance of synapses, which are the connections between neurons. Additionally, astrocytes play a role in regulating blood flow to the brain, a process known as neurovascular coupling.

Oligodendrocytes are responsible for producing myelin, a fatty substance that forms an insulating sheath around neuronal axons. Myelin is essential for rapid and efficient transmission of nerve impulses and helps to prevent electrical signals from escaping the axon. In diseases such as multiple sclerosis, the destruction of myelin by the immune system leads to impaired neuronal function.

Microglia are the immune cells of the brain and play a role in protecting the brain from infection and injury. They are involved in pruning synapses during development and are also activated in response to brain injury or disease. Microglia can exhibit both beneficial and detrimental effects on neuronal function, depending on the circumstances of their activation. Overall, neuron-associated cells are critical for proper brain function, and disruptions in their function can lead to neurological diseases.
CL:0000110:
Peptidergic neurons are a type of neuron that function by releasing peptides as their primary form of neurotransmitter. These neurons can be found throughout the central and peripheral nervous systems, and they play a crucial role in a variety of physiological processes such as pain modulation, feeding behavior, and emotional regulation. Peptides released by peptidergic neurons include substance P and enkephalins, both of which are involved in pain perception and modulation.

In addition to their neurotransmitter function, peptidergic neurons also have unique morphological features compared to other types of neurons. They typically have large cell bodies and extensive dendritic trees, allowing them to receive and integrate input from a large number of neurons. This feature also contributes to the spatial specificity of their function. For example, some peptidergic neurons in the hypothalamus regulate feeding behavior by integrating signals from the digestive system and responding to the levels of nutrients and hormones in the blood.

Furthermore, peptidergic neurons have been implicated in a variety of pathological conditions, including chronic pain, addiction, and mood disorders. Understanding the function of these neurons and the peptides they release is critical in developing new treatments for these disorders. Overall, peptidergic neurons are a diverse and important class of neurons that play a crucial role in the nervous system's overall function.
CL:0001035:
Bone cells are specialized cells that play a crucial role in the formation and maintenance of bone tissue. There are several different types of bone cells, including osteoblasts, osteocytes, and osteoclasts. Osteoblasts are responsible for the formation of new bone tissue, while osteocytes help regulate bone remodeling and mineralization. Osteoclasts, on the other hand, are involved in the breakdown of bone tissue.

Osteoblasts are responsible for laying down new bone tissue during a process called ossification. These cells synthesize and secrete bone matrix proteins, such as collagen and osteocalcin, which then mineralize to form the hard, rigid structure of bone tissue. Osteoblasts also produce signaling molecules that activate and communicate with other bone cells, such as osteocytes and osteoclasts, to coordinate bone growth and remodeling.

Osteocytes are mature bone cells that are embedded within the bone matrix. These cells have long, branched dendritic processes that extend out into the bone tissue. Osteocytes play a critical role in regulating bone remodeling and mineralization, as well as responding to mechanical stimuli, such as pressure and strain. They also serve as a communication network within bone tissue, allowing for coordinated responses to changes in mechanical and physiological conditions.

Overall, bone cells are essential for maintaining the structural integrity of bone tissue and supporting a variety of physiological functions, such as calcium regulation, hematopoiesis, and locomotion. Dysfunction or loss of bone cells can result in a range of skeletal disorders, such as osteoporosis, bone fractures, and bone cancers.
CL:0000072:
Non-branched duct epithelial cells are cells that form the lining of non-branched ducts in various organs of the human body such as the salivary gland, mammary gland, and sweat gland. These cells are usually cuboidal in shape with distinct nuclei and are found in a single layer in the duct walls. They play a vital role in facilitating the transportation and transfer of fluids, ions, and other substances to different parts of the body.

The primary function of non-branched duct epithelial cells is to secrete or absorb substances from the ductal fluid. For instance, the cells in the salivary gland ducts absorb electrolytes and water to help concentrate saliva. Similarly, the ductal cells of the mammary gland absorb nutrients and secrete milk. Non-branched duct epithelial cells also act as a barrier that prevents harmful substances from entering the duct. Hence, they help maintain the internal environment of the gland by keeping it separate from the surrounding tissues and blood vessels.

The cells of non-branched duct epithelium are responsible for generating and maintaining the structural integrity of ducts. They adhere to each other through tight junctions, ensuring that ductal fluids are directed toward the appropriate location. Additionally, these cells are capable of self-renewal, which helps to maintain the ductal structure and function. When not functioning correctly, non-branched duct epithelial cells can cause various pathologies, such as tumors and cysts.
CL:0000061:
Cementoblasts are specialized cells that produce and mineralize cementum, a hard tissue covering the roots of teeth. These cells are derived from mesenchymal cells in the dental follicle and reside in the periodontal ligament, which connects the cementum to the alveolar bone in the jaw. Cementoblasts play a crucial role in maintaining the integrity of the tooth-supporting apparatus and are involved in various cellular and molecular processes that regulate tooth root development, repair, and regeneration.

The main function of cementoblasts is to form and maintain the cementum layer on the root surface of teeth. This process involves the production and secretion of organic matrix molecules, such as collagens, glycoproteins, and proteoglycans, as well as the initiation and regulation of mineralization. Cementoblasts also play a role in the attachment and remodeling of the periodontal ligament fibers, which help anchor the tooth to the bone and provide support during mastication and other oral functions. It is worth noting that cementoblasts are highly specialized cells that exhibit distinct phenotypic and functional properties compared to other hard tissue-forming cells, such as osteoblasts and odontoblasts.

In addition to their role in cementum formation, cementoblasts participate in various physiological and pathological processes that affect periodontal health. For instance, these cells can produce and release growth factors and cytokines that modulate inflammation, immune responses, and tissue repair in response to oral infections or injuries. Moreover, cementoblasts have been shown to have stem cell-like properties, which means they can differentiate into other cell types in the periodontal ligament and potentially contribute to tissue regeneration and repair. Overall, cementoblasts are pivotal players in maintaining the structural and functional integrity of the periodontium and therefore have significant implications for oral health and disease.
CL:0000114:
Surface ectodermal cells are a type of epithelial cell that originate from the ectoderm and are located on the surface of an organism. They play a critical role in numerous physiological processes, such as skin development, formation of hair and nails, and sensory perception. In particular, surface ectodermal cells are involved in the formation of the epidermis, which is the outermost layer of skin that acts as a protective barrier against environmental factors such as ultraviolet radiation, dehydration, and pathogens.

During embryonic development, surface ectodermal cells differentiate into various cell types, including keratinocytes, which produce the structural protein keratin that gives skin its strength and elasticity, as well as melanocytes which produce melanin that determines skin color. These cells also give rise to sebaceous glands, hair follicles, and sweat glands, all of which are essential for regulating body temperature and maintaining skin health.

In addition to their structural functions, surface ectodermal cells also contribute to sensory perception by producing specialized cells such as the Merkel cells, which are involved in touch sensation, and the lens of the eye, which plays a critical role in vision. Overall, surface ectodermal cells are crucial for the formation and maintenance of various tissues and organs in the body and play a vital role in normal physiological function.
CL:0000878:
Central nervous system macrophages are a type of immune cell that reside in the central nervous system (CNS). They are also known as microglia and are the resident macrophages of the CNS. These cells play an important role in immune surveillance of the CNS, as well as in maintaining homeostasis, synaptic pruning, and neural development.

One of the main functions of central nervous system macrophages is to monitor the CNS for signs of infection or injury. When activated, microglia secrete cytokines and chemokines that recruit other immune cells to the site of injury or infection. They also phagocytose dead cells and debris to clear the area and promote tissue repair.

In addition to their immune surveillance role, central nervous system macrophages also play a critical role in maintaining homeostasis in the CNS. They are involved in synaptic pruning, which is the elimination of weak or unwanted synapses, and in neurogenesis, which is the formation of new neurons. They also play a role in myelin maintenance and in regulating the extracellular environment of the CNS, including the levels of neurotransmitters and cytokines.
CL:0000082:
Epithelial cells of the lung make up the lining of the airways and alveoli, which play a crucial role in gas exchange. These cells are essential in protecting the lungs from harmful particles, such as pollutants, and help to maintain the proper balance of gases in the bloodstream. The epithelial cells of the lung are specialized, and different regions of the lung have unique types of epithelial cells.

The alveolar type I (AT1) cells are the most abundant in the lungs and are highly specialized in their function. They form a thin barrier between the air and the blood, allowing efficient gas exchange between the lungs and the rest of the body. AT1 cells are also responsible for secreting surfactant, which is crucial in preventing the collapse of the alveoli during expiration.

The alveolar type II (AT2) cells are another type of epithelial cell in the lungs. These cells are essential in the production and secretion of pulmonary surfactant, which lowers the surface tension in the lungs and helps to prevent alveolar collapse. AT2 cells also have regenerative properties and can differentiate into other cell types in response to injury or infection.

In summary, the epithelial cells of the lung have vital roles in protecting the lungs and maintaining efficient gas exchange. The different types of cells, such as AT1 and AT2 cells, are specialized in their functions and work together to keep the lungs healthy and functioning properly.
CL:0000100:
A motor neuron is a specialized cell type found in the nervous system that controls and coordinates voluntary muscle movements. Motor neurons are considered efferent neurons, meaning they transmit signals from the nervous system to muscles. These neurons are essential for the brain to communicate with muscles in order to perform tasks such as walking, talking, and grasping objects.

The anatomy of a motor neuron consists of a cell body, dendrites, and an axon. The cell body contains the nucleus and other organelles, while dendrites receive signals from other neurons and the axon transmits signals to the target muscle or gland. Motor neurons have a long axon that extends from the spinal cord to the muscle fibers it innervates. The end of the axon branches out to form small synaptic terminals that make direct contact with muscle cells. When activated, these terminals release a neurotransmitter that binds to receptors on the muscle cells, leading to muscle contraction.

Motor neurons can be classified into two types: somatic motor neurons and autonomic motor neurons. Somatic motor neurons control skeletal muscles, whereas autonomic motor neurons control smooth and cardiac muscles, as well as glands. Loss of motor neurons can result in muscular dystrophy, ALS (Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis), or paralysis. Hence, understanding the function and properties of motor neurons is crucial for developing treatments for these conditions and maintaining proper motor function.
CL:0000113:
Mononuclear phagocytes are a type of immune cell that play a crucial role in the body's defense against foreign invaders, such as bacteria, viruses, and other pathogens. They are a heterogeneous cell population that share a common origin from bone marrow-derived monocytes, and they can be found in many different tissues throughout the body, including the liver, lungs, spleen, and lymph nodes.

Mononuclear phagocytes are best known for their ability to phagocytose, or engulf, foreign particles and debris. They use a variety of surface receptors to recognize and bind to these particles, then internalize them into specialized compartments called lysosomes, where they are degraded and processed for presentation to other immune cells. In addition to phagocytosis, mononuclear phagocytes also play important roles in antigen presentation, cytokine production, and tissue repair.

One important subpopulation of mononuclear phagocytes are the macrophages, which are found in most tissues and are highly versatile. They perform many different functions depending on their location and context, including helping to maintain tissue homeostasis, removing dying cells and debris, and initiating immune responses. Another important subpopulation of mononuclear phagocytes are the dendritic cells, which act as professional antigen-presenting cells and are essential for initiating and shaping adaptive immune responses. Overall, mononuclear phagocytes are a vital component of the immune system and are critical for maintaining both the health and function of tissues throughout the body.
CL:0000125:
Glial cells, also known as neuroglia, are a type of non-neuronal cells that are found throughout the nervous system. Glial cells function to support, protect, and nourish neurons. While neurons are considered the primary functional cells of the nervous system, they cannot function without the support of glial cells.

There are three main types of glial cells: astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, and microglia. Astrocytes are the most abundant type of glial cell and play an important role in maintaining the integrity of the blood-brain barrier. They also help regulate the chemical environment in the brain and provide nourishment to neurons. Oligodendrocytes are responsible for producing myelin, a fatty substance that insulates neurons and helps them transmit signals faster. Microglia are immune cells that protect the brain from infections and inflammation.

In addition to their supportive functions, researchers have also discovered that glial cells play a role in neural development and synaptic plasticity, the ability of the brain to form and modify connections between neurons. Dysfunctions in glial cells have been implicated in several neurological disorders such as multiple sclerosis and Alzheimer's disease. Therefore, a better understanding of glial cells and their functions is critical to developing new treatments for these disorders.
CL:2000032:
Peripheral nervous system neurons (PNS neurons) are a diverse group of cells that function to transmit signals between the body and the central nervous system (CNS). They are found throughout the PNS, which includes the nerves and ganglia outside of the brain and spinal cord.
