They are responsible for clearing away dead cells, debris, and other waste products, as well as promoting the growth and differentiation of other cells. Macrophages have been shown to play a critical role in wound healing, tissue regeneration, and even in the development and maintenance of certain organs, such as the liver and lungs. Overall, macrophages are a highly versatile and essential cell type in the immune system that that carry out a wide range of functions to protect and maintain the body.
CL:0000421:
Coelomocytes are specialized cells found within the coelomic fluid of invertebrates with a true coelom. These cells are primarily involved in the maintenance of the coelomic fluid composition, as well as in the immunological defense mechanisms of the organism. There are several different types of coelomocytes, each with their own specific functions and morphological characteristics.

One of the primary functions of coelomocytes is phagocytosis, which involves the ingestion and breakdown of foreign particles or pathogens within the coelomic fluid. These cells also play a vital role in the immune response of invertebrate organisms, producing a variety of antimicrobial peptides and enzymes. Additionally, coelomocytes are involved in the regulation of coelomic fluid osmolarity, with some cells involved in removing excess water or electrolytes.

The morphology of coelomocytes varies significantly depending on the species of invertebrate. Some coelomocytes are small and spherical, while others are elongated and spindle-shaped. In some organisms, such as echinoderms, coelomocytes may have motile cilia or other appendages to aid in the circulation of coelomic fluid. The diversity of coelomocyte morphology reflects the diversity of functions that these cells perform in maintaining the coelomic environment and protecting the organism from pathogens and other threats.
CL:0000429:
Imaginal disc cells are a type of cells found in insects, particularly in the larval stage of development. They are responsible for forming the adult structures of the insect during the pupal phase. These cells are unique in that they are undifferentiated and have the capacity to develop into different types of adult specialized cells, including the wings, legs, eyes, and antennae. 

The imaginal discs are small sac-like structures located in the body of the larva, each containing a pool of imaginal disc cells. During the pupal stage, these cells divide and differentiate into the various adult cell types that make up the mature insect. This ability to differentiate into multiple cell types is also what makes imaginal disc cells of interest to researchers studying stem cells and developmental biology.

Imaginal disc cells are vital to the development of the adult insect and provide an excellent model for studying developmental biology. Understanding how these cells differentiate and form the various adult structures could pave the way for new therapies to regenerate damaged tissues in humans. Furthermore, recent studies have revealed that imaginal disc cells have an innate immune system that combats bacterial infections. This discovery has potential applications in the development of new antibiotics and understanding how insects have evolved to defend themselves against pathogenic bacteria.
CL:0000416:
Polytene cells are specialized cells that are only found in certain tissues and organs of various organisms. These cells are characterized by their large size and unique chromosome structure, which is formed by repeated rounds of DNA replication and chromosome alignment without cell division. As a result, polytene cells can contain tens, hundreds, or even thousands of copies of each chromosome, arranged in parallel and visible under a light microscope as a distinctive "banding" pattern.

One of the main functions of polytene cells is to provide high levels of gene expression and protein production in response to specific physiological demands. For example, in the salivary glands of fruit flies, polytene cells synthesize and secrete large amounts of enzymes and proteins needed for digestion and reproduction. The high ploidy level of these cells allows for rapid and coordinated production of these proteins, which are then transported to other parts of the body through the developing fly's bloodstream.

In addition to their role in protein synthesis, polytene cells have also been studied for their potential in genetic and developmental research. Because polytene chromosomes are so large and visible, they can be used to map the locations of specific genes, as well as to study the effects of genetic mutations and environmental factors on chromosome structure and function. Overall, polytene cells represent a fascinating and versatile cell type that continues to reveal new insights into the complexity of cellular function and gene regulation.
CL:0000390:
Blood cells in Nematoda and Protostomia are an important class of cells that function in oxygen transport, as well as in the immune system. These cells are found in the blood vessels and lymphatic system of these organisms, and play a critical role in maintaining the health of the animal. There are different types of blood cells in these organisms, each with its unique structure and function.

One of the essential blood cells in nematodes and protostomes is the erythrocyte or the red blood cell. These cells are specialized for oxygen transport and have a characteristic biconcave shape that optimizes their surface area to volume ratio. They achieve gas exchange by exchanging carbon dioxide for oxygen in the lungs or gills and then carrying this oxygen to the tissues throughout the body. In some cases, the erythrocytes also carry nutrients and waste products between cells.

Another key type of blood cell found in nematodes and protostomes is the leukocyte or the white blood cell. These cells aid in the animal's immune response and can be further divided into various subtypes, including granulocytes and agranulocytes. Granulocytes, such as neutrophils and eosinophils, are involved in the defense against bacteria, fungi, and parasites. Agranulocytes, on the other hand, include monocytes and lymphocytes and are involved in both innate and adaptive immunity.

In conclusion, blood cells in Nematoda and Protostomia are diverse and crucial to the organism's survival. While erythrocytes play a critical role in oxygen transport, leukocytes support immunity and host defense. Understanding the function of these cells helps researchers better understand the physiology of these organisms and potentially develop new treatments for diseases.
CL:0000422:
Mitogenic signaling cells are a type of specialized cells that play a crucial role in regulating the growth and division of other cells. They produce signaling molecules, known as mitogens, which bind to specific receptors on the surface of target cells and trigger a cascade of intracellular events that stimulate cell proliferation. Mitogenic signaling cells are found in various tissues throughout the body, including the liver, bone marrow, and pancreas.

One of the primary functions of mitogenic signaling cells is to promote tissue repair and regeneration following injury or damage. For instance, after liver damage, hepatic stellate cells secrete mitogens that stimulate the proliferation of hepatocytes, the major cell type in the liver, to regenerate lost or damaged tissue. Similarly, bone marrow cells called mesenchymal stem cells produce growth factors that promote the proliferation and differentiation of blood-forming cells, aiding in the repair of damaged blood vessels and tissues.

In addition to their role in tissue repair, mitogenic signaling cells also play a significant role in cancer development. Cancer cells can hijack the mitogenic signaling pathway to promote their own uncontrolled growth, leading to the formation of tumors. Understanding the mechanisms of mitogenic signaling cells is critical in developing targeted therapies for cancer treatment. Overall, mitogenic signaling cells are vital players in development, regenerative processes, and diseases such as cancer, highlighting the importance of continued research on mitogenic signaling and its regulation.
CL:0000850:
A serotonergic neuron is a type of neuron that synthesizes and secretes serotonin, a neurotransmitter that plays a key role in the regulation of mood, appetite, and sleep. These neurons are found mainly in the raphe nuclei of the brainstem, and they project their axons to various regions of the brain, including the thalamus, hypothalamus, and cortex. Serotonergic neurons are also present in the enteric nervous system, where they regulate the function of the gastrointestinal tract.

The primary function of serotonergic neurons is to modulate various physiological and behavioral processes, including mood, appetite, and sleep. Serotonin has been implicated in depression and anxiety, and drugs that modulate serotonin levels are commonly used to treat these disorders. Serotonergic neurons are also involved in regulating appetite and body weight, and dysfunction of these neurons has been implicated in the development of obesity. In addition, serotonin plays a role in the regulation of sleep, with low levels of serotonin being associated with sleep disturbances.

In addition to their role in physiological processes, serotonergic neurons are also thought to play a role in various pathological conditions. For example, dysfunction of these neurons has been implicated in the development of psychiatric disorders such as depression, anxiety, and schizophrenia. In addition, serotonergic neurons have been implicated in the development of certain types of cancer, including lung, prostate, and breast cancer. Further research is needed to fully understand the role of serotonergic neurons in these conditions, and to develop new therapies that target these neurons.
CL:0000418:
Arcade cells, also known as canal of Schlemm endothelial cells, are a specialized type of endothelial cells found in the human eye. These cells form a unique structure called the canal of Schlemm, which is responsible for draining aqueous humor from the eye and maintaining intraocular pressure. The canal of Schlemm is a circular channel that runs circumferentially around the corneoscleral junction and is lined with arcade cells.

The role of arcade cells in the regulation of intraocular pressure is crucial for preventing damage to the eye. In patients with glaucoma, the pressure in the eye becomes elevated and leads to vision loss if left untreated. The function of arcade cells in maintaining proper drainage of aqueous humor has made them a target of glaucoma research. Understanding the physiology of arcade cells may lead to better treatment options for glaucoma patients.

While arcade cells are primarily associated with the drainage of aqueous humor, recent studies have also focused on their potential involvement in immune responses. These cells have been shown to express immune-related genes and may play a role in inflammation and tissue remodeling in the eye. Further research is needed to fully understand the function of arcade cells in the immune system and how they interact with other cells in the eye.
CL:0000391:
Podocytes (sensu Diptera), also known as visceral epithelial cells, are important components of the renal glomerulus, which is responsible for filtering blood. They are unique among epithelial cells due to their intricate cellular architecture, which consists of numerous interdigitating foot processes that play a crucial role in the filtration barrier. Podocytes are characterized by the presence of specialized junctions called slit diaphragms, which are composed of a complex of transmembrane proteins that regulate the passage of molecules from the blood into the urinary space.

The primary function of podocytes is to form the filtration barrier, which is composed of three layers: the glomerular endothelium, the glomerular basement membrane, and the podocyte foot processes. The filtration barrier is responsible for preventing the loss of proteins and other important molecules from the blood into the urinary space while allowing the passage of waste products. Defects in podocyte function have been implicated in a range of kidney diseases, including nephrotic syndrome, diabetic nephropathy, and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.

In addition to their role in the filtration barrier, podocytes are also involved in the regulation of renal blood flow and blood pressure through the production of podocyte-derived vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). Podocytes have also been shown to play a role in the maintenance of the glomerular basement membrane and the regulation of immune responses within the kidney. Overall, podocytes are a critical component of the renal glomerulus and play a crucial role in maintaining normal kidney function.
CL:0000410:
CNS long range interneurons are a subtype of interneurons that are primarily found in the central nervous system (CNS). They are known to play a crucial role in receiving, processing, and transmitting information between different regions of the brain and spinal cord. Their extensive axonal projections make them ideal candidates for relaying signals over long distances in the CNS. These neurons are involved in a wide variety of functions, including motor control, sensory perception, and higher cognitive processing.

The dendritic arbors of CNS long range interneurons are characterized by their wide geographic spread, which allows them to receive inputs from multiple sources. They process this information and use their axonal projections to integrate the signals and communicate with other neurons in the brain. The communication between CNS long range interneurons and other cells in the CNS is crucial for the modulation of neural activity and overall network dynamics. Dysfunction of these neurons can result in a wide range of neurological disorders, including epilepsy, schizophrenia, and Parkinson's disease.

In summary, CNS long range interneurons are a type of interneuron that play a critical role in information processing and transmission in the CNS. Their extensive axonal projections enable them to relay signals over long distances, allowing them to communicate with other neurons in different regions of the brain and spinal cord. They are involved in a wide variety of functions and play a critical role in the modulation of neural activity in the CNS. Dysfunction of these neurons can lead to a range of neurological disorders, highlighting their importance in normal brain function and health.
CL:0000407:
Scolopidial ligament cells are specialized cells found in the sensory organs of insects known as scolopidia. These cells play an important role in the detection of mechanical stimuli, such as sound, vibration, and touch. In simple terms, they act as mechanoreceptors that aid an insect's perception of its surroundings. 

Scolopidia are composed of a group of sensory neurons that are surrounded by a supportive structure known as the scolopale. The scolopidial ligament cells are attached to the scolopale and act as an anchor for the sensory neurons. The cells themselves are spindle-shaped and are characterized by a dense network of actin filaments that are responsible for maintaining their shape and providing the necessary structural support. 

When a mechanical stimulus is applied to an insect's body, the resulting vibrations cause the sensory neurons within the scolopidia to deform. This deformation is then detected by the scolopidial ligament cells, which respond by generating electrical impulses that are sent to the insect's central nervous system. In this way, scolopidial ligament cells play a crucial role in an insect's ability to perceive its environment and respond accordingly. 

Overall, scolopidial ligament cells are an essential component of the sensory system in insects. Their ability to detect and respond to mechanical stimuli enables insects to navigate their environment and avoid potential threats. As such, a deeper understanding of the function of these cells could have implications for the development of new insect control methods or the design of more effective sensory systems for robots and other machines.
CL:0000411:
Caenorhabditis hypodermal cells are epithelial cells that form a continuous layer around the nematode worm's body. They are responsible for several important functions, including barrier protection, structural support, and sensory perception. Hypodermal cells also play a crucial role in the development of the nematode by regulating cell proliferation and differentiation.

The hypodermis is composed of three distinct cell types, each with specific functions. The outermost layer consists of syncytial cells that form a syncytium, which is a multinucleated cell with many nuclei but no cell walls between them. The syncytium allows for rapid and coordinated changes in the body shape and movement of the nematode. The middle layer is composed of seam cells, which are stem-like cells that divide and differentiate throughout development, contributing to the formation and maintenance of the hypodermis. Finally, the innermost layer consists of specialized socket cells, which anchor muscle cells to the underlying hypodermal layer.

In addition to their structural roles, hypodermal cells serve as mechanosensors, responding to changes in pressure and touch. They also play a role in the regulation of body fluid balance by secreting and absorbing fluids. Defects in hypodermal cell function can result in developmental abnormalities or impaired motility, as seen in certain Caenorhabditis mutants. Overall, Caenorhabditis hypodermal cells are essential for maintaining the integrity and functionality of the nematode's body.
CL:0000404:
Electrically signaling cells, commonly known as neurons, are specialized cells that function to transmit electrical or chemical signals in the nervous system. These cells are the building blocks of the nervous system, allowing us to sense the environment, communicate with each other, and respond to stimuli. Neurons are structurally and functionally complex cells that exhibit a diverse array of shapes and sizes, which enable them to perform different functions.

Neurons function through a complex process of electrical and chemical signaling. When a neuron is stimulated, an electrical signal is generated and travels along the length of the cell, from the dendrites to the cell body and then to the axon. At the end of the axon, the electrical signal triggers the release of chemical messengers called neurotransmitters, which are designed to communicate with other neurons or target cells. This process enables neurons to transmit information rapidly and precisely, allowing us to make rapid decisions and respond to stimuli with great speed.

The function of electrically signaling cells is vital to the proper functioning of the nervous system. These cells enable us to process and respond to external stimuli, ranging from touch to taste to smell to sound. They also enable us to communicate with each other and to control our movements and behaviors. Dysfunction or damage to electrically signaling cells can lead to a wide range of neurological disorders, including Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease, and epilepsy. Understanding the structure and function of these complex cells is critical to our ability to diagnose, treat, and prevent these diseases, and to advance our knowledge of the nervous system as a whole.
CL:0000430:
Xanthophore cells, also known as yellow pigment cells, are a type of chromatophore found in various animal species including fish and amphibians. These cells are responsible for producing and storing yellow pigments such as pteridines and carotenoids, which can be used for camouflage, communication, or other biological functions.

Xanthophore cells use specialized organelles called pigment sacs to store and transport the yellow pigments. These organelles are surrounded by a network of microfilaments and microtubules that allow the pigment sacs to move and distribute pigments within the cell. When a signal is received, such as a change in light or temperature, xanthophore cells can rapidly change the distribution and intensity of the yellow pigment within their bodies to perfectly blend in with the surrounding environment or to display bright and vivid colors.

In many fish species, xanthophore cells are found in close association with other types of chromatophores, such as iridophores and melanophores, to create intricate patterns and colorations on the skin. Xanthophore cells are also involved in several important biological processes such as immune response, wound healing, and photoprotection. Overall, xanthophore cells are a fascinating cell type with unique properties that allow them to play crucial roles in both the visual appeal and survival of many animal species.
CL:0000427:
GLR cells, also known as glutamate receptor cells, are a type of neuron found in the central nervous system of vertebrates. These cells are named after their primary function, which is to receive glutamate signals from other neurons in the brain. Glutamate is the most abundant neurotransmitter in the brain and is responsible for regulating a variety of functions, including cognition, memory, and learning.

GLR cells are particularly important because they are involved in the process of long-term potentiation (LTP). LTP is a process by which the strength of synaptic connections between neurons is increased, leading to improved neural communication. Glutamate receptors on GLR cells play a critical role in this process by binding to and receiving glutamate signals from other neurons. Studies have shown that alterations in LTP can lead to a variety of neurological disorders, including Alzheimer's disease and epilepsy.

Overall, GLR cells play a crucial role in regulating neural communication and synaptic plasticity within the brain. By receiving glutamate signals from other neurons and participating in processes like LTP, GLR cells help to ensure that the brain is able to process and respond to complex stimuli. Dysfunction of these cells can lead to a wide range of neurological disorders, highlighting their importance in maintaining proper brain function.
CL:0000420:
Syncytial epithelial cells are specialized cells that are found lining the surfaces of organs such as the placenta and the lungs. These cells are typically large and multinucleated, meaning that they contain multiple nuclei within a single cell membrane. Syncytial epithelial cells are highly important for their role in facilitating the exchange of nutrients and gases between the mother and the developing fetus during pregnancy and in facilitating the gas exchange that occurs in the lungs during respiration.

One of the key functions of syncytial epithelial cells is to increase the surface area available for exchange processes. This is achieved through the formation of highly convoluted membranes that extend outwards from the cell body. These complex membranous folds create a large surface area that is in close proximity to the maternal blood supply in the placenta or the air-filled spaces of the lungs, allowing for efficient exchange of materials. Additionally, the multinucleated nature of syncytial epithelial cells allows for coordinated regulation of transport processes, ensuring that the needs of the developing fetus or the respiratory system are met.

Although syncytial epithelial cells are essential for proper fetal development and respiratory function, they are also vulnerable to damage from toxins, infections, and other stresses. Disruption of the structure or function of these cells can lead to serious consequences for both the mother and the developing fetus, including developmental defects, miscarriage, or respiratory failure. As such, understanding the biology of syncytial epithelial cells and their role in normal physiology is critical for the development of effective treatments and interventions to prevent or mitigate these adverse outcomes.
CL:0000419:
Seam cells are a specialized type of stem cell found in the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans, a common model organism in molecular biology. Seam cells are located in the lateral hypodermal ridges, or "seams," of the worm and play a critical role in development and differentiation. Specifically, these cells are responsible for the generation of the worm's hypodermis, which is the outer layer of cells that covers the entire body. 

Seam cells have some unique characteristics compared to other stem cells. They are known to divide asymmetrically, meaning that one daughter cell will differentiate into a hypodermal cell, while the other will remain a seam cell. This process allows for the constant renewal and maintenance of the hypodermis throughout the worm's life. Additionally, seam cells are highly responsive to environmental cues and can differentiate into other cell types depending on the conditions. This has made them a valuable tool for studying the molecular mechanisms and signaling pathways involved in stem cell differentiation and development. 

Overall, seam cells are an essential element of C. elegans development. Their ability to divide asymmetrically and differentiate in response to environmental cues make them a powerful model for studying stem cell biology. By better understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying seam cell differentiation, researchers can gain insights into how stem cells function in other organisms, including humans and potentially identify targets for therapeutic interventions in stem cell-related diseases.
CL:0000436:
Vaginal lubricant secreting cells are specialized epithelial cells found in the female reproductive tract. These cells play a crucial role in maintaining vaginal health and function. Vaginal lubrication is essential for comfortable sexual intercourse, and these cells are responsible for producing the mucosal secretions that lubricate the vagina. The amount and type of secretion produced by these cells can also vary based on hormonal changes and sexual arousal levels.

The vaginal lubricant secreting cells are located in the upper layers of the vaginal epithelium. They have a unique morphology, with a large, pale-staining nucleus and abundant cytoplasm filled with mucin granules. The mucin granules contain glycoproteins and mucopolysaccharides, which contribute to the lubricating properties of the vaginal secretions. These cells are regulated by estrogen and progesterone, with changes in hormone levels affecting both the quantity and quality of the vaginal secretions.

In addition to their lubricating function, these cells also play a role in maintaining the vaginal microbiome. The vaginal secretions produced by these cells contain antimicrobial peptides that help to prevent infections and maintain a healthy balance of bacteria in the vagina. Dysregulation of these cells can lead to conditions like vaginal dryness and bacterial vaginosis. Overall, vaginal lubricant secreting cells are an essential component of female reproductive health, contributing to comfortable sexual intercourse and the maintenance of vaginal health.
CL:0000438:
Luteinizing hormone (LH) is a glycoprotein hormone that is secreted by specialized cells within the anterior pituitary gland called luteinizing hormone-secreting cells (LH cells). These cells are a type of endocrine cell that release LH in response to gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), which is secreted by neurons in the hypothalamus. LH cells are essential for regulating reproductive function in both males and females.

In females, LH plays a crucial role in ovulation and menstrual cycle regulation. During the menstrual cycle, GnRH released by the hypothalamus stimulates LH release from the pituitary gland, leading to the production and release of estrogen from follicular cells in the ovaries. This surge of estrogen then triggers a positive feedback loop that results in a surge of LH, causing ovulation. After ovulation, LH promotes the development of the corpus luteum, a temporary endocrine structure that produces progesterone to prepare the uterus for implantation.

In males, LH also plays a critical role in regulating reproductive function. LH stimulates testosterone production in Leydig cells in the testes. Testosterone is responsible for the development and maintenance of male secondary sexual characteristics, including the growth of facial hair, deepening of the voice, and increased muscle mass. Thus, LH-secreting cells have an essential role in maintaining reproductive health in both males and females.
CL:0000440:
Melanocyte stimulating hormone (MSH) is a neuropeptide that regulates melanosome production in melanocytes, the pigment-producing cells in the skin. MSH is synthesized and secreted by melanocyte stimulating hormone-secreting cells (MSH cells), also known as corticotrophs, in the anterior pituitary gland. MSH cells are a type of endocrine cell that release MSH in response to corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) from the hypothalamus.

MSH cells are a key component of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis, which is responsible for regulating the body's stress response. CRH stimulates MSH cells to produce and secrete MSH into the bloodstream. Once in the bloodstream, MSH binds to melanocortin 1 receptors (MC1R) on the surface of melanocytes and initiates a series of biochemical reactions that ultimately increase melanosome production. This process is important for protecting the skin from sunlight-induced damage.

In addition to regulating melanosome production, MSH has been shown to have anti-inflammatory and analgesic effects. MSH is also involved in other physiological processes, such as appetite regulation and energy homeostasis. Dysregulation of the HPA axis and MSH signaling has been implicated in a number of conditions, including obesity, depression, and chronic pain.
CL:0000439:
Prolactin-secreting cells, also known as lactotrophs, are a type of endocrine cell located in the anterior pituitary gland. These cells are responsible for producing and secreting prolactin, a hormone that plays a vital role in lactation, reproduction, and immune system regulation. Prolactin is also involved in several other physiological processes such as metabolism, mood regulation, and growth and development.

Lactotrophs are characterized by their large, round nuclei and prominent secretory granules within the cytoplasm. They are under the control of hypothalamic hormones, primarily dopamine, which inhibits prolactin secretion. However, other factors such as estrogen, thyrotropin-releasing hormone, and growth hormone-releasing hormone can increase prolactin production and release from these cells.

Dysregulation of prolactin secretion by lactotrophs can lead to several disorders, including hyperprolactinemia, a condition in which there is an excess amount of prolactin in the blood. This can cause infertility, menstrual irregularities, and galactorrhea. Prolactinomas, tumors of the prolactin-secreting cells, are another disorder that can result in elevated prolactin levels and can lead to various symptoms including headache, visual disturbances, and even pituitary apoplexy.
CL:0000424:
Excretory cells are specialized cells that are responsible for eliminating waste products and excess water from the body. They are a key component of the excretory system and are found in a variety of organisms, from simple invertebrates to complex mammals. These cells typically have a distinct morphology, with a large nucleus and a membrane-bound structure called a contractile vacuole that is responsible for expelling waste and regulating water balance in the cell. 

Excretory cells play a crucial role in maintaining homeostasis within the body. In organisms with a circulatory system, excretory cells are responsible for filtering waste products from the blood and transporting them to the organs of excretion, such as the kidneys in mammals. In simpler organisms, excretory cells may be involved in eliminating waste directly into the surrounding environment. These cells are particularly important in aquatic organisms, where the concentration of waste products in the water can have significant impacts on the health of the organism and the ecosystem as a whole.

Several different types of excretory cells have been described in different organisms, each with their own unique morphology and specialized roles. For example, in the nematode C. elegans, excretory cells called nephridial cells are responsible for eliminating waste and maintaining osmotic balance. In insects, specialized tubules known as Malpighian tubules are responsible for filtering waste and regulating water balance. Despite these variations, all excretory cells are united by their function in eliminating waste and balancing the internal environment of the organism.
CL:0000444:
Obliquely striated muscle cells, also referred to as cardiac muscle cells, are a type of highly specialized muscle cell found exclusively in the heart tissue. These cells are responsible for the heart's permanent and continuous contraction, which pumps blood throughout the body, thereby delivering essential nutrients and oxygen to the vital organs. While they resemble skeletal and smooth muscles in several ways, they exhibit unique structural and functional characteristics that enable them to perform their specific role in the body.

Obliquely striated muscle cells exhibit a unique pattern of striations, generated by the arrangement of overlapping thick and thin filaments, that enable them to contract and relax continuously and rhythmically. They are also characterized by their numerous mitochondria, which provide the constant supply of energy required for involuntary cardiac contractions. These cells are interconnected by intercalated discs, which contain specialized gap junctions that allow for synchronized electrical impulses among the cells, resulting in the coordinated contractions of the heart.

In addition to their role in pumping blood, obliquely striated muscle cells are also involved in several signaling pathways that regulate blood pressure, electrolyte balance, and cardiac growth. Impairment in these pathways can lead to various cardiovascular diseases, including hypertrophy, arrhythmias, and heart failure. Therefore, understanding the structure and function of these cells is crucial for the diagnosis and treatment of several cardiac disorders.
CL:0000464:
Epidermoblasts are a type of stem cell that originates from the outermost layer of skin, known as the epidermis. These cells are often described as "pluripotent," meaning they have the ability to give rise to multiple cell types, including keratinocytes, the cells that make up the majority of the epidermis. The differentiation of epidermoblasts into keratinocytes is controlled by various signaling pathways and transcription factors.

In addition to their role in skin development and regeneration, epidermoblasts have also been implicated in the development and progression of skin cancers, such as basal cell carcinoma. It is thought that these cells may acquire genetic mutations or epigenetic alterations that drive abnormal growth and proliferation, ultimately leading to the formation of tumors.

Researchers are actively studying epidermoblasts in order to better understand their role in both normal skin development and disease. By gaining a deeper understanding of these cells, we may be able to develop new therapies for skin conditions and cancers that target the mechanisms underlying their formation and function.
CL:0000428:
A yolk cell, also known as a nutritive cell or vitellocyte, is a specialized cell found in egg-laying animals such as birds, fishes, and reptiles. Unlike most other cells in the organism, the primary function of the yolk cell is to provide a source of nutrients for the developing embryo. These cells are largely composed of stored nutrients such as lipids, proteins, and carbohydrates, which are essential for energy production and growth.

Yolk cells can vary considerably in size and composition depending on the species and type of egg, ranging from small, homogenous cells to large, granular cells that occupy most of the egg volume. In some organisms, such as birds, yolk cells are produced in the liver and then transported to the developing egg through specialized ducts. In others, such as fish, yolk cells are produced directly in the egg and gradually accumulate during development.

Despite its primary role as a nutrient source, yolk cells can also play other important roles in embryo development. For example, yolk cells in some fish and amphibians may contain hormones and other signaling molecules that are involved in the regulation of early development. In addition, the deposition of yolk in the egg can provide physical protection and support for the developing embryo, helping to ensure that it will survive and thrive to hatching.
CL:0000737:
Striated muscle cells, also known as skeletal muscle cells, are one of three types of muscle cells found in the human body. These cells are long, multinucleated, and striated, meaning they have a characteristic striped pattern. Striated muscle cells are responsible for all voluntary movements in the body, such as walking, talking, and running. These cells are connected to bone via tendons, which allow for the transmission of force and movement.

The function of striated muscle cells is to contract and provide movement for the body. This is achieved through a series of specialized proteins called myofilaments, which create the characteristic striated pattern. When activated by a nerve impulse, myofilaments in the cell interact with each other, causing the cell to shorten and produce force. This force is then transmitted to the tendons and bone, ultimately resulting in movement.

Striated muscle cells require a large amount of energy to function, as the process of muscle contraction is highly energy-intensive. This energy is provided through a specialized organelle called the mitochondria, which is present in high numbers within the cell. Additionally, these cells can adapt to changing conditions through a process called hypertrophy, where the cell increases in size and strength in response to increased demand. Overall, striated muscle cells play a crucial role in the human body by allowing for movement and physical activity.
CL:0000432:
Reticular cells are a specialized type of stromal cells found in the bone marrow, lymph nodes, spleen, and thymus gland. These cells are characterized by their branching network of thin, elongated cytoplasmic processes that form a supportive framework called the reticular network. Reticular cells secrete extracellular matrix components such as collagen, glycoproteins, and reticular fibers, which form the scaffolding for other cells to attach and migrate.

In the bone marrow, reticular cells support the development and maturation of hematopoietic cells, which give rise to all types of blood cells. They also regulate the entry and exit of cells in and out of the bone marrow. In the lymph nodes and spleen, reticular cells form the framework for lymphoid tissue, where they support the functions of immune cells such as lymphocytes and macrophages. In the thymus gland, reticular cells provide a scaffold for the development and maturation of T-lymphocytes, which are important for immune defense against viruses, bacteria, and cancer.

Reticular cells also play a crucial role in maintaining the tissue architecture and homeostasis by secreting cytokines and growth factors that regulate cell proliferation, differentiation, and survival. Dysfunction or abnormal proliferation of reticular cells has been implicated in the pathogenesis of several diseases, including lymphomas, myeloproliferative disorders, and autoimmune diseases. Overall, reticular cells are an essential component of the stromal microenvironment that provides structural and functional support for the various tissues in the body.
CL:0000449:
Brown fat cells, also known as brown adipocytes, are a type of adipocyte that are responsible for generating heat in the body through a process called non-shivering thermogenesis. They are found primarily in small mammals as well as in newborn humans, where they play a crucial role in maintaining body temperature. These cells contain a high concentration of mitochondria, which gives them their brown color and allows them to produce heat by burning fatty acids.

Brown fat cells are activated by exposure to cold temperatures or by certain hormones, such as norepinephrine, which is released by the sympathetic nervous system. When activated, these cells use stored triglycerides to generate heat. This process is mediated by the uncoupling protein 1 (UCP1), which allows protons to leak across the mitochondrial inner membrane, bypassing ATP synthesis and releasing energy as heat instead.

Research has shown that brown fat cells may play a role in metabolic diseases such as obesity and type 2 diabetes. Increasing the activity of brown fat cells through diet or exercise may lead to improved glucose metabolism and decreased body fat. Additionally, recent studies have focused on the potential of brown fat cells as a therapeutic target for obesity and related metabolic disorders.
CL:0000442:
Follicular dendritic cells (FDCs) are specialized cells found in lymphoid follicles in secondary lymphoid organs such as lymph nodes and spleen. FDCs play a key role in the immune response by presenting antigens to B-cells, which are responsible for producing antibodies. They accomplish this by trapping and retaining immune complexes on their surface for extended periods of time, allowing B-cells to encounter and recognize the antigens. In addition, FDCs secrete various cytokines and chemokines that direct immune cells to sites of infection or inflammation.

FDCs are unique among immune cells in that they do not originate from hematopoietic stem cells, but rather from stromal cells in the lymphoid tissues. They are characterized by their distinctive shape, with long, branching processes that form a network within the follicle. FDCs are also distinguished by the presence of complement receptors, Fc receptors, and other molecules that enable them to capture and present antigens to B-cells.

Because of their important role in antigen presentation and immune regulation, FDCs have been studied extensively in the context of infectious diseases, autoimmunity, and cancer. Understanding the functions and mechanisms of FDCs may ultimately lead to new approaches for vaccine development, immune system modulation, and therapeutic interventions.
CL:0002260:
Epithelial cells of the parathyroid gland are responsible for the secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH), a critical regulator of calcium and phosphate homeostasis in the body. These cells are tightly packed and form spherical clusters, known as parathyroid adenomas, within the parathyroid gland. They are also known to form small clefts and tubules to facilitate communication with neighboring cells and the bloodstream.

PTH secretion by these epithelial cells is regulated by serum calcium levels. When serum calcium levels are low, PTH secretion is stimulated, causing an increase in calcium reabsorption from the kidneys, activation of vitamin D, and release of calcium from the bones. On the other hand, when serum calcium levels are high, PTH secretion is suppressed to prevent the buildup of excess calcium in the blood.

In addition to their critical role in calcium and phosphate homeostasis, epithelial cells of the parathyroid gland also play a role in the pathogenesis of certain diseases. For example, overproduction of PTH by these cells can lead to hyperparathyroidism, a condition characterized by excessive bone resorption, hypercalcemia, and hypercalciuria. Understanding the function and regulation of these cells is essential for developing treatments for these disorders.
CL:0000456:
Mineralocorticoid-secreting cells, also known as aldosterone-secreting cells, are specialized epithelial cells located within the outer layer of the adrenal cortex. These cells are responsible for the synthesis and secretion of the hormone aldosterone, which plays a crucial role in regulating electrolyte balance and blood pressure within the body. 

Aldosterone acts on the distal convoluted tubules and cortical collecting ducts of the kidney, promoting the reabsorption of sodium ions and the excretion of potassium ions. Through these actions, aldosterone promotes the retention of sodium, which can increase blood volume and blood pressure. Additionally, aldosterone can stimulate the excretion of hydrogen ions through the kidneys, which can help regulate the body's pH balance. 

In addition to its role in electrolyte balance and blood pressure regulation, aldosterone may also play a role in glucose metabolism, immune function, and inflammation. Dysregulation of aldosterone secretion can lead to a variety of health problems, including hypertension, hypokalemia, and edema. Understanding the function of mineralocorticoid-secreting cells and their regulation is critical for developing effective treatments for these conditions.
CL:0000373:
Histoblasts are a type of stem cell that appear in the developing embryo during the stage of gastrulation. Their role is to give rise to the different cell types that make up the body tissues, organs and structures. One of the striking features of these cells is their ability to change fate and differentiate into multiple lineages depending on extracellular signals, which includes bone, cartilage, muscle, and adipose tissues. In phenotypic terms, histoblasts are characterized by the ability to self-renew and differentiate into every cell type of the organism, serving as a source of regenerative and reparative abilities throughout the lifespan.

Histoblasts play a crucial role in the process of morphogenesis, which is the creation of form and structure in the developing embryo. In the early stages of embryonic development, histoblasts proliferate and differentiate into cells that will form many different body parts and structures. These cells are able to change their fate and become specialized to create different organs and tissues. For example, some cells could differentiate into heart muscle while others may differentiate into bone or adipose tissue.

In conclusion, histoblasts are an essential stem cell type responsible for the development of different structures and organs and for regenerating damaged tissues throughout the life of an organism. The unique ability to differentiate into any type of tissue makes these cells ideal candidates for regenerative medicine, which aims to repair or regenerate tissue that has been damaged due to disease or injury.
CL:0000453:
Langerhans cells are a specialized type of dendritic cell found in the epidermis of the skin and mucous membranes. They are named after Paul Langerhans who discovered them in 1868. These cells are characterized by their unique appearance: they have a dendritic shape with numerous projections, and they contain intracytoplasmic Birbeck granules.

Langerhans cells play a crucial role in the immune system's response to external stimuli such as pathogens, allergens, and toxins that encounter the skin. They act as antigen-presenting cells (APCs), meaning they engulf and digest foreign substances within their cytoplasm and then present pieces of these antigens on their surface to T-helper cells. When these T-cells become activated, they can coordinate an immune response to eliminate the pathogen or allergen.

In addition to their immune function, Langerhans cells also play a role in maintaining skin homeostasis. Recent studies have shown that they can act as sensors of mechanical stress and pressure, which can trigger the release of cytokines and other signaling molecules involved in wound healing and tissue repair. Overall, Langerhans cells are essential for the skin's immune defense while also contributing to tissue maintenance and repair.
CL:0000443:
Calcitonin-secreting cells, also known as C-cells, are specialized cells found in the thyroid gland. C-cells are responsible for producing the hormone calcitonin, which helps regulate calcium levels in the blood. When calcium levels in the blood become too high, calcitonin is released by C-cells, which inhibits the action of osteoclasts in the bone, thereby reducing bone resorption and promoting calcium deposition. 

C-cells have a unique morphology in comparison to other thyroid cells, with a round or oval shape and a relatively small size. They are located in the interfollicular spaces of the thyroid gland and are found in clusters. C-cells are distinct from other thyroid cells because they originate from different embryonic germ layers. While thyroid follicular cells derive from endodermal tissue, C-cells originate from neural crest cells. 

Calcitonin-secreting cells play a crucial role in the maintenance of calcium homeostasis in the body. When calcium levels in the blood are too high, C-cells release calcitonin, which helps reduce calcium absorption from the bone and excretion in the kidneys. This results in a decrease in blood calcium levels. C-cells also play a potential role in other physiological functions such as energy metabolism and bone growth, making them an interesting target for research into treatments for metabolic and skeletal disorders.
CL:0000434:
Eccrine cells are a type of sweat gland cells found in the skin of mammals, including humans. They are simple, coiled, tubular glands that regulate body temperature and maintain fluid balance by producing sweat, a fluid that contains water, salt and other compounds. The primary function of eccrine cells is to secrete sweat onto the surface of the skin, where it evaporates and helps to dissipate excess body heat. They are mainly concentrated on the palms, soles, and forehead, but can be found all over the body.

The sweat produced by eccrine cells is odorless, transparent, and composed mainly of water and electrolytes. It is different from the sweat produced by apocrine cells, which is thicker and contains fatty acids, making it prone to bacterial decomposition and producing body odor. Under normal circumstances, the secretion of sweat by eccrine cells is primarily regulated by the autonomic nervous system, which responds to the internal and external conditions of the body. For example, during exercise or when the body is exposed to a hot environment, the nervous system sends signals to eccrine cells to produce more sweat to help regulate the body’s temperature.

Eccrine cells have a crucial role in maintaining the homeostasis of the body. Failure of these cells can result in excessive sweating, known as hyperhidrosis, or anhidrosis, a condition in which no sweat is produced. Disorders related to eccrine cells can be caused by several factors including genetic mutations, nerve damage, certain medications or underlying medical conditions. Therefore, a better understanding of these cells and their functions is necessary for the diagnosis and treatment of various skin-related conditions.
CL:0000639:
The basophil cells of pars distalis of adenohypophysis are endocrine cells located in the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland. These cells produce and release a hormone called adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), also known as corticotropin, which stimulates the secretion of cortisol by the adrenal gland. ACTH is important in the body's response to stress, and its release is regulated by the hypothalamus and the adrenal gland.

Basophil cells of pars distalis of adenohypophysis have distinct morphological characteristics that allow them to be identified under a microscope. They have a large, round nucleus and numerous granules that contain the hormone ACTH. The granules are released from the cell in response to a signaling pathway that involves the hypothalamus and the adrenal gland. When ACTH is released into the bloodstream, it travels to the adrenal gland and stimulates the production and release of cortisol.

The regulation of ACTH release by basophil cells of pars distalis of adenohypophysis is complex and involves many feedback mechanisms. The hypothalamus secretes corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) in response to various stimuli such as stress, which then stimulates the release of ACTH by the basophil cells. However, once cortisol levels in the blood rise, they inhibit the release of CRH and ACTH, effectively shutting down the stress response. Overall, the basophil cells of pars distalis of adenohypophysis play a critical role in the regulation of the body's response to stress through the production and release of the hormone ACTH.
CL:0000446:
Chief cells are a type of epithelial cell that are found within the parathyroid gland, a small endocrine gland located near the thyroid gland in the neck region of humans and other vertebrates. These cells play an important role in regulating calcium homeostasis in the body, which is essential for proper skeletal development and other physiological processes.

The primary function of chief cells is the production and secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH), a peptide hormone that helps regulate blood calcium levels. When blood calcium levels are low, chief cells synthesize and secrete PTH into the bloodstream, which stimulates the release of calcium from bone tissue and increases the reabsorption of calcium by the kidneys. PTH also enhances the absorption of calcium in the small intestine by promoting the production of active vitamin D.

In addition to its role in calcium homeostasis, PTH also has other important physiological effects. It helps regulate phosphate concentration in the blood by increasing the excretion of phosphate in the kidneys. PTH also stimulates the production of osteoclasts, which are cells that break down bone tissue and release calcium into the bloodstream. Overall, chief cells in the parathyroid gland play a critical role in maintaining calcium and phosphate homeostasis in the body, which is essential for proper physiological function.
CL:0000431:
Iridophores are specialized pigment cells found in a variety of animals, including fish, amphibians, and reptiles. They are responsible for producing iridescent colors that are used for a range of functions, including camouflage, communication, and mate selection. Iridophores are comprised of a specialized class of pigment-containing organelles known as iridosomes, which are encapsulated within a layer of cytoplasm.

In fish, iridophores are often located in the skin and produce a variety of colors, including gold, silver, and blue. These colors are used for camouflage, particularly in species that live in shallow water environments where they need to blend in with their surroundings to avoid detection by predators. In addition to camouflage, iridophores in fish have also been shown to play a role in mate selection, with males displaying brighter, more iridescent colors during courtship displays.

In amphibians and reptiles, iridophores are often found in specialized structures known as chromatophores, which are responsible for color change in response to environmental cues such as temperature or light. In these animals, iridophores may produce colors ranging from greens and blues to reds and oranges. While the precise function of iridescence in these animals is not fully understood, it is believed to play a role in communication and warning signals, particularly in species that are toxic or venomous. Overall, the unique properties of iridophores make them a fascinating topic of study for cell biologists and zoologists alike.
CL:0002335:
Brown preadipocytes are a type of precursor cell that give rise to brown adipocytes. These cells contain large amounts of mitochondria and cytoplasmic lipid droplets that are used for generating heat. Brown preadipocytes express genes such as PRDM16, PPARgamma, and FOXC2, which are involved in the regulation of adipogenesis and thermogenesis.

The function of brown preadipocytes is to differentiate into brown adipocytes, which play a critical role in regulating energy balance. Brown adipose tissue is responsible for non-shivering thermogenesis, a process by which the body generates heat in response to cold exposure or overfeeding. Brown adipocytes are activated by sympathetic nerves through the release of norepinephrine, which stimulates the expression of uncoupling protein 1 (UCP1) in mitochondria. UCP1 uncouples oxidative phosphorylation from ATP synthesis, resulting in the dissipation of energy as heat. 

Brown preadipocytes also secrete hormones and cytokines, such as adiponectin and interleukin-6, which have important roles in metabolic homeostasis. Adiponectin regulates insulin sensitivity and lipid metabolism, while interleukin-6 activates thermogenesis and promotes browning of white adipose tissue. Understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying the differentiation and function of brown preadipocytes could lead to the development of novel therapies for obesity and type 2 diabetes.
CL:0000437:
Gonadotrophs are a type of endocrine cell found in the anterior pituitary gland. These cells secrete two hormones: follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH), which play vital roles in the reproductive system. The secretion of these hormones is regulated by gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), which is produced and released by the hypothalamus.

The function of FSH is to stimulate the growth and development of follicles in the ovaries or seminiferous tubules in the testes. Follicles are structures that contain developing oocytes, or eggs, in females and seminiferous tubules are the site of sperm production in males. FSH also stimulates the production of estrogen in females and testosterone in males. LH, on the other hand, triggers the release of mature eggs from the follicles in females, a process known as ovulation. In males, LH stimulates the production of testosterone from Leydig cells found in the testes.

Disorders of gonadotrophs can lead to infertility, delayed puberty, and other reproductive disorders. For example, a deficiency in FSH can result in infertility due to the failure of follicle development, while LH deficiency can lead to impaired ovulation and the development of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) in females. Excessive production of FSH or LH can also lead to these disorders, as well as precocious puberty and other hormonal imbalances.
CL:0000445:
Apoptosis is a programmed cell death process that plays a crucial role during development and in the maintenance of tissue homeostasis. Apoptosis fated cell is a cell type that has been programmed to undergo apoptosis. These cells are genetically instructed to activate a series of molecular events leading to self-destruction in response to certain physiological or pathological signals. The activation of apoptotic pathways is a tightly regulated process involving signaling cascades that culminate in the release of proteins from mitochondria and the activation of caspases, a family of cysteine proteases that degrade cellular structures and DNA.

Apoptosis fated cells are involved in numerous developmental and pathological processes, including tissue remodeling, immune system regulation, and cancer. During embryonic development, apoptosis fated cells are essential for shaping the developing organs and sculpting structures like fingers and toes. In adults, apoptosis plays a crucial role in eliminating damaged or infected cells, preventing the spread of infectious agents or genetic errors. In the immune system, apoptosis fated cells are involved in the negative selection of immune cells that recognize self-antigens, preventing autoimmune disorders. Dysregulation of apoptosis has been linked to numerous diseases, including cancer, neurodegeneration, and autoimmune disorders.

In summary, apoptosis fated cells are a crucial type of cell that plays a critical role in tissue homeostasis and development. These genetically instructed cells undergo self-destruction in response to certain physiological or pathological signals through tightly regulated signaling pathways. Understanding the mechanisms regulating apoptosis fated cells is crucial for developing new therapies for a wide range of diseases.
CL:0000441:
Follicle stem cells (FSCs) are a type of adult stem cell found in the hair follicles of mammals, including humans. These cells are responsible for maintaining and regenerating hair follicles throughout life, which plays a critical role in hair growth, cycling, and regeneration. During normal hair growth, FSCs differentiate into specialized precursor cells that contribute to the formation of hair shafts. However, FSCs can also become activated in response to tissue damage, such as in cases of wound healing or burn injuries, where they aid in tissue repair.

In addition to their role in hair follicle development and regeneration, FSCs have also been found to play an important role in skin homeostasis and maintenance. Specifically, FSCs have been shown to contribute to the formation of sebaceous glands, which produce the oily substance that helps lubricate and protect the skin. Additionally, FSCs have also been implicated in the formation of skin tumors, with abnormal activation of these cells leading to the development of basal cell carcinomas and other types of skin cancers.

Overall, the study of FSCs is an important area of research that has implications for both cosmetic and medical applications. By better understanding the mechanisms underlying FSC function and regulation, researchers may be able to develop new therapies for a wide range of hair and skin disorders, as well as for cosmetic purposes such as hair loss or gray hair.
CL:0010021:
Cardiac myoblasts are a type of cell found in the development of the embryonic heart. They are a precursor cell type that eventually differentiate into cardiomyocytes that form the functional contractile units of the adult heart. During heart development, the cardiac myoblasts migrate and proliferate to form the trabeculae, which is the inner spongy layer of the heart. These cells are also involved in the development of the heart valves and the formation of the interventricular septum.

Cardiac myoblasts play a critical role in repairing damaged or injured heart tissue. During a heart attack, these cells are recruited to the site of injury where they divide and differentiate into cardiomyocytes as part of the repair process. Additionally, researchers have found that cardiac myoblasts have the potential to be used in regenerative medicine for heart disease. When transplanted into damaged heart tissue, these cells can differentiate into functional cardiomyocytes, leading to improved heart function.

In conclusion, cardiac myoblasts play a key role in the development and repair of the heart. As a precursor cell type, they differentiate into cardiomyocytes that form the functional contractile units of the adult heart. Their potential for cardiac regeneration makes them a promising target for cell-based therapies for heart disease.
CL:0000469:
Ganglion mother cells (GMCs) are neural precursor cells that give rise to specialized neurons in the developing nervous system. These cells undergo asymmetric cell division, which results in the generation of two daughter cells with distinct fates - one daughter cell becomes a post-mitotic neuron while the other retains its proliferative capacity and continues to divide as a GMC. GMCs are important for establishing the correct number and identity of neurons during nervous system development.

The asymmetric division of GMCs is regulated by a complex network of molecular pathways. One such pathway involves the coordination of mitotic spindle orientation and cell fate determinants. During cell division, the mitotic spindle is oriented along a specific axis, which results in the unequal segregation of molecular determinants between the two daughter cells. This generates two cells with distinct molecular profiles and developmental potentials.

Studies have shown that alterations in the asymmetric division of GMCs can result in defects in neural development and neurodegenerative diseases. Therefore, understanding the mechanisms that regulate GMC division and fate determination is crucial for the development of therapeutic interventions for a range of neurological conditions. Overall, GMCs play a critical role in nervous system development and function, and their study is an important area of research in cell and developmental biology.
CL:0000460:
Glucocorticoid secreting cells are a type of endocrine cells that are found in the adrenal cortex. They are responsible for producing and secreting glucocorticoids, which are steroid hormones that are important for regulating a wide variety of physiological processes in the body. Glucocorticoids help to regulate metabolism, immune function, and stress responses, and they are also important for maintaining blood glucose levels.

Glucocorticoid secreting cells produce cortisol, which is the primary glucocorticoid hormone in humans. Cortisol is involved in the body's response to stress, and it helps to regulate glucose levels by increasing gluconeogenesis and decreasing the uptake of glucose into cells. Cortisol also plays a role in immune function by suppressing inflammation and inhibiting the proliferation of immune cells. In addition, glucocorticoids are involved in the regulation of blood pressure and the maintenance of electrolyte balance.

Disorders of glucocorticoid production can have significant effects on health. Overproduction of cortisol can lead to Cushing's syndrome, which can cause symptoms such as weight gain, skin changes, and high blood pressure. Underproduction of cortisol can lead to Addison's disease, which can cause symptoms such as fatigue, low blood pressure, and increased susceptibility to infections. Treatments for these disorders often involve the use of glucocorticoid medications to supplement or replace the body's own hormone production.
CL:0000468:
The neuroglioblast (sensu Nematoda and Protostomia) is a type of stem cell found in the nervous system of nematode worms and other protostomes. These cells are responsible for generating both neurons and glial cells, making them crucial for the development and maintenance of the nervous system. Neuroglioblasts are known for their ability to divide asymmetrically, producing both a neuron and a glial cell with each division.

The neurons produced by neuroglioblasts are responsible for transmitting electrical signals throughout the nervous system, allowing for movement, sensation, and cognitive function. Glial cells, on the other hand, provide support and protection for neurons, helping to maintain their structure and function. Without neuroglioblasts, the nervous system would not be able to develop or function properly.

In addition to their role in development, neuroglioblasts may also have important implications for regenerative medicine. Studies have shown that these cells are capable of differentiating into both neurons and glial cells even in adulthood, raising the possibility of using them to repair damaged or diseased tissue in the nervous system. Overall, the neuroglioblast represents a critical component of the nervous system, both during development and in adulthood.
CL:0000435:
An alkali-secreting cell, also known as an oxyntic or parietal cell, is a specialized type of epithelial cell found in the lining of the stomach. These cells are responsible for secreting hydrochloric acid (HCl) and intrinsic factor into the stomach lumen. The primary function of hydrochloric acid is to lower the pH of the stomach, which creates a highly acidic environment that is optimal for the breakdown of food and the activation of digestive enzymes. Intrinsic factor is essential for the absorption of vitamin B12, which is necessary for the production of red blood cells.

The secretion of hydrochloric acid by alkali-secreting cells is a complex process that involves a series of steps. First, carbon dioxide and water molecules combine in the cytoplasm of the cell to form carbonic acid. This reaction is catalyzed by an enzyme called carbonic anhydrase. The carbonic acid then dissociates into bicarbonate ions (HCO3-) and hydrogen ions (H+). The bicarbonate ions are transported out of the cell and into the bloodstream, while the hydrogen ions are pumped into the stomach lumen through a proton pump located in the cell membrane.

Alkali-secreting cells play a crucial role in the proper functioning of the digestive system. Without these cells, the pH of the stomach would not be low enough to activate digestive enzymes or to kill harmful bacteria that may be ingested with food. However, excessive secretion of hydrochloric acid by these cells can lead to conditions such as gastritis, peptic ulcer disease, and even gastric cancer. Therefore, a delicate balance must be maintained in the regulation of alkali-secreting cells to ensure optimal digestive health.
CL:0000648:
Kidney granular cells, also known as juxtaglomerular cells, are specialized cells located in the afferent arterioles of the kidney. These cells play a crucial role in regulating blood pressure and fluid balance in the body. Kidney granular cells produce and secrete the enzyme renin in response to changes in blood pressure and sodium levels.

Renin is a key component of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), a hormonal pathway that regulates blood pressure and fluid balance. Renin catalyzes the conversion of angiotensinogen, a protein in the blood, into angiotensin I, which is then converted to angiotensin II. Angiotensin II is a potent vasoconstrictor that causes blood vessels to narrow and raises blood pressure. It also stimulates the release of aldosterone, a hormone that causes the kidneys to retain sodium and water, further increasing blood volume and pressure.

In addition to their role in regulating blood pressure, kidney granular cells also play a role in the formation of the kidney's filtration units, called glomeruli. These cells are located adjacent to the glomerulus and provide a physical and functional connection between the renal arterioles and glomerular capillaries. Dysfunction or damage to kidney granular cells can lead to hypertension and renal disorders, highlighting the importance of these cells in maintaining overall health and homeostasis in the body.
CL:0000470:
Digestive enzyme secreting cells are specialized cells that are responsible for secreting enzymes that break down nutrients in the digestive tract. They are found throughout the digestive system, from the mouth to the pancreas. The enzymes secreted by these cells play a crucial role in the digestion of carbohydrates, proteins, and fats, which are essential for providing energy and building blocks for the body.

There are several different types of digestive enzyme secreting cells, each of which secretes a specific type of enzyme. For example, cells in the mouth and stomach secrete enzymes that break down carbohydrates and proteins, while cells in the pancreas secrete enzymes that break down lipids (fats). These enzymes are released into the digestive tract in response to the presence of food and work together to break down large nutrient molecules into smaller, more easily absorbable molecules.

In addition to their role in nutrient digestion, digestive enzyme secreting cells also play a role in protecting the digestive tract from pathogens and other harmful organisms. For example, enzymes secreted by cells in the stomach help to kill bacteria and other microbes that are ingested with food. Without these enzymes, the digestive system would not be able to effectively break down and absorb nutrients, leading to malnutrition and other health problems.
CL:0005001:
Iridoblasts are specialized cells found in the integument of many lower vertebrates, particularly fish, amphibians, and reptiles. These cells are responsible for producing the iridescent structural colors seen in the skin, scales, and feathers of these animals. Iridophores, which are the pigment cells that contain the iridoblasts, reflect light through a combination of pigment and light-refracting structures that consist of arrays of parallel platelets. The iridoblasts are responsible for creating these platelets, which are layered on top of each other to produce the iridescent effect.

The iridescent coloration produced by iridoblasts serves a number of functions in these animals. For example, it can be used for camouflage, as the colors can match the reflective properties of the surrounding environment. Additionally, iridescent colors can be used for signaling purposes, such as when male fish display their vibrant colors during courtship displays. Some species of chameleons can also use their iridoblasts to rapidly change their skin coloration to blend in with their environment or communicate with other members of their species.

Recent studies have also suggested that iridoblasts may play a role in heat regulation. The platelets reflect a significant amount of light and heat away from the body, potentially helping to regulate body temperature. Overall, iridoblasts are a fascinating type of cell that are not only responsible for creating beautiful colors in animals, but also provide important functions for survival and communication.
CL:0000448:
A white fat cell, also known as an adipocyte, is a cell that specializes in storing energy in the form of fat. These cells are found throughout the body, but are most commonly found in adipose tissue, which is located beneath the skin and around internal organs. Their primary function is to store excess energy in the form of triglycerides, which are released into the bloodstream as needed to provide energy to other cells in the body. 

White fat cells contain a single, large lipid droplet that occupies most of the cytoplasmic volume. As adipocytes mature, they develop a network of blood vessels and nerves that supply the cells with nutrients and help regulate their activity. In addition to storing triglycerides, white fat cells also secrete hormones and other signaling molecules that help regulate metabolism and energy balance. Some of these hormones, such as leptin, signal the brain to decrease appetite and increase energy expenditure, while others, such as adiponectin, help regulate glucose uptake and insulin sensitivity in other tissues.

White fat cells play a crucial role in maintaining energy balance in the body, and their dysfunction has been linked to a variety of metabolic disorders, including obesity, type 2 diabetes, and cardiovascular disease. While these cells are traditionally considered to be passive energy storage units, research has shown that they are complex and dynamic cells that play an active role in regulating energy homeostasis and responding to changes in environmental and physiological cues. Understanding the function of white fat cells, and the mechanisms that regulate their activity, may provide new insights into the prevention and treatment of metabolic diseases.
CL:0000423:
Tip cells, also known as leading cells, are a specialized type of endothelial cell found in the growing vasculature of developing tissues or tumors. These cells are responsible for guiding and leading new capillary sprouts as they branch and extend during angiogenesis. Tip cells lead the sprout by extending filopodia, which are thin extensions of the cell membrane containing actin filaments, to sense and respond to guidance cues from the surrounding environment. 

Tip cells express a distinct set of genes that facilitate their specialized functions. For example, they express high levels of transmembrane receptors such as VEGFR2 and Notch1, which bind and respond to growth factors and guidance cues, and proteases such as urokinase-type plasminogen activator, which are involved in extracellular matrix remodeling during angiogenesis. Additionally, tip cells exhibit a highly polarized morphology with an actin- and microtubule-rich cytoskeleton that enables them to rapidly and dynamically extend and retract filopodia in response to environmental signals.

Overall, tip cells play a crucial role in the regulation of vascular development and can be potential targets for the development of anti-angiogenic therapies for cancer treatment. Understanding the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying tip cell function is critical for the development of novel therapies aimed at modulating angiogenesis.
CL:0011020:
Neural progenitor cells (NPCs), also known as neural stem cells, are a type of self-renewing and multipotent cells that give rise to the majority of neurons and glia cells in the central nervous system during development. NPCs are found primarily in the ventricular zone lining the brain ventricles and the subventricular zone near the lateral ventricles. These cells have the ability to divide symmetrically or asymmetrically, generating either two identical daughter cells or two distinct daughter cells with different fates, respectively. 
        
During embryonic development, NPCs actively divide and differentiate into neurons and glia under the influence of various growth factors and signaling molecules. As neurogenesis progresses, NPCs become increasingly restricted in their differentiation potential, ultimately producing specific types of neurons and glia that populate the specific region of the nervous system. In the adult brain, NPCs remain dormant but can be reactivated under certain conditions to provide new neurons and glia for repair and maintenance of neural tissue.
        
NPCs play a crucial role in the development and repair of the nervous system. Defects in NPC proliferation and differentiation have been implicated in numerous neurological disorders, including Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease, and multiple sclerosis. Understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying NPC regulation and differentiation is essential for developing future regenerative therapies and treatments for these disorders.
CL:0000479:
Vasopressin stimulating hormone secreting cells, also known as corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) cells, are a type of neuroendocrine cell found in the hypothalamus of the brain. These cells are responsible for secreting the hormone CRH, which plays a crucial role in the regulation of the body's response to stress.

When activated by stress, CRH cells release CRH into the pituitary gland, which triggers the release of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) into the bloodstream. ACTH then stimulates the release of cortisol from the adrenal gland, which helps the body to cope with stress by increasing blood sugar levels, decreasing inflammation, and altering immune system function.

In addition to their role in stress response, CRH cells also play a role in the regulation of other physiological processes, including immune function, appetite, and mood. Dysregulation of CRH signaling has been linked to various psychiatric disorders, including depression, anxiety, and post-traumatic stress disorder. Studying vasopressin stimulating hormone secreting cells is crucial for understanding the complex mechanisms of stress response and the development of effective treatments for stress-related disorders.
CL:0000990:
Conventional dendritic cells (cDCs) are a type of immune cell that are specialized in initiating adaptive immune responses against foreign antigens.
