Strategies that reduce the formation of foam cells or enhance their clearance from the arterial wall are under investigation for the treatment and prevention of atherosclerosis.
CL:0000513:
Cardiac muscle myoblasts are specialized precursor cells that give rise to cardiac myocytes, which are responsible for the contractile force of the heart. These cells play an essential role in cardiac development and growth, as well as in the repair and regeneration of damaged heart tissue throughout the lifespan of an organism. As such, cardiac muscle myoblasts have attracted significant attention as a potential therapeutic target for heart disease and injury.

Upon differentiation into cardiac myocytes, cardiac muscle myoblasts exhibit a unique morphology and physiology that are optimized for efficient and coordinated contraction. These cells express a range of contractile proteins, including myosin, actin, and tropomyosin, that are organized into specialized sarcomeres within the cell. Additionally, cardiac muscle myoblasts are electrically coupled to one another via gap junctions, allowing for the rapid spread of electrical signals throughout the heart and coordinated contraction of the myocardium.

Emerging evidence suggests that cardiac muscle myoblasts may also play a role in the modulation of cardiac function in response to stress. Under conditions of ischemic injury or chronic hypoxia, for example, these cells have been shown to upregulate the expression of pro-survival and pro-angiogenic factors, such as VEGF and HGF, that promote tissue regeneration and vascularization. This suggests that cardiac muscle myoblasts have the potential to be harnessed as a therapeutic target for promoting heart health and repair.
CL:0000492:
CD4-positive helper T cells, also known as CD4+ T cells, are a specialized type of lymphocyte that play a critical role in the immune system. These cells are named for the presence of the CD4 protein on their surface, which allows them to interact with other cells of the immune system. Helper T cells are particularly important in the adaptive immune response, which is the body's targeted response to specific pathogens.

When a foreign pathogen enters the body, it is recognized by various immune cells which trigger an immune response. CD4+ T cells are activated by the presence of antigens on the surface of the pathogen, after which they undergo clonal expansion, producing many identical cells. These activated cells then migrate to the site of the infection where they release cytokines that activate other immune cells, such as cytotoxic T cells and B cells.

Helper T cells function mainly by secreting cytokines which help regulate the immune response, including the activation of other immune cells and the production of antibodies. Without CD4+ T cells, the immune system would not be able to effectively fight off pathogens, and the body would be much more vulnerable to infection. However, overactive helper T cells can also cause autoimmune diseases, such as rheumatoid arthritis or multiple sclerosis, where the immune system attacks the body's own tissues. Overall, CD4-positive helper T cells play an important role in the immune system by coordinating and regulating the response to foreign pathogens.
CL:0000534:
Primary interneurons are a type of neuron found in the central nervous system (CNS) that connect other neurons and modulate neural activity. They are critical components of neural circuits and play a vital role in information processing and integration. Primary interneurons are named as such because they are the first interneurons encountered by incoming sensory neurons as they enter the CNS.

Primary interneurons have many distinct features that separate them from other cell types. They typically have a small, round cell body with very short dendrites that receive input from other neurons. This input is then transmitted through a single, long axon that extends to other neurons in the circuit. Primary interneurons can release many different neurotransmitters, including glutamate and GABA, which allow them to excite or inhibit neural activity as needed.

One of the key functions of primary interneurons is to help process sensory information in the CNS. As incoming sensory neurons enter the CNS, they synapse onto primary interneurons, which then transmit this information to other neurons in the circuit. This information can be modulated by the primary interneuron, either by exciting or inhibiting the downstream neurons, depending on the nature and strength of the input received. This modulation is thought to be critical for many cognitive processes, including attention, perception, and memory.
CL:0000516:
Perineuronal satellite cells, also known as satellite glial cells or satellite cells, are specialized support cells found in close association with neurons in various areas of the nervous system, including the sensory ganglia and the optic nerve. These cells are morphologically and functionally distinct from the Schwann cells that wrap around axons in the peripheral nervous system and from the astrocytes that surround neurons in the central nervous system. Perineuronal satellite cells maintain a structural and physiological relationship with the neurons they ensheath, contributing to their survival and function.

Perineuronal satellite cells are known to modulate the microenvironment surrounding neurons, thereby controlling the access of nutrients and other essential molecules to the neurons they surround. Under normal conditions, these cells maintain a close communication with the neurons they ensheath, exchanging signals that help to sculpt the architecture and function of the nervous system. Dysfunction or pathological changes in perineuronal satellite cells have been implicated in a number of neurological disorders, including chronic pain, neuropathy, and neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease.

Research on perineuronal satellite cells is still in its early stages, and more work is needed to fully understand the precise roles that these cells play in the functioning of the nervous system. Nonetheless, it is clear that these cells are critical for the maintenance of neural circuitry and the processing of sensory information, highlighting the importance of understanding the complex interplay between neurons and their associated support cells.
CL:0005002:
Xanthoblasts are immature granulocytes of the blood that belong to the myeloid lineage. They are characterized by their pale yellow color due to the presence of granules that contain lysosomal enzymes and acid phosphatase. Xanthoblasts are typically larger than lymphocytes but smaller than mature granulocytes. They are derived from myeloid stem cells in the bone marrow and differentiate into basophils, eosinophils, or neutrophils.

The function of xanthoblasts is to contribute to the innate immune response by phagocytosing and destroying foreign particles such as bacteria and fungi. They also play a role in the inflammatory response by releasing cytokines, which recruit other immune cells to the site of infection or injury. Xanthoblasts are involved in the process of leukocytosis, where the body increases the number of white blood cells in response to infection or inflammation.

In certain diseases such as leukemia, xanthoblasts may be present in abnormally high numbers in the blood. This can lead to a compromised immune system due to an imbalance of different types of white blood cells. Understanding the function and characteristics of xanthoblasts is important in diagnosing and treating blood-related disorders.
CL:0000559:
Promonocytes are a type of white blood cell that originate in the bone marrow and differentiate into mature monocytic cells. They are typically larger than lymphocytes and have a distinctive kidney-shaped nucleus. Promonocytes can circulate in the blood stream for several days before maturing into monocytes that migrate to specific tissues and organs.

The function of promonocytes is to serve as precursor cells for monocytes, which are an important part of the immune system. Monocytes are involved in the process of phagocytosis, which occurs when invading pathogens are engulfed by the cell and destroyed. Monocytes can also produce cytokines, which help to regulate the immune response. 

Deficiencies or abnormalities in promonocytes can lead to various diseases, such as infections, autoimmune disorders, and blood cancers. For example, leukemia is a type of cancer that can result from the uncontrolled growth and accumulation of promonocytes, which can interfere with normal blood cell production and lead to a compromised immune system.
CL:0000545:
T-helper 1 (Th1) cells are a subtype of T-helper cells that play a crucial role in the immune response by helping activate other immune cells, including CD8+ T cells, B cells, and macrophages. They are primarily involved in mediating cell-mediated immunity against intracellular pathogens, such as viruses, bacteria, and parasites.

Th1 cells are activated by antigen-presenting cells (APCs), such as dendritic cells and macrophages, when the cells present antigens to them. Once activated, Th1 cells produce and secrete cytokines, which activate other immune cells involved in the immune response. These cytokines include interferon-gamma (IFN-γ), interleukin-2 (IL-2), and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α).

Th1 cells are essential in clearing intracellular pathogens by promoting the activation of phagocytes, including macrophages and neutrophils, which can engulf and destroy infected cells. Additionally, Th1 cells are involved in stimulating the production of opsonizing antibodies by B cells, which can aid in the clearance of extracellular pathogens.

Overall, Th1 cells play a vital role in mediating cell-mediated immunity against intracellular pathogens and aiding in the activation of other immune cells involved in the immune response.
CL:0000536:
A secondary motor neuron, also known as a gamma motor neuron, is a type of neuron that plays a crucial role in motor control. These neurons are located in the ventral horn of the spinal cord and have a smaller diameter than alpha motor neurons, which are another type of motor neuron. Secondary motor neurons innervate intrafusal muscle fibers within muscle spindles, which are sensory receptors that detect changes in muscle length and transmit this information to the brain.

The function of secondary motor neurons is to adjust the sensitivity of muscle spindles to changes in muscle length, which in turn helps to regulate muscle tone and maintain proper muscle function. When secondary motor neurons are activated, they cause the intrafusal muscle fibers within muscle spindles to contract, which stretches the sensory nerve endings attached to them. This results in an increase in the firing rate of sensory neurons, which sends a signal to the brain indicating that the muscle is being stretched.

Secondary motor neurons are essential for fine motor control and are involved in various activities such as maintaining posture, controlling limb movements, and adjusting muscle tone. Dysfunction of these neurons can lead to a variety of motor disorders, including muscle spasticity and hyperreflexia. Therefore, understanding the function and properties of secondary motor neurons is vital for improving our knowledge of motor control and developing treatments for motor-related disorders.
CL:0000547:
Proerythroblasts are the earliest identifiable precursors of red blood cells and belong to the erythrocyte lineage. These cells are characterized by their large size and their nuclei that can exhibit one or two nucleoli. Proerythroblasts arise from hematopoietic stem cells in the bone marrow and give rise to erythroblasts, which subsequently mature into reticulocytes and then into erythrocytes.

The function of proerythroblasts is to differentiate into erythroblasts and finally into red blood cells. During this process, the cells undergo extensive changes in morphology, gene expression, and metabolic activity. Proerythroblasts are distinguished from other hematopoietic stem cell lineages by their specific expression of transcription factors such as GATA-1 and GATA-2, which promote the development of red blood cells.

Proerythroblasts are also characterized by their association with erythropoietin, a hormone that stimulates the development and differentiation of red blood cells. Erythropoietin is produced by the kidneys in response to hypoxia, which drives the production of red blood cells to increase oxygen delivery to tissues throughout the body. The accurate classification of proerythroblasts is important for understanding the process of erythropoiesis and for the diagnosis and treatment of diseases such as anemia and leukemia.
CL:0000507:
Endorphin secreting cells are specialized cells found predominantly in the hypothalamus and pituitary gland. These cells are known to synthesize and secrete a group of polypeptides called endorphins, which are chemical messengers that help regulate pain and produce a feeling of well-being. As such, endorphin secreting cells play a critical role in the body's response to stress, pain, and addiction.

Endorphins are a type of neuropeptides that bind to specific receptors in the body to produce an analgesic effect. These peptides are synthesized from large precursor proteins known as proopiomelanocortin (POMC), which is a gene expressed in the hypothalamus and other regions of the brain. Endorphin secreting cells differentiate from POMC-expressing cells and secrete endorphins in response to various stimuli. The release of endorphin is regulated by neurotransmitters such as dopamine and norepinephrine, and is known to be involved in the reward pathway, thus playing a crucial role in modulating mood, pain, and addiction.

In summary, endorphin secreting cells are a vital component of the body's response to pain, stress, and addiction. These cells synthesize and secrete endorphins, a group of neuropeptides that bind to specific receptors to produce an analgesic effect and a feeling of well-being. Endorphin secreting cells are regulated by various neurotransmitters and play a vital role in maintaining homeostasis in the body.
CL:0000544:
Slowly adapting mechanoreceptor cells are specialized cells that are responsible for detecting changes in pressure and vibrations of low frequencies in their surrounding environment. These cells are found in various locations throughout the body, such as the skin, tendons, joints, and internal organs. They are involved in a wide range of functions, including touch sensation, proprioception (the sense of body position and movement), and blood pressure regulation.

The slowly adapting mechanoreceptor cells are highly sensitive to changes in pressure and are capable of detecting very subtle variations in their environment. They consist of a specialized structure called a Merkel cell, which is closely associated with a nerve ending. When the Merkel cell is deformed by a change in pressure, it triggers the nerve ending to send signals to the brain, which then interprets the sensation as touch or pressure.

One important aspect of the function of slowly adapting mechanoreceptor cells is their ability to provide feedback to the body about its position and movement. This is particularly important for activities like walking, running, and other physical activities that involve complex movements of the limbs and body. By providing continuous feedback to the nervous system about the position and movement of the body, these cells help to maintain balance and coordination, and prevent injury. In addition to their role in touch and proprioception, slowly adapting mechanoreceptor cells are also involved in blood pressure regulation, by detecting changes in pressure within blood vessels and signaling the nervous system to adjust blood flow accordingly.
CL:0000565:
The fat body cell is a type of insect cell that acts as a metabolic organ, playing a vital role in regulating energy homeostasis and lipid storage. These cells are large and filled with lipid droplets, which are used to store energy from food and provide fuel for the insect during times of low food availability. They are found in the hemocoel, the insect equivalent of the circulatory system.

Fat body cells have a variety of functions beyond energy storage, including the synthesis and secretion of hormones, immune function, and detoxification of harmful compounds. They also play a key role in the regulation of insect growth and development, with factors produced by the fat body influencing key developmental transitions such as molting.

Understanding the function of fat body cells is important in the context of insect biology, and may have implications for controlling insect pests and preventing the spread of insect-borne diseases. Further research on the mechanisms underlying the regulation of fat body cell function could also have broader implications for our understanding of metabolic homeostasis and energy balance in other organisms.
CL:0000765:
Erythroblasts are a type of precursor cell that develops into red blood cells. They are found in the bone marrow and are crucial for the production of healthy red blood cells. Erythroblasts are large in size and have a characteristic appearance with a round nucleus and a cytoplasm that is rich in hemoglobin. 

During differentiation, erythroblasts undergo a series of changes that transform them into mature red blood cells. Initially, erythroblasts make large amounts of hemoglobin, which is a protein that carries oxygen throughout the body. As they mature, they condense their nuclei and expel other organelles to make room for the hemoglobin-filled cytoplasm. Eventually, they lose their nuclei altogether and become fully mature red blood cells that are released into circulation. 

Defects in erythroblast differentiation can lead to a variety of hematological disorders, including anemias. Anemia is a condition in which there are not enough red blood cells to transport oxygen to the body's tissues, which can lead to fatigue, shortness of breath, and other symptoms. Understanding the molecular mechanisms that control erythroblast differentiation may lead to the development of new therapies for anemia and other blood disorders.
CL:0000510:
Paneth cells are a type of specialized epithelial cell located in the small intestine, at the base of the crypts of Lieberkühn. These cells are named after the Austrian physiologist Joseph Paneth, who first described them over a century ago. Paneth cells play a critical role in protecting the gut against bacterial infections by secreting antimicrobial peptides, such as defensins and lysozyme. These peptides function by disrupting the bacterial cell membranes or cell walls, leading to cell death. Therefore, Paneth cells are an essential component of the innate immune system in the gut.

In addition to their antimicrobial function, Paneth cells also secrete growth factors that regulate intestinal stem cell proliferation and differentiation. This function is critical in maintaining the integrity of the intestinal epithelium and promoting intestinal tissue repair after injury or inflammation. Moreover, recent studies have suggested that Paneth cells play a role in regulating the gut microbiota by modulating the composition of the microbial communities that inhabit the gut. These findings have opened up new avenues to better understand the complex interactions between the gut microbiota, immune system, and intestinal epithelium.

Overall, Paneth cells are a unique cell type in the small intestine that play essential roles in protecting the gut against microbial infections, promoting tissue repair after injury, and regulating the gut microbiota. Dysfunction of Paneth cells has been associated with various intestinal disorders, such as inflammatory bowel disease and infectious enteritis. Therefore, further studies of Paneth cells may reveal novel insights into the pathogenesis and treatment of these diseases.
CL:0000529:
Pigmented epithelial cells are a specialized type of cell found in the retina of the eye. They are also known as retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) cells. These cells are responsible for several different functions, including the absorption of excess light, the phagocytosis of photoreceptor outer segments, and the maintenance of the blood-retinal barrier. 

One of the primary functions of pigmented epithelial cells is the absorption of excess light in the retina. This is important because the high levels of light in the retina can cause damage to the photoreceptor cells that are responsible for vision. Pigmented epithelial cells contain pigments such as melanin that absorb excess light and protect the photoreceptor cells from damage.

Another important function of pigmented epithelial cells is the phagocytosis of photoreceptor outer segments. Photoreceptor cells in the retina have a high turnover rate, and their outer segments need to be regularly replaced. Pigmented epithelial cells are responsible for phagocytosing, or engulfing and digesting, the old outer segments of photoreceptor cells. This process is essential for maintaining a healthy retina and proper vision.

Finally, pigmented epithelial cells play a critical role in maintaining the blood-retinal barrier, which is essential for protecting the retina from harmful substances in the bloodstream. These cells form tight junctions between each other that prevent substances from the bloodstream from entering the retina. This is important because the retina is a delicate structure that is sensitive to damage.
CL:0000530:
A primary neuron, also known as a projection neuron or a pyramidal neuron, is a type of neuron that is the principal cell type in the cerebral cortex, hippocampus, and amygdala in vertebrates. These cells are responsible for the majority of information processing and communication within the central nervous system. Primary neurons have a large, pyramidal-shaped cell body with many branching dendrites, which receive signals from other neurons, and a single elongated axon, which transmits signals to other neurons either within the same or different regions of the brain.

Primary neurons have varying functions depending on the region of the brain in which they are located. In the cerebral cortex, these neurons are responsible for integrating sensory information and initiating motor actions. The hippocampus, on the other hand, is critical for learning and memory. Primary neurons in the hippocampus play a crucial role in forming new memories and retaining existing ones. In the amygdala, primary neurons are involved in the processing of emotions, notably fear and anxiety.

Overall, primary neurons play a critical role in the functioning of the nervous system and are essential for the proper cognitive and emotional processing in animals and humans. Dysfunctional primary neurons have been implicated in a variety of neurological disorders, including Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease, and schizophrenia, highlighting their importance in understanding these conditions and developing effective therapies.
CL:0000553:
Megakaryocyte progenitor cells are a type of hematopoietic stem cell that give rise to megakaryocytes (MKs), the largest cells in the bone marrow. MKs are responsible for producing platelets, which are crucial for blood clotting and wound healing. Therefore, megakaryocyte progenitor cells play an essential role in maintaining the body’s normal hemostasis and preventing excessive bleeding or thrombosis. 

Megakaryocyte progenitor cells are found in the bone marrow, where they undergo a series of steps to become mature megakaryocytes that release platelets into the circulation. These steps involve changes in the cell's size and morphology, as well as the expression of specific genes that control platelet production. The process of platelet release is highly regulated and requires the coordinated actions of several signaling pathways that involve interactions with other cell types, such as endothelial cells and immune cells. 

Dysfunction of megakaryocyte progenitor cells can lead to several blood disorders, such as thrombocytopenia (low platelet count), myeloproliferative disorders (excessive platelet production), and leukemia. Therefore, understanding the molecular and cellular mechanisms that govern megakaryocyte progenitor cells' development and function is of great importance in the field of hematology, and may lead to the development of novel therapies for these disorders.
CL:0000552:
Orthochromatic erythroblasts are cells that are derived from a proerythroblast and pass through several stages of differentiation in the course of erythropoiesis. These cells are located in the bone marrow and are characterized by their small size and their dense and condensed chromatin. During the final stages of erythropoiesis, these cells lose their nuclei, cell organelles, and other metabolic activities, leading to the formation of mature red blood cells. 

The function of orthochromatic erythroblasts is to produce red blood cells, or erythrocytes, which are responsible for carrying oxygen from the lungs to different parts of the body. The differentiation of these cells involves the synthesis of a large number of hemoglobin molecules, which are responsible for the red color of the cells and their capacity to bind and transport oxygen. The regulation of erythropoiesis is largely controlled by the hormone erythropoietin, which is produced in the kidneys and stimulates the production of erythrocytes in the bone marrow. 

Orthochromatic erythroblasts are a critical component of the erythropoietic pathway, and abnormalities in erythropoiesis can lead to a variety of blood disorders, such as anemia, polycythemia vera, and sickle cell disease. Understanding the mechanisms by which these cells differentiate and produce red blood cells is therefore of great importance for both basic research and clinical practice.
CL:0000582:
A neutrophilic metamyelocyte is a type of white blood cell that is produced in the bone marrow and helps to fight infection in the body. It is an immature form of a neutrophil, which is a type of granulocyte that is responsible for fighting bacterial infections. This cell type is characterized by its distinct shape, with an elongated nucleus that is often horseshoe-shaped or bent.

The function of a neutrophilic metamyelocyte is to differentiate into a mature neutrophil that can respond to and eliminate bacterial infections. To do this, it undergoes a series of changes as it matures, including acquiring the ability to move through the bloodstream to sites of infection. Once it reaches an infected area, the neutrophilic metamyelocyte is able to phagocytize, or engulf, bacteria and other harmful substances, effectively neutralizing and destroying them.

Overall, the neutrophilic metamyelocyte plays an important role in the body's immune response to bacterial infections. By producing and differentiating into mature neutrophils, it helps to ensure that the body is able to effectively fight off potentially harmful pathogens and maintain overall health and wellness.
CL:0000546:
T-helper 2 cells, also known as Th2 cells, are a type of T helper cell that play a critical role in the immune system's response to extracellular pathogens. These cells are primarily involved in promoting and regulating humoral immunity, which involves the production of antibodies by B cells. Th2 cells also play a role in allergic responses and can contribute to the development of allergic diseases.

The primary function of Th2 cells is to stimulate the production of IgE antibodies by B cells in response to extracellular parasites, such as helminths. Th2 cells produce cytokines, including interleukin-4 (IL-4), IL-5, and IL-13, which promote the differentiation and activation of B cells, as well as the recruitment and activation of eosinophils and basophils. In addition, Th2 cells produce chemokines that attract other cells of the immune system, such as macrophages and dendritic cells, to the site of infection.

Th2 cells also play a role in allergic responses and the development of allergic diseases, such as asthma and allergic rhinitis. In individuals with allergies, Th2 cells activate and promote the activation of other immune cells, such as mast cells and eosinophils, which release inflammatory mediators that lead to the typical symptoms of allergies, such as itching, sneezing, and wheezing. While Th2 cells are important for the immune response to parasites and other extracellular pathogens, their dysregulation can lead to chronic inflammation and the development of autoimmune and allergic diseases.
CL:0001012:
CD7-negative lymphoid progenitor, also known as granulocyte monocyte progenitor (GMP), is a type of multipotent hematopoietic stem cell that gives rise to a variety of blood cells, including granulocytes, monocytes, and dendritic cells. These cells play critical roles in the innate immune response and are involved in inflammation and tissue repair.

GMPs are typically found in the bone marrow and differentiate into granulocyte and monocyte precursors, which then mature into the various types of blood cells. The differentiation and maturation of GMPs is tightly regulated by a network of transcription factors and signaling pathways, including the cytokines IL-3, IL-6, and GM-CSF.

Granulocytes, including neutrophils, eosinophils, and basophils, are important for fighting infections and are involved in allergic reactions. Monocytes differentiate into macrophages and dendritic cells, which play key roles in phagocytosis and antigen presentation, respectively. Together, these cells are essential for the proper functioning of the immune system and maintaining overall health.
CL:0000891:
Foam cells are a type of cell that is formed when macrophages engulf and accumulate an excessive amount of lipid droplets, mostly cholesterol, thereby transforming into lipid-laden cells. These cells possess a foamy appearance, hence referred to as foam cells. Foam cells play a crucial role in the development of atherosclerosis, an inflammatory disorder characterized by the buildup of fatty deposits, or plaques, within the arterial walls. When the foam cells accumulate within the atherosclerotic plaques, they contribute to the formation of the complex lesions that are characteristic of this disease. 

Foam cells are also formed as a result of several other pathological conditions, including tuberculosis and other chronic inflammatory diseases. These cells play a critical role in the immune response, as they are responsible for eradicating microbial pathogens and other debris from the site of infection or tissue damage. However, excessive foam cell formation leads to the development of several human disorders, including atherosclerosis, foam cell-associated dermatosis, and other metabolic disorders.

Despite the growing knowledge regarding the cellular and molecular mechanisms that drive foam cell formation, more in-depth studies are necessary to unambiguously understand the underlying pathophysiological processes that contribute to the formation of these cells. As such, the identification and characterization of novel genes, signaling pathways, and metabolic enzymes that are critical for the formation of foam cells provide an exciting area of research for scientists and clinicians. Such knowledge will likely lead to new therapeutic interventions that directly target the formation of foam cells, leading to the development of effective treatments for the associated pathological conditions.
CL:0000554:
Gastrin-stimulating hormone-secreting cells, also known as G-cells, are a type of endocrine cell primarily found in the stomach lining. These specialized cells are responsible for secreting the hormone gastrin, which plays a key role in regulating the production of gastric acid and the motility of the gastrointestinal tract. G-cells are particularly sensitive to certain types of food, such as proteins and caffeine, and are activated in response to the presence of these substances.

Gastrin is a peptide hormone that binds to specific receptors on the parietal cells of the stomach, promoting acid secretion and regulating the growth and differentiation of these cells. Gastrin also plays a role in controlling the release of digestive enzymes from the pancreas and stimulating the contraction of the lower esophageal sphincter. In addition to its role in digestion, gastrin has been implicated in a variety of other physiological processes, including wound healing, neuroprotection, and immune function.

Dysfunction of gastrin-secreting cells can lead to a range of gastrointestinal disorders, including gastritis, peptic ulcers, and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Treatments for these conditions often involve medications that target gastric acid secretion, such as proton pump inhibitors or histamine receptor antagonists. Research into the role of gastrin and G-cells in various pathologies is ongoing, with the hope of developing more targeted therapies for these disorders.
CL:0000560:
Band form neutrophils, also known as immature neutrophils, are a type of white blood cell that play a critical role in the body's immune system. These cells are part of the innate immune response and are among the first to arrive at the site of an infection. They are characterized by their band shape, which resembles a curved rod with a slightly curved nucleus.

The primary function of band form neutrophils is to defend the body against bacterial and fungal infections. When an infection is detected, these cells are quickly recruited to the site of infection where they release antimicrobial granules and enzymes to kill invading pathogens. They are also capable of phagocytosis, which means they can engulf and destroy harmful bacteria and fungi.

Like other types of white blood cells, band form neutrophils are produced in the bone marrow. They are released into the bloodstream where they circulate for several hours before being recruited to the site of an infection. The presence of a high number of band form neutrophils in the blood can be an indicator of an active bacterial infection, making them an important diagnostic marker for certain types of infections. Overall, band form neutrophils play a vital role in the body's immune defense against infection.
CL:0000570:
Parafollicular cells (also known as C cells) are specialized neuroendocrine cells found in the thyroid gland. They are named for their location in the thyroid gland, situated in between or adjacent to thyroid follicles. Parafollicular cells play a key role in regulating calcium levels in the body by secreting calcitonin, a hormone that helps lower blood calcium levels. The low calcium levels promote bone formation and decrease bone resorption. 

In addition to playing a critical role in calcium homeostasis, parafollicular cells also have potential roles in modulating other physiological processes such as cell proliferation, differentiation, and development. Studies suggest that the calcitonin produced by parafollicular cells may exert a chondroprotective effect by reducing cartilage degradation and arthritis. 

Parafollicular cells can be identified easily in histological sections by their unique characteristics, including their location in the thyroid gland, morphology, and immunohistochemical markers. The distinct properties of parafollicular cells make them a subject of extensive research, which can help us gain a deeper understanding of their function and potential therapeutic applications.
CL:0000555:
Neuronal brush cells are a rare type of chemosensory receptor found in the respiratory and digestive tract, including the nasal respiratory epithelium, lung, gallbladder, and small intestine. They are named for the characteristic microvilli that protrude from their apical surface, forming a brush-like structure, which is responsible for their sensory function. They have been shown to express several types of taste receptors and other chemosensory receptors, such as bitter taste receptors, and are involved in the detection and regulation of luminal contents, including bacteria, toxins, and nutrients.

In addition to their chemosensory function, neuronal brush cells have been implicated in several other physiological processes. Recent studies have shown that they play a role in the regulation of intestinal motility and secretion, as well as in the development and maintenance of the intestinal epithelium. They have also been implicated in the immune response to bacterial and viral infections, suggesting a potential role in host defense. Further research on neuronal brush cells may provide insight into the pathophysiology of digestive and respiratory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease and asthma.

Despite their potential significance, neuronal brush cells remain poorly understood, with many aspects of their function and regulation yet to be elucidated. Nevertheless, their unique morphology and chemosensory capabilities make them a fascinating cell type with the potential to shed light on a diverse range of biological processes.
CL:0001051:
CD4-positive, CXCR3-negative, CCR6-negative, alpha-beta T cells are a type of T lymphocyte that play a critical role in immune surveillance and response. These cells express the CD4 glycoprotein that helps in their activation by interacting with the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class II molecules on antigen-presenting cells (APCs). The absence of the chemokine receptors CXCR3 and CCR6 suggests that these cells do not home to sites of inflammation or mucosal tissues, but instead, circulate in the blood and secondary lymphoid organs.

Upon activation, CD4-positive, CXCR3-negative, CCR6-negative, alpha-beta T cells differentiate into effector cells that secrete cytokines to modulate the immune response. These cells have been shown to produce interleukin-2 (IL-2), interferon-gamma (IFN-gamma), and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha), which play a crucial role in mediating cellular immunity against pathogens, tumors, and autoimmunity. Additionally, CD4-positive, CXCR3-negative, CCR6-negative, alpha-beta T cells can differentiate into T helper (Th) cells that help in the activation of other immune cells, such as B cells and cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs).

In summary, CD4-positive, CXCR3-negative, CCR6-negative, alpha-beta T cells are a subset of T lymphocytes that orchestrate immune responses by secreting cytokines and differentiating into effector and helper cells. These cells are critical in providing protection against infectious diseases and tumors and are an essential component of the adaptive immune system.
CL:0000561:
Amacrine cells are retinal interneurons found in the inner nuclear layer. They play a crucial role in processing visual information by integrating signals from bipolar cells and transmitting them to ganglion cells. These cells are a diverse group and can be divided into several subtypes based on their morphological, electrophysiological, and neurochemical properties. The extensive dendritic arborization of amacrine cells allows them to interact with multiple bipolar cells and ganglion cells, enhancing their function in the visual system.

In addition to their role in visual processing, amacrine cells are also involved in modulating the activity of other retinal neurons. They can release various neurotransmitters such as GABA, glycine, dopamine, and acetylcholine, which can either depolarize or hyperpolarize their target cells. This modulation allows for fine-tuning of signal processing and adjustment in response to changing environmental conditions, such as increased or decreased light intensity.

Furthermore, amacrine cells have been implicated in retinal diseases such as glaucoma and diabetic retinopathy. Dysfunction of these cells can lead to altered visual processing and contribute to the development and progression of these diseases. The study of amacrine cells and their function is an active area of research, and new insights into their roles in visual processing and retinal disease are constantly being discovered.
CL:2000060:
Placental villous trophoblasts are specialized cells that make up the outermost layer of the human placenta. These cells are responsible for establishing a connection between the maternal blood supply and the developing fetus. Trophoblasts have a unique ability to invade the maternal uterine wall and remodel the maternal blood vessels to nourish the growing fetus. During the process of invasion, trophoblasts come into contact with many maternal immune cells, which they must evade to prevent rejection of the fetus.

Placental villous trophoblasts are a heterogeneous population of cells that undergo differentiation into various subtypes during pregnancy. The two main subtypes of trophoblasts are syncytiotrophoblasts and cytotrophoblasts. Syncytiotrophoblasts, which are multinucleated cells that form a continuous layer on the surface of the placental villi, are responsible for the exchange of nutrients, gases and waste products between the maternal and fetal circulations. Cytotrophoblasts differentiate into invasive subtypes that are responsible for breaking down and remodeling the maternal uterine wall to form spaces called "lacunae" which fill with maternal blood and provide a rich source of nutrients for the developing fetus.

In conclusion, placental villous trophoblasts play a crucial role in establishing and maintaining a healthy pregnancy. The ability of trophoblasts to evade maternal immune recognition and establish a connection between the maternal and fetal circulations is essential for proper development of the fetus and subsequent pregnancy outcomes. The cellular and molecular mechanisms involved in the differentiation and function of these cells are of great interest in efforts to improve pregnancy outcomes and develop therapies for pregnancy-related disorders.
CL:0000551:
Unimodal nociceptors, also known as Type 1 nociceptors, are specialized sensory neurons that detect harmful or potentially harmful stimuli, also known as noxious stimuli. These stimuli include extremes of temperature, mechanical pressure, and exposure to harmful chemicals. This type of nociceptor is unimodal as it responds to only one type of stimulus, unlike polymodal nociceptors that can respond to a wide variety of noxious stimuli.

Unimodal nociceptors are found in various tissues such as the skin, muscles, and joints, and their main function is to alert the body of noxious stimuli that may cause tissue damage. These cells have specialized nerve endings called free nerve endings that detect and transduce noxious stimuli into electrical signals, which are then transmitted to the central nervous system to initiate the perception of pain. Unimodal nociceptors are also responsible for the withdrawal reflex, which is an involuntary movement to protect the body from the noxious stimulus.

Furthermore, unimodal nociceptors are involved in the development of chronic pain. Upon tissue damage, these cells undergo a process called sensitization, which causes them to become more responsive to noxious stimuli and produce a heightened perception of pain. This often results in the development of persistent pain long after the tissue damage has healed, which can severely affect the quality of life of affected individuals. Understanding the function and molecular mechanisms underlying the activation and sensitization of unimodal nociceptors is crucial for the development of effective pain management strategies.
CL:0000557:
Granulocyte monocyte progenitor (GMP) cells are a type of hematopoietic stem cell found in the bone marrow that give rise to both granulocytes and monocytes. These cells play a critical role in innate immunity, as granulocytes and monocytes are vital components of the body's defense against infection and inflammation. Granulocytes include neutrophils, eosinophils, and basophils, while monocytes differentiate into macrophages and dendritic cells. 

The differentiation of GMP cells into granulocytes and monocytes is tightly regulated by a number of signaling pathways and transcription factors. For example, the myeloid differentiation factor 88 (MyD88) signaling pathway is essential for the differentiation of GMP cells into monocytes, while CCAAT/enhancer-binding protein alpha (C/EBPalpha) is critical for the differentiation of GMP cells into neutrophils. Dysregulation of these pathways can lead to aberrant differentiation and the development of hematologic malignancies such as leukemia and myelodysplastic syndromes.

Research on GMP cells has shed light on the mechanisms that govern the balance between innate immunity and hematopoiesis in the bone marrow, as well as the pathophysiology of hematologic malignancies. By understanding the role of GMP cells in the immune system and the signaling pathways that control their differentiation, researchers may be able to develop new therapies for infections, inflammation, and hematologic malignancies.
CL:0002421:
A nucleated reticulocyte is an immature red blood cell that is formed in the bone marrow before being released into the blood stream. These cells are characterized by a network of residual ribosomal RNA that is still being synthesized and scattered organelles within the cytoplasm, giving them their unique reticulated appearance. Unlike mature red blood cells, nucleated reticulocytes have a nucleus, which is eventually lost as they mature.

The primary function of nucleated reticulocytes is to transport oxygen from the lungs to the tissues throughout the body. However, due to their immature state, they are not as effective at doing so as mature red blood cells. As a result, nucleated reticulocytes are usually only found in small quantities in the bloodstream.

In certain pathological conditions, such as anemia or hemolytic disease, the body may increase its production and release of nucleated reticulocytes into the bloodstream as a compensatory mechanism. Increased levels of nucleated reticulocytes can also indicate bone marrow dysfunction or injury. Thus, their presence or absence in blood tests can serve as important diagnostic markers for various disease states.
CL:0000532:
Cap motoneurons are a specific type of motor neuron that are responsible for controlling muscle contractions. These neurons are located within the spinal cord and have long axons that extend out to the muscle fibers. Cap motoneurons are unique among motor neurons because they are able to sustain high-frequency firing, which is essential for generating rapid and forceful muscle contractions. Cap motoneurons also have a high threshold for activation, which allows them to selectively activate a specific group of muscle fibers.

One of the key features of cap motoneurons is their ability to respond to different types of sensory information. Cap motoneurons receive inputs from a variety of sensory neurons, including muscle spindles, Golgi tendon organs, and cutaneous receptors. These sensory inputs allow the motoneuron to adjust the level of muscle contraction based on the demands of the task. For example, if a muscle is being stretched rapidly, cap motoneurons will respond by increasing the rate of firing to generate a stronger contraction.

Cap motoneurons are particularly important for controlling movements that require rapid and precise adjustments. For example, cap motoneurons are heavily involved in the control of hand movements, such as grasping and manipulating objects. Studies have shown that these neurons play a critical role in the fine-tuning of hand movements by allowing for rapid adjustments of muscle contraction levels. Overall, cap motoneurons are a key type of neuron that play an essential role in the control of movement and are particularly important for tasks that require precise and rapid adjustments of muscle contractions.
CL:0000579:
Border follicle cells are specific cells found in the egg chamber of Drosophila melanogaster, commonly known as the fruit fly. These specialized cells play important roles throughout oogenesis, the process of egg cell development. The border follicle cells surround the developing egg chamber, providing structural and functional support during early follicle development.

Border follicle cells are crucial for proper egg chamber formation. They form a complex network of cells that connect adjacent follicles, which allows for proper development and maturation of the ovary. In addition, they are responsible for producing important signaling factors, such as DPP, that help to regulate the differentiation and proliferation of germ cells and somatic cells.

During mid-oogenesis, border follicle cells play a role in the secretion of the eggshell, which is essential for egg protection and viability. They also play a role in nutrient uptake and provide metabolites to the growing oocyte. Overall, border follicle cells provide critical support throughout the process of egg development and are essential for successful reproduction in Drosophila.
CL:0000584:
Enterocytes, also known as absorptive cells, are a type of epithelial cell found in the small intestine and colon. These cells play a critical role in nutrient absorption and digestion in the digestive system. Enterocytes are characterized by their distinct brush border, which consists of microvilli that increase the absorptive surface area of the small intestine.

In addition to nutrient absorption, enterocytes play a key role in protecting the body from potentially harmful substances. They are capable of selectively transporting nutrients across the intestinal barrier while blocking the passage of bacteria, toxins, and other harmful molecules. Enterocytes also produce a variety of enzymes and hormones involved in digestion and metabolic regulation.

Given their critical role in nutrient absorption and gut barrier function, enterocytes have been the subject of intense research in recent years. Understanding the mechanisms by which these cells work could lead to the development of new treatments for digestive disorders and diseases.
CL:0009004:
Retinal cells are specialized cells found in the retina, which is the light-sensitive layer of tissue that lines the back of the eye. The retina contains several types of cells that work together to convert light into electrical signals that can be interpreted by the brain. Retinal cells are the building blocks of the retina and play a crucial role in vision.

There are several types of retinal cells, including photoreceptor cells, bipolar cells, and ganglion cells. Photoreceptor cells, which include rods and cones, are responsible for capturing light and converting it into electrical signals. Bipolar cells receive these signals from the photoreceptor cells and transmit them to the ganglion cells, which then send the signals to the brain for interpretation.

In addition to these major types of retinal cells, there are also several types of supporting cells that help to maintain the function of the retina. These include Müller cells, which provide structural support and help to regulate the flow of nutrients and waste products within the retina, and retinal pigment epithelial cells, which help to absorb excess light and protect the retina from damage.

Overall, retinal cells are essential for vision and play a crucial role in converting light into electrical signals that can be processed by the brain. The complex interactions between the various types of retinal cells are still not fully understood, but ongoing research is helping to shed light on the intricate mechanisms underlying vision.
CL:0002563:
The intestinal epithelial cells, also known as enterocytes, are the main cellular components of the lining of the small and large intestine. These cells are specialized for the absorption and transport of nutrients, ions, and water from the digestive tract into the bloodstream. The surface of the intestine is covered with microvilli, which are membrane protrusions that increase the surface area for enhanced absorption. Intestinal epithelial cells are polarized, with distinct apical and basolateral domains that are responsible for different functions. The apical domain faces the lumen of the intestine and is involved in the uptake of nutrients and secretion of mucus and enzymes, while the basolateral domain faces the blood vessels and is responsible for the transport of absorbed nutrients into the bloodstream.

In addition to their absorptive functions, intestinal epithelial cells play an important role in forming a barrier between the lumen of the intestine and underlying tissues. This barrier prevents harmful substances, such as bacteria, viruses, and toxins, from entering the body and causing infection or inflammation. Intestinal epithelial cells produce tight junctions, which are protein complexes that seal the gaps between adjacent cells and prevent the passage of molecules and microorganisms. The integrity of this barrier depends on the proper function of intestinal epithelial cells, which can be compromised in certain disease conditions, such as inflammatory bowel disease, celiac disease, and intestinal infections.

Another important feature of intestinal epithelial cells is their high rate of turnover and regeneration. The intestinal lining is constantly exposed to mechanical and chemical stress, as well as to insults from microorganisms and food antigens. Intestinal epithelial cells are able to replace themselves rapidly by dividing and differentiating from stem cells located in the crypts of Lieberkühn. This process is regulated by various factors, such as growth factors, signaling molecules, and the microbiota. Alterations in the turnover and regeneration of intestinal epithelial cells can contribute to the development of intestinal diseases, such as colorectal cancer and inflammatory bowel disease.
CL:0010009:
Camera-type eye photoreceptor cells are specialized cells found in the eye that are responsible for allowing organisms to perceive light and form images. These cells contain a protein known as rhodopsin, which is able to detect light and convert it into a chemical signal that the brain can interpret. The photoreceptor cells are arranged in a specific pattern within the eye that allows for efficient capture of light and detection of moving objects.

The camera-type eye photoreceptor cell has two distinct regions - the inner segment, which contains the cell’s nucleus and organelles, and the outer segment, which is filled with stacks of membrane-bound discs containing rhodopsin. When light is captured by the cell, it triggers a series of chemical reactions that lead to the activation of rhodopsin and the generation of an electrical signal. This signal is then relayed to the brain via a network of neurons.

Defects in camera-type eye photoreceptor cells can lead to vision loss and blindness. Some diseases, such as retinitis pigmentosa, are characterized by the degeneration of these cells, and can lead to progressive loss of vision over time. In order to better understand the function of these cells and develop treatments for diseases that affect them, researchers are actively studying the molecular mechanisms underlying their development and function.
CL:0000528:
Nitrergic neurons, also known as nitric oxide (NO) producing neurons, are specialized cells responsible for synthesizing and releasing NO in different regions of the nervous system. These neurons are mostly found in the peripheral nervous system, but they are also present in some regions of the central nervous system. Nitrergic neurons play an important role in regulating various physiological processes, including blood pressure, intestinal motility, and neurotransmission.

The primary function of nitrergic neurons is to produce NO, a gas signaling molecule that regulates various cellular processes by diffusing across cell membranes. NO is involved in several physiological functions, including vasodilation, neurotransmission, and immune regulation. In nitrergic neurons, NO production is regulated by the enzyme nitric oxide synthase (NOS), which catalyzes the conversion of arginine to NO and citrulline. The regulation of NO release from nitrergic neurons is a complex process that involves several intracellular and extracellular signaling pathways.

Nitrergic neurons act as a critical component of the enteric nervous system, regulating intestinal motility and sphincter control. Disruptions in nitrergic function have been implicated as a significant factor in several gastrointestinal disorders, including irritable bowel syndrome and gastroparesis. In addition to their role in gut function, nitrergic neurons have been implicated in several other neurological processes, including the regulation of blood pressure and the modulation of synaptic transmission. Dysfunction in nitrergic neurons has been linked to the development of several diseases, including hypertension, Alzheimer's disease, and schizophrenia, making these cells a promising target for therapeutic interventions.
CL:0000567:
Polymodal nociceptors are primary sensory neurons that respond to a wide variety of painful stimuli, such as thermal, mechanical, and chemical noxious stimuli. These neurons are of great importance, as they are responsible for detecting harmful or potentially harmful stimuli at the peripheral level. They are found in the skin, muscles, joints, and viscera of the body.

Polymodal nociceptors have a specialized structure that enables them to detect noxious stimuli. They have free nerve endings with specialized ion channels on their terminals, which allow them to respond to changes in temperature, pressure, and chemical substances. When these ion channels are activated, they lead to the generation of an action potential, which is then propagated along the axon of the neuron to the spinal cord.

Polymodal nociceptors play a critical role in the sensation of pain. When they are activated in response to noxious stimuli, they send signals to the brain via the spinothalamic tract, which is responsible for the transmission of painful sensations. Moreover, these neurons also play a role in the inflammatory response, as they release neuropeptides that cause vasodilation and increased permeability of blood vessels in the area of tissue damage. Overall, polymodal nociceptors are critical for the detection of harmful stimuli and the generation of pain sensations, making them an essential cell type in the body.
CL:0000574:
Erythrophores are specialized cells that are mainly found in the skin of fish and other aquatic vertebrates. These cells contain pigment called erythrosin and are responsible for the red and orange coloration of the skin. The changes in the coloration of the skin is a result of the movement of pigment granules within the erythrophores that can be controlled by hormones or changes in the surrounding environment.

The primary function of erythrophores is to provide camouflage and communication in fish and other aquatic vertebrates. For example, when threatened or trying to attract a mate, certain species of fish can manipulate the movement of pigment granules within their erythrophores to change the color and pattern of their skin to blend in or stand out against their surroundings. This allows them to avoid predators or attract potential mates. 

In addition to their role in coloration and communication, erythrophores have also been found to play a role in thermoregulation, wound healing and immunity in some fish species. For example, studies have shown that erythrophores can alter their pigment granule movement to help regulate body temperature or to protect against infection or injury. Overall, the function of erythrophores highlights the important role that specialized cells play in the survival and evolution of aquatic species.
CL:0000563:
An endospore is a specialized type of bacterial cell that is highly resistant to environmental stressors such as heat, radiation, and desiccation. It is formed within the bacterial cell and is essentially a dormant form of the cell that is able to survive under adverse conditions until conditions improve. Endospores are particularly resistant to high temperatures, making them a major concern in food safety and sterilization procedures.

The process of endospore formation, or sporulation, occurs when conditions are unfavorable for the bacterial cell's growth and proliferation. The cell undergoes a complex series of changes, eventually producing an endospore contained within a tough outer layer. The endospore is essentially a survival mechanism, allowing the bacterial cell to remain dormant until conditions become more favorable for growth and replication. Upon encountering favorable conditions, such as sufficient nutrients and moisture, the endospore can germinate and the bacterial cell can resume its normal metabolic activity.

Endospores are of particular interest to microbiologists and food safety experts because of their resistance to heat. The spores can survive boiling temperatures that would otherwise kill the bacterial cell in its normal state. This can be a concern in food processing and sterilization procedures, as even a small number of surviving endospores can lead to bacterial contamination of a food product. Because of their ability to survive under adverse conditions, endospores are also an important tool for studying microbial physiology, as they provide a model for understanding how bacteria adapt to extreme environments.
CL:0000571:
A leucophore is a specialized type of pigment cell found in the skin of certain fish, particularly those that live in deep ocean waters. Leucophores are responsible for producing white or silver coloration on the skin of these fish, which helps to camouflage them in their environment. The name "leucophore" comes from the Greek words "leukos", meaning white, and "phoros", meaning carrier.

Leucophores are similar in structure to other pigment cells, such as melanophores, which produce brown or black pigments, and xanthophores, which produce yellow or orange pigments. However, instead of producing pigments themselves, leucophores contain reflective platelets that reflect light and give the appearance of a bright, white color. This reflection is achieved through the interaction between the platelets and specific proteins in the cell membrane.

In addition to their role in camouflage, leucophores may also play a role in communication between fish. Some species of fish are able to change the intensity of their leucophores, which may convey information about their reproductive state or aggression level to potential mates or competitors. Overall, the specialized function of leucophores in producing white or silver coloration on the skin of certain fish has allowed these species to adapt and thrive in their unique environments.
CL:1001610:
A bone marrow hematopoietic cell (BMHC) is a type of cell that is responsible for the production of different types of blood cells. These cells are found in the bone marrow, which is the spongy tissue that occurs in the cavities of bones. BMHCs have the remarkable ability to differentiate into different types of blood cells, including red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.

The production of blood cells is a key function of the BMHC. These cells are essential for the body's immune and oxygen transport systems. Red blood cells, for instance, are responsible for carrying oxygen throughout the body, while white blood cells are involved in the immune response to infection and foreign substances. On the other hand, platelets are tiny cells that play a crucial role in blood clotting and wound healing.

BMHCs use a process called hematopoiesis to produce blood cells. This process involves the differentiation of stem cells into more specialized cell types. The stem cells differentiate into progenitor cells, which then differentiate further into mature blood cells. Abnormalities in hematopoiesis can lead to conditions such as anemia, leukemia, and thrombocytopenia.

In conclusion, bone marrow hematopoietic cells are crucial for our body's immune system and oxygen transport. Their ability to differentiate into various blood cells allows them to play a vital role in maintaining our health and fighting off infections. The study of these cells has led to a better understanding of blood-related diseases and the development of new treatments.
CL:0005003:
Leucoblasts are a type of stem cell that give rise to white blood cells known as leukocytes. The term "leucoblast" is typically used to describe the earliest stage of leukocyte development, when the cells are still highly undifferentiated and have the potential to become any type of white blood cell. These cells are characterized by their large size, relatively large nucleus, and small amount of cytoplasm.

As leucoblasts mature, they differentiate into various types of white blood cells, including lymphocytes, monocytes, neutrophils, eosinophils, and basophils. Each of these types of cells plays a different role in the immune system, such as identifying and attacking foreign pathogens, producing antibodies, and coordinating the immune response. Leucoblasts are critical to the proper functioning of the immune system, as they are responsible for generating the diverse array of leukocytes necessary for effective immune defense.

Because of their critical role in the immune system, abnormalities or dysfunction in leucoblasts can lead to serious health problems. For example, some types of leukemia are characterized by the uncontrolled proliferation and abnormal differentiation of immature white blood cells, including leucoblasts. In these cases, the body becomes overwhelmed with immature white blood cells that cannot effectively perform immune functions, leading to immunodeficiency and a heightened risk of infections and other health problems.
CL:0000564:
Neutrophilic promyelocytes are a type of white blood cell that are classified as myeloid precursors to neutrophils, which are the most abundant circulating white blood cells in humans and play a crucial role in the innate immune system. During the process of hematopoiesis, neutrophilic promyelocytes are formed from hematopoietic stem cells in the bone marrow and are characterized by their large and round nuclei with multiple nucleoli and by their relatively abundant granular cytoplasm.

As neutrophilic promyelocytes mature, they differentiate into more advanced stages of development known as myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and finally, segmented neutrophils, which are the mature and functional cells that can migrate to sites of infection and inflammation in order to phagocytose and destroy microorganisms through the release of reactive oxygen species and antimicrobial proteins. Therefore, neutrophilic promyelocytes are essential intermediates in the production of mature neutrophils that can provide protection from potentially harmful foreign invaders and contribute to the inflammatory response.

Abnormalities in the development of neutrophilic promyelocytes and other myeloid precursor cells can result in various types of blood disorders, including myelodysplastic syndromes, acute myeloid leukemia, and congenital neutropenia. Therefore, understanding the biology of neutrophilic promyelocytes and their development into mature neutrophils is critical in order to diagnose and treat these conditions.
CL:0000533:
Primary motor neurons, also known as alpha motor neurons, are a type of neuron located in the spinal cord and brainstem regions of the nervous system. They are responsible for controlling voluntary movements of the body through the contraction of skeletal muscle fibers, which results in the execution of specific movements, such as walking or throwing a ball. These neurons are considered the final common pathway for motor control and are therefore critical for the functioning of the musculoskeletal system.

Primary motor neurons have a distinct morphology, with a large, pyramid-shaped cell body and a long axon that extends from the cell body to innervate skeletal muscles. These neurons receive input from other neurons, including interneurons and sensory neurons, which allow for the integration of information before the final output signal is sent to the muscles. The axons of primary motor neurons form synapses with individual muscle fibers, allowing for precise control of individual muscles and the smooth execution of complex movements.

Damage to primary motor neurons can lead to motor neuron diseases, such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), which can result in muscle weakness, paralysis, and eventual death. Understanding the function and anatomy of primary motor neurons is crucial for developing treatments for these devastating diseases and for advancing our overall understanding of the nervous system's control of movement.
CL:0000549:
Basophilic erythroblasts are immature nucleated erythrocytes that originate from pluripotent stem cells in the bone marrow. They are the earliest erythroid progenitors that are morphologically recognizable, with a large nucleus and a small amount of cytoplasm. These cells are named for the abundant basophilic staining of their nuclei due to the presence of actively synthesized ribosomal RNA. Basophilic erythroblasts differentiate into other erythroblast types, including polychromatic and orthochromatic erythroblasts, which ultimately give rise to mature, hemoglobin-filled erythrocytes.

The main function of basophilic erythroblasts is to synthesize hemoglobin, the iron-containing protein that binds oxygen in the lungs and delivers it to the body's tissues. During basophilic erythroblast differentiation, the cells markedly increase hemoglobin synthesis, which is a hallmark of erythroid maturation in the bone marrow. Basophilic erythroblasts also undergo extensive cellular division, with each erythroblast giving rise to multiple daughter cells, thereby producing a large number of erythrocytes to ensure adequate oxygen delivery to the body. This process, called erythropoiesis, is tightly regulated by erythropoietin, a hormone produced by the kidney that acts on erythroid progenitors in the bone marrow to stimulate red blood cell production.

In summary, basophilic erythroblasts are the earliest recognizable precursors of erythrocytes and have a crucial role in synthesizing hemoglobin and producing a large number of erythrocytes to transport oxygen to the tissues. Understanding the molecular mechanisms that regulate erythropoiesis and differentiation of erythroid progenitors can have great implications for the treatment of anemias and other hematological disorders.
CL:0002672:
Retinal progenitor cells are a type of multipotent cell that can differentiate into various cell types within the retina. These cells are responsible for generating and maintaining the neural retina during development and throughout adulthood. In the developing embryo, retinal progenitor cells undergo proliferation and differentiation to form the various layers of the retina, including the photoreceptor layer, bipolar cell layer, and ganglion cell layer. In adulthood, they continue to divide and give rise to new retinal cells, allowing for the ongoing maintenance and repair of the tissue.

The differentiation of retinal progenitor cells is directed by various signaling pathways and transcription factors. Notably, the Notch signaling pathway plays a critical role in maintaining the stem-like properties of retinal progenitor cells and preventing premature differentiation. Conversely, activation of the Wnt signaling pathway promotes the differentiation of retinal progenitor cells into specific cell types within the retina. Additionally, the transcription factors Pax6, Six3, and Otx2 are important regulators of retinal progenitor cell differentiation, promoting the development of specific cell types and the formation of distinct retinal layers.

Abnormalities in retinal progenitor cell proliferation and differentiation can lead to various retinal disorders, including retinal detachment and degenerative diseases such as age-related macular degeneration and retinitis pigmentosa. Understanding the mechanisms that regulate retinal progenitor cell behavior may thus provide insights into the underlying causes of these conditions and offer potential therapeutic targets for their treatment.
CL:0001034:
A "cell in vitro" refers to a cell culture that is grown outside of its natural environment, such as in a lab or in a test tube. In vitro, which means "in glass," is commonly used to describe experiments that are performed in artificial conditions. The cells used in in vitro cultures can come from a variety of sources, including primary tissue samples or established cell lines.

These cells are often used in research to study cellular behavior and characteristics, and are an important tool in drug development and toxicology testing. By growing cells in vitro, researchers can closely control the conditions under which the cells are grown and the signals to which they are exposed. This can include the specific nutrients provided to the culture, the temperature, humidity, and gases in the growing environment, and the signals that are added to stimulate cell growth and differentiation.

Cell cultures can be used to study a wide range of cell types and functions, from basic cell biology to disease states and drug development. By carefully controlling the conditions under which cells are grown, researchers can gain valuable insights into how cells function under normal and abnormal conditions. This can include the study of cell signaling pathways, regulation of gene expression, and cellular responses to environmental stressors. Cell cultures can also be used to develop and test new treatments for a wide range of diseases, including cancer, infectious diseases, and genetic disorders.
CL:0000601:
Cochlear outer hair cells (OHCs) are specialized cells found in the ear. They are responsible for transforming sound vibrations into electrical signals that can be sent to the brain for interpretation. These cells are located in the Organ of Corti within the cochlea, which is part of the inner ear. 

OHCs are able to amplify sound waves via a motor protein called prestin. This amplification greatly enhances the sensitivity and selectivity of the auditory system, allowing us to hear a wide range of sounds. The unique molecular and mechanical properties of OHCs make them essential for normal hearing. 

In addition to their amplification function, OHCs also play a role in protecting the inner ear from loud sounds. They can contract in response to high levels of sound, limiting the amount of damage that can occur. Unfortunately, OHCs are susceptible to damage themselves, and their loss can lead to hearing impairment. Understanding the function and properties of cochlear outer hair cells is crucial for developing treatments for hearing loss and related disorders.
CL:0002381:
Uninucleate conidia are a type of fungal spore that are produced asexually by many fungal species. These spores are typically small, ranging from 2-10 microns in size, and are characterized by having a single nucleus. They are often used as a method of dispersal, allowing fungi to create new colonies in other locations.

The process of uninucleate conidia production typically occurs through a series of cell divisions, during which the cytoplasm and other cell components are divided equally among daughter cells. Once the conidia are produced, they can be dispersed by wind, water, or other means until they find a suitable location to germinate and grow into a new fungus.

While the specific functions of uninucleate conidia can vary depending on the fungal species that produces them, they are generally used as a means of reproduction and dispersal. By producing large numbers of small, lightweight spores, fungi are able to spread their offspring over large distances and increase the likelihood of colonizing new environments. As such, uninucleate conidia play an important role in the survival and evolution of many fungal species.
CL:0000594:
Skeletal muscle satellite cells are a type of muscle stem cell that are essential for postnatal skeletal muscle growth and regeneration. These cells reside beneath the basal lamina that surrounds mature muscle fibers and are typically quiescent, meaning they are not actively dividing or differentiating. However, in response to injury or exercise-induced damage, satellite cells are activated and undergo cell division to generate myogenic progenitor cells that can differentiate into new muscle fibers or fuse with existing muscle fibers to repair damage. 

The ability of skeletal muscle satellite cells to contribute to muscle repair and growth is critical for maintaining muscle function throughout an individual's lifetime. As such, alterations in satellite cell function are associated with age-related muscle wasting, or sarcopenia, and muscle diseases like muscular dystrophy. Understanding the biology of satellite cells and their interactions with the extracellular environment is an area of intense research with exciting potential for therapeutic interventions. 

In summary, skeletal muscle satellite cells are a population of muscle stem cells that play a crucial role in muscle growth and repair. These cells are activated in response to muscle damage and differentiate into myogenic progenitor cells, which can contribute to the formation of new muscle fibers or repair existing ones. Studying the biology of satellite cells is important for understanding the mechanisms underlying muscle regeneration and for developing new therapies for muscle diseases.
CL:0000588:
An odontoclast is a type of cell involved in the process of resorption in teeth. These large, multinucleated cells are responsible for breaking down and remodeling the dentin and mineralized tissue of the tooth during development, normal tooth turnover, and various pathological conditions. This process of resorption is important for tooth maintenance, allowing for the removal of damaged or old tissue and the effective healing of tooth injuries.

Odontoclasts are derived from monocytes and macrophages, which play crucial roles in immune function and inflammation. When activated, odontoclasts express a range of enzymes and signaling molecules that allow them to digest and dissolve the minerals and organic matrix of tooth tissue. These include acid phosphatases, cathepsins, and carbonic anhydrase, which are responsible for the dissolution and removal of mineral components, as well as various prostaglandins and cytokines involved in the regulation of odontoclast activity.

While odontoclasts are primarily known for their role in resorption, recent studies have suggested that they may also play important roles in modulating immune responses in the tooth and promoting the maintenance of the tooth-associated microbiome. Understanding the various functions and regulatory mechanisms of odontoclasts may help to develop new therapies for the treatment of tooth decay, gum disease, and other conditions affecting dental health.
CL:0000596:
Sexual spores are reproductive cells produced by certain organisms, such as fungi and algae, as part of their sexual life cycle. They are formed when two haploid cells, usually of different mating types, fuse together to form a diploid cell called a zygote.
