Mature alpha-beta T cells accomplish their function through the recognition of antigens displayed on the surface of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules. This interaction results in proliferation and differentiation of the T cell, as well as the secretion of cytokines that trigger other immune cells. Mature alpha-beta T cells can differentiate into various functional subsets that perform diverse immune functions, such as cytotoxic T cells that kill infected cells, regulatory T cells that suppress other immune cells, and helper T cells that secrete cytokines to assist B cells in producing antibodies.

In conclusion, the mature alpha-beta T cell is a critical player in the immune system, responsible for the recognition and elimination of foreign pathogens. They perform these functions by interacting with MHC molecules on antigen-presenting cells, proliferating, differentiating and secreting cytokines. The versatility of mature alpha-beta T cell in its ability to differentiate into various functional subsets further underscores its importance in the immune response.
CL:0000615:
Basidiospores are tiny reproductive structures that are produced by the basidiomycetes, a group of fungi that includes the well-known mushrooms, as well as other important fungi such as rusts and smuts. Basidiospores are a crucial part of the basidiomycete life cycle, as they are responsible for facilitating the dispersal of the fungus and the establishment of new colonies. In many cases, basidiospores are the only visible part of the basidiomycete, appearing as small, colored dots on the surface of a mushroom or other fruiting body.

Basidiospores are produced within specialized structures known as basidia, which are located on the surface of the fruiting body. The basidia are shaped like tiny clubs, and each one produces four basidiospores. When conditions are favorable, the basidiospores are ejected from the basidium and carried away on the wind, where they may land on a suitable substrate and germinate to form a new colony.

Despite their small size, basidiospores are important for the survival and dispersal of basidiomycete fungi. They are often produced in enormous numbers, and their ability to be carried long distances by the wind means that they can distribute the fungus across great distances. Once they have landed on a suitable substrate, basidiospores germinate and begin to grow, forming a new colony that will eventually produce its own fruiting body and continue the cycle. Overall, basidiospores are a fascinating and important component of the basidiomycete life cycle, enabling these fungi to survive and thrive in a wide range of environments.
CL:0001067:
Group 1 innate lymphoid cells (ILC1s) are a type of innate lymphoid cells that play an essential role in the early response to pathogen infections and tissue damage. These cells were first identified as a distinct population of lymphoid-like cells that are capable of producing IFN-γ upon activation. ILC1s are characterized by the expression of specific transcription factors such as T-bet and Eomes, which are essential for their development, maintenance, and function.

ILC1s are mainly found in mucosal tissues such as the intestine and respiratory system, where they act as the first line of defense against pathogens. They recognize and respond to various stimuli, including cytokines, pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs), and stress signals released by damaged cells. Upon activation, ILC1s produce large amounts of IFN-γ, which activates the immune cells to clear the infection or tissue damage. ILC1s also play a vital role in regulating inflammation and tissue repair processes, and their dysregulation has been linked to the pathogenesis of various inflammatory diseases.

Overall, ILC1s represent a crucial component of the innate immune system that contributes to the defense against pathogenic infections and tissue damage. Their ability to produce IFN-γ and regulate inflammation makes them an attractive target for therapeutic interventions in various inflammatory and infectious diseases. Further studies are needed to better understand the regulation and function of ILC1s in health and disease contexts.
CL:0008018:
Somatic muscle myoblasts are a type of muscle cell that plays a crucial role in muscle development and repair in vertebrates. These cells are present during embryonic development, where they proliferate and fuse to form skeletal muscle fibers. In adults, somatic muscle myoblasts are responsible for repairing and regenerating muscle tissue in response to injury or exercise.

The primary function of somatic muscle myoblasts is to differentiate into myocytes, or muscle cells, which can then fuse with existing muscle fibers to repair or increase muscle mass. During muscle repair, somatic muscle myoblasts are activated and proliferate rapidly to form new muscle cells, which subsequently fuse with existing myofibers to repair damaged tissue. In cases of prolonged muscle damage, such as muscular dystrophy, somatic muscle myoblasts can differentiate into muscle stem cells, known as satellite cells, which help to maintain muscle regeneration.

In addition to their reparative functions, somatic muscle myoblasts play a critical role in muscle growth and hypertrophy. Under conditions of exercise or physical activity, these cells are activated and begin to proliferate and differentiate into new myocytes, which contribute to an increase in muscle mass. In this way, somatic muscle myoblasts are essential for both muscle maintenance and adaptation to changing conditions, such as exercise or injury.
CL:0000603:
A dikaryon is a type of fungal cell that contains two genetically distinct haploid nuclei, which have not yet undergone fusion. During the early stages of fungal sexual reproduction, two haploid nuclei from different parent cells that have compatible mating types will fuse, forming a diploid nucleus that further divides and undergoes meiosis to form haploid spores. In a dikaryon, however, these haploid nuclei remain separate and are housed within the same cytoplasm, where they coexist and often coordinate their activities.

Dikaryons play a crucial role in the development of many fungi, including those that produce edible mushrooms like the button mushroom and the shiitake. One of the key functions of dikaryotic cells is that they enable the formation of complex fruiting bodies, such as mushrooms, by coordinating the differentiation and growth of specialized structures like gills, caps, and stalks. In dikaryons, the two haploid nuclei can regulate gene expression and protein synthesis in tandem, allowing for the precise orchestration of developmental events that give rise to these intricate multicellular structures.

In addition to their role in fungal reproduction and fruiting body development, dikaryotic cells also have unique cellular and biochemical properties that make them of interest to researchers in a variety of fields. For example, the two haploid nuclei can have different chromosomal sets, leading to interesting differences in gene expression and the regulation of cellular processes. By studying dikaryons, scientists can gain insights into the genetic and epigenetic mechanisms underlying fungal development, evolution, and adaptation to different environments.
CL:0002374:
Ear hair cells, also called auditory hair cells, play a critical role in the detection of sound waves and translation of these mechanical stimuli into neural signals. These specialized sensory cells are located in the cochlea, which is the inner ear snail-shaped structure responsible for hearing. The ear hair cells are responsible for detecting different sound frequencies and their precise location on the basilar membrane of the cochlea. 

The hair cells in the cochlea are arranged in rows along the organ of Corti, which is located within the basilar membrane. The hair cells are named for their peculiar hair-like stereocilia that protrude from their apical surface. The stereocilia of the hair cells are arranged in a graduated staircase-like structure called the hair bundle. When sound waves enter the cochlea, the basilar membrane vibrates, causing the hair bundle to bend back and forth. This motion causes the stereocilia to pivot, bending against their kinocilium. This triggers the opening of ion channels, allowing an influx of potassium ions that depolarize the cell and lead to the release of neurotransmitters at the synaptic junctions with the afferent nerve fibers. These neurotransmitters facilitate the transmission of auditory signals to the brainstem, eventually leading to the perception of sound. 

Ear hair cells are prone to damage and degeneration due to aging, noise exposure, and various environmental and genetic factors. Loss of hair cells can lead to severe hearing impairment and deafness. Furthermore, damaged synaptic connections between hair cells and afferent nerve fibers can impair signal transmission and lead to abnormal auditory processing. Current research is focused on understanding the mechanisms of hair cell damage and regeneration, and developing effective therapies to restore hearing loss caused by hair cell damage.
CL:0000629:
Storage cells, also known as adipocytes, are specialized cells that store energy in the form of fat for later use by the body. They are found throughout the body, but are most abundant in adipose tissue, which is located under the skin and around internal organs. These cells play a crucial role in maintaining energy balance and regulating metabolism.

Adipocytes are unique in their ability to expand and contract based on energy availability. When the body takes in more energy than it needs, storage cells enlarge and store the excess as triglycerides. On the other hand, when energy is scarce, these cells shrink as their contents are released into the bloodstream to be used as energy by other cells in the body. This dynamic process allows the body to regulate energy balance and maintain homeostasis.

In addition to energy storage, storage cells are also involved in a variety of hormonal and metabolic processes. Adipocytes secrete hormones and cytokines that regulate appetite, insulin sensitivity, and immune function. They also play a role in storing and releasing other molecules, such as cholesterol and vitamin D. Understanding the complex functions of storage cells is essential for developing treatments for obesity, diabetes, and other metabolic disorders.
CL:0000825:
Pro-NK cells, also known as pre-NK cells, are a type of lymphocyte that plays an important role in the innate immune response. These cells are the precursors to natural killer (NK) cells, which are known for their ability to target and eliminate virus-infected and cancerous cells. Pro-NK cells are primarily found in the bone marrow, where they differentiate and mature into fully functional NK cells before entering the circulation.

The development of pro-NK cells is regulated by a variety of signaling pathways and transcription factors, including the common gamma chain cytokines Interleukin-2 (IL-2), IL-7, and IL-15. These cytokines stimulate the proliferation and differentiation of pro-NK cells into mature NK cells that express a wide array of activating and inhibitory receptors. Once activated, pro-NK cells can target and eliminate target cells via a variety of mechanisms, including the release of cytotoxic granules and the triggering of apoptosis in the target cell.

Pro-NK cells are also important for the formation of cellular memory in the innate immune system. As these cells differentiate and mature into fully functional NK cells, they undergo epigenetic modifications that lead to the long-term expression of certain activating and inhibitory receptors. This memory-like response allows for a more efficient and effective response to subsequent infections or the reactivation of dormant viruses. Overall, pro-NK cells play a critical role in the innate immune response and contribute to the maintenance of overall immune system homeostasis.
CL:0002315:
The supporting cells of the cochlea, also known as the pillar cells, are a vital component of the inner ear responsible for maintaining the structural integrity of the organ of Corti. These cells provide support for the sensory hair cells, which detect sound waves and convert them into electrical signals that the brain can interpret. The supporting cells are therefore essential for proper hearing function.

There are two types of supporting cells in the cochlea, inner and outer pillar cells. The outer pillar cells are located on the outer edge of the organ of Corti and connect to one another, forming a strong pillar-like structure. The inner pillar cells are situated on the inner edge of the organ of Corti and create a similar supporting structure. Together, these cells provide the foundation for the sensory hair cells to function properly.

In addition to providing support, the supporting cells of the cochlea play a crucial role in the development and maintenance of the sensory hair cells. These cells form tight junctions with the sensory hair cells, creating a barrier that keeps the fluids of the inner ear separated from the endolymphatic sac. This barrier is essential for maintaining the proper ionic environment in the inner ear, which is necessary for proper hearing function. Without the supporting cells, the hair cells would be unable to maintain their structure and function, leading to hearing loss and other auditory disorders.
CL:0000631:
Labyrinth supporting cells are a crucial component of the cochlea, the sensory organ responsible for hearing in mammals. These cells are present in the spiraling canals of the cochlea and are essential for the proper functioning of the inner ear. Labyrinth supporting cells play a vital role in modulating the mechanical forces acting on the sensory hair cells, thus enabling precise detection and transduction of sound waves.

The labyrinth supporting cells are located in the stria vascularis, a specialized tissue responsible for secreting the endolymph, which is critical for the maintenance of the high potassium concentration in the endolymphatic fluid. These cells are responsible for the regulation of the potassium recycling pathway, which is crucial for maintaining the high potassium concentration in the extracellular space. Labyrinth supporting cells provide metabolic support to the neighboring hair cells and help maintain their ionic composition, which is vital for the proper functioning of the sensory epithelium.

In addition to their critical role in the maintenance of the cochlear environment, the labyrinth supporting cells also play a role in auditory processing. These cells are involved in the synaptic transmission between the hair cells and primary afferent neurons. They facilitate the release of neurotransmitters and modulate the signaling between the hair cells and afferent neurons. Labyrinth supporting cells, therefore, play a crucial role in the intricate process of hearing and are essential for the proper functioning of the inner ear.
CL:0002165:
Phalangeal cells are a type of specialized cells in the cerebellum, which functions to control movement and coordination. These cells are found in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellar cortex and extend their processes, called parallel fibers, into the molecular layer. Phalangeal cells receive excitatory inputs from parallel fibers and inhibitory inputs from the stellate and basket cells, which regulate their output activity.

The main function of phalangeal cells is to make synaptic contacts with the parallel fibers, and ultimately generate an inhibitory response to Purkinje cells. This process is critical for motor coordination, as the output of the Purkinje cells controls the firing of the deep cerebellar nuclei, which are responsible for the fine-tuned control of movement. Mutations in genes encoding proteins expressed in phalangeal cells have been linked to several neurological disorders, including spinocerebellar ataxia and autism spectrum disorders.

In summary, phalangeal cells play a crucial role in regulating motor coordination by providing inhibitory input to Purkinje cells in the cerebellum. These cells receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers, and inhibitory input from stellate and basket cells, resulting in a finely-tuned output that modulates the firing of deep cerebellar nuclei. Mutations in genes expressed in these cells have been associated with several neurological disorders.
CL:0000681:
Radial glial cells (RGCs) are elongated cells that play a crucial role during development of the nervous system. During early embryonic development, RGCs serve as progenitor cells, generating neurons and glia cells. RGCs are characterized by their unique radial morphology and extend from the innermost layer of the neural tube to the outermost layer, traversing through the neural tube. 

During development, RGCs provide a scaffold for neuronal migration to their final destination within the nervous system. They create a physical path that allows neurons to migrate in an organized and directional manner. This function of RGCs is dependent on their unique morphology, with one end extending to the ventricular surface of the neural tube and the other end extending to the pial surface. RGCs also play a role in axon guidance by providing guidance cues to developing axons, helping them to navigate and connect to their appropriate targets. 

After embryonic development, RGCs continue to play a role in the nervous system as they differentiate into astrocytes, a type of glial cell that helps to maintain the structure and function of the brain. Additionally, RGCs are involved in the repair and regeneration of the nervous system after injury. By understanding the function of RGCs, researchers are able to gain insight into the development, maintenance, and repair of the nervous system.
CL:2000004:
Pituitary gland cells are one of the most important endocrine cells found in the human body. These cells are located in the pituitary gland, which is a small, pea-shaped gland that sits at the base of the brain. They are responsible for producing and secreting a variety of hormones that help regulate growth, metabolism, reproduction, and stress responses.

There are several types of pituitary gland cells, each of which produces a different hormone. For example, somatotrophs produce growth hormone (GH), which is essential for normal growth and development, while thyrotrophs produce thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), which stimulates the thyroid gland to produce thyroid hormones. Gonadotrophs produce luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), which are important for fertility and reproductive function.

In addition to producing and secreting hormones, pituitary gland cells are also responsible for regulating the levels of these hormones in the bloodstream. The release of hormones is tightly regulated by a variety of feedback mechanisms, ensuring that the body remains in a state of balance and homeostasis. When these mechanisms fail, it can lead to hormonal imbalances and disorders such as acromegaly, hypothyroidism, and infertility.
CL:0000634:
Claudius cells are a type of supporting cell found in the organ of Corti within the inner ear. These specialized cells are named after their discoverer, Johannes Claudius, and are essential for maintaining the unique microenvironment required for auditory transduction. These cells are characterized by their location within the organ of Corti, residing just apical to the inner hair cells. 

Claudius cells play a crucial role in the proper functioning of the organ of Corti. They form a tight barrier that separates the endolymphatic compartment from the perilymphatic space, which is essential for maintaining the high concentration of potassium ions required for auditory transduction. In addition, these cells are known to secrete a variety of factors, including cytokines and extracellular matrix molecules, that help to maintain the structural integrity of the sensory epithelium. 

Interestingly, recent studies have suggested that Claudius cells may not only play a passive role in maintaining the microenvironment of the organ of Corti but may also actively contribute to auditory function. For example, these cells have been shown to possess voltage-gated potassium channels that enable them to generate electrical activity in response to auditory stimuli. This suggests that Claudius cells may play a direct role in the processing of sound signals within the inner ear, in addition to their well-established role in supporting and maintaining the function of the sensory epithelium.
CL:0000627:
Transporting cells are specialized cells responsible for moving substances, such as nutrients, gases, or waste products, across a biological barrier or between different compartments of an organism. These cells can be found in various tissues and organs, such as the lungs, intestines, kidneys, and blood vessels, and can be classified based on their location and mode of transport.

Epithelial transport cells, for instance, form a selective barrier that separates different body fluids or compartments and regulate the movement of ions, water, and solutes in response to specific signals and needs. Different types of epithelial transport cells can be distinguished based on the source and destination of the transported substances, such as absorptive cells in the intestine, which are responsible for absorbing nutrients from digested food, or renal tubular cells, which reclaim valuable solutes from urine and help maintain the body's fluid and electrolyte balance.

Other types of transporting cells include blood cells, such as red blood cells or leukocytes, which transport oxygen, nutrients, immune cells, and other substances through the circulatory system to different tissues and organs. Similarly, lymphatic cells, such as lymphocytes and dendritic cells, are involved in transporting and processing foreign substances and antigens from tissues to lymph nodes and other lymphatic organs for immune surveillance and activation.

In summary, transporting cells play essential roles in maintaining homeostasis and supporting physiological functions by regulating the movement of substances within and between different compartments of the body. Their diverse functions and properties make them a key target for biomedical research and therapeutic interventions.
CL:0000626:
Olfactory granule cells are a type of interneuron found in the olfactory bulb, which is a structure located in the forebrain that processes information about scents detected by the nose. While the main function of olfactory granule cells is not yet fully understood, they are thought to play a crucial role in the processing of olfactory information within the olfactory bulb by modulating the activity of other types of neurons. 

Olfactory granule cells are small and have a dense network of processes that allows them to form synapses with other neurons, including mitral cells and tufted cells. Studies have shown that olfactory granule cells receive input from both the olfactory receptor neurons that detect odors in the environment and from other neurons within the olfactory bulb. They then integrate this information and can modify the output of mitral and tufted cells, which are the primary output neurons of the olfactory bulb that project to other brain areas. 

While the precise function of olfactory granule cells is still being investigated, it is clear that they play an important role in the processing of olfactory information. Their ability to modulate the activity of other neurons suggests that they may be involved in the regulation of odor discrimination and perception. Additionally, recent research has also suggested that olfactory granule cells may be involved in the coding of complex odorant mixtures. Further investigation of the function of olfactory granule cells may lead to a better understanding of how the brain processes and interprets olfactory information.
CL:0000636:
Mueller cells, also known as astrocytes type I, are a type of glial cell found in the retina of the eye. They span the entire thickness of the retina and form the outermost layer of the retina. Mueller cells provide physical, metabolic and trophic support to the retinal neurons. They are also involved in the maintenance of the blood-retina barrier.

The primary function of Mueller cells is to regulate the ionic homeostasis of the retina. They play a crucial role in the uptake and metabolism of glutamate, the major neurotransmitter in the retina. Mueller cells express various transporters and enzymes that clear extracellular glutamate released by photoreceptor cells and bipolar cells. This process prevents excessive activation of glutamate receptors in postsynaptic neurons, which can lead to excitotoxicity and neuronal cell death.

In addition to their role in glutamate clearance, Mueller cells are also involved in the regulation of the retinal blood flow. They produce vasoactive substances such as vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and endothelin-1 (ET-1) that control the diameter of retinal blood vessels. Mueller cells also have a role in the response to retinal injury and disease. In certain pathological conditions, such as retinal detachment or diabetic retinopathy, Mueller cells change their morphology and function, leading to retinal remodeling and dysfunction.
CL:0000633:
Hensen cells, also known as supporting cells of the organ of Corti, are specialized glial cells located in the sensory epithelium of the cochlea, a part of the inner ear. These cells provide structural and metabolic support for hair cells, which are the primary sensory cells responsible for the transduction of sound waves into neural impulses. Hensen cells are named after the German anatomist Victor Hensen, who first described them in the late 19th century.

Hensen cells have elongated, columnar shapes and are arranged in rows along the length of the cochlear duct. Their apical surfaces are in contact with the tectorial membrane, which is a gel-like structure that overlies the hair cells. Hensen cells extend cellular processes called phalangeal processes, which form a sheath around the basal portions of hair cells. This sheath helps to anchor the hair cells in place and provides a pathway for the exchange of nutrients and waste products between hair cells and the blood supply in the underlying spiral ligament.

In addition to their structural role, Hensen cells also play a role in the regulation of the ionic environment of the organ of Corti. They have ion channels on their plasma membranes that allow them to actively transport ions such as potassium and sodium. This activity helps to maintain the endocochlear potential, which is a critical factor for the proper functioning of hair cells. Dysfunction or loss of Hensen cells can lead to various forms of hearing impairment, including sensorineural hearing loss.
CL:2000073:
Migratory cardiac neural crest cells are a population of cells that originate from the ectoderm during embryonic development. They migrate into the heart and contribute to various structures such as the cardiac outflow tract, great vessels, and the majority of the cardiac septa. These cells play a crucial role in the formation of the cardiovascular system and defects in their migration or differentiation can lead to congenital heart diseases. 

During early embryonic development, cardiac neural crest cells are induced to delaminate from the neural tube and migrate along defined pathways to their predetermined locations within the heart. Once they arrive at their destination, they differentiate into various cell types such as smooth muscle cells, fibroblasts, and neurons. The precise regulation of this process is vital for proper cardiac development and function.

In addition to their role in cardiovascular development, migratory cardiac neural crest cells have been shown to play a role in cardiac repair and regeneration. Studies have demonstrated that these cells can differentiate into various lineages and contribute to the repair of damaged cardiac tissue. Understanding the molecular mechanisms that govern the migration, differentiation, and function of migratory cardiac neural crest cells is essential for the development of new therapies for the treatment of cardiac diseases.
CL:0000655:
The secondary oocyte is a vital cell type involved in the process of reproduction in female mammals. Following ovulation, the secondary oocyte is released from the ovary and travels through the fallopian tube toward the uterus. The primary function of the secondary oocyte is to facilitate fertilization with a sperm cell, resulting in the formation of a zygote.

The secondary oocyte is highly specialized and has several unique adaptations that enable it to fulfill its role in reproduction. One important feature of the secondary oocyte is its possession of a large, nutrient-rich cytoplasm. This cytoplasm provides the developing zygote with the essential nutrients it needs to grow and develop into a healthy embryo.

In addition to its nutrient-rich cytoplasm, the secondary oocyte is also characterized by the presence of a haploid nucleus. This nucleus contains half the genetic material of the parent organism, and when fused with a sperm cell's haploid nucleus, forms a diploid zygote. Overall, the secondary oocyte is a crucial component of the mammalian reproductive system, playing an essential role in the formation of new life.
CL:0000646:
Basal cells are small, round cells located in the innermost layer of the skin's epidermis, as well as in other epithelial tissues such as the lining of the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts. They serve as the stem cells of these tissues, dividing to produce daughter cells that are capable of differentiating into specialized cell types of the tissue in which they reside. In the skin, basal cells give rise to keratinocytes, which form the majority of the epidermis and provide a barrier against the external environment.

Basal cells are also important for repairing tissues that have been damaged by injury or disease. When the skin is wounded, basal cells migrate to the site of injury and begin to divide rapidly to generate new cells to replace those that have been lost. This process is critical for the healing of cuts, burns, and other injuries. Similarly, in the respiratory tract, basal cells can regenerate damaged lung tissue, and in the gastrointestinal tract, they can repair the lining of the gut.

In addition to their role in tissue repair and maintenance, basal cells have been implicated in the development of certain types of cancer. For example, basal cell carcinoma, a common form of skin cancer, arises from mutations in basal cells that cause them to proliferate uncontrollably. Understanding the biology of basal cells and their interactions with other cell types will be important for developing new strategies to treat and prevent these diseases.
CL:0000638:
Acidophil cells of the pars distalis of adenohypophysis are a type of endocrine cell found in the anterior pituitary gland. These cells are known for their ability to secrete large amounts of growth hormone and prolactin, both of which play important roles in regulating growth, development, and reproductive function in vertebrates. Acidophil cells are so named because they have a distinct acidic cytoplasmic granulation that stains readily with acidophilic dyes.

In addition to their role in regulating growth and reproductive function, acidophil cells are also believed to play a role in the immune system. Recent studies have shown that acidophil cells might influence the immune system by regulating the production and secretion of cytokines and chemokines, which are important signaling molecules in the immune response. Specifically, acidophil cells have been shown to produce interleukin-6, a cytokine that is involved in the regulation of immune cell growth and differentiation, as well as CCL2, a chemokine that is involved in the recruitment of immune cells to sites of inflammation.

Overall, the acidophil cells of the pars distalis of adenohypophysis are a complex and dynamic cell type that play important roles in regulating physiological processes throughout the body. Their ability to secrete growth hormone and prolactin makes them important players in the endocrine system, while their potential role in immune regulation adds an additional layer of complexity to our understanding of these fascinating cells.
CL:0000632:
Hepatic stellate cells (HSCs), also known as perisinusoidal cells or Ito cells, are a population of cells found in the liver. These cells play an essential role in liver physiology and pathology. They are responsible for regulating the extracellular matrix (ECM) and storing vitamin A. In pathological conditions, HSCs can be activated and differentiate into myofibroblast-like cells, leading to the deposition of excess ECM, which contributes to the development of liver fibrosis.

Under normal physiological conditions, HSCs play an important role in regulating the ECM by producing and maintaining a balance between ECM synthesis and degradation. They are also involved in the degradation and removal of aged or damaged erythrocytes. In addition, HSCs are major vitamin A-storing cells in the body, accounting for up to 80% of the total body vitamin A stores. This suggests that HSCs are of metabolic importance in the body, and their malfunctioning can severely impact vitamin A homeostasis.

In liver disease, HSCs can become activated and differentiate into myofibroblast-like cells, leading to the accumulation of excess ECM. This event results in the development of liver fibrosis, which is the excessive accumulation of scar tissue. The activation of HSCs is a complex, multi-step process involving various signaling pathways and cytokines. Therefore, the study of HSCs is crucial to understanding the pathogenesis of liver diseases. Targeting HSCs has emerged as an attractive therapeutic option in the management of liver fibrosis, and several experimental therapies aiming to reduce HSC activity are currently under investigation.
CL:0000651:
Mucous neck cells are a type of epithelial cell found in the gastric glands of the stomach. These cells are located at the neck of the gastric pit and secrete mucus that helps protect the stomach wall from the acidic environment and digestive enzymes. Mucous neck cells are identified by their distinctive shape, which includes a narrow neck and a round, ovoid body.

The mucus secreted by mucous neck cells is comprised of glycoproteins and bicarbonate ions. The glycoproteins form a protective layer on the surface of the stomach lining, while the bicarbonate ions help neutralize the acidic environment of the stomach. This layer of mucus helps prevent the stomach lining from being damaged by the strong acids and enzymes produced during digestion. In addition to their protective role, mucous neck cells also secrete growth factors that help maintain the structure of the gastric glands.

Dysfunction of mucous neck cells has been associated with various gastric diseases, including peptic ulcer disease and gastric cancer. Inhibiting the secretion of mucus by these cells can lead to the degradation of the gastric lining, which can lead to ulcers and other complications. Understanding the role of mucous neck cells in the normal functions of the stomach, as well as their contributions to pathological conditions, is an important area of research in digestive physiology and pathology.
CL:0000673:
Kenyon cells are a type of neuron found in the brain of invertebrates such as insects and crustaceans. These cells are best known for their role in the formation and storage of memories. In insects such as fruit flies, Kenyon cells are part of the mushroom bodies which are responsible for learning and memory.

Kenyon cells have a unique structure and morphology that allows them to form synapses with multiple neurons in the brain. They also have a high degree of plasticity, meaning they can change the strength and number of their connections in response to new experiences or stimuli. This plasticity is thought to be a key factor in the formation and storage of memories.

In addition to their role in memory formation, Kenyon cells also play a role in various other behaviors such as odor perception, courtship behavior, and sleep regulation. These cells have been extensively studied in insects and crustaceans, and their properties and functions continue to be an active area of research in the field of neuroscience.
CL:0000836:
Promyelocytes are cells that typically arise from myeloblasts, and they are myeloid precursors that are located in the bone marrow. These cells have a large, round nucleus and a relatively plentiful cytoplasm. Promyelocytes are slightly larger than myeloblasts but are similar in appearance. They are not normally found in the peripheral blood, and they appear in the bone marrow as a result of differentiation of earlier hematopoietic cells. Promyelocytes can mature into mature neutrophils under normal conditions.

The function of the promyelocyte is to differentiate further into specific blood cells. This is a natural process that is part of the body's immune response to infection or injury. Promyelocytes are a crucial part of the immune system because they can differentiate into different types of white blood cells, including basophils, eosinophils, or neutrophils. Neutrophil precursors like the promyelocyte play a vital role in the innate immune response, particularly in phagocytosis or engulfing of bacterial pathogens. The maturation process of myeloid precursors like promyelocytes into mature neutrophils in response to infection is known as "emergency granulopoiesis."

In some cases, an abnormally high number of promyelocytes can be found in the blood, which can signify a potentially serious medical condition. In certain blood cancers, such as acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), there is an overproduction of abnormal promyelocytes, which can lead to a decreased number of normal blood cells and cause an increased risk of bleeding and infections. Understanding the function and characteristics of promyelocytes is crucial in the prognosis and treatment of these conditions.
CL:0000642:
Folliculostellate cells (FSCs) are non-endocrine cells that are found in the anterior pituitary gland. They are a type of glial-like cell that play a crucial role in maintaining the structure and function of the pituitary gland. FSCs are characterized by their cuboidal shape and abundant cytoplasmic processes, which extend into the surrounding endocrine cells and form a network-like structure. 

One of the most important functions of FSCs is to provide structural support to the pituitary gland. They form a scaffold-like structure that holds the endocrine cells in place and allows them to function properly. FSCs also secrete extracellular matrix proteins that help to maintain the integrity of the gland. 

In addition to their structural role, FSCs also play a role in regulating the secretion of hormones from the pituitary gland. They are thought to be involved in paracrine signaling, which allows them to communicate with the endocrine cells and modulate their activity. FSCs have been shown to produce a variety of signaling molecules, including cytokines, growth factors, and neurotransmitters. Overall, the function of FSCs is critical for the proper functioning of the pituitary gland and for overall hormonal homeostasis.
CL:0000645:
Pituicytes are specialized glial cells found in the posterior pituitary gland. They are elongated and have numerous fine processes that ensheathe the axons of neurons. These cells are important for maintaining the structural integrity of the posterior pituitary gland and ensuring the proper release of hormones from the gland. 

Pituicytes are involved in the regulation and release of two important hormones: oxytocin and vasopressin. These hormones are synthesized in the hypothalamus and then transported along the axons of neurons to the posterior pituitary gland. Pituicytes help to store and release these hormones into the bloodstream when needed. Oxytocin is involved in many physiological processes, including uterine contractions during childbirth and milk letdown during nursing. Vasopressin, on the other hand, helps to regulate water balance in the body and is also known as the antidiuretic hormone. 

In addition to their role in regulating the release of hormones, pituicytes are also involved in the response to injury or disease in the pituitary gland. These cells are able to proliferate and migrate to areas of damage in order to repair and regenerate the tissue. Pituicyte dysfunction has been associated with a number of pituitary gland disorders, including pituitary adenomas and diabetes insipidus. Understanding the role of pituicytes in the pituitary gland is important for developing better treatments for these and other pituitary disorders.
CL:0012000:
Astrocytes of the forebrain are specialized glial cells found in the brain, specifically in the cerebral cortex, hippocampus, and basal ganglia. They are characterized by their star-like shape and their numerous branching processes. Astrocytes are known to perform a wide range of essential functions, including nutrient and ion uptake, regulation of synaptic plasticity, and regulation of cerebral blood flow.

One of the primary functions of astrocytes of the forebrain is to maintain the structural and functional integrity of the brain. Astrocytes play a crucial role in regulating the extracellular environment by taking up and recycling neurotransmitters, such as glutamate, and maintaining optimal ion concentrations. Additionally, astrocytes provide mechanical and metabolic support to neurons, contributing to neural circuit formation and plasticity.

Another important function of astrocytes of the forebrain is their role in regulating cerebral blood flow. Astrocytes are known to regulate the diameter of cerebral blood vessels, which allows for controlled delivery of oxygen and nutrients to active regions of the brain. This process, known as neurovascular coupling, is vital for normal brain function. Dysfunction of astrocytes has been implicated in a range of neurological disorders, including epilepsy, Alzheimer's disease, and Parkinson's disease.

In summary, astrocytes of the forebrain are critical components of the brain's support system. They perform a wide range of functions that are essential for brain function and are involved in a variety of neurological disorders. Understanding the specific roles of astrocytes in the brain is essential for developing new treatments for these disorders and improving our overall understanding of brain function.
CL:0002522:
Renal filtration cells, also known as podocytes, are a specialized type of cell found in the kidney's glomeruli, which are responsible for filtering blood. The podocytes are crucial for ensuring that essential proteins and other molecules remain in the bloodstream while wastes and excess fluids are eliminated through urine. The role of these cells is paramount as they provide an important layer of filtration, preventing the loss of large molecules like proteins into the urine. 

Podocytes have a unique structure that allows them to create a filtration barrier. Their cytoplasmic extensions, called foot processes, interdigitate with those of neighboring podocytes to form a network of branched structures, the slit diaphragm complex. This complex serves as a molecular sieve that restricts the passage of large substances such as proteins while allowing smaller ones to cross into the urine. 

These cells also play an important role in blood vessel health. They produce a variety of growth and adhesion factors that help regulate the function of the endothelial cells lining the glomerular capillaries. Therefore, any impairment to the podocytes' functionality can lead to an abnormal glomerular filtration rate (GFR), which can result in renal damage and the development of diseases such as glomerulonephritis or diabetic nephropathy. Overall, renal filtration cells are essential for the proper functioning of the kidney and the maintenance of overall body health.
CL:0000644:
Bergmann glial cells are specialized astrocytes found in the cerebellum, a region of the brain that is primarily involved in motor coordination and balance. These cells are named after the German anatomist Karl Bergmann, who first described them in 1874. Bergmann glial cells have a characteristic radial morphology, with their cell bodies residing in the molecular layer of the cerebellum and their processes extending towards the Purkinje cell layer.

The primary function of Bergmann glial cells is to provide structural and metabolic support to the Purkinje cells, which are the principal output neurons of the cerebellum. These glial cells form a close association with the synapses of the Purkinje cells, providing a scaffold for the formation and plasticity of these synaptic connections. Bergmann glial cells also express a variety of ion channels and transporters, which play important roles in regulating the extracellular environment of the cerebellum.

In addition to their role in supporting neuronal function, Bergmann glial cells also play a critical role in cerebellar development. Studies have shown that these glial cells are involved in the migration and differentiation of granule cells, which are the most numerous type of neuron in the cerebellum. Furthermore, disruptions in Bergmann glial cell function have been implicated in a variety of neurological disorders, including ataxia and cerebellar atrophy. Overall, Bergmann glial cells are a key player in the intricate network of cells and structures that make up the cerebellum.
CL:0000625:
CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells are a subset of T lymphocytes that play a crucial role in the adaptive immune system. They express the CD8 glycoprotein, which is a co-receptor that binds to major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I molecules on antigen-presenting cells (APCs). This allows CD8-positive T cells to recognize and respond to intracellular pathogens, such as viruses and certain bacteria, that have infected host cells.

Upon encountering an antigen-presenting cell displaying an MHC class I-peptide complex that matches its T cell receptor (TCR), CD8-positive T cells become activated and undergo clonal expansion to generate a population of effector cells. These effector cells then migrate to the site of infection, where they exert their cytotoxic activity by releasing granzymes and perforins to induce apoptosis in infected cells. In addition, CD8-positive T cells can secrete cytokines, such as interferon-gamma and tumor necrosis factor-alpha, to enhance the immune response and recruit other immune cells to the site of infection.

CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells are also involved in immune surveillance against cancer cells. They can recognize and kill tumor cells that express aberrant antigens or overexpress normal self-antigens, which helps to prevent the development of cancer. However, tumor cells can evade CD8-positive T cell-mediated immune surveillance by downregulating MHC class I expression or expressing immune checkpoint proteins that inhibit T cell function. Therefore, strategies that enhance CD8-positive T cell activity, such as checkpoint inhibitor therapy and CAR-T cell therapy, are being developed as novel treatments for cancer.
CL:0002490:
Organ of Corti supporting cells, also known as pillar cells, are specialized cells located in the organ of Corti within the cochlea of the inner ear. They are named for their characteristic shape, as they form two rows of supportive structures that run along the length of the organ of Corti. The primary function of these cells is to provide structural support for the hair cells, which are responsible for converting sound vibrations into electrical signals that can be transmitted to the brain. In addition to providing structural support, organ of Corti supporting cells are also involved in the maintenance and repair of the organ of Corti.

One of the key roles of organ of Corti supporting cells is to provide a scaffold for the hair cells. They are arranged in two rows, with one row on each side of the organ of Corti. These cells serve as a physical barrier between the outer and inner hair cells, and help to maintain the proper arrangement of the cells within the cochlea. Without this support, the hair cells would be unable to properly detect sound waves and convert them into electrical signals.

Another important function of organ of Corti supporting cells is to secrete substances that are necessary for the survival and proper function of the hair cells. These cells produce a variety of substances, such as growth factors and extracellular matrix proteins, that help to support the growth and longevity of the hair cells. They are also capable of generating new hair cells if the existing ones are damaged or lost, although the extent of this regenerative capacity is still being studied.

Overall, organ of Corti supporting cells play a critical role in the maintenance of the cochlea and its function in hearing. Their structural support and secretory functions are essential for the proper functioning of the hair cells, and for sensory transduction that leads to the perception of sound.
CL:0000650:
Mesangial cells are pericytes of the kidney that play a vital role in maintaining the structure and functioning of the glomerulus in the kidney. These cells are located in between the capillary loops of the glomerulus and are thought to act as contractile cells that regulate blood flow and filtration in the glomerulus. They also play a role in regulating the extracellular matrix in the glomerulus to maintain its structural integrity.

One important function of mesangial cells is to regulate the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). They do this by contracting or relaxing in response to changes in blood pressure and flow rate. As they contract, they reduce the surface area of the capillaries in the glomerulus, which decreases the GFR. Conversely, as they relax, the surface area of the capillaries increases, which increases the GFR. This process is called autoregulation and helps to maintain a stable GFR even when there are changes in systemic blood pressure.

In addition to their role in regulating the GFR, mesangial cells are also involved in the formation and maintenance of the extracellular matrix in the glomerulus. They secrete a variety of matrix proteins and proteoglycans that form the scaffolding for the glomerulus. They also remove excess extracellular matrix proteins to prevent excessive accumulation that could impair filtration. Dysfunction of mesangial cells can lead to various kidney diseases, including glomerular sclerosis and mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis.
CL:0000653:
Podocytes are a specialized type of epithelial cell found in the glomerular filter of the kidney. They are also known as visceral epithelial cells or glomerular epithelial cells and play a crucial role in the kidney's ability to filter waste products from the blood and produce urine. Podocytes have complex foot-like processes called pedicels, which interdigitate with those of other podocytes to form a unique structure called the slit diaphragm. This structure functions as a molecular sieve, regulating the size and amount of filtered molecules that pass through the glomerulus.

The proper functioning of podocytes is essential for maintaining renal function. Additionally, they play a crucial role in the maintenance of the structural integrity of the glomerular filter. Diseases affecting podocytes, such as focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) and diabetic nephropathy, can ultimately lead to chronic kidney disease. In these diseases, podocytes become damaged, leading to increased filtration of larger molecules, such as proteins, into the urine. This can result in proteinuria and eventually lead to renal failure.

In summary, podocytes are important specialized cells that play a unique role in the filtration of waste products in the kidney. Their complex foot-like processes and the slit diaphragm they form create a distinct structure that regulates filtration and ultimately maintains renal function. Dysfunction of podocytes can lead to renal failure and is a hallmark of several kidney diseases.
CL:0000652:
Pinealocytes are highly specialized cells located in the pineal gland, which is a small, pinecone-shaped endocrine gland found in the brain. The primary function of the pineal gland is the secretion of melatonin, a hormone that regulates the body's circadian rhythm, or internal biological clock. Pinealocytes are responsible for the synthesis and secretion of melatonin, which is produced through a complex enzymatic process involving the amino acid tryptophan.

Pinealocytes have a unique morphology that sets them apart from other types of cells in the brain. They possess a large number of mitochondria, which are responsible for energy production, and they also have an abundance of microtubules, which are important for cell division and intracellular transport. These features allow pinealocytes to carry out their specialized function of melatonin synthesis and secretion, which is critical for maintaining normal sleep-wake cycles and other biological processes.

In addition to their role in melatonin production, pinealocytes also play a key role in regulating the body's response to environmental cues such as light and dark. The pineal gland is known to be a photoreceptor organ that receives information about light levels from the retina and adjusts melatonin production accordingly. Pinealocytes have specialized light-sensitive proteins called opsins, which allow them to detect changes in light levels and regulate melatonin synthesis accordingly. In this way, pinealocytes are an integral part of the body's complex regulatory system, helping to maintain normal physiological functions and respond to changes in the environment.
CL:0000647:
A multinucleated giant cell (MGC) is an unusual type of cell that forms from the fusion of two or more macrophages or other cells. These cells are typically found in regions of chronic inflammation or infection, where they play a critical role in immune defense and tissue repair. MGCs can have anywhere from two to several hundred nuclei, and their size and shape can vary depending on the tissue in which they are found.

MGCs are best known for their ability to phagocytose foreign materials, such as bacteria and other pathogens, and to present these materials to other immune cells for destruction. They do this through the use of specialized structures called lysosomes, which can break down and digest a wide variety of biomolecules. MGCs are also capable of synthesizing and secreting a range of cytokines, chemokines, and other signaling molecules, which can help initiate and coordinate the immune response.

In addition to their role in immunity, MGCs have been implicated in a number of other physiological and pathological processes. For example, they are commonly seen in certain types of bone and joint disorders, where they can help to resorb damaged or disordered tissue. They are also found in certain types of tumors, where they may play a role in promoting or inhibiting tumor growth. Overall, the study of MGCs is an active area of research, with many exciting avenues for further investigation.
CL:0000577:
Enteroendocrine cells (ECs) are specialized cells found in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract that synthesize and secrete different hormones that coordinate digestive functions within the GI tract. Type EC enteroendocrine cells are one subtype of the enteroendocrine cell family that are found in the small and large intestines. They play a vital role in the regulation of digestion, metabolism and food intake through the production of various hormones and peptides.

Type EC enteroendocrine cells are used to sense and communicate the nutrient status of the intestine to the central nervous system, and other parts of the body that help regulate energy homeostasis. Some of the key hormones that type EC enteroendocrine cells produce include glucagon-like peptide 1 (GLP-1), peptide YY (PYY), and cholecystokinin (CCK), among others. These hormones work together to regulate appetite, glucose metabolism, and the absorption of nutrients in the intestine.

The mechanisms of type EC enteroendocrine cells are complex and difficult to study. With advances in molecular biology technologies, researchers have been able to learn more about these cells than ever before. Understanding the function of type EC enteroendocrine cells has potential implications for treating obesity and diabetes, as well as other disorders that affect the digestive system.
CL:0000654:
A primary oocyte is a germ cell that is a precursor to a mature egg or ovum. These cells are diploid, meaning they contain two sets of chromosomes. Primary oocytes are found in the ovaries of female organisms and are produced during fetal development. While they are present in the ovaries, primary oocytes are arrested in the prophase stage of meiosis I until puberty. During this time, the oocytes are surrounded by a layer of granulosa cells, which form a structure called a primordial follicle and provide support for the oocyte as it develops.

The primary function of a primary oocyte is to eventually develop into a mature egg that can be fertilized by a sperm. This process requires the oocyte to undergo two meiotic divisions - first, meiosis I must be completed to produce a secondary oocyte and a polar body, and then meiosis II occurs after fertilization to produce a mature egg and another polar body. These processes are tightly regulated by hormones and signals from neighboring cells, and any disruption can lead to infertility or developmental abnormalities.

Overall, primary oocytes play a critical role in reproduction and the continuation of species. While they are relatively simple cells, they require a complex network of support cells and signals to develop and differentiate properly. As researchers continue to study the mechanisms behind oocyte development and maturation, new insights could lead to improved fertility treatments and a better understanding of reproductive health.
CL:0000678:
Commissural neurons are specialized cells found in the central nervous system (CNS) and play a crucial role in relaying information between the two hemispheres of the brain by connecting the left and right sides of the CNS. These neurons have an elongated axon that crosses the midline of the body, allowing them to transmit signals across the hemispheres. Commissural neurons are primarily involved in coordinating movement between the two sides of the body and are found throughout the spinal cord and brainstem.

At the molecular level, commissural neurons express specific genes and proteins that allow for their specialized functions. For example, these cells express Netrin-1, a guidance molecule, that aids in the proper growth and guidance of their axons across the midline. Additionally, commissural neurons express unique ion channels and neurotransmitter receptors that allow them to receive and transmit information across the CNS.

In humans, defects in commissural neuron development or function can lead to a range of neurological disorders, including seizures and impaired motor coordination. Understanding the role and molecular mechanisms of commissural neurons is critical for developing therapies to treat these conditions.
CL:0000659:
Eggshell secreting cells are a unique type of cell that are responsible for creating the protective layer that surrounds a developing egg. These cells are found in the ovaries of female organisms that lay eggs, and they play a vital role in ensuring the survival of the developing embryo. Without eggshell secreting cells, the developing embryo would be vulnerable to damage from environmental factors such as predators, parasites, and pathogens.

Eggshell secreting cells are unique in their structure and function. They are responsible for secreting a complex mixture of proteins and other compounds that form the eggshell, which is a specialized extracellular matrix that surrounds the developing embryo. This process is highly regulated and requires the coordinated activity of several different types of eggshell secreting cells to produce a complete and functional eggshell.

While eggshell secreting cells are primarily responsible for creating the protective eggshell, they also play a role in regulating the development of the embryo. They secrete signaling molecules that help to regulate the growth and differentiation of the cells that make up the embryo, ensuring that it develops properly and is able to survive outside of the protective environment of the eggshell. Overall, eggshell secreting cells are an essential component of the reproductive cycle in egg-laying animals, and their function is vital to the survival of these species.
CL:0000671:
Centripetally migrating follicle cells are specialized epithelial cells that are found in the Drosophila melanogaster egg chamber. These cells are involved in the formation of the eggshell and the progression of oogenesis. The follicle cells undergo a coordinated pattern of migration to form a monolayer over the growing oocyte.

The migration of these cells is directed towards the oocyte, which is located at the center of the egg chamber. As the follicle cells migrate, they secrete materials that form the chorion, a protective layer that surrounds the developing embryo. Additionally, the follicle cells also secrete materials that regulate the transport of nutrients and gases into the developing oocyte.

The process of centripetal migration is complex and involves a variety of molecular and cellular mechanisms. Recent studies have identified several key signaling pathways that are involved in the regulation of this process, including the JAK/STAT and EGFR pathways. Dysfunction of these pathways can result in defects in follicle cell migration and eggshell formation, which can lead to infertility and developmental abnormalities. Therefore, centripetally migrating follicle cells are an important cell type that plays an essential role in reproduction and embryonic development.
CL:0000682:
M cells of gut, also known as microfold cells, are specialized epithelial cells found in the intestinal wall, particularly in the Peyer's patches of the small intestine. The primary function of M cells is to transport antigens and microorganisms from the gut lumen into the underlying lymphoid tissue, thus playing a critical role in immune surveillance and defense against pathogens.

The unique morphology of M cells allows them to uptake luminal antigens and transport them to the underlying lymphoid tissue, where immune cells and antigens can interact. M cells have an undulating plasma membrane, which creates deep wrinkles on the apical surface, forming pockets for the entry of microorganisms and antigens. Additionally, M cells have a thin glycocalyx layer and reduced mucus production which further facilitates uptake of antigens.

In addition to their role in antigen transport, it has been suggested that M cells also function as an antigen-sampling gateway for dendritic cells, thus influencing the development of the adaptive immune response. Moreover, M cells may also participate in pathogenesis of various gastrointestinal diseases, including infections and inflammatory bowel disease. Overall, M cells are essential components of the gut-associated lymphoid tissue, contributing significantly to immunity and host defense in the gut.
CL:0000684:
Littoral cells, also known as Kupffer cells, are a type of specialized macrophage cell found within the liver. These cells have a flattened and irregular shape, with long processes extending throughout the hepatic sinusoids. Littoral cells play a crucial role in the immune function of the liver, as they are responsible for filtering and removing foreign particles, such as bacteria and toxins, from the bloodstream that flows through the liver. 

In addition to their immune function, littoral cells are also involved in the regulation of iron metabolism within the liver. These cells express high levels of the protein hepcidin, which inhibits the release of iron from liver stores into the bloodstream. Littoral cells are also involved in the clearance of senescent red blood cells, as they express receptors for the uptake of heme, the byproduct of hemoglobin breakdown. 

Littoral cells are a critical component of the liver microenvironment and are involved in maintaining liver homeostasis. In conditions such as liver disease, littoral cells can become activated and produce pro-inflammatory cytokines, leading to liver injury and fibrosis. Understanding the function of littoral cells is essential in developing therapeutic interventions for liver diseases and in maintaining overall liver health.
CL:0000649:
Prickle cells are specialized cells that are well known for their role in the formation and morphogenesis of organs such as wings, bristles, and hairs in many insects. The cells are named prickle cells because of their characteristic long, thin, and spiky shape, which comes as a result of their long actin-based protrusions. Prickle cells are also found in the vertebrate nervous system and are thought to play a vital role in the development of the brain and the formation of neural circuits.

In insects, prickle cells are necessary for the formation and patterning of the cuticle, which is the exoskeletal structure that provides a protective shield for the insect's body. They are derived from the epidermal cells and often arise from cells that are already specialized to produce a wide range of structures, including bristles and sensory organs. Prickle cells are essential in the sense that they provide a basis for the proper anchoring and alignment of these structures, ensuring that they grow out in the correct direction and at the right angle to the body.

In vertebrates, prickle cells are involved in the formation and maintenance of the nervous system. They are thought to play an essential role in the development of neural circuits by regulating the growth, enlargement, and migration of neurons. Recent studies suggest that prickle cells participate in the signaling pathways that regulate cell adhesion, cell polarity, and cytoskeleton organization. Dysfunction of prickle cells could potentially lead to neural defects, such as neural tube closure defects, impaired brain development, and other neural malformations.
CL:1000450:
Epithelial cells of glomerular capsule, also known as podocytes, are specialized cells that form the inner layer of the renal glomerulus, which is the filtration unit of the kidney. These cells have a complex morphology with interdigitating foot processes that wrap around the glomerular capillaries. The podocyte foot processes are connected to each other by a specialized junctional complex known as the slit diaphragm, which acts as a selective filtration barrier for the passage of proteins and other macromolecules into the urine.

The main function of podocytes is to maintain the integrity of the glomerular filtration barrier and regulate the flow of fluid and solutes across it. Podocytes actively participate in the process of glomerular filtration by controlling the size-selective permeability of the filtration barrier. They also produce and secrete various extracellular matrix proteins, including collagen and laminin, which play a critical role in maintaining the structural integrity of the glomerulus. Furthermore, podocytes are involved in the regulation of glomerular blood flow and the secretion of several growth factors that are essential for the development and maintenance of the kidney.

Dysfunction of podocytes is associated with a range of kidney diseases, including diabetic nephropathy, glomerulonephritis, and nephrotic syndrome. Damage to the podocyte foot processes or the slit diaphragm can result in proteinuria, which is the excessive loss of protein into the urine. Therefore, a better understanding of the biology of podocytes and their role in the pathogenesis of kidney diseases is essential for the development of new therapeutic approaches to treat these conditions.
CL:0000679:
A glutamatergic neuron is a type of nerve cell which utilizes the neurotransmitter glutamate to convey excitatory signals throughout the nervous system. These neurons can be found in a variety of areas throughout the brain, including the cerebral cortex, hippocampus, and cerebellum. They are responsible for a wide range of functions, including learning, memory, and the regulation of movement.

Glutamatergic neurons are characterized by the presence of special synapses known as glutamatergic synapses, which contain specialized receptors for glutamate. When an action potential reaches the presynaptic terminal of a glutamatergic neuron, it triggers the release of glutamate molecules into the synapse. These molecules then bind to the receptors on the postsynaptic cell, triggering an influx of calcium ions and ultimately causing the activation of downstream signaling pathways.

These neurons are essential for normal brain function and are involved in a variety of neurological disorders. For example, the abnormal regulation of glutamatergic signaling has been implicated in conditions such as Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease, and schizophrenia. In addition, drugs that target the glutamatergic system are currently being investigated as potential treatments for these and other neurological disorders.
CL:0002085:
Tanycytes are specialized ependymal cells found in the hypothalamus of the brain. These cells are characterized by their elongated and polarized morphology, with a long basal process extending from the cell body towards the blood vessels and a shorter apical process that reaches the cerebrospinal fluid. Tanycytes are classified into two subtypes: α and β, based on their location and morphology. Alpha tanycytes are located in the ventricular zone, while beta tanycytes are located in the median eminence.

Tanycytes are involved in a variety of functions related to energy homeostasis and hormone regulation. They act as a barrier between the blood and the cerebrospinal fluid, regulating the exchange of molecules across this interface. In the hypothalamus, tanycytes have been shown to transport hormones and nutrients into the brain, including leptin, insulin, and lipids. They can also act as neural stem cells, capable of generating new neurons and glial cells in the hypothalamus.

Moreover, tanycytes are involved in the regulation of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis, which controls the release of hormones such as growth hormone, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and gonadotropins. They can also modulate the activity of neighboring neurons and astrocytes through the release of signaling molecules such as transmitters, cytokines, and growth factors. Overall, the complex functions of tanycytes make them a key player in the regulation of metabolism, neurogenesis, and hormone signaling in the brain.
CL:0000691:
Stellate interneurons are a group of inhibitory neurons found in the cerebellar cortex of the brain. They are named after their distinctive star-shaped dendritic arbors that are characterized by multiple branches extending outwards like the rays of a star. Stellate interneurons play an important role in the regulation of motor coordination and fine-tuning of movement.

Stellate interneurons receive input from both excitatory and inhibitory neurons in the cerebellar cortex and process this information to regulate motor output. They are involved in the control of movements such as posture, balance, and coordination of fine motor skills. Stellate interneurons also play a role in the regulation of eye movements and contribute to the smooth pursuit of moving objects.

Dysfunction of stellate interneurons has been implicated in a variety of neurological disorders, including ataxias and motor impairments. By studying the function of stellate interneurons and their role in motor control, researchers are working to develop new treatments for these disorders. Overall, stellate interneurons are a critical component of the cerebellar circuitry that ensures the accuracy and precision of motor output.
CL:0000690:
R2 photoreceptor cells are a specialized type of cell found in the compound eyes of various insects such as fruit flies. These cells are responsible for detecting light and are key players in the insect's visual pathway. Each compound eye is composed of hundreds of individual units, known as ommatidia, and each ommatidium contains eight R2 photoreceptor cells.

R2 photoreceptor cells have a unique structure that allows them to detect light. They are elongated cells with a thin, cylindrical shape. At the back end of the cell is a nucleus and various organelles, while the front end is covered in microvilli that extend towards the center of the ommatidium. These microvilli contain a protein called Rhodopsin, which is responsible for detecting photons of light.

The function of R2 photoreceptor cells is to detect changes in light intensity and color and to convert this information into electrical signals that can be transmitted to the insect's brain. These cells are particularly sensitive to blue and green light, and play a key role in detecting the edges of objects and in sensing movement. By working together with other types of photoreceptor cells in the compound eye, R2 cells help insects navigate their surroundings and avoid obstacles.
CL:0000686:
Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is a clear, colorless liquid that surrounds the brain and spinal cord, acting as a cushion to protect these vital organs. Cerebrospinal fluid secreting cells, also known as choroid plexus epithelial cells, are responsible for producing the majority of CSF in the central nervous system. These cells are found in the choroid plexus located in the ventricles of the brain.

The primary function of cerebrospinal fluid secreting cells is to maintain the delicate balance of CSF within the central nervous system. They accomplish this by actively transporting ions, glucose, and other essential molecules from the blood into the CSF. Through this process, they also help to remove waste products and excess fluid, which contributes to the stability of intracranial pressure.

Cerebrospinal fluid secreting cells play a critical role in maintaining the homeostasis of the central nervous system. Any disruption in their function can lead to serious neurological conditions, such as hydrocephalus, a condition characterized by an abnormal buildup of CSF in the brain. Studying the function of these cells may provide insights into the causes of neurological diseases and contribute to the development of novel therapeutic approaches.
CL:1000147:
Cardiac valve cells are specialized cells found in the heart valves. These cells are known for their ability to regulate blood flow through the heart by opening and closing the valve leaflets. They serve an important function in ensuring that blood is properly directed through the heart and prevents any backflow of blood. Cardiac valve cells are able to withstand and adapt to the hydrodynamic forces generated by the blood flow making them essential to the overall function of the heart.

Cardiac valve cells are classified into two main types; endothelial cells and interstitial cells. Endothelial cells are the flattened cells that line the surface of the heart valves and form a barrier between circulating blood and valve tissues. They play an integral role in maintaining the structural integrity of the valve by regulating valve permeability and fluid exchange. Interstitial cells, on the other hand, are found in the valve matrix and are responsible for synthesizing and remodeling extracellular matrix components, maintaining tissue homeostasis, and regulating valve mechanics.

Aside from their role in valve function, cardiac valve cells have also been implicated in various cardiovascular diseases. For instance, endothelial dysfunction has been associated with atherosclerosis and calcification of heart valves. Interstitial cells have also been implicated in valve fibrosis and calcification, which can lead to valve stenosis and ultimately, heart failure. Therefore, understanding the molecular mechanisms that regulate cardiac valve cell function could provide important insights into the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of heart valve diseases.
CL:0000674:
Interfollicle cells, also known as follicular dendritic cells, are a type of stromal cells that populate the interfollicular regions of lymphoid follicles. They are characterized by their elongated, dendritic shape and their ability to retain immune complexes on their surface for long periods of time. 

The primary function of interfollicle cells is to trap and display antigen-antibody complexes, which are produced during an immune response. These cells possess specialized stellate processes that are coated with complement receptor 1 (CR1) and Fc receptors, which bind to the complement component C3b and the Fc region of IgG, respectively. This allows them to capture, retain, and display immune complexes on their surface, where they can be recognized and interacted with by B cells. 

Interfollicle cells are essential for the proper functioning of germinal centers, where B cells undergo somatic hypermutation and class switching in response to antigens. By capturing and retaining antigen, interfollicle cells provide a continuous supply of antigen to B cells, which can then use it as a substrate for selection, proliferation, and differentiation. Additionally, they contribute to the establishment of a microenvironment that is rich in survival factors, cytokines, and co-stimulatory molecules, which are critical for the generation and maintenance of high-affinity antibody responses.
CL:0000692:
A terminal Schwann cell is a specialized type of Schwann cell that is found at the neuromuscular junction, which is the point where a motor neuron (nerve cell) meets a muscle cell. Terminal Schwann cells form a cap around the motor neuron's ending, known as the presynaptic terminal, and the muscle cell's membrane, known as the postsynaptic membrane. This cap is known as the motor endplate. 

The function of terminal Schwann cells is to support and maintain the structure and function of the neuromuscular junction. They are involved in the release and reuptake of neurotransmitters, which are chemical signals that allow the motor neuron to communicate with the muscle cell. Terminal Schwann cells also play a role in synapse formation and elimination, which is the process by which synapses are either created or removed depending on the needs of the nervous system. 

In addition to their role at the neuromuscular junction, terminal Schwann cells are also involved in nerve regeneration after injury. They can guide and support the regrowth of damaged motor neurons, which can help to restore function to affected muscles. Overall, terminal Schwann cells play a critical role in the proper function of the nervous system and are essential for healthy muscle movement.
CL:0000683:
Ependymoglial cells are a type of glial cell that lines the ventricles of the brain and the central canal of the spinal cord.
