Thymocytes are involved in the formation of mature T cells, which play a critical role in the immune system. The thymus gland is most active during childhood and adolescence, and it gradually decreases in size and functionality as a person ages.

During their development, thymocytes undergo a process known as thymic selection, which involves the elimination of T cells that are potentially harmful to the body. This process ensures that only T cells that can recognize foreign antigens but not attack the body's own cells will be allowed to mature and function within the immune system. Thymic selection is critical for the prevention of autoimmune diseases, which occur when the immune system mistakenly attacks the body's own cells.

Thymocytes are also involved in the regulation of immune responses. They can differentiate into regulatory T cells, which help to suppress excessive immune responses that can lead to tissue damage. Regulatory T cells play a crucial role in maintaining immune tolerance, preventing the immune system from attacking the body's own tissues. Overall, thymocytes play a critical role in the development and regulation of the immune system, and their dysfunction can lead to a variety of immune-related disorders.
CL:0000811:
CD8-positive, alpha-beta thymocytes are a subtype of T lymphocytes that primarily mature in the thymus. These cells express the CD8 glycoprotein as well as a T-cell receptor (TCR) consisting of an alpha and beta chain. CD8-positive, alpha-beta thymocytes are involved in the adaptive immune response and play a crucial role in clearing intracellular pathogens, such as virus-infected cells or tumor cells.

During their maturation in the thymus, CD8-positive, alpha-beta thymocytes undergo a series of selection processes that ensure their ability to recognize and respond to foreign antigens while avoiding self-reactivity. This process, known as thymic selection, results in the generation of a diverse repertoire of T cells with the ability to recognize a wide range of antigens.

Once they have matured, CD8-positive, alpha-beta thymocytes migrate to the periphery, where they scan for foreign antigens presented on the surface of infected or malignant cells. Upon encountering an antigen, these cells become activated and differentiate into cytotoxic T cells, which are responsible for killing infected or malignant cells. CD8-positive, alpha-beta thymocytes are crucial for the generation of effective immune responses against intracellular pathogens and have been used in adoptive cell therapy for cancer treatment.
CL:0000773:
Eosinophilic metamyelocytes are a specific cell type in the blood that are part of the eosinophil lineage. They are considered as intermediate stages in eosinophil maturation, with further development resulting in a fully mature eosinophil. These cells are characterized by their condensed nuclear chromatin and eosinophilic granules, which are secretory vesicles responsible for the cell's function. The eosinophilic metamyelocyte plays a vital role in the immune system's response against parasitic infections, allergic reactions, and inflammatory responses.

One of the primary functions of the eosinophilic metamyelocyte is to produce cytokines that control the recruitment and activation of other immune cells to a site of inflammation. The cytokines produced by these cells can modulate the activity of other immune cells, such as monocytes, macrophages, and T cells. Moreover, the eosinophilic metamyelocyte plays a specific role in combating parasitic infections by releasing enzymes, including major basic protein, eosinophilic cationic protein, eosinophil peroxidase, and eosinophil-derived neurotoxin, among others. These secretory vesicles work together to degrade the cell membrane of parasites, neutralizing and killing them.

In addition to their role in fighting infections, eosinophilic metamyelocytes are frequently implicated in allergenic responses. Activated eosinophilic metamyelocytes migrate to a site of inflammation in response to chemotactic signals and release cytokines and enzymes that contribute to the initiation and persistence of these inflammatory responses. Excessive or uncontrolled activation of these cells may lead to chronic inflammation, tissue damage, and various health complications. Further study of eosinophilic metamyelocytes may lead to a better understanding of allergy and parasitic responses, leading to novel immune-based therapies.
CL:0000805:
Immature single positive thymocytes are a type of immune cell that is found in the thymus gland. These cells are characterized by their single positive expression of either CD4 or CD8 antigens. Immature single positive thymocytes are the precursor cells of mature T-cells and their role is critical in the development and maturation of the immune system.

During the process of T-lymphocyte development, immature single positive thymocytes are formed from their precursors, the CD4/CD8 double positive thymocytes. At this stage of development, they undergo a series of selection processes to ensure their functional capabilities before maturing into either CD4 or CD8 T-cells. Immature single positive thymocytes that pass the selection process will proceed to the maturation stage in which they will express CD4 or CD8 as their single positive antigen.

Immature single positive thymocytes play a crucial role in the function of the immune system by providing a pool of progenitor cells for the production of mature T-cells. These cells undergo a series of developmental processes that are essential for the normal functioning of the immune system and are critical in the activation of immune response in the presence of foreign pathogenic agents. Immature single positive thymocytes also contribute to the diversity of T-cell receptors that is essential for the immune system to identify and respond to a wide range of pathogenic agents.
CL:0000906:
Activated CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells are a subset of T lymphocytes that are known for their potent cytotoxic activity against various infected or transformed cells. These cells are characterized by the presence of CD8 glycoprotein on their surface, which enables them to respond to antigens presented by MHC class I molecules. Upon activation, these cells undergo clonal expansion and differentiation, ultimately resulting in the generation of a large population of effector CD8 T cells that can efficiently eliminate target cells through a variety of mechanisms.

CD8 T cells recognize and kill virally infected cells as well as cancerous cells, making them critical components of the immune system's response to infection and cancer. The cells accomplish this by releasing cytotoxic granules, expressing pro-apoptotic molecules such as FAS ligand, as well as via release of interferon-gamma and other cytokines that recruit and enhance the function of other immune cells. Activated CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells are also capable of differentiating into long-lived memory CD8 T cells, important for maintaining immunological memory that enables more rapid and efficient responses to secondary infections.

In summary, activated CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells play a crucial role in host defense against infectious agents and malignant cells. These cells are selectively activated upon recognition of specific antigen-derived peptides presented by MHC class I molecules and possess the capacity to proliferate, differentiate into effector and memory cells, and kill infected or transformed cells. Their prominent role in cellular immunity makes them attractive targets for development of immunotherapies against a range of diseases.
CL:0000799:
Immature gamma-delta T cells are a unique subset of T cells with distinct features. They are a small population of lymphocytes found mainly in thymus, peripheral blood, and lymphoid tissues. They express the gamma-delta T cell receptor (TCR), which recognizes and binds to non-peptide antigens. Unlike mature alpha-beta T cells, these cells do not require antigen processing and recognition by MHC molecules to become activated. Instead, they can directly recognize and respond to a broad range of ligands, including lipids, proteins, and other small molecules. 

The function of immature gamma-delta T cells is not fully understood. However, studies suggest that they play a crucial role in innate immunity and tissue homeostasis. They can directly kill infected or malignant cells, produce cytokines, and recruit other immune cells to the site of infection or injury. In addition, they are involved in the regulation of immune responses by interacting with dendritic cells and modulating the function of other immune cells, such as B cells and conventional T cells. 

In summary, immature gamma-delta T cells are a unique subset of T cells that can directly recognize and respond to a broad range of antigens without the need for antigen processing and presentation. They have an important role in innate immunity and tissue homeostasis, and their function is regulated by interactions with other immune cells. Further research on the molecular mechanisms underlying their activation and function will contribute to a better understanding of their role in health and disease.
CL:0000788:
Naive B cells are a type of lymphocyte that are a critical component of the adaptive immune system. These B cells are known as "naive" because they have not yet encountered their specific antigen and undergone activation. They are produced in the bone marrow and circulate through the blood and lymphatic system until they encounter their specific antigen, at which point they become activated and differentiate into plasma cells. Naive B cells play a key role in the primary immune response, which is the initial response to a new infection.

The main function of naive B cells is to recognize and respond to pathogens by producing antibodies. Antibodies are proteins that specifically bind to antigens on pathogens, allowing the immune system to neutralize or eliminate the pathogen. Naive B cells are able to recognize a wide variety of different antigens, thanks to their diverse antigen receptors. When a naive B cell encounters its specific antigen, it becomes activated and undergoes clonal expansion, producing a large number of clones that can then differentiate into either plasma cells or memory B cells.

In addition to producing antibodies, naive B cells also play a role in the regulation of the immune response. They are able to interact with other immune cells, such as T cells and dendritic cells, to help coordinate the response to a pathogen. Naive B cells can also differentiate into regulatory B cells, which have immunomodulatory functions and help prevent autoimmune diseases. Overall, naive B cells are a vital component of the adaptive immune system, playing a key role in the primary immune response and contributing to the regulation of immune function.
CL:0000806:
DN2 thymocytes are a subset of T cell precursors that reside in the thymus and play a crucial role in T cell development. They are characterized by their lack of expression of CD4 and CD8, and their expression of c-Kit and CD44. DN2 thymocytes arise from DN1 thymocytes and give rise to DN3 thymocytes, which further differentiate to eventually give rise to mature T cells. 

The main function of DN2 thymocytes is to undergo proliferation and rearrangement of their TCR genes in order to generate a diverse pool of T cells that are capable of recognizing a broad range of foreign antigens. During this process, DN2 thymocytes undergo a series of checkpoints that ensure the proper development of the TCR repertoire. This includes selection for functional TCRβ chains and signaling through the pre-TCR complex, which is necessary for survival and further differentiation of thymocytes. 

In addition to their role in generating a diverse pool of T cells, recent studies have also suggested that DN2 thymocytes may be involved in regulating the development of other T cell subsets, such as regulatory T cells and invariant natural killer T cells. Specifically, it has been proposed that DN2 thymocytes may influence the generation of these cell types through the production of specific cytokines and by serving as a reservoir of precursor cells. Overall, DN2 thymocytes play a crucial and dynamic role in T cell development and function.
CL:0000796:
CD8-alpha-beta-positive, alpha-beta intraepithelial T cells (CD8αβ IELs) are a type of immune cell that is found primarily in the epithelial layer of the intestine. These cells are distinguished by the expression of the CD8 protein and the alpha-beta T cell receptor. This population of T cells is able to recognize and respond to foreign antigens, making them critical for defense against pathogens and maintaining gut homeostasis. 

CD8αβ IELs play an important role in immune surveillance and protection against invading pathogens. These cells are highly responsive to viral infections and can detect and eliminate infected cells. They also play a role in maintaining the integrity of the intestinal barrier. CD8αβ IELs are able to secrete cytokines and produce cytotoxic mediators that can target and destroy malignant cells. This property has made them an important target in cancer research, with the hope of harnessing their ability to recognize and kill tumor cells. 

In addition to their protective role, CD8αβ IELs have been implicated in the development of autoimmune diseases. Dysregulation of these cells has been linked to inflammatory bowel disease, celiac disease, and other autoimmune disorders. Understanding the biology of CD8αβ IELs is critical for developing new therapies and strategies for the treatment of these debilitating diseases. Overall, CD8αβ IELs play a critical role in immune surveillance, protection against pathogens, maintenance of gut homeostasis, and the development of autoimmune diseases.
CL:0002042:
Immature natural killer T cells, or iNKT cells, are a subset of T cells that are critical in the early stages of the immune response. Within the iNKT cell population, there are four distinct stages of development. The fourth stage, known as immature NK T cell stage IV, is characterized by the expression of both NK receptors and T cell receptors.

Immature NK T cell stage IV cells are found primarily in the thymus and spleen, where they undergo further differentiation and maturation before entering the peripheral circulation. During this process, iNKT cells are thought to play a key role in the development of tolerance to self-antigens as well as in the recognition and elimination of foreign pathogens.

One of the unique features of iNKT cells is their ability to rapidly produce large amounts of cytokines in response to stimulation. This property makes them important effectors in various immune processes, including antitumor and antiviral responses. In addition to their direct effector functions, iNKT cells also play an important regulatory role in the immune system, influencing the activity of other immune cells and promoting or inhibiting immune responses as needed.Overall, immature NK T cells stage IV are a critical component of the immune system, supporting both innate and adaptive immune responses while maintaining a delicate balance between tolerance and immunity.
CL:0000814:
Mature NK T cells are a unique subset of T lymphocytes that express markers typically found in both T and NK cell lineages. They are characterized by the expression of the NK cell marker NK1.1 and the T cell receptor (TCR). They recognize glycolipid antigens presented by the non-classical MHC-I molecule CD1d, which triggers their rapid production of cytokines such as interferon-gamma and their cytotoxic activity. 

Mature NK T cells play an important role in both innate and adaptive immunity. They are involved in the regulation of immune responses by regulating dendritic cells, natural killer cells, and other immune cells. They are also involved in the recognition and clearance of certain types of tumors and virally infected cells. Additionally, mature NK T cells are thought to play a role in the prevention and development of autoimmune diseases, although the exact mechanisms involved are not yet fully understood. 

The unique properties of mature NK T cells make them an attractive target for immunotherapy in diseases such as cancer and infectious diseases. However, their low frequency in the blood and peripheral tissues presents a significant challenge for their isolation and expansion for clinical use. Nonetheless, the elucidation of the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying their development and function continues to provide important insights into the regulation of immune responses, and the potential for manipulating these cells for therapeutic purposes.
CL:0000954:
Small pre-B-II cells are the cells from the B cell lineage that are in the immediate developmental stage prior to becoming B cells. They are characterized by their small size, polygonal shape, scanty cytoplasm, and oval nuclei. These cells arise from the IL-7 receptor alpha-expressing progenitors and undergo proliferation and differentiation toward the pre-B-II cells. 

The primary function of the small pre-B-II cells is to begin the process of forming mature B cells. They differentiate into large pre-B cells, which then develop into immature B cells and ultimately into naive B cells. During this process, the cells undergo rearrangements of immunoglobulin heavy and light chain genes, which leads to the production of immunoglobulins or antibodies. Thus, the small pre-B-II cells play a critical role in the adaptive immune response by producing B cells that can recognize and neutralize pathogens.

In addition to their role in B cell development, small pre-B-II cells have been linked to certain diseases such as acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It has been observed that overexpression of certain genes in these cells can lead to the development of ALL. Furthermore, the study of small pre-B-II cells has contributed significantly to the understanding of the mechanisms of B cell development and differentiation. Therefore, small pre-B-II cells are an essential cell type that is critical for the proper functioning of the immune system and the prevention of diseases.
CL:0000782:
Myeloid dendritic cells (mDCs) are a specialized subset of dendritic cells that play a critical role in the initiation and regulation of adaptive immune responses. These cells derive from the common myeloid progenitor and are primarily found in peripheral tissues, particularly in those that are exposed to the external environment, such as the skin, respiratory tract, and gastrointestinal tract. mDCs are characterized by their ability to capture and process antigens, migrate to regional lymph nodes, and present antigens to T cells.

The primary function of mDCs is to capture and process antigens from pathogens or other sources, such as dying cells or tissues undergoing stress or damage. mDCs are equipped with specialized receptors and pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) that allow them to recognize and respond to a wide range of molecular patterns associated with pathogens or tissue damage. Once activated, mDCs undergo a process of maturation, which involves upregulation of costimulatory molecules and major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules, and migration to regional lymph nodes where they present captured antigens to T cells.

The ability of mDCs to present antigens and activate T cells is central to their role in initiating and regulating adaptive immune responses. Upon encountering antigen-specific T cells, mDCs stimulate their proliferation, differentiation, and effector functions, such as the production of cytokines and cytotoxic molecules. In addition, mDCs can also induce tolerance and immune suppression through a process known as regulatory T cell induction. Overall, the unique functions of mDCs make them important targets for therapeutic strategies aimed at modulating immune responses in a wide range of inflammatory and autoimmune disorders.
CL:0000838:
Lymphoid lineage restricted progenitor cells (LRPs) are hematopoietic stem cells that give rise to all mature lymphocytes, including B cells, T cells, and natural killer cells. These cells are considered to be at an intermediate stage between hematopoietic stem cells and committed lymphocyte progenitors, and are identified by the expression of surface markers such as Flt3 and Ly6D. LRPs differentiate into lymphoid progenitors, which can then further differentiate into the different types of mature lymphocytes.

LRPs play a vital role in the immune system by generating a diverse population of lymphocytes. B cells are responsible for producing antibodies against pathogens, while T cells can directly kill infected cells or help to activate other immune cells. Natural killer cells are important for recognizing and eliminating virus-infected and cancer cells. Differentiation of these lymphocytes from LRPs is tightly regulated and involves a complex interplay of transcription factors and signaling molecules.

Aberrant development of LRPs can lead to immune dysfunction and diseases such as leukemia and lymphomas. Understanding the molecular mechanisms involved in LRP differentiation and function can help identify new targets for the development of immunotherapies and treatments for these diseases.
CL:0000809:
Double-positive, alpha-beta thymocytes are immature T cells that are found in the thymus gland. These cells are characterized by the expression of both CD4 and CD8 surface markers, hence the term "double-positive". Double-positive, alpha-beta thymocytes undergo a process of positive and negative selection in the thymus, resulting in the formation of mature T cells with either CD4 or CD8 expression, and recognition of self-antigens.

During positive selection, double-positive, alpha-beta thymocytes are exposed to self-peptides presented by major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules on the surface of thymic epithelial cells. Those thymocytes that recognize and interact with self-peptides displayed on MHC class I molecules receive a survival signal to develop into CD8+ T cells, while those that recognize self-peptides presented on MHC class II molecules develop into CD4+ T cells.

In addition to positive selection, double-positive, alpha-beta thymocytes also undergo negative selection to eliminate autoreactive T cells that would cause autoimmune diseases. During negative selection, thymocytes that recognize self-peptides with high affinity are eliminated through apoptosis or silenced by regulatory T cells. This process ensures the survival and function of T cells that recognize foreign antigens with high specificity and minimal reactivity against self-antigens. Thus, double-positive, alpha-beta thymocytes play a crucial role in establishing self-tolerance and promoting immune homeostasis.
CL:0000937:
Pre-natural killer cells are a type of lymphocyte that are precursors to natural killer cells. They are generated in the bone marrow and then move to the thymus where they mature. Unlike natural killer cells, pre-natural killer cells express T-cell receptors on their surface and therefore have been classified as a type of T-cell. 

Pre-natural killer cells play an important role in the immune system, as they are responsible for recognizing and eliminating infected or abnormal cells. They accomplish this by releasing cytotoxic molecules such as granzymes and perforin that cause apoptosis in target cells. Additionally, pre-natural killer cells can produce cytokines that stimulate other cells of the immune system.

Research has shown that pre-natural killer cells may also have a role in regulating immune responses. Studies have identified unique subsets of pre-natural killer cells that have different functions, including the ability to mediate inflammatory responses or suppress immunity. This complexity underscores the importance of understanding the functions of all cell types in the immune system in order to develop effective therapies for diseases.
CL:0000802:
CD8-alpha alpha positive, gamma-delta intraepithelial T cells are a type of T cell found in the epithelial layer of various tissues, including the skin, gut, and reproductive tract. These cells are characterized by the expression of the CD8-alpha alpha homodimer and the gamma-delta TCR, which are unique among T cell subsets. CD8-alpha alpha positive, gamma-delta intraepithelial T cells play an important role in mucosal immunity by recognizing and responding to a variety of pathogens, including bacteria, viruses, and parasites.

Studies have shown that CD8-alpha alpha positive, gamma-delta intraepithelial T cells are involved in the regulation of epithelial homeostasis and contribute to the maintenance of mucosal barrier integrity. These cells have been shown to protect against infection by producing cytokines and cytotoxic molecules that directly target infected or damaged cells. In addition, they have been implicated in the regulation of local immune responses by serving as a source of IL-17, IL-22, and other cytokines that can recruit other immune cells to the site of infection.

Overall, CD8-alpha alpha positive, gamma-delta intraepithelial T cells are a critical component of the innate immune system and provide a first line of defense against mucosal pathogens. Their ability to respond rapidly to infection and regulate local immune responses makes them an important target for immunotherapies and vaccine development. Further research into the mechanisms by which these cells function could lead to the development of more effective treatments for a variety of mucosal infections and inflammatory diseases.
CL:0000822:
B-2 B cells, also known as conventional B cells, are a type of lymphocyte that play a crucial role in the adaptive immune system. These cells are derived from hematopoietic stem cells in the bone marrow and are responsible for producing antibodies that can recognize and neutralize specific pathogens. B-2 B cells express unique surface receptors called B cell receptors (BCRs), which bind to specific antigens and initiate signaling pathways that activate the cell to proliferate and differentiate, ultimately leading to the generation of high-affinity antibodies.

Once activated, B-2 B cells undergo clonal expansion and somatic hypermutation, resulting in the production of a diverse repertoire of antibody molecules. These antibodies can then bind to antigens on the surface of pathogens, marking them for destruction by other cells in the immune system or by the antibodies themselves. B-2 B cells can also differentiate into long-lived plasma cells, which secrete large amounts of antibodies into the bloodstream, providing long-term protection against future infections.

In addition to their role in pathogen clearance, B-2 B cells have also been implicated in the development of autoimmune diseases, where they produce autoantibodies that attack healthy tissues. Understanding the function and regulation of B-2 B cells is crucial for the development of vaccines and immunotherapies against infectious diseases and for the treatment of autoimmune disorders.
CL:0000787:
Memory B cells are a type of lymphocyte that play a vital role in the body's immune response. These cells are generated in response to an initial infection or vaccination and linger in the body, ready to quickly respond if the same pathogen is reintroduced. Memory B cells are produced in the germinal centers of lymph nodes during the course of an immune response. Unlike their naïve counterparts, memory B cells exhibit low levels of cell division, differentiated cell markers, and alterations to their antigen receptors. 

When a pathogen enters the body for a second time, memory B cells are activated and quickly produce antibodies that are specific to the pathogen. This response is faster and more robust than the initial response, providing protection against the pathogen with minimal symptoms. Memory B cell differentiation is also known never to quality control the constant region of the B cell receptor after its initial assembly. This allows the antibodies to be generated quickly without the need for B cells to go through the whole process of assembly, which can take time. 

The role of memory B cells in defending against pathogens has seen them become a vital tool in the development of effective vaccines. Inactivated or attenuated pathogens can be used to stimulate the immune response, generating a pool of memory B cells specific to the pathogen, and long-lasting immunity. Furthermore, the use of monoclonal antibodies has been shown to recognize and influence the activity of specific B cell receptors for a given antigen when memory B cells of the same specificity are not prevalent. Thus, the application of memory B cells for the advancement of the protection against infections and the fight against disease, such as cancer, makes them a key player in the study of immunology.
CL:0000794:
CD8-positive, alpha-beta cytotoxic T cells are key players in the adaptive immune response. These specialized cells are a subtype of T lymphocytes that actively seek and destroy virus-infected or cancerous cells within the body. Upon activation, they migrate to the site of infection or tumor and recognize specific antigens presented by the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I molecules on the surface of their target cells. CD8+ T cells use their T-cell receptors (TCR) to recognize the antigen-MHC complex and initiate a killing response, resulting in the elimination of the infected or malignant target cells.

The primary function of CD8+ T cells is to kill infected or malignant cells, making them crucial for the body's defense against pathogens and cancer. Activated CD8+ T cells are able to kill target cells using two main pathways: the perforin/granzyme pathway and the Fas/FasL pathway. The perforin/granzyme pathway involves the release of cytolytic granules containing perforin and granzyme. Perforin creates pores in the target cell membrane, allowing granzyme to enter the target cell and induce apoptosis. The Fas/FasL pathway, on the other hand, involves the interaction of Fas on the target cell surface with FasL on the CD8+ T cell surface, leading to target cell apoptosis.

CD8+ T cells also play an important role in immunological memory. After successfully eliminating a pathogen or cancer cell, a subset of CD8+ T cells becomes memory cells, which can persist in the body for a long time. These memory cells provide a rapid and effective response upon re-encountering the same pathogen or cancer cell, allowing for a more efficient and targeted immune response.
CL:0000798:
Gamma-delta T cells are a subset of T lymphocytes that possess a distinct T cell receptor (TCR) consisting of γ and δ chains, instead of the conventional α and β chains. These cells are found in tissues such as the skin, gut, and lungs, and have been shown to play a crucial role in early immune responses against infections and tumors. Gamma-delta T cells are considered to be part of the innate immune system, as they respond rapidly to antigens in a non-specific manner, independently of antibodies or major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules.

One of the main functions of gamma-delta T cells is to provide a first-line of defense against infectious agents. These cells are able to recognize and respond to a diverse range of bacterial, viral, and fungal antigens, including molecules that are conserved across different pathogens. Gamma-delta T cells can secrete a variety of cytokines and chemokines, and can directly kill infected cells through the release of cytotoxic molecules such as perforin and granzymes. This makes them important players in the control of infections at mucosal surfaces, where they are particularly abundant.

Besides their role in immunity against pathogens, gamma-delta T cells can also modulate responses to tumors and tissue damage. Some studies have suggested that these cells may be involved in the recognition and elimination of tumor cells, particularly in cases where conventional αβ T cells are ineffective. Gamma-delta T cells are also known to participate in wound healing and repair, and have been shown to promote tissue regeneration and angiogenesis. Overall, gamma-delta T cells are a fascinating and versatile class of immune cells that continue to attract the interest of researchers and clinicians alike.
CL:0000793:
CD4-positive, alpha-beta intraepithelial T cells (CD4+ IELs) are a specialized subset of T cells that reside in the epithelial layer of the gut mucosa. These cells are believed to play a crucial role in maintaining gut homeostasis and promoting immune tolerance to dietary and microbial antigens. CD4+ IELs are characterized by expression of the CD4 surface marker, which distinguishes them from other intraepithelial T cells that lack CD4 expression. Additionally, CD4+ IELs express the alpha-beta T cell receptor, which allows them to recognize and respond to a wide array of antigens.

One of the key functions of CD4+ IELs is to promote epithelial barrier function. These cells produce cytokines such as TGF-beta and IL-10 that stimulate the production of mucus and antimicrobial peptides by epithelial cells, which helps to prevent invasion by harmful pathogens. CD4+ IELs also help to regulate the growth and differentiation of epithelial cells, which is important for maintaining the integrity of the gut barrier. Additionally, CD4+ IELs are thought to play an important role in immune tolerance by suppressing the activation of other immune cells in response to harmless antigens.

CD4+ IELs have also been implicated in the pathogenesis of several gastrointestinal diseases. For example, in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), there is a marked decrease in the number of CD4+ IELs in the gut mucosa, which contributes to chronic inflammation and tissue damage. In celiac disease, CD4+ T cells specific for gluten peptides drive the destruction of epithelial cells in the small intestine, leading to malabsorption and other symptoms. Thus, understanding the function and regulation of CD4+ IELs may have important implications for the development of novel strategies for treating gastrointestinal diseases.
CL:0000821:
B-1b B cells are a subtype of B cells that belong to the innate immune system. These cells are characterized by the expression of CD5, a surface marker that distinguishes them from conventional B cells. B-1b B cells are primarily found in the peritoneal and pleural cavities, but they can also be present in the spleen and bone marrow. These cells are known to produce natural antibodies that provide immediate protection against pathogens and can participate in the clearance of apoptotic cells and tissue repair.

In addition to their antibody production, B-1b B cells have been found to play an important role in regulating immune responses. These cells can produce cytokines and chemokines that can influence the activation and differentiation of other immune cells, such as T cells and dendritic cells. Studies have shown that B-1b B cells can also interact with other cell types, such as NK cells, and participate in the recognition and response to viral and bacterial infections.

Because B-1b B cells are part of the innate immune system, they have a unique function in host defense and immune regulation. While conventional B cells require activation by antigen to produce antibodies, B-1b B cells are able to produce natural antibodies that provide immediate protection against pathogens. Moreover, by interacting with other immune cells and producing cytokines and chemokines, B-1b B cells can shape the overall immune response and contribute to immune homeostasis.
CL:0000807:
DN3 thymocytes are immature precursor cells that develop in the thymus, a small organ located in the upper chest, and are critical for the production of T cells, which are an essential component of the immune system. These cells are classified by their surface markers, as they lack expression of both CD4 and CD8 co-receptors, but express the CD25, CD44, and CD117 surface markers. DN3 thymocytes are important for the process of T cell receptor (TCR) gene rearrangement, which  results in a diverse repertoire of T cells that can recognize a wide range of foreign molecules.

The differentiation of DN3 thymocytes is a tightly regulated process that is controlled by many signaling pathways. When the signal from the TCR engages a peptide-major histocompatibility complex (MHC) on thymic epithelial cells, DN3 thymocytes that do not interact effectively with peptide-MHC complexes undergo programmed cell death (apoptosis). However, those DN3 thymocytes that interact correctly mature to the DN4 stage and undergo further differentiation into CD4+ and CD8+ αβ lineage T cells.

Research has shown that DN3 thymocytes play an important role in cancer immunotherapy, as these cells can be manipulated ex vivo to generate large numbers of T cells that can be infused into patients. Additionally, understanding the molecular mechanisms that regulate T cell development, including DN3 thymocytes, may lead to new therapies for immune system disorders such as autoimmune diseases, immunodeficiencies and cancer. Hence, studies on DN3 thymocytes continue to elucidate the fundamental mechanisms that regulate immunity, paving the way for improved diagnosis and treatment of various diseases.
CL:0000894:
DN1 thymic pro-T cell is a progenitor cell that belongs to the T cell lineage and is found in the earliest stage of thymic development. These cells comprise approximately 5% of all thymocytes and are CD4-CD8- double negative. They are known to possess self-renewal and differentiation capabilities and can give rise to all T cell subtypes. DN1 thymic pro-T cells differentiate into the DN2 stage after receiving survival signals from Notch signaling, which is a crucial pathway for T cell development.

The role of DN1 thymic pro-T cells in T cell development is crucial, as they initiate the formation of the T cell lineage at the earliest stage of thymic development. They are responsible for the development of the T cell receptor (TCR) repertoire, which is required for recognizing foreign antigens. DN1 cells undergo several rounds of cell division before they exit the DN stage. During this process, they undergo receptor gene rearrangement to generate a diverse TCR repertoire. DN1 stage T cells also contribute to the formation of the pre-T cell receptor complex, which is required for survival and differentiation of T cell precursors.

In conclusion, DN1 thymic pro-T cells play a significant role in the development of the T cell lineage by generating a diverse TCR repertoire and contributing to the formation of the pre-T cell receptor complex. These cells possess self-renewal and differentiation capabilities and give rise to all T cell subtypes. Hence, a better understanding of DN1 thymic pro-T cells will allow us to develop novel therapies for T cell-dependent diseases.
CL:0000823:
Immature natural killer cells, also known as NK cells, are a type of lymphocyte that play an important role in the immune system. These cells are characterized by their lack of membrane-bound B cell receptor or T cell receptor, and their ability to recognize and kill infected or abnormal cells without prior antigen exposure. They develop in the bone marrow and undergo a process of maturation and activation before they are able to perform their functions effectively.

The function of immature NK cells is to provide rapid and nonspecific immune responses against viruses, bacteria, and cancer cells. These cells are capable of recognizing and eliminating other cells that have reduced levels of self-major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I molecules, which are commonly downregulated in infected or abnormal cells. This activity is vital in the early stages of pathogenic infection, as it prevents the spread of infected cells and allows for the coordination of the immune system to elicit a more specific and effective response.

In conclusion, immature natural killer cells are an essential component of the immune system that provide rapid and nonspecific immune responses against infections and abnormal cells. Their ability to recognize and eliminate cells with reduced self-MHC class I expression makes them an important first line of defense against pathogenic invasion. As we continue to learn more about immune cell function and behavior, we may gain a better understanding of how to harness the power of these cells for therapeutic purposes.
CL:0000801:
Gamma-delta intraepithelial T cells (γδ IEL) are a unique subset of T cells that reside specifically in the epithelial lining of various tissues in the body including the skin, intestines, and lungs. These specialized T cells make up around 5-10% of the T cells found in the epithelium. One of the main functions of γδ IELs is to serve as a first line of defense against pathogens, particularly in areas where the epithelial barrier is weak and prone to infection.

γδ IELs are unique compared to other T cell subsets because they express a distinct T cell receptor (TCR) composed of γ and δ chains instead of the typical α and β chains. This unique TCR allows γδ IELs to recognize and respond to a wide range of antigens, including lipid and glycolipid compounds. γδ IELs also have a strong cytotoxic activity against infected cells and have been shown to play a role in tumor immunosurveillance.

In addition to their immune functions, γδ IELs have also been shown to play a role in tissue homeostasis and repair. They are involved in the regulation of epithelial cell turnover in the intestines and lungs, and have been shown to have a higher proliferation rate than other T cells in the epithelium. Overall, γδ IELs are an important component of the immune system and play an essential role in maintaining the health and integrity of epithelial tissues throughout the body.
CL:0000800:
Mature gamma-delta T cells are a subset of T cells that express T cell receptors (TCRs) composed of gamma and delta chains. These cells are unique among T cells, as they display a tissue-specific distribution pattern and have shown to play a crucial role in both innate and adaptive immune responses. Gamma-delta T cells can be found in various tissues such as the skin, lung, liver, and intestine, and they are particularly abundant in the epithelium, where they serve as the first line of defense against infections and tumors.

The function of mature gamma-delta T cells is highly diverse and multifaceted. They have been shown to mediate direct cytotoxicity against infected or tumor cells, activate other immune cells such as dendritic cells and B cells, and produce various cytokines and chemokines to modulate the immune response. Moreover, gamma-delta T cells can recognize various ligands, such as stress-induced antigens and non-peptide metabolites, which makes them highly reactive to certain types of pathogens. This unique feature of gamma-delta T cells makes them ideal candidates for immunotherapy, as these cells can be manipulated to target specific antigens.

In summary, mature gamma-delta T cells are a unique subset of T cells that have shown to be crucial in immunity and are responsible for several innate immune functions. They play an essential role in immunosurveillance, and their antitumor activity has made them a focal point of research into cancer immunotherapy.
CL:0000808:
DN4 thymocytes are a subset of immature T cells that originate from DN3 thymocytes and continue to differentiate into DN5 thymocytes. In general, thymocytes are T cell precursors that develop within the thymus gland. DN4 thymocytes are characterized by the absence of cell surface markers CD4 and CD8, and the presence of CD25 and CD44. These cells are critically important in the process of T cell development and are responsible for generating diverse T cell repertoires capable of recognizing and responding to a wide range of pathogens.

During T cell development, DN4 thymocytes undergo signaling events that instruct them to differentiate into either CD4+ or CD8+ T cells, which are important in mediating both cellular and humoral immune responses. Specifically, DN4 thymocytes undergo a process of lineage commitment known as beta-selection. This process is characterized by the expression of a functional T cell receptor (TCR) and selection against TCR-mediated apoptosis. Only those cells that successfully complete beta-selection will proceed to the next stage of T cell development.

In summary, DN4 thymocytes are a critical stage of T cell development that are responsible for generating diverse T cell repertoires capable of responding to a wide range of pathogens. These cells are characterized by the absence of CD4 and CD8 markers, and the presence of CD44 and CD25. During development, DN4 thymocytes undergo beta-selection, a process that ultimately determines whether they will differentiate into CD4+ or CD8+ T cells.
CL:0001082:
An immature innate lymphoid cell is a type of white blood cell that belongs to the innate immune system. These cells are found in lymphoid tissues such as the tonsils and spleen, and they play a crucial role in the early stages of the immune response. Immature innate lymphoid cells do not have a specific receptor on their surface that would recognize a particular pathogen, but they possess a wide range of pattern recognition receptors that allow them to detect molecules that are characteristic of pathogens, such as bacterial or viral components.

Upon detecting a pathogenic molecule, immature innate lymphoid cells quickly differentiate into effector cells that are specialized in killing the invading pathogen or activating other immune cells to fight the infection. Like other innate immune cells, immature innate lymphoid cells do not have the ability to recognize and remember a specific pathogen, which means that they cannot provide long-term protection against a particular infection. However, they are involved in the initiation of the adaptive immune response, which provides long-lasting protection against pathogens through the production of antibodies and memory cells.

Overall, immature innate lymphoid cells are an important component of the innate immune system. Their ability to respond quickly to pathogens and activate other immune cells makes them critical for the defense against infections. While they do not provide long-term protection, they play a crucial role in the early stages of the immune response, and their interactions with other immune cells are essential for a successful immune response.
CL:0000817:
A precursor B cell, also known as a pro-B cell, is a type of hematopoietic stem cell that emerges in the bone marrow of mammals. It is an early stage in B cell development, occurring after the pro-B cell stage and before the pre-B cell stage. Precursor B cells are characterized by the presence of certain proteins, such as the surface antigen CD19, on their cell membranes. They also express genes encoding enzymes, transcription factors, and other proteins that are essential for B cell maturation and immunoglobulin gene rearrangement.

The main function of precursor B cells is to differentiate into mature B cells, which produce antibodies and play a critical role in the adaptive immune response. During the pro-B to pre-B transition, precursor B cells undergo a process called V(D)J recombination, in which the genes that encode the antigen-binding region of the B cell receptor (BCR) are rearranged. As the cells progress through the pre-B stage, they produce a functional BCR and undergo further maturation, eventually giving rise to naive B cells that can respond to foreign antigens.

In addition to their role in B cell development, precursor B cells interact with other cells in the bone marrow microenvironment and respond to various signals from cytokines and chemokines. They also have the capacity to proliferate and differentiate into different cell types under certain conditions, such as during infections or immunodeficiency disorders. Precursor B cells play a critical role in maintaining normal immune function and are a key target in the development of therapies for immune-related diseases.
CL:0000846:
Vestibular dark cells are a type of cell found within the inner ear, specifically in the vestibular organs. These cells are named for their dark appearance due to the abundance of melanin within their cytoplasm. Vestibular dark cells are believed to be a subtype of glial cells known as type II vestibular supporting cells. 

The precise function of vestibular dark cells is not fully understood, but they are thought to play a role in regulating the ion composition of the endolymph fluid within the inner ear. In particular, vestibular dark cells are capable of secreting potassium ions, which helps to maintain the proper ion balance necessary for optimal function of sensory hair cells within the vestibular system. Additionally, vestibular dark cells may play a role in the regeneration of damaged sensory hair cells within the inner ear.

Research into the precise function of vestibular dark cells is ongoing, but these cells are believed to be crucial for proper hearing and balance. Dysfunction of these cells, either through genetic mutations or damage, can lead to hearing loss and balance disorders such as vertigo and dizziness. Further study of vestibular dark cells may lead to new treatments for these conditions and a deeper understanding of the inner workings of the ear.
CL:0002489:
Double negative thymocytes (DNTs) are a subset of cells in the thymus that lack both CD4 and CD8 cell surface markers. These cells are considered to be at an early stage of T cell development and are characterized by their high proliferation rate and sensitivity to apoptosis. DNTs play an important role in T cell repertoire development by undergoing a process of positive and negative selection in the thymus.

During positive selection, DNTs interact with thymic stromal cells presenting self-peptides in the context of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules. If DNTs recognize self-peptides with high affinity, they differentiate into CD4 or CD8 single positive T cells and exit the thymus to become part of the peripheral T cell repertoire. If DNTs do not recognize self-peptides or recognize them with low affinity, they undergo negative selection and are eliminated by apoptosis. This process is crucial in preventing autoimmunity and ensuring that the T cell repertoire is self-tolerant.

In addition to their role in T cell development, DNTs have been shown to play a role in immune responses to viral infections. Studies have shown that DNTs can be activated by cytokines such as interleukin-2 (IL-2) and interferon-gamma (IFN-gamma) and can produce cytokines such as IL-4 and IL-10. DNTs have also been shown to have cytotoxic activity against virus-infected cells. However, the exact mechanisms by which DNTs contribute to viral immunity are still not fully understood and require further investigation.
CL:0000845:
Marginal zone B cells of the spleen are a subset of B lymphocytes that reside in the marginal zone between the red and white pulp of the spleen. These cells have a unique phenotype, expressing high levels of cell surface markers including CD19, CD21, CD23, and CD1d, and low levels of CD1c. Marginal zone B cells play a critical role in the immune response to blood-borne pathogens by providing a first line of defense against bacterial and viral infections.

Upon encountering foreign antigens, these cells rapidly differentiate and secrete high levels of antigen-specific antibodies. Beyond their role in antibody production, marginal zone B cells also participate in the clearance of cellular debris, apoptotic bodies, and immune complexes circulating in the bloodstream. Additionally, these cells can present antigens to other immune cells, including T lymphocytes and dendritic cells, through antigen presentation pathways.

Dysregulation of marginal zone B cells has been implicated in several autoimmune diseases as well as in the progression of certain types of cancers. Therefore, understanding the mechanisms underlying the development, maintenance, and function of marginal zone B cells is of great interest to researchers in the field of immunology.
CL:0000840:
Immature conventional dendritic cells (cDCs) are a type of antigen-presenting cell that plays a vital role in innate and adaptive immune responses. cDCs arise from bone marrow hematopoietic stem cells and differentiate into immature precursors that are present in tissues such as skin, lymph nodes, and spleen. These cells are characterized by their dendritic protrusions, which help them to capture antigens from the environment. 

Once an antigen is captured, cDCs undergo a process called maturation, which involves upregulation of MHC molecules, co-stimulatory receptors, and cytokine secretion. These changes allow cDCs to present the captured antigen to T cells and activate them. Immature cDCs, however, are not yet fully capable of this function and mainly act as antigen capture cells. 

In addition to activating T cells, cDCs also play a role in inducing immune tolerance, or immunological unresponsiveness. Immature cDCs can capture self-antigens and present them to T cells without activating them, leading to T cell anergy (a state of unresponsiveness). Therefore, immature cDCs are essential in maintaining peripheral tolerance and preventing autoimmune responses. Hence, cDCs hold a unique position between innate and adaptive immunity and are fundamental in shaping the appropriate immune response.
CL:0000851:
Neuromast mantle cells are specialized cells found in the sensory organs of aquatic vertebrates called neuromasts. These cells surround the hair cells which are responsible for detecting movements and vibrations in water. Neuromast mantle cells provide structural support to the hair cells and are themselves highly innervated by afferent and efferent nerve fibers. 

In addition to providing structural support, neuromast mantle cells also play a crucial role in regulating the development and regeneration of the hair cells. Studies have shown that these cells secrete factors that promote the proliferation and differentiation of hair cell progenitors, thereby contributing to the regeneration of damaged hair cells. Moreover, neuromast mantle cells have been shown to respond to changes in the mechanical environment by altering their shape and orientation, thus helping to maintain the sensitivity of the sensory organ to water movements.

Overall, neuromast mantle cells are essential for the function and maintenance of the sensory organs in aquatic vertebrates. Their intricate relationship with the hair cells and dependence on afferent and efferent nerve fibers highlights the complexity of sensory systems and underscores the importance of understanding the cellular mechanisms underlying such systems. Further research into the molecular and cellular nature of neuromast mantle cells may provide insights into their potential therapeutic applications in the treatment of sensory disorders.
CL:0000832:
Eosinophilic myeloblasts are a group of immature cells that are part of the eosinophil lineage in the bone marrow. They are characterized by their large size, round nucleus, and prominent nucleoli. Eosinophilic myeloblasts are involved in the production of eosinophils, which are a type of white blood cell that plays a crucial role in the immune system.

Eosinophilic myeloblasts differentiate into eosinophils through a complex process that involves several stages of maturation. During this process, the cells undergo a number of morphological and functional changes that are necessary for their proper development. Eosinophilic myeloblasts are capable of producing cytokines and growth factors that regulate their own growth and differentiation, as well as that of other cells in the immune system.

Eosinophilic myeloblasts perform a number of important functions in the body. They are primarily involved in the defense against parasitic infections, as well as in the regulation of allergic responses and inflammatory reactions. Eosinophilic myeloblasts are also involved in the maintenance of tissue homeostasis, and play a role in the repair and regeneration of damaged tissues. Overall, eosinophilic myeloblasts are critical for the proper functioning of the immune system, and their dysfunction can lead to a variety of diseases and disorders.
CL:0000826:
Pro-B cells are a type of hematopoietic stem cell that differentiate into B cells, one of the major types of lymphocytes. Hematopoietic stem cells reside in the bone marrow and give rise to all blood cells. Pro-B cells are a very early stage in B cell development and are characterized by the expression of certain markers on their surface, including CD43 and CD117. These cells undergo a series of developmental stages, ultimately leading to the production of mature B cells that can produce antibodies.

Pro-B cells play a critical role in the immune system. When the body encounters an antigen, such as a virus or bacteria, pro-B cells jump into action to generate B cells that can recognize and neutralize the threat. During B cell development, pro-B cells undergo rearrangement of their immunoglobulin genes to generate unique antigen receptors. This process, known as V(D)J recombination, is essential for generating B cells with diverse antigen specificities. Pro-B cells also require signaling from other cells and cytokines to continue their development and maturation.

Dysregulation of pro-B cell development can have significant consequences for human health. For example, defects in V(D)J recombination can lead to immunodeficiency, making individuals more susceptible to infections. Abnormalities in B cell development and maturation can also contribute to the development of autoimmune diseases and hematological malignancies, such as leukemia and lymphoma. Thus, a thorough understanding of pro-B cell biology is critical for developing new therapies to combat these diseases.
CL:0000847:
Ciliated olfactory receptor neurons (ORNs) are specialized cells responsible for detecting odorants in the air. These neurons are found in the olfactory epithelium, a specialized tissue located in the nasal cavity. Ciliated ORNs are named for the hair-like structures, known as cilia, that extend from their surface. These cilia act as sensors, detecting odorants and initiating the process of odor perception. 

Ciliated ORNs are highly specialized cells that play a critical role in the sense of smell. When an odorant binds to a receptor on a cilia, it triggers a series of events that result in the production of an electrical signal. This signal is then transmitted to the olfactory bulb, a structure located at the base of the brain. The olfactory bulb processes this signal, allowing us to perceive and identify different odors. 

The ability to detect different odors is essential for many animals, including humans. In addition to allowing us to enjoy the smells of our surroundings, our sense of smell is also closely tied to memory and emotion. Some research suggests that loss of the sense of smell may be an early indicator of certain neurological conditions, making the study of ciliated ORNs and the mechanisms of olfactory perception an important area of research.
CL:2000074:
Splenocytes are a type of lymphocyte that are found in the spleen, an organ located in the upper left abdomen. The spleen is part of the immune system and is responsible for filtering the blood and removing damaged or old red blood cells. There are two main types of splenocytes: B cells and T cells.

B cells are a type of white blood cell that create antibodies, proteins that specifically target and bind to foreign substances in the body. When a foreign substance, or antigen, is detected in the body, B cells are activated and begin to produce antibodies that target the antigen. These antibodies either directly neutralize the antigen or mark it for destruction by other immune cells. B cells are an integral part of the adaptive immune system and are essential for fighting infections.

T cells are another type of white blood cell that are involved in cell-mediated immunity. They are responsible for recognizing and killing infected cells and cancer cells. T cells can also help activate other immune cells, such as B cells, and coordinate the immune response. There are different types of T cells, including helper T cells and cytotoxic T cells, each with a specific function in the immune system.

Overall, splenocytes play a critical role in the immune system by identifying and destroying foreign substances and infected cells in the body. Dysfunction of splenocytes can lead to decreased immunity and increased susceptibility to infections.
CL:0000860:
Classical monocytes are a type of white blood cell with a distinctive kidney bean-shaped nucleus. These monocytes are produced in the bone marrow and represent approximately 90% of the total monocyte population. They are also known as CD14++CD16- monocytes, reflecting their surface markers. 

Classical monocytes play a crucial role in the innate immune response, acting as scavengers of cellular debris and clearing away dead or damaged cells. They are also involved in the process of phagocytosis, in which they engulf and digest foreign substances such as bacteria or viruses. Due to their ability to migrate into tissues and differentiate into macrophages, classical monocytes are essential for the functioning of the immune system. 

In addition to these roles, classical monocytes are also implicated in the development of inflammatory responses. They can produce and release pro-inflammatory cytokines and chemokines that attract other immune cells to the site of infection or injury. This process can lead to the activation of the adaptive immune response, in which specific antibodies are produced to target the pathogen. By performing these functions, classical monocytes play an important role in protecting the body from foreign invaders and maintaining overall health.
CL:0000829:
Basophilic myeloblast is a type of white blood cell that is involved in the immune response. It is an immature precursor cell that gives rise to basophils, which play a role in allergy and inflammation, as well as other types of granulocytes that are involved in fighting infection. Basophilic myeloblast cells are identified by their high concentration of basophilic granules in the cytoplasm, which stain blue or purple with basic dyes.

Basophilic myeloblasts are found in the bone marrow, where they undergo a process of differentiation and maturation to become fully functional granulocytes. This process involves changes in their morphology, gene expression, and biochemical properties. Basophilic myeloblasts have a high rate of proliferation, which allows for rapid production of mature cells in response to infection or other immune challenges.

In addition to their role in the immune system, basophilic myeloblasts are also being studied for their potential use in cancer therapy. Recent research has shown that these cells can be engineered to express chimeric antigen receptors (CARs) that target cancer cells, allowing them to be used as a tool for targeted immunotherapy. Overall, the study of basophilic myeloblasts is an important area of research that has implications for both basic science and clinical medicine.
CL:0000843:
Follicular B cells are a subset of B lymphocytes that are primarily found in the splenic germinal centers and lymph nodes. These cells are responsible for generating antibodies against pathogens that have entered the body's circulation. Follicular B cells respond to antigens that are presented on the surface of follicular dendritic cells by clonal expansion and differentiation into antibody-secreting plasma cells and memory B cells.

Follicular B cells are characterized morphologically by the presence of elongated nuclei and cytoplasmic projections. They also express a signature set of surface markers that distinguish them from other subpopulations of B lymphocytes. These include CD19, CD20, CD21, and CD23. Follicular B cells are involved in the humoral immune response, which is mediated by the production of antibodies by plasma cells that are derived from these cells.

In addition to their role in antibody production, follicular B cells also play an important role in maintaining germinal center structure and function. They provide critical support for the proliferation and survival of T follicular helper cells, which are necessary for the production of high-affinity antibodies. Follicular B cells also interact with other immune cells, such as macrophages and dendritic cells, to promote an efficient and coordinated immune response. The function of follicular B cells in immune regulation and pathogenesis of autoimmune diseases is an area of active research.
CL:0000837:
Hematopoietic multipotent progenitor cells (HMPs) are a type of stem cell that resides in the bone marrow and gives rise to all types of blood cells. Their differentiation potential allows them to generate erythrocytes, platelets, myeloid, and lymphoid cells. In essence, HMPs are the precursor cells that initiate the hematopoietic cascade, making them crucial to the replenishment of the human body's blood cell population. 

When HMPs begin to differentiate, they can differentiate into multiple blood cell lineages and produce numerous progenitors in a predictable way. Hematopoietic transcription factors, such as GATA-1, c-MYB, and PU.1, have essential roles in HMP proliferation and differentiation. The correct interplay between these transcription factors regulates lineage-specific gene expression and determines the fate of HMPs. 

HMPs are vital in hematopoietic recovery following bone marrow transplantation, chemotherapy, or injury. Mesenchymal stromal cells and cytokines, such as stem cell factor (SCF) and thrombopoietin (TPO), regulate HMP differentiation and self-renewal. A better understanding of the precise mechanisms that govern HMP differentiation provides insights into various clinical applications. Therapies that target HMPs can help improve hematopoietic regeneration in individuals with bone marrow disease or cytoablative therapy-induced stem cell depletion.
CL:0000852:
Neuromast supporting cells are specialized epithelial cells that provide essential structural and functional support to the neuromasts - sensory organs found in the skin of fish and some amphibians. These cells are responsible for maintaining the equilibrium of the animal and protect the mechanoreceptor hair cells present in the neuromasts.

They are typically arranged in a ring-like structure surrounding a centrally located group of hair cells (nerve cells with small hair-like projections that detect motion) protruding into a gelatinous matrix. Neuromast supporting cells form tight junctions with each other, creating a barrier that separates the hair cells and fluid in the matrix from surrounding tissues and prevents the loss of the gelatinous matrix substance. These tight junctions are also necessary for maintaining the delicate pressure balance inside the neuromasts, which is necessary for the hair cells to work properly.

Moreover, neural communication between the hair cells and their surrounding supporting cells is critical for balance control. Neuromast supporting cells are thought to help regulate the electrical activity in the hair cells, and also perform a crucial role in regenerating the hair cells if they become damaged through injury or aging processes. In conclusion, neuromast supporting cells play a fundamental role in maintaining the balance and sensory perception of animals through their support and protection of the hair cells of neuromasts.
CL:0002169:
Basal cells of the olfactory epithelium are responsible for continually regenerating the olfactory receptor neurons (ORNs) throughout an individual's life. Found in the neuroepithelium, basal cells proliferate and differentiate into either supporting cells or ORNs. When ORNs are damaged, either by injury or aging, basal cells divide and differentiate into new ORNs, ensuring the sense of smell remains functional.

In addition to their regenerative function, basal cells play a key role in sustaining the olfactory epithelium. They secrete extracellular matrix components and maintain a microenvironment important for ORN survival. Basal cells also produce various cytokines and growth factors that help to mediate the interaction between the olfactory epithelium and the underlying lamina propria.

Despite the importance of basal cells in olfactory function, they are relatively understudied when compared to ORNs. Recent studies have begun to shed light on the molecular mechanisms governing basal cell differentiation and regenerative capabilities. A better understanding of the basal cell population could have important implications for treating disorders of the olfactory system, including anosmia (loss of smell) and hyposmia (reduced ability to smell).
CL:0000856:
Neuromast hair cells are sensory cells found in the lateral line system of fish and amphibians. These specialized cells are responsible for detecting changes in water pressure and vibrations, and thus play a critical role in the detection of prey, predators, and obstacles in the aquatic environment. Neuromast hair cells are highly specialized, being able to sense frequencies ranging from a few hertz to several kilohertz, making them important for the detection of both subtle and sudden changes in their surroundings.

The structure of neuromast hair cells is unique, consisting of a hair bundle of mechanosensitive stereocilia that are organized in a staircase-like pattern. When water pressure causes the stereocilia to move, this triggers the opening of ion channels, leading to the influx of calcium ions and the subsequent release of neurotransmitters. These neurotransmitters then signal to the nervous system and allow the fish or amphibian to perceive changes in their environment.

Interestingly, neuromast hair cells have the capacity to regenerate after damage, which is believed to be a protective mechanism against environmental stresses such as pollution and physical trauma. Their regenerative capacity has also made them a model system for studying the mechanisms of regeneration and the potential applications of regenerative medicine. Overall, neuromast hair cells are remarkable sensory cells that play an important role in the detection of environmental stimuli in aquatic animals.
CL:0001201:
B cells are a type of white blood cells that are an integral part of the immune system, playing a crucial role in the humoral immune response. They are generated in the bone marrow and undergo a maturation process before being released into the circulation. These cells express a variety of cell surface receptors, including CD19, CD21, and CD79a, which are important for their activation and function.

B cells play a central role in antibody-mediated immunity, where they produce antibodies in response to an antigenic challenge. The antibodies produced by B cells bind to the antigen, neutralizing or clearing it from the body. CD19 is a transmembrane protein that plays a crucial role in the activation, proliferation, and survival of B cells. It acts as a co-receptor, working with the B cell receptor to initiate downstream signaling cascades that lead to antibody production. CD19-positive B cells are important in the immune response against infectious agents, as well as in the recognition and clearance of abnormal cells, such as cancer cells.

In addition to their role in antibody-mediated immunity, CD19-positive B cells play an important role in regulating the immune response. They can serve as antigen-presenting cells (APCs), presenting antigens to T cells and facilitating their activation. This process is important in the development of immunological memory, where the immune system can remember previous encounters with antigens and mount a more effective response upon secondary exposure. In summary, CD19-positive B cells are a key component of the immune system, working to recognize and clear pathogens, as well as regulate the immune response through antigen presentation.
CL:0000844:
Germinal Center B cells are a subtype of B lymphocytes that are found primarily in the germinal centers of secondary lymphoid tissues such as lymph nodes and spleen. They are characterized by their expression of activation-induced cytidine deaminase (AID), which plays a key role in generating the high-affinity antibodies that are crucial for effective humoral immune responses.

In response to antigens, naive B cells undergo clonal expansion and differentiation, giving rise to both short-lived plasma cells and long-lived memory B cells. Germinal Center B cells play a central role in this process by undergoing somatic hypermutation, in which the antibody genes are randomly mutated at a high frequency, and class-switch recombination, which changes the class of the antibody being produced. These processes allow for the generation of a diverse repertoire of high-affinity antibodies that can target a wide range of pathogens.

Germinal Center B cells are also involved in a process known as affinity maturation, in which cells that produce antibodies with higher affinity for the antigen are selectively expanded and those with lower affinity are eliminated. This process contributes to the generation of highly specific and effective antibody responses. Overall, Germinal Center B cells are key players in the adaptive immune response, serving to generate diverse and highly specific antibody responses to a wide variety of pathogens.
CL:0000824:
Mature natural killer (NK) cells are a type of cytotoxic lymphocyte, which are important members of the innate immune system, recognizing and eliminating infected or aberrant host cells without prior sensitization. Natural killer cells are derived from the common lymphoid progenitor, the same precursor that gives rise to B and T lymphocytes. The development of NK cells involves a series of differentiation stages, resulting in mature effector cells that can rapidly respond to viral infections or tumors. NK cells are widely distributed throughout the body, residing in various tissues including the spleen, liver, lung, and bone marrow.

One of the key functions of mature NK cells is their ability to recognize and kill target cells which have downregulated or lost their MHC class I molecules. MHC class I is normally expressed on the surface of healthy cells and is responsible for presenting normal cellular peptides to T lymphocytes, which subsequently results in the rejection of abnormal or infected cells. However, some pathogens and tumors have evolved mechanisms to downregulate MHC class I expression, evading detection by T lymphocytes. This is where NK cells come into play, as they have the unique ability to recognize and kill these abnormal cells without the need for MHC class I recognition.

In addition to their cytotoxic function, mature NK cells also play a critical role in the regulation of the immune response, producing cytokines and chemokines that help to activate and recruit other immune cells. Mature NK cells secrete cytokines such as IFN-γ, TNF-α, and GM-CSF, which stimulate the activation and differentiation of other cells such as macrophages, dendritic cells, and T lymphocytes. Thus, mature NK cells act as important modulators of the immune response, helping to coordinate the activity of different immune cells in response to infection or tissue damage.
CL:0000853:
Olfactory epithelial supporting cells are non-neuronal cells that play a crucial role in the function of the olfactory system, which is responsible for our sense of smell. These cells are found within the olfactory epithelium, a specialized tissue located in the upper part of the nasal cavity. Their function is primarily to provide structural support and nourishment to the olfactory receptor neurons, which are responsible for detecting odorants in the air.

In addition to their supportive role, olfactory epithelial supporting cells also play a key role in the regeneration of olfactory receptor neurons. These cells are capable of dividing and differentiating into new olfactory receptor neurons, which is important for maintaining our sense of smell throughout our lives. Moreover, olfactory epithelial supporting cells secrete mucus that protects the delicate olfactory receptor neurons from environmental insults such as toxins and pathogens.

Recent research has also uncovered potential therapeutic applications of olfactory epithelial supporting cells in the treatment of neurological disorders. These cells have been found to be capable of secreting factors that promote the growth and survival of neurons, which could be beneficial for treating conditions such as Parkinson's disease. Overall, olfactory epithelial supporting cells are a vital component of the olfactory system and are essential for the perception of smell and proper olfactory function.
CL:0002031:
Hematopoietic lineage restricted progenitor cells (HLPs) are a type of stem cell found in the bone marrow that give rise to various types of blood cells, including red and white blood cells and platelets. They are considered multipotent, meaning they have the potential to differentiate into a limited number of cell types within a specific lineage, in this case, the hematopoietic lineage. HLPs are characterized by the expression of certain cell surface markers, such as CD34 and CD38.

The differentiation of HLPs is tightly regulated, with signals from the microenvironment playing a crucial role in determining their fate. Hematopoietic growth factors, such as erythropoietin and granulocyte colony-stimulating factor, can stimulate the proliferation and differentiation of HLPs into mature cells. HLPs can differentiate into several types of progenitor cells, including common myeloid progenitors and common lymphoid progenitors.

Understanding the biology of HLPs has important clinical implications. Dysregulation of HLP differentiation can lead to hematological disorders, such as leukemia and aplastic anemia. Therapeutic interventions aimed at restoring or enhancing HLP differentiation have been developed and hold promise for the treatment of these disorders. Overall, HLPs are a critical component of the hematopoietic system, playing a vital role in the maintenance of blood-cell homeostasis.
CL:0000885:
Gut-associated lymphoid tissue macrophages, abbreviated as GALT macrophages, are specialized immune cells that reside in the mucosal layers of the gastrointestinal tract. These cells play a significant role in protecting the body from harmful pathogens by identifying, engulfing, and destroying foreign particles and microorganisms. The GALT macrophages are found throughout the gastrointestinal tract, including the stomach, small intestine, colon, and appendix.

GALT macrophages are known for their ability to recognize a wide range of antigens presented by various pathogens that enter the body through the gut. Upon encountering any foreign particles, these cells produce multiple cytokines and chemokines, thus alerting other immune cells about the presence of a potential threat. In addition to this, GALT macrophages have the ability to recruit other immune cells to the gut through the secretion of chemoattractants.
