They also play a vital role in maintaining the gut's homeostasis by mediating the clearance of apoptotic cells and cellular debris.

Apart from its involvement in host defense mechanisms, GALT macrophages have been known to contribute to several inflammation-related conditions such as inflammatory bowel disease, where the immune cells are recruited to the gut and secrete cytokines that contribute to tissue damage and fibrosis. Owing to their pivotal role in regulating gut homeostasis, GALT macrophages present a potential therapeutic target for several inflammatory gut diseases.
CL:0000849:
Crypt olfactory receptor neurons (cORNs) are a subtype of olfactory sensory neurons (OSNs) found in the olfactory epithelium. These specialized neurons are responsible for detecting volatile molecules that are inhaled through the nasal cavity. Unlike other OSNs, cORNs are located within crypts that extend deep into the underlying tissue, and they project their axons to different regions of the olfactory bulb compared with that of other OSNs. The function of the crypt structure is not yet completely understood, but cORNs are thought to play a role in detecting specific odorants that other OSNs may not be able to detect.

CORNs are highly sensitive to odorants and are capable of detecting even very low concentrations of volatile molecules. They rely on a family of G protein-coupled receptors, known as olfactory receptors, which are located on the cilia that protrude from the apical end of the neurons. When an odorant molecule binds to a specific receptor, it triggers a cascade of events that ultimately lead to the generation of an electrical signal, which is transmitted to the olfactory bulb. This signal is then interpreted by the brain to perceive specific smells.

The identification and characterization of different classes of OSNs, including cORNs, have provided important insights into the mechanisms of olfactory perception. While much is still unknown about the crypt structure and the precise role of cORNs in olfactory perception, ongoing research focuses on understanding the unique properties of these neurons and how they contribute to our sense of smell.
CL:0000854:
Interneuromast cells are a type of non-sensory cells found in neuromasts, which are clusters of hair cells that detect water movement and help fish and amphibians perceive their surroundings. These cells have a unique structure that allows them to interact with other cells and play key roles in neuromast function. Interneuromast cells are typically located at the base of neuromasts, and they are involved in a variety of functions related to sensory biology.

One important function of interneuromast cells is to provide structural support for neuromasts. These cells produce extracellular matrix proteins that help anchor the neuromast to surrounding tissues. Without these cells, neuromasts would not be able to remain in place and function properly. In addition to providing structural support, interneuromast cells also play a role in maintaining the ionic composition of the endolymph, the fluid that surrounds the hair cells. This is important because hair cells rely on specific ion concentrations to function properly, and changes in ion levels can affect their sensitivity to water movement.

Interneuromast cells also have a role in sensory transduction. They are thought to act as intermediaries between the hair cells and other cells involved in sensory signaling, such as neural cells. These cells may be involved in modulating the sensitivity of the hair cells, as well as in transmitting signals from the sensory organs to the nervous system. Overall, interneuromast cells are important players in the complex biology of sensory systems, helping to keep neuromasts functioning properly and allowing animals to sense their environment.
CL:0000867:
Secondary lymphoid organ macrophages are a crucial component of the immune system, residing within secondary lymphoid organs such as lymph nodes, spleen, and tonsils. These macrophages play an essential role in regulating the immune response by engulfing and presenting antigens to T and B cells. This interaction between macrophages and lymphocytes is vital for the activation of the adaptive immune response, allowing the body to mount a defense against invading pathogens.

One of the primary functions of secondary lymphoid organ macrophages is to clear cellular debris, apoptotic cells, and foreign particles from the lymphatic fluid. These macrophages also have the unique ability to recognize specific antigens on pathogens and present them to T cells, which helps activate the adaptive immune response. In addition to antigen presentation, these macrophages also secrete cytokines, growth factors, and other molecules that help regulate the immune response.

Secondary lymphoid organ macrophages are found in specific locations within these organs, including the subcapsular sinus and medullary cords in lymph nodes. These macrophages express a unique set of markers, including CD11c, CD11b, and F4/80. Through their involvement in antigen processing and presentation, these macrophages play a vital role in the prevention of autoimmune diseases, infection, and cancer. Overall, secondary lymphoid organ macrophages form a crucial part of the immune system by regulating immune responses and maintaining homeostasis within the body.
CL:0000886:
Nasal and bronchial associated lymphoid tissue macrophages, or NALT/BALT macrophages, are specialized immune cells found in regions of the respiratory system that are particularly vulnerable to pathogens. These include the nasal cavity, trachea, and bronchi, which are lined with mucous membranes that trap and filter foreign particles before they can enter the lungs. NALT/BALT macrophages play a critical role in the innate immune response by engulfing and destroying these trapped particles, including bacteria, viruses, and environmental toxins.

In addition to their role in pathogen clearance, NALT/BALT macrophages also play a critical role in the adaptive immune response by presenting antigens to other immune cells, such as T and B cells. When these cells encounter a specific antigen, NALT/BALT macrophages help to activate and direct their responses, allowing for a targeted and efficient immune response.

Overall, the specialized functions of NALT/BALT macrophages make them an essential component of the host defense system in the respiratory system, helping to maintain the integrity of the airways and stave off infections.
CL:0000841:
Mature conventional dendritic cells (cDCs) are professional antigen-presenting cells that play an essential role in the initiation of a primary immune response. These cells are derived from hematopoietic stem cells and are found in lymphoid and non-lymphoid tissues. Mature cDCs possess a unique capacity to capture antigens in peripheral tissues, migrate to secondary lymphoid organs, and present antigen peptides to T cells, thus initiating an adaptive immune response against invading pathogens.

The process of dendritic cell maturation is driven by a range of activating signals, including cytokines and pathogen-associated molecular patterns. Upon maturation, cDCs upregulate the expression of crucial co-stimulatory molecules, such as CD80 and CD86, and major histocompatibility complexes (MHC) class I and II, to effectively present antigen peptides to T cells. Additionally, cDCs produce a range of cytokines that help to direct the differentiation of T cells into effector or memory cells, thus tailoring the immune response to the antigenic insult.

Mature cDCs are essential for the maintenance of immune tolerance and the prevention of autoimmunity. These cells play a crucial role in the clearance of pathogens, including viruses, bacteria, and parasites, and are critical for the induction of protective immune responses against infections. Moreover, cDCs have been implicated in the pathogenesis of a range of diseases, including cancer, autoimmune disorders, and inflammatory bowel disease, highlighting the importance of this specialized cell type in the maintenance of human health.
CL:0000869:
Tonsillar macrophages are a type of immune cell found in the tonsils. They are part of the innate immune system and play an important role in the body's defense against infection and disease. Tonsillar macrophages are derived from monocytes and are characterized by their ability to engulf and digest foreign particles, such as bacteria, viruses, and other pathogens. They are also involved in the clearance of dead and damaged cells from the tonsils.

Tonsillar macrophages are able to recognize and respond to a wide range of pathogens, including bacteria, viruses, and fungi. They do this through the use of pattern recognition receptors (PRRs), which are specialized proteins on their cell surfaces that detect specific types of molecules associated with pathogens. Once a pathogen is detected, tonsillar macrophages will engulf and digest it through a process known as phagocytosis.

In addition to their role in fighting infection, tonsillar macrophages also play a role in maintaining the balance of the immune system. They are involved in the regulation of T cells, which are important immune cells that help to coordinate the body's response to infection. Tonsillar macrophages can present antigens to T cells, helping to activate or suppress their function as needed. Overall, the function of tonsillar macrophages is crucial for the proper functioning of the immune system and the body's defense against infection and disease.
CL:0000819:
B-1 B cells are a distinct subtype of B lymphocytes that have a unique phenotype, tissue distribution, and functional characteristics. These cells are primarily found in the peritoneal and pleural cavities, as well as in the intestinal lamina propria and other mucosal-associated lymphoid tissues. B-1 B cells are distinguished from conventional B cells by their expression of specific surface markers, including CD5 and CD11b, and their ability to self-renew and differentiate into antibody-secreting plasma cells without requiring T cell help. 

One of the main functions of B-1 B cells is the production of natural antibodies, also called "innate" or "germ-line" antibodies, which provide a first line of defense against common pathogens, such as bacteria and viruses. These antibodies are often polyreactive, meaning they can recognize and bind to multiple antigens with low affinity, but also have broad specificity and can recognize conserved structures that are shared among different pathogens. Therefore, B-1 B cells contribute to the innate immune response and play a key role in the early stages of infection, before the adaptive immune system has had time to mount a specific response. 

Besides their role in antibody production, B-1 B cells also have immunomodulatory functions and can influence the activity of other immune cells. For example, B-1 B cells can secrete factors, such as IL-10 and TGF-beta, that promote the differentiation of regulatory T cells and dampen inflammation. They can also present antigens to T cells and contribute to the activation of the adaptive immune response when needed. Overall, B-1 B cells are a fascinating and important cell type that have many unique features and functions that still need to be fully understood.
CL:0000862:
Suppressor macrophages are a type of immune cell that play a crucial role in regulating inflammation and preventing excessive immune response. These cells are derived from monocytes and are known for their ability to suppress the function of other immune cells, including T cells, B cells, and natural killer cells. Suppressor macrophages are particularly important in limiting the activity of these cells during chronic infections, autoimmune diseases, and cancer.

One of the primary mechanisms by which suppressor macrophages regulate immune function is through the production of anti-inflammatory cytokines, such as interleukin-10 (IL-10), transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta), and prostaglandin E2 (PGE2). These cytokines act on other immune cells to inhibit their activity and prevent excessive inflammation. In addition, suppressor macrophages can directly interact with other immune cells and trigger their apoptosis or induce a state of anergy, rendering them unresponsive to further activation signals.

Furthermore, suppressor macrophages have been shown to play an important role in promoting tissue repair and regeneration. In response to tissue damage or injury, these cells migrate to the affected area and promote the clearance of dead cells and tissue debris. They also release growth factors and extracellular matrix components, which promote the proliferation and differentiation of stem and progenitor cells, ultimately leading to the formation of new tissue. Because of their dual role in regulating immune function and promoting tissue repair, suppressor macrophages are a promising therapeutic target for a range of diseases, including chronic infections, autoimmune disorders, and tissue injuries.
CL:0000861:
Elicited macrophages are a specific subset of macrophages that are induced to migrate into tissues in response to inflammation or infection. These specialized cells arise from circulating monocytes and are recruited to the site of injury or infection by chemokine signaling. Once at the site, elicited macrophages play a key role in the immune response by engulfing and clearing pathogens, damaged cells, and debris through phagocytosis.

In addition to their phagocytic functions, elicited macrophages also have an important role in regulating inflammation. They are able to produce a wide range of cytokines and chemokines that activate and recruit other immune cells to the site of injury, and also help to orchestrate the resolution of inflammation by producing anti-inflammatory mediators. This ability to switch between pro- and anti-inflammatory states makes elicited macrophages a critical component of the immune response, helping to balance the need to contain and eliminate pathogens with the need to limit tissue damage and promote healing.

Overall, elicited macrophages are a highly specialized cell type that play a key role in both innate and adaptive immune responses. Their ability to migrate to inflamed tissues and balance pro- and anti-inflammatory signaling make them a critical component of the immune response to infection and injury.
CL:0000865:
Gastrointestinal tract (lamina propria) macrophages are a type of immune cell that resides in the lamina propria layer of the gastrointestinal tract. These macrophages are responsible for a variety of functions related to immune defense and tissue homeostasis. Their location within the gut allows them to effectively monitor and respond to any foreign antigens that may enter the body through food or other means.

One of the primary functions of gastrointestinal tract (lamina propria) macrophages is to phagocytose and clear any pathogens or debris that are present in the gut. This process helps to prevent infection and inflammation by removing potentially harmful substances before they can cause damage to the body. In addition to their phagocytic activity, these macrophages play an important role in regulating the immune response in the gut. They produce cytokines and other signaling molecules that help to coordinate the activities of other immune cells and modulate inflammation.

Gastrointestinal tract (lamina propria) macrophages also have a role in maintaining tissue homeostasis within the gut. They are involved in the clearance of apoptotic cells and cellular debris, which helps to prevent the accumulation of waste products that can lead to tissue damage and inflammation. Additionally, these macrophages play a role in tissue repair and regeneration, as they are able to produce growth factors and cytokines that promote the growth and differentiation of gastrointestinal epithelial cells. Overall, gastrointestinal tract (lamina propria) macrophages are a critical component of the gut immune system and play a vital role in maintaining the health and function of the gastrointestinal tract.
CL:0000863:
Inflammatory macrophages, also called M1 macrophages, are a type of immune cell that plays a crucial role in initiating and promoting inflammation in response to an infection, injury, or tissue damage. These cells are specialized phagocytes that can engulf and digest foreign particles, apoptotic cells, and debris generated during inflammation. In addition to their phagocytic function, inflammatory macrophages produce and secrete a wide range of pro-inflammatory cytokines, chemokines, and enzymes that help amplify the inflammatory response and recruit more immune cells to the site of inflammation. 

Upon activation by microbial products or cytokines, inflammatory macrophages also undergo a metabolic shift that enhances their ability to generate reactive oxygen and nitrogen species that are toxic to invading pathogens. However, this enhanced metabolism can also contribute to tissue damage if it is dysregulated or sustained for too long. Inflammatory macrophages have been implicated in various inflammatory diseases, such as rheumatoid arthritis, atherosclerosis, and inflammatory bowel disease, where they can promote tissue destruction and fibrosis. 

Despite their pro-inflammatory function, inflammatory macrophages are critical for host defense against infections, especially those caused by intracellular pathogens, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Salmonella, and Listeria. These cells can also promote tissue repair and remodeling by producing growth factors and extracellular matrix components in the later stages of inflammation. Thus, the balance between inflammatory and anti-inflammatory macrophages is crucial for maintaining tissue homeostasis and preventing chronic inflammation and autoimmunity.
CL:0000879:
Meningeal macrophages are specialized immune cells that play a critical role in the central nervous system (CNS) by maintaining immune homeostasis and protecting the brain and spinal cord from infections and injury. These cells are classified as resident macrophages, which means they are produced locally and do not require replenishment from circulating monocytes.

Meningeal macrophages are located in the meninges, the protective membranes that surround and cushion the CNS. These cells are strategically positioned to detect and respond to any pathogens or debris that may enter the CNS through the blood or lymphatic systems. Moreover, they are involved in clearing cellular waste and damaged cells, which is crucial for maintaining tissue integrity and preventing chronic inflammation that can lead to neurodegenerative diseases.

In addition to their immune functions, meningeal macrophages also have an important role in regulating the activity of other immune cells, such as T cells and B cells, in the CNS. They express a unique set of proteins, such as the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class II molecules, which enable them to present antigens to other immune cells and initiate an immune response if needed. Furthermore, recent studies have shown that meningeal macrophages can also communicate with neurons and influence their activity, highlighting their broader role in CNS physiology beyond just immunity.
CL:0000870:
Peyer's patch macrophages are a specialized type of macrophage found within the clusters of lymphoid tissue known as Peyer's patches in the small intestine. These macrophages play a critical role in the immune response, as they are responsible for phagocytosing and processing foreign particles that enter the gut.

In addition to their phagocytic abilities, Peyer's patch macrophages are also capable of antigen presentation. Antigen presentation is the process by which a cell displays fragments of proteins, called antigens, on its surface to be recognized by other immune cells. Peyer's patch macrophages play an important role in this process by presenting antigens to T cells, which then become activated and initiate an immune response against the pathogen.

Furthermore, Peyer's patch macrophages are also important in maintaining tolerance to the commensal bacteria that reside in the gut. Unlike pathogenic bacteria, commensal bacteria are not harmful and are necessary for normal gut function. Peyer's patch macrophages help to maintain this tolerance by phagocytosing commensal bacteria and displaying their antigens to T cells in a way that does not trigger an immune response.

In summary, Peyer's patch macrophages play a key role in the immune response within the gut. They are responsible for phagocytosing and processing foreign particles, presenting antigens to T cells, and maintaining tolerance to commensal bacteria.
CL:0000871:
Splenic macrophages, also known as splenic red pulp macrophages, are a type of phagocytic cells found in the spleen. As part of the reticuloendothelial system, splenic macrophages play an important role in the removal of aged and damaged red blood cells from circulation. They are the predominant cell type in the spleen and are essential for maintaining its function.

Splenic macrophages are characterized by their high phagocytic activity and their ability to clear cellular debris and other waste products from the blood. They perform this important function by engulfing and digesting red blood cells, which are removed from circulation when they become old or damaged. The spleen is responsible for producing new red blood cells, and splenic macrophages help to ensure that the blood remains free of old or dysfunctional cells that could impair its function.

In addition to their role in phagocytosis, splenic macrophages are also involved in the regulation of the immune response. They can present antigens to T cells, which helps to activate the adaptive immune system and mount an appropriate response. Splenic macrophages also produce cytokines and other signaling molecules that can influence the behavior of other cells in the immune system. Overall, these important cells play a critical role in maintaining the health and function of the body, and their loss or dysfunction can have serious consequences for human health.
CL:0000848:
Microvillous olfactory receptor neurons, also known as microvillous cells, are specialized sensory cells located in the olfactory epithelium of the nose. These cells are responsible for detecting and responding to various odorants in the surrounding environment. Microvillous olfactory receptor neurons are characterized by their long, slender microvilli that protrude from the apical surface of the cell into the mucus layer of the olfactory epithelium. These microvilli are highly enriched in odorant receptors, which bind to specific odorants and initiate a signaling cascade that ultimately leads to the generation of an olfactory signal.

In addition to detecting odorants, microvillous olfactory receptor neurons also play a critical role in mediating the sense of smell. The axons of these neurons project from the olfactory epithelium through small openings in the skull called cribriform plate and into the olfactory bulb of the brain. Within the olfactory bulb, microvillous olfactory receptor neurons synapse onto second-order neurons, which in turn relay the olfactory signal to higher brain regions for further processing. In this way, microvillous olfactory receptor neurons are essential for the perception and discrimination of odors.

Microvillous olfactory receptor neurons are a unique cell type with specialized structures and functions that allow for the detection and processing of complex odorants. Understanding the mechanisms underlying the function of these cells is essential for developing treatments for olfactory disorders and for the development of advanced sensors that can detect and identify specific odorants.
CL:0000898:
Naive T cells are a subtype of T lymphocytes that have not yet been exposed to antigen. They are produced in the bone marrow and migrate to the thymus gland where they mature and differentiate into functional T cells. Naive T cells express both CD4 and CD8 co-receptors but have not yet committed to either the helper or cytotoxic T cell pathways. 

Once matured and circulated into the peripheral lymphoid tissues, naive T cells actively scan for foreign antigens presented by dendritic cells, macrophages, and B cells. Upon encountering a specific antigen, naive T cells begin to clonally expand and differentiate into effector T cells. These effector T cells migrate to the site of the infection or injury and function to eradicate the pathogen or damaged cells. 

In summary, naive T cells play a critical role in adaptive immunity by acting as the first line of defense against pathogens and foreign antigens. Their ability to differentiate into the appropriate subset of effector T cells is essential for the success of the immune response. Without naive T cells, the immune system would be unable to effectively fight off infections or control cell growth and differentiation.
CL:0000881:
Perivascular macrophages are a specialized subset of tissue-resident macrophages found throughout the body in close proximity to blood vessels. These cells are known to perform a number of important functions, including tissue homeostasis, immune surveillance and regulation of blood vessel function. They are characterized by their expression of specific markers, including the mannose receptor CD206, the scavenger receptor MARCO, and the transcription factor Sox2.

One of the key functions of perivascular macrophages is the regulation of blood vessel function. These cells are thought to play a critical role in maintaining the integrity of the blood-brain barrier, which prevents potentially harmful substances from entering the brain. They are also involved in the regulation of blood flow, both by interacting with vascular smooth muscle cells and by clearing debris and damaged cells from the vessel wall.

In addition to their role in regulating blood vessel function, perivascular macrophages are also important for tissue homeostasis and immune surveillance. They are involved in surveying tissue for foreign invaders and abnormal cells, and facilitating their clearance through phagocytosis or other means. They can also secrete cytokines and other signaling molecules to help coordinate the immune response to an infection or injury. Overall, perivascular macrophages are a crucial component of the immune system and play a key role in maintaining tissue integrity and function.
CL:0000868:
Lymph node macrophages are a specialized type of immune cell that reside in the lymph nodes. They are part of the innate immune system and play a critical role in identifying and engulfing foreign pathogens, damaged cells, and cellular debris. Lymph node macrophages act as scavengers that patrol the lymph node and remove any unwanted material, including bacteria, viruses, and even infected cells. They are also involved in the activation of T cells, which are specialized immune cells that play a critical role in the adaptive immune response.

Lymph node macrophages are derived from monocytes, which are a type of blood cell that can differentiate into different types of immune cells. Once they enter the lymph nodes, these monocytes differentiate into macrophages and begin to carry out their important functions. Lymph node macrophages are equipped with a range of receptors that recognize pathogens and foreign material. They use these receptors to engulf and digest the unwanted material, breaking it down into small pieces that can be presented to T cells for recognition.

In addition to their role in immune defense, lymph node macrophages are also important for maintaining tissue homeostasis. They produce cytokines and other signaling molecules that regulate the behavior of neighboring cells, including other immune cells and stromal cells that provide structural support to the lymph node. By coordinating the activities of different cell types, lymph node macrophages help to ensure that the lymph node functions properly and can mount an effective immune response when needed. Overall, lymph node macrophages play a vital role in both the innate and adaptive immune response and are essential for maintaining immune system homeostasis.
CL:0000872:
Splenic marginal zone macrophages are a unique subset of macrophages located in the marginal zone of the spleen. These macrophages are strategically positioned to sense and engulf foreign antigens before they enter the circulation. The splenic marginal zone macrophages mediate the initial step of filtering the blood. They are specialized in capturing and clearing blood-borne pathogens, antigens, and cellular debris. These macrophages are phagocytic in nature and can engulf bacteria, viruses, fungi, and parasites.

One of the unique characteristics of splenic marginal zone macrophages is their ability to capture blood-borne antigens and traffic them to other immune cells for activation and initiation of a systemic immune response. The splenic marginal zone macrophages also play a crucial role in maintaining immune tolerance by removing self-antigens, apoptotic cells, and debris. They actively clear aged erythrocytes and recycle iron, biliverdin, and other by-products of red blood cell catabolism.

In summary, splenic marginal zone macrophages are a particular type of macrophages localized in the spleen's marginal zone. They are specialized in capturing and clearing blood-borne pathogens, antigens, and cellular debris, thus playing a crucial role in maintaining immune homeostasis. Through their unique antigen-presenting capacity, splenic marginal zone macrophages also initiate systemic immune responses that protect against infections and pathological conditions, making them an essential component of the innate immune system.
CL:0000875:
Non-classical monocytes, also known as intermediate monocytes, are a specific subtype of monocytes that make up around 10% of total monocyte population in the human body. They are characterized by their distinct morphology, with a larger size and more convoluted shape compared to classical monocytes. Non-classical monocytes are important players in the immune system, involved in both the innate and adaptive immune response.

One of the primary functions of non-classical monocytes is to patrol the endothelial walls of blood vessels and detect any signs of tissue damage or infection. These cells are able to quickly migrate to sites of inflammation and infection, where they differentiate into tissue-resident macrophages and dendritic cells. Non-classical monocytes are also involved in antigen presentation and contribute to the activation and proliferation of T cells.

In addition to their immune functions, non-classical monocytes have also been found to play a role in regulating vascular health and blood clotting. These cells produce and release a number of cytokines and growth factors that promote angiogenesis, the formation of new blood vessels. They are also involved in the clearance of debris and dead cells from the blood, helping to prevent the formation of blood clots and maintain vascular health. Overall, non-classical monocytes are a crucial component of the immune system with a wide range of functions in both innate and adaptive immunity, as well as in vascular health.
CL:0000873:
Splenic Metallophillic Macrophages (SMM cells) are a subset of macrophages that make up the marginal zone of the spleen. They are characterised by their location, structure, and function. SMM cells are called “metallophillic” because they have high-affinity receptors for metal ions such as calcium and magnesium on their cell surface. These receptors allow SMM cells to bind and remove foreign particles, including pathogens and circulating immune complexes, from the blood.

SMM cells are also known for their role in the immune system’s response to blood-borne infections. They interact with both B and T cells to initiate an immune response against invading pathogens. SMM cells present antigens to T cells and provide co-stimulatory signals necessary for T cell activation, maturation, and proliferation. SMM-derived cytokines also mediate the differentiation, maturation, and production of IgM antibodies. Therefore, SMM cells are essential in defending the body against bacterial infections, especially encapsulated bacteria like Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae.

In summary, Splenic Metallophillic Macrophages are an important subset of macrophages that play a crucial role in the immune response against blood-borne infections. Their high-affinity receptors allow them to efficiently capture foreign particles, and they act as antigen-presenting cells to T cells, initiating the immune response. SMM cells are a promising target for future research into developing novel treatments for bacterial infections and other diseases.
CL:0000866:
Thymic macrophages are a specialized type of phagocytic immune cell found within the thymus gland. These cells play a crucial role in the development and maturation of T cells, which are important components of the adaptive immune system. Thymic macrophages are derived from the same stem cells as other macrophages, but they express unique cell surface molecules and secrete distinct signaling molecules.

One of the primary functions of thymic macrophages is the clearance of apoptotic, or dying, cells from the thymus. As T cells undergo selection, a process by which only those cells that recognize self-antigens are allowed to mature, a large proportion of T cells are eliminated through programmed cell death. Thymic macrophages play an essential role in engulfing these apoptotic cells, preventing an inflammatory immune response and promoting a tolerogenic environment.

In addition to their role in apoptotic cell clearance, thymic macrophages are also involved in the expression of important signaling molecules that regulate T cell development. One such molecule is thymic stromal lymphopoietin (TSLP), which is expressed by thymic macrophages and can activate dendritic cells to promote T cell development. Thymic macrophages also secrete cytokines that are involved in inflammation and immune activation, such as interleukin-6 (IL-6) and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α).
CL:0000892:
Smooth muscle cell-derived foam cells are a type of specialized cells that are known to play an essential role in the development of atherosclerosis, which is a progressive disease of the arterial walls. They are formed by the accumulation of lipid-rich material within the cytoplasm of smooth muscle cells, which results in their transformation into foam cells.

The function of these cells in the vascular wall is associated with their ability to take up and transport lipids, which contributes to the formation of fatty streaks in the arterial wall. These fatty streaks are the first observable lesion in the development of atherosclerosis. Over time, smooth muscle cell-derived foam cells can cluster to form atheromas, which are complex fibrofatty plaques that continue to grow in size until they cause significant arterial obstruction.

Despite their contribution to the development of atherosclerosis, smooth muscle cell-derived foam cells are also capable of playing a beneficial role in the repair and regeneration of the arterial wall. These cells can produce factors that are involved in wound healing and tissue repair, which can help to promote the recovery of damaged arterial tissues. However, the balance between the positive and negative effects of smooth muscle cell-derived foam cells in the arterial wall is still not fully understood, and further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms of these processes.
CL:0000876:
Splenic white pulp macrophages are a subtype of macrophages that reside within the white pulp of the spleen. They are involved in immune surveillance and play a critical role in the removal of cellular debris, apoptotic cells, and infectious agents from the bloodstream. These macrophages are strategically positioned at the interface between blood vessels and lymphoid tissue, allowing for efficient clearance of pathogens and antigens.

The splenic white pulp macrophages are vital for the maintenance of immune homeostasis and the prevention of autoimmunity. They act as antigen-presenting cells, playing a crucial role in the initiation and regulation of adaptive immune responses. These macrophages are capable of phagocytosing antigenic material, processing it, and presenting it to T cells to initiate an immune response.

Additionally, splenic white pulp macrophages are essential for the clearance of circulating blood cells that are past their lifespan. The macrophages identify, phagocytose, and break down red blood cells that are no longer functional, such as those with damaged membranes, in order to recycle hemoglobin. This function is critical in preventing hemolytic anemia, in which unprocessed cellular debris accumulates in circulation, leading to red blood cell destruction and anemia. Overall, splenic white pulp macrophages are a diverse population of immune cells that contribute to innate and adaptive immunity, maintenance of immune homeostasis, and erythrocyte turnover.
CL:0000884:
Mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue macrophages, also known as M cells, represent a specialized subset of intestinal macrophages that are associated with lymphoid follicles located within the gastrointestinal mucosa. These cells play a critical role in the immune defense of the gut by facilitating the transport of antigens and pathogens across the intestinal epithelium through a process called transcytosis. M cells achieve this by rapidly internalizing luminal material and transporting it to the underlying lymphoid tissues for processing and presentation to the immune cells.

In addition to their function as antigen presenting cells, mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue macrophages also play a crucial role in maintaining homeostasis within the intestinal mucosa. These cells regulate the gut microbiome by secreting antimicrobial peptides and cytokines that help to shape the composition of the gut bacterial communities. Furthermore, M cells are involved in the resolution of inflammation through the clearance of apoptotic cells and debris within the gut, preventing the accumulation of potentially harmful materials.

Overall, mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue macrophages play a vital role in regulating immune responses within the gut. These cells facilitate the transport of antigens and pathogens, shape the gut microbiome, and maintain gut homeostasis. The proper functioning of M cells is essential for the development of effective immune responses and the prevention of inflammatory and infectious diseases within the gastrointestinal tract.
CL:0000883:
Thymic cortical macrophages are a type of immune cell found in the thymus gland. They are a specialized subset of macrophages that reside in the cortex of the thymus and play a key role in the development and selection of T cells. These cells are characterized by the expression of various surface markers including F4/80, CD68, and CD11b.

Thymic cortical macrophages are involved in phagocytosis of apoptotic cells, a process crucial for the efficient clearance of dead cells and tissue remodeling. This function is especially important during the development of T cells in the thymus, where large numbers of immature T cells undergo apoptosis as the result of negative selection. Thymic cortical macrophages are also responsible for the degradation of tissue-resident antigens, which are necessary for the selection and maturation of T cells.

In addition to their role in T cell selection, thymic cortical macrophages have been shown to interact with other immune cells, including dendritic cells and regulatory T cells. Recent studies have also suggested that these cells may play a role in the pathogenesis of autoimmune diseases by mediating the persistence of self-reactive T cells. Overall, the study of thymic cortical macrophages has provided important insights into the mechanisms underlying T cell development and immune tolerance in the thymus.
CL:0001029:
Common dendritic progenitor cells, or CDPs, are a type of bone marrow-derived progenitor cell that give rise to classical dendritic cells (cDCs) and plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs). CDPs are characterized by their expression of the transcription factors FMS-like tyrosine kinase 3 ligand receptor (Flt3R) and ID2. They are found primarily in the bone marrow and spleen, where they differentiate into cDCs and pDCs and subsequently migrate to peripheral tissues and lymphoid organs to serve critical roles in immune surveillance and regulation.

cDCs derived from CDPs are important antigen-presenting cells that play a crucial role in linking innate and adaptive immunity. They are specialized in capturing and processing antigens, then presenting them to T cells to initiate an adaptive immune response. cDCs can be further classified into two subsets, designated as CD8α+ and CD11b+ cDCs, that have distinct functions in the immune response. CD8α+ cDCs are important for cross-presentation of antigens from infected cells to cytotoxic T cells, while CD11b+ cDCs are better for triggering the differentiation of helper T cells.

pDCs, on the other hand, have a unique function in innate immune surveillance. They are specialized in detecting viral nucleic acids through the expression of Toll-like receptors (TLRs) and other pattern recognition receptors (PRRs). Once activated, pDCs produce large amounts of type I interferon, which triggers an antiviral response in neighboring cells and recruits other immune cells to the site of infection. In addition to their immune surveillance function, pDCs are also involved in the regulation of immune tolerance and the pathogenesis of autoimmune diseases.
CL:0000914:
Immature natural killer T (iNKT) cells are a subset of T lymphocytes that express a semi-invariant T cell receptor (TCR). These cells form in the bone marrow and migrate to the thymus for further maturation. iNKT cells can recognize glycolipid antigens presented by the CD1d molecule on antigen-presenting cells.

iNKT cells have a unique ability to rapidly secrete cytokines upon activation, which allows them to modulate the immune response in a variety of settings. This cytokine response can promote either pro- or anti-inflammatory effects, depending on the context. iNKT cells have been implicated in the regulation of autoimmune diseases, infectious diseases, cancer, and allergies.

Overall, the role of iNKT cells in immune surveillance and host defense is still being elucidated, but their unique effector functions and antigen recognition capabilities suggest that these cells play an important role in immune regulation and maintenance of tissue homeostasis.
CL:0000903:
Natural T-regulatory cells, also known as nTregs, are a subset of T cells that play a critical role in regulating the immune system. These cells are derived from the thymus and express the transcription factor Foxp3, which is necessary for their function and maintenance. 

The primary function of nTregs is to suppress the immune response and prevent autoimmunity. They achieve this by interacting with other immune cells, such as effector T cells and antigen-presenting cells, and inhibiting their activation and proliferation. This is accomplished by secreting anti-inflammatory cytokines, such as IL-10 and TGF-β, which suppress inflammatory responses and promote immune tolerance. 

In addition to their role in preventing autoimmunity, nTregs are also involved in maintaining tolerance to self-antigens, preventing chronic inflammation, and promoting tissue repair after injury or infection. Dysregulation of nTreg function has been implicated in a variety of autoimmune and inflammatory disorders, such as multiple sclerosis, type 1 diabetes, and rheumatoid arthritis. Thus, understanding the biology and function of these cells has important implications for the development of novel therapies for these diseases.
CL:0000902:
Induced T-regulatory cells (iTregs) are a distinct subset of regulatory T-cells that develop from peripheral CD4+CD25- T-cells in response to environmental cues. They are induced to suppress immune responses and play a crucial role in maintaining immune homeostasis and preventing autoimmunity. iTregs can also be generated in vitro by culturing naive T-cells with cytokines and TGF-β1.

The suppressive function of iTregs involves their ability to secrete anti-inflammatory cytokines such as IL-10 and TGF-β1, directly or indirectly inhibit the function of effector T-cells, and promote the activity of other immune regulatory cells such as tolerogenic dendritic cells. Through these mechanisms, iTregs limit immune responses to self-antigens, pathogens, and commensal microorganisms, and prevent tissue damage and inflammation.

iTregs have been implicated in a variety of autoimmune disorders, allergic reactions, and transplant rejection. They are therefore a promising therapeutic target for immunomodulation. Studies have shown that adoptive transfer of iTregs or induction of their generation in vivo or ex vivo can ameliorate autoimmune diseases, prolong allograft survival, and enhance the efficacy of cancer immunotherapy.
CL:0000880:
Choroid plexus macrophages are a type of specialized immune cell that resides in the choroid plexus of the brain. These macrophages play an important role in immune surveillance and maintaining brain health. The choroid plexus is a structure that produces the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), which is responsible for bathing the brain and providing it with nutrients and oxygen. 

Choroid plexus macrophages are responsible for the removal of debris and unwanted cells from this CSF. These cells are phagocytic in nature, meaning that they engulf and digest cellular debris, damaged cells, and infectious agents. They are also responsible for detecting and responding to foreign substances that may enter the CSF, including bacteria and viruses. As part of the immune response, these macrophages produce cytokines, signaling molecules that help to activate other immune cells to target and eliminate the harmful agents.

In addition to their immune functions, choroid plexus macrophages also play a crucial role in maintaining the integrity of the blood-brain barrier (BBB). The BBB is a protective barrier that separates the blood from the brain and prevents harmful substances from entering the central nervous system. Choroid plexus macrophages help to maintain the BBB by interacting with other cells in the choroid plexus, regulating the production and organization of tight junctions between cells, and reducing inflammation and oxidative stress that can cause damage to the BBB.
CL:0000901:
Tr1 cells (Type 1 regulatory T cells) are a subtype of regulatory T cells that play a vital role in immune homeostasis. These cells are characterized by their ability to produce high levels of the anti-inflammatory cytokine interleukin (IL)-10 and transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta). Tr1 cells dampen down inflammatory responses and rein in immune responses to prevent excessive tissue damage.

Tr1 cells have shown promise in treating autoimmune diseases and chronic inflammatory conditions. They have the ability to migrate to inflamed tissues and negatively regulate the effector responses of T cells, B cells, and antigen-presenting cells. Tr1 cells also have the unique ability to adapt to different cytokine environments, and they can be induced to alter their cytokine profile according to the needs of the immune system.

Research into Tr1 cells is ongoing, and understanding the mechanisms by which these cells function could have significant therapeutic implications for a broad range of diseases. Harnessing the anti-inflammatory potential of Tr1 cells through cell therapy or immunomodulatory drugs could provide a targeted approach to treating autoimmune diseases, chronic inflammation, and other immunological disorders.
CL:0000889:
Myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs) are a heterogeneous population of immature myeloid cells that have potent immunosuppressive activity. These cells originate from the bone marrow and are generated under pathological conditions such as cancer, chronic inflammation, and autoimmune diseases. They are characterized by the expression of myeloid cell markers such as CD11b, Gr1, and CD33 in mice and CD11b, CD33, and HLA-DR^low/− in humans. 

MDSCs are potent suppressors of immune responses mediated by CD4+ and CD8+ T cells and natural killer cells. They can inhibit T-cell proliferation and cytokine production by several mechanisms, including the depletion of amino acids, production of reactive oxygen and nitrogen species, and induction of regulatory T cells. In addition, MDSCs can directly promote tumor growth by facilitating angiogenesis, promoting tumor invasion and metastasis, and suppressing antitumor immune responses. 

MDSCs have emerged as critical regulators of immune homeostasis and as potential targets for cancer immunotherapy. Strategies to inhibit MDSC expansion or suppress their immunosuppressive activity, such as administration of myeloid growth factors, inhibitors of MDSC pathways, and adoptive transfer of tumor-specific T cells, are under development for cancer treatment. Understanding the biology and function of MDSCs in cancer and chronic inflammation may lead to the identification of new therapeutic targets for these conditions.
CL:0000887:
Lymph node subcapsular sinus macrophages are specialized immune cells that reside in the subcapsular sinus of lymph nodes. They play a critical role in filtering antigens and foreign particles from lymphatic fluid and initiating immune responses in the lymph nodes. These macrophages form a unique network that operates as the first line of defense against invading pathogens and other foreign agents. 

Lymph node subcapsular sinus macrophages are equipped with specialized receptors that enable them to recognize and bind to antigens and pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs). Upon binding, they initiate a cascade of signaling events that trigger the activation of nearby immune cells, including lymphocytes, which then migrate to the lymph node to mount an immune response. In addition, these macrophages are essential in facilitating the trafficking of lymphocytes between lymph nodes and other parts of the body. 

The function of lymph node subcapsular sinus macrophages is critical for maintaining the immune system's surveillance and defense against invading pathogens. Dysregulation of this system can lead to immune disorders and increased susceptibility to infections. Understanding the biology of these macrophages is essential for the development of new therapies and strategies to enhance the immune response against infectious diseases and cancer.
CL:0002436:
A mature CD4 single-positive thymocyte is a type of T-lymphocyte that has completed its final stage of differentiation in the thymus. These cells express the CD4 co-receptor and are positively selected for their ability to recognize MHC class II molecules presented by antigen-presenting cells, which is crucial for their role in the immune response. Once these cells leave the thymus, they migrate to peripheral lymphoid tissues where they play a crucial role in adaptive immunity.

In response to antigen exposure, CD4 single-positive thymocytes differentiate into helper T-cells, which secrete cytokines that activate other immune cells to participate in the immune response. These cells are responsible for providing support to the immune system by regulating the activation and proliferation of several other immune cell types. Additionally, mature CD4 single-positive thymocytes help B-cells produce antibodies and activate cytotoxic T-cells to eliminate virally infected or malignant cells.

Defects in the development of CD4 single-positive thymocytes can lead to immunodeficiency, autoimmune disorders, and cancer. Understanding the function of these cells is essential in the development of immunotherapies that aim to enhance immune responses to combat diseases such as cancer. In conclusion, mature CD4 single-positive thymocytes are a crucial subset of T-lymphocytes that play a fundamental role in the regulation of the immune response by providing support to other immune cells and fighting off infections and malignancies.
CL:0000874:
Splenic red pulp macrophages are macrophages found in the red pulp of the spleen and are also known as red pulp macrophages. These cells play an essential role in clearing out damaged or aged red blood cells (RBCs) from the circulation. The filtering process of RBCs is vital because the spleen is the primary site for RBC disposal. When RBCs are cleared from the circulation, they are broken down into their constituent parts, including heme. The degradation of heme is critical because it generates iron that can be used in the formation of new RBCs. Therefore, splenic red pulp macrophages maintain the balance between clearing RBCs and recycling heme in the spleen.

Apart from their role in the clearance of RBCs, splenic red pulp macrophages also have a crucial role in immune function. These cells assist in the immune response by phagocytosing microorganisms, foreign particles present in the bloodstream, and other cellular and molecular debris. Additionally, splenic red pulp macrophages are involved in the generation and repair of tissue within the spleen.

Furthermore, recent research has shown that splenic red pulp macrophages play a vital role in the regulation of erythropoiesis. These cells release growth factors that help regulate the proliferation and differentiation of erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow.

In summary, splenic red pulp macrophages play a critical role in the clearance of red blood cells, immune system function, and the regulation of erythropoiesis. Their role in maintaining the balance between cellular and molecular homeostasis in the spleen is critical to maintaining overall homeostasis within the body.
CL:0000910:
Cytotoxic T cells (CTLs) are a specialized group of T lymphocytes that play a crucial role in the immune response against viral and bacterial infections as well as tumor cells. These cells possess the unique ability to recognize and eliminate cells that are infected or transformed by viruses and cancerous cells. They do this by binding to specific antigens on the surface of the targeted cells and inducing apoptosis or programmed cell death.

Importantly, CTLs require activation by antigen-presenting cells (APCs) to carry out their effector functions. Once activated, they undergo clonal expansion and differentiation into effector T cells, which are responsible for targeting infected cells. Effector T cells also produce cytokines that help recruit and activate other immune cells to aid in the immune response.

The role of CTLs in immune surveillance has made them a key focus in the development of immunotherapeutic approaches against cancer. Current strategies that target these cells aim to enhance their activity by promoting their recruitment, expansion, and activation within the tumor microenvironment. CTLs, therefore, have a vital role in the immune response against infectious and malignant diseases and hold great potential for the development of novel immunotherapeutic strategies.
CL:0002425:
Early T lineage precursors, or ETPs, are a type of hematopoietic stem cell that are the earliest identifiable precursor cells for the T cell lineage. These cells are found in the thymus and bone marrow and give rise to all other T cell subtypes throughout development. ETPs are characterized by the expression of certain cell surface markers, including CD34, CD1a, and CD117, as well as the absence of markers associated with more mature T cell subsets.

ETPs play a critical role in the development of the immune system, as they are the starting point for the generation of T cells, which are responsible for coordinating immune responses to pathogens and foreign substances. During development, ETPs undergo a process of cell division and differentiation, giving rise to several intermediate T cell progenitors before ultimately differentiating into mature T cells. The differentiation process is tightly regulated by a variety of factors, including cytokines and interactions with other cells in the thymus microenvironment.

Defects or disruptions in ETP development can have serious consequences for the immune system. For example, mutations in genes involved in the regulation of ETP differentiation have been linked to the development of T cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia, a type of blood cancer that arises from abnormal T cell proliferation. Conversely, efforts to manipulate ETPs for therapeutic purposes, such as in the context of adoptive T cell immunotherapy for cancer, are currently being explored.
CL:0000916:
Dendritic epidermal T cells (DETCs) are a unique subset of T cells that reside in the epidermis of the skin. They are characterized by their large dendritic morphology and their association with nerve endings. These cells play a crucial role in the skin's immune response to various pathogens and injuries.

DETCs are one of the most abundant resident T cell populations in the skin and are particularly important for their ability to recognize and respond to stress-induced antigens. These antigens are often associated with cellular damage or infection and can activate DETCs to produce a rapid immune response. This response can include the release of cytokines and the recruitment of other immune cells to the site of infection or injury.

In addition to their immune function, DETCs are also involved in maintaining the skin's barrier function. These cells have been shown to interact with other cell types in the epidermis, such as keratinocytes and melanocytes, to promote skin homeostasis and wound healing. Overall, the unique properties of dendritic epidermal T cells make them an important contributor to the skin's ability to deal with various stresses and maintain its structure and function.
CL:0000907:
Central memory CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells, also known as Tcm cells, are a subset of T cells that play a crucial role in the immune response against pathogens. These cells are characterized by the expression of CD8, which is a protein receptor found on the surface of certain T cells. They are distinguished from other T cells by their ability to circulate through the lymphoid organs and remain in a quiescent state until they encounter an antigen.

Tcm cells are formed after a primary immune response to an antigen. During this response, some activated effector T cells differentiate into memory T cells, with a portion of these becoming Tcm cells. These T cells have a long lifespan and can persist in the body for several years, making them an important component of immunological memory. Upon re-exposure to the antigen, Tcm cells can rapidly differentiate into effector T cells and initiate an immune response quickly and effectively.

The function of Tcm cells is to maintain immunological memory and provide long-term protection against subsequent infections. They are important in mediating long-term immunity to viral and bacterial infections, as well as in preventing the development of some types of cancer. Due to their ability to establish immunological memory, Tcm cells are critical in the development of vaccines and in the generation of long-lasting protective immunity.
CL:0000888:
Lymph node tingible body macrophages (TBMs) are a subset of macrophages that are found in the lymph nodes. These cells belong to the mononuclear phagocyte system, which plays a critical role in innate immunity against infection. TBMs derive from monocytes that migrate to the lymph nodes and differentiate into macrophages. TBMs are unique in their ability to phagocytose and degrade cell debris and apoptotic bodies found within the lymph nodes. These cells play a crucial role in preventing autoimmune diseases by removing and breaking down the self-reactive lymphocytes.

TBMs are characterized by their large size, ovoid shape, and cytoplasmic inclusions called “tingible bodies.” These cells are found primarily in the germinal centers of lymph nodes, where they interact with B cells. TBMs participate in the process of antibody production by phagocytosing apoptotic B cells and presenting the antigenic material to other immune cells. Additionally, TBMs can acquire and display antigens from other cell types, promoting the presentation of antigens from diverse sources.

In summary, lymph node TBMs have a critical role in the immune response by eliminating and processing cellular debris and apoptotic cells. They are important for maintaining peripheral tolerance and promoting effective adaptive immune responses. These cells have a unique morphology and function which sets them apart from other macrophage populations in the body.
CL:0002437:
Mature CD8 single-positive thymocytes are a type of immune cell that plays a critical role in the adaptive immune response. These cells develop in the thymus, a specialized primary lymphoid organ, from a precursor population known as double-positive thymocytes. CD8 single-positive thymocytes express the CD8 co-receptor, one of the key surface markers that helps to identify and differentiate them from other lymphocytes.

The primary function of mature CD8 single-positive thymocytes is to recognize and eliminate cells that have been infected with intracellular pathogens, such as viruses or intracellular bacteria. This recognition is mediated by the T cell receptor (TCR) on the surface of the CD8 single-positive thymocyte. When the TCR on a CD8 single-positive thymocyte binds to a foreign antigen presented on the surface of an infected host cell, the CD8 single-positive thymocyte becomes activated and initiates an immune response to eliminate the infected cell.

Mature CD8 single-positive thymocytes are part of a larger network of cells and molecules that work together to mount an effective immune response. Once activated, CD8 single-positive thymocytes can differentiate into effector cells that carry out the immune response, or into memory cells that can rapidly respond to future infections. Together with other immune cells such as CD4 T cells, B cells, and antigen-presenting cells, CD8 single-positive thymocytes play a critical role in protecting the body from infectious disease.
CL:0000890:
Alternatively activated macrophages (AAMs) are a subset of macrophages that have been activated by cytokines and other stimuli to undertake specific roles in immune responses. Unlike classical macrophages that are activated by interferon-gamma and microbial stimuli, AAMs are activated by interleukin-4, interleukin-13, and interleukin-10. AAMs are involved in the resolution of inflammation, tissue repair, and remodeling. 

AAMs are characterized by the expression of specific markers, including arginase-1, chitinase-like molecules, Ym1, and Fizz1. These markers are involved in immunomodulation, extracellular matrix remodeling, and anti-inflammatory responses. AAMs can also promote tissue repair by releasing growth factors, such as platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF), and producing extracellular matrix components. Additionally, AAMs can interact with other immune cells, such as T cells and natural killer cells, to modulate their responses and promote homeostasis.

Furthermore, AAMs have been implicated in several disease processes, including asthma, fibrosis, and cancer. In asthma, AAMs contribute to airway hyperresponsiveness and mucus production through the production of chitinase-like molecules. In fibrosis, AAMs promote extracellular matrix deposition and exacerbate fibrosis progression. In cancer, AAMs have been shown to promote tumorigenesis by creating an immunosuppressive environment and promoting angiogenesis. Understanding the biology and function of AAMs is critical for the development of new therapies for these diseases.
CL:0000905:
Effector memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells are a type of T cell that plays a critical role in adaptive immune responses against pathogens and cancer. These cells are characterized by their ability to migrate to peripheral tissues where they scan for foreign antigens and secrete cytokines to induce an immune response. The effector memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells are an important subset of the CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cell population because they have already been activated and have developed memory to specific antigens.

The primary function of effector memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells is to recognize and eliminate pathogens that have infected the body. These cells recognize foreign antigens presented by antigen-presenting cells and secrete cytokines such as interferon-gamma, which activates immune cells such as macrophages and natural killer cells to destroy infected cells. In addition, effector memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells play an important role in generating long-lasting immunity to previously encountered pathogens by developing memory to specific antigens.

Effector memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells are also crucial in anti-tumor immunity. They have been shown to infiltrate tumors and secrete cytokines that induce cancer cell death. Furthermore, these cells play a role in the activation of cytotoxic T cells, which target and eliminate cancer cells. Therefore, enhancing the function of effector memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells is a promising area of research for developing new cancer therapies.
CL:0000918:
Tc2 cells are a type of immune cell that play a critical role in the body's defense against infection and disease. These cells are a subtype of CD8+ T cells, which are known for their ability to recognize and eliminate virus-infected cells in the body. Tc2 cells, in particular, are characterized by their production of cytokines such as IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13, which work together to stimulate the immune system and promote the development of a strong and effective immune response.

The primary function of Tc2 cells is to help the body fight off infections caused by viruses and other pathogens. These cells do this by recognizing and binding to infected cells, then releasing cytokines that help to activate other immune cells in the body. In addition to their role in infection control, Tc2 cells also play a role in regulating immune responses in the body, helping to ensure that the immune system does not overreact to harmless substances or cause damage to healthy tissues.

Overall, Tc2 cells are an important component of the body's immune system, playing a critical role in both infection control and immune regulation. By understanding more about these cells and how they function, researchers may be able to develop new treatments and therapies for a variety of diseases and conditions, from viral infections to autoimmune disorders.
CL:0000904:
Central memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells, also known as Tcm, are a subset of T cells that circulate through secondary lymphoid organs, such as lymph nodes and spleen. These cells express the CD4 co-receptor and the alpha-beta T cell receptor (TCR), which is responsible for recognizing and binding to antigen-presenting cells. Tcm cells are characterized by their ability to respond rapidly to antigen re-exposure, as they have a long lifespan, can undergo robust proliferation, and differentiate into effector T cells upon activation.

Tcm cells play a critical role in adaptive immunity against viral and bacterial infections, as well as in the development and maintenance of immune memory. Upon activation, Tcm cells can differentiate into effector T cells, which are capable of killing infected cells or producing cytokines to promote inflammation. However, unlike effector cells, Tcm cells are able to persist long-term and can provide protection against subsequent exposure to the same pathogen. Tcm cells also contribute to immune surveillance against cancer cells, as they can recognize and eliminate tumor cells.

Moreover, Tcm cells are involved in regulating the immune response and preventing autoimmune diseases. They secrete cytokines that promote the proliferation of other immune cells and inhibit the differentiation of regulatory T cells, which suppress immune activity. Additionally, Tcm cells play a pivotal role in transplant rejection, as they recognize and attack foreign tissues. Hence, understanding the biology and function of Tcm cells is critical for developing new therapies for infectious and autoimmune diseases and improving transplantation outcomes.
CL:0000908:
CD8-positive, alpha-beta cytokine-secreting effector T cells are a type of immune cell that plays a critical role in defending the body against viral infections and cancer. These cells are also known as cytotoxic T cells or killer T cells due to their ability to directly destroy infected or abnormal cells. CD8-positive T cells are so named because they express a protein called CD8 on their surface, which helps them recognize cells that are infected with a virus or have become cancerous.

Effector T cells are differentiated T cells that have become activated in response to an antigen and have acquired specialized functions to carry out their role in the immune response. CD8-positive, alpha-beta cytokine-secreting effector T cells are particularly important because they secrete cytokines, which are proteins that regulate the immune response and help coordinate the activity of other immune cells. Additionally, these cells are able to migrate to sites of infection or tumor growth and directly attack the abnormal cells using toxic molecules or by inducing cell death.

The function of CD8-positive, alpha-beta cytokine-secreting effector T cells is critical for maintaining a healthy immune system and fighting off infections and cancer. However, dysregulation or dysfunction of these cells can also contribute to autoimmune diseases or immune deficiencies. Therefore, understanding the biology of these cells and how they interact with other cells in the immune system is essential for developing new therapies and improving our ability to fight disease.
CL:0000897:
CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells are a type of T lymphocyte, characterized by the presence of the CD4 protein on their surface. They belong to the adaptive immune system and play a crucial role in defending the body against pathogens. These cells are generated during an immune response to infection, and once activated, they differentiate into effector T cells that can recognize and eliminate the pathogen. After the infection is cleared, a subset of activated T cells persists as memory T cells to mediate long-term protection against the same pathogen in case of re-infection.

Memory T cells have distinct functional properties that make them efficient at providing rapid and robust immune responses. CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells specifically respond to antigens presented by major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class II molecules, which are primarily expressed on professional antigen-presenting cells, such as dendritic cells and macrophages. By recognizing specific antigens, memory T cells can quickly mount an immune response, bypassing the requirement for further activation and differentiation. CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells also provide help to other cells of the immune system, such as B cells, by secreting cytokines and promoting their maturation and differentiation.

In addition to their role in pathogen defense, CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells are also implicated in autoimmune diseases, allergies, and cancer. These conditions can arise when the immune system mistakenly identifies self-antigens as foreign, leading to the formation of memory T cells that attack healthy tissues. Therefore, understanding the biology of CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells is important for developing effective therapies for immune disorders.
CL:0000882:
Thymic medullary macrophages (TMMs) are a type of specialized immune cell that resides in the medullary region of the thymus. TMMs play a critical role in central tolerance, a process that eliminates self-reactive T cells before they enter the peripheral lymphoid organs. In the thymus, TMMs are responsible for the clearance of apoptotic thymocytes, the degradation of cellular debris, and the presentation of self-antigens to immature T cells. This process promotes tolerance to self-antigens and is essential for preventing autoimmunity.

TMMs are characterized by their unique morphology and expression of cell surface markers. They are large, irregularly shaped cells with an abundance of lysosomes and phagocytic vacuoles. TMMs express high levels of scavenger receptors, which enable them to efficiently bind and internalize apoptotic thymocytes and other cellular debris. They also express major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class II molecules, which are critical for presenting self-antigens to immature T cells.

In addition to their key role in central tolerance, TMMs have been implicated in the negative regulation of immune responses. Studies have shown that TMMs can inhibit the activation and proliferation of T cells in vitro and in vivo. TMMs have also been shown to express high levels of the immune checkpoint molecule PD-L1, which can bind to PD-1 receptors on T cells and inhibit their activation. These findings suggest that TMMs may play a broader role in the regulation of immune responses beyond central tolerance.
CL:0002401:
Mature dendritic epithelial T cell precursors are a subset of T cells that play a crucial role in the immune system's response to infection and cancer. These cells are unique in their ability to differentiate into various types of T cells that are essential for mounting an effective immune response. Mature dendritic epithelial T cell precursors are primarily found in the thymus, where they undergo a complex process of differentiation and maturation before being released into the bloodstream.

Once released into the bloodstream, mature dendritic epithelial T cell precursors travel to various parts of the body, where they play a critical role in coordinating the immune response. These cells are expert antigen-presenting cells, which means they can present foreign substances to other immune cells, such as cytotoxic T cells and B cells, triggering their activation. As such, mature dendritic epithelial T cell precursors are essential for the initiation and regulation of an effective immune response.

Mature dendritic epithelial T cell precursors are an important part of the body's immune system, and their functions in immune regulation and coordination are essential for proper immune function. While the exact mechanisms by which these cells function are not yet fully understood, research into the unique properties and functions of mature dendritic epithelial T cell precursors has great potential to advance our understanding of immune system function and improve treatments for immune-related disorders.
CL:0000921:
Type I natural killer T (NKT) cells are a subset of T lymphocytes that express both an invariant T cell receptor (TCR) and natural killer (NK) cell markers. They play a crucial role in immune responses against various infections and diseases, including cancer. NKT cells recognize glycolipid antigens presented by the MHC class I-like molecule CD1d on the surface of antigen-presenting cells. This activates a rapid and strong cytokine response, which either enhances or suppresses immune responses depending on the type and context of the antigen.

Type I NKT cells are considered "pro-inflammatory" because they secrete cytokines such as interferon-gamma (IFN-gamma) and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha) that activate and recruit other immune cells to the site of infection or inflammation. They are also involved in the regulation of autoimmune diseases, as they can either promote or inhibit autoreactive T cell responses, depending on the specific antigen and the context in which it is presented.

Overall, the unique properties and functions of type I NKT cells make them promising targets for immune-based therapies against cancer, infectious diseases, and autoimmune disorders. Further research into the role and regulation of these cells could lead to exciting new discoveries and therapeutic strategies in the field of immunology.
CL:0002393:
Intermediate monocytes, also known as CD14++CD16+ monocytes, are a subset of monocytes that belong to the innate immune system. These cells are characterized by their unique surface markers which distinguish them from classical and non-classical monocytes. Intermediate monocytes make up approximately 5-10% of the total monocyte population in human peripheral blood.

These cells play a crucial role in the inflammatory response by migrating to sites of injury or infection and differentiating into macrophages and dendritic cells. Intermediate monocytes have been shown to produce high levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines such as interleukin-6 (IL-6), tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α), and interleukin-1 beta (IL-1β). Additionally, they are involved in the phagocytosis and clearance of pathogens and debris from damaged tissue.

Intermediate monocytes have also been implicated in the pathophysiology of numerous diseases such as atherosclerosis, where they are thought to promote plaque formation and progression through their ability to adhere to endothelial cells and produce pro-inflammatory cytokines. Furthermore, these cells have been shown to contribute to the development of autoimmune diseases such as lupus and multiple sclerosis by promoting inflammation and immune dysregulation.

In summary, intermediate monocytes are a distinct subset of monocytes that play a critical role in the innate immune response. These cells are characterized by their unique surface markers, and they are involved in the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines, phagocytosis, and tissue repair. Understanding the functions of these cells is essential for developing targeted therapies to treat diseases that involve dysregulation of the immune system.
CL:0000899:
T-helper 17 (Th17) cells are a subset of CD4+ T cells that play a critical role in orchestrating the immune response against extracellular bacterial and fungal infections. These cells are characterised by their production of the cytokine interleukin-17 (IL-17), which triggers inflammation and recruits immune cells such as neutrophils to the site of infection. Th17 cells also produce other cytokines including IL-21 and IL-22, which can promote tissue repair and contribute to host defence against pathogens.

Despite their protective role in immunity against pathogens, aberrant Th17 cell activity has been associated with a number of autoimmune diseases including rheumatoid arthritis, multiple sclerosis and inflammatory bowel disease. In these conditions, Th17 cells are thought to contribute to tissue damage and inflammation due to their production of proinflammatory cytokines such as IL-17 and IL-21. The precise mechanisms underlying Th17 cell differentiation and activity in health and disease are the subject of ongoing research and are of interest for the development of new therapeutics to modulate immune responses.

Th17 cell differentiation is tightly regulated by a complex network of transcription factors, cytokines and signalling pathways.
