During differentiation, pre-B-II cells undergo clonal expansion, generating a large population of B cells that express diverse receptors. These receptors, known as B cell receptors (BCRs), recognize specific antigens and trigger an immune response. Once activated, mature B cells can differentiate into plasma cells that produce and secrete antibodies, which are essential for eliminating pathogens and providing long-term protection against infections.

In addition to their role in adaptive immunity, pre-B-II cells have also been implicated in autoimmune diseases such as lupus and rheumatoid arthritis. Abnormalities in B cell development can lead to the production of autoantibodies, which attack the body's own tissues. Understanding the molecular mechanisms that regulate pre-B-II cell differentiation and B cell receptor signaling is therefore important for developing new therapies for these diseases.
CL:0002056:
Fraction F mature B cells represent a distinct stage in the development of B cells from progenitor to fully differentiated effector cells. These cells are located in the peripheral lymphoid organs such as the spleen, lymph nodes, and Peyer's patches. They are characterized by their expression of CD19, CD20, and other surface markers, as well as their ability to produce and secrete antibodies in response to antigen stimulation.

The key function of fraction F mature B cells is to produce high-affinity antibodies against foreign antigens for the protection of the host organism. These antibodies are produced through a complex process of somatic hypermutation and class switch recombination that occurs in the germinal centers of secondary lymphoid organs. Fraction F mature B cells play a critical role in this process by providing the necessary substrate for the generation of high-affinity memory and plasma B cells. 

In addition to their antibody-producing function, fraction F mature B cells also play a regulatory role in the immune system. They can present antigens to T cells and activate them to participate in immune responses, or they can suppress T cell activation and maintain immune tolerance. Fraction F mature B cells are also involved in the control of autoimmune diseases and cancer immunotherapy. Overall, these cells are critical players in the immune response and are essential for the maintenance of an optimal immune system.
CL:0000941:
Thymic conventional dendritic cells (cDCs) are a specialized subset of dendritic cells (DCs) found in the thymus organ. These cells are involved in regulating the development and differentiation of T cells, which are specialized immune cells that help defend the body against infectious agents and cancer cells. Thymic cDCs play a critical role in shaping the T cell repertoire by presenting self and foreign antigens to developing T cells and by providing signals that direct their differentiation into various T cell subtypes.

Thymic cDCs express a unique set of cell surface molecules, including CD11c, CD11b, CD103, and MHC class II, that distinguish them from other cells in the thymus. These molecules allow thymic cDCs to capture antigens from other cells in the thymus and present them to developing T cells in a highly efficient manner. When a T cell recognizes an antigen presented by a thymic cDC, it undergoes a process of positive or negative selection, which determines whether it will survive and differentiate into a functional T cell or undergo apoptosis.

In addition to their role in T cell development, thymic cDCs also play a role in maintaining immune tolerance by removing self-reactive T cells from the thymus before they enter the peripheral circulation. This process, known as central tolerance, is critical for preventing autoimmune diseases, where the immune system attacks the body's own cells and tissues. Thymic cDCs achieve central tolerance by presenting self-antigens to developing T cells in a way that induces either deletion or functional inactivation of autoreactive T cells. Overall, thymic cDCs are essential components of the thymus microenvironment that regulate the production of mature T cells and prevent the development of autoimmunity.
CL:0000966:
Bm4 B cells are a type of B cell that are commonly found in the bone marrow and spleen of mice. These cells are known for their ability to produce a specific type of antibody known as IgM. Bm4 B cells are involved in the humoral immune response, which is the part of the immune system that involves the production of antibodies to fight off infections.

Bm4 B cells are activated when they encounter a foreign antigen, such as a virus or bacterium. Once activated, Bm4 B cells begin to produce large amounts of IgM antibodies that are highly specific to that antigen. These antibodies are then released into the bloodstream where they can specifically bind to the foreign antigen and either neutralize it or mark it for destruction by other immune cells.

In addition to their role in the humoral immune response, Bm4 B cells have also been shown to play a role in autoimmunity. Studies have found that Bm4 B cells are involved in the production of autoantibodies, which are antibodies that mistakenly target the body's own tissues and organs. This can lead to the development of autoimmune diseases such as lupus or rheumatoid arthritis.
CL:0000967:
Bm5 B cells are a subset of B cells that are commonly found in the spleen. They are known for their ability to produce autoantibodies, which target the body's own tissues. This makes them a key player in autoimmune diseases, such as lupus, and they have been extensively studied in this context. Bm5 B cells express a unique set of surface markers, including CD72 and CD45R/B220, which help to distinguish them from other B cell subsets.

In addition to their role in autoimmunity, Bm5 B cells may also play a role in the generation of memory B cells. Memory B cells are a type of B cell that are created during an immune response and "remember" the pathogen that triggered the response. This allows the immune system to quickly mount a response if the pathogen is encountered again. There is evidence to suggest that Bm5 B cells are more efficient at generating memory B cells than other B cell subsets.

Overall, Bm5 B cells are an important subset of B cells with unique functional properties. Their ability to produce autoantibodies makes them an important player in autoimmune diseases, while their role in generating memory B cells suggests that they may play a broader role in the immune response. Further research is needed to fully understand the function of Bm5 B cells and how they contribute to the immune system.
CL:0000965:
Bm3 B cells are a type of B lymphocyte found in the peripheral blood of chickens. These cells are characterized as being positive for the MHC class II cell surface receptor and negative for the B-cell marker Bu-1. Bm3 B cells are unique in comparison to other B cell subtypes due to their ability to produce antibodies against a wide range of antigens. This function is attributed to the presence of specialized receptors on the B cell surface that are capable of recognizing a vast array of antigenic molecules.

In addition to being involved in the humoral immune response, Bm3 B cells have also been shown to play a role in the regulation of cellular immunity in chickens. Studies have shown that these cells have the ability to produce cytokines and other immunomodulatory molecules such as transforming growth factor beta (TGF-beta) and interleukin-10 (IL-10). These factors help to regulate the activity of T cells, which are critical for effective cellular immunity.

Overall, Bm3 B cells are a unique subset of B lymphocytes that play important roles in both humoral and cellular immunity. Their ability to produce antibodies against a wide range of antigens and their immunomodulatory capabilities make them an important component of the immune system in chickens. Further research on these cells could lead to new insights into the mechanisms underlying immune regulation and the development of more effective vaccines and immunotherapies.
CL:0000962:
Bm2 B cells are classified as a type of B cell that is present in the spleen and plays an essential role in the immune response. These cells primarily serve as the precursors for antibody-secreting cells and, consequently, enhance the immunological response. Bm2 cells are known to respond to antigens present in the body and produce antibodies that bind specifically to them. These antibodies form immune complexes that can effectively neutralize antigens and help the immune system identify and eliminate foreign pathogens.

The function of Bm2 cells is not limited to antibody production as they also regulate the activity of other immune cells. Bm2 cells can act as antigen-presenting cells by processing and presenting antigens to other immune cells, such as T cells. This interaction between Bm2 and T cells enhances the immune response and ultimately results in a more effective elimination of the antigen. Additionally, Bm2 cells are known to secrete cytokines that promote the development of other immune cells, such as natural killer cells and T cells.

Bm2 cells also play an essential role in autoimmune diseases by promoting the production of autoantibodies that attack the body's own tissues. This can lead to various autoimmune disorders, such as systemic lupus erythematosus and rheumatoid arthritis. Hence, understanding the biology and function of Bm2 B cells can be critical in the development of new therapies and treatments for autoimmune disorders.
CL:0000960:
A T3 B cell, also known as a transitional B cell, is a type of immune cell that is involved in the maturation of B cells. This cell type is found in the blood and lymphoid tissues, where it plays a crucial role in the development of a functional immune system. 

During the early stages of B cell development, cells undergo a series of differentiation steps that eventually lead to the production of mature B cells. T3 B cells are a transitional stage in this process and represent a critical checkpoint in the development of the B cell repertoire. These cells are characterized by the expression of specific surface markers, including CD19, CD24, and CD38.

One of the key functions of T3 B cells is to undergo somatic hypermutation, a process that introduces genetic variability into the B cell receptor (BCR) in response to antigen stimulation. This process helps to generate B cells with high-affinity BCRs that are able to recognize and bind to specific pathogens. In addition to somatic hypermutation, T3 B cells are also involved in the generation of memory B cells, which provide long-term protection against recurrent infections. Overall, T3 B cells play a critical role in the development of a functional immune system and are essential for effective adaptive immunity.
CL:0000925:
Activated CD4-positive type I NK T (NKT) cells are a unique subset of T lymphocytes that express both T cell receptor (TCR) and natural killer (NK) cell receptors. They play a critical role in regulating immune responses by producing large amounts of cytokines rapidly after activation. These cells have the ability to recognize glycolipid antigens presented by the nonclassical MHC class I-like molecule CD1d, which is expressed by dendritic cells, B cells, and macrophages. Upon recognition of CD1d-glycolipid complexes, NKT cells rapidly produce a variety of cytokines such as interferon-gamma, IL-4, IL-10, and tumor necrosis factor-alpha that modulate immune responses.

Activated CD4-positive type I NKT cells have been implicated in a wide range of immune responses, including antitumor, anti-viral, and anti-bacterial immunity, as well as the regulation of autoimmune diseases. These cells can kill target cells directly through the release of cytotoxic granules or indirectly by inducing apoptosis or recruiting other immune cells. In addition, they can modulate the function of other immune cells such as dendritic cells, macrophages, B cells, and conventional T cells. This makes activated CD4-positive type I NKT cells desirable targets for immunotherapy in a variety of diseases.

Overall, activated CD4-positive type I NKT cells have a crucial role in regulating immune responses by producing a variety of cytokines and by contributing to the activation or inhibition of other immune cells. Their unique TCR and NK receptor expression allows them to recognize and respond to glycolipid antigens presented by CD1d, making them important players in the initiation and modulation of immune responses.
CL:0000998:
CD8α-negative CD11b-negative dendritic cells (DN DCs) are a rare subset of dendritic cells found in both lymphoid and non-lymphoid tissues. They are characterized by a lack of expression of the CD8α and CD11b surface markers, and thus are distinct from other dendritic cell subsets. DN DCs are generated from hematopoietic stem cells in the bone marrow, and can differentiate into multiple subpopulations of dendritic cells depending on environmental cues.

DN DCs are thought to play a role in immune tolerance, as they have been shown to induce regulatory T cell responses in some contexts. In addition, DN DCs have been implicated in the response to viral infections, as they can efficiently present viral antigens to CD4 T cells. Studies have also suggested a potential role for DN DCs in the generation of memory T cells.

Overall, the functions of DN DCs are not fully understood and require further investigation. However, the unique properties of DN DCs make them an intriguing subset of dendritic cells with the potential to play important roles in both immune tolerance and immunity to infectious agents.
CL:0000979:
IgG memory B cells are a subset of B cells that are key players in the adaptive immune response to pathogens. These cells are responsible for providing long-term protection against previously encountered pathogens through the production of high-affinity immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibodies. Unlike naïve B cells, IgG memory B cells do not require T cell help to differentiate into plasma cells, which produce large quantities of IgG antibodies.

Upon initial exposure to a pathogen, B cells differentiate into plasma cells and secrete antibodies to fight off the infection. Once the pathogen is cleared, a small population of these B cells differentiate into IgG memory B cells. These memory B cells are long-lived and are capable of rapidly differentiating into plasma cells upon re-exposure to the same pathogen. This rapid response allows for a more efficient clearance of the pathogen, often before the individual even experiences any symptoms of infection.

The production of IgG memory B cells is a result of the process of affinity maturation, which occurs during the germinal center reaction. During this process, B cells undergo somatic hypermutation and affinity selection, resulting in the production of B cells with high-affinity antibodies. These high-affinity B cells go on to become either plasma cells or IgG memory B cells. The production of IgG memory B cells is crucial for the success of vaccinations, as it allows for long-term protection against infectious diseases.
CL:0000982:
IgG plasmablasts are a specialized type of B-cell that are responsible for producing and secreting large amounts of immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibodies in response to an antigen. These cells are generated during the later stages of the immune response and play a critical role in providing long-lasting immunity against pathogens. IgG plasmablasts are characterized by their high rate of proliferation and antibody secretion, which allows them to rapidly produce large amounts of specific antibodies.

The main function of IgG plasmablasts is to produce and secrete large quantities of IgG antibodies that bind to antigens and neutralize them. IgG antibodies are the most abundant class of antibodies in the human body and play a critical role in providing long-term protection against infectious agents. IgG plasmablasts are able to produce highly specific antibodies that recognize and bind to the antigens of a particular pathogen, allowing for targeted elimination of the invader.

In addition to their role in producing antibodies, IgG plasmablasts have also been shown to contribute to the regulation of the immune response. These cells are able to interact with other immune cells, such as T-cells and dendritic cells, and can influence the activity and function of these cells. This makes IgG plasmablasts important players in the overall function of the immune system and highlights their importance in maintaining overall health and well-being.
CL:0001053:
IgD-negative memory B cells are a type of white blood cell that play an important role in the immune system's ability to recognize and respond to pathogens that have been previously encountered. Unlike naive B cells that have not yet been exposed to antigens, IgD-negative memory B cells have undergone class-switch recombination, a process in which they have changed their immunoglobulin isotype from IgM or IgD to other classes, such as IgG or IgA. This allows them to produce more specialized antibodies with greater affinity and efficiency against specific pathogens.

IgD-negative memory B cells are generated in response to infections or immunizations, and they persist in the body for extended periods of time, providing long-term protection against the same pathogen. They are able to quickly differentiate into plasma cells, which produce large amounts of antibodies in response to the pathogen, or to undergo further rounds of proliferation and differentiation to replenish the pool of memory B cells. In addition, IgD-negative memory B cells can also give rise to antibody-secreting cells that produce a variety of antibody isotypes, including IgA, IgG, and IgE, providing a diverse range of effector mechanisms to combat pathogens.

Overall, IgD-negative memory B cells are critical components of the adaptive immune system that confer lasting immunity against pathogens encountered during an individual's lifetime. Their ability to rapidly recognize and respond to previously encountered pathogens also makes them attractive targets for vaccine development, as stimulating their proliferation and differentiation can provide long-term protection against infectious diseases.
CL:0000978:
IgM short-lived plasma cells are a type of B lymphocyte that produce immunoglobulin M (IgM) antibodies in response to an antigenic challenge. These cells are formed in germinal centers of lymphoid tissues such as spleen, lymph nodes, and Peyer's patches. They have a relatively short lifespan compared to IgM long-lived plasma cells, surviving only for a few days to a week before they undergo programmed cell death.

The main function of IgM short-lived plasma cells is to provide an immediate response against an invading pathogen. They are the first line of defense against primary infections and are responsible for the production of an early phase of specific plasma cell response that is characterized by high IgM antibody titers. The rapid response of these cells is essential in the early stages of infection when the pathogen is still replicating and has not yet overwhelmed the host immune system.

In addition to their role in primary immune response, IgM short-lived plasma cells also play a critical role in secondary immune response. They participate in re-infection by rapidly differentiating into plasma cells that produce high-affinity antibodies (mainly IgG) upon re-exposure to the same pathogen. These high-affinity antibodies are more specific and have a higher affinity to the pathogen as compared to the IgM antibodies produced during the primary immune response. Therefore, IgM short-lived plasma cells are essential in the induction of long-lasting immunity against invading pathogens.
CL:0000931:
Activated Type II NK T cells are a subset of T cells that express natural killer (NK) cell markers and T cell receptors (TCRs). These cells combine the functions of both NK cells and T cells in their ability to recognize and kill infected cells and tumor cells. Activated Type II NK T cells are involved in both innate and adaptive immune responses and play a crucial role in regulating immune responses.

In terms of their role in the immune system, activated Type II NK T cells are important for the recognition of glycolipid antigens presented by CD1d molecules on antigen-presenting cells. Upon activation, these cells rapidly produce cytokines such as IFN-γ, IL-4, and IL-13, which can activate other immune cells and direct the immune response towards either a Th1 or Th2 response. Activated Type II NK T cells are also involved in the control of autoimmune diseases and have been shown to have potential therapeutic applications for the treatment of cancer.

Furthermore, activated Type II NK T cells exhibit a strong antitumor immune response due to their ability to recognize and kill tumor cells. They can also regulate the activity of immune cells such as dendritic cells (DCs) and macrophages, which can further enhance the immune response against tumor cells. Activated Type II NK T cells are being investigated for their potential in cancer immunotherapy, including in combination with other immunotherapeutic agents such as checkpoint inhibitors and monoclonal antibodies.
CL:0000981:
Double negative memory B cells, also known as DN2 B cells, are a subpopulation of B cells that have been shown to play a critical role in the immune response to certain infections. These cells are unique in that they lack the expression of both CD27 and IgD markers, and are characterized by their high expression of CD95 and CD80 surface markers. DN2 B cells are typically generated during the germinal center reaction in the spleen, where they undergo a process of somatic hypermutation and affinity maturation.

The function of DN2 B cells within the immune system is to serve as a long-lived memory reservoir for the production of high-affinity antibodies against previously encountered pathogens. Following an initial immune response to an infecting agent, a small population of DN2 B cells will survive and differentiate into long-lived memory cells that circulate throughout the body and are poised to rapidly respond to future infections by the same pathogen. The memory cells are able to differentiate into antibody-secreting plasma cells upon re-exposure to the same pathogen, thus providing a heightened level of immunity against recurrent infections.

Overall, DN2 B cells are an important component of the adaptive immune system due to their ability to generate a long-lasting and effective immune response to previously encountered pathogens. Their presence within the germinal centers of the spleen highlights their critical role in the immune response to certain infections, and they are therefore being actively studied for their potential use in the development of vaccines and other immunotherapeutic approaches.
CL:0001060:
Hematopoietic oligopotent progenitor cells, also known as HOPCs, are a type of stem cell that has the ability to give rise to several types of blood cells. Specifically, HOPCs are lineage-negative, meaning that they have not yet committed to developing into a particular type of blood cell (such as red blood cells or immune cells). As a result, HOPCs possess a great deal of potential for therapeutic applications in regenerative medicine.

HOPCs are able to differentiate into several different types of blood cells, including erythrocytes (red blood cells), leukocytes (white blood cells), and platelets. This ability makes them an essential component of our body's ability to fight infections, transport oxygen throughout the body, and maintain hemostasis (the process by which our blood clots to prevent excessive bleeding).

Researchers are currently exploring the potential of HOPCs for use in therapies for a range of blood disorders, including anemia, leukemia, and various immune system disorders. By harnessing the power of these versatile cells, scientists hope to develop new treatments that can help patients overcome these conditions and lead healthier, more fulfilling lives. Overall, hematopoietic oligopotent progenitor cells are a fascinating and incredibly important type of cell that may hold the key to treating a wide range of diseases and conditions in the future.
CL:0000969:
Regulatory B cells are a subset of B lymphocytes that have the ability to suppress and modulate immune responses. Unlike conventional B cells, regulatory B cells do not produce high levels of antibodies in response to an antigen, but instead have an immunomodulatory function. Regulatory B cells act at multiple stages of the immune response and are involved in both the innate and adaptive immune systems.

Regulatory B cells are involved in a variety of immune processes, including the regulation of autoreactive T cells, prevention of autoimmunity, and induction of tolerance. These cells can also promote the resolution of inflammation by producing anti-inflammatory cytokines, and can inhibit the activity of pro-inflammatory immune cells. In addition, regulatory B cells can suppress the activation and proliferation of T cells and dendritic cells, and modulate the production of antibodies by other B cells.

Research on regulatory B cells is ongoing, and the potential clinical applications of these cells are being investigated. For example, regulatory B cells may be used to treat autoimmune diseases such as multiple sclerosis, rheumatoid arthritis, and lupus. Additionally, regulatory B cells may have a role in the treatment of graft-versus-host disease and in combating cancer by regulating the anti-tumor immune response. Overall, regulatory B cells represent an important cell type in the immune system, and their immunomodulatory function is critical for maintaining immune homeostasis and preventing autoimmunity.
CL:0000983:
IgM plasmablasts are a type of immune cell differentiated from B cells that play a key role in the primary immune response to an antigen. Upon encountering a pathogen, B cells undergo differentiation into plasmablasts, which produce and secrete antibodies specific to that antigen. IgM plasmablasts, in particular, are known for their recognition of antigens during the early stages of an immune response.

IgM plasmablasts primarily differentiate from naive B cells, which have not yet been exposed to an antigen. Upon activation, these B cells rapidly proliferate and differentiate into short-lived plasmablasts that secrete large quantities of IgM antibodies. These IgM antibodies play a crucial role in neutralizing pathogens during the initial immune response.

In addition to their role in the primary immune response, IgM plasmablasts also play a role in the development of long-lasting immunity. A subset of IgM plasmablasts differentiates into memory B cells that persist in the body for a prolonged period of time. These memory B cells are able to mount a faster and more effective immune response upon re-exposure to the same pathogen, leading to the rapid production of high-affinity antibodies. Overall, IgM plasmablasts play a crucial role in the immune response to pathogens, both in the short-term and in the development of long-term immunity.
CL:0000992:
An immature CD11c-low plasmacytoid dendritic cell (pDC) is a type of dendritic cell that plays a critical role in the immune system. These cells are derived from the bone marrow and are known for their ability to produce type I interferon in response to viral infections. Immature pDCs are characterized by low levels of CD11c, a cell surface protein commonly found on other types of dendritic cells. Instead, they express high levels of other markers such as CD123 and BDCA-2, which are unique to pDCs.

Unlike other dendritic cells, immature pDCs are not efficient antigen-presenting cells. However, they play a critical role in initiating the immune response to viral infections by secreting type I interferon. This triggers the activation of other immune cells, including cytotoxic T cells and natural killer cells, which work together to eliminate the virus. Immature pDCs also play a role in regulating the immune response by suppressing the activation of T cells.

In addition to their role in antiviral immunity, immature pDCs have also been shown to play a role in the pathogenesis of autoimmune diseases. Patients with autoimmune disorders such as lupus and psoriasis have been found to have higher levels of circulating pDCs, suggesting that these cells may contribute to the development of these diseases. Thus, understanding the function and regulation of immature pDCs is critical for developing new therapies for viral infections and autoimmune diseases.
CL:0000976:
IgA short-lived plasma cells are a specialized type of cells that play a crucial role in the immune system of mammals such as humans. They are found in the gastrointestinal tract, respiratory tract, and mammary gland, among other organs of the body. IgA short-lived plasma cells are differentiated from B lymphocytes upon activation by antigens, such as those present in bacteria or viruses, and produce large quantities of immunoglobulin A (IgA) antibodies. These antibodies are secreted into the mucosa, where they help to prevent infections by neutralizing and eliminating pathogens.

IgA short-lived plasma cells have a relatively short lifespan, typically ranging from a few days to two weeks. This is in contrast to other types of plasma cells, which can live for months or even years. However, despite their brief existence, IgA short-lived plasma cells are essential for the effective functioning of the immune system. They provide a rapid and potent response to new antigens, allowing the immune system to quickly eliminate potential threats and prevent the spread of disease.

One of the key features of IgA short-lived plasma cells is their ability to localize to particular areas of the body. For example, IgA short-lived plasma cells in the gastrointestinal tract produce antibodies that are specific to the microbes and antigens found in that environment, while those in the respiratory tract produce antibodies that target airborne pathogens. This specialized localization allows for highly targeted immune responses, which can help to prevent infections while minimizing damage to healthy tissues.

Pre-conventional dendritic cells (pre-cDCs) are a subset of dendritic cells that play a crucial role in the initiation of the immune response. These cells are found primarily in the bone marrow and peripheral lymphoid tissues, where they reside in an immature state ready to respond to foreign antigens. Pre-cDCs are known for their characteristic morphology, with long dendrites extending from their cell bodies that allow for efficient antigen uptake. 

Once pre-cDCs encounter foreign antigens, they undergo a process of maturation and migrate to the lymph nodes, where they present these antigens to T cells to initiate an immune response. Pre-cDCs have been shown to be particularly efficient at cross-presentation of antigens, meaning that they are able to present exogenous antigens on MHC class I molecules to CD8+ T cells, leading to the activation of cytotoxic T cells. 

In addition to their role in initiating immune responses, pre-cDCs have been implicated in immune tolerance. These cells have been shown to induce regulatory T cells, which help to dampen excessively strong immune responses that can lead to autoimmunity. Dysregulation of pre-cDC function has been linked to numerous autoimmune and inflammatory disorders, making these cells a potential target for therapeutic intervention in the future.

Mature CD11c-low plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs) are key players in innate and adaptive immune responses against viral and bacterial infections, as well as in the regulation of immune tolerance. pDCs are characterized by their ability to produce high levels of type I interferon (IFN) in response to viral infection or CpG DNA stimulation, which contributes to the induction of an antiviral state in neighboring cells and the activation of various immune cells including T and B cells. 

Mature CD11c-low pDCs have a unique phenotype with low expression of surface markers, including CD11c and major histocompatibility complex class II (MHC II), which distinguishes them from other dendritic cell subsets. They express high levels of bone marrow stromal antigen 2 (BST2) and CD123 on their surface, which are used as specific markers for their identification. Mature CD11c-low pDCs are primarily found in lymphoid tissues, such as the spleen and lymph nodes, and can also be found in peripheral blood. 

In addition to their antiviral functions, mature CD11c-low pDCs also contribute to immune tolerance by inducing regulatory T cells (Tregs) and secreting anti-inflammatory cytokines such as IL-10 and TGF-β. This ability to induce Tregs is particularly important in preventing autoimmune diseases and transplant rejection. Overall, mature CD11c-low pDCs play a critical role in the regulation of immune responses and the maintenance of immune homeostasis.

CD11c-negative plasmacytoid dendritic cells are a subset of dendritic cells that express high levels of Toll-like receptors (TLRs). These cells are capable of producing large amounts of type I interferon (IFN) in response to viral infections, making them critical players in the host defense against viruses. Unlike other dendritic cell populations, CD11c-negative plasmacytoid dendritic cells lack CD11c expression, but they express the cell surface markers CD123 and CD303.

CD11c-negative plasmacytoid dendritic cells can differentiate into antibody-producing cells, indicating that they play a role in adaptive immunity as well. These cells are thought to be involved in the pathogenesis of autoimmune diseases such as lupus, where an abnormality in the production of type I interferon has been observed. CD11c-negative plasmacytoid dendritic cells express the transcription factor E2-2, which is important for their development and function.

Overall, CD11c-negative plasmacytoid dendritic cells are a crucial component of the immune system, serving as key orchestrators of antiviral immune responses. Their ability to produce large amounts of type I interferon, along with their potential involvement in adaptive immunity and autoimmunity, makes them an important cell type to study and understand.

Mature CD8_alpha-negative CD11b-positive dendritic cells are a specialized subtype of dendritic cells found in peripheral tissues such as lymph nodes and spleen. These cells are important for the initiation and regulation of immune responses by presenting antigens to T cells and promoting their activation. They are characterized by the absence of CD8α and the presence of CD11b on their surface.

Mature CD8_alpha-negative CD11b-positive dendritic cells have a unique ability to efficiently capture and process antigens from their surroundings and present them to T cells through their major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules. This process, called antigen presentation, is essential for the activation of T cells and the generation of effective immune responses against infectious agents and cancer cells.

Moreover, mature CD8_alpha-negative CD11b-positive dendritic cells also play a crucial role in the maintenance of immune tolerance by inducing the deletion or inactivation of auto-reactive T cells that recognize self-antigens. This process prevents the development of autoimmune diseases and ensures the preservation of normal tissue homeostasis. In summary, mature CD8_alpha-negative CD11b-positive dendritic cells are a key component of the immune system that orchestrates both protective and regulatory immune responses by generating and presenting antigenic information to T cells.

An immature CD8_alpha-negative CD11b-positive dendritic cell is a type of dendritic cell primarily found in lymphoid and non-lymphoid tissues. These cells are derived from hematopoietic stem cells and play a significant role in the immune system. They are considered part of the innate immune system as they act as one of the first lines of defense against infection and foreign pathogens.

These dendritic cells play an active role in antigen presentation to T-cells and are involved in the development of immune responses against infections. They are capable of recognizing antigenic peptides and presenting them to specialized T-cells, leading to the activation of both innate and adaptive immune responses. Furthermore, immature CD8_alpha-negative CD11b-positive dendritic cells can also induce immune tolerance by promoting the differentiation of regulatory T-cells. This regulatory function is important in preventing autoimmune diseases.

Immature CD8_alpha-negative CD11b-positive dendritic cells express a variety of pattern recognition receptors involved in pathogen recognition, including Toll-like receptors. The expression of these receptors allows dendritic cells to recognize a wide range of pathogens, including bacteria, viruses, and parasites. Activated dendritic cells coordinate the immune response by producing cytokines, chemokines, and other immune mediators to recruit immune cells to the site of infection. These cells also play a role in tissue homeostasis and maintenance of tolerance to self-antigens.

IgG short lived plasma cells are a specialized type of immune cells that arise from B cells upon activation by antigens. These cells possess the unique ability to produce and secrete large amounts of immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibodies. Unlike traditional long-lived plasma cells, these cells have a shorter lifespan and die off within a few days of their creation. Their main function is to quickly generate a large number of antibody-secreting cells during an immune response and contribute to the early stages of effective immune defense.

Upon encountering their respective antigens, B cells undergo a process of proliferation and differentiation into plasma cells. IgG short-lived plasma cells represent an early wave of plasma cells that arise in the immune response, and are instrumental in the generation of high-affinity antibodies that can efficiently neutralize the invading pathogens. These cells secrete large amounts of IgG antibodies, which can home to sites of inflammation and infection, and tag the pathogens for destruction by other immune cells. These antibodies can also activate the complement system, leading to further destruction of the pathogens.

The lifespan of IgG short-lived plasma cells is regulated by several factors, including the presence of survival factors and cytokines within the microenvironment. These cells rely on continuous stimulation and support from other immune cells to maintain their function. While they have a relatively short lifespan, their contributions to the immune response are essential in containing and eliminating pathogens, and paving the way for the generation of longer lived protective immunity.

CD11c-low plasmacytoid dendritic cells are a type of immune cell that play a critical role in the body's defense against viral infections and cancer. These cells are characterized by their low expression of CD11c, a surface protein that is normally found on other types of dendritic cells that are involved in initiating immune responses against pathogens. Instead, plasmacytoid dendritic cells are identified by their high levels of expression of the surface proteins CD123 and BDCA-2.

Plasmacytoid dendritic cells are known for their ability to produce large amounts of type I interferon in response to viral infections. Type I interferon is a key player in the immune response to viral infections, stimulating the activation of other immune cells, like T cells and natural killer cells, that can directly destroy infected cells. In addition to their antiviral function, plasmacytoid dendritic cells have been shown to play a key role in eliciting an immune response against cancer. Specifically, these cells can help to trigger the activation of cytotoxic T cells, which are capable of recognizing and destroying cancer cells.

Despite their critical role in the immune system, plasmacytoid dendritic cells are rare cells, typically accounting for less than 1% of the immune cells in the blood. They are also a relatively recent discovery, having only been identified in the late 1990s. Despite these challenges, researchers are continuing to investigate the role of plasmacytoid dendritic cells in the immune response to viral infections and cancer, with the ultimate goal of harnessing their potential for therapeutic purposes.

An immature CD11c-negative plasmacytoid dendritic cell (ipDC) is a type of dendritic cell that plays a crucial role in the innate immune response against viral infections. These cells are characterized by the absence of the CD11c surface marker, which is used as a marker for conventional dendritic cells. Instead, ipDCs express high levels of the cell surface marker CD123, also known as the alpha chain of the interleukin-3 receptor. 

IpDCs are precursor cells that differentiate into mature plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs) upon activation by viral infections or other stimuli. They are able to produce large amounts of type 1 interferons, such as IFN-alpha, in response to viral infections. This makes them a critical component of the host defense against viral infections. Additionally, ipDCs are able to activate naive T cells and promote the development of anti-viral CD8+ T cell responses, which are important for clearing viral infections.

In summary, immature CD11c-negative plasmacytoid dendritic cells are a specialized type of dendritic cell that play a critical role in the innate immune response against viral infections. These cells are important for producing type 1 interferons and promoting the development of anti-viral T cell responses.

CD8-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells are an important subset of T lymphocytes that are known for their potent cytotoxic activity. These cells derive from mature CD8 T cells that have undergone antigen-specific activation in response to foreign antigens. Unlike CD8-positive, alpha-beta effector T cells, memory T cells are characterized by a more quiescent state and a higher capacity for antigen recognition and immune memory.

CD8-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells play a critical role in the body's immune defense against multiple types of pathogens such as viruses, bacteria, and parasites. At the time of their activation, these cells differentiate into long-lived memory cells that can persist in the body for extended periods and respond more efficiently to re-exposure to the same antigen. This response is crucial to prevent future infections from the same pathogen as the cell-mediated immune memory facilitates a faster and more effective response.

Moreover, CD8-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells are essential for providing immune surveillance against tumors. They have been shown to have specific cytotoxic activity against malignant cells that express tumor-specific antigens. The cytotoxic activity of these cells allows them to kill cancerous cells and prevent tumorigenesis, making them an attractive immunotherapeutic target for cancer therapy.  Overall, CD8-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells are a critical component of the immune system that play a significant role in immunological memory and provide essential protection against infections and cancers.

Interstitial dendritic cells (IDCs) are a subset of dendritic cells that reside in the interstitial spaces of various tissues such as the skin, lungs, and intestine. IDCs are bone marrow-derived cells that play a critical role in immune surveillance and initiation of immune responses against foreign antigens. They are characterized by their specialized dendritic processes which help them to capture antigens, process them and present them to T cells for activation.

IDCs are known to express a variety of pattern recognition receptors such as toll-like receptors (TLRs), NOD-like receptors (NLRs), and RIG-like receptors (RLRs) which allows them to recognize different types of pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs). Upon recognition of PAMPs, IDCs produce a variety of cytokines and chemokines that help in the recruitment and activation of other immune cells to the site of infection. 

IDCs also interact with other cell types in the tissue microenvironment such as fibroblasts, epithelial cells, and endothelial cells through the expression of various adhesion molecules and chemokines. This interaction helps to regulate immune responses and maintain tissue homeostasis. Overall, IDCs play a critical role in the immune system by initiating and regulating immune responses against pathogens and maintaining immune tolerance to self-antigens.

Mature dermal dendritic cells are a specialized type of immune cell mainly located in the skin. They play a crucial role in defending the body against foreign pathogens by capturing and presenting antigens to T cells. Mature dermal dendritic cells have a unique structure that allows them to interact with T cells in the skin. They have extensive dendritic projections that contact T cells, as well as other immune cells like Langerhans cells. These interactions enable them to transfer captured antigens to T cells, thereby activating immune responses. Moreover, mature dermal dendritic cells produce various cytokines that promote inflammation and recruit other immune cells to the site of infection. 

Mature dermal dendritic cells have a complex network of receptors that detect and respond to different stimuli. They express pattern recognition receptors such as toll-like receptors (TLRs) that recognize pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs). Upon activation, these receptors trigger signaling pathways that upregulate the expression of co-stimulatory molecules like CD80 and CD86, which enhance antigen presentation to T cells. Overall, mature dermal dendritic cells are critical mediators of immune responses in the skin and play a crucial role in fighting off infections.

CD1a-positive Langerhans cells are a unique subset of dendritic cells that are found primarily in the skin and mucosal surfaces. One of the primary functions of CD1a-positive Langerhans cells is antigen presentation. These cells are able to uptake antigens, including microbial pathogens and self-antigens, and present them to T cells in order to initiate an immune response. This function is particularly important in the skin, where Langerhans cells are the first line of defense against invading pathogens.

These cells have been shown to express regulatory cytokines and participate in the production of regulatory T cells, which help to prevent autoimmune diseases and maintain immune homeostasis. Overall, CD1a-positive Langerhans cells are a crucial component of the skin immune system and are essential for the maintenance of skin homeostasis and the prevention of skin infections and diseases.

Therefore, understanding the molecular mechanisms that regulate pDC function is essential for developing targeted therapies for these conditions. Mature CD11c-negative pDCs are a vital component of the immune system, playing a critical role in the initiation of immune responses against viral infections and cancers while serving as a potential target for immunotherapies and vaccine development.

Unswitched memory B cells are a specialized subpopulation of B lymphocytes that play a significant role in the body's immune response. These cells are crucial for identifying and combating pathogens that have not been previously encountered by the immune system. Unswitched memory B cells, as the name suggests, have not undergone class-switching, which is the process that enables B cells to switch from producing immunoglobulin M (IgM) to other antibody classes such as IgG, IgA, and IgE, with different immunological functions. In addition to producing IgM, these cells also express low levels of IgD on their surface.

The primary function of unswitched memory B cells is to maintain a long-term memory of pathogens encountered by the body. Upon initial contact with a pathogen, the immune system generates a massive diverse population of B cells that produces a wide range of antibodies to fight the pathogen. After successful clearance of the pathogen, B cells that recognize the pathogen are selectively maintained as memory B cells. These memory B cells have the capacity to recognize and respond more robustly to the pathogen if it is encountered again. Unswitched memory B cells, being a part of memory B cell population, are capable of recognizing and responding to new infections that have not been encountered before.

In summary, unswitched memory B cells are an essential component of the immune system. They play a significant role in providing long-term immunity against previously unencountered pathogens by maintaining a memory of the pathogens. These cells are specialized in producing antibodies for IgM and expressing low levels of IgD on their surface, which allows them to function efficiently in their unique role within the immune system.

An IgM plasma cell is a subtype of plasma cell that is responsible for producing and secreting immunoglobulin M (IgM) antibodies. These cells are a crucial part of the immune system's humoral response, which is the part of the immune system that involves the production of antibodies to fight off foreign pathogens and infections. IgM plasma cells are generated in response to an initial infection and serve as the primary source of IgM antibodies during the early stages of an immune response.

IgM is the first antibody produced in response to an infection, and it is particularly effective at neutralizing pathogens such as bacteria and viruses. IgM antibodies are also important for activating other components of the immune system, such as complement proteins, which can enhance the body's ability to clear infections. IgM plasma cells play a critical role in ensuring that there is a rapid and robust humoral immune response to new infections, providing protection against the pathogen before it can cause significant harm.

In addition to their role in fighting infections, IgM plasma cells also play a critical role in long-term immunity. After an initial infection, some IgM plasma cells differentiate into long-lived plasma cells that can continue to produce low levels of IgM antibodies for years or even decades. This provides the body with a level of protection against future infections with the same pathogen, as the presence of pre-existing IgM antibodies can help to limit the severity of the infection and reduce the risk of complications. Overall, IgM plasma cells are an important component of the immune system's response to infection and play a critical role in both short-term and long-term immunity.
CL:0001021:
CD34-positive, CD38-positive common lymphoid progenitors (CLPs) are multipotent hematopoietic stem/progenitor cells that give rise to all lymphoid lineages in the adult organism. They are characterized by the expression of surface markers CD34 and CD38, and lack of expression of myeloid and erythroid markers. 

CLPs are responsible for the development of B cells, T cells, and natural killer (NK) cells. B cells are important for producing antibodies to protect against foreign pathogens, T cells are involved in cell-mediated immunity, and NK cells provide rapid response to viral infections and tumor cells. The differentiation potential of CLPs is regulated by the interaction with stromal cells that provide necessary signals for lymphoid development. 

CLPs migrate from the bone marrow to the thymus and fetal liver during embryonic development, and are critical for the establishment of functional lymphoid tissues. In addition, they are important for immune reconstitution after bone marrow transplantation. The dysregulation of CLPs can lead to various diseases, including immunodeficiencies, leukemias, and lymphomas. Therefore, the study of CLPs is important for understanding the development of lymphoid lineage and for developing new therapies for immunological disorders.
CL:0001016:
Immature CD1a-positive Langerhans cells, also known as iLCs, are a type of antigen-presenting cell found in the epidermis of the skin, as well as in the mucosa of the respiratory, gastrointestinal, and urinary tracts. These cells play a critical role in the immune system by recognizing and presenting foreign antigens to T cells to initiate an immune response. 

Immature CD1a-positive Langerhans cells are unique in that they express high levels of CD1a, a glycoprotein involved in lipid presentation to T cells, as well as high levels of Birbeck granules, which are rod-shaped structures within the cell that are thought to be involved in antigen processing. These cells are able to uptake antigens through receptor-mediated endocytosis and phagocytosis. Then, they migrate to lymph nodes where they present the antigen to T cells to initiate an immune response.

Although iLCs play an important role in the immune system, they are also implicated in inflammatory skin diseases such as psoriasis and atopic dermatitis. In these diseases, iLCs overproduce chemokines and cytokines, leading to chronic inflammation. Understanding the function and regulation of iLCs may provide important insights into the pathogenesis of these diseases and may offer new potential therapeutic targets.
CL:0001008:
Kit and Sca1-positive hematopoietic stem cells are adult stem cells that generate all different blood cells. These cells are found in the bone marrow and have the ability to differentiate into multiple types of blood cells, such as red and white blood cells, platelets, and immune cells. They are identified by the presence of the surface markers Kit and Sca1, which are used to isolate and purify these cells for further study and therapeutic applications.

The function of Kit and Sca1-positive hematopoietic stem cells is critical for the maintenance of the blood-forming system. These stem cells are responsible for the lifelong production of blood cells and play a crucial role in repairing the blood system after injury or disease. Additionally, they are a promising source of cells for regenerative therapies, as they can be expanded in culture and used to generate a variety of blood cell types for transplantation into patients with blood disorders.

Over the years, research has provided a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms that control the proliferation and differentiation of Kit and Sca1-positive hematopoietic stem cells. This knowledge has allowed scientists to explore new pathways to improve the expansion and differentiation of these cells and to create new and targeted therapies for a variety of blood disorders. The importance of these cells in the maintenance of the blood system and their potential for clinical applications make them a key focus of research in cell biology and regenerative medicine.
CL:0002465:
CD11b-positive dendritic cells (CD11b+ DCs) are a type of immune cell that plays a critical role in the regulation of innate and adaptive immunity. These cells are characterized by the expression of CD11b, a surface marker that distinguishes them from other dendritic cell subsets. CD11b+ DCs are found in various tissues throughout the body, including the spleen, lymph nodes, and skin.

CD11b+ DCs are known for their ability to capture and process antigens, which they display to T cells in order to initiate an immune response. These cells play a particularly important role in the initiation of antigen-specific T cell responses. CD11b+ DCs are also important for the priming and polarization of T helper cell responses. They can drive the differentiation of T cells into Th1, Th2, or Th17 subsets, depending on the presence of different cytokines in their local environment.

CD11b+ DCs are also involved in the regulation of immune tolerance. They are crucial for the maintenance of self-tolerance, preventing the immune system from attacking the body's own tissues. In addition, they are involved in the induction of peripheral tolerance by promoting the generation of regulatory T cells. This helps to prevent autoimmune diseases and allergic responses by suppressing immune responses to harmless antigens.
CL:0001018:
The immature CD8_alpha-low Langerhans cell is a type of dendritic cell that is found mainly in the epidermis of the skin and mucosa. These cells are responsible for the capture and processing of antigens and the presentation of these antigens to the immune system in order to trigger an immune response. The CD8 alpha-low Langerhans cell is a precursor to the mature Langerhans cell and plays a key role in the initiation of adaptive immunity.

The CD8 alpha-low Langerhans cell is characterized by its low levels of CD8 alpha expression and high levels of CD207 (langerin) expression. These cells are highly specialized in their function and are capable of capturing antigens through several mechanisms, including phagocytosis, macropinocytosis, and receptor-mediated endocytosis. Once captured, these antigens are processed and presented on major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules to T cells, which can then initiate an immune response.

Overall, the immature CD8 alpha-low Langerhans cell plays a crucial role in the initiation of adaptive immune response by capturing and processing antigens and presenting them to T cells. These cells are an important component of the immune system and their dysfunction or depletion can lead to immune-related disorders and diseases.
CL:0002035:
Slamf1-negative multipotent progenitor cells represent a class of hematopoietic progenitor cells that are mainly found in the bone marrow, and have the ability to differentiate into various cell types of the immune system. They are defined as negative for the surface expression of Slamf1 (Signaling Lymphocytic Activation Molecule Family member 1), which is a glycoprotein receptor that is expressed on the surface of many hematopoietic cells. Slamf1-negative multipotent progenitor cells are able to give rise to all blood cells, including erythrocytes, megakaryocytes, granulocytes, monocytes, dendritic cells, and B and T lymphocytes.

The functions of Slamf1-negative multipotent progenitor cells are essential for the maintenance of the immune system, since they are responsible for the generation of a continuous supply of new blood cells throughout life. These cells have the potential to replenish the entire blood system in conditions of stress, such as during infections or after chemotherapy. The differentiation of Slamf1-negative multipotent progenitor cells is tightly regulated by a complex network of transcription factors and cytokines that ensure the proper balance between self-renewal and differentiation.

Recent studies have shown that Slamf1-negative multipotent progenitor cells can also contribute to tissue repair and regeneration, beyond their traditional role in the immune system. For example, they have been shown to differentiate into osteoblasts, adipocytes, and chondrocytes, suggesting a potential application in regenerative medicine. Understanding the biology of Slamf1-negative multipotent progenitor cells is therefore important for the development of new therapies for a broad range of diseases, from immune disorders to bone and cartilage defects.
CL:0001015:
CD8_alpha-low Langerhans cells are a distinct subset of Langerhans cells found in the skin. Langerhans cells are dendritic cells that play an important role in the immune system by capturing and presenting antigens to T cells in order to initiate an immune response. The CD8_alpha-low Langerhans cell subset differs from other Langerhans cells in that they have lower levels of CD8α expression and higher levels of CD11b expression. 

CD8_alpha-low Langerhans cells have been shown to play a role in regulating immune responses in the skin. Studies have shown that these cells are more efficient at capturing antigens and activating CD4+ T cells than other Langerhans cell subsets. In addition, they have also been shown to be involved in the induction of regulatory T cells and the suppression of inflammatory responses in the skin. 

Overall, CD8_alpha-low Langerhans cells are a unique subset of Langerhans cells that play a crucial role in regulating immune responses in the skin. Their ability to capture and present antigens, activate other immune cells, and regulate inflammatory responses highlights their importance in maintaining skin homeostasis and preventing skin diseases.
CL:0001006:
Dermal dendritic cells (DDCs) are a unique subset of dendritic cells (DCs) that inhabit the skin and play a crucial role in the immune response to skin infections and pathogens. These cells are strategically positioned in the epidermis and dermis, where they constantly monitor the environment for potential threats such as invading microorganisms or allergens. DDCs are characterized by their complex dendritic morphology and expression of specific cell surface markers, including CD207/langerin and CD11b.

DDCs are widely recognized for their ability to sense and capture antigens from the skin and transport them to the draining lymph nodes to initiate a T-cell response, ultimately resulting in the differentiation of effector immune cells. DDCs also have a critical role in modulating the immune response to skin infections. For example, they can induce differentiation of T-cell subsets such as regulatory T cells, which help to limit excess inflammation and prevent tissue damage.

In addition to their immunological functions, recent studies have identified a role for DDCs in maintaining skin homeostasis. These cells have been shown to promote wound healing as well as prevent cancer development by inducing apoptosis of damaged skin cells. Taken together, the unique properties of dermal dendritic cells make them key players in both immune surveillance and skin health.
CL:0001019:
CD115-positive monocytes, also known as common dendritic progenitors (CDPs), are a type of bone marrow-derived cells that serve as precursor cells for both macrophages and dendritic cells. They express the receptor for colony-stimulating factor 1 (CSF1), also known as CD115, which is crucial for their survival and differentiation. CD115-positive monocytes comprise a small population of hematopoietic cells and are considered to be a very early stage of myeloid differentiation.

In terms of function, CD115-positive monocytes are primarily involved in the innate immune response. Upon migration to infected or inflamed tissues, they differentiate into macrophages, which engulf and digest pathogens and debris. Macrophages can also act as antigen-presenting cells and activate adaptive immunity. In addition, CD115-positive monocytes are also capable of differentiating into dendritic cells, which are specialized antigen-presenting cells that promote the activation of adaptive immune responses.

Given their important role in the immune system, aberrant function of CD115-positive monocytes has been linked to various pathologies, including infectious diseases, autoimmune disorders, and cancer. Understanding the mechanisms that govern the differentiation and function of these cells may therefore provide insights into the development and treatment of these diseases.
CL:0001042:
T-helper 22 cells, or Th22 cells, are a subset of CD4+ T cells that produce and secrete IL-22 cytokine. They play an important role in the immune system as they enhance anti-bacterial defense while also helping in the maintenance and repair of tissue barriers. 

Th22 cells primarily function as a mediator of inflammation in response to pathogens. IL-22, the cytokine produced by Th22 cells, coordinates the activities of immune cells, acting on epithelial cells to promote the production of antimicrobial peptides, induce mucus production, and repair tissue damage. Additionally, Th22 cells are known to play a key role in skin inflammatory diseases such as psoriasis and atopic dermatitis. 

However, a dysregulated population of Th22 cells can lead to autoimmune and inflammatory diseases. Th22 cell responses can be induced by various stimuli, including IL-6 and TNF-α, which are produced during chronic inflammation. Therefore, they are considered a potential therapeutic target for various inflammatory diseases.
CL:0000987:
IgA plasma cells, also known as Immunoglobulin A-secreting plasma cells, are a type of antibody-secreting cell involved in immune responses. These cells are derived from B lymphocytes and are responsible for producing and secreting immunoglobulin A (IgA) antibodies in mucosal tissues. IgA antibodies are critical in defending mucosal surfaces from harmful pathogens that enter the body through these regions.

IgA plasma cells are primarily found in mucosal tissues such as the respiratory, digestive, and reproductive tracts. They help to provide a first line of defense against infections by producing IgA antibodies that recognize and neutralize pathogens. IgA antibodies can bind to bacterial, viral, and fungal antigens, preventing them from attaching to and infecting host cells.

In addition to their role in immune defense, IgA plasma cells also play a role in the maintenance of healthy gut flora. IgA antibodies can bind to commensal bacteria, preventing them from causing inflammation or invading the body. Studies have shown that IgA deficiency is associated with increased susceptibility to gastrointestinal infections and autoimmune diseases. Thus, IgA plasma cells are an essential component of the immune system and are critical in protecting our bodies against harmful pathogens.
CL:0001017:
Mature CD1a-positive Langerhans cells are a type of dendritic cell that are mainly found in the epidermis of the skin and mucosal surfaces, such as those found in the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts. They are named after their discoverer, the German anatomist, and physician, Paul Langerhans. These cells play a crucial role in the immune system and are known for their unique ability to present antigens to T cells, thereby initiating an effective T cell-mediated immune response.

CD1a-positive Langerhans cells arise from bone marrow-derived progenitor cells and migrate to peripheral tissues, particularly the skin, where they establish close contacts with keratinocytes. Upon encountering a foreign antigen, such as from a pathogen, Langerhans cells capture and process the antigen, and then migrate to the draining lymph nodes where they present the antigen to naïve T cells. This process activates T cells, which then differentiate into effector T cells that can eliminate the pathogen.

Apart from their role in immunity, Langerhans cells have been implicated in the pathogenesis of autoimmune diseases, particularly in skin diseases such as psoriasis. They have also been shown to be involved in the induction of peripheral tolerance to self-antigens. In conclusion, mature CD1a-positive Langerhans cells have a crucial role in the immune system by presenting antigens to T cells and thereby initiating an effective T cell-mediated immune response.
CL:0001001:
The immature CD8_alpha-negative CD11b-negative dendritic cells are a subset of dendritic cells that do not express the CD8α or CD11b antigen. They are generally present in peripheral tissues and are known for their potent antigen-presenting capability. These cells play a crucial role in shaping the immune response by presenting the captured foreign antigens to the T cells and initiating an adaptive immune response.

The immature CD8_alpha-negative CD11b-negative dendritic cells are characterized by their unique ability to capture, process, and present antigens to the naïve T cells in the secondary lymphoid organs. This process involves the internalization of the antigen and its subsequent processing into smaller peptide fragments. These fragments are then loaded onto the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules of the dendritic cells, which are subsequently expressed on the cell surface. The MHC-peptide complex is then recognized by the T cell receptor, which initiates a series of signaling events that lead to the activation and differentiation of the T cells.

Furthermore, immature CD8_alpha-negative CD11b-negative dendritic cells promote the differentiation of T cells into effector T cells depending on the type of antigen presented and the environmental signals received. This property of the dendritic cells is important in determining the nature of the adaptive immune response and ultimately in eliminating the invading pathogens.

In summary, the immature CD8_alpha-negative CD11b-negative dendritic cells are an important subset of dendritic cells that play a crucial role in shaping the adaptive immune response. Their ability to capture and present antigens to the naïve T cells, as well as their plasticity in promoting the differentiation of T cells into effector T cells, make them critical players in the immune system.
CL:0001039:
Terminally differentiated osteoblasts are specialized bone-forming cells that arise from mesenchymal stem cells. Their primary function is to facilitate the mineralization and remodeling of the extracellular matrix within developing bones. Terminally differentiated osteoblasts produce and secrete type I collagen, alkaline phosphatase, and osteocalcin, which form the organic matrix of bone and are essential for mineral deposition.

As terminally differentiated cells, osteoblasts have limited proliferative abilities and are relatively resistant to apoptosis. Once generated, they can remain dormant within the bone matrix or undergo apoptosis and be replaced by new osteoblasts. Additionally, in response to certain physiological stimuli, such as bone injury or remodeling, terminally differentiated osteoblasts can differentiate further into osteocytes or bone-lining cells.

Osteoblasts play a crucial role in bone homeostasis and growth, and their dysfunction can lead to a wide range of bone-related diseases, including osteoporosis, osteogenesis imperfecta, and bone cancer. Understanding the molecular mechanisms that regulate osteoblast differentiation, survival, and function may provide new therapeutic targets for these diseases and improve overall bone health.
CL:0001011:
The immature interstitial dendritic cell (IIDC), also known as the interstitial dendritic cell (IDC), is a type of dendritic cell found in the interstitial spaces of lymphoid and non-lymphoid tissues. This cell type is derived from bone marrow progenitor cells and is characterized by a highly branched network of interdigitating processes that extend into the extracellular matrix. IIDCs play a crucial role in the regulation of both innate and adaptive immune responses.

IIDCs are known for their ability to efficiently capture and process antigens from the surrounding tissue environment. They use a variety of receptors, including lectins, scavenger receptors, and Toll-like receptors, to recognize and bind pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) and danger-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs). Once they have taken up antigens, IIDCs migrate to the draining lymph nodes, where they present them to T cells and B cells, initiating an immune response.

In addition to their role in antigen presentation, IIDCs also secrete a wide range of cytokines and chemokines that act on other cells in the immune system. These include interleukin-12 (IL-12), which promotes the differentiation of Th1 cells that secrete interferon-gamma (IFN-γ), and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α), which activates inflammatory responses and promotes antigen cross-presentation. Overall, the functions of IIDCs are essential for the maintenance of immunological homeostasis and the defense against infectious agents.
CL:0001022:
CD115-positive monocytes are a subtype of white blood cells that play an essential role in innate immunity and inflammation. These cells express the receptor CD115, also known as Colony Stimulating Factor 1 Receptor (CSF1R), on their cell surface, which is essential for their survival, proliferation, and differentiation. The main function of CD115-positive monocytes is to patrol the blood and tissues and act as the first line of defense against invading pathogens by recognizing, engulfing, and destroying them. 

CD115-positive monocytes are known to differentiate into several types of cells that depend on the type of signals they receive in their microenvironment. Some of the cells that CD115-positive monocytes can generate include macrophages, dendritic cells, and osteoclasts. Macrophages are phagocytic immune cells that engulf and digest cellular debris, apoptotic cells, and foreign pathogens, while dendritic cells are specialized in presenting antigens to T cells and play a critical role in adaptive immunity. Osteoclasts, on the other hand, are bone-resorbing cells that play a vital role in bone remodeling and regeneration.

Mutations or dysregulations in the CD115-positive monocytes can lead to various inflammatory and autoimmune diseases, such as atherosclerosis, rheumatoid arthritis, and multiple sclerosis. Thus, a better understanding of the function and regulation of CD115-positive monocytes could provide new insights into the pathophysiology of these diseases and lead to the development of effective treatments.
CL:0000999:
CD4-positive CD11b-positive dendritic cells are a specialized subset of dendritic cells that play a crucial role in the initiation and regulation of adaptive immune responses. These cells are found primarily in the secondary lymphoid organs, including lymph nodes and spleen, and are essential for linking innate and adaptive immune responses. They are characterized by the expression of CD4 and CD11b cell surface markers, which are involved in cell adhesion and antigen presentation.

The primary function of CD4-positive CD11b-positive dendritic cells is to present antigens to T cells, which are critical for the generation of an effective immune response. These cells capture antigens from invading pathogens and then present them to T cells in the context of major histocompatibility complex class II molecules. This process leads to the activation and proliferation of antigen-specific T cells, which then differentiate into effector cells that can eliminate the invading pathogen.

CD4-positive CD11b-positive dendritic cells also play a key role in shaping the nature of the immune response. These cells are able to secrete cytokines and chemokines that can direct the differentiation of T cells into different subsets, such as Th1, Th2, or regulatory T cells. This process allows CD4-positive CD11b-positive dendritic cells to fine-tune the immune response and ensure that it is appropriately tailored to the pathogen that is being encountered. In addition, these cells are also involved in the generation of immunological memory, which allows the host to mount a more rapid and effective immune response upon subsequent encounters with the same pathogen.
CL:0001020:
Mature CD8α-low Langerhans cells are a specialized subset of dendritic cells that reside in the epidermis, mucosal tissues, and lymphoid organs of mammals. These cells are named after their characteristic Birbeck granules, which are unique tennis racket-shaped organelles found within their cytoplasm. Mature Langerhans cells are CD45+MHCII+ cells that play a pivotal role in the immune system by processing and presenting antigens to T lymphocytes for recognition and response.

One main function of mature CD8α-low Langerhans cells is their ability to capture antigens that penetrate the skin and mucosal barriers. Once antigens are obtained, the Langerhans cells digest the antigens and present them on their surface in the context of MHC class II molecules. T lymphocytes that recognize these antigen-MHC complexes then bind to the mature Langerhans cells and trigger an immune response. This process is crucial for protecting the body against invading pathogens and for identifying and removing abnormal or infected cells.

Mature CD8α-low Langerhans cells also have the unique ability to induce tolerance to harmless antigens and self-antigens. This tolerogenic function is achieved by the secretion of specific cytokines and the regulation of T cell activation. In addition to their immunological functions, mature Langerhans cells play a critical role in the maintenance of skin homeostasis. These cells secrete various chemokines and cytokines that aid in wound healing, skin regeneration, and the prevention of skin autoimmunity.
CL:0001030:
CD117-positive common myeloid progenitors (CMPs) and CD217-positive common lymphoid progenitors (CLPs) are two distinct types of stem cells that give rise to all the blood and immune cells in the body. CMPs differentiate into erythrocytes, megakaryocytes, and granulocytes, while CLPs differentiate into T cells, B cells, and natural killer cells. These progenitor cells play an essential role in hematopoiesis, which is the process of blood cell formation.

CMPs and CLPs are characterized by the expression of the surface markers CD117 and CD217, respectively. These markers are essential for identifying and isolating these progenitor cells from other blood cells. Once isolated, these cells can be cultured and differentiated into various types of blood cells in vitro. This ability to differentiate into different cell types makes these progenitor cells valuable tools in regenerative medicine and cancer treatment.

Overall, CD117-positive common myeloid progenitors and CD217-positive common lymphoid progenitors are critical cell types in hematopoiesis and play a crucial role in maintaining the balance of blood and immune cells in the body. Understanding the molecular mechanisms of these progenitor cells can lead to new therapies for blood disorders and immune-related diseases.
CL:0001033:
Hippocampal granule cells are one of the most abundant cell types found in the dentate gyrus of the hippocampus region of the brain. These cells play a crucial role in the formation and maintenance of memory and learning processes. They receive input from the entorhinal cortex and process information from various regions of the brain before sending their output to the CA3 region of the hippocampus.

Hippocampal granule cells have a unique morphology with a small triangular or oval-shaped cell body and multiple branching dendritic processes. The dendrites have large numbers of spines that receive synaptic inputs from other neurons. These spines can undergo structural changes in response to learning and environmental experiences, which modulate the connectivity and function of granule cells.

The main function of hippocampal granule cells is to integrate and process information from various sources, including sensorimotor, contextual, and emotional experiences, to form representations of the external world that are stored and retrieved as memory traces. These cells also play a role in pattern separation, a process by which similar but distinct events are encoded as separate memories. Hippocampal granule cells are affected in various neurological disorders like epilepsy, Alzheimer's disease, and depression, leading to the disruption of learning and memory processes.
CL:0010012:
Cerebral cortex neurons are specialized cells found in the cerebral cortex, the outer layer of the brain responsible for conscious activity and sensory processing. These neurons are typically characterized by their complex dendritic branching patterns and their ability to perform complex processing of sensory information.
