Dysregulation of erythroid progenitor cell development has been linked to a range of anemias, and understanding the mechanisms underlying this process is fundamental to developing novel therapies to treat these disorders.
CL:0001056:
Dendritic cells (DCs) are a type of immune cell that play a crucial role in the regulation of adaptive and innate immunity. DCs function as antigen-presenting cells (APCs) by capturing and processing antigens, then presenting them to naive T cells in lymphoid tissues. Human DCs are a heterogeneous population that can be divided into different subsets based on their phenotype and function. 

One major subset of human DCs is the conventional DCs (cDCs), which are further divided into two subtypes: cDC1s and cDC2s. cDC1s are specialized in cross-presenting antigens from infected or dying cells to CD8+ T cells, thus inducing robust T cell-mediated cytotoxic responses. In contrast, cDC2s are highly effective at inducing CD4+ T cell-mediated immune responses and antibody production by B cells. In addition to cDCs, there is also a minor population of plasmacytoid DCs (pDCs) that are potent producers of type I interferons in response to viral infections. 

Being critical components of the immune system, dendritic cells have been widely investigated for their potential immunotherapeutic applications. For instance, DC-based vaccines that load antigens onto DCs ex vivo have shown promising results in inducing immune responses against cancer and infectious diseases. Furthermore, the ability of DCs to modulate immune responses makes them attractive targets for the treatment of autoimmune disorders, allergies, and transplant rejection. Therefore, a better understanding of the biology and function of human dendritic cells is essential for the development of effective therapies to combat various diseases.
CL:0002022:
Ly-76 high positive erythrocyte is a specific type of red blood cell that plays an important role in the immune system. These erythrocytes are characterized by their high expression of the Ly-76 protein, which is thought to be involved in immune cell recognition and activation. Ly-76 high positive erythrocytes are primarily found in the spleen and bone marrow, where they are thought to play a role in the clearance of damaged or infected red blood cells.

In addition to their immune function, Ly-76 high positive erythrocytes are also important for maintaining normal oxygen delivery throughout the body. These cells have a unique shape and flexibility that allows them to flow easily through narrow blood vessels, ensuring that oxygen is delivered to all tissues and organs. They are also able to release oxygen more readily than other types of red blood cells, which makes them particularly important in conditions where oxygen delivery may be compromised.

Overall, Ly-76 high positive erythrocytes are a fascinating and important cell type that play a critical role in both immune function and oxygen delivery. Further research on these unique cells is needed to fully understand their function and potential therapeutic applications in a range of medical conditions.
CL:0001081:
Group 2 innate lymphoid cells, also known as ILC2s, are a subset of innate lymphoid cells that play a crucial role in immune regulation and tissue homeostasis. They are mainly found in mucosal tissues such as the lungs, intestines, and skin. ILC2s are activated by various cytokines and can produce type 2 cytokines such as interleukin-5 (IL-5), IL-9, and IL-13, which are involved in the regulation of immune responses, tissue repair, and host defense against parasites.

In the lungs, ILC2s play a vital role in the regulation of asthma and other allergic diseases. Upon activation, they produce cytokines that recruit inflammatory cells to the lungs, leading to airway inflammation and bronchoconstriction. In addition, ILC2s induce mucus production, which contributes to airway obstruction. By identifying the cellular and molecular pathways that control ILC2 activation, researchers hope to develop new therapies for asthma and other allergic diseases.

ILC2s also play a critical role in the gut by regulating intestinal inflammation and tissue repair. They are particularly important in protecting against intestinal parasites, such as helminths. Upon activation, ILC2s produce cytokines that recruit eosinophils and other inflammatory cells to the site of infection. They also promote tissue repair by inducing the production of growth factors and antimicrobial peptides. Overall, ILC2s are an essential component of the innate immune system, and their dysregulation has been implicated in various diseases, including asthma, inflammatory bowel disease, and cancer.
CL:0002002:
Kit-positive granulocyte monocyte progenitor (GMP) is a type of hematopoietic stem cell found in the bone marrow that gives rise to both granulocytes and monocytes, two distinct types of white blood cells involved in the innate immune response to infection. As a precursor to these cells, the Kit-positive GMP is an important driver of immune cell development and function.

The Kit-positive GMP is identified by the presence of the Kit receptor, a type of protein found on the surface of the cell that is involved in cellular signaling and communication. This receptor is necessary for the survival and proliferation of the GMP, enabling it to divide and differentiate into both granulocytes and monocytes as needed. This ability to generate two distinct cell types allows for a versatile and adaptable immune response in the face of changing infectious threats.

Specifically, granulocytes are a specialized type of immune cell that target and eliminate pathogens such as bacteria and fungi. Monocytes, on the other hand, are another type of immune cell that migrate to sites of infection and inflammation, where they develop into macrophages and help to clear away damaged tissue and debris. Together, these cell types play crucial roles in protecting the body from infectious disease and maintaining overall health. The Kit-positive GMP is therefore a critical component of the immune system, supporting the development and function of these key immune cells.
CL:0001032:
Cortical granule cells, also known as cortical granule exocytosis cells, are a specialized type of cell found in the eggs and oocytes of certain organisms. These cells are unique in their structure and function, and play an important role in the process of fertilization. Cortical granule cells are characterized by their abundant cytoplasmic granules, which contain a variety of proteins and enzymes that are released upon fertilization.

The main function of cortical granule cells is to prevent polyspermy, the fertilization of an egg by multiple sperm cells. When a sperm successfully penetrates the egg, it triggers a series of events in the cortical granule cells that lead to the exocytosis of their granules. These granules release a variety of chemicals that create a physical barrier on the surface of the egg, preventing any other sperm from entering. This process is critical for ensuring the successful fertilization of an egg by a single sperm.

Cortical granule cells are also involved in other aspects of fertilization. They are responsible for preparing the egg for embryo development by modifying the egg's zona pellucida, a layer of glycoproteins that surrounds the egg. Through the release of their enzymes and other chemical signals, cortical granule cells trigger the hardening of the zona pellucida and prevent any additional sperm from entering. Overall, cortical granule cells play a critical role in the fertilization process and are essential for the successful development of many organisms.
CL:0002000:
Kit-positive erythroid progenitor cells are a type of hematopoietic stem cell that differentiate into red blood cells. They are characterized by their expression of the protein KIT, also known as CD117, on their surface. These cells are multipotent, meaning they have the ability to differentiate into several types of blood cells, but their primary function is to produce erythrocytes.

During erythropoiesis, the process of red blood cell production, Kit-positive erythroid progenitor cells undergo several stages of differentiation, ultimately giving rise to mature erythrocytes. In response to the hormone erythropoietin, these progenitor cells begin to proliferate and differentiate into erythroblasts. The erythroblasts then undergo several rounds of mitosis, gradually reducing in size and increasing in hemoglobin content until they become reticulocytes. The reticulocytes are then released into the bloodstream where they mature into erythrocytes.

Kit-positive erythroid progenitor cells play an essential role in maintaining healthy levels of red blood cells in the body. Their differentiation and production of erythrocytes are highly regulated by hormones and growth factors such as erythropoietin and stem cell factor. Dysregulation of erythropoiesis can result in conditions like anemia or erythrocytosis. Studying the molecular mechanisms that govern the differentiation of Kit-positive erythroid progenitor cells not only increases our understanding of erythropoiesis but also provides insight into potential therapeutic targets for treating blood disorders.
CL:0001065:
Innate lymphoid cells (ILCs) are a heterogeneous group of lymphocytes that are involved in the maintenance and regulation of tissue homeostasis, immune surveillance, and protection against pathogens. Unlike adaptive lymphocytes that require prior exposure to antigen, ILCs are activated rapidly in response to various inflammatory or tissue damage signals. ILCs are classified into three major groups based on their cytokine production, developmental pathways, and transcription factors: group 1 ILCs (ILC1s) produce IFN-γ and are related to Th1 cells, group 2 ILCs (ILC2s) produce IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 and are related to Th2 cells, and group 3 ILCs (ILC3s) produce IL-17 and/or IL-22 and are related to Th17 cells.

ILCs have been identified in various tissues including lymphoid organs, epithelial barriers of mucosal and non-mucosal tissues, fetal liver, and secondary lymphoid organs. ILCs are integral components of the innate immune system and have diverse functions in different tissues and settings. For example, ILC2s are implicated in the maintenance of tissue homeostasis by regulating tissue repair and regeneration, as well as in the pathogenesis of allergic and parasitic diseases. ILC3s are involved in controlling immunity and inflammation at mucosal barrier surfaces by regulating the production of antimicrobial peptides, maintenance of epithelial integrity, and tissue repair. ILC1s are important in defense against intracellular infections, tumor surveillance, and tissue repair.

Overall, ILCs are critical for the normal function and homeostasis of various tissues and play important roles in immune defense against pathogens and tumor cells. Dysregulation of ILC function has been associated with various diseases such as allergy, asthma, inflammatory bowel disease, and cancer. Thus, understanding the biology and regulation of ILCs is crucial for the development of new therapeutic approaches for these diseases.
CL:0002007:
The Kit-low, CD34-positive eosinophil progenitor cell is a precursor cell that gives rise to mature eosinophils. These cells are characterized by low expression levels of the cell surface receptor Kit (CD117) and high expression levels of CD34. Eosinophil progenitors are found in the bone marrow and give rise to eosinophils, which play an important role in the immune response against parasites and in allergic reactions.

The Kit-low, CD34-positive eosinophil progenitor cell is stimulated to differentiate into eosinophils by several cytokines, including interleukin-5 (IL-5) and granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF). These cells differentiate in response to signals from the microenvironment, which includes stromal cells and extracellular matrix components. The differentiation process involves several steps, including commitment to the eosinophil lineage and acquisition of the characteristic granules that contain toxic proteins and enzymes.

Once mature, eosinophils are able to migrate to tissues where they can perform their effector functions. These cells are particularly important in the host's defense against parasitic infections, where they can directly kill parasites and promote tissue repair. Eosinophils are also implicated in allergic reactions, where they contribute to inflammation and tissue damage. Dysregulation of eosinophil differentiation and function has been implicated in a variety of diseases, including asthma, eosinophilic esophagitis, and hypereosinophilic syndromes.
CL:0001071:
Group 3 innate lymphoid cells (ILC3s) are a subset of innate lymphoid cells that play a key role in maintaining gut homeostasis. They are characterized by the expression of the transcription factor RORγt and the production of cytokines such as IL-22 and IL-17. ILC3s are present in the gut-associated lymphoid tissue (GALT) and are involved in regulating the immune response to commensal bacteria and intestinal pathogens.

One of the key functions of ILC3s is the maintenance of gut epithelial integrity. They do this by producing cytokines that stimulate the production of antimicrobial peptides and promote the proliferation of gut epithelial cells. ILC3s also enhance mucus production, which helps to trap pathogens and prevent them from adhering to the gut epithelium. This plays an important role in preventing bacterial translocation and maintaining gut barrier function.

ILC3s are also involved in regulating the adaptive immune response. They interact with dendritic cells and T cells to promote the production of IgA antibodies and the differentiation of regulatory T cells. ILC3s also help to maintain a balance between pro-inflammatory and anti-inflammatory responses in the gut. Dysregulation of ILC3s has been implicated in the development of inflammatory bowel disease and other gut disorders.

In summary, ILC3s are a subset of innate lymphoid cells that play an important role in maintaining gut homeostasis. They promote gut epithelial integrity and regulate the adaptive immune response to commensal bacteria and pathogens. Dysregulation of ILC3s can have serious implications for gut health and may contribute to the development of gut disorders.
CL:0001074:
CD34-positive, CD56-positive, CD117-positive common innate lymphoid precursor (CILP) is a type of stem cell found in the bone marrow and fetal liver of humans. CILPs have been identified as a precursor to all innate lymphoid cells (ILCs) in the human body. The three surface markers present on CILPs help identify them from other stem cells. CD117 indicates the receptor for stem cell factor, which is required for self-renewal of stem cells. CD34 is a marker found on hematopoietic stem cells, which are cells that can differentiate into all types of blood cells. CD56, also known as neural cell adhesion molecule, plays a role in immune cell adhesion and signaling.

CILPs have been shown to differentiate into all subsets of ILCs, including natural killer (NK) cells, lymphoid tissue inducer (LTi) cells, and the three subsets of group 2 ILCs: ILC2s, ILC2-like cells, and nuocytes. NK cells are involved in the body's defense against viral-infected cells and tumor cells, while LTi cells are involved in the development of lymph nodes and other secondary lymphoid organs. Group 2 ILCs play roles in regulating immunity to parasitic infections and in allergic inflammation. Therefore, CILPs play an essential role in both innate immunity and tissue remodeling during embryonic development and adulthood.

CILPs hold significant therapeutic potential as they can differentiate into various subsets of ILCs, each with a unique role in the immune system. A better understanding of the differentiation process of CILPs can help shed light on how ILCs develop and function in various tissues and organs. Further research into CILPs could pave the way for new immunotherapies and treatments for a range of conditions, including autoimmune diseases, infections, and cancer.
CL:0001080:
NKp44-negative group 3 innate lymphoid cells (ILC3s) are innate immune cells that are found in human lymphoid tissues such as the tonsils and lymph nodes. Unlike their NKp44-positive counterparts, these cells lack the expression of a specific natural killer cell receptor and are identified by their high expression of CD117 and RORγt. ILC3s play an important role in the maintenance of barrier integrity in mucosal tissues through the production of cytokines such as IL-22 and IL-17A. 

ILC3s are essential for the defense against extracellular pathogens and are involved in the promotion of tissue repair. These cells secrete IL-22, which acts on epithelial cells to promote the production of antimicrobial peptides, the restoration of barrier function, and the maintenance of homeostasis. Additionally, ILC3s promote tissue repair by secreting IL-17A, which regulates the activity of neutrophils and is crucial for the activation of fibroblasts. Furthermore, ILC3s interact with other immune cells such as dendritic cells and T cells, modulating their activity and promoting a coordinated immune response.

In addition to their role in innate immunity, ILC3s have been implicated in the pathogenesis of various diseases such as inflammatory bowel disease and psoriasis. Dysregulation of ILC3 function has been associated with these conditions, highlighting the importance of these cells in maintaining barrier integrity and immune homeostasis. Understanding the function and regulation of ILC3s has the potential to lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies for a range of human diseases.
CL:0002003:
CD34-positive, GlyA-negative erythroid progenitor cells are a type of precursor cell that are committed to the development of red blood cells, also known as erythrocytes. These cells are characterized by the presence of the CD34 cell surface marker, which is used to identify hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells. GlyA, or glycophorin A, is a protein that is expressed on the surface of mature red blood cells but is absent in these erythroid progenitor cells.

The function of CD34-positive, GlyA-negative erythroid progenitor cells is to differentiate into mature red blood cells. During their development, these cells undergo a series of differentiation steps that result in the production of functional erythrocytes capable of carrying oxygen throughout the body. This process is tightly regulated by a variety of factors, including hormones and growth factors that signal to these cells when to proliferate and differentiate. Once fully mature, erythrocytes are released into the bloodstream, where they have a lifespan of approximately 120 days before being removed by the spleen.

Defects in the production of erythrocytes can lead to a variety of blood disorders, including anemia and sickle cell disease. Understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying the differentiation of CD34-positive, GlyA-negative erythroid progenitor cells is crucial for developing effective treatments for these diseases. Researchers have made significant progress in recent years in uncovering the key regulatory pathways involved in erythropoiesis, which has led to the development of new therapies for these disorders.
CL:0002024:
Kit-positive megakaryocyte progenitor cells are a subtype of hematopoietic stem cells that play a crucial role in the development and maintenance of the blood and immune systems. They are characterized by the expression of the Kit receptor, which is a protein that binds to a specific cytokine called stem cell factor. This interaction triggers a cascade of signaling events that promote the survival, proliferation, and differentiation of the progenitor cells into mature megakaryocytes.

Megakaryocytes are a specialized type of blood cell that are responsible for the production of platelets, which are essential for blood clot formation and wound healing. Kit-positive megakaryocyte progenitor cells give rise to these cells by undergoing a process called megakaryopoiesis, which involves multiple rounds of DNA replication without cell division (endomitosis), leading to the formation of giant polyploid cells that subsequently break up into platelets.

The regulation of Kit-positive megakaryocyte progenitor cells is precisely controlled by a complex network of signaling pathways and transcription factors that allows the cell to respond to various physiological and pathological stimuli. Abnormalities in this process can lead to various hematological disorders, such as thrombocytopenia and myeloproliferative neoplasms. Thus, understanding the biology of Kit-positive megakaryocyte progenitor cells is critical for the development of new therapies for these diseases.
CL:0002005:
CD34-positive, CD38-positive megakaryocyte erythroid progenitor cell, also known as MEP cell, is a type of hematopoietic stem cell that belongs to the erythroid-megakaryocyte lineage. MEP cells are found in the bone marrow and can differentiate into red blood cells, megakaryocytes, and platelets, which are essential for oxygen transport and blood clotting. The expression of CD34 and CD38 on the surface of MEP cells allows researchers to identify and isolate them for further study.

MEP cells play a crucial role in the production of erythrocytes and platelets, which are necessary for proper blood circulation and clotting. The differentiation of MEP cells into erythrocytes is stimulated by erythropoietin, a hormone produced by the kidneys in response to low oxygen levels in the blood. The differentiation of MEP cells into megakaryocytes is stimulated by thrombopoietin, a hormone produced by the liver and kidneys that regulates platelet production.

MEP cells are particularly important in disorders of the blood, such as anemia and thrombocytopenia, where there is a deficiency of red blood cells and platelets, respectively. Understanding the molecular pathways that control MEP cell differentiation and function is critical for developing new therapies for these disorders, as well as for enhancing our understanding of normal hematopoiesis.
CL:0002021:
GlyA-positive erythrocytes, also known as GlyA+ erythrocytes, are mature red blood cells that express the Glycophorin A protein on their cell surface. This cell type is present in the blood and is responsible for carrying oxygen from the lungs to the body's tissues and transporting carbon dioxide from the tissues back to the lungs for exhalation. Glycophorin A is a marker that distinguishes erythrocytes from other cell types and aids in their recognition by the immune system.

GlyA+ erythrocytes are crucial for maintaining homeostasis in the body. Hemoglobin, a protein found in these cells, binds to oxygen in the lungs and releases it in the tissues where it is needed. The cells' unique biconcave shape allows for efficient gas exchange by increasing their surface area and flexibility. Additionally, their lack of a nucleus and other organelles allows for more space to carry hemoglobin, further optimizing their function as oxygen carriers.

Disrupted GlyA expression can result in anemia, a condition characterized by low levels of functioning erythrocytes and a decreased ability to transport oxygen. Conversely, certain pathologies, such as hereditary spherocytosis, are associated with an increase in the number of GlyA+ erythrocytes in circulation. Overall, GlyA+ erythrocytes are a vital component of the circulatory system and play an irreplaceable role in oxygen transport and maintaining overall health.
CL:0001005:
Mature CD8 alpha-positive CD11b-negative dendritic cells (mCD8a+CD11b- DCs) are a specialized subset of dendritic cells (DCs) that play a crucial role in initiating and regulating immune responses. These cells are characterized by their expression of CD8 alpha and lack of CD11b surface markers.  mCD8a+CD11b- DCs are primarily found within lymph nodes and the spleen, and are believed to originate from precursor cells in bone marrow. Once matured, these dendritic cells play a key role in the activation of CD8+ T cells which are critical in the adaptive immune response against virus-infected cells and tumor cells.

mCD8a+CD11b- DCs achieve their function by capturing antigens from infected cells or tissues. These captured antigens are then processed and presented on the surface of these dendritic cells in a way that stimulates the production of T cells. In particular, the presentation of the antigen in combination with molecules such as CD80 or CD86 can activate CD8+ T cells to become cytotoxic and eradicate the antigen-bearing cells.

The unique function of mCD8a+CD11b- DCs in the immune response has drawn considerable interest from researchers. Knowledge of these cells has led to numerous advances in our understanding of certain aspects of adaptive immunity and provides a potential platform for further development of vaccines and other immunotherapies.
CL:0002052:
Fraction D precursor B cell, also known as D pro-B cell, is a specific cell type in the B cell lymphopoiesis process. It is the earliest stage of B cell development in the bone marrow and is characterized by the expression of CD43, CD24, and CD19 markers. These cells, along with the previously described fraction C pro-B cells, differentiate into committed B cell precursors that will eventually lead to mature B cells.

During its development, fraction D precursor B cells generate D-JH gene rearrangements, the first step in the production of a functional B cell receptor. This gene rearrangement is essential for the subsequent differentiation and survival of B cells. The process of D-JH gene rearrangement is mediated by the recombinase enzymes Rag1 and Rag2 that are expressed specifically in precursor B cells.

In summary, fraction D precursor B cell plays a crucial role in the development of B cells. It is the earliest stage of B cell differentiation, and it generates the first step in the production of a functional B cell receptor. This cell type, along with other pro-B cells, gives rise to the diverse and adaptive immune system of vertebrates.
CL:0002017:
Kit-negative, Ly-76 high orthochromatophilic erythroblasts are a type of precursor cells that give rise to red blood cells. They are characterized by their lack of expression of the Kit receptor and high expression of the Ly-76 surface marker. Orthochromatophilic erythroblasts are in the later stages of erythropoiesis, during which the cells undergo enucleation and accumulation of hemoglobin. This maturation process ultimately results in the production of functional red blood cells that can deliver oxygen throughout the body.

The absence of the Kit receptor in Kit-negative, Ly-76 high orthochromatophilic erythroblasts is important because it allows for the final stages of maturation to occur. Kit signaling inhibits enucleation of erythroblasts, the process where the nucleus is expelled from the cell. Therefore, the downregulation of Kit in orthochromatophilic erythroblasts permits this key step to occur, as well as the accumulation of hemoglobin.

Kit-negative, Ly-76 high orthochromatophilic erythroblasts are also important targets for therapeutic intervention in certain conditions such as anemia. By promoting erythroid maturation and increasing the number of functional erythrocytes, these cells represent a potential target for treatments that aim to increase red blood cell production. Additionally, they may serve as a biomarker for blood disorders, such as myelodysplastic syndromes, which are characterized by abnormal erythropoiesis.
CL:0002400:
Fraction B/C precursor B cells are multipotent hematopoietic stem cells that give rise to cells of the B cell lineage. These cells are found in the bone marrow and undergo a series of differentiation steps to become mature B cells. Fraction B/C precursor B cells are characterized by the expression of various cell surface markers such as CD19, CD10, and CD34.

During B cell development, fraction B/C precursor B cells go through several stages of development, including the pro-B cell, pre-B cell, and immature B cell stages. Each stage is characterized by the expression of different cell surface markers and the rearrangement of immunoglobulin genes. Through the process of V(D)J recombination, B cells are able to generate a diverse repertoire of immunoglobulin receptors that can recognize a wide range of antigens.

The function of fraction B/C precursor B cells is to generate a pool of B cells that are capable of recognizing and responding to a wide range of antigens. As these cells differentiate, they acquire the ability to produce antibodies and mount an immune response against invading pathogens. In addition to their role in adaptive immunity, fraction B/C precursor B cells have also been implicated in the pathogenesis of certain types of leukemia and lymphoma.
CL:0002015:
Kit-negative, Ly-76 high polychromatophilic erythroblasts are a type of erythroid progenitor cell found in the bone marrow. As indicated by their name, they do not express the receptor tyrosine kinase Kit and instead express high levels of the lymphocyte antigen 76 (Ly-76). These cells are at the late stages of erythropoiesis, characterized by the production of hemoglobin and the loss of their nucleus.

The main role of Kit-negative, Ly-76 high polychromatophilic erythroblasts is to produce red blood cells, also known as erythrocytes. During erythropoiesis, these cells undergo several rounds of cell division, and as they mature, they synthesize more hemoglobin and reduce their overall size. Hemoglobin is a crucial protein in red blood cells that binds to oxygen and transports it around the body. Once erythroblasts have lost their nucleus, they are released into the bloodstream as reticulocytes, which are then further processed into mature erythrocytes that can perform their oxygen-carrying function.

In summary, Kit-negative, Ly-76 high polychromatophilic erythroblasts play a vital role in the production of red blood cells. As they progress through the stages of erythropoiesis, they produce more hemoglobin and lose their nucleus, ultimately becoming mature erythrocytes. Understanding the function and characteristics of these cells is crucial for understanding the biology of blood development and identifying potential targets for treating anemia, a disease that results from a deficiency of red blood cells.
CL:0002014:
A Kit-negative, Ly-76 high basophilic erythroblast, also known as a type 2 basophilic erythroblast, is a distinct population of erythroblasts in the bone marrow during erythropoiesis. These immature cells are characterized by their high expression of Ly-76, a surface marker, and the absence of expression of Kit, another surface marker. They are called basophilic due to their affinity for basic dyes, which stain the cell's cytoplasm blue-purple.

Type 2 basophilic erythroblasts play a crucial role in the production of red blood cells, or erythrocytes. These basophilic erythroblasts differentiate into polychromatic erythroblasts, which synthesize and accumulate large amounts of hemoglobin to form the red pigment in erythrocytes.  They can be identified in bone marrow smears by their large size, round and centrally located nuclei, finely granular cytoplasm, and their uniform basophilia. In addition to being involved in erythrocyte production, these cells have also been shown to produce cytokines and other signaling molecules important for immune cell development and function.

Overall, type 2 basophilic erythroblasts play an essential role in erythropoiesis and contribute to the formation of mature erythrocytes, which are vital for oxygen transport in the body. The identification and characterization of these cells in bone marrow smears can be informative for diagnosing erythropoietic disorders and understanding the molecular mechanisms behind erythrocyte production.
CL:0002019:
Ly-76 high reticulocytes are an immature type of red blood cell characterized by high levels of the lymphocyte antigen-76 (Ly-76), a marker on the cell surface. These cells represent a transitional stage between the immature erythroblast and the mature erythrocyte. Reticulocytes are released from the bone marrow into the bloodstream where they undergo further maturation and differentiation into red blood cells, the main oxygen-carrying cells in the body.

The function of Ly-76 high reticulocytes is to sustain the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood. As they mature into erythrocytes, reticulocytes synthesize and accumulate hemoglobin, the protein responsible for binding and transporting oxygen. This process ensures a steady supply of oxygen to all tissues and organs in the body. In conditions of increased demand for red blood cells, such as anemia, the number of reticulocytes in the blood may rise to compensate for the deficiency.

Ly-76 high reticulocytes are also involved in the cellular response to stress and injury. Under conditions of hypoxia, the low oxygen tension in the tissues triggers the release of erythropoietin, a hormone that stimulates erythropoiesis, or the production of red blood cells. Reticulocytes respond to erythropoietin by proliferating and differentiating into erythrocytes at an accelerated rate, which increases the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood and promotes tissue oxygenation. Thus, Ly-76 high reticulocytes play a crucial role in maintaining homeostasis in the body by ensuring adequate oxygenation of the tissues.
CL:0002020:
GlyA-positive reticulocytes are immature red blood cells that are characterized by their expression of the glycophorin A (GlyA) protein on their cell surface. These cells are produced in the bone marrow and are released into the bloodstream where they mature into mature red blood cells. Reticulocytes can be identified by a special staining technique which differentiates them from mature red blood cells.

The function of GlyA-positive reticulocytes is crucial to maintaining oxygen transport to the body's tissues. They are responsible for producing hemoglobin, a protein that binds and transports oxygen. As reticulocytes mature into red blood cells, they produce more hemoglobin and lose their nucleus, which increases their efficiency in oxygen transport. Once they have matured, red blood cells circulate in the bloodstream for approximately 120 days before being cleared by the spleen.

GlyA-positive reticulocytes play an important role in diagnosing and monitoring a range of blood disorders. Patients with anemia, which is characterized by a decrease in the number of red blood cells, often have an increase in the number of reticulocytes as their body tries to compensate for the lack of oxygen-carrying capacity in their blood. Doctors can measure the number of reticulocytes in a patient's blood to help diagnose and monitor anemia. In addition, reticulocyte counts can be used to monitor the effectiveness of treatments such as blood transfusions or medications designed to boost red blood cell production.
CL:0002049:
Fraction C precursor B cells are a type of early B cell found in the bone marrow of mammals, including humans. These cells are defined by their expression of certain surface proteins, including CD23, CD93, and CD43. Fraction C precursor B cells play a critical role in the development of the adaptive immune system by giving rise to mature B cells, which produce antibodies in response to foreign pathogens.

During development, fraction C precursor B cells undergo a series of complex differentiation steps that ultimately give rise to mature B cells. This process is tightly regulated by a number of different signaling pathways and transcription factors. Defects in this process can lead to a variety of diseases including immunodeficiency disorders, autoimmune disorders, and cancer.

Fraction C precursor B cells also play an important role in the establishment of immune tolerance, which is critical for preventing autoimmune diseases. This is because these cells are capable of generating central tolerance, a process by which developing B cells are exposed to self-antigens and either deleted or rendered inactive if they recognize these antigens. This process ensures that B cells do not produce antibodies against self-antigens, which can lead to autoimmunity.
CL:0002026:
CD34-negative, CD41-positive, CD42-positive megakaryocyte cells are a type of bone marrow-derived cell that are responsible for the production of platelets. These cells are characterized by the expression of CD41 and CD42 receptors on their surface, while lacking CD34 expression. Megakaryocytes undergo a unique differentiation process, whereby they undergo endomitosis, meaning that they replicate their DNA without undergoing cell division, resulting in the formation of a large polyploid cell.

The primary function of megakaryocytes is the production of platelets, which are important in blood clotting. Megakaryocytes release platelets into the bloodstream by extending proplatelet projections into the blood vessels of the bone marrow. Following proplatelet elongation, platelets are released into the circulation, where they assist in the formation of blood clots. Additionally, these cells are known to play a role in the proliferation and differentiation of other hematopoietic cells, such as erythrocytes, leukocytes, and monocytes.

Megakaryocytes are regulated by a number of cytokines and growth factors, including thrombopoietin, which is essential for their proliferation and differentiation. Dysregulation of megakaryocyte development and function can lead to a number of hematological disorders, including thrombocytopenia and myeloproliferative disorders. Despite their relatively small size and brief lifespan in the circulation, platelets play a critical role in hemostasis, and megakaryocyte dysfunction can have serious clinical consequences.
CL:0002044:
The Kit-positive, integrin beta7-high basophil mast progenitor cell (Ki-BMP) is a rare and unique type of hematopoietic progenitor cell that is responsible for generating both basophils and mast cells. These cells express high levels of integrin beta7, a cell adhesion molecule important for homing to lymphoid tissues, and also have the ability to respond to stem cell factor (SCF) through the expression of the transmembrane receptor protein tyrosine kinase (c-Kit).

The Ki-BMP cell plays a crucial role in the immune system as both basophils and mast cells are key players in the allergic response. Basophils are granulocytes that release histamine and other mediators upon activation, leading to vasodilation, smooth muscle contraction, and increased vascular permeability. Mast cells also release histamine and other mediators, and are involved in wound healing and defense against pathogens. Dysregulation of basophil and mast cell function has been implicated in several allergic and inflammatory disorders including asthma, eczema, and gastrointestinal disorders.

The identification of the Ki-BMP cell and its role in basophil and mast cell differentiation and function provides a deeper understanding of the immune system and opens new avenues for the development of therapeutic interventions for allergic and inflammatory diseases.
CL:0002029:
Fc-epsilon RIalpha-low mast cell progenitor is a type of progenitor cell that differentiates into mast cells. These cells play a crucial role in the immune system's response to parasitic infections, allergic reactions, and other inflammatory conditions. These cells are identified by the low expression of the Fc-epsilon RIalpha receptor, which is involved in the activation of mast cells.

Mast cells are critical cells of the immune system that release histamines and other mediators of inflammation in response to antigen stimulation. They are distributed throughout the body, including the skin, respiratory tract, and gastrointestinal tract, and play a crucial role in immune surveillance and response. The differentiation of Fc-epsilon RIalpha-low mast cell progenitor cells into mature mast cells is regulated by several factors, including cytokines, growth factors, and other environmental cues.

Recent studies have shown that Fc-epsilon RIalpha-low mast cell progenitor cells are the precursors of connective tissue-type mast cells and play a critical role in inflammation and tissue remodeling. These cells are found in the circulation and in certain tissue reservoirs and can differentiate into mature mast cells in response to inflammatory stimuli. The ability of these cells to differentiate and respond quickly to antigenic stimulation makes them an attractive target for therapeutic interventions aimed at controlling inflammation and allergic reactions.
CL:0002023:
CD34-positive, CD41-positive, CD42-positive megakaryocyte progenitor cell is a type of progenitor cell that is found in the bone marrow and spleen. These cells are characterized by the expression of three cell surface markers: CD34, CD41, and CD42. CD34 is a marker for early hematopoietic progenitor cells, while CD41 and CD42 are markers expressed by megakaryocyte lineage cells. These cells are essential for the development of megakaryocytes, which are the precursors of platelets.

The main function of CD34-positive, CD41-positive, CD42-positive megakaryocyte progenitor cell is to differentiate into megakaryocytes, which are large, polyploid cells that produce platelets. Platelets are essential for the normal clotting of blood, and their production depends on the proper function of megakaryocytes. During megakaryocyte development, CD34-positive, CD41-positive, CD42-positive megakaryocyte progenitor cells undergo several rounds of cell division, leading to the production of megakaryocyte progenitor cells that eventually differentiate into mature megakaryocytes.

In summary, CD34-positive, CD41-positive, CD42-positive megakaryocyte progenitor cells are a type of progenitor cell that gives rise to megakaryocytes, which are the precursors of platelets. These cells are essential for the normal clotting of blood and play a critical role in maintaining homeostasis.
CL:0002011:
Kit-positive macrophage dendritic cell progenitor (MDP) is a type of hematopoietic progenitor cell that gives rise to both macrophages and dendritic cells. These cells are identified by the expression of the c-kit (Kit) receptor on their cell surface, which is a marker for their early differentiation. MDP cells are located in the bone marrow and are derived from a common myeloid progenitor cell. This cell type plays a crucial role in the immune system by producing immune cells that recognize and respond to pathogenic invaders, such as viruses, bacteria, and other foreign substances.

MDP cells produce two types of immune cells: macrophages and dendritic cells. Macrophages are specialized immune cells that engulf and digest foreign substances such as bacteria, viruses, and other pathogens. They also play a role in the removal of dead cells and debris that accumulate in tissues. Dendritic cells are antigen-presenting cells that help the immune system to recognize and respond to foreign substances. They capture and process antigens, and then display them on their cell surface, which allows them to activate other immune cells, such as T cells and B cells.

In summary, Kit-positive macrophage dendritic cell progenitor cells are a crucial component of the immune system. They produce immune cells that recognize, respond to, and ultimately eliminate foreign substances in the body. Their differentiation into macrophages and dendritic cells plays a vital role in maintaining the health of tissues and organs and protecting the body from disease.
CL:0002027:
CD9-positive, CD41-positive megakaryocyte cells are large bone marrow-derived cells that play a crucial role in the process of platelet formation, also known as thrombopoiesis. These cells differentiate and mature into platelets, which are responsible for the essential function of blood clotting. Megakaryocytes are characterized by their large size, polyploid nature, and unique morphological features, such as cytoplasmic extensions called proplatelets, which give rise to platelet formation.

CD9 and CD41 are surface markers that specifically define the megakaryocyte lineage. CD9 is a tetraspanin molecule that plays a key role in various cellular functions including cell adhesion and migration. CD41, or Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa, is a heterodimeric transmembrane receptor expressed on the surface of megakaryocytes and is crucial for platelet aggregation. Consequently, CD9-positive, CD41-positive megakaryocytes play a central role in the hemostatic response following injury and are essential for maintaining the structural integrity of the vasculature.

Overall, these specialized cells play a crucial role in maintaining normal hemostasis, and deficiencies in megakaryocyte function can result in a variety of hematological disorders, including thrombocytopenia and platelet dysfunction. Understanding the molecular mechanisms that regulate the differentiation and function of CD9-positive, CD41-positive megakaryocytes is crucial for developing new treatments for conditions associated with impaired platelet function and thrombosis.
CL:0002012:
Kit-low proerythroblast is a specific type of immature red blood cell that emerges from the differentiation of hematopoietic stem cells within the bone marrow. These cells contain a nucleus and are characterized by their low expression of the Kit receptor (CD117). Kit-low proerythroblasts are large cells with a basophilic cytoplasm and have a high nucleo-cytoplasmic ratio, which is vital for the synthesis of hemoglobin. The synthesis of hemoglobin is the primary function of Kit-low proerythroblasts, and this process is fundamental to their eventual maturation into mature red blood cells.

The development of Kit-low proerythroblasts into mature red blood cells is a complex process that ultimately involves the loss of their nucleus. This process also involves the creation of a sufficient concentration of hemoglobin within the cell to ensure the efficient transportation of oxygen to body tissues and organs. The synthesis of hemoglobin is accomplished by the coordinated expression of genes that support the synthesis of specific polypeptide chains. Nevertheless, Kit-low proerythroblasts are also vulnerable to outside factors such as toxins and infection, which can disrupt the maturation and growth of these vital cells, leading to diseases such as anemia.

In summary, Kit-low proerythroblasts are large, immature red blood cells generated from hematopoietic stem cells and characterized by their low expression of the Kit receptor. The function of Kit-low proerythroblasts is to synthesize hemoglobin, eventually maturing into fully functional, mature red blood cells. The development of Kit-low proerythroblasts is a complex process that requires the activation and coordinated expression of several genes. Ultimately, any disruption in this complex process can lead to a failure in red blood cell production and severe health consequences.
CL:0002030:
Fc-epsilon RIalpha-high basophil progenitor cells are a type of hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) that give rise to basophils - a type of granulocyte involved in the immune response to parasitic and allergic disorders. These progenitor cells are characterized by high levels of the Fc-epsilon RI alpha chain, which is a receptor for immunoglobulin E (IgE). IgE is responsible for activating basophils and other immune cells in an allergic response, making these cells an important component of the innate immune response.

Basophil progenitor cells are found in the bone marrow and undergo multiple stages of differentiation, eventually leading to the development of mature basophils. Along with mast cells, basophils express high levels of IgE receptors and release histamines and other cytokines when activated by IgE. These cells play important roles in fighting parasites and allergies, but overactivation can cause inflammatory responses that result in asthma, allergic rhinitis and other allergic disorders.

In summary, Fc-epsilon RIalpha-high basophil progenitor cells give rise to basophils - a type of granulocyte involved in the inflammatory response to parasitic and allergic disorders. These cells are characterized by high levels of the Fc-epsilon RI alpha chain, a receptor for immunoglobulin E (IgE), which is responsible for activating basophils and other immune cells in an allergic response. Basophils play an important role in the immune system, but overactivation can lead to allergic disorders that impact a large part of the global population.
CL:0002033:
Short-term hematopoietic stem cells (ST-HSCs) are multipotent progenitor cells found in the bone marrow that give rise to all the different types of blood cells throughout the adult lifespan. These cells are characterized by their ability to regenerate themselves and to differentiate into all the blood lineages, including erythrocytes, platelets, and all the types of white blood cells. ST-HSCs are thought to be a transitional stage between the rare long-term repopulating hematopoietic stem cells (LT-HSC) and more committed multipotent progenitor (MPP) cells.

ST-HSCs play a critical role in maintaining the homeostasis of the hematopoietic system by constantly producing new cells to replace old ones. Depending on the demand, these cells can differentiate into any of the different types of blood cells. Under steady-state conditions, the majority of ST-HSCs transit to the MPP state and go on to produce lineage-committed cells. In response to stress or injury, however, ST-HSCs can rapidly self-renew to maintain the stem cell pool and also produce different blood cell types to address the increased demand.

Because of their role in maintaining blood cell homeostasis, ST-HSCs have important therapeutic potential in a number of blood-related diseases such as leukemia, anemia, and immunodeficiency disorders. Furthermore, understanding the molecular mechanisms that regulate their differentiation and self-renewal could lead to the development of novel therapies that target these cells to promote or suppress their function, depending on the desired outcome.
CL:0002013:
A GlyA-positive basophilic erythroblast is an immature red blood cell that has not yet lost its nucleus. These cells are identified by their basophilic staining properties, which means they will stain blue-purple with basic dyes. They also express the GlyA antigen, which is a glycophorin A protein found on the surface of red blood cells. 

The main function of the GlyA-positive basophilic erythroblast is to differentiate into a fully mature red blood cell. As they mature, they will lose their nucleus and undergo changes in their membrane and cytoplasmic constituents. Once they are fully mature, they are released into the circulation to transport oxygen from the lungs to the tissues. 

The process of erythropoiesis, or the formation of red blood cells, is tightly regulated by a hormone called erythropoietin. The production of erythropoietin is stimulated by low oxygen levels in the body, which signals the bone marrow to increase the production of red blood cells. In healthy individuals, the balance between red blood cell production and destruction is carefully maintained to ensure that there are enough red blood cells to distribute oxygen throughout the body.
CL:0002070:
Type I vestibular sensory cells are specialized cells found in the inner ear that are responsible for detecting mechanical movements and changes in gravity. These sensory cells are located in the vestibular system, which is responsible for maintaining balance and spatial orientation. Type I vestibular sensory cells are also known as hair cells due to the presence of tiny hair-like structures on their surface that allow them to detect movement. 

When mechanical movement or changes in gravity occur, the hair-like structures on the surface of the type I vestibular sensory cells bend, which leads to the opening of ion channels and the release of neurotransmitters. These signals are then processed by the central nervous system to help maintain balance and spatial orientation. 

Damage or degeneration of type I vestibular sensory cells can result in vestibular disorders, such as Meniere's disease or positional vertigo. Researchers have been studying ways to regenerate or repair these cells to potentially treat these disorders. Overall, type I vestibular sensory cells play a crucial role in the maintenance of balance and spatial orientation, and any dysfunction can have significant consequences for an individual's quality of life.
CL:0002054:
Fraction E immature B cells, also called pro-B cells, are a type of developing white blood cell that reside in the bone marrow. These cells are crucial for the development of the immune system, as they give rise to mature B cells that produce antibodies to target invading pathogens. 

Fraction E immature B cells are characterized by their expression of rearranged immunoglobulin heavy chain genes. This expression is a hallmark of the B cell lineage and is necessary for the further development of these cells. As these cells mature, they undergo VDJ recombination, which is the process of rearranging the genes that code for the B cell receptor. 

Through a series of differentiation steps, fraction E immature B cells eventually differentiate into mature B cells, which travel to lymphoid tissues throughout the body and produce antibodies when they encounter foreign substances. Thus, fraction E immature B cells play a critical role in the development of the immune system and ultimately in protecting the body from infections. Studying the development and differentiation of these cells can provide valuable insights into the mechanisms underlying immune system function and immunological disorders.
CL:0002006:
The Kit-positive, CD34-negative megakaryocyte erythroid progenitor cell is a hematopoietic stem cell that can differentiate into both megakaryocytes and erythrocytes. These cells are crucial in maintaining the proper oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood and controlling the clotting response. Kit, also known as CD117, is a receptor tyrosine kinase protein that is expressed on the surface of these progenitor cells. This receptor is important for survival, proliferation, and differentiation of a variety of cell types, including these megakaryocyte erythroid progenitor cells.

Megakaryocytes are the precursors to platelets, which are essential in blood clotting and wound healing. Erythrocytes, also known as red blood cells, are responsible for carrying oxygen to tissues throughout the body. The differentiation of these cells from the megakaryocyte erythroid progenitor cell is regulated by a complex interplay of transcription factors and molecular signaling pathways. Dysregulation of these pathways can lead to blood disorders such as thrombocytopenia and anemia.

In addition to their importance in maintaining healthy blood function, these cells also have potential clinical applications. Transplantation of hematopoietic stem cells, including megakaryocyte erythroid progenitor cells, can be used to treat a variety of blood disorders and diseases, including leukemia and sickle cell anemia. Understanding the molecular mechanisms that regulate the differentiation of megakaryocytes and erythrocytes from these progenitor cells may lead to the development of new therapies for these conditions.
CL:0002036:
Slamf1-positive multipotent progenitor cells, also known as MPP-Slamf1, are a subset of hematopoietic stem cells found in bone marrow. These cells have the potential to differentiate into all blood cell types, including erythrocytes, platelets, granulocytes, monocytes, and lymphocytes. Slamf1, or signaling lymphocyte activation molecule family member 1, is a protein that is expressed on the surface of MPP-Slamf1 cells and has been identified as a marker for this specific cell population.

MPP-Slamf1 cells are crucial for maintaining proper blood cell homeostasis. These cells are able to self-renew, meaning they can divide and produce more of themselves. Additionally, they can differentiate into both myeloid and lymphoid lineages, which is essential for the replenishment of blood cells that are constantly being produced and destroyed in the body. MPP-Slamf1 cells have been shown to be particularly important in the early stages of blood cell development, as they give rise to a variety of downstream progenitors that eventually produce all blood cell types.

Research on MPP-Slamf1 cells is ongoing, as scientists continue to investigate the precise molecular mechanisms involved in their differentiation and self-renewal. Understanding these mechanisms has important implications for treating diseases that involve dysfunctional blood cells, such as leukemia and anemia. Additionally, further study of MPP-Slamf1 cells may provide insight into how blood cell development is regulated in the body and could lead to the development of new therapies to support the production of healthy blood cells.
CL:0002046:
Early pro-B cells are a type of lymphoid cell that develop into B cells within the bone marrow. In the process of differentiation, early pro-B cells undergo rearrangement of immunoglobulin heavy chain genes developed in the earliest stage of B cell development. The B lineage commitment is primarily determined in these early stages and therefore, these cells play a critical role in the proper development of the immune system and are essential for the production of an effective adaptive immune response against pathogens.

Early pro-B cells differentiate from hematopoietic stem cells and progress through several developmental stages. Early pro-B cells express the markers CD19, CD45R/B220, and IgM, and lack the expression of CD43. These cells also express the transcription factors Pu.1, E2A, and the proto-oncogene Ikaros, which play important roles in B cell differentiation, proliferation, and survival.

In the bone marrow, early pro-B cells are supported by the surrounding microenvironment and receive signals from various cytokines that promote their survival, differentiation, and maturation. Any defects or abnormalities in early pro-B cell development can disrupt the balance of the immune system, leading to immunodeficiencies and uncontrolled B cell proliferation. Understanding the function of early pro-B cells is crucial for developing therapies for a wide range of diseases, including leukemia, lymphoma, and autoimmune disorders.
CL:0002034:
Long-term hematopoietic stem cells (LT-HSCs) are a type of multipotent stem cell found in the bone marrow of adult mammals. These cells, which give rise to all types of blood cells, have the ability to self-renew and differentiate into a variety of progenitor cells, which in turn can differentiate into mature blood cells. LT-HSCs play an important role in maintaining the homeostasis of the hematopoietic system throughout the lifetime of an individual.

LT-HSCs are characterized by the expression of specific markers, including CD34 and CD38. These cells also express a number of transcription factors, such as GATA2 and Runx1, that are involved in maintaining their stemness and regulating their differentiation into specific blood cell lineages. LT-HSCs exist in a state of quiescence, but can be activated to proliferate and differentiate in response to signals from the microenvironment of the bone marrow.

Due to their ability to self-renew and differentiate into all types of blood cells, LT-HSCs have been the focus of much research in the field of regenerative medicine. Studies have shown that these cells have the potential to be used in the treatment of a wide range of blood disorders, including leukemia and anemia. However, much more research is needed to fully understand the biology of LT-HSCs and their potential therapeutic applications.
CL:0002041:
Immature NK T cell stage III is a type of natural killer T cell that plays a critical role in the immune system. These cells are characterized by the expression of both NK cell receptors and a T cell receptor (TCR), which enables them to bridge the innate and adaptive immune systems. Immature NK T cell stage III cells are part of a larger class of cells called invariant NKT cells, due to the invariant nature of their TCR.

The function of immature NK T cell stage III cells is to recognize and respond rapidly to a variety of pathogens, including bacteria, viruses, and fungi. These cells are particularly effective at targeting cancerous cells, making them an attractive target for cancer immunotherapy. Unlike conventional T cells, which require processing of antigens by antigen-presenting cells, immature NK T cell stage III cells recognize antigens directly, allowing for a faster immune response.

In addition to their role in fighting infection and disease, immature NK T cell stage III cells also play a role in immune regulation. These cells can help modulate both the innate and adaptive immune responses, preventing excessive inflammation and autoimmunity. As such, they are being studied as a potential therapeutic target for a variety of conditions, including autoimmune disorders and transplant rejection.
CL:0002025:
CD34-positive, CD41-positive, CD42-negative megakaryocyte progenitor cells are stem cells that have the capacity to develop into megakaryocytes, which are responsible for producing platelets. These cells express CD34, a surface marker found on hematopoietic stem cells, as well as CD41, which is present on cells of the platelet lineage. However, they do not express CD42, a glycoprotein that is essential for platelet formation. 

Megakaryocyte progenitors are found in the bone marrow and are essential for platelet production, which plays a crucial role in hemostasis. Platelets are responsible for blood clotting, which prevents excessive bleeding after injury. These progenitor cells differentiate into megakaryocytes, which undergo a series of complex cytoplasmic changes to form platelets, a process called thrombopoiesis. Megakaryocytes undergo polyploidization, meaning they become multi-nucleated as a result of repeated rounds of DNA replication without cell division, in order to produce enough cytoplasm to support platelet formation.

CD34-positive, CD41-positive, CD42-negative megakaryocyte progenitor cells are critical to the formation of platelets and thus to hemostasis. They are capable of self-renewal, allowing them to continuously produce new megakaryocytes and maintain platelet production throughout a person's life. Understanding the properties and biology of these cells is vital for developing strategies to manipulate and enhance platelet production, which can be useful in treating certain bleeding disorders or in improving blood transfusion practices.
CL:0002398:
Gr1-positive, CD43-positive monocytes are a type of white blood cell that plays a crucial role in the body's immune response to infections. These cells are part of the mononuclear phagocyte system that helps to identify, engulf, and destroy foreign pathogens. Gr1 is a surface marker that is commonly used to identify these monocytes, while CD43 is a glycoprotein that is expressed on the surface of these cells.

Gr1-positive, CD43-positive monocytes originate from the bone marrow and are found circulating in the bloodstream. Once they enter tissues, they differentiate into macrophages, which are specialized cells that engulf and digest foreign particles, dead cells, and debris. Macrophages also secrete cytokines and chemokines that attract other immune cells to the site of infection, which enhances the immune response.

Overall, Gr1-positive, CD43-positive monocytes are essential components of the immune system that play a crucial role in the body's defense against infections. Their ability to identify and engulf foreign pathogens, as well as recruit other immune cells to the site of infection, makes them important players in the immune response. Ultimately, a better understanding of the function and behavior of these cells can lead to the development of new strategies to combat infections and improve human health.
CL:0002004:
A CD34-negative, GlyA-negative proerythroblast is a type of early erythroid progenitor cell that develops into the erythroblast stage. These cells do not express the glycoprotein-A (GlyA) marker, which is associated with fully differentiated erythrocytes. Furthermore, they lack the CD34 marker, which is commonly expressed on hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells.

The proerythroblast is a critical stage in erythropoiesis, the process by which erythrocytes (red blood cells) are produced. At this stage, the cell undergoes several rounds of cell division while maintaining a high rate of protein synthesis. This increases the size of the cell and develops its characteristic elongated nucleus, known as the basophilic erythroblast stage.

The differentiation of the proerythroblast into erythroblasts is triggered by erythropoietin, a hormone produced by the kidneys in response to hypoxia. Erythroblasts develop into reticulocytes, which are mostly released into the bloodstream, where they further mature into erythrocytes. The CD34-negative, GlyA-negative proerythroblast is a key intermediary stage in the development of mature erythrocytes and is crucial for healthy blood formation.
CL:0002050:
The fraction C' precursor B cell is a type of cell that is found in the hematopoietic system and is specifically involved in the process of B cell development. This cell type is known to reside in the bone marrow and is responsible for differentiating into mature B cells that are able to produce antibodies. The fraction C' precursor B cell is a vital precursor in the development of B cells and plays a major role in the overall immune system function.

One of the most important functions of the fraction C' precursor B cell is to undergo multiple stages of differentiation to become a mature B cell that is able to function within the immune system. The B cells produced by the fraction C' precursor B cell are crucial in recognizing and responding to foreign antigens that enter the body. These mature B cells are responsible for producing a specific type of antibody that can target and neutralize harmful substances that threaten the body. 

Overall, the fraction C' precursor B cell is an essential cell type that is involved in the development of the immune system. The ability to produce mature B cells that are capable of producing specific antibodies is a crucial function that is necessary for protecting the body from foreign invaders. The fraction C' precursor B cell highlights the complex nature of the hematopoietic system and serves as an important example of the intricate processes that occur within the body to maintain overall health.
CL:0002060:
Melanophages are a specialized subset of macrophages that have been recognized for their ability to engulf and digest melanin-containing cells, such as melanocytes and keratinocytes. They are commonly found in the skin, especially in the dermis and subcutaneous tissues, where they play a vital role in regulating pigmentation. Melanophages are derived from monocytes, which differentiate into macrophages upon entering tissues.

Studies have shown that melanophages actively participate in the process of melanosome transfer from melanocytes to keratinocytes. This process is crucial for the maintenance of skin pigmentation and protection against UV damage, as melanin absorbs UV radiation and prevents its harmful effects on skin cells. Melanophages are also involved in the clearance of damaged and dead melanocytes, which helps to regulate the turnover of pigment-producing cells in the skin.

In addition to their role in pigmentation, melanophages also play a crucial role in the immune response to skin infections and inflammation. They are capable of phagocytosing and destroying invading microorganisms, and can also secrete cytokines and chemokines that recruit other immune cells to the site of infection or injury. Studies have suggested that melanophages may be involved in the pathogenesis of several skin disorders, such as vitiligo and melanoma, and may also serve as a potential target for new therapies.
CL:0002037:
CD2-positive, CD5-positive, CD44-positive alpha-beta intraepithelial T cells are a subset of T cells located within the epithelial layer of various organs, including the skin and gut. These T cells are positive for several surface markers, including CD2, CD5, and CD44. They play an important role in the immune defense against pathogens and tumors, as well as in tissue homeostasis and regeneration.

One of the primary functions of CD2-positive, CD5-positive, CD44-positive alpha-beta intraepithelial T cells is to provide rapid local immune responses against invading pathogens. These T cells are strategically located at mucosal surfaces where they can quickly detect and respond to microbial threats. They are also involved in immune surveillance, monitoring the epithelial layer for signs of cellular damage or abnormal growth.

In addition to their immune functions, CD2-positive, CD5-positive, CD44-positive alpha-beta intraepithelial T cells also contribute to tissue homeostasis and regeneration. They secrete cytokines that promote epithelial cell survival and proliferation, helping to maintain a healthy epithelial barrier. Moreover, these T cells are capable of differentiating into several different cell types, including Th1 and Th17 cells, which have been implicated in the repair of injured tissues.

Overall, CD2-positive, CD5-positive, CD44-positive alpha-beta intraepithelial T cells are a versatile and important subset of T cells with diverse functions. Their location within the mucosal epithelial layer and their ability to rapidly respond to pathogens and tissue damage make them a crucial component of the immune system.
CL:0002075:
Brush cells are a specific type of columnar epithelial cell that are commonly found in the respiratory and digestive tracts. They have a distinct appearance, characterized by a tuft of microvilli extending from their apical surface. Although their exact function is not fully understood, they are believed to play a crucial role in the detection and clearance of harmful substances in the airway.

In the respiratory tract, brush cells are primarily located in the trachebronchial tree and have been shown to express many of the same chemosensory receptors as taste cells on the tongue. They are capable of detecting a wide range of inhaled substances, including allergens, toxins, and pathogens, and can initiate a rapid local immune response to protect the lungs from infection or injury. Brush cells have also been found to play a role in airway inflammation, with studies showing that they can trigger the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines in response to certain stimuli.

Overall, brush cells are a fascinating and important cell type that have many essential functions in the respiratory tract. While much is still unknown about their exact mechanisms and pathways, ongoing research is shedding new light on how these cells contribute to lung health and disease.
CL:0002016:
CD71-low, GlyA-positive polychromatic erythroblasts are immature red blood cells that are found in bone marrow during erythropoiesis, the process by which red blood cells are formed. These cells are characterized by the expression of low levels of CD71, a transferrin receptor, and positivity for glycophorin A (GlyA), a well-established erythroid-specific marker. Additionally, the polychromatic feature of these cells describes their ability to stain with both basic and acidic dyes due to their active biosynthetic activity.

These polychromatic erythroblasts are the stage of maturation following the basophilic erythroblast and preceding the orthochromatic erythroblast. During this stage, red blood cells undergo significant changes in their morphology and protein expression. The cell's nucleus becomes smaller and more pyknotic, and hemoglobin production is increased, leading to a decrease in cytoplasmic volume. The increased expression of GlyA indicates the increased production of membrane proteins to form the characteristic biconcave shape of mature red blood cells.

The function of polychromatic erythroblasts is critical to the production of red blood cells. They are responsible for the synthesis of hemoglobin, the protein responsible for carrying oxygen throughout the body. Without the proper production and maturation of these cells, an individual can develop anemia, a condition in which oxygen-carrying capacity is decreased. Therefore, a thorough understanding of the process of erythropoiesis and the role of each stage, including CD71-low, GlyA-positive polychromatic erythroblasts, is crucial to the treatment and prevention of anemia.
CL:0002066:
Feyrter cells, also known as perifollicular cells, are specialized cells located at the base of hair follicles and the surrounding dermal papilla. These cells are named after Austrian anatomist Leopold Ritter von Feyrter who discovered them in 1912. Feyrter cells are characterized by their elongated shape and the ability to produce pigment and store fat.

The main function of Feyrter cells is to provide support to the hair follicle and regulate hair growth. These cells play a crucial role in the hair growth cycle by controlling the differentiation of hair follicle cells and the amount of melanin pigment produced. They are also responsible for secreting various growth factors that promote hair growth and prevent hair loss.

Additionally, Feyrter cells are involved in the regulation of sebaceous gland activity, which secrete sebum to lubricate the skin and hair. These cells produce enzymes that break down the lipids in sebum and regulate its secretion, thereby preventing blockage of hair follicles and the development of acne. Overall, Feyrter cells play an important role in maintaining healthy hair and skin.
CL:0002080:
Pancreatic centro-acinar cells are a type of specialized epithelial cell found in the exocrine pancreas. These cells are located in the center of the pancreatic acini and are responsible for the secretion of bicarbonate-rich fluid into the pancreatic ducts. This fluid is necessary for the neutralization of acidic chyme that enters the small intestine from the stomach and for the activation of pancreatic enzymes, which are essential for the digestion of proteins, carbohydrates, and fats.

In addition to their ductal secretion function, pancreatic centro-acinar cells have been found to possess stem cell-like characteristics. These cells express markers associated with embryonic pancreatic progenitor cells and have the ability to differentiate into several different cell lineages, including acinar, ductal, and endocrine cells. This plasticity may play a role in the regeneration of the exocrine pancreas following injury or disease.

Pancreatic centro-acinar cells are vital for the proper functioning of the exocrine pancreas. Their specialized secretory function and stem cell-like characteristics make them a fascinating cell type with potential implications for the treatment of pancreatic diseases.
CL:0002040:
Immature NK T cells, also known as NKT2 cells, are a subset of natural killer T cells that play a crucial role in both the innate and adaptive immune response. These cells are characterized by the expression of both NK cell receptors and T cell receptors, allowing them to recognize and quickly respond to a wide range of pathogens. During early development, these cells go through three different stages of maturation known as stages I, II, and III. The immature NK T cell stage II is characterized by the up-regulation of specific genes involved in both NK and T cell receptor signaling pathways, which allows these cells to differentiate into either type I NKT cells or type II NKT cells.

Functionally, immature NK T cells have been shown to be involved in a variety of biological processes, including the regulation of immune surveillance, the maintenance of immune tolerance, and the promotion of anti-tumor immunity. Specifically, these cells have been shown to be capable of producing a wide range of cytokines, including IFN-γ and IL-4, which help to orchestrate different aspects of the immune response. Additionally, these cells have been shown to be capable of directly killing cancer cells and other infected cells through the release of cytotoxic granules.

Overall, the immature NK T cell stage II represents a key component of the immune system and plays an important role in promoting immune surveillance and anti-tumor immunity. While much still remains to be discovered about the precise molecular mechanisms that underlie this cell type's function, ongoing research in this area is likely to provide valuable insights into the development of new strategies for treating a wide range of diseases and disorders.
CL:0002039:
Immature NK T cell stage I, also known as iNKT stage I, is a unique subset of T cells with features of both T cells and natural killer (NK) cells. These cells are CD1d-restricted, meaning they recognize glycolipid antigens presented by the CD1d molecule rather than peptides presented by traditional MHC class I molecules. iNKT stage I cells are distinct from other T cells in their rapid response to glycolipid antigens and their ability to produce both Th1 and Th2 cytokines. 

iNKT stage I cells contribute to both innate and adaptive immunity by rapidly secreting cytokines upon activation. Their production of Th1 cytokines such as interferon-gamma (IFN-γ) helps activate immune cells such as macrophages and dendritic cells to eliminate infected cells. In addition, iNKT stage I cells can produce Th2 cytokines such as interleukin-4 (IL-4) and interleukin-13 (IL-13), which help stimulate antibody production and enhance immune responses to extracellular pathogens. 

Overall, iNKT stage I cells play a crucial role in immune responses against a wide range of pathogens and diseases. They are being investigated for their potential roles in vaccine design, cancer therapy, and autoimmune disease treatment. Improved understanding of iNKT cell biology and function will likely lead to new approaches to enhance or modulate immune responses in a variety of settings.
CL:0002062:
Type I pneumocytes, also known as squamous alveolar cells, are a type of lung epithelial cell that play a crucial role in facilitating gas exchange. These cells are extremely thin and make up the majority of the alveolar surface area. Their flattened shape allows for efficient diffusion of gases between the air in the lungs and the bloodstream. In addition to facilitating gas exchange, type I pneumocytes are also involved in maintaining the structural integrity of the alveoli and preventing fluid accumulation in the lungs.

Although type I pneumocytes are relatively simple in structure, their importance cannot be overstated. Without these cells, gas exchange in the lungs would be severely compromised, leading to respiratory failure and potentially death. However, despite their critical role in lung function, type I pneumocytes are often damaged by environmental toxins, viral infections, and other factors. In severe cases, this damage can lead to conditions such as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), which is characterized by widespread damage to the alveolar wall and severe respiratory distress.
