Memory B cells are formed after an initial encounter with an antigen and subsequently provide an accelerated response upon re-exposure to the same antigen. CD38 is a transmembrane glycoprotein that is involved in cell signaling and plays a role in antibody production.

CD38-positive IgG memory B cells are responsible for the production of high-affinity IgG antibodies and are able to undergo rapid proliferation upon re-exposure to the antigen. This rapid proliferation is due to the memory B cells having undergone somatic hypermutation, a process that increases the affinity of the B cell receptors for the antigen. Consequently, this results in a faster and more effective immune response. CD38 is also involved in the regulation of intracellular calcium concentration, which is important in B cell activation and differentiation.

In summary, CD38-positive IgG memory B cells are an important component of the adaptive immune response, providing long-lasting protection against pathogens that have been encountered before. These cells produce high-affinity IgG antibodies and are able to undergo rapid proliferation upon re-exposure to the antigen, leading to a faster and more effective immune response. The expression of CD38 is involved in B cell signaling and regulation of intracellular calcium concentrations, which are important in B cell activation and differentiation.
CL:0002111:
CD38-negative unswitched memory B cells are a subtype of B cells that are characterized by their upregulated expression of CD27, lack of expression of CD38, and retention of IgM on their surface. They are critical for the rapid production of protective antibodies against previously encountered pathogens, and play an important role in host defense against infections. These cells are generated from germinal center-independent pathways and have the potential to differentiate into switched memory B cells.

Unswitched memory B cells are mostly found in the peripheral blood and secondary lymphoid organs. They respond to antigenic stimulation by re-entering germinal centers and undergoing further rounds of somatic hypermutation and clonal selection, leading to the generation of long-lived plasma cells and memory B cells. Interestingly, unswitched memory B cells have been shown to contribute to antibody responses against weakly immunogenic antigenic stimuli such as self-antigens, commensal bacteria, and viruses with low virulence. 

In summary, CD38-negative unswitched memory B cells are a critical component of the immune system and play a vital role in the generation of long-lasting humoral immunity against previously encountered pathogens. Their unique expression profile and localization in the immune system render them an interesting target for immunotherapeutic interventions, and further research on these cells could provide insights into novel therapeutic approaches for infectious diseases and autoimmune disorders.
CL:0002102:
CD38-negative naive B cells are a specific sub-group of B cells that play a vital role in the human immune system. These cells are characterized as a mature, naïve type of B cell that has not yet been exposed to an antigen. They are distinguished from other B cells by their lack of CD38 expression, a surface marker that is associated with the activation and differentiation of B cells.

The primary function of CD38-negative naive B cells is to identify and respond to antigens that enter the body. Once these cells are activated by an antigen, they differentiate into either memory B cells or antibody-secreting plasma cells. Memory B cells are long-lived cells that remember the antigen they were exposed to and are able to mount a more robust response upon subsequent exposure. Plasma cells, on the other hand, secrete large amounts of antibodies that are specific to the recognized antigen. These antibodies play a critical role in neutralizing pathogens in the blood and preventing them from causing an infection.

CD38-negative naive B cells are also important in the development of immunological tolerance. They can recognize self-antigens, molecules that are normally present within the body, and eliminate B cells that bind to them. In this way, CD38-negative naive B cells help prevent autoimmune diseases, where the immune system mistakenly attacks the body's own tissues. Overall, the function of CD38-negative naive B cells is to provide a crucial first-line of defense against foreign pathogens and maintain the delicate balance between protective immunity and immune tolerance.
CL:0002125:
CD27-negative gamma-delta T cells are a subset of T cells that are part of the adaptative immune system. These cells are characterized by the lack of the CD27 protein on their surface. They are called gamma-delta T cells because they express the gamma-delta T cell receptor (TCR) instead of the alpha-beta TCR expressed by the majority of T cells. 

CD27-negative gamma-delta T cells are mainly found in tissues such as the skin, gut, and lungs where they play a crucial role in the early response against pathogens. Unlike alpha-beta T cells, gamma-delta T cells recognize and respond to their targets in an antigen-independent manner, which means they can recognize and respond to a variety of molecules that are not necessarily derived from pathogens. This unique feature makes them important sentinels of tissues where they can detect and kill infected or transformed cells.

In addition to their role in the immune response against pathogens and cancer, CD27-negative gamma-delta T cells are also involved in tissue homeostasis and repair. They have been shown to promote tissue repair and regeneration by secreting growth factors and stimulating the proliferation of epithelial cells. CD27-negative gamma-delta T cells are still an area of active research, and their full functions are yet to be fully understood.
CL:0005022:
Vascular lymphangioblasts are an important type of cell that are involved in the development of the lymphatic system, which is responsible for draining fluid from tissues and returning it to the bloodstream. These cells are found in the early stages of lymphatic development, and are responsible for forming the initial network of lymphatic vessels that eventually grow into a complex system throughout the body.

Vascular lymphangioblasts are also important for regulating the immune system, as they produce a variety of growth factors and signaling molecules that promote the growth and survival of other immune cells. In particular, they play a key role in the activation of T-cells, which are a type of white blood cell that are essential for fighting infections and cancer.

In addition to their role in lymphatic development and immune function, vascular lymphangioblasts have recently been found to play a role in tumor development and progression. Studies have shown that these cells are attracted to and can be recruited by tumors, where they promote the growth and spread of cancer cells. As a result, targeting these cells may be a promising approach for developing new cancer therapies.
CL:0002133:
Stromal cells are a diverse group of cells in the body that provide structural support to tissues and organs. In the ovary, stromal cells of the ovarian cortex are responsible for producing hormones and providing support to ovarian follicles. These cells are essential for the growth and development of the follicles, which are responsible for producing eggs.

One of the primary functions of stromal cells in the ovarian cortex is to produce estrogen and progesterone. These hormones are essential for the growth and maturation of the follicles, as well as the maintenance of the menstrual cycle. Additionally, stromal cells provide structural support to the ovary, helping to maintain the integrity of the organ.

Stromal cells of the ovarian cortex also play a critical role in supporting the growth and development of ovarian follicles. These cells are located in close proximity to the follicles and provide them with essential nutrients and support. Without stromal cells, the follicles would not be able to grow and mature properly, and ovulation would not occur. Overall, the stromal cells of the ovarian cortex are critical for the proper functioning of the ovary and are essential for female reproductive health.
CL:0002116:
B220-low CD38-positive unswitched memory B cells, also known as MBC1 cells, are a particular type of B lymphocyte that remains in a naive, unswitched state. These cells are distinguished by their expression of the B220 marker at low levels and their high expression of CD38, a cell surface marker. They play an essential role in the immune system, acting as long-term guardians against infections by pathogens that have been encountered before.

Unlike other memory B cell types, which undergo isotype switching and hypermutation in response to antigen stimulation, MBC1 cells retain their original B cell receptor specificity. These unswitched memory cells are better equipped to respond to pathogens that recur with the same epitope, which means they can mount a quicker response and produce more robust and specific antibodies. MBC1 cells are often found in mucosal tissues, such as the gut or respiratory tract, where they can provide long-term protection against local infections.

In summary, B220-low CD38-positive unswitched memory B cells are a crucial subset of B lymphocytes that are tasked with protecting the body against recurrent infections by recognizing pathogens they have encountered before. By retaining their original naive isotypes, MBC1 cells can mount a more rapid and specific response to pathogens, providing long-lasting protection in mucosal tissues. Further research on this cell population could lead to new treatments for chronic infections and immune-mediated diseases.
CL:0002120:
CD24-positive CD38-negative IgG-negative class switched memory B cells are a type of B cell that play an essential role in the immune system's response to infections. These cells are distinguished by the presence of CD24 on their surface and the absence of CD38 and IgG. They are also known as resting memory B cells.

CD24-positive CD38-negative IgG-negative class switched memory B cells are generated from activated B cells that have undergone class switching and affinity maturation following encounter with an antigen. These cells can differentiate into plasma cells, which secrete high-affinity antibodies, or undergo further rounds of proliferation and differentiation to generate more specialized memory B cell subsets.

The primary function of CD24-positive CD38-negative IgG-negative class switched memory B cells is to provide long-term immunity against previously encountered pathogens. They do so by rapidly differentiating into plasma cells upon re-exposure to the antigen and secreting high levels of specific antibodies that can neutralize the pathogen. Moreover, these cells can also undergo secondary diversification of their antibody repertoire, leading to the generation of new antibodies that can better bind to variant forms of the antigen. In summary, CD24-positive CD38-negative IgG-negative class switched memory B cells are essential components of the adaptive immune system that provide long-lasting protection against infectious diseases by generating and maintaining a diverse repertoire of memory B cells.
CL:0002113:
B220-low CD38-negative unswitched memory B cells, also known as CD27+IgM+ memory B cells, are a subtype of B cells that play a crucial role in the immune system. These cells are characterized by low expression of the B220 marker and the lack of CD38 receptor on their cell surface. They are considered an important component of the humoral immune response, providing a rapid and efficient defense against re-exposure to pathogenic antigens.

Primarily found in the spleen and lymph nodes, unswitched memory B cells differentiate into plasma cells and produce high-affinity immunoglobulin M (IgM) antibodies in response to antigenic stimulation. These cells also have immunological memory, meaning that they can recognize previously encountered pathogens and mount a swift immune response upon re-infection. Additionally, they can serve as a pool of precursors for isotype-switched memory B cells, which produce a wider range of immunoglobulin classes.

B220-low CD38-negative unswitched memory B cells are involved in the immune response against both viral and bacterial infections, as well as in defense against tumor cells. Defects in the development or regulation of these cells have been associated with a variety of diseases, including autoimmune disorders and immunodeficiency syndromes. Therefore, the study of these cells is essential for the understanding and development of new therapies for immune-related diseases.
CL:0002110:
B220-low CD38-positive naive B cells are a subpopulation of B cells that are characterized by low expression of the B220 antigen and high expression of the CD38 antigen. These cells are typically found in the bone marrow, spleen, and lymph nodes of mammals, and are considered to be naive because they have not yet encountered their specific antigen.

The main function of B220-low CD38-positive naive B cells is to produce antibodies against foreign antigens. When an antigen enters the body, the B cell receptor on the surface of the B cell binds to it, triggering the activation and proliferation of the B cell. This results in the production of plasma cells, which secrete large amounts of antigen-specific antibodies, and memory B cells, which can quickly respond to subsequent encounters with the same antigen.

In addition, B220-low CD38-positive naive B cells play an important role in the regulation of immune responses. They can act as antigen-presenting cells, helping to activate other immune cells such as T cells, and can also secrete cytokines that modulate the behavior of other cells in the immune system. Overall, B220-low CD38-positive naive B cells are an essential component of the mammalian immune system, helping to protect the body from a wide variety of pathogens.
CL:0002109:
B220-positive CD38-positive naive B cells are a subset of B lymphocytes involved in humoral immunity. They are characterized by their expression of the B220 and CD38 markers. B lymphocytes are responsible for producing antibodies against foreign antigens. Naive B cells are those that have not yet encountered an antigen, thus they have not undergone differentiation into plasma cells or memory B cells. 

B220 is a cell surface marker that identifies B cells and is specific to the B-cell lineage. It is also known as CD45R. CD38 is a transmembrane glycoprotein that is expressed on the surface of many immune cells, including B cells. This marker is involved in various cellular processes, including cell adhesion, proliferation, and differentiation. 

Functionally, naive B cells play a crucial role in the adaptive immune response. They are responsible for the primary immune response to new antigens encountered by the body. During this process, naive B cells recognize and bind to the antigen. Once bound, the B cell engulfs the antigen and processes it into smaller fragments for presentation to T cells. This initiates a complex signaling cascade that results in the differentiation of the B cell into a plasma cell, which produces antibodies that can neutralize the antigen. Naive B cells also have the ability to differentiate into memory B cells, which have a longer lifespan and are able to mount a secondary immune response upon re-exposure to the same antigen.
CL:0002128:
Tc17 cells are a type of T lymphocyte (T cell) that produce the cytokine interleukin 17 (IL-17). They play a crucial role in the immune response to a variety of pathogens, including fungal, bacterial, and viral infections. Tc17 cells are involved in the recruitment of neutrophils and macrophages to sites of infection, assisting in the clearance of invading pathogens. 

In addition to their role in the immune response to infection, Tc17 cells are also involved in the pathogenesis of a number of autoimmune diseases. They are thought to contribute to the development of diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis, multiple sclerosis, and psoriasis by driving inflammation and tissue damage. 

Tc17 cells are characterized by the expression of a number of key cytokines, such as IL-17A, IL-17F, and IL-22. They are induced by a specific combination of cytokines and signaling pathways, including IL-1 beta, IL-6, and IL-23. The differentiation and function of Tc17 cells are tightly regulated by the transcription factor RORγt, which is required for the expression of IL-17 and related cytokines. Targeting Tc17 cells and their cytokines may provide a novel therapeutic approach for the treatment of autoimmune and inflammatory diseases.
CL:0002136:
Type II cells of the adrenal cortex are also known as the zona fasciculata cells. These cells are responsible for producing glucocorticoids which are essential for the regulation of metabolism. Glucocorticoids produced by the type II cells of the adrenal cortex play an important role in the regulation of blood glucose levels, the metabolism of fats, and the suppression of the immune system.

The type II cells of the adrenal cortex are found in the middle layer of the gland and are characterized by their relatively large size and abundance of smooth endoplasmic reticulum. The cells produce and secrete glucocorticoids in response to the adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) produced by the pituitary gland. ACTH stimulates the production of glucocorticoids by binding to receptors on the surface of the type II cells of the adrenal cortex.

The importance of the type II cells of the adrenal cortex is highlighted by the fact that deficiencies in glucocorticoid production can lead to a number of serious health conditions including Addison's disease. On the other hand, excessive production of glucocorticoids can lead to conditions such as Cushing's syndrome. Understanding the function and regulation of type II cells of the adrenal cortex is therefore critical for both the diagnosis and treatment of these conditions.
CL:0002099:
Type I cells of the adrenal cortex are large and polygonal cells that form a characteristic outermost layer of the gland. As one of the two main cell types found in the adrenal cortex, the primary function of type I cells is the synthesis and secretion of steroid hormones known as mineralocorticoids. Mineralocorticoids play an essential role in regulating salt and water balance in the body through their effects on the kidneys. Specifically, they facilitate the reabsorption of sodium from the urine back into the bloodstream, which helps to maintain blood pressure and electrolyte balance.

Type I cells are responsible for producing the main mineralocorticoid hormone known as aldosterone. Aldosterone is synthesized in response to the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) and acts to regulate blood pressure and electrolyte balance by promoting sodium retention in the kidneys. In addition to their role in aldosterone synthesis and secretion, type I cells also produce small amounts of glucocorticoids like cortisol. Glucocorticoids play a role in regulating metabolism, immune function, and response to stress, among other things.

In summary, type I cells of the adrenal cortex are vital for the synthesis and secretion of mineralocorticoids like aldosterone. These hormones play an important role in maintaining blood pressure and electrolyte balance in the body and are essential for normal physiological functioning. In addition to their role in mineralocorticoid production, type I cells also produce some glucocorticoids, which have important functions in metabolism, immune function, and stress response.
CL:0002150:
Epithelioid macrophages are a specialized type of immune cells found predominantly in areas of chronic inflammation. They are derived from monocytes and are characterized by their enlarged, rounded shape and abundant cytoplasmic granules, which often contain phagocytosed material. 

These cells play a key role in the host defense mechanism against intracellular pathogens such as mycobacteria and fungi. They are also involved in the process of granuloma formation, a hallmark of chronic inflammation. The activation of epithelioid macrophages is followed by the recruitment of other immune cells, leading to the formation of a well-organized structure consisting of macrophages, lymphocytes, and fibroblasts.

In addition to their role in immunity, epithelioid macrophages are also involved in tissue repair and regeneration. They produce various growth factors and cytokines that promote cell proliferation and differentiation, as well as extracellular matrix synthesis. In summary, epithelioid macrophages are crucial for the maintenance of tissue homeostasis and the resolution of inflammation.
CL:0002108:
CD38-negative IgG memory B cells are a subset of B cells that have undergone clonal expansion and differentiation to form terminally differentiated B cells. This cell type is distinguished from other B cell types by its lack of CD38 expression and its production of IgG antibodies. Memory B cells are an important component of the humoral immune response, as they provide long-lasting protection against previously encountered pathogens by rapidly producing high-affinity antibodies upon re-exposure to the pathogen.

CD38-negative IgG memory B cells were first identified in studies of human blood B cells, where they comprise a small fraction of total B cells. Although their function is not fully understood, CD38-negative IgG memory B cells are thought to play a key role in the maintenance of immunity against bacteria and viruses. In addition to producing high-affinity IgG antibodies, these cells are capable of antigen presentation and cytokine secretion, which contribute to the activation and regulation of other immune cells.

CD38-negative IgG memory B cells have been implicated in a variety of disease states, including autoimmune disorders, chronic infections, and lymphomas. The study of these cells may thus have important implications for the development of new therapies for these conditions. Overall, the identification and characterization of CD38-negative IgG memory B cells provides important insights into the complex immune response to infection and highlights the potential importance of these cells in both health and disease.
CL:0002140:
Acinar cells are specialized epithelial cells that make up the secretory portion of the sebaceous gland. These cells are responsible for producing and secreting sebum, an oily substance that helps to lubricate and protect the skin and hair. Sebaceous glands are most commonly found in the skin, although they can also be found in other locations such as the eyelids, genitals, and nipples.

The primary function of acinar cells in the sebaceous gland is to synthesize and secrete sebum. This oily substance is composed of a mixture of lipids, including triglycerides, free fatty acids, wax esters, and cholesterol esters. Sebum is released onto the skin surface through the pilosebaceous duct, where it spreads over the skin, forming a protective barrier that helps to prevent water loss and keep the skin supple.

In addition to their role in sebum production, acinar cells of the sebaceous gland have also been shown to have immunomodulatory functions. Studies have found that these cells produce and secrete various cytokines and chemokines that may play a role in immune regulation and inflammation. This suggests that acinar cells may play a more complex role in skin physiology than previously thought, highlighting the importance of further research in this area.
CL:0002138:
Endothelial cells of lymphatic vessels are a specialized type of cells that are responsible for the formation and function of the lymphatic system, which plays a crucial role in maintaining a healthy immune system. These cells form the inner lining of lymphatic vessels and are involved in the transport of lymphatic fluid, which contains lymphocytes, antigens, and other immune-related molecules, from the tissues to the lymph nodes.

The main function of endothelial cells of lymphatic vessels is to regulate the flow of lymphatic fluid by forming small valves called lymphatic valves. These valves prevent the backflow of fluid and ensure the unidirectional flow of lymph towards the lymph nodes. In addition, they also help to regulate the pressure within the lymphatic vessels, which is important for the proper functioning of the lymphatic system.

Endothelial cells of lymphatic vessels also play an important role in the immune response by affecting the migration of immune cells, such as dendritic cells and T cells, from the tissues to the lymph nodes. These cells interact with the endothelial cells and are guided to the lymphatic vessels, where they are transported to the lymph nodes for antigen presentation and recognition. Overall, endothelial cells of lymphatic vessels are essential for the proper functioning of the lymphatic system and the maintenance of a healthy immune response.
CL:0002129:
A regular atrial cardiac myocyte, or simply atrial myocyte, is a specialized type of muscle cell that is found in the heart's atria, the upper chambers of the heart. These cells are responsible for generating the contractions that push blood into the ventricles, effectively controlling the flow of blood through the heart. Atrial myocytes are connected to one another by intercalated discs, which allow them to synchronize their contractions and function as a coordinated unit, ensuring efficient pumping of blood.

At the molecular level, atrial myocytes are characterized by the presence of a specific set of proteins and ion channels that facilitate their contractile function. These include actin and myosin, which interact to generate the force necessary for contraction, as well as various ion channels, such as the L-type calcium channel, that regulate the influx of calcium ions into the cell during each contraction cycle.

In addition to their role in cardiac function, atrial myocytes have been implicated in a number of pathophysiological conditions, such as arrhythmia and atrial fibrillation. The development of pharmacological agents that target these cells and the ion channels that regulate their function has therefore been a focus of research in cardiovascular medicine.
CL:1001601:
Adrenal gland glandular cells, also known as adrenal cortical cells, are specialized cells located in the adrenal cortex of the adrenal gland. These cells are responsible for synthesizing and secreting steroid hormones, namely glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids, and androgens. The adrenal gland glandular cells play a pivotal role in the regulation of several physiological processes, including glucose homeostasis, electrolyte balance, and blood pressure.

Glucocorticoids, such as cortisol, are produced by the adrenal gland glandular cells in response to stress. These hormones play an important role in regulating the immune system, promoting gluconeogenesis, and facilitating the breakdown of fats and proteins. Mineralocorticoids, such as aldosterone, are also produced by these cells and are essential for maintaining electrolyte balance and blood pressure. Androgens, such as testosterone, are produced in small amounts by the adrenal gland glandular cells and are important for the development and maintenance of secondary sexual characteristics.

In addition to their endocrine functions, the adrenal gland glandular cells also play a role in the regulation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). This system is a complex pathway that helps regulate blood pressure and fluid balance in the body. When blood pressure drops, renin is released by the kidneys, which then stimulates the adrenal gland glandular cells to produce aldosterone. Aldosterone acts on the kidneys to increase sodium reabsorption, which helps increase blood volume and maintain blood pressure.

Overall, the adrenal gland glandular cell is a specialized cell type that plays an essential role in the regulation of several physiological processes in the body. By synthesizing and secreting steroid hormones, these cells help maintain glucose homeostasis, electrolyte balance, and blood pressure. Additionally, they play a role in the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, helping to regulate blood pressure and fluid balance.
CL:0002130:
Regular interatrial cardiac myocytes are specialized muscle cells found in the wall of the heart's atria. These cells are responsible for generating the force required to pump blood through the heart and into the lungs. They have a characteristic elongated shape with a single nucleus and are organized into layers that allow them to contract in a coordinated fashion. Regular interatrial cardiac myocytes are electrically connected to each other, forming a functional syncytium that enables the rapid and efficient contraction of the atrial walls.

In addition to their contractile function, regular interatrial cardiac myocytes also play a critical role in regulating the heart's electrical activity. They are equipped with specialized ion channels and receptors that allow them to generate and propagate electrical signals. These signals are essential for coordinating the contraction of the atrial walls and ensuring that blood is moved efficiently through the heart. Abnormalities in the electrical activity of regular interatrial cardiac myocytes can lead to arrhythmias and other forms of heart disease.

Moreover, regular interatrial cardiac myocytes communicate with other cells in the heart, such as the sinoatrial node and the atrioventricular node, through specialized electrical connections. These connections allow the regular interatrial cardiac myocytes to receive signals from other parts of the heart and to respond appropriately to changes in the heart's activity. Overall, regular interatrial cardiac myocytes are highly specialized cells that are essential for the proper functioning of the heart.
CL:0002112:
A B220-positive CD38-negative unswitched memory B cell is a type of immune cell that plays a vital role in the body's defense against pathogens such as viruses and bacteria. These cells are formed when activated B cells undergo a process called class switching, which allows them to produce different types of antibodies with varying functions. However, B220-positive CD38-negative unswitched memory B cells have not undergone this process, meaning they can only produce antibodies of a single type. This makes them highly specialized for targeting specific antigens and contributing to long-lasting immunity against previously encountered pathogens.

B220-positive CD38-negative unswitched memory B cells are unique in that they are long-lived and can persist in the body for decades. This allows them to quickly respond to reinfection by producing antibodies specific to the pathogen they previously encountered. These cells also play a critical role in vaccine-induced immunity, as they are responsible for maintaining protective antibody levels long after initial vaccination. Additionally, B220-positive CD38-negative unswitched memory B cells have been found to play a role in autoimmune diseases and allergic reactions, as they can produce antibodies that attack the body's own cells or respond to harmless substances as if they were harmful pathogens.

In conclusion, B220-positive CD38-negative unswitched memory B cells are a specialized type of immune cell that produce a single type of antibody and are responsible for long-lasting immunity against previously encountered pathogens. These cells play a critical role in vaccine-induced immunity and contribute to autoimmune diseases and allergic reactions. Understanding the function of these cells is crucial for developing effective vaccines and treatments for various immunological disorders.
CL:0002119:
CD38-positive IgG-negative class switched memory B cells are a subtype of B lymphocyte that plays a crucial role in acquiring and maintaining immunological memory. These cells are characterized by the presence of CD38 on their cell surface and the absence of surface IgG, a marker of class-switched B cells, which are responsible for the production of high-affinity antibodies. CD38-positive IgG-negative class switched memory B cells have already encountered and responded to specific antigens, and upon subsequent encounters with the same antigen, they undergo rapid proliferation and differentiation into antibody-secreting cells.

CD38-positive IgG-negative class switched memory B cells arise from germinal center reactions, where they acquire somatic hypermutations that increase the affinity and specificity of their antigen receptors. These cells are critical for long-term protection against pathogens because they can persist for decades, providing rapid and robust responses to previously encountered antigens. In addition, CD38-positive IgG-negative class switched memory B cells can differentiate into plasma cells that secrete high-affinity antibodies, which can bind to antigens more effectively compared to naïve B cells.

The functions of CD38-positive IgG-negative class switched memory B cells are essential for maintaining immunological memory and long-term protection against pathogens. These cells enable the immune system to respond rapidly and effectively to previously encountered antigens, preventing reinfection and maintaining immunity. Ongoing research aims to elucidate the molecular mechanisms underlying the differentiation and maintenance of CD38-positive IgG-negative class switched memory B cells, which may lead to the development of more effective vaccines and immunotherapies.
CL:0002106:
IgD-positive CD38-positive IgG memory B cells (IgD+CD38+IgG MEMs) are a subpopulation of B lymphocytes that are essential in providing long-term immunity via the production of high-affinity antibodies. By expressing a combination of immunoglobulin receptors, these cells can respond rapidly to a foreign antigen that has been previously encountered by the immune system. IgD+CD38+IgG MEMs are considered to be one of the most potent types of memory B cells because they generate highly specific immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibodies that are effective against pathogens.

IgD+CD38+IgG MEMs are formed during the germinal center reaction, which occurs after an infection or after immunization. During this process, B cells undergo somatic hypermutation and affinity maturation, which allows them to improve the quality of their antibodies by introducing specific mutations into the variable regions of their immunoglobulin genes. IgD+CD38+IgG MEMs have undergone these processes and have been selected for the highest-affinity IgG antibody production. Once activated, these cells differentiate into antibody-secreting cells that produce persistently high levels of specific IgG antibodies.

The ability of IgD+CD38+IgG MEMs to mount a rapid and effective response to previously encountered pathogens is important for maintaining long-term immunity. Upon re-exposure to the same pathogen, this subpopulation of memory B cells will quickly generate highly specific IgG antibodies that will neutralize the pathogen before it can cause disease. The formation and persistence of IgD+CD38+IgG MEMs is therefore essential for the immune system to provide long-lasting protection against infectious diseases.
CL:1000448:
Epithelial cells of sweat glands are specialized cells that reside in the internal lining of sweat glands in the skin. Derived from the embryonic ectoderm, these cells exhibit different morphological and functional characteristics depending on the region of the sweat gland where they reside.

There are two main types of sweat glands: eccrine and apocrine. Eccrine sweat glands are distributed all over the body and primarily regulate the body temperature while apocrine sweat glands are found in the axillary and genital regions and secrete a viscous and odorous secretion through hair follicles. The epithelial cells of sweat glands play essential roles in both types of glands. 

In eccrine sweat glands, epithelial cells participate in the process of sweat secretion. They are responsible for the uptake of electrolytes and water from the blood, the transportation of these components to the sweat-producing cells, and the final excretion of the sweat onto the skin surface. The whole process is activated by the sympathetic nervous system and is crucial for thermal regulation of the body. In apocrine sweat glands, epithelial cells also participate in the process of secretion, but their main function is to support the growth and secretion of apocrine cells. Therefore, the epithelial cells of sweat glands are responsible for the maintenance and regulation of sweat gland development and function, ultimately contributing to overall skin homeostasis.
CL:0002107:
IgD-negative CD38-positive IgG memory B cells are a specialized type of white blood cell that plays a crucial role in the immune system's ability to remember previous encounters with pathogens. These cells are generated during an immune response and persist for years, providing long-lasting immunity against particular pathogens. IgD-negative CD38-positive IgG memory B cells are characterized by their lack of expression of the IgD antibody receptor, high expression of the CD38 cell surface marker, and production of the IgG class of antibodies.

The primary function of IgD-negative CD38-positive IgG memory B cells is to rapidly produce IgG antibodies upon re-exposure to a previously encountered pathogen. This process, known as a secondary immune response, is much faster and more efficient than the primary immune response that occurs during the first encounter with a pathogen. IgD-negative CD38-positive IgG memory B cells are important for protection against many viral and bacterial infections, and they also play a critical role in providing long-term immunity following vaccination.

In addition to their role in immunity, IgD-negative CD38-positive IgG memory B cells are involved in the pathogenesis of autoimmune diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus and rheumatoid arthritis. In these conditions, the immune system mistakenly attacks the body's own tissues, and IgD-negative CD38-positive IgG memory B cells have been shown to contribute to this process. Researchers are actively studying these cells in an effort to develop new treatments for autoimmune diseases and improve our understanding of the immune system as a whole.
CL:0002143:
A dark chief cell of parathyroid gland, also known as chief cell, is a type of endocrine cell found in the parathyroid gland. These glandular cells are named for their dark staining cytoplasm as seen under the microscope and are responsible for producing and secreting parathyroid hormone (PTH), a key hormone that regulates calcium homeostasis in the body. Chief cells make up the majority of the parathyroid gland and are generally larger than the other type of parathyroid cells, known as oxyphil cells.

PTH secretion by chief cells is tightly regulated by the concentration of both calcium and phosphate ions in the blood. When calcium levels become low, chief cells release PTH, which acts on the bones to stimulate calcium release into the blood, and on the kidneys to decrease calcium loss in the urine. PTH also stimulates the production of active vitamin D in the kidneys, which then acts in the intestines to increase the absorption of calcium from food. Through these mechanisms, PTH helps to increase the concentration of calcium in the blood back to normal levels.

In summary, dark chief cells of the parathyroid gland are endocrine cells that produce and secrete parathyroid hormone in response to low calcium levels in the blood. PTH acts on bones, kidneys and intestines to increase calcium levels back to normal.
CL:0002162:
Internal epithelial cells of the tympanic membrane are a specialized type of epithelial cells located in the middle ear. These cells play an essential role in the function of the ear, particularly in the regulation of sound and pressure. The tympanic membrane is commonly referred to as the eardrum, and these specialized cells are located on the inner surface of the membrane.

The primary function of internal epithelial cells of the tympanic membrane is to secrete a mucus-like substance that helps to keep the inner ear moist and protect it from infection and other external factors. Additionally, these cells are responsible for the production of a fluid known as endolymph that helps to regulate the pressure and movement of sound waves within the ear.

These cells are also important in maintaining the integrity of the tympanic membrane. They form a tight barrier between the inner ear and the external environment, which helps to prevent the entry of foreign substances and bacteria that could potentially cause damage or infection. In this way, internal epithelial cells of the tympanic membrane are crucial in supporting the overall function of the ear and protecting it from harm.
CL:0002104:
The IgG-negative double negative memory B cell, also known as DN2 or CD27-IgM-IgD- memory B cell, is a type of B lymphocyte that lacks the expression of both immunoglobulin G (IgG) and the CD27 co-stimulatory molecule, hence the name "double negative." These cells are formed during the germinal center response, an essential process for the immune system to develop long-lasting immunity against pathogens. Once formed, DN2 cells migrate to the bone marrow and persist for an extended period, capable of generating a robust and rapid response upon re-exposure to the same pathogen.

The function of IgG-negative double negative memory B cells is to provide long-lasting immunity against pathogens that have been encountered previously. Upon encountering an antigen for a second time, DN2 cells differentiate into plasma cells, the effector cells that secrete large quantities of antibodies to rapidly neutralize or eliminate the pathogen. Unlike naive B cells that require several rounds of activation and differentiation to become fully capable of generating an antibody response, DN2 cells mount a rapid and potent response, making them crucial for vaccine-mediated immunity.

In addition to their role in immunological memory, IgG-negative double negative memory B cells have been implicated in various pathological conditions. Studies have shown that this subset of B cells can promote chronic inflammation and contribute to the pathogenesis of autoimmune diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and rheumatoid arthritis. Understanding the molecular mechanisms that regulate the activation and differentiation of DN2 cells may provide new insights into how to modulate immune responses to prevent or treat autoimmune diseases.
CL:0002152:
Columnar cells are epithelial cells that form a single layer in the innermost surface of the endocervix, which is the opening between the uterus and vaginal canal. These columnar cells are column-shaped and have nuclei at the bottom, near the basement membrane. The endocervix in the female reproductive system plays an essential role in the transport of eggs from the uterus to the vagina.

The columnar cells of the endocervix are responsible for producing and secreting mucus that accumulates in the cervical canal. The secretion of mucus from columnar cells provides a protective barrier and lubrication to the uterus and vagina. In addition, the columnar cells of the endocervix are involved in cyclic changes that occur throughout the menstrual cycle, such as changes in mucus secretion and the height of the endocervical canal.

Abnormal changes in the columnar cells of the endocervix can result in several health issues, including cervical cancer. Understanding the function of columnar cells in the female reproductive system is crucial for the development of screening and diagnostic tools to detect abnormalities in the endocervix and prevent possible health risks.
CL:0002135:
Nonkeratinized cells of the epidermis, also known as living cells of the epidermis, are a type of squamous epithelial cell that make up the outermost layer of the epidermis. These cells are found in areas of the skin that are not exposed to friction or pressure, such as the face and genitals. The nonkeratinized cells of the epidermis are responsible for maintaining the skin's barrier function, protecting the underlying tissues and organs from mechanical damage, as well as preventing the entry of microorganisms and harmful substances.

Nonkeratinized cells of the epidermis are unique in their ability to undergo rapid division to replace lost or damaged cells, a process known as epidermal regeneration. These cells play a crucial role in wound healing, as they migrate to the wound site and proliferate to form a new layer of skin. In addition to their barrier functions, nonkeratinized cells of the epidermis are also involved in sensory perception. They contain nerve endings that respond to touch, temperature, and pain, allowing us to perceive sensations on the skin's surface.

In conclusion, nonkeratinized cells of the epidermis are essential components of the skin's structure and function. These cells provide a physical barrier against external threats and are involved in sensory perception and wound healing. Understanding the functions and characteristics of nonkeratinized cells of the epidermis is crucial to the development of treatments and therapies for skin disorders and injuries.
CL:0002124:
CD27-positive gamma-delta T cells are a rare subset of T cells that express the CD27 molecule on their surface and have a gamma-delta T cell receptor. They are primarily found in peripheral blood, lymphoid tissues, and mucosal sites such as the intestine, lung, and skin. These cells play a crucial role in the immune response by participating in the defense against infections, tumors, and autoimmune diseases.

Studies have shown that CD27-positive gamma-delta T cells have unique characteristics that distinguish them from other T cells. They are known for their potent cytotoxicity and ability to produce cytokines such as interferon-gamma and tumor necrosis factor-alpha, which activate and recruit other immune cells to the site of infection. CD27-positive gamma-delta T cells are particularly important in the early stages of infection when the adaptive immune response has not yet been fully established. They also have the ability to recognize different types of antigens, including self-antigens, and can regulate the immune response to prevent excessive inflammation and tissue damage.

In addition to their role in immune defense, CD27-positive gamma-delta T cells have been implicated in various disease processes. Alterations in the number and function of these cells have been associated with infections, autoimmune diseases, and cancer. Further research is needed to fully understand the specific contribution of CD27-positive gamma-delta T cells to these conditions and to identify potential therapeutic targets.
CL:0002336:
Buccal mucosa cells are found lining the inner cheek wall and are a type of epithelial cell. In addition to providing a protective barrier to underlying tissues, buccal mucosa cells have an important function in the immune response of the body. These cells play a crucial role in identifying and responding to foreign substances that enter the body through the mouth, such as bacteria, viruses, and other harmful agents.

Buccal mucosa cells are also involved in the process of taste sensation. Microvilli, or small hair-like structures, extend from the surface of these cells and contain receptors that detect different flavors and transmit signals to the brain. Additionally, buccal mucosa cells produce mucus, which helps to lubricate the mouth and aids in the process of swallowing.

Interestingly, buccal mucosa cells are being studied for potential use in regenerative medicine and tissue engineering. With their ability to rapidly proliferate and differentiate into other cell types, researchers are exploring the possibility of using these cells to repair or replace damaged tissues in the body. This area of study holds great promise for the future of medicine.
CL:0002146:
Clear cells of the eccrine sweat gland are specialized epithelial cells that are responsible for the formation of sweat. These cells are flat, thin, and transparent in appearance and are found in the secretory coil and duct of the sweat gland. As part of their function, these cells remove water and electrolytes from the blood and secrete a watery solution to cool the body during thermal stress.

Clear cells have abundant mitochondria to facilitate the active transport of ions and water from the blood into the gland lumen. The cells also have numerous microvilli on their apical surface, which increase the surface area for secretion. The composition of the secretion produced by these cells is dependent on various factors like age, sex, and the intensity of physical activity of the individual.

The eccrine sweat gland and the clear cells are essential for the regulation of body temperature. When the body temperature rises, the sympathetic nervous system stimulates these glands to produce sweat, a process known as thermoregulation. This process is essential, mainly for humans since they are entirely dependent on the production of sweat to thermoregulate the body. Dysfunction of clear cells has been linked to conditions such as hyperhidrosis, where excessive sweating occurs even in non-stressful situations, and anhidrosis, where the skin fails to produce sweat.
CL:0002155:
Echinocytes, also known as burr cells or crenated cells, are a type of red blood cell (erythrocyte) that have an uneven surface with spiky projections extending from the cell membrane. This unique morphology is typically associated with pathological conditions such as certain kidney diseases, liver diseases, and vitamin E deficiency. Echinocytes can also be induced by physical stress on the cells, such as changes in temperature or pH.

The function of echinocytes is not completely understood, but they are thought to have a reduced capacity for oxygen transport due to their abnormal shape. They may also be more prone to hemolysis (rupture) due to mechanical stress, which can lead to anemia and other complications. In addition, echinocytes have a reduced ability to deform and pass through narrow capillaries, which may explain their association with diseases that affect blood flow or the microcirculation.

Overall, echinocytes are an abnormal type of red blood cell that can provide important diagnostic information in certain disease states. Although their exact role in disease pathogenesis is not fully understood, they are thought to contribute to the progression of some conditions through their effects on oxygen transport, hemolysis, and blood flow.
CL:0002209:
Intermediate epitheliocytes are a type of epithelial cell that are located in epithelial tissues. These cells are polygonal in shape and have a distinct cytoskeleton, which is composed of intermediate filaments. These filaments provide the cell with structural support and help it maintain its shape. Intermediate epitheliocytes are named for their intermediate position between basal and apical cells in the epithelial layer. They play a crucial role in maintaining the integrity and function of epithelial tissues.

The primary function of intermediate epitheliocytes is to provide mechanical support to the epithelium. These cells are highly specialized for this role and are able to withstand mechanical stress. They are also highly resistant to damage from environmental factors such as toxins and oxidants. This makes them particularly important in tissues that are regularly exposed to external stimuli such as the skin, lung, and gut. In these tissues, intermediate epitheliocytes provide a robust first line of defense against potential damage.

In addition to their mechanical function, intermediate epitheliocytes can also play a role in the modulation of cell signaling pathways. These cells express a variety of receptors on their surface that are involved in cellular signaling. They can also produce a range of cytokines and growth factors that are involved in tissue repair and regeneration. By modulating these pathways, intermediate epitheliocytes play an important role in maintaining tissue homeostasis, and are critical for proper tissue function.
CL:0002126:
CD25-positive, CD27-positive immature gamma-delta T cells are a unique subset of T cells that play an important role in the immune system. These cells are characterized by the expression of CD25, which is a marker of T cell activation, and CD27, which is a marker of T cell memory. They are considered "immature" because they have not yet undergone a full developmental program and are still capable of differentiating into different types of T cells. 

Gamma-delta T cells are a subset of T cells that possess a T-cell receptor (TCR) that recognizes antigens in a different manner from the more well-known alpha-beta T cells. They are often found at mucosal surfaces and have been shown to play a critical role in the immune response to infections and tumors. CD25-positive, CD27-positive immature gamma-delta T cells are a specific subset of gamma-delta T cells that are involved in immune surveillance and immune regulation.

The function of CD25-positive, CD27-positive immature gamma-delta T cells is not completely understood, but several studies suggest that they play a role in the immune response to cancer. They have been shown to be important in controlling the growth and spread of tumors, and there is evidence that they may be able to recognize and kill cancer cells. Additionally, these cells may play a role in the regulation of other immune cells, helping to balance the immune response and prevent over-activation of the immune system. Overall, CD25-positive, CD27-positive immature gamma-delta T cells are an important subset of T cells that contribute to the immune system's ability to recognize and respond to a wide range of threats, including infections and cancer.
CL:0002137:
Type III cells of the adrenal cortex, also known as the spongiocytes, are one of the three main types of cells that make up the cortex of the adrenal gland. They are characterized by their unique spongy appearance, which is due to the presence of numerous lipid droplets in the cytoplasm. Type III cells are involved in the production and secretion of glucocorticoids, which are hormones that play a key role in metabolism and the body's stress response.

As part of the HPA axis (hypothalamus-pituitary-adrenal axis), type III cells are regulated by the release of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) from the pituitary gland, which in turn stimulates the production and secretion of glucocorticoids by the adrenal cortex. Glucocorticoids are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, including the regulation of blood glucose levels, the metabolism of proteins, lipids and carbohydrates, and the suppression of inflammation and immune responses.

In addition to their role in hormone production, type III cells also have a supportive function in the adrenal gland. They produce a variety of extracellular matrix proteins and enzymes that help to maintain the structural integrity of the gland, and they also provide a physical barrier between the hormone-secreting cells of the cortex and the blood vessels that supply them. Overall, type III cells of the adrenal cortex are a key component of the endocrine system and play a vital role in the regulation of the body's response to stress and metabolic control.
CL:0002161:
Superficial external epithelial cells of the tympanic membrane, also known as outer epithelial cells, are a type of flattened epithelial cells found in the outermost layer of the tympanic membrane. These cells play a significant role in maintaining the integrity and function of the tympanic membrane.

The primary function of the superficial external epithelial cells is to protect the ear from external agents, including physical injury and infections. These cells form a tight barrier that prevents the entry of harmful substances into the middle ear by sealing any microfractures or perforations in the tympanic membrane. This way, they maintain the optimal acoustic properties of the membrane, which is critical for sound transmission.

In addition to their protective function, superficial external epithelial cells of the tympanic membrane are vital for the process of hearing. They are equipped with numerous hair-like structures called cilia that can detect sound vibrations and convert them into nerve signals that are sent to the brain. This makes them an integral part of the ear's sensory apparatus, which allows us to experience the sense of hearing. Overall, the superficial external epithelial cells of the tympanic membrane are an essential component of the ear's structure and function, and their proper function is critical for maintaining our ability to hear.
CL:0002166:
Epithelial cells of Malassez are a specific type of epithelial cell found in dental tissues. These cells play an essential role in the development and maintenance of dental tissues and are responsible for secreting and maintaining the collagen fibers that make up the periodontal ligament. They are located within the dental pulp and are thought to act as sensory receptors within the dental pulp. 

Epithelial cells of Malassez are believed to originate from the Hertwig's epithelial root sheath, which plays a crucial role in the development of the roots of teeth. These cells are essential for the formation of a secure attachment between the tooth and surrounding bone, which is necessary for the proper functioning and stability of the dental arch. They are also involved in the regeneration of damaged periodontal ligament tissue and may play a crucial role in the development and treatment of periodontal diseases. 

Overall, epithelial cells of Malassez are a vital component of dental tissues. Their role in dental development and maintenance makes them an important cell type to study in the context of oral health. Understanding the function of these cells may help researchers develop better therapies for periodontal diseases and other dental conditions.
CL:0002134:
Stromal cells of the ovarian medulla are an important cell type that play a crucial role in the development and maintenance of the female reproductive system. These cells are located in the medulla of the ovary, which is the central region of the organ. They are a type of connective tissue cell and are thought to arise from mesenchymal stem cells.

One of the primary functions of stromal cells of the ovarian medulla is to provide support to the developing follicles within the ovary. These cells are involved in the production of extracellular matrix (ECM) proteins, including collagens, which provide a scaffold for the developing follicles. In addition to providing structural support, stromal cells also secrete growth factors and cytokines that promote follicular growth and maturation.

Another important function of stromal cells of the ovarian medulla is to produce steroid hormones. These cells are capable of producing both estrogen and progesterone, which are essential for the regulation of the female reproductive cycle. The production of these hormones is tightly regulated by the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis, a complex network of signaling pathways that involves interactions between the hypothalamus, pituitary gland, and ovary. Dysregulation of this axis can lead to conditions such as polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and fertility issues.

In summary, stromal cells of the ovarian medulla are a vital component of the female reproductive system. Their functions include providing structural support to developing follicles, producing steroid hormones, and regulating the complex network of signaling pathways that govern the female reproductive cycle.
CL:4030034:
Respiratory ciliated cells are specialized cells found in the respiratory tract that possess cilia, which are tiny hair-like structures that extend from the cell surface and beat in coordinated waves. These cells play a crucial role in clearing mucus and foreign particles from the respiratory system and protecting the lungs against infection and damage. The cilia move in a coordinated motion that sweeps mucus and trapped particles out of the lungs, preventing them from accumulating and causing harm.

Respiratory ciliated cells are found throughout the respiratory tract, from the nasal cavity to the bronchioles, and are particularly abundant in the trachea and larger bronchi. In addition to their role in clearing mucus, respiratory ciliated cells also secrete a thin layer of mucus that lines the respiratory surface and helps to humidify and protect the airways. They also play a role in sensing and responding to changes in the respiratory environment, such as changes in temperature or air quality.

Dysfunction or loss of respiratory ciliated cells can lead to a number of respiratory diseases, such as cystic fibrosis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and asthma. In these diseases, the normal beating motion of the cilia is impaired, leading to a build-up of mucus and trapped particles in the lungs, which can result in infection, inflammation, and tissue damage. Understanding the function of respiratory ciliated cells is critical for developing effective therapies to treat these diseases and restore normal respiratory function.
CL:0002158:
External epithelial cells of the tympanic membrane are part of the external acoustic meatus and constitute the outermost layer of the tympanic membrane. The tympanic membrane is also known as the eardrum. The external epithelium is roughly two to three cell layers thick and primarily consists of squamous epithelial cells. These cells play a role in protecting the ear canal and the middle ear from bacterial and fungal infections by secreting cerumen, commonly known as earwax. 

In addition to their protective function, external epithelial cells of the tympanic membrane are also involved in sound transmission. Sound waves travel through the external acoustic meatus and cause the tympanic membrane to vibrate. The vibrations are then transmitted through the middle ear to the inner ear. The external epithelial cells contribute to the efficient transfer of sound waves by ensuring that the tympanic membrane remains taut and by minimizing any disruptions to the sound wave as it travels through the ear canal. 

Overall, the external epithelial cells of the tympanic membrane are vital for the protection and function of the ear. Their ability to secrete earwax and contribute to sound transmission ensures that the ear remains healthy and able to efficiently perform its auditory function. Any functional or structural defects in this cell type could lead to hearing loss or infections.
CL:0005012:
Multi-ciliated epithelial cells are a special type of epithelial cell that are characterized by the presence of multiple motile cilia projecting from the cell surface. These cells are found in various parts of the body, including the respiratory tract, the ependymal lining of the brain ventricles, and the reproductive tract. In the respiratory tract, multi-ciliated epithelial cells are responsible for the movement of mucous and debris out of the lungs, whereas in the brain, they facilitate the movement of cerebrospinal fluid. These cells have been described as having a "whirlpool-like" motion, with their cilia beating in unison to create a fluid flow.

Multi-ciliated epithelial cells play a crucial role in maintaining the health and function of these tissues. In the respiratory tract, they help to protect against infection by removing foreign particles and pathogens from the lungs. In the brain, they are essential for the proper distribution of cerebrospinal fluid, which helps to maintain proper brain function. Dysfunction of these cells can lead to a range of diseases, including respiratory infections and hydrocephalus (excessive accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid in the brain).

Overall, multi-ciliated epithelial cells are an important and unique type of cell that play critical roles in the function and health of various tissues in the body. Their specialized structure and function make them essential for the proper function of the respiratory, reproductive, and nervous systems.
CL:0002149:
The epithelial cells of uterus are specialized cells that line the inner surface of the uterus, also known as endometrium. These cells are vital for reproductive health as they play a major role in menstrual cycle and pregnancy. During a menstrual cycle, the epithelial cells of the uterus undergo cyclic changes in response to hormonal fluctuations. They proliferate and secrete a variety of biochemicals that are involved in menstrual bleeding and are necessary for implantation of the fertilized egg. In case pregnancy occurs, they transform into a specialized type of cells that are essential for the nourishment and protection of the developing embryo.

Epithelial cells of the uterus are considered secretory cells, meaning that they produce and secrete substances, including mucus, glycoproteins, and enzymes, which are necessary for the transport and survival of sperm. Furthermore, they provide a protective barrier against infections and other external threats by secreting antimicrobial peptides and cytokines. The optimal function of these cells is essential for reproductive health and any disruption in their activity can lead to medical conditions such as endometriosis, infertility, or cancer.

In conclusion, the epithelial cells of the uterus are important cell types essential for reproductive health. Their functions range from producing and secreting substances necessary for fertilization and implantation to providing a protective barrier against infections. Understanding the role of these cells is key to the diagnosis and treatment of various medical conditions related to the uterus.
CL:0002147:
Clear chief cells are a specialized subpopulation of chief cells that make up the majority of the epithelial cells of the parathyroid gland. These cells are so named because their cytoplasm appears clear in histological sections due to a lack of cytoplasmic granules. Clear chief cells are responsible for synthesizing and secreting parathyroid hormone (PTH), a key regulator of calcium and phosphorus homeostasis in the body.

PTH secretion by clear chief cells is regulated by the concentration of ionized calcium in the bloodstream. When calcium levels drop below a critical threshold, clear chief cells release PTH into the bloodstream. PTH acts on target organs such as bone and kidney to increase calcium resorption and decrease calcium excretion, thereby restoring calcium homeostasis. In addition to its role in maintaining calcium balance, PTH also plays a crucial role in bone metabolism, stimulating bone resorption by osteoclasts.

Dysfunction of clear chief cells and their associated PTH secretion can lead to a variety of disorders, such as primary hyperparathyroidism, a condition characterized by excess PTH secretion and resulting hypercalcemia. This can lead to a number of serious complications, including kidney stones, bone loss, and impaired cognitive function. Understanding the function and regulation of clear chief cells is therefore crucial for diagnosing and treating these and other disorders of calcium and bone metabolism.
CL:0002122:
B220-positive CD38-positive IgG-negative class switched memory B cells are a specific population of B cells that are present in the immune system. These cells express the B220 surface marker, which is commonly found on B cells within the bone marrow and spleen. Additionally, they also express CD38, a cell surface protein that regulates B cell activation and differentiation. These cells are characterized as IgG-negative, meaning they do not produce a specific type of antibody that is important for neutralizing viral infections.

These class switched memory B cells play a critical role in the immune response by providing long-lasting protection against previously encountered pathogens. The B220-positive CD38-positive IgG-negative phenotype identifies a population of memory B cells that have undergone class switching, a process by which B cells change the type of antibody they produce. This allows them to produce a wide range of antibody types that are important for targeting diverse pathogens. Additionally, these cells can rapidly respond to secondary infections by rapidly differentiating into plasma cells or generating a new round of memory B cells.

Furthermore, these cells have been shown to play a role in autoimmune diseases such as lupus and rheumatoid arthritis. It is suggested that these cells might contribute to the development of autoimmunity by producing autoantibodies that react with self-antigens, leading to tissue damage and inflammatory responses. Overall, the B220-positive CD38-positive IgG-negative class switched memory B cell population represents an important component of the immune system that plays a multifaceted role in the generation of protective immunity and the development of autoimmune diseases.
CL:0002183:
The stem cell of the gastric gland is a highly specialized cell type that is responsible for maintaining the normal function and regeneration of the gastric epithelium. These cells are located within the gastric gland and have the ability to self-renew and differentiate into the various cell types that make up the gastric epithelium. 

The gastric gland is composed of mucus-secreting cells, parietal cells, and chief cells. The stem cell of gastric gland serves as the progenitor for these specialized cell types. These differentiated cell types are responsible for secreting mucus and acid, which helps to maintain the acidic environment of the stomach necessary for digestion. 

Dysfunction of the stem cells of gastric gland can lead to the development of gastric cancer. Recent research has shown that these stem cells play a critical role in the development and progression of gastric cancer by promoting tumor growth and resistance to chemotherapy. Understanding the biology and function of these cells may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of gastric cancer.
CL:0002160:
Basal external epithelial cells of tympanic membrane are a type of epithelial cell that are found in the external layer of the tympanic membrane, also known as the eardrum. These cells are responsible for maintaining the integrity and protection of the tympanic membrane. They form a barrier that prevents harmful agents such as bacteria, viruses, and foreign objects from entering the ear canal and causing damage to the inner ear.

Basal external epithelial cells also play an important role in the production and secretion of mucus, which helps to lubricate and protect the surface of the tympanic membrane. This mucus is essential for maintaining the overall health of the ear and preventing infections and other complications from occurring. Additionally, these cells are involved in the regeneration and repair of damaged cells in the tympanic membrane, which allows for proper functioning of the ear.

Overall, basal external epithelial cells of tympanic membrane are a crucial component of the ear's defense system and are essential for maintaining the health and proper functioning of the ear. Their ability to form a protective barrier, produce mucus, and regenerate damaged cells makes them an important cell type that plays a critical role in maintaining ear health.
CL:1001318:
Renal interstitial pericytes are a type of perivascular cell located in the interstitial space of the kidney. These cells have a unique morphology with small elongated bodies and numerous processes extending from the cell body. They are part of a complex network of cells that play a crucial role in the maintenance and function of the kidney.

The primary function of renal interstitial pericytes is to regulate blood flow in the kidney by controlling the diameters of the blood vessels. These pericytes can change their shape and contract around blood vessels to regulate blood flow, which is important in maintaining optimal renal function. Additionally, they play a role in the immune response within the kidney by secreting cytokines and interacting with immune cells.

Recent research has shown that renal interstitial pericytes also play a role in renal fibrosis, a pathological condition associated with chronic kidney disease. During the progression of fibrosis, pericytes undergo a phenotypic switch and differentiate into myofibroblasts. This differentiation process leads to the deposition of extracellular matrix and the development of fibrotic tissue, leading to decreased renal function. Understanding the role of renal interstitial pericytes in renal fibrosis could lead to new therapeutic targets for treating chronic kidney disease.
CL:0002176:
Secondary follicular cells of the ovary are a type of somatic cell that play a crucial role in the growth and maturation of ovarian follicles. These cells surround and support developing oocytes, providing structural and nutritional support through the secretion of hormones and extracellular matrix components. Secondary follicular cells are characterized by their columnar shape, secretory activity, and expression of markers such as GATA4 and FOXL2.

One of the primary functions of secondary follicular cells is the secretion of estrogen, which is essential for follicular growth and development. These cells express aromatase, an enzyme that converts androgens to estrogens, and also produce other steroid hormones such as progesterone. In addition to endocrine signaling, secondary follicular cells also provide mechanical support and create an optimal microenvironment for oocyte development. They secrete extracellular matrix components such as collagen and laminin, which anchor the oocyte within the follicle and facilitate its communication with neighboring cells.

Overall, secondary follicular cells are essential for the development and maturation of ovarian follicles, and the successful production of mature oocytes. Through their combined endocrine and structural support functions, these cells play a critical role in regulating reproductive health and fertility in females.
CL:0002151:
Late promyelocytes are a type of myeloid cell that are found in the bone marrow of mammals. These cells are part of the process of hematopoiesis, which is the process by which blood cells are produced. Late promyelocytes are the last stage of development before becoming myelocytes, which then mature into granulocytes. 

Late promyelocytes are larger than early promyelocytes and have more cytoplasm. They are characterized by the presence of granules in their cytoplasm, which are specific to the type of granulocyte they will differentiate into. For example, late promyelocytes that will differentiate into neutrophils will have specific granules in their cytoplasm, while those that will differentiate into eosinophils will have different granules.

The function of late promyelocytes is to differentiate into myelocytes, which will then mature into granulocytes. Granulocytes are an important component of the immune system, as they help to defend the body against pathogens and other foreign invaders. Neutrophils, for example, are the most abundant type of granulocyte and are important for responding to bacterial infections. Eosinophils, on the other hand, are important for responding to parasitic infections and allergic reactions. Late promyelocytes play a critical role in the development of these important immune cells.
CL:0002144:
Capillary endothelial cells are a specialized type of epithelial cell that line the interior surfaces of capillaries, which are the smallest blood vessels in the body. Their primary function is to regulate the movement of substances, such as nutrients, gases, and waste products, between the blood and the surrounding tissues. Capillary endothelial cells are a key component of the microcirculation, the network of small blood vessels that delivers oxygen and nutrients to the cells of the body.

Capillary endothelial cells have a number of unique structural and functional features that enable them to perform their vital roles. They are very thin and flat, which allows for efficient diffusion of substances between the blood and the surrounding tissue. They also have numerous tiny projections called microvilli, which increase their surface area and facilitate the exchange of substances. In addition, capillary endothelial cells are joined by tight junctions, which help to maintain the integrity of the blood vessel wall and prevent leakage.

In addition to their role in substance exchange, capillary endothelial cells have important functions in the regulation of blood flow and immune system function. They can control blood vessel diameter through the production of vasoactive substances such as nitric oxide and endothelin, which can cause the vessels to constrict or dilate as needed to meet the metabolic demands of the tissues. Capillary endothelial cells also play a key role in the recruitment of immune cells to sites of infection or injury, through the expression of various adhesion molecules and chemokines. Overall, capillary endothelial cells are a truly indispensable cell type that are essential for the proper functioning of virtually every organ and tissue in the body.
CL:0002181:
Mucous neck cells are specialized cells located within the neck region of the gastric gland in the stomach. These cells produce and secrete mucin, a glycoprotein that forms mucus when mixed with water. The mucus produced by these cells helps to protect the stomach lining from the harsh acidic environment of the stomach and aids in the lubrication of food as it passes through the digestive tract.

In addition to their role in producing and secreting mucus, mucous neck cells play an important role in regulating the pH of the stomach. These cells secrete bicarbonate ions, which neutralize the hydrochloric acid produced by parietal cells, helping to maintain the acidic environment required for proper digestion.

Mucous neck cells are also involved in the repair and regeneration of the stomach lining. These cells have the ability to differentiate into other cell types, such as surface mucous cells, when the lining of the stomach is damaged. This process, known as metaplasia, can help repair the damage and restore the integrity of the stomach lining. Overall, mucous neck cells play a critical role in protecting and maintaining the health of the stomach.
CL:0002170:
Keratinized cells of the oral mucosa are epithelial cells found in the mucous membranes lining the oral cavity, including the cheeks, lips, and tongue. These cells are characterized by their unique composition of keratin, a tough fibrous protein that provides protection against abrasion and mechanical damage. Keratinized cells are specialized for their role in providing a barrier against the external environment, and are involved in a variety of cellular functions within the mucosal layer.

The primary function of keratinized cells of the oral mucosa is to protect the underlying tissues from mechanical damage, as well as against chemical and microbial insults. Keratinized cells line the oral cavity and form a protective layer that helps to prevent abrasions, injuries, and infections.
