Cardiac endothelial cells are a specialized type of endothelial cell that makes up the inner lining of blood vessels in the heart. These cells play a crucial role in maintaining the structural integrity and function of the heart by providing nutrients, oxygen, and waste removal to surrounding cardiac tissue. They are responsible for regulating blood flow to the heart muscle, and are involved in the formation and maintenance of the intricate network of vessels that supply oxygen and nutrients throughout the myocardium.

In addition to their role in blood flow regulation and nutrient exchange, cardiac endothelial cells are also involved in the regulation of the heart's electrical activity. They produce and release factors that influence the cardiac conduction system, which controls the rate and rhythm of the heartbeat. Dysfunction of these cells has been linked to a variety of cardiovascular diseases, including ischemic heart disease, atherosclerosis, and hypertension. As such, a better understanding of the structure and function of cardiac endothelial cells has important implications for the prevention and treatment of these conditions.

Overall, cardiac endothelial cells are a critical component of the cardiovascular system, playing important roles in the regulation of blood flow, nutrient exchange, and electrical activity. Research into the biology of these cells holds great promise for the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of cardiovascular disease.
CL:0002338:
CD56-positive, CD161-positive immature natural killer (NK) cells are a subset of NK cells found in peripheral blood, lymph nodes, and tonsils. These cells are identified by the expression of CD56, CD161, and lack of CD3. Upon maturation, these cells will lose the expression of CD161 and become CD56bright NK cells. 

Immature NK cells are important in immune surveillance and play a major role in host defense against viral infections, tumor cells and intracellular pathogens. These cells are capable of recognizing and killing virus-infected cells and tumor cells without prior sensitization. Furthermore, they can rapidly produce cytokines, such as interferon-gamma (IFN-γ), to activate other immune cells and initiate an immune response. In addition to their cytotoxicity and cytokine secretion, immature NK cells also express a variety of activating and inhibitory receptors, such as NKG2D and killer cell immunoglobulin-like receptor (KIR), which help to regulate their activity and prevent autoimmunity. 

In conclusion, CD56-positive, CD161-positive immature NK cells are a critical component of the innate immune system, providing rapid responses to viral infections and tumors. Through their cytotoxicity and cytokine secretion capabilities, as well as their regulatory receptors, these cells are able to initiate, coordinate, and modulate immune responses to ensure effective clearance of pathogens and infected cells.
CL:0002324:
The myoepithelial cell of mammary gland, also known as the myoepithelial cell of breast, is a specialized type of epithelial cell that is found between the basement membrane and the luminal epithelial cells in breast tissue. These cells are characterized by their contractile properties, as they contain a significant amount of smooth muscle-like filaments and can actively contract and relax. Their role in mammary gland function is to help facilitate the ejection of milk from the glandular tissue during breastfeeding.

In addition to their contractile properties, myoepithelial cells also play a critical role in maintaining the structural integrity of the mammary gland. They provide a physical barrier between the luminal epithelial cells and the surrounding stroma, preventing the luminal cells from invading the surrounding tissue. Myoepithelial cells also secrete a variety of extracellular matrix proteins and other factors that help to regulate and maintain the surrounding stroma.

Finally, myoepithelial cells are also known to play a role in the development and progression of breast cancer. Changes in the properties of these cells have been linked to the development of some forms of breast cancer, and studies have suggested that myoepithelial cells may serve as a protective barrier against malignancy. Understanding the function and behavior of myoepithelial cells is therefore critical to our understanding of breast development and disease.
CL:0002365:
Medullary thymic epithelial cells (mTECs) are a unique type of epithelial cells located in the medulla of the thymus. These cells play a crucial role in the development of self-tolerance, which is the prevention of the immune system from attacking its own tissues. As a part of the thymic medullary microenvironment, mTECs express a wide range of self-antigens that are presented to developing T cells, leading to the elimination of self-reactive T cells through negative selection.

MTECs are responsible for the expression and presentation of self-antigens in the thymus. This process is important for the education and selection of T cells, which are cells critical for the development of adaptive immunity. Through the expression of self-antigens, mTECs influence the repertoire of mature T cells that emerge from the thymus, and contribute to the development of self-tolerance. Failure to express or present self-antigens by mTECs can lead to autoimmunity.

In addition to their important role in negative selection, mTECs are also involved in the positive selection of T cells, in which T cells with potential to recognize MHC antigens are selected. This process occurs in collaboration with thymic dendritic cells, leading to the development of immune cells that are capable of responding to foreign antigens. In addition, recent studies have shown that mTECs also have important immunoregulatory functions by producing cytokines and expressing co-stimulatory molecules that regulate the activity of immune cells.
CL:0002307:
Brush border cells of the proximal tubule are a specialized cell type located in the renal nephron. They form a continuous layer of interconnected cells along the luminal surface of the proximal convoluted tubule. This cell type is characterized by the presence of a brush border composed of densely packed microvilli that increase the surface area available for absorption and reabsorption. These cells play a critical role in regulating the reabsorption of solutes, electrolytes, and water from the filtrate that passes through the proximal tubule.

The brush border cells of the proximal tubule are responsible for reabsorbing approximately 70% of filtered sodium and water. They also play a key role in reabsorbing glucose, amino acids, and other nutrients that are filtered by the glomerulus. This cell type accomplishes this through the activities of various transporters and channels that are extremely efficient at moving ions and molecules from the filtrate across the epithelium and into the bloodstream. In addition, brush border cells of the proximal tubule also play a role in secreting organic compounds, including drugs, toxins, and metabolites, into the filtrate for excretion by the body.

Due to the important role played by brush border cells of the proximal tubule in the regulation of solute and water balance by the kidney, dysfunction of these cells can lead to a range of clinical disorders, including electrolyte and water imbalances, kidney stones, and impaired glucose metabolism. This cell type is also a key target in the development of drugs and therapies designed to treat these conditions. Overall, brush border cells of the proximal tubule represent an essential component of the renal nephron and are critical for maintaining body homeostasis.
CL:0002350:
Endocardial cells are specialized cells that form the innermost lining of the heart chambers and heart valves. These cells play an essential role in maintaining the structure and function of the heart. Endocardial cells are a type of endothelial cell that forms a thin layer of cells, which is critical for the regulation of heart development during embryonic growth.

During the embryonic stage, endocardial cells help in heart tissue formation through the secretion of growth factors and adhesion molecules. These molecules help in the migration of cells, as well as the formation of blood vessels, required for ventricle and atrium formation. In the adult heart, endocardial cells continue to play critical roles in heart function, including the formation of a barrier that separates blood flow in the atria and ventricles, and the maintenance of a continuous layer of cells to prevent heart damage.

A malfunction in endocardial cells can result in various heart conditions such as rheumatic fever and infective endocarditis. Rheumatic fever occurs when the body's immune system attacks the endocardial cells, leading to inflammation, while infective endocarditis occurs when harmful bacteria enter the bloodstream and infect the endocardial cells. Hence, understanding the function of endocardial cells is crucial for the diagnosis and treatment of heart diseases.
CL:0002299:
Type-2 epithelial cell of thymus, also known as TEC2, is a specialized cell type found in the thymus gland. TEC2 cells are a subset of thymic epithelial cells and are responsible for the negative selection of T cells, a process that eliminates T cells with high affinity for self-antigens. This allows for the generation of a diverse and functional T cell repertoire, which is crucial for proper immune function.

TEC2 cells are characterized by their unique morphology and gene expression profile. They have a branched structure with numerous cytoplasmic processes that form a network throughout the thymus, allowing for efficient interactions with developing T cells. TEC2 cells also express a range of antigens that are involved in mediating interactions with T cells, including MHC class I and II molecules, and various co-stimulatory molecules such as CD80 and CD86.

In addition to their role in negative selection of T cells, TEC2 cells also play a crucial role in establishing and maintaining thymic microenvironmental niches that support T cell development. They secrete cytokines and other signaling molecules that regulate thymocyte development and differentiation, and they also provide physical support and guidance for migrating thymocytes.

Overall, TEC2 cells are a critically important cell type within the thymic epithelial cell compartment, with functions that are essential for the generation of a functional and diverse T cell repertoire. Their unique morphology and gene expression profile make them a fascinating subject for further research into the molecular mechanisms underlying thymocyte selection and development.
CL:0009116:
Progenitor cells of mammary luminal epithelium are a type of stem cell that play a crucial role in the development and maintenance of the mammary gland. These cells are responsible for generating the luminal epithelial cells, which are one of the two main cell types in the gland that produce milk. Unlike other mammary gland cells, mammary luminal epithelial progenitor cells are capable of self-renewal and differentiation into multiple cell types, making them a critical component of mammary gland biology.

Mammary luminal epithelial progenitor cells typically reside in the basal layer of the mammary gland ductal epithelium and are characterized by the expression of specific molecular markers such as keratins 5 and 14. These cells give rise to the luminal epithelial cells that line the mammary gland ducts, which are responsible for producing milk. During lactation, mammary luminal epithelial progenitor cells differentiate into mature luminal cells, which are the primary milk-secreting cells in the mammary gland.

Aberrant development or function of mammary luminal epithelial progenitor cells can lead to the development of breast cancer or other diseases of the mammary gland. Therefore, understanding the molecular mechanisms controlling the proliferation, differentiation, and self-renewal of these cells is critical for both physiological and pathological contexts. Further research into mammary luminal epithelial progenitor cells could have important implications for the development of new therapies for breast cancer and other diseases affecting the mammary gland.
CL:0002347:
CD27-high, CD11b-high natural killer cells (NK cells) are a subset of the innate immune system that plays a crucial role in host defense against tumors and pathogens. In mice, they are primarily found in the liver and bone marrow and are distinguished from other NK cells by their high expression of CD27, a member of the tumor necrosis factor receptor superfamily, and CD11b, an integrin receptor that facilitates cell adhesion.

These CD27-high, CD11b-high NK cells are characterized by their effector functions, which enable them to rapidly eliminate target cells by releasing cytotoxic granules and secreting cytokines. In particular, they are highly effective at killing tumor cells and infected cells, making them an important component of the immune system's surveillance against cancer and viral infections.

Interestingly, CD27-high, CD11b-high NK cells exhibit a phenotypic and functional resemblance to memory T cells, which suggests that they may play a role in immunological memory. They also display a degree of diversity in their antigen specificity and receptor repertoire, which allows them to respond to a wide range of threats. Taken together, these features make CD27-high, CD11b-high NK cells a valuable component of the immune system's arsenal against disease and a promising target for therapeutic interventions.
CL:0002296:
Type-4 epithelial cells of the thymus, also known as cortical thymic epithelial cells (cTECs), are critical components of the thymic microenvironment, providing a unique niche for the differentiation, positive selection and maturation of developing T-cells. cTECs are so-named because they are found mainly in the cortex region of the thymus. These cells play a crucial role in the selection of thymocytes, serving as the major presenter of self-peptides in the process of positive selection. Positive selection refers to the process by which T-cells with the ability to recognize self-peptides with appropriate specificity are selected to mature. 

cTECs also play a crucial role in negative selection, ensuring that the immune system does not attack healthy tissues in the body by eliminating self-reactive lymphocytes. Negative selection is mediated by the presentation of organ-specific antigens by cTECs to developing thymocytes. Therefore, abnormalities in the development or function of cTECs can lead to autoimmune diseases and immunodeficiencies. cTECs have also been found to regulate the expression of chemokines that guide thymocyte migration, as well as the expression of cytokines involved in thymocyte survival and differentiation. 

Additionally, cTECs have been found to be involved in the maintenance of the thymic architecture by producing extracellular matrix molecules and growth factors essential to sustain the structural integrity of the thymus. The loss of cTECs results in thymic atrophy, a significant hallmark of aging and immunodeficiency, which reduces the pool of immature T-cells available to populate the peripheral lymphoid organs, leading to compromised immune function. In summary, Type-4 epithelial cells of the thymus play a vital role in the development and selection of T-cells, in the maintenance of immune homeostasis, and in the maintenance of thymic structure and function.
CL:0002417:
Primitive erythroid lineage cells are a type of red blood cell that develop in the early stages of embryonic development in mammals. They are distinct from definitive erythroid cells, which are the mature red blood cells found in adults. Primitive erythroid cells are larger and nucleated compared to definitive erythroid cells. They also express different sets of genes and rely on different signaling pathways for their development.

The main function of primitive erythroid lineage cells is to transport oxygen from the mother's blood to the developing embryo. They do this by synthesizing hemoglobin, a protein that binds to oxygen and allows it to be transported throughout the body. Primitive erythroid cells are important for ensuring the proper growth and development of the embryo, as well as providing the necessary oxygen for its survival.

In addition to their role in oxygen transport, primitive erythroid cells also play a role in regulating the immune system during embryonic development. They have been shown to express several immune-related genes and cytokines, suggesting that they may help to modulate the development of other immune cells in the embryo. Overall, primitive erythroid lineage cells play a crucial role in embryonic development and in ensuring the proper growth and survival of the developing organism.
CL:0002294:
Type-1 epithelial cells of the thymus, also known as cortical thymic epithelial cells (cTECs), play a critical role in the development of T-cells. These cells form the structural framework of the cortex and are responsible for the positive selection of immature thymocytes that will go on to mature into T-cells. Through this process, cTECs contribute to the overall immune response and maintenance of peripheral tolerance.

Cortical thymic epithelial cells express an array of surface proteins that allow for the interaction with immature thymocytes in a process known as thymic education. This interaction enables cTECs to present self-peptides to developing T-cells, which are then positively selected based on their ability to recognize these peptides within the context of self-MHC molecules. Additionally, cTECs play an essential role in the negative selection of autoreactive T-cells, thus preventing autoimmunity.

In addition to their critical function in T-cell development, studies have shown that cortical thymic epithelial cells also secrete cytokines and chemokines that are involved in the recruitment, development, and differentiation of various immune cells, including dendritic cells and B-cells. Thus, cTECs contribute to the complex network of immune cells and their interactions within the thymus and ultimately throughout the entire body.
CL:1000349:
Basal cells of the epithelium of the bronchus are a type of progenitor cell found in the airway epithelium. These cells are located at the basal lamina of the surface epithelium and play a significant role in the regeneration and repair of the bronchial epithelium. Basal cells are critical to the maintenance of the respiratory tract lining, which provides a barrier against harmful particulates, pathogens, and allergens.

Basal cells are multipotent stem cells that can differentiate into many types of epithelial cells, including ciliated cells, secretory cells, and mucous cells. When the respiratory epithelium is damaged, these cells proliferate, migrate to the site of injury, and differentiate to replace the damaged cells. The ability of basal cells to self-renew and differentiate makes them an essential element of lung homeostasis. Basal cells are also involved in maintaining the proper balance between mucus production and periciliary fluid turnover, which is vital for the clearance of inhaled particles and microbes.

Basal cells of the bronchial epithelium have also been implicated in the development of lung cancer. Several studies have demonstrated that changes in the basal cell population may contribute to the initiation and progression of lung tumors. For example, recent research has shown that basal cells can give rise to lung adenocarcinomas, which are the most common type of lung cancer. Thus, understanding the biology of basal cells and their interactions with other cells within the epithelium is essential for developing new diagnostic and therapeutic approaches for lung cancer.
CL:0002295:
Type-6 epithelial cells of thymus, also known as cortical thymic epithelial cells (cTECs), are a unique population of epithelial cells found in the thymus gland. The thymus is responsible for the maturation and selection of T-cells, a critical component of the immune system. Type-6 epithelial cells are specifically involved in the selection of positive and negative T-cell clones for survival or apoptosis, respectively. They do this by presenting a variety of self-antigens to developing T-cells, which helps the immune system distinguish between self and foreign invaders.

Type-6 epithelial cells are characterized by their expression of a number of molecules that are important for T-cell development and selection. They express class I and class II MHC molecules, as well as co-stimulatory molecules like CD40 and CD80/86, which are essential for T-cell activation. In addition, they produce cytokines like thymic stromal lymphopoietin (TSLP), which helps to regulate the development and maturation of T-cells. The proper regulation of T-cell development and selection is essential for the maintenance of a functional immune system and the prevention of autoimmune diseases.

Overall, type-6 epithelial cells of thymus play a crucial role in the selection and maturation of T-cells, which are critical for the proper functioning of the immune system. Their ability to present self-antigens to developing T-cells helps to ensure that only properly functioning T-cells are allowed into circulation, which helps to prevent autoimmune diseases. Their expression of critical signaling molecules and cytokines also helps to regulate the proper development and maturation of T-cells, which is essential for the maintenance of immunological homeostasis.
CL:0002311:
Mammotrophs are cells found in the pituitary gland, a small gland located at the base of the brain. They are also known as lactotrophs due to their role in producing and secreting prolactin, a hormone that stimulates milk production in the mammary glands. Mammotrophs are classified as endocrine cells because they release their products, including prolactin, directly into the bloodstream.

Prolactin secretion by mammotrophs is tightly regulated by a complex feedback system involving several other hormones and neural inputs. In females, prolactin is primarily responsible for stimulating milk production after childbirth, while in males, it plays a role in regulating reproductive function and immune response. Dysregulation of mammotrophs can lead to conditions such as hyperprolactinemia, which can cause infertility and other issues.

Research on mammotrophs continues to uncover new insights into their function and regulation, leading to potential targets for therapeutic interventions in conditions involving prolactin dysregulation. With their vital role in milk production and regulation of reproductive function, mammotrophs are an important cell type to study for both basic scientific understanding and clinical applications.
CL:0002298:
Type-5 epithelial cells of the thymus, also known as medullary thymic epithelial cells, play an essential role in the maturation and selection of T cells. These cells form a network that provides a space for developing T cells to mature and differentiate through interactions with self-peptides presented by major histocompatibility complex molecules. Type-5 epithelial cells also express a wide range of self-antigens, allowing for the negative selection of T cells with high-affinity receptors for these antigens. Additionally, these cells contribute to the maintenance of immune tolerance by promoting the development and activation of regulatory T cells.

Type-5 epithelial cells are unique among thymic epithelial cells due to their expression of the autoimmune regulator (AIRE) protein. AIRE is responsible for the expression of tissue-specific antigens in type-5 epithelial cells, allowing for the selection of T cells with receptors that recognize self-antigens in peripheral tissues. This process is critical for preventing autoimmune disease, as autoreactive T cells that escape negative selection in the thymus can cause damage to host tissues.

In addition to their role in T cell development and tolerance, type-5 epithelial cells also contribute to the maintenance of thymic architecture and the production of thymic hormones. These cells form distinct layers within the thymic medulla, providing structural support for the developing T cell population. Additionally, they secrete thymic stromal lymphopoietin (TSLP), a cytokine that plays a role in the differentiation and activation of dendritic cells and T cells. Overall, type-5 epithelial cells of the thymus are critical for the development and regulation of the immune system, ensuring that T cells are educated to recognize foreign antigens while avoiding self-reactivity.
CL:0002358:
A pyrenocyte is a specialized cell located in the fruiting bodies of certain fungi, including ascomycetes and basidiomycetes. These cells are responsible for producing and storing the spores that are essential to the reproductive cycle of these fungi. Pyrenocytes develop from specialized hyphae and are typically located deep within the fungal tissue. 

The function of the pyrenocyte is to produce and store the spores that are necessary for the survival and spread of the fungus. These spores are typically released into the environment when the fruiting body ruptures or opens, allowing the spores to be dispersed by wind, rain, or other means. Once they have been dispersed, the spores can germinate and give rise to new fungal colonies, ensuring the continued survival and success of the species. 

In addition to their role in reproduction, pyrenocytes may also play a role in the regulation of fungal growth and development. Some studies have suggested that these cells may secrete hormones or other signaling molecules that influence the behavior of neighboring cells, helping to coordinate the complex developmental processes that underlie fungal growth and differentiation.
CL:0002332:
Ciliated cells are specialized cells that are present in the bronchi, which are the large airways that lead to the lungs. These cells have small hair-like projections on their surface known as cilia, which move in coordinated fashion to help transport mucus and other substances out of the airways and towards the throat, where they can be either coughed or sneezed out. Ciliated cells not only play a crucial role in keeping the airways clear, but also serve as an important part of the immune system's defense against foreign particles and pathogens that may enter the respiratory tract.

Ciliated cells of the bronchus are therefore vital in maintaining healthy respiratory function. In diseases such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or cystic fibrosis, the cilia may be damaged or compromised, leading to an inability to clear secretions effectively and increased susceptibility to infections. In addition to their role in transporting mucus, ciliated cells also play a role in regulating airway tone through the release of vasoactive substances, and may be involved in sensory signaling that alerts the body to potential irritants or toxins in the environment.

Overall, the ciliated cells of the bronchus represent an important and specialized cell type that is critical for efficient respiratory function and host defense. The coordinated movements of the cilia on these cells are essential for transporting mucus and other substances out of the airways, and they may also play additional roles in regulating airway tone and alerting the body to potential threats. Understanding the structure and function of ciliated cells is therefore key to developing effective therapies for respiratory diseases and maintaining healthy lung function.
CL:0002366:
Myometrial cells are smooth muscle cells found in the myometrium, the muscular layer of the uterus. These cells play a crucial role in uterine contractions during labor and delivery as well as regulating blood flow during menstruation. Myometrial cells have a spindle-like shape and their contractile ability is regulated by the release of hormones such as oxytocin.

During pregnancy, myometrial cells remain relatively quiescent until the later stages when they are stimulated by hormones to contract. These contractions help to thin and open the cervix as well as push the fetus through the birth canal. The ability of myometrial cells to contract during labor is crucial for the successful delivery of the baby. In addition, myometrial cells also play a role in reducing blood loss during menstruation by contracting and closing off blood vessels in the endometrium.

In addition to their contractile function, myometrial cells are also involved in other physiological processes such as regulating the immune response in the uterus and maintaining pregnancy by preventing premature contractions. Understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying myometrial cell function is important for developing treatments for conditions such as preterm labor and uterine fibroids, which can be caused by abnormal myometrial cell activity.
CL:0002346:
Dx5-negative, NK1.1-positive immature natural killer cell (iNK cell) is a type of lymphocyte that plays a crucial role in the innate immune system. These cells operate during the early stages of an immune response. iNK cells are involved in the recognition and destruction of tumor cells and virus-infected cells, promoting an anti-tumor and antiviral response. iNK cells are defined by their expression of NK1.1 antigen and a lack of expression of the Dx5 antigen. Additionally, these cells have low levels of CD11b expression, which distinguishes them from mature NK cells.

iNK cells are characterized as immature cells due to their lack of CD27 and CD11b expression. These surface markers are usually expressed by mature NK cells. The iNK cell subset is important for the development and regulation of mature NK cells. They play an important role in supporting the proliferation of these cells during immune responses. iNK cells are primarily found in the bone marrow and mature in peripheral tissues such as the liver and spleen.

Overall, iNK cells have an important role in recognizing and killing cells that have been infected by viruses or transformed into cancerous cells. These cells are particularly important within the early stages of infection or tumor development. Understanding the mechanisms of iNK cells may lead to new treatments for cancers and viral infections.
CL:1001586:
Mammary gland glandular cells are specialized epithelial cells that make up the lobules and ducts of the mammary gland in female mammals. These cells play a critical role in the production, secretion, and storage of milk during lactation. The mammary gland is a unique organ that undergoes significant changes throughout life, primarily in response to hormonal cues, and mammary gland glandular cells are at the forefront of these dynamic changes. 

During lactation, mammary gland glandular cells synthesize and secrete milk components such as lactose, lipids, and proteins. The secretion of these components is tightly regulated by hormones such as prolactin and oxytocin, which stimulate mammary gland glandular cells to produce milk and eject it into the lactiferous ducts in response to suckling. Mammary gland glandular cells are highly polarized, with the basal surface of the cell facing the basement membrane and the apical surface facing the lumen of the ducts. The apical surface of mammary gland glandular cells is characterized by the presence of secretory vesicles, which fuse with the plasma membrane to release milk components into the ducts.

Beyond lactation, mammary gland glandular cells also play a critical role in the development and maintenance of the mammary gland. During puberty and pregnancy, these cells undergo significant proliferation and differentiation to prepare for lactation. Additionally, mammary gland glandular cells are involved in the formation of mammary tumors, with the majority of breast cancers arising from the uncontrolled growth of these cells. Understanding the biology of mammary gland glandular cells is therefore crucial for developing effective treatments for breast cancer as well as for promoting healthy lactation in breastfeeding mothers.
CL:0002362:
Granule cell precursors are a type of neural progenitor cell found in the cerebellum of the developing brain. These cells give rise to granule cells, which are the most abundant type of neuron in the cerebellum. Granule cell precursors undergo a complex and highly regulated process of proliferation, differentiation, and migration during development to generate the appropriate number and distribution of granule cells.

During proliferation, granule cell precursors divide rapidly and asymmetrically to generate a pool of daughter cells that will eventually differentiate into granule cells. This process is tightly regulated by various signaling pathways, including the Sonic Hedgehog pathway and the Notch pathway. As granule cell precursors differentiate, they begin to express specific genes and proteins that are characteristic of mature granule cells, such as the neurotransmitter glutamate and the calcium-binding protein calbindin.

Once differentiation is complete, granule cell precursors migrate along a specific path to their final destination in the cerebellar granule cell layer. This migration is also regulated by various signaling pathways and involves interactions with other cell types in the developing cerebellum. Once they have reached their final destination, granule cells continue to differentiate and mature, forming synapses with other neurons in the cerebellum and contributing to the fine-tuning of motor coordination and learning and memory.
CL:0002304:
Non-pigmented ciliary epithelial cells are found in the ciliary body of the eye. They are responsible for producing aqueous humor, a clear fluid that fills the anterior chamber of the eye and maintains intraocular pressure. The cells are column-shaped and are arranged in a single layer of about 2-3 cells. They have numerous cilia on their apical surface, which enhances the fluid secretion process.

These cells have an important role in the maintenance of the ocular environment. They perform a crucial role in regulating the pressure within the eye that is essential for maintaining vision. Aqueous humor is needed to provide nutrients and remove waste from avascular structures such as the cornea and lens and plays an essential role in maintaining the refractive properties of the eye. Non-pigmented ciliary epithelial cells continuously produce and secrete aqueous humor which moves through the pupil into the anterior chamber to maintain the pressure within the eye.

Alterations in the function or production of aqueous humor by non-pigmented ciliary epithelial cells can lead to various eye diseases such as glaucoma. With its vital role in the eye, research into the ciliary body, especially the non-pigmented ciliary epithelial cells, is critical for advancing our understanding of ocular pathologies and developing novel treatments for conditions affecting the eye.
CL:0002348:
CD27-low, CD11b-high natural killer cells are a type of immune cell that can recognize and kill cancerous or infected cells. In mice, these cells are mainly located in lymphoid tissues such as the spleen, liver, and bone marrow. They are characterized by their low expression of CD27, a protein involved in cell activation and differentiation, and high expression of CD11b, a protein that allows the cell to adhere to and interact with other cells.

The function of CD27-low, CD11b-high natural killer cells is to provide rapid and early immune responses against viral infections and tumors. These cells are part of the innate immune system and can recognize and kill abnormal cells without the need for prior exposure or recognition by other immune cells. CD27-low, CD11b-high natural killer cells do this by releasing cytotoxic granules that can induce apoptosis (programmed cell death) in target cells, as well as through the secretion of cytokines that can enhance the activity of other immune cells.

In addition to their role in immune surveillance and defense, CD27-low, CD11b-high natural killer cells also play a crucial role in regulating immune responses. These cells can produce both pro-inflammatory and anti-inflammatory cytokines, depending on the context and the nature of the stimulus. By doing so, CD27-low, CD11b-high natural killer cells can modulate the activity of other immune cells and regulate the balance between immune activation and tolerance. Overall, CD27-low, CD11b-high natural killer cells are an important component of the immune system, providing both innate and adaptive immunity against a variety of pathogens and abnormal cells.
CL:0002418:
The hemangioblast is a multipotent cell type that gives rise to both blood and endothelial cells during embryonic development. These cells are first observed forming within the embryonic mesoderm and are believed to be derived from the primitive streak. As they differentiate, hemangioblasts give rise to both blood cells, including erythrocytes, granulocytes, and platelets, as well as endothelial cells, which form the lining of blood vessels.

Although hemangioblasts are primarily observed during embryonic development, they have been found in adult bone marrow and peripheral blood in small quantities. Additionally, it has been suggested that the malignant growth of certain tumors may be driven by the presence of hemangioblast-like cells. Despite these observations, the precise role of hemangioblasts in adult tissues remains unclear.

Studying the basic biology of hemangioblasts has important implications both for understanding developmental processes and for the potential use of these cells in medical therapies. Recent studies have demonstrated the potential utility of hemangioblasts in the generation of blood and vascular cell types. Given their broad differentiation potential, it is possible that hemangioblasts could serve as a valuable resource in regenerative medicine, as well as providing insights into the mechanisms that underlie the generation of the diverse cell types found throughout the body.
CL:0002601:
Uterine smooth muscle cells, also known as myometrial cells, are the primary cell type responsible for the contractions of the uterus during labor and delivery. These cells are spindle-shaped with a centrally located nucleus and lack striations, which differentiates them from skeletal and cardiac muscle cells. The myometrium is composed of smooth muscle cells arranged in layers that provide the uterus with the ability to contract and relax in a coordinated manner.

During pregnancy, uterine smooth muscle cells remain quiescent with occasional contractions to help maintain the pregnancy and promote blood flow to the developing fetus. As term approaches, the myometrium becomes increasingly sensitive to hormonal and neural signals that prepare the uterus for labor. These signals induce the production of receptors for oxytocin, a hormone that stimulates uterine contractions. The frequency and strength of contractions increase during labor, primarily due to the activation of these receptors on uterine smooth muscle cells.

After delivery, uterine smooth muscle cells undergo a process called involution, where the uterus returns to its pre-pregnancy size and shape through a combination of contraction and tissue remodeling. Uterine smooth muscle cells play a critical role in the intricate process of pregnancy and childbirth, and an alteration in their function can lead to complications such as preterm labor or postpartum hemorrhage.
CL:0002363:
Keratocytes, also known as corneal fibroblasts, are specialized cells found in the cornea of the eye. The cornea is the clear, dome-shaped tissue that covers the iris and pupil and helps to focus light onto the retina. The keratocytes are responsible for maintenance of the structure and clarity of the cornea.

Keratocytes are sparsely distributed and are surrounded by an extracellular matrix that consists of collagen fibers and proteoglycans. These cells are responsible for the synthesis of collagen, which provides the cornea with its tensile strength. They also help to maintain the transparency of the cornea by regulating the water content and refractive index.

In addition to their structural role, keratocytes play an important role in the wound healing processes in the cornea. When the cornea is injured, the keratocytes become activated and change their shape to produce migrating cells that can repair the damaged tissue. Keratocytes can also differentiate into myofibroblasts, which contract to facilitate healing and repair of the cornea.

Overall, keratocytes are essential for maintaining the structure and function of the cornea and play an important role in wound healing and repair. Dysfunction or damage to these cells can lead to corneal diseases such as keratoconus and corneal scarring, which can result in vision impairment.
CL:0002378:
Immature Vgamma2-positive fetal thymocytes are a type of T cell located in the thymus gland. They are part of the initial stages of T cell development, and are characterized by the expression of Vgamma2, a type of T-cell receptor (TCR). Vgamma2-positive cells are rare in adult thymus, but constitute a major subset of fetal thymocytes.

During development in the thymus, immature Vgamma2-positive fetal thymocytes undergo a series of maturation stages before becoming fully functional T cells. These cells, together with other T-cell precursors, migrate to the thymus and undergo proliferation and differentiation until they reach a mature stage. Functionally, Vgamma2-positive T cells have been implicated in the immune response to viral and bacterial pathogens, as well as in tumor surveillance.

In addition to their role in immune response, Vgamma2-positive T cells have been implicated in the development of immunological tolerance. Specifically, these cells are thought to promote peripheral tolerance by suppressing the immune response to self-antigens. Understanding the biology of immature Vgamma2-positive fetal thymocytes has important implications for understanding the mechanisms underlying immune regulation and how it may be harnessed for therapeutic purposes.
CL:0002353:
Fetal liver hematopoietic progenitor cells are immature cells that have the ability to differentiate into various blood cell types. They are found in the fetal liver and serve as a crucial component in developing a functional hematopoietic system. Fetal liver hematopoietic progenitor cells display high self-renewal capacity and can differentiate into various blood cell lineages, including erythrocytes, granulocytes, lymphocytes, and platelets. 

These cells are essential for the formation of the hematopoietic system, which is responsible for the production of blood cells throughout an organism's lifespan. Fetal liver hematopoietic progenitor cells play a critical role in the formation of blood cells in the fetus, and their impairment can lead to various hematological disorders. Thus, the study of fetal liver hematopoietic progenitor cells and their differentiation pathways is crucial for understanding the development of normal and abnormal hematopoiesis.

In conclusion, fetal liver hematopoietic progenitor cells are a crucial component in the development of a functional hematopoietic system. These cells have the ability to self-renew and differentiate into various blood cell lineages, including erythrocytes, granulocytes, lymphocytes, and platelets. The study of fetal liver hematopoietic progenitor cells is essential for understanding the physiology of normal and abnormal hematopoiesis, which can help in the development of therapies for various hematological disorders.
CL:0002354:
Yolk sac hematopoietic stem cells are a subpopulation of multipotent stem cells located in the yolk sac embryo during the early stages of development. These cells play an essential role in the formation of blood cells and contribute to the development of the embryo's hematopoietic system. They are characterized by their potential to differentiate into all types of blood cells, including red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.

Yolk sac hematopoietic stem cells are the first hematopoietic stem cell population to emerge during embryonic development. They represent a critical stage in the development of the hematopoietic system, as they are responsible for generating the first wave of blood cells, which subsequently repopulate the developing embryo. As the embryo grows and develops, hematopoietic stem cells eventually migrate to the liver and bone marrow, where they continue to produce blood cells throughout life.

In summary, yolk sac hematopoietic stem cells are a vital population of cells critical to the formation and development of the hematopoietic system. They have the unique ability to differentiate into all types of blood cells and play a crucial role in embryonic development. Understanding the role of these cells in the embryonic development of the hematopoietic system is essential to developing effective therapies for numerous blood-related disorders.
CL:1000615:
Kidney cortex tubule cells are specialized epithelial cells found in the proximal and distal convoluted tubules of the renal cortex. These cells play a critical role in the reabsorption and secretion of solutes and maintaining the balance of fluids and electrolytes in the body. They are polarized cells with a distinct apical and basolateral membrane that helps in regulating the movement of molecules in and out of the cell. 

The main function of kidney cortex tubule cells is to reabsorb valuable substances such as glucose, amino acids, bicarbonate ions, and inorganic ions (sodium, chloride, and potassium) from the primary urine filtrate and prevent their loss in urine. Moreover, these cells also secrete waste substances, drugs, and foreign substances from the blood into the urine for their excretion. Kidney cortex tubule cells have a high metabolic rate and require a significant amount of energy to carry out their functions. Therefore, they are rich in mitochondria, peroxisomes, and endoplasmic reticulum, which produce energy and detoxify harmful substances.

In addition, kidney cortex tubule cells also play a crucial role in acid-base homeostasis, producing and excreting ammonium ions to regulate the pH of the blood. Their unique ability to produce and secrete erythropoietin hormone regulates the production of red blood cells by the bone marrow. Dysfunction of kidney cortex tubule cells can result in various disorders such as renal tubular acidosis, Fanconi syndrome, and Bartter syndrome, which affect the proper functioning of the kidneys, leading to electrolyte imbalances and metabolic acidosis. Overall, kidney cortex tubule cells are critical in maintaining the balance of fluids and electrolytes in the body and ensuring proper renal function.
CL:0002349:
CD27-high, CD11b-low natural killer (NK) cells are a distinct subset of mouse NK cells that play a crucial role in the immune system by promptly responding to foreign and abnormal cells in the body. These cells are important in the early stages of the immune response and are characterized by the expression of CD27, a co-stimulatory molecule that promotes cell survival and proliferation, and low levels of CD11b, a cell surface marker that is commonly expressed on other immune cells.

CD27-high, CD11b-low NK cells are known to exhibit enhanced cytotoxic activity against target cells and are capable of producing cytokines such as interferon-gamma (IFN-gamma) and tumor necrosis factor (TNF), which are important in activating other immune cells and promoting inflammation. These cells are particularly effective in controlling viral infections and have been shown to play a significant role in tumor immunosurveillance.

In addition to their cytotoxic functions, CD27-high, CD11b-low NK cells have also been shown to play a regulatory role in immune responses by promoting the differentiation of T cells into a specific subset that helps to dampen immune responses. This regulatory function is achieved through the secretion of certain cytokines that promote the differentiation of regulatory T cells.

Overall, CD27-high, CD11b-low NK cells are a unique subset of immune cells that play a critical role in the immune surveillance against foreign and abnormal cells in the body. Their key functions include the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines and the direct killing of target cells, as well as the modulation of immune responses through the promotion of regulatory T cell differentiation.
CL:0002364:
Cortical thymic epithelial cells (cTECs) are specialized cells found in the thymus gland. These cells play a critical role in the development and selection of T cells, which are a type of white blood cell important for immune function. cTECs are responsible for expressing a diverse array of self-antigens in the thymus, which allows developing T cells to undergo a process called thymic selection. During thymic selection, developing T cells are screened for their ability to recognize self-antigens but not attack healthy tissue. cTECs that fail to express self-antigens effectively can lead to autoimmunity, while cTECs that express too many self-antigens can result in a weakened immune system that is unable to fight off infections.

cTECs are a heterogeneous population of cells that can be further subdivided based on the expression of various markers. For example, a subpopulation of cTECs expresses high levels of MHCII, a protein that is essential for presenting antigens to T cells. These MHCII-expressing cTECs are particularly critical for the positive selection of T cells, a process that ensures that only T cells that can recognize and respond to self-antigens are allowed to mature. Another subpopulation of cTECs expresses a protein called Aire, which is responsible for inducing the expression of tissue-specific antigens in the thymus. These tissue-specific antigens help ensure that developing T cells are exposed to a diverse range of self-antigens and therefore have a better chance of recognizing and responding to pathogens.

In summary, cortical thymic epithelial cells are a critical component of the thymus gland and play a crucial role in the development and selection of T cells. These cells express a diverse range of self-antigens and are responsible for ensuring that developing T cells can recognize self-antigens without attacking healthy tissue. By regulating the expression of self-antigens and inducing the expression of tissue-specific antigens, cTECs are essential for ensuring that the immune system is well equipped to fight off a wide range of pathogens while avoiding autoimmunity.
CL:0002380:
Oospores are specialized cells formed during sexual reproduction in certain oomycetes, a group of heterokonts that includes water molds, downy mildews, and white rusts. Oospores are similar in some ways to spores, but they are formed under specific conditions and serve a different function. Oospores are produced when two sexual compatible strains of oomycetes come together and fuse. The resulting cell is the oospore. 

Oospores can play an important role as a means of dispersal for oomycetes. They are tough, resistant structures that can withstand harsh conditions and remain viable for extended periods. Oospores can be dispersed by wind, water, or other means, allowing oomycetes to spread to new habitats. In addition, oospores are able to overwinter in soil or other substrates, providing a way for oomycetes to survive unfavorable conditions and re-emerge when conditions are more favorable.

Oospores also serve as a means of producing genetic diversity in oomycetes. The fusion of two compatible strains during oospore formation allows for the combination of different genetic traits, resulting in offspring with new and potentially advantageous combinations of traits. This genetic diversity is important for the survival and success of the species, allowing them to adapt to changing environmental conditions and fend off predators or pathogens.
CL:0002373:
Growth hormone releasing hormone secreting cells (GHRH cells) are a type of endocrine cell found in the hypothalamus of the brain. These cells secrete growth hormone releasing hormone (GHRH), a peptide hormone that stimulates the release of growth hormone (GH) from the anterior pituitary gland. GHRH cells are part of a complex regulatory system that controls the levels of GH in the blood, which in turn plays an important role in regulating growth, metabolism, and other physiological processes. 

GHRH cells are typically found in the arcuate nucleus and the ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus. These cells are activated by various stimuli, including low blood glucose levels, stress, and physical activity. When activated, GHRH cells secrete GHRH into the portal circulation, where it travels to the anterior pituitary gland and stimulates the release of GH. This process is tightly regulated by a negative feedback system involving GH and other hormones that act on the hypothalamus and pituitary gland. 

GHRH cells are also involved in the regulation of other physiological processes, including sleep, feeding behavior, and mood. Studies have shown that disruptions in the function of GHRH cells can lead to growth disorders, metabolic disorders, and other health problems. Therefore, understanding the function of GHRH cells and their role in the regulation of the endocrine system is critical for the diagnosis and treatment of many diseases.
CL:0002388:
A multinucleate arthroconidium is a large cell that is formed from the fragmentation of the hyphae of fungi. This type of cell is characterized by having multiple nuclei, which are surrounded by cytoplasm. The arthroconidia are able to detach from the hyphae and spread through the environment, often through the release of spores.

The function of the multinucleate arthroconidium is primarily related to fungal reproduction. These cells are able to divide and generate more hyphae, which can help the fungus to grow and colonize new environments. Additionally, arthroconidia can be transported by air currents or other methods, allowing for the spread of the fungus to new habitats.

Although arthroconidia are primarily associated with their role in fungal reproduction, they may also play a role in the pathogenesis of some fungi. For example, arthroconidia produced by certain species of Aspergillus and Penicillium have been associated with respiratory illnesses in humans. In these cases, the arthroconidia may be inhaled and can cause allergic reactions or infections in susceptible individuals.
CL:0002382:
Multinucleate conidium is a specialized type of fungal cell that emerges from hyphae. These cells are characterized by having multiple nuclei that are enclosed within a single cell membrane. They are commonly produced by fungi during their asexual reproductive phase, where they serve as specialized spores. The nuclei within the conidium are genetically identical, and as such, the cell is able to give rise to multiple identical progeny upon germination. 

The primary function of the multinucleate conidium is to facilitate the dispersal of fungal spores to new colonization sites. When conditions are favorable, the conidium is released from the parent hyphae and can be spread over a wide area by wind, water, or other vectors. Once it has landed on a suitable substrate, the conidium germinates and begins to grow into a new hyphae, allowing it to colonize the area and continue to propagate. 

Multinucleate conidia also play an important role in the virulence of some pathogenic fungi. For example, certain types of fungal infections can be spread through the release of spores, which can then infect other hosts. In some cases, these spores can be highly resistant to environmental stresses, allowing them to persist and spread for long periods of time. By understanding the biology of the multinucleate conidium, researchers can gain insight into the mechanisms by which these fungal pathogens spread and cause disease.
CL:0002389:
An uninucleate arthroconidium is a type of fungal cell that is formed through fragmentation of a pre-existing hyphae or spores in certain fungi. This cell type is characterized by a single nucleus, a septum (cross-wall) that divides the cell into two compartments, and a thick and melanin-rich cell wall. These features make the uninucleate arthroconidium resilient and capable of surviving under harsh environmental conditions, such as desiccation and extreme temperatures.

The function of the uninucleate arthroconidium is primarily related to the dispersal, survival, and infection of fungi. As a result of its robust structure, this fungal cell type can be easily dispersed through the air, soil, water, or through other living organisms such as insects. Once in a suitable environment, uninucleate arthroconidia can germinate and give rise to new hyphae or spores, leading to the propagation of a fungal population. Additionally, uninucleate arthroconidia may also play a role in fungal pathogenesis by infecting plants or animals, causing diseases such as ringworm and athlete's foot.

In conclusion, the uninucleate arthroconidium is an important cell type in the life cycle of many fungi. Its unique features make it a versatile and resilient cell, capable of surviving and thriving in various environments and involved in functions such as dispersal, propagation, and pathogenesis.
CL:0002375:
Schwann cell precursors (SCPs) are a type of glial cell that play a critical role during development of the peripheral nervous system (PNS). SCPs differentiate into mature Schwann cells (SCs), which myelinate axons in the PNS, allowing for efficient conduction of nerve impulses. SCPs are identified by their expression of specific markers, including Sox10 and p75NTR, and their morphology - they are multipolar cells that ensheath axons prior to their myelination.

During development, SCPs arise from neural crest cells and migrate along the length of axons, where they establish a 1:1 relationship with individual axons. SCPs are then induced by axonal signals to undergo differentiation into immature SCs, which subsequently migrate back along the axon and begin to myelinate the axon. Molecular signaling between the axon and SCP is critical for the successful myelination of axons in the PNS, and disruptions in this signaling can result in neuropathies such as Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease.

In addition to playing a crucial role during PNS development, SCPs have been implicated in the regeneration of damaged nerves. Following injury to the PNS, SCPs are recruited to the site of injury, where they differentiate into repair Schwann cells. These cells can promote axon growth and provide a favorable environment for nerve regeneration. Thus, SCPs have important functions both during development and following nerve injury, highlighting their critical role in maintaining proper nervous system function.
CL:0002390:
Uninucleate Blastconidium is a type of non-motile, unicellular fungal spore that is responsible for the asexual reproduction of various fungi species. The term blastconidium is derived from the Latin “blastus” meaning sprout or bud, indicating that this spore type develops from budding-like mechanism on the parent cell. These spores develop as an extension of the parent cell, breaking off eventually as an independent, unicellular structure. 

The primary function of uninucleate blastconidia is to facilitate the rapid asexual propagation of fungi. These spores are formed in large numbers and can be dispersed by air, water or any other means of transportation. As the spore lands on a favorable substrate, it germinates giving rise to a new colony of fungi. Uninucleate blastconidia can remain dormant for long periods of time or under unfavorable conditions, waiting for the right conditions to initiate germination.

The formation of uninucleate blastconidia is crucial to the success and propagation of various fungal species. The ability to produce large numbers of identical spores also plays a crucial role in the pathogenesis of different fungal diseases in humans and plants. The capacity of uninucleate blastconidia to produce genetically identical spores that can quickly colonize a given substrate or host, demonstrates the significance of these spores in the life cycle of different fungi species.
CL:0002343:
Decidual natural killer (dNK) cells are a specialized subgroup of natural killer (NK) cells that exist in the decidua of pregnant women. They are a heterogeneous population of cells that play critical roles in maintaining pregnancy through multiple mechanisms, such as regulating trophoblast invasion, fetal growth, and angiogenesis. The dNK cells play immunomodulatory roles in trophoblast invasion and angiogenesis, which are crucial for the establishment of a successful pregnancy.

Unlike other NK cells, dNK cells have distinct phenotypic and functional features. They are characterized by high expression of CD56, low expression of CD16, and the absence of CD3. Moreover, dNK cells also produce unique cytokines like insulin-like growth factor-2, which exclusively promotes the invasion of trophoblast cells. During early gestation, dNK cells are the dominant immune cell population in the decidua, comprising 70% of the total population. Additionally, they interact with other immune cells, including T cells, macrophages, and dendritic cells, to establish a cytokine milieu in the decidua, which is important for maintaining pregnancy.

In conclusion, decidual natural killer cells are a crucial component of the fetal-maternal interface, that play a crucial role in maintaining pregnancy through regulation of trophoblast invasion, fetal growth and angiogenesis. They do so by interacting with other immune cells and secreting specific cytokines that promote proper placental development. Understanding the function of dNK cells is important for not only understanding fertility but also developing interventions in cases of infertility, pre-eclampsia and miscarriage.
CL:0002383:
The conidium of conidiophore head is a type of specialized fungal spore that is formed at the tip of a specialized structure called a conidiophore. This spore is specifically formed in fungi that produce asexual spores and is responsible for the dispersal of the fungus as well as the initiation of new infections. The conidiophore itself is a long, slender structure that grows out of the fungal mycelium and is usually located at the end of a stalk.

The conidium of conidiophore head is generally a small, oval-shaped structure with a smooth and usually colorless surface. It is often produced in large quantities, and because it is specifically adapted for dispersal, it is frequently carried by the wind to new locations where it can germinate and initiate new infections. Some fungi are able to produce different types of conidia depending on the environmental conditions, which allows them to adapt to changing conditions and maximize their survival.

Overall, the function of the conidium of conidiophore head is to allow the fungus to effectively disseminate and colonize new areas. This is important for the survival of the fungus, as it allows it to both spread and infect new hosts. Different species of fungi have evolved different strategies for producing and dispersing their conidia, as well as different types of conidia that are adapted to different environments and conditions. Understanding the biology and function of the conidium of conidiophore head is important for the development of effective antifungal treatments and the management of fungal infections.
CL:0002356:
Primitive reticulocytes are early-stage red blood cells characterized by the presence of a reticulum, or network of ribosomal RNA, in the cytoplasm. These cells are larger and more basophilic than mature erythrocytes and represent a transition stage between nucleated erythroblasts and enucleated erythrocytes. In mammals, primitive reticulocytes are released into the circulation by the bone marrow and undergo maturation to form mature erythrocytes. 

The primary function of red blood cells, including primitive reticulocytes, is to transport oxygen from the lungs to the tissues. This is accomplished through the binding of oxygen to hemoglobin, a protein found in high concentrations in erythrocytes. Primitive reticulocytes, like other red blood cells, lack many organelles and do not have a nucleus, allowing them to efficiently carry oxygen. In addition to their role in oxygen transport, reticulocytes have also been shown to play a role in modulating immune responses. 

In some pathological conditions, the number of reticulocytes in the circulation may increase. This can occur as a response to anemia, where the body produces more reticulocytes in an attempt to compensate for the reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood. In other cases, defects in erythropoiesis may lead to the release of immature reticulocytes into the circulation, which can be used as a diagnostic tool to evaluate the severity of hematological disorders. In summary, primitive reticulocytes play an important role in erythropoiesis and have key functions in oxygen transport and immune modulation.
CL:0002379:
Meningothelial cells are a type of mesothelial cell that line the outer surface of the meninges, which are the three membrane layers enclosing the brain, spinal cord, and optic nerves. These cells are polygonal in shape and have thin, elongated nuclei. They are primarily involved in providing mechanical support and assisting in the maintenance of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) that bathes the central nervous system. 

Meningothelial cells are responsible for the production and transportation of CSF into the subarachnoid space, which is a cavity filled with the clear, colorless fluid that surrounds the brain and spinal cord. This fluid acts as a cushion and provides support to the brain and prevents it from damage. The cells are thought to play an active role in the biochemistry of the CSF by secreting molecules and participating in the transport of ions and other molecules across the meningeal barrier. 

In addition to their main role in the production of CSF, meningothelial cells also have a role in the pathogenesis of primary and metastatic tumors of the meninges. They are the primary cell type comprising meningiomas, which are common brain tumors that arise from the meninges. These tumors are often benign, slow-growing, and are rarely malignant. Overall, meningothelial cells play a crucial role in the maintenance of the central nervous system and have implications in both normal and pathological conditions.
CL:0002395:
Gr1-high classical monocytes are a distinct subset of monocytes that play a crucial role in the immune system. These cells are characterized by their high expression of the surface marker Gr1, which distinguishes them from other subsets of monocytes. Gr1-high classical monocytes are primarily involved in the recognition and phagocytosis of foreign invaders, such as bacteria, viruses, and fungi, and are essential for initiating an immune response against these pathogens.

In addition to their role in infection control, Gr1-high classical monocytes also play a crucial role in tissue repair and wound healing. These cells can differentiate into various cell types, such as macrophages and dendritic cells, which are involved in tissue remodeling and regeneration. Furthermore, Gr1-high classical monocytes are also involved in the clearance of damaged cells and cellular debris, a process known as efferocytosis.

Despite their important roles in the immune system, Gr1-high classical monocytes have also been implicated in the pathogenesis of several diseases, including atherosclerosis, cancer, and autoimmune disorders. For example, these cells have been shown to contribute to the development of atherosclerotic plaques by promoting the accumulation of lipids in the arterial walls. Therefore, a better understanding of the biology of Gr1-high classical monocytes is essential in the development of effective therapies for these diseases.
CL:0002385:
Blastoconidium is a type of fungal cell that is characterized by its asexual reproduction process. These cells are produced by budding from the parent cell, resulting in the formation of a small outgrowth or bud. This bud then detaches from the parent cell to become an independent offspring cell. Blastoconidia play a vital role in the life cycle of fungi as they facilitate the spread and colonization of the organism in various environments.

Blastoconidia are particularly essential in the growth and reproduction of yeasts, a type of fungus that plays a crucial role in food and beverage production as well as biomedical research. Yeast blastoconidia are often used in laboratory experiments to study cell growth, differentiation, and metabolism. Beyond the lab, yeast blastoconidia facilitate the production of fermented foods, including bread, beer, and wine. They also serve as a model organism for research into genetic disorders and developmental biology.

In addition to yeast, blastoconidia are found in other pathogenic and non-pathogenic fungi. In some instances, their effects can be harmful to human health, leading to a range of diseases such as candidiasis, a commonly occurring infection caused by the yeast Candida albicans. On the other hand, non-pathogenic fungi that produce blastoconidia play a critical role in the decomposition of organic matter, nutrient cycling, and soil ecosystem functioning. Overall, blastoconidia serve as essential components of fungal growth, diversity, and function in various ecosystems and human environments.
CL:0002402:
Peyer's patch B cells are specialized lymphocytes located in the Peyer's patches of the small intestine. These patches are collections of lymphoid tissues that are strategically located along the gut lining to detect and initiate immune responses against invading pathogens. Peyer's patch B cells play a crucial role in the humoral immune response where they produce and secrete antibodies in response to invading pathogens.

Peyer's patch B cells are activated when pathogen-derived antigens are presented to them by antigen-presenting cells. Upon activation, they differentiate into plasma cells, which can produce over a thousand antibodies per second. These antibodies are specifically designed to recognize and bind to the invading pathogen's antigens, facilitating its recognition and destruction by other immune cells. Apart from producing antibodies, Peyer's patch B cells also contribute to antigen presentation, activation of T cells, and production of cytokines that regulate various immune responses.

The function of Peyer's patch B cells is crucial for the maintenance of gut immune homeostasis and the prevention of pathogen overgrowth. Dysfunction or inadequate response by Peyer's patch B cells can lead to several gastrointestinal diseases such as inflammatory bowel disease, celiac disease, and other malabsorption syndromes. Understanding the distinct characteristics and functions of Peyer's patch B cells will help in the development of targeted therapeutic interventions against various gut-associated diseases.
CL:0002384:
An uninucleate macroconidium is a specialized cell type that is found in certain fungi. It is characterized by its large size and unique shape, which resembles a tube or a bubble. The macroconidium contains only one nucleus and is produced asexually by the fungus as a means of reproduction. Unlike some other fungal cell types, macroconidia are not involved in the production of spores and instead play a more specialized role.

The function of the uninucleate macroconidium is to serve as a means of dispersal for the fungus. When the macroconidium is mature, it is released from the parent fungus and can travel through the air or water to find a new location to grow. Once it has found a suitable environment, the macroconidium can germinate and begin to grow into a new fungus. This dispersal method allows the fungus to spread quickly and effectively, ensuring that it can survive and thrive in a variety of conditions.

In addition to their role in fungal reproduction and dispersal, uninucleate macroconidia can also be important in research and medical applications. Because of their unique structure and function, macroconidia have been used as a model system for studying fungal biology and genetics. They have also been investigated for their potential as a source of new drugs and therapies for a range of human diseases, including cancer and infectious diseases. Overall, the uninucleate macroconidium is a fascinating and important cell type that plays a vital role in the world of fungi and beyond.
CL:0002386:
Aspergillus fumigatus is a highly pathogenic fungus that poses a significant threat to immunocompromised patients. The fungus reproduces asexually by forming specialized structures called conidiophores, which produce spores known as conidia. Among the different types of conidia produced by A. fumigatus, the multinucleate macroconidia are the most abundant and important for virulence.

The multinucleate macroconidia are spheroid or elliptical in shape and measure between 20 and 60 microns in length. These structures are formed by the aggregation of eight uninucleate cells, each of which contains a single nucleus. Upon maturation, each cell undergoes a series of coordinated developmental processes that involves the deposition of different layers of cell wall materials, proteins, and lipids. The outermost layer of the macroconidium is hydrophobic and has a rough, textured surface that facilitates airborne dispersion.

The function of the multinucleate macroconidia in A. fumigatus is to disseminate the fungus in the environment and infect host tissues. The macroconidia are dispersed by airflow and can travel long distances before settling down on surfaces or being inhaled by humans or animals. Once inside the host, the macroconidia germinate and give rise to hyphae that invade and colonize the lung tissue. The macroconidia also play a crucial role in the evasion of host immune defenses by inhibiting phagocytosis and inducing immunosuppression.
CL:0002410:
Pancreatic stellate cells, also known as PSCs, are specialized cells found in the pancreas. They are responsible for maintaining the structure of the pancreas and regulating the production of enzymes and other substances that aid in digestion. In addition, PSCs are involved in the repair and regeneration of damaged tissue.

PSCs are activated in response to injury or inflammation in the pancreas. When activated, they secrete various growth factors and cytokines that promote the proliferation and migration of other cells in the pancreas. PSCs also produce extracellular matrix proteins, which help to maintain the structural integrity of the pancreas and facilitate tissue repair.

However, in chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic cancer, PSCs can become overactive and produce excessive amounts of extracellular matrix proteins, leading to fibrosis and the formation of a stiff, scar-like tissue. This can hinder the normal functioning of the pancreas and contribute to the development of various pancreatic diseases. Therefore, understanding the function of PSCs is crucial for the development of effective therapies for pancreatic diseases.
CL:0002357:
Fetal derived definitive erythrocytes are specialized cells that play a crucial role in the development of the fetus. These cells are derived from the fetal liver, and are responsible for transport of oxygen to the developing tissues. Fetal erythrocytes differ from adult erythrocytes in several ways, including increased oxygen carrying capacity and decreased susceptibility to oxidative stress. These characteristics allow the developing fetus to efficiently acquire the oxygen necessary for growth and development.

Fetal derived definitive erythrocytes are characterized by their unique morphology, function, and surface markers. These cells are typically smaller and more nucleated than adult erythrocytes, and express markers such as CD71 and CD235a. Fetal erythrocytes are also able to produce higher levels of fetal hemoglobin, which has a higher affinity for oxygen than adult hemoglobin. This allows the fetus to effectively extract oxygen from the maternal bloodstream.

In addition to their role in oxygen transport, fetal derived definitive erythrocytes have been implicated in several important physiological processes. These cells may play a role in regulating fetal immune function, as studies have shown that fetal erythrocytes are capable of presenting antigens to developing immune cells. Fetal erythrocytes have also been shown to participate in the process of angiogenesis, which is the growth of new blood vessels. Overall, fetal derived definitive erythrocytes are a critical component of fetal development, and continue to be studied in order to better understand their function and potential therapeutic applications.
CL:0002405:
Gamma-delta thymocytes are a subset of T lymphocytes that express the gamma-delta T-cell receptor (TCR) on their surface. They are produced in the thymus and represent a small fraction of the T cell population in peripheral blood. Although their function is not completely understood, it is known that they play important roles in immune system development, surveillance, and response.

Gamma-delta thymocytes are thought to be involved in the recognition and elimination of certain types of pathogens, including bacteria, viruses, and parasites. This is due to their ability to respond rapidly to antigens and their capacity to produce a variety of cytokines upon activation. Moreover, recent studies have shown that gamma-delta thymocytes have cellular memory capabilities, which allow them to mount more effective responses upon re-infection with the same pathogen.

In addition to their involvement in host defense, gamma-delta thymocytes are also thought to play a role in tissue repair and regeneration. Studies have shown that these cells migrate to sites of injury and inflammation, where they can participate in tissue remodeling, angiogenesis, and wound healing. This suggests that gamma-delta thymocytes have broader functions beyond traditional immune system activity and may be important targets for therapies aimed at stimulating tissue repair and regeneration.
CL:0002367:
Trabecular meshwork cells are a key component of the trabecular meshwork, a specialized tissue in the eye that plays a critical role in regulating intraocular pressure. These cells are located at the junction between the iris and cornea and are involved in the drainage of aqueous humor from the eye. Through a complex network of pores and channels, trabecular meshwork cells help to maintain a balance between the production and outflow of this fluid, which is important for maintaining healthy vision.

In addition to their role in regulating intraocular pressure, trabecular meshwork cells also play a key role in the development and progression of ocular diseases such as glaucoma. Changes in the function or structure of these cells can disrupt the delicate balance of aqueous humor dynamics and lead to increased pressure within the eye. This, in turn, can cause damage to the optic nerve and eventually lead to vision loss.
