Understanding the biology of trabecular meshwork cells is therefore critical for the development of new treatments for ocular diseases.

Research in recent years has revealed a growing number of factors that are involved in regulating the function and behavior of trabecular meshwork cells. These include growth factors, cytokines, and other signaling molecules that are produced both within the eye and in other tissues throughout the body. By understanding the complex interplay between these factors and the biology of trabecular meshwork cells, researchers hope to develop novel therapies that can target specific pathways involved in regulating intraocular pressure and prevent vision loss in patients with ocular diseases.
CL:0002370:
Respiratory goblet cells are columnar epithelial cells that secrete mucus in the respiratory tract of humans and other animals. These specialized cells are responsible for maintaining the moisture and integrity of the respiratory system towards continuous exposure to various environmental pollutants. The respiratory goblet cells are simple in structure, with a narrow apical surface and a broad basal surface. The apical surface is covered with microvilli that create a large surface area for the secretion of mucin.

The primary function of respiratory goblet cells is to secrete mucus that helps to trap foreign particles such as dust, bacteria, and viruses, preventing them from reaching the lungs. The mucus is a thick fluid consisting of water, glycoproteins, lipids, and salts, and it acts as a lubricant, preventing the respiratory epithelial surfaces from drying out. The respiratory goblet cells also play a crucial role in innate immunity by synthesizing and secreting mucin that contains important antimicrobial peptides like lysozyme and lactoferrin. These peptides help to defend the respiratory system against bacterial and viral infections.

Diseases such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, asthma, and cystic fibrosis display abnormal mucus secretion that is associated with enhanced goblet cell activity. While goblet cells are critical in maintaining the respiratory system's health, overproduction of mucus can lead to severe respiratory distress. An In-depth understanding of the respiratory goblet cell functions is vital for developing effective therapeutic interventions for various respiratory diseases.
CL:0002359:
A placental hematopoietic stem cell (pHSC) is a type of stem cell that is found specifically within the placenta of a developing mammalian fetus. pHSCs are a rare and highly specialized type of stem cell which have the ability to differentiate into all the different types of blood cells found in the body, including red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. As such, pHSCs play a critical role in the development of the fetal circulatory system, and are also important for maintaining healthy blood production throughout the life of an individual.

One of the unique properties of pHSCs is their ability to self-renew, meaning that they are capable of dividing and producing more stem cells that can differentiate into all the different types of blood cells. This self-renewal capacity is critical for ensuring that there are always enough pHSCs available to produce blood cells throughout the lifespan. pHSCs are also capable of responding to signals from the body to differentiate into different types of blood cells, depending on the specific needs at any given time. For example, in response to injury or infection, pHSCs can produce more white blood cells to help fight off the infection, while in response to chronic blood loss, pHSCs can produce more red blood cells to maintain adequate oxygen delivery to tissues.

Overall, the discovery of pHSCs has been a significant advance in our understanding of stem cells and the development of the circulatory system. These cells have the potential to be used in a wide range of therapeutic applications, including the treatment of blood disorders such as leukemia, anemia, and immune deficiencies. As research continues to uncover the secrets of pHSCs and their properties, we can expect to gain even more insight into the role of these important stem cells in human health and disease.
CL:0002403:
Mature Vgamma2-positive fetal thymocytes are a subpopulation of T cells that develop in the fetal thymus. These cells are characterized by the expression of Vgamma2 T cell receptors (TCRs) which are thought to play a crucial role in the recognition and response to various antigens. Vgamma2 TCRs are predominantly expressed on T cells of the gamma-delta lineage, which represent a small subset of T cells in the body.

During fetal development, thymocytes undergo positive and negative selection processes that are essential for the development of a functional and self-tolerant immune system. Vgamma2-positive fetal thymocytes are involved in this process and play a critical role in the selection of gamma-delta T cells. They are known for their ability to efficiently recognize and respond to microbial antigens, which suggests their role in early immune defense. However, the exact role of Vgamma2 TCRs in fetal T cell development and function is still not fully understood.

Overall, mature Vgamma2-positive fetal thymocytes play a critical role in the development of the fetal immune system. Their unique expression of Vgamma2 TCRs allows them to recognize a broad range of antigens, which is believed to be important for early immune defense. Further research is needed to fully understand the function of Vgamma2 TCRs and the role of mature Vgamma2-positive fetal thymocytes in the development and function of the immune system.
CL:0002352:
Gestational hematopoietic stem cell (GHSC) is a rare but important cell type that is involved in the growth and development of the fetal hematopoietic system during pregnancy. These cells are generated in the yolk sac and fetal liver, and they are capable of self-renewal and differentiation into the various blood cell types, including red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. GHSCs are able to migrate from the fetal liver to the fetal spleen and bone marrow, where they continue to proliferate and differentiate.

During gestation, GHSCs play a critical role in supporting the expanding blood volume of the fetus, as well as in the development of the immune system. GHSCs are also involved in the formation of the lymphatic system, which is important for the regulation of fluid balance and the transport of immune cells throughout the body. GHSCs have been the subject of extensive research in recent years due to their potential use in regenerative medicine, including the treatment of blood-related disorders such as leukemia and anemia.

Despite their promise as a therapeutic target, GHSCs remain poorly understood. Further research is needed to better understand the mechanisms that regulate the self-renewal and differentiation of these cells, as well as their potential utility in cell-based therapies. Ultimately, a better understanding of GHSC biology could lead to new treatments for a range of hematological disorders and other conditions.
CL:0009014:
Peyer's patch lymphocytes are a type of immune cell found predominantly in the gut-associated lymphoid tissue (GALT). These lymphocytes are primarily involved in the surveillance and defense against invading pathogens that may enter the gut via the oral route. The Peyer's patch lymphocytes are an important component of the adaptive immune system and are essential for the induction of a robust immune response against pathogens.

In the small intestine, Peyer's patches are organized into structures that contain a wide variety of immune cells, including T and B lymphocytes, macrophages, dendritic cells, and stromal cells. The lymphoid tissue is strategically located near the epithelium lining the gut, allowing for the quick recognition and targeting of pathogens that may breach the mucosal barrier. Upon encountering pathogens, Peyer's patch lymphocytes undergo activation and proliferation, leading to the production of effector cells, such as cytotoxic CD8+ T cells, that can directly eliminate infected cells. Additionally, Peyer's patch lymphocytes can produce and secrete cytokines that help recruit other immune cells to the site of infection.

Defects in Peyer's patch lymphocyte function can lead to increased susceptibility to gut infections and inflammatory disorders such as inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and celiac disease. Peyer's patch lymphocytes are also thought to play a role in food tolerance, as their activation and differentiation can impact the balance between intestinal immunity and tolerance to food antigens. Overall, understanding the biology of Peyer's patch lymphocytes is critical for developing new therapies and interventions to prevent and treat gut infections and inflammatory diseases.
CL:0002409:
Mature Vgamma2-negative thymocytes are a type of T cells that develop in the thymus gland and play a critical role in the immune response. These cells are characterized by the absence of the Vgamma2 chain, which is a component of the T cell receptor (TCR). Instead, they express other TCR chains, such as Vgamma1, Vdelta1, or Vdelta3, which allow them to recognize a diverse range of antigens.

The main function of mature Vgamma2-negative thymocytes is to differentiate into different subsets of T cells, including CD4+ helper T cells, CD8+ cytotoxic T cells, and regulatory T cells. This differentiation process is tightly regulated by various molecular signals, such as cytokines and chemokines, which are produced by thymic stromal cells. Once matured, these T cells then migrate to peripheral lymphoid tissues, where they interact with antigen-presenting cells and mount immune responses against pathogens and other foreign substances.

It is worth mentioning that dysfunction of mature Vgamma2-negative thymocytes has been associated with various immunological disorders, including autoimmune diseases, immunodeficiencies, and malignancies. Therefore, understanding the development and function of these cells is of great interest to immunologists and has important implications for the diagnosis and treatment of these diseases.
CL:0002391:
A multinucleate blastoconidium is a type of cell that is formed through budding. Budding is a process of asexual reproduction seen in some organisms such as fungi. In the case of multinucleate blastoconidium, this cell type originates from the fungal hyphae, which is the branching filaments that constitute the main body (or thallus) of a fungal organism. The multinucleate blastoconidium is formed when a bud emerges from the hyphae and eventually separates from the parent cell. 

The function of multinucleate blastoconidium varies based on the type of fungus it is a part of. However, generally speaking, these cells play several roles. One of the main functions of the multinucleate blastoconidium is to serve as a reproductive or dispersal unit for the fungus. Once it has separated from the parent cell, the multinucleate blastoconidium can develop into a new individual or be dispersed to colonize new environments. Furthermore, some fungi have the ability to fuse multinucleate blastoconidia with other cells of the same or different species, leading to the formation of multinucleate structures referred to as hyphal anastomoses. These anastomoses can enable nutrient sharing, genetic exchange, and increase virulence in certain pathogenic fungi.

In conclusion, multinucleate blastoconidia is an important cell type as it serves as a critical unit of reproduction and dispersal in many fungal species. This cell type is formed through budding and can play various roles depending on the species of the fungus. Nonetheless, irrespective of the specific function, the multinucleate blastoconidium is essential for the survival, growth, and propagation of the fungal organisms.
CL:0002438:
NK1.1-positive natural killer (NK) cells are a type of lymphocyte found in the mouse immune system. These cells play a critical role in the innate immune response by recognizing and eliminating infected and cancerous cells. NK cells express the cell surface receptor NK1.1, which is used to identify them in laboratory experiments.

NK cells can identify abnormal cells in the body through a process called "missing self-recognition." This means that NK cells are able to detect cells that lack normal levels of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I molecules, which are present on the surface of most healthy cells. When an NK cell identifies a cell as abnormal, it can release cytotoxic molecules such as perforin and granzyme to destroy the target cell.

In addition to their cytotoxic function, NK cells also secrete cytokines such as interferon-gamma and tumor necrosis factor-alpha, which can activate other immune cells and promote inflammation. Overall, NK1.1-positive NK cells play an important role in the immune system's ability to protect against viral infections and tumors, and understanding their function may lead to the development of new therapies for these diseases.
CL:0002406:
Immature Vgamma2-positive thymocyte is a type of T-cell that undergoes development in the thymus, and expresses the specific antigen receptor, Vgamma2. These cells are part of the adaptive immune response, which is responsible for recognizing and eliminating foreign pathogens. The Vgamma2 gene is unique to a small subpopulation of T cells that can recognize specific molecules on pathogenic cells and thus are capable of destroying them. The function of immature Vgamma2-positive thymocytes is critical for the development of the immune system and the prevention of infections.

The development of immature Vgamma2-positive thymocytes occurs in the thymus, an organ located near the heart that plays an essential role in the development and maturation of T cells. As these cells mature, they undergo a complex process of selection and differentiation to ensure that the T cell antigen receptor developed is capable of recognizing antigens from foreign pathogens. Immature Vgamma2-positive thymocytes play a crucial role in this developmental process by expressing the Vgamma2 gene, which enables them to recognize specific pathogenic molecules and develop into mature T cells that can fight off infections.

In summary, Immature Vgamma2-positive thymocytes are a unique T-cell population that plays a critical role in the development of the immune system. Their expression of the Vgamma2 gene enables them to recognize specific pathogenic molecules, which is essential for the prevention and elimination of infections. The detailed understanding of these cells' function and development in the thymus is crucial to developing novel therapeutics and interventions for diseases caused by defects in immune function.
CL:0002415:
Immature Vgamma1.1-positive, Vdelta6.3-positive thymocytes are a type of T cell that is found in the thymus gland during early stages of development. These cells originate from hematopoietic stem cells and undergo a unique maturation process in the thymus that leads to the generation of a diverse repertoire of T cells.

As their name suggests, immature Vgamma1.1-positive, Vdelta6.3-positive thymocytes express both the Vgamma1.1 and Vdelta6.3 gene segments of the T cell receptor (TCR) complex. This characteristic enables their identification by flow cytometry. These cells play an important role in the development of the immune system. They are part of the innate immune system and do not require prior exposure to an antigen to become activated.

During development, immature Vgamma1.1-positive, Vdelta6.3-positive thymocytes undergo a process of positive and negative selection in the thymus. This involves the recognition of self-antigens presented by thymic epithelial cells. Upon successful completion of this process, mature T cells with diverse TCR repertoires are generated. These mature T cells then migrate to peripheral tissues where they play important roles in immune surveillance and immunological memory.
CL:0002305:
Epithelial cells of the distal tubule, also known as distal convoluted tubule (DCT) cells, are specialized cells found in the kidney nephrons. The DCT follows the loop of Henle and is responsible for regulating the concentration of ions and the pH of urine. These cells have a cuboidal shape and are polarized, with distinct apical and basolateral surfaces. The apical surface faces the tubule lumen and has microvilli that increase the surface area for reabsorption. The basolateral surface faces the interstitial fluid and contains transporters and channels that regulate ion transport.

One of the primary functions of epithelial cells of the distal tubule is the reabsorption of sodium ions (Na+) and the secretion of potassium ions (K+) into the tubule lumen. This process is regulated by the hormone aldosterone, which stimulates the expression of Na+/K+ ATPase pumps on the basolateral membrane and epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) on the apical membrane. This leads to the reabsorption of Na+ from the tubule lumen into the interstitial fluid and the secretion of K+ from the interstitial fluid into the tubule lumen. The DCT also plays a role in the acid-base balance of the body, regulating the secretion of hydrogen ions (H+) and the reabsorption of bicarbonate ions (HCO3-) into the urine.

In addition to their transport functions, DCT cells are also involved in the production of the hormone renin. Renin is released by specialized DCT cells called juxtaglomerular cells in response to low blood pressure or low sodium levels in the blood. Renin acts on angiotensinogen to produce angiotensin I, which is then converted to angiotensin II by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) in the lungs. Angiotensin II is a potent vasoconstrictor and stimulates the release of aldosterone, leading to increased sodium reabsorption and water retention by the kidneys. Overall, the epithelial cells of the distal tubule play a crucial role in maintaining the electrolyte and fluid balance of the body.
CL:0002444:
Ly49H-positive natural killer (NK) cells are a specialized subset of immune cells within the mouse immune system. These cells express the Ly49H receptor on their surface, which allows them to specifically target and eliminate cells infected with certain viruses, such as cytomegalovirus. 

Ly49H-positive NK cells are active in the early stages of immune responses and can rapidly detect and eliminate infected cells, preventing the virus from spreading throughout the body. They achieve this through the release of cytotoxic granules and the production of cytokines such as interferon-gamma, which both help to restrict viral replication and activate other immune cells. Ly49H-positive NK cells are particularly important in immune responses against viral infections, and their activity can help to limit the severity of infections and prevent disease.

Overall, the Ly49H-positive NK cell population plays an important role in orchestrating immune responses against viral infections in the mouse immune system. Their specific targeting of infected cells and ability to rapidly eliminate them are an essential component of the early immune response, highlighting the importance of these cells in the maintenance of immune system health and function.
CL:0002412:
Vgamma1.1-positive, Vdelta6.3-positive thymocytes are a subset of T lymphocytes that are primarily found in the thymus gland and are crucial for the development of the immune system. These thymocytes are characterized by the expression of cell surface receptors known as gamma-delta T cell receptors (TCRs) that are different from the alpha-beta TCRs present on most T cells.

The Vgamma1.1-positive, Vdelta6.3-positive thymocytes play a critical role in the initial stages of the immune response and are involved in both innate and adaptive immunity. They are particularly important in fighting off bacterial, fungal, and parasitic infections. In addition to their role in immunity, these T cells are also involved in tissue homeostasis and play a critical role in the maintenance of healthy tissues.

Overall, Vgamma1.1-positive, Vdelta6.3-positive thymocytes are a fascinating subset of T cells that play a critical role in the development and maintenance of the immune system. Their unique TCRs, coupled with their broad range of effector functions, make them an important target for both basic research and clinical applications. Continued research into the function and regulation of these cells has the potential to lead to novel therapies for a wide range of immune-related disorders.
CL:0002439:
NKGA2-positive natural killer cell, mouse, is a lymphocyte that belongs to the natural killer cell family. These cells play a vital role in the innate immune system and provide the first line of defense against viral infections and cancer. NKGA2-positive natural killer cells recognize and eliminate target cells that have reduced or lost MHC class I expression.

NKGA2-positive natural killer cells are characterized by the expression of NKGA2 protein on their surface. This protein is a type II transmembrane receptor, which binds to various ligands, including MHC class I molecules. The binding of NKGA2 to MHC class I molecules triggers the activation of NK cells and promotes their cytotoxic activity against diseased and infected cells. 

Studies have shown that NKGA2-positive natural killer cells can also produce various cytokines, such as IFN-γ, TNF-α, and GM-CSF, which improve the immune response against pathogens and contribute to the activation and differentiation of other immune cells. Overall, NKGA2-positive natural killer cells play a crucial role in the immune system by recognizing and eliminating abnormal cells and producing cytokines to enhance the immune response against pathogens.
CL:0002407:
Mature Vgamma2-positive thymocytes are a specialized type of T cell that develop in the thymus gland, a vital organ for the maturation of T cells. These cells are characterized by the presence of the Vgamma2 T-cell receptor (TCR) on their surface, a unique protein that recognizes and binds specific antigens. Vgamma2-positive thymocytes are known to play a crucial role in the adaptive immune response, protecting the body against a wide range of infectious agents.

The function of mature Vgamma2-positive thymocytes is primarily focused on the recognition and elimination of viral infection. These cells are capable of producing large amounts of cytokine, which are immune-signaling molecules that help to coordinate the adaptive immune response. When the Vgamma2 TCR binds with an antigen presented by an infected cell, it stimulates the proliferation and differentiation of the thymocytes into effector T cells, which can then eliminate the infected cells. Mature Vgamma2-positive thymocytes are also thought to have a role in tumor immunity, helping to identify and eliminate cancer cells.

Overall, the function of mature Vgamma2-positive thymocytes is critical to the proper functioning of the immune system. These cells are instrumental in recognizing and eliminating viral infections and cancerous cells, making them essential for maintaining the health of the body. Understanding the role of these cells can provide valuable insight into the development of new treatments for diseases that affect the immune system.
CL:0002396:
CD14-low, CD16-positive monocytes, also known as non-classical monocytes, play an essential role in the innate immune system. These cells are a unique subset of monocytes found in peripheral blood and lymphoid organs that can differentiate into dendritic cells or macrophages. They are characterized by their low expression of the CD14 receptor and high expression of the CD16 receptor. CD14-low, CD16-positive monocytes are essential in the surveillance and defense against pathogens and are involved in antigen presentation during immune responses.

The primary function of CD14-low, CD16-positive monocytes is their ability to migrate to tissues, recognize, and phagocytose pathogens or foreign substances. CD14-low, CD16-positive monocytes are known for their strong capacity to engulf bacteria and play an important role in the resolution of infections. Additionally, CD14-low, CD16-positive monocytes exhibit high expression of co-stimulatory molecules and major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules, enabling them to effectively present antigens to T cells, further activating the adaptive immune response.

CD14-low, CD16-positive monocytes also play a role in inflammatory diseases. Studies have shown that in chronic inflammatory disorders, such as rheumatoid arthritis and multiple sclerosis, there is an increased percentage of CD14-low, CD16-positive monocytes circulating in the blood and tissues. These cells have the potential to generate a pro-inflammatory response by producing cytokines and chemokines, leading to the recruitment and activation of other immune cells, such as neutrophils and T cells. 

In summary, CD14-low, CD16-positive monocytes are a unique subset of monocytes with essential roles in innate immunity, including antigen presentation and phagocytosis. They also play a role in both resolving infections and contributing to inflammatory responses in chronic disease states.
CL:0002426:
CD11b-positive, CD27-positive natural killer cells are a subpopulation of mouse natural killer cells that express both CD11b and CD27 cell surface markers. These cells have been shown to play a crucial role in the innate immune response, specifically in the defense against viral infections and tumors. 

Researchers have found that CD11b-positive, CD27-positive natural killer cells can directly kill virus-infected cells and tumor cells through the secretion of cytolytic granules that contain perforin and granzymes. Additionally, these cells can produce cytokines such as interferon-gamma and tumor necrosis factor-alpha, which can activate and recruit other immune cells to the site of infection or tumor. 

CD11b-positive, CD27-positive natural killer cells have also been found to have immunoregulatory functions. Studies have shown that these cells can suppress autoimmune responses in mouse models of autoimmune diseases such as multiple sclerosis and type 1 diabetes. This suggests that targeting these cells could be a potential therapeutic strategy for treating these diseases. Overall, CD11b-positive, CD27-positive natural killer cells play a critical role in immune surveillance and regulation, making them an important focus of immunological research.
CL:0002448:
Ly49H-negative natural killer (NK) cells are a subset of immune cells found in mice that are capable of destroying abnormal and infected cells. Unlike other NK cells, Ly49H-negative NK cells lack the Ly49H receptor found on the surface of the Ly49H-positive NK cells. Instead, these cells express various inhibitory and activating receptors, which enable them to identify and eliminate target cells through a variety of mechanisms.

Ly49H-negative NK cells play a critical role in the innate immune response, providing a rapid defense against infections and cancer. These cells produce a large arsenal of cytokines and chemokines, including interferon-gamma (IFN-γ), tumor necrosis factor (TNF), and perforin, which work together to stimulate and activate other immune cells and destroy infected or cancerous cells.

In summary, Ly49H-negative NK cells are a subset of natural killer cells that lack the Ly49H receptor. They play an important role in the innate immune response by identifying and eliminating abnormal cells through the production of cytokines and chemokines. Understanding the function and behavior of these cells can provide valuable insights into the immune system's response to diseases such as cancer, infectious diseases, and autoimmunity.
CL:0002411:
Vgamma1.1-positive, Vdelta6.3-negative thymocytes are a type of T lymphocyte (T cell) that develop in the thymus gland. These cells are characterized by the expression of the Vgamma1.1 T-cell receptor (TCR) chain and the absence of the Vdelta6.3 TCR chain. The development of Vgamma1.1-positive, Vdelta6.3-negative thymocytes is regulated by signaling from stromal cells in the thymus, which promote the differentiation and maturation of T cells.

The function of Vgamma1.1-positive, Vdelta6.3-negative thymocytes is still being investigated, but studies have suggested that they may play a role in the immune response to certain pathogens and in the regulation of autoimmune responses. These cells have been shown to recognize certain antigens, particularly those associated with viral infections, and to produce cytokines that help to activate other immune cells. In addition, Vgamma1.1-positive, Vdelta6.3-negative thymocytes have been shown to play a role in the maintenance of immune tolerance, which is the ability of the immune system to distinguish self from non-self and avoid attacking healthy tissue.

Overall, Vgamma1.1-positive, Vdelta6.3-negative thymocytes are an important component of the immune system and play a crucial role in the body's defense against pathogens and maintenance of immune tolerance. Further research into the function of these cells may lead to new insights into the development of immune-based therapies for a variety of diseases and conditions.
CL:0002424:
DN2b thymocytes are a distinct cell type that reside in the thymus, a primary lymphoid organ where T cells mature. These thymocytes are characterized by their surface expression of CD25, but not CD44 or CD117. DN2b cells are at an intermediate stage of T cell development, arising from the earlier DN2a stage and giving rise to the later DN3 stage.

The function of DN2b thymocytes is to undergo T cell receptor gene rearrangement, a critical process in T cell development. During this stage, the T cell receptor genes undergo recombination in order to generate a diverse T cell repertoire capable of recognizing a wide range of antigens. DN2b cells are known to actively rearrange their T cell receptor genes, resulting in the production of a diverse array of T cell receptor proteins.

In addition to their role in T cell receptor gene rearrangement, DN2b thymocytes are also important in driving the differentiation and expansion of other thymocyte populations. DN2b cells secrete cytokines such as IL-7 and thymic stromal lymphopoietin (TSLP) that can stimulate the proliferation of earlier thymocytes and promote their maturation. Overall, DN2b thymocytes play a critical role in generating a diverse and functional T cell repertoire that is essential for immune defense against pathogens.
CL:0002428:
Double-positive blasts are cells that are found in the bone marrow and thymus during the process of T-cell development. These cells are identified by the expression of both CD4 and CD8 co-receptors on their surface, which is a characteristic feature of immature T-cells. Double-positive blasts are involved in the formation of mature T-cells, which help in the immune system's response to foreign antigens.

Double-positive blasts go through a rigorous process of selection in order to become mature T-cells. During this selection process, cells that can recognize self-antigens are eliminated, while those that can recognize foreign antigens are retained and allowed to mature. This process ensures that the T-cells formed are able to recognize and respond only to foreign antigens and not attack the body's own cells.

Thus, double-positive blasts play an essential role in the proper functioning of the immune system. Any mutations or defects in their development can lead to a wide range of immune disorders or diseases. Studying the development and function of these cells can help researchers gain a better understanding of the immune system and develop new therapies for diseases that involve immune dysfunction.
CL:0002434:
The CD24-positive, CD8 single-positive thymocyte is a highly specialized type of T cell that is found within the thymus gland. These cells express two specific surface markers or proteins, CD24 and CD8, which help in the identification and classification of the cell type. CD8 single-positive thymocytes are immunocompetent and have the ability to recognize and respond to specific antigens.

During T cell development, thymocytes emerge, undergo positive and negative selection, and differentiate into mature T cells. CD8 single-positive thymocytes are the final stage in the development of CD8 T cells, as they have completed development and are now capable of migrating to peripheral tissues and recognizing cells that carry antigens presented by major histocompatibility complexes (MHCs).

CD24-positive, CD8 single-positive thymocytes play a significant role in immune surveillance against pathogens and cancer cells. Upon encountering antigen and activation, these cells proliferate and differentiate into cytotoxic T cells, which can directly kill infected and cancerous cells. They can also produce cytokines, which activate other immune cells and recruit them to the site of infection or inflammation. Overall, CD24-positive, CD8 single-positive thymocytes are an essential component of adaptive immunity, which ensures effective recognition and elimination of pathogens.
CL:0002423:
DN2a thymocytes are a subset of immature T cells that develop in the thymus gland. These cells are part of the early stages of thymocyte development, which involves a complex process of differentiation and selection to produce functional T cells that can recognize and respond to foreign antigens. DN2a thymocytes are characterized by their expression of the CD25 and CD44 cell surface markers, which distinguish them from other subsets of thymocytes.

During development, DN2a thymocytes undergo rearrangement of their T cell receptor (TCR) genes to generate a diverse repertoire of TCRs, which allows T cells to recognize a wide variety of antigens. This process is tightly regulated and is essential for the development of a functional immune system. DN2a thymocytes also undergo positive and negative selection, which allows for the elimination of potentially harmful T cells and the retention of those that can recognize foreign antigens without attacking self-tissues.

The function of DN2a thymocytes is critical for the development of a functional immune system. These cells are essential for generating a diverse and self-tolerant population of T cells that can recognize a wide range of foreign antigens. Defects in thymocyte development can lead to immune dysfunction and increased susceptibility to infections, autoimmunity, and cancer. Understanding the biology of DN2a thymocytes and other thymocyte subsets is therefore essential for the development of new therapies for immune-related disorders.
CL:0002413:
Mature Vgamma1.1-positive, Vdelta6.3-negative thymocytes are a specialized type of immune cell that develop in the thymus gland. These cells play a critical role in the adaptive immune response, helping to identify and eliminate foreign pathogens and abnormal cell growth. This particular type of thymocyte expresses the gamma1.1 chain of the T-cell receptor (TCR) and lacks expression of the delta6.3 chain, distinguishing it from other thymocytes and conferring unique functional properties.

Upon maturation, these cells exit the thymus and migrate to peripheral sites where they assist in immune surveillance and defense. As effector cells, Vgamma1.1-positive, Vdelta6.3-negative thymocytes are able to rapidly recognize and respond to a range of foreign antigens, including bacteria, viruses, and tumor cells. Additionally, these cells are thought to play a specialized role in the response to certain types of infectious agents, particularly those that can evade detection by other immune cells.

While much remains to be learned about the specific functions of Vgamma1.1-positive, Vdelta6.3-negative thymocytes, ongoing research is focused on further characterizing the molecular mechanisms underlying their development and activation. This knowledge is essential for the development of targeted therapies and immunotherapies that can enhance or modulate immune responses to promote health and wellbeing.
CL:0002451:
Mammary stem cells (MaSCs) are rare populations of cells located in the mammary gland that have the remarkable ability to produce all the cell types that make up the mammary gland, including ductal and glandular cells during development, pregnancy, and lactation. MaSCs are identified by their distinct cell surface markers, but their functionality is best defined by their regenerative potential when transplanted into a mammary fat pad. 

MaSCs play an essential role in breast development, homeostasis, and tissue regeneration. They are responsible for the continuous replenishment of the mammary gland throughout adulthood and the regulation of mammary gland size and function. Moreover, MaSCs are implicated in the development and progression of breast cancer, as they are thought to be the cells that give rise to breast tumors. Therefore, understanding the biology of MaSCs is crucial for the development of better diagnostic and therapeutic strategies for breast cancer. 

Recent advances in single-cell genomics and lineage tracing techniques have revealed the diverse heterogeneity of the MaSC population at a molecular and functional level. This newfound knowledge will provide invaluable insights into the regulation of mammary gland development and the mechanisms underlying breast cancer initiation, progression, and metastasis.
CL:0002440:
Ly49D-positive natural killer (NK) cells are a subset of innate lymphoid cells in mice that play a crucial role in the immune system's defense against invading pathogens. These cells have been shown to be capable of recognizing and eliminating virally infected cells and tumor cells through a variety of mechanisms. Ly49D is a specific receptor expressed on the surface of these cells that recognizes MHC class I molecules expressed on target cells, allowing for highly specific recognition and elimination.

Along with their role in immunity to infection and cancer, Ly49D-positive NK cells have also been implicated in reproduction and pregnancy. During pregnancy, these cells have been shown to interact with trophoblast cells in the uterus, contributing to the maintenance of a healthy pregnancy. Additionally, Ly49D-positive NK cells have been shown to be capable of differentiating into more specialized innate lymphoid cell subsets.

Despite their critical functions, the specific regulation and activation of Ly49D-positive NK cells is not yet fully understood. However, ongoing research is shedding light on the complex interactions and signaling pathways that allow for the development and activation of these cells, providing new avenues for therapeutic interventions in diseases such as cancer and infections.
CL:0002445:
Ly49D-negative natural killer cells, also known as Ly49D− NK cells, are a subset of natural killer cells that are found in mice. These cells are called natural killer cells because they are able to recognize and destroy cells that are abnormal or infected with viruses, without prior sensitization. Unlike other natural killer cells, Ly49D− NK cells do not express the Ly49D receptor on their surface, which is typically involved in recognizing self and non-self cells.

Ly49D− NK cells have been shown to play a crucial role in regulating the immune response to viral infections in mice. These cells are able to produce large amounts of interferon-gamma, which is a cytokine that activates other cells of the immune system and helps eliminate viral infections. In addition to viral infections, Ly49D− NK cells have also been implicated in the immune response to tumors.

Several studies have demonstrated the importance of Ly49D− NK cells in immune surveillance and clearance of viral infections in mice. For example, Ly49D− NK cells have been shown to play a critical role in the control of mouse cytomegalovirus infection, a common herpesvirus that can cause disease in immune compromised individuals. Overall, these findings suggest that Ly49D− NK cells are an important subset of immune cells that contribute to the immune system's ability to defend against viral infections and cancers.
CL:0002368:
Respiratory epithelial cells are specialized cells that line the airways of the respiratory tract. They play a critical role in the process of respiration by providing a barrier between the air and the underlying tissue, as well as by participating in the exchange of gases between the lungs and the bloodstream. These cells are found throughout the respiratory tract, from the trachea to the alveoli.

The primary function of respiratory epithelial cells is to create a barrier between the environment and the underlying tissue. This barrier prevents harmful particles, such as dust and bacteria, from passing into the lungs and causing damage. The cells accomplish this through the use of cilia, small hair-like structures that line the surface of the cells. The cilia move in a coordinated fashion, effectively sweeping the mucus and trapped particles up and out of the airway.

Respiratory epithelial cells are also responsible for facilitating the exchange of gases between the lungs and the bloodstream. Oxygen from the air diffuses across the cell membranes and into the bloodstream, while carbon dioxide from the bloodstream diffuses across the cell membranes and into the airway to be exhaled. This process occurs primarily in the alveoli, tiny air sacs located at the end of the bronchioles. Overall, respiratory epithelial cells are essential for maintaining the health and proper function of the respiratory system, and any damage to these cells can lead to serious respiratory problems.
CL:0002461:
CD103-positive dendritic cells (DCs) are a subset of DCs that express the integrin αE chain, also known as CD103. These DCs are known for their specialized role in the immune system, particularly in maintaining immune tolerance in peripheral tissues. 

In terms of function, CD103-positive DCs are specialized in antigen presentation, which is crucial for the initiation and regulation of immune responses. They can capture antigens from the surrounding environment and then migrate to the draining lymph nodes to present these antigens to T cells, which are essential for mounting an effective immune response. CD103-positive DCs are especially important in presenting antigens from non-invasive pathogens that cause infection in peripheral tissues and organs. 

Moreover, CD103-positive DCs have been shown to have a key role in the regulation of immune responses in the gastrointestinal tract. They can induce the differentiation of regulatory T cells, which can suppress immune responses and promote tolerance against food antigens and commensal bacteria. Thus, CD103-positive DCs play a crucial role in the maintenance of immune homeostasis in peripheral tissues, and their dysfunction has been implicated in various autoimmune and inflammatory diseases.
CL:0002450:
Tether cells, also known as enwrapping cells, are a specialized type of cells found in the body's connective tissues. These cells function by forming a physical connection between two distinct types of tissues, mainly muscles and tendons or bones and ligaments. Tether cells are a crucial component of the musculoskeletal system and play a vital role in enabling the smooth and efficient movement of bones and joints.

Tether cells are characterized by their unique morphology, with elongated, spindle-shaped bodies that contain multiple long processes extending from their surface. These processes anchor the cell within the connective tissue and provide a mechanism for communicating with other cells, enabling them to coordinate and maintain tissue homeostasis. Through their physical connection, tether cells facilitate force transmission between two distinct tissues and absorb mechanical stress to prevent tissue injury, which is necessary for the proper functioning of the musculoskeletal system.

In addition to their mechanical function, tether cells are also involved in regulating tissue metabolism and growth. By secreting specific cellular signaling molecules, tether cells can activate or inhibit the growth and differentiation of neighboring cells, ultimately influencing tissue development and repair. Overall, tether cells represent a unique and highly specialized cell type that plays a crucial role in the healthy functioning of the musculoskeletal system.
CL:0002463:
SIRPa-positive adipose dendritic cells (SIRPa+ ADCs) are a distinct population of dendritic cells that are found abundantly in adipose tissue. These cells are characterized by their high expression of SIRPa (signal regulatory protein alpha), which is a cell-surface protein that is involved in regulating cell activation and immune responses. SIRPa+ ADCs are also known to express CD11c, a marker commonly used to identify dendritic cells.

SIRPa+ ADCs have been shown to play an important role in maintaining adipose tissue homeostasis and regulating systemic metabolism. These cells are able to sense changes in nutrient availability and respond by secreting cytokines and chemokines that recruit immune cells and modulate metabolic processes. In addition, SIRPa+ ADCs have been implicated in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and the development of obesity-related metabolic disorders.

Overall, SIRPa+ adipose dendritic cells are a unique population of dendritic cells that exert important immunometabolic functions in adipose tissue. Their ability to regulate immune responses and metabolic processes makes them attractive targets for therapeutic interventions aimed at treating obesity and related disorders.
CL:0002447:
CD94-negative natural killer cells, mouse are a subset of natural killer cells that do not express the CD94 receptor. These cells are important components of the innate immune system and are involved in the recognition and elimination of virally infected and cancerous cells. CD94-negative NK cells are characterized by their ability to rapidly secrete cytokines, such as interferon-gamma and tumor necrosis factor-alpha, and their ability to directly kill target cells without prior sensitization.

CD94-negative NK cells are known to play an important role in antitumor immunity. In mouse models, depletion of CD94-negative NK cells has been shown to promote tumor growth and metastasis. Additionally, CD94-negative NK cells have been found to be particularly effective at eliminating tumor cells that have downregulated the expression of major histocompatibility complex class I molecules, a common mechanism used by tumors to evade recognition by the immune system.

In summary, CD94-negative natural killer cells, mouse are a specialized subset of natural killer cells that play a critical role in the innate immune response to virus-infected and cancerous cells. These cells are capable of responding rapidly to danger signals and can eliminate target cells through direct killing or cytokine secretion. The unique properties of CD94-negative NK cells make them an important target for the development of novel immunotherapy strategies for cancer.
CL:0002457:
Epidermal Langerhans cells are dendritic cells that reside in the epidermis of the skin. These cells play an important role in immune surveillance and in the induction of immune responses in the skin. Langerhans cells express several pattern recognition receptors and can recognize pathogens and danger signals. Upon activation, they migrate to the draining lymph nodes and present antigens to T-cells, triggering an immune response. 

In addition to their immune functions, Langerhans cells also play a role in maintaining skin homeostasis. They participate in the regulation of the skin barrier function by producing antimicrobial peptides and cytokines. They also contribute to the development of tolerance to self-antigens in the skin. 

Langerhans cells have a characteristic morphology with branched dendrites that extend between keratinocytes in the epidermis. They express CD1a, a marker specific to Langerhans cells, as well as other markers such as CD207 and langerin. The number of Langerhans cells in the skin varies depending on factors such as age, UV exposure, and skin diseases. Understanding the role of Langerhans cells in immunity and skin homeostasis is important for the development of therapies for skin diseases and for the design of effective vaccines targeting the skin.
CL:0002441:
CD94-positive natural killer (NK) cells are a subset of NK cells that express the CD94/NKG2A receptor on their cell surface. These cells play important roles in immune surveillance, particularly in defense against viral infections and tumor development. CD94-positive NK cells recognize and eliminate abnormal cells, such as virus-infected or cancerous cells, through recognition of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I molecules or stress-induced ligands. 

In mouse models, CD94-positive NK cells have been shown to be involved in the adaptive immune response and to support the expansion of CD8+ T cells during viral infections. These cells produce IFN-gamma, a cytokine that activates macrophages and provides additional signals that enhance the recruitment and activation of other immune cells. Furthermore, CD94-positive NK cells may play a role in the regulation of their own function by modulating the activity of other NK cells. 

The presence of CD94-positive NK cells in different tissues suggests that they have a broad range of functions beyond their cytotoxic activity. Notably, CD94 has been shown to have anti-inflammatory properties, suggesting that CD94-positive NK cells may play a role in regulating the immune response and maintaining homeostasis in tissues. Together, the functions of CD94-positive NK cells make them an important component of the immune system and represent a promising target for immunotherapeutic strategies.
CL:0002454:
Cd4-negative, CD8_alpha-negative, CD11b-positive dendritic cells are a subset of dendritic cells that play an important role in the immune system. They are derived from bone marrow and are involved in the presentation of antigens to T cells, which helps activate an immune response against foreign invaders. 

Cd4-negative, CD8_alpha-negative, CD11b-positive dendritic cells can be found in lymphoid and non-lymphoid tissues, including skin and muscle tissue. Their primary function is to capture antigens and process them into fragments that can be presented to T cells. Once presented, these fragments stimulate T cells to differentiate into effector cells, which can target and destroy cells infected with pathogens or cancerous cells.

These dendritic cells also play a role in modulating the immune response, as they produce cytokines that influence the type of T cell response generated. Additionally, they have been shown to play a role in autoimmune disorders, where they can either promote or inhibit the development of autoimmune responses.

Overall, Cd4-negative, CD8_alpha-negative, CD11b-positive dendritic cells serve as a critical link between the innate and adaptive immune responses. Their ability to capture and present antigens to T cells, as well as modulate the immune response, make them a vital component of the immune system's ability to fight off foreign invaders.
CL:0002408:
Immature Vgamma2-negative thymocytes are a type of developing T cells that originate from hematopoietic stem cells and migrate to the thymus. These thymocytes are not yet fully mature and have not yet gone through positive or negative selection to become a functional T cell. Vgamma2-negative thymocytes are a subset of T cells that are characterized by the absence of expression of the T cell receptor (TCR) Vgamma2 chain. 

During T cell development, immature thymocytes undergo numerous stages of maturation and differentiation. Immature Vgamma2-negative thymocytes are characterized by the expression of CD25 and CD44 surface markers, which distinguish them from other T cell subsets. These cells also express a pre-T cell receptor (pre-TCR) and rearranged TCR beta chain genes. The pre-TCR complex plays a critical role in the survival and proliferation of immature thymocytes before they acquire a functional TCR. 

The function of immature Vgamma2-negative thymocytes is to undergo positive and negative selection to become mature and functional T cells. Positive selection occurs when thymocytes that can interact with major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules presented by thymic epithelial cells are allowed to survive and mature. Negative selection occurs when developing thymocytes that recognize self-antigens are eliminated. Vgamma2-negative thymocytes that successfully pass both positive and negative selection will differentiate into mature functional T cells that can recognize and respond to antigens presented by antigen-presenting cells.
CL:0002399:
CD1c-positive myeloid dendritic cells (mDCs) are a specialized type of immune cells that belong to the dendritic cell family. These cells have a unique ability to prime T cells and initiate adaptive immune responses. The CD1c molecule, which is expressed on the surface of these cells, is responsible for presenting lipid antigens to T cells. CD1c-positive myeloid dendritic cells are found in lymphoid tissues such as lymph nodes, spleen, and bone marrow.

The primary function of CD1c-positive myeloid dendritic cells is antigen presentation. These cells have a high capacity to take up antigens from their surroundings, process them, and present them to T cells. This process is essential for initiating an immune response against foreign invaders such as viruses, bacteria, and fungi. CD1c-positive myeloid dendritic cells are also important in the maintenance of peripheral tolerance and prevention of autoimmunity. They achieve this by presenting self-antigens to T cells in a way that induces tolerance and prevents T cell activation.

Furthermore, CD1c-positive myeloid dendritic cells have been implicated in the pathogenesis of various diseases such as cancer, autoimmune disorders, and infectious diseases. Recent studies have shown that these cells play a critical role in the initiation and progression of cancer by shaping the tumor microenvironment and activating tumor-specific T cells. In autoimmune disorders such as multiple sclerosis and rheumatoid arthritis, CD1c-positive myeloid dendritic cells have been shown to be involved in the activation of autoreactive T cells, leading to tissue damage and inflammation. In infectious diseases such as tuberculosis and HIV, these cells play a critical role in the immune response against the pathogens.

In summary, CD1c-positive myeloid dendritic cells are a critical component of the immune system with an essential function in antigen presentation, T cell priming, and maintenance of peripheral tolerance. These cells also play a role in the pathogenesis of various diseases, making them an attractive target for therapeutic interventions.
CL:0002360:
AGM hematopoietic stem cells (AGM HSCs) are a crucial cell type found in the AGM region of developing mammalian embryos. AGM HSCs are the precursors to all the different blood cell types found in the body. These cells are unique because they are the first HSCs that emerge during embryonic development. AGM HSCs play a crucial role in supplying the nascent embryo with its first waves of hematopoietic cells. Furthermore, these cells also provide a reservoir of cells that the body can rely on later in life to replenish and replace damaged or depleted cells.

The AGM region is considered to be a particularly fruitful location to study hematopoiesis because of its relative accessibility and because it is devoid of other confounding tissues. Additionally, AGM HSCs have a unique molecular signature that is distinct from HSCs found in other regions of the embryo. AGM HSCs share many similarities with other types of HSCs, including their ability to differentiate into a number of different blood cell types and their capacity for self-renewal. However, they also express a number of distinctive developmental regulators and cell surface markers, which are believed to govern their unique developmental behavior.

Research into AGM hematopoietic stem cells has important implications for the field of regenerative medicine. Understanding how these cells develop and differentiate could help researchers generate new therapies for a variety of blood-related disorders, from anemias to leukemias, by guiding the development of new treatment options. Their unique molecular characteristics could also provide important new clues about how stem cells function more broadly, and how other stem cell populations can be manipulated for therapeutic purposes.
CL:0002459:
Langerin-negative dermal dendritic cells (LNDDCs) are a subset of dendritic cells found in the dermis layer of skin. LNDDCs are characterized by their lack of expression of the protein langerin, which is found in another type of dendritic cell called Langerhans cells. Instead, LNDDCs express the markers CD1a and DC-SIGN. 

The main function of LNDDCs is to process and present antigens to T cells in order to initiate an immune response against pathogens or foreign substances in the skin. LNDDCs are particularly efficient at capturing antigens and migrating to the lymph nodes to present them to T cells. LNDDCs also play a role in regulating immune responses to self-antigens, preventing autoimmune reactions. 

Recent studies have also suggested that LNDDCs play a role in wound healing and tissue repair. LNDDCs have been shown to promote the migration of fibroblasts and keratinocytes, which are important cells for skin regeneration. Additionally, LNDDCs may regulate the formation of blood vessels in the skin, which is essential for delivering nutrients and oxygen to cells during the healing process. Overall, LNDDCs are an important component of the skin immune system and play crucial roles in both immune defense and tissue repair.
CL:0002342:
Circulating endothelial cells are a specialized type of cell that play a crucial role in maintaining proper vascular function. These cells are typically found in the blood and lymphatic system and are derived from mature or activated endothelial cells that have detached from the inner lining of blood vessels. Circulating endothelial cells are believed to be involved in angiogenesis, the process of forming new blood vessels, as well as in wound healing and inflammation.

One of the key functions of circulating endothelial cells is to promote angiogenesis. These cells are thought to be involved in the early stages of blood vessel formation, helping to guide and support the growth and branching of new vessels. They can also contribute to the repair and regeneration of damaged blood vessels, aiding in the recovery of tissue after injury or disease.

In addition to their role in angiogenesis, circulating endothelial cells have been implicated in a variety of other physiological and pathological processes. For example, they are involved in regulating blood clotting and the formation of blood vessels during embryonic development. They may also play a role in the development and progression of diseases such as cancer and cardiovascular disease, as well as in the healing of chronic wounds. Overall, circulating endothelial cells are a fascinating and important cell type with a wide range of physiological functions.
CL:0002427:
Resting double-positive thymocytes are cells found in the thymus that have not yet undergone selection for either CD4 or CD8 cells. These cells play a critical role in the development of the immune system as they are the precursors to both CD4 and CD8 T cells. Resting double-positive thymocytes are identified by the presence of both CD4 and CD8 on their surface, along with the T cell receptor (TCR). It is estimated that approximately 80% of thymocytes are double-positive at any given time.

During the process of thymocyte development, resting double-positive thymocytes go through a series of differentiation steps, eventually leading to the selection of either CD4 or CD8 cells. This selection process is mediated by the interaction between the TCR on the surface of the thymocyte and major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules expressed by thymic epithelial cells. This interaction determines whether the thymocyte becomes a CD4 or CD8 T cell. While resting double-positive thymocytes are still undergoing selection, they are functionally immature and inactive.

Moreover, resting double-positive thymocytes are also involved in negative selection, a process in which potentially self-reactive thymocytes are eliminated. This is critical for the prevention of autoimmune diseases. During negative selection, thymocytes that recognize self-antigens are eliminated, while those that can recognize foreign antigens are allowed to survive. The eventual selection process of resting double-positive thymocytes into CD4 or CD8 T cells is critical for the development of a functional immune system.
CL:0002387:
Arthroconidia are a type of fungal spore that are characterized by their segmented appearance. Unlike most fungal spores, arthroconidia are not produced externally on hyphae or spore-bearing structures; instead, they are generated through the fragmentation of specialized cells called arthroconidiogenous cells. This process is known as arthroconidiation. The resulting arthroconidia are typically smaller than other types of fungal spores and have a characteristic multi-celled appearance, with each cell connected by a narrow, septate junction. 

Arthroconidia are important for the life cycle and dispersal of certain pathogenic and non-pathogenic fungi. They have been identified in a range of fungal species, including members of the genera Trichophyton and Microsporum, which are responsible for common skin infections such as ringworm. The ability of arthroconidia to persist for extended periods of time in the environment and to cause infection in humans and animals makes them particularly important targets for research into antifungal drug development. Studies have shown that arthroconidia are capable of surviving under adverse conditions, such as high temperature, low humidity, and exposure to UV radiation, which contributes to their success in establishing infections in a variety of hosts. 

In addition to their importance in fungal pathogenesis, arthroconidia have also been used in bioremediation and biotechnology. For example, some species of fungi are able to degrade environmental pollutants such as polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) and chlorinated solvents, and arthroconidia can be used to inoculate contaminated soil and help break down these compounds. Arthroconidia have also been studied for their potential to produce useful compounds, such as enzymes and bioactive molecules. Overall, the unique morphology and ecology of arthroconidia make them a fascinating and important type of fungal cell.
CL:0002458:
Langerin-positive dermal dendritic cells (Langerin+ dDCs) are a specialized subset of dendritic cells found in the skin. These cells are characterized by their expression of the C-type lectin receptor langerin (CD207), which allows them to bind and internalize antigens from the environment. Langerin+ dDCs have been shown to play a crucial role in the initiation and regulation of immune responses in the skin.

In response to skin injury or infection, Langerin+ dDCs migrate to the draining lymph nodes where they present antigen to T cells and initiate a specific immune response. They can also induce tolerance and prevent autoimmunity by promoting the development of regulatory T cells. Langerin+ dDCs are also known to produce cytokines and chemokines that attract other immune cells to the site of infection or injury, further facilitating the immune response.

In addition to their role in immune responses, Langerin+ dDCs have also been implicated in skin homeostasis and wound healing. These cells contribute to the maintenance of skin integrity by regulating the proliferation and differentiation of keratinocytes. They have also been shown to play a crucial role in the wound healing process by promoting angiogenesis and tissue repair. Overall, Langerin+ dDCs are a crucial component of the skin immune system and play a critical role in maintaining skin health and preventing disease.
CL:0002394:
CD141-positive myeloid dendritic cells are a specialized subset of dendritic cells (DCs) that play a critical role in the initiation of immune responses against pathogens. These cells are also known as conventional dendritic cells type 1 (cDC1s) and are characterized by the expression of CD141 (also known as thrombomodulin), which is a transmembrane glycoprotein that is involved in regulating blood coagulation and inflammation. 

The main function of CD141-positive myeloid dendritic cells is to capture antigens from invading pathogens in the peripheral tissues, process them, and present antigenic peptides to T cells in the draining lymph nodes. This process, known as antigen presentation, is essential for the activation of naive T cells and the generation of antigen-specific immune responses. CD141-positive myeloid dendritic cells are particularly efficient in cross-presenting exogenous antigens to CD8+ T cells, which is important for the induction of cytotoxic T cell responses against viral infections and cancer cells.

CD141-positive myeloid dendritic cells also have the ability to produce high levels of type I interferons (IFNs) in response to viral infections and other stimuli. Type I IFNs are cytokines that play an important role in innate and adaptive immune responses by inducing the expression of antiviral and pro-inflammatory genes in infected and neighboring cells. In addition, CD141-positive myeloid dendritic cells can secrete other cytokines, such as interleukin-12 (IL-12), IL-15, and IL-18, that are important for promoting the proliferation and survival of T cells, natural killer (NK) cells, and other immune cells. 

In summary, CD141-positive myeloid dendritic cells are a critical component of the immune system that functions to initiate and modulate immune responses against a wide range of pathogens. These cells have unique features, such as their ability to cross-present antigens and produce type I IFNs, that make them particularly effective at inducing cytotoxic T cell responses and promoting antiviral immunity. Understanding the biology of CD141-positive myeloid dendritic cells is important for the development of effective vaccines and immunotherapies against infectious diseases and cancer.
CL:0002431:
CD4-positive, CD8-intermediate double-positive thymocytes are a unique cell type that develop in the thymus during T cell maturation. These cells exist in a transitional stage between immature thymocytes and mature T cells. They can be identified by their expression of both CD4 and CD8 surface receptors, with intermediate levels of expression for each.

During thymocyte development, double-positive cells undergo a process of positive and negative selection, which determines their fate as either CD4 or CD8 T cells. This selection is crucial for the proper development of a functional T cell repertoire capable of recognizing and responding to pathogens. Double-positive cells undergo positive selection by interacting with self-major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules on thymic epithelial cells. If they produce T cell receptors (TCRs) that weakly bind to MHC molecules, they will be eliminated by negative selection, while strong binding T cells undergo clonal expansion. The process culminates in the differentiation of CD4 T cells and CD8 T cells, both of which are critical components of the adaptive immune system.

CD4-positive, CD8-intermediate double-positive thymocytes represent a vital stage in the development of T cells. They serve as a precursor to the two major subsets of mature T cells and undergo crucial selection processes during thymic development. While their exact function has yet to be fully elucidated, they are known to play a critical role in the development of a functional immune system. Understanding the function of these cells is essential for advancing our knowledge of T cell development and the immune response.
CL:0002466:
Small intestine serosal dendritic cells are a subset of dendritic cells located in the serosal layer of the small intestine. They play a critical role in maintaining gut homeostasis by regulating immune responses to commensal and pathogenic microbes. These cells are equipped with specialized pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) that enable them to recognize and capture microbial antigens from the intestinal lumen. Upon sensing the presence of antigens, they migrate to the mesenteric lymph nodes to initiate immune responses.

Small intestine serosal dendritic cells are characterized by their ability to promote the differentiation of T cells into regulatory T cells (Tregs) that suppress the activity of effector T cells. Tregs are essential for preventing immune-mediated damage to the intestinal epithelial barrier and maintaining tolerance to commensal microbes. In addition to their role in regulating T cell responses, these dendritic cells also produce cytokines that mediate immune cell communication and activation.

Overall, small intestine serosal dendritic cells are a crucial component of the intestinal immune system that orchestrates immune responses against microbial pathogens while maintaining tolerance to the commensal microbiota. Their ability to regulate T cell responses and promote the generation of Tregs enables them to prevent harmful immune-mediated inflammation and maintain gut homeostasis.
CL:0002477:
Adipose macrophages (AMs) are a specialized type of immune cell found in adipose tissue. They have been shown to play a key role in regulating adipose tissue inflammation and metabolism. These cells are derived from the bone marrow and migrate to adipose tissue in response to a variety of signals, including the presence of inflammatory cytokines.

AMs are known to play a complex role in the regulation of adipose tissue function. They are able to modulate the inflammatory response within adipose tissue by secreting a range of factors, including cytokines, chemokines, and growth factors. Additionally, AMs are known to interact with other cells within adipose tissue, including adipocytes and other immune cells, such as T cells.

Recent research has highlighted the key role that AMs play in regulating glucose homeostasis and insulin sensitivity. Studies have demonstrated that depletion of AMs in mice leads to impaired glucose tolerance and insulin resistance, highlighting the importance of these cells in regulating systemic metabolism. Additionally, changes in the number and function of AMs have been observed in obesity and other metabolic disorders, suggesting that these cells may be a critical target for future therapeutic interventions.
CL:0002446:
Ly49CI-negative natural killer cells are a subset of innate lymphoid cells that are part of the immune system in mice. These cells are known to be cytotoxic, meaning they are capable of directly killing virus-infected cells and even tumor cells. Ly49CI-negative natural killer cells are characterized by the absence of a surface receptor protein called Ly49CI. This receptor protein is typically found on other natural killer cells and is believed to play a role in the recognition and elimination of virus-infected cells.

Ly49CI-negative natural killer cells are an important component of the immune response to viral infections and cancers in mice. These cells are activated when they encounter virus-infected cells or cancerous cells in the body. Upon activation, Ly49CI-negative natural killer cells release cytotoxic granules containing enzymes that induce apoptosis (programmed cell death) in the infected or cancerous cells. In addition, these cells produce cytokines, which are signaling molecules that help to coordinate the immune response by recruiting other immune cells to the site of infection or cancer.

Overall, Ly49CI-negative natural killer cells play a critical role in the immune response to viral infections and cancer in mice. Although much is still unknown about these cells, research into their function and activation may lead to the development of novel immunotherapies for the treatment of viral infections and cancer in humans.
CL:0002456:
CD8α-positive plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs) are a type of immune cell that play a key role in the immune system's response to viral infections. These cells are unique in that they are able to produce high levels of type I interferons, which are important for antiviral immunity. CD8α-positive pDCs also play a role in the regulation of adaptive immune responses, as they are able to present antigens to T cells and promote their activation.

In addition to their antiviral functions, CD8α-positive pDCs have also been implicated in the pathogenesis of autoimmune diseases. In some cases, these cells have been shown to promote the activation of autoreactive T cells, leading to tissue damage and disease. However, the mechanisms behind this pathogenic role are not yet fully understood, and further research is needed to elucidate the complex interactions between CD8α-positive pDCs and the immune system.

Overall, CD8α-positive pDCs are a critical component of the immune system with important roles in both antiviral immunity and the regulation of adaptive immune responses. While they are typically associated with protective immune responses, they can also contribute to the development of autoimmune diseases under certain circumstances. A better understanding of the functions and mechanisms of CD8α-positive pDCs may eventually lead to novel therapies for a range of viral and autoimmune diseases.
CL:0002469:
MHC-II-negative classical monocytes are a subset of white blood cells that play a critical role in the immune system's innate response. These cells are characterized by their size, morphology, and staining characteristics when viewed under the microscope. Classical monocytes are identified based on the expression of the surface marker CD14 and the absence of the marker CD16. Unlike other types of monocytes, MHC-II-negative classical monocytes do not express major histocompatibility complex class II (MHC-II).

The primary function of MHC-II-negative classical monocytes is to act as phagocytes, which means they are capable of engulfing and digesting foreign particles, such as bacteria and viruses. These cells are critical for the innate immune system's response to infection because they can quickly recognize and eliminate pathogens before they have a chance to spread to other parts of the body. Additionally, MHC-II-negative classical monocytes play a role in tissue repair and wound healing by releasing growth factors and cytokines that promote tissue regeneration.

In summary, MHC-II-negative classical monocytes are a key part of the body's innate immune response, functioning primarily as phagocytes to help eliminate foreign invaders and promote tissue repair. With their unique characteristics and important functions within the immune system, understanding the role of MHC-II-negative classical monocytes is crucial for developing effective treatments for a variety of infectious and inflammatory diseases.
CL:0002432:
CD24-positive, CD4 single-positive thymocytes are a type of T cell that is found in the thymus, a small gland located in the upper chest. They are distinguished from other thymocytes by their expression of two key surface proteins: CD24 and CD4. CD24 is a glycoprotein that is abundant on the surface of many cell types, while CD4 is a co-receptor that interacts with major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class II molecules on antigen-presenting cells.

The function of CD24-positive, CD4 single-positive thymocytes is to undergo a process of positive selection in the thymus, during which they are screened for their ability to recognize and respond to foreign antigens. This process is critical for the development of an effective immune system, as it ensures that only those T cells that can recognize the body's own cells without attacking them are allowed to leave the thymus and circulate throughout the body. CD4 is particularly important for this process, as it allows thymocytes to interact with MHC class II molecules present on antigen-presenting cells.

Once they have completed positive selection, CD24-positive, CD4 single-positive thymocytes leave the thymus and enter the bloodstream as mature T cells. From there, they migrate to various tissues throughout the body, where they function to identify and eliminate foreign organisms and cancerous cells. Despite the central role that these cells play in the immune system, relatively little is known about the specific signals that regulate their development and function. Ongoing research in this area may provide new insights into the mechanisms that underlie immune cell function, as well as new therapeutic targets for the treatment of immune disorders.
CL:0002474:
A lymphoid MHC-II-negative classical monocyte is a type of immune cell that plays a critical role in the body's defense against pathogens, such as viruses and bacteria. These cells are derived from the bone marrow and are characterized by their large size, kidney-shaped nucleus, and lack of major histocompatibility complex class II (MHC-II) expression. 

In terms of function, lymphoid MHC-II-negative classical monocytes are key players in the innate immune response. Upon encountering pathogens, these cells are recruited to the site of infection, where they differentiate into macrophages and dendritic cells. Macrophages are phagocytic cells that engulf and digest pathogens, whereas dendritic cells present pathogen-derived antigens to T cells, triggering an adaptive immune response. 

Beyond their role in pathogen defense, lymphoid MHC-II-negative classical monocytes also contribute to tissue repair and homeostasis. For example, in response to tissue damage, these cells can differentiate into M2-like macrophages, which promote tissue regeneration by producing growth factors and clearing apoptotic cells. Additionally, lymphoid MHC-II-negative classical monocytes have been shown to play a role in maintaining the integrity of the blood-brain barrier, as they are selectively recruited to this barrier in response to inflammation and infection.
CL:0002455:
CD8_alpha-negative plasmacytoid dendritic cells, also known as pDC2 cells, are a unique group of dendritic cells that play an important role in the human immune system's response to viral infections. These cells are located primarily in the blood and lymphoid tissues and can be differentiated from other dendritic cells by their lack of CD8 alpha surface marker.

pDC2 cells are specialized to detect viral DNA and RNA using a variety of intracellular receptors, including TLR7 and TLR9. Upon recognition of viral nucleic acids, pDC2 cells rapidly secrete high levels of type I interferon (IFN), which helps to activate other immune cells and inhibit viral replication. pDC2 cells can also produce cytokines such as IL-6 and TNF-alpha, which can further enhance the immune system's response to infection.

In addition to their role in antiviral immune responses, pDC2 cells are also implicated in autoimmune diseases and tumor immunology. These cells can recognize self-antigens and promote the activation of autoreactive T cells, leading to the development of autoimmune disorders.
