On the other hand, pDC2 cells can also be harnessed as a potential immunotherapeutic target for cancer treatment, as they can induce anti-tumor responses through the production of IFN and activation of cytotoxic T cells. These unique features of CD8 alpha-negative plasmacytoid dendritic cells make them a fascinating and essential cell type in the field of immunology.
CL:0002467:
Gr1-high myeloid suppressor cells (G-MDSCs) are a subset of myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs), which are a heterogeneous population of immature and dysfunctional myeloid cells that can suppress T cell immune responses. G-MDSCs are characterized by their high expression of the surface marker Gr1, along with CD11b and Ly6C. These cells are found in the bone marrow, blood, and tumor microenvironment of cancer patients, where they can promote tumor growth and metastasis by dampening anti-tumor immune responses.

G-MDSCs exert their suppressive functions through several mechanisms, including the production of reactive oxygen and nitrogen species, the depletion of essential amino acids such as arginine and cysteine, and the secretion of immunosuppressive cytokines and chemokines such as TGF-β and IL-10. These mechanisms can impair the activation, proliferation, and effector functions of T cells, natural killer cells, and dendritic cells, leading to immune evasion by tumors and increased susceptibility to infections.

Although G-MDSCs have been extensively studied in the context of cancer, their roles in other pathological and physiological conditions such as infections and inflammation are still being investigated. Targeting G-MDSCs and other MDSC subsets represents a promising therapeutic strategy to boost anti-tumor immune responses and alleviate immune suppression in various diseases.
CL:0002429:
CD69-positive double-positive thymocytes are developing T cells that have the CD4 and CD8 co-receptors on their surface and express the activation marker CD69. These cells are found in the thymus gland and are crucial for the development of mature T cells. Double-positive thymocytes are so named because they express both CD4 and CD8, which are usually found on mature T-helper and cytotoxic T cells, respectively. These co-receptors play a role in T cell maturation and self-tolerance.

CD69 is a marker of T cell activation, and its expression on double-positive thymocytes is an indication that they are positively selected for further maturation. Positive selection occurs when these cells interact with major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules on thymic epithelial cells and survive apoptosis. This process ensures that only T cells that can recognize self-MHC molecules are allowed to mature. Additionally, CD69 has been linked to the regulation of cytokine production and T cell-mediated immunity. Thus, CD69-positive double-positive thymocytes play a crucial role in establishing a mature T cell repertoire that can recognize and respond appropriately to pathogens while avoiding self-reactivity.

In summary, CD69-positive double-positive thymocytes are developing T cells that have the potential to become either CD4 or CD8 single-positive T cells. Their co-expression of CD4 and CD8 and the activation marker CD69 makes them of particular importance for T cell lineage commitment and self-tolerance. Through positive selection, these cells contribute to the establishment of a diverse and functional T cell repertoire capable of fighting infections and maintaining immune homeostasis.
CL:0002442:
Natural killer (NK) cells are innate lymphoid cells that play a critical role in immune surveillance against tumors and viral infections. CD94-negative, Ly49CI-negative NK cells are a subset of NK cells found in mice that lack expression of the CD94 and Ly49CI receptors. These cells have been shown to be important in the control of viral infections and the early stages of tumor formation, although their exact role in immunity is not yet fully understood.

CD94-negative, Ly49CI-negative NK cells exhibit a distinct phenotype characterized by the expression of activating receptors such as NK1.1 and Ly49H, and the lack of inhibitory receptors like Ly49A, B, C, and G. This unique receptor repertoire allows them to recognize and eliminate virus-infected or malignant cells without being inhibited by self-tolerance mechanisms. CD94-negative, Ly49CI-negative NK cells are also able to produce proinflammatory cytokines such as IFN-γ and TNF-α, which further enhance their cytotoxic activity and contribute to the recruitment of other immune cells to the site of infection or inflammation.

The function of CD94-negative, Ly49CI-negative NK cells is thought to be particularly important in the early stages of immune responses against viruses and tumors. These cells have been shown to be rapidly activated in response to viral infections such as murine cytomegalovirus and lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus, and to contribute to the efficient clearance of infected cells. Similarly, CD94-negative, Ly49CI-negative NK cells have been reported to be critical in the control of malignant cells in vivo. However, more research is needed to fully understand the precise roles of these cells in the immune response to pathogens and cancer.
CL:0002482:
Dermal melanocytes are specialized cells found in the skin that produce the pigment melanin, responsible for skin, hair, and eye color. Located in the lower layer of the epidermis, they are derived from neural crest cells and migrate to the skin during embryonic development. Dermal melanocytes play a crucial role in protecting the skin from harmful UV radiation by absorbing and diffusing the incoming rays. 

In addition to their photo-protective function, dermal melanocytes also contribute to wound healing and immunity. They release cytokines and chemokines that attract immune cells to the site of inflammation and promote tissue repair. Recent studies also suggest that dermal melanocytes may play a role in skin homeostasis and aging. Melanocytes decrease in number and activity with age, contributing to the loss of skin pigmentation and the formation of age-related hyperpigmentation. 

Dermal melanocytes are also linked to several disorders, including vitiligo and melanoma. In vitiligo, the immune system attacks and destroys melanocytes, leading to a loss of normal skin pigmentation. Melanoma is a deadly skin cancer that arises from melanocytes. Understanding the biology of dermal melanocytes is critical for developing new therapies for skin-related disorders and for ultimately improving skin health.
CL:0002479:
F4/80-positive adipose macrophages are a type of immune cell found in adipose tissue. These cells express the F4/80 protein, which is a common marker for mature macrophages. Adipose macrophages play a critical role in adipose tissue homeostasis and inflammation. Specifically, this particular subtype of macrophage is responsible for regulating adipose tissue inflammation and insulin sensitivity.

In obesity, the number of F4/80-positive adipose macrophages is increased and these cells become activated, secreting pro-inflammatory cytokines such as tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α), interleukin-6 (IL-6), and monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 (MCP-1). These cytokines can promote insulin resistance by inhibiting insulin signaling in adipocytes, leading to dysregulated glucose homeostasis and other metabolic disturbances.

In addition, F4/80-positive adipose macrophages also play a role in the clearance of apoptotic adipocytes and debris, which is necessary for adipose tissue remodeling and proper functioning. Dysregulation of this process can lead to the accumulation of dead adipocytes and chronic inflammation in adipose tissue, contributing to the pathogenesis of obesity-related metabolic disorders such as type 2 diabetes.
CL:0002414:
Immature Vgamma1.1-positive, Vdelta6.3-negative thymocytes are a specialized subset of T cells present in the thymus. These cells are characterized by the expression of the Vgamma1.1 gene segment of the T cell receptor (TCR), which is involved in the recognition of antigens presented by major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules. In contrast, immature Vgamma1.1-positive, Vdelta6.3-negative thymocytes do not express the Vdelta6.3 gene segment of the TCR, which is typically expressed by T cells in the gut epithelium. 

The function of immature Vgamma1.1-positive, Vdelta6.3-negative thymocytes is to undergo positive and negative selection in the thymus, a critical process that ensures the development of functional and self-tolerant T cells. During positive selection, immature thymocytes that successfully recognize self-antigens presented by MHC molecules receive signals that promote their survival and differentiation into mature T cells. In contrast, immature thymocytes that fail to recognize self-antigens undergo negative selection, leading to either apoptosis or differentiation into regulatory T cells that help maintain self-tolerance. The specificity of immature Vgamma1.1-positive, Vdelta6.3-negative thymocytes for self-antigens presented by MHC molecules is determined, in part, by the rearrangement and expression of their TCR genes. 

These cells are important in the cellular immune system and play a crucial role in protecting the body against foreign pathogens and cancer cells. Dysfunction or dysregulation of immature Vgamma1.1-positive, Vdelta6.3-negative thymocytes development can lead to autoimmune diseases such as Sjogren's syndrome and rheumatoid arthritis. Understanding the biology of these cells is therefore essential for the development of novel treatments for these diseases.
CL:0002464:
SIRPa-negative adipose dendritic cells are a specialized type of immune cell found within adipose tissue. These cells are characterized by the absence of the protein SIRPa, which is a receptor that interacts with the CD47 protein. This unique characteristic distinguishes them from other dendritic cells found within adipose tissue. SIRPa-negative adipose dendritic cells comprise only a small portion of the total adipose-resident immune cells and have been identified in both mice and humans.

Recently, SIRPa-negative adipose dendritic cells have been found to play a critical role in regulating adipose tissue inflammation and insulin resistance. By promoting immune tolerance within adipose tissue, these cells help to prevent chronic low-grade inflammation that can lead to metabolic disorders such as obesity, type 2 diabetes, and cardiovascular disease. In addition, SIRPa-negative adipose dendritic cells have been shown to promote the recruitment and activation of regulatory T-cells, which further contribute to immune stability and tolerance within adipose tissue.

Overall, SIRPa-negative adipose dendritic cells represent a unique and important subset of dendritic cells that contributes to the maintenance of immune homeostasis within adipose tissue. They play a crucial role in preventing inflammation, insulin resistance, and other metabolic disorders associated with obesity. Understanding the function and characteristics of these cells is critical to developing new therapies aimed at improving metabolic health and treating metabolic diseases.
CL:0002480:
A nasal mucosa goblet cell is a unicellular glandular epithelial cell that secretes mucus in the respiratory passages. These specialized cells are responsible for producing and secreting the protein-rich mucus layer that covers the nasal cavity and protects it from external pathogens, pollutants, and debris. The mucus layer is crucial for maintaining the health of the respiratory system by trapping foreign particles and pathogens and preventing them from entering the lungs. In this way, the nasal mucosa goblet cells play an essential role in the body's immune defense mechanisms.

Nasal mucosa goblet cells are found in the nasal mucosa, which is the lining of the nasal cavity. They are characterized by a large, globular shape and a distinct appearance under the microscope due to the accumulation of mucus in their cytoplasm. These cells are abundant in the nasal passages and are continuously secreting mucus to maintain the health of the respiratory system.

The function of the nasal mucosa goblet cell is vital for the body's overall health. Any disruption in the production of mucus by these cells can lead to respiratory infections, allergies, and other respiratory diseases. Researchers are continuing to investigate the role of nasal mucosa goblet cells and their potential as a target for therapeutic interventions in respiratory diseases. Overall, the nasal mucosa goblet cell is an essential cell type that plays a vital role in maintaining the health of the respiratory system.
CL:0002416:
Mature Vgamma1.1-positive, Vdelta6.3-positive thymocytes are a subset of T cells that are found in the thymus, an organ responsible for the development and education of T cells. These cells express a specific combination of T cell receptors (TCRs), including the Vgamma1.1 and Vdelta6.3 chains, which define their antigen specificity. This specific subset of T cells have been shown to play important roles in the immune response against various pathogens and in maintaining tissue homeostasis.

Throughout their development, thymocytes undergo a process of positive and negative selection in order to ensure that only those cells capable of recognizing foreign antigens are allowed to mature and leave the thymus. Vgamma1.1-positive, Vdelta6.3-positive thymocytes have been shown to play a critical role in positive selection, where they participate in the recognition and response to self-peptides presented by major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules. These cells have also been implicated in the immunomodulation of autoimmune diseases, as well as in anti-tumor immunity.

In addition to their function in positive selection, mature Vgamma1.1-positive, Vdelta6.3-positive thymocytes have been shown to be involved in immune surveillance of various tissues, including the skin and gut. These cells have been shown to recognize and respond to antigens presented by non-classical MHC molecules, suggesting that they may play a role in the response to infection by certain pathogens. Furthermore, studies have suggested that these cells are involved in the regulation of immune responses to commensal bacteria in the gut, and may be important in the maintenance of intestinal homeostasis. Overall, mature Vgamma1.1-positive, Vdelta6.3-positive thymocytes are an important subset of T cells with diverse roles in immune surveillance, immune regulation, and host defense.
CL:0002460:
CD8alpha-negative thymic conventional dendritic cells (cDCs) are professional antigen-presenting cells that can activate naïve T cells and initiate an adaptive immune response. These cells are found in the thymus, where they play a critical role in shaping the T cell repertoire by presenting self-antigens to developing T cells and deleting those that recognize self. Unlike CD8alpha-positive cDCs, CD8alpha-negative cDCs do not express CD8alpha, and they have distinct developmental origins and gene expression profiles. 

CD8alpha-negative cDCs can be further subdivided into two subsets based on their expression of CD11b. The CD11b-high subset is highly phagocytic and is specialized for processing antigens from pathogens such as bacteria and fungi. The CD11b-low subset is more efficient at cross-presentation, a process by which exogenous antigens are presented on MHC class I molecules to activate CD8+ T cells. CD8alpha-negative cDCs are also important producers of cytokines such as interleukin-12, which help to polarize the immune response towards a T helper 1 (Th1) phenotype.

In addition to their role in negative selection, CD8alpha-negative cDCs have been implicated in autoimmune diseases such as multiple sclerosis. In these diseases, autoreactive T cells escape thymic deletion and are activated by peripheral DCs, including CD8alpha-negative cDCs, leading to tissue damage. Understanding the function of CD8alpha-negative cDCs in health and disease will be an important step towards developing new therapies for immune disorders.
CL:0002443:
Ly49CI-positive natural killer (NK) cells are a subset of innate immune cells found in mice. These cells express the Ly49CI receptor which allows them to interact with major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I molecules on target cells. Ly49CI-positive NK cells function to eliminate viral-infected and cancerous cells by releasing cytotoxic granules and cytokines.

In addition to cytotoxicity, Ly49CI-positive NK cells also play a role in regulating immune responses. These cells are able to produce cytokines such as interferon-gamma (IFN-γ) and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α) which can activate other immune cells such as dendritic cells and T cells. Ly49CI-positive NK cells also have the ability to interact with dendritic cells to promote immune tolerance.

Overall, Ly49CI-positive NK cells play a crucial role in the innate immune response to viral infections and cancer by directly killing infected or cancerous cells and by regulating the immune response through cytokine production and interacting with other immune cells. Further research on these cells could lead to the development of new immunotherapies for the treatment of viral infections and cancer.
CL:0002433:
CD69-positive, CD4-positive single-positive thymocytes are a population of cells found in the thymus, the primary site of T-cell development. These cells are characterized by their expression of the CD69 activation marker and CD4 co-receptor, and are known as "single-positive" because they express either CD4 or CD8 but not both. CD4-positive thymocytes play a critical role in the development of the immune system by selecting for thymocytes with T-cell receptors (TCRs) that are capable of recognizing foreign antigens presented by major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules.

During thymic development, immature T-cells undergo a process of positive and negative selection, where their ability to recognize self-antigens presented by MHC molecules is tested. CD4-positive thymocytes participate in positive selection, which results in the survival and differentiation of thymocytes with TCRs that can recognize foreign antigens presented by MHC class II molecules. CD4-positive thymocytes interact with cortical thymic epithelial cells (cTECs) that express MHC class II complexes with self-peptides. Thymocytes that bind strongly to these MHC-peptide complexes receive survival signals and differentiate further into mature CD4-positive T-cells.

In addition to their role in positive selection, CD4-positive thymocytes also play a role in the generation of regulatory T-cells (Tregs), a specialized subset of T-cells that are essential for maintaining immune tolerance and preventing autoimmunity. CD4-positive thymocytes can differentiate into Tregs when they encounter high levels of self-antigens presented by MHC class II molecules on cTECs. This process results in the production of Tregs that recognize and suppress autoreactive T-cells, thereby preventing autoimmune diseases.
CL:0002470:
MHC-II-positive classical monocytes belong to the family of white blood cells known as monocytes, which play a crucial role in the immune system's defense against pathogens. These cells are identified by the presence of major histocompatibility complex class II (MHC-II) molecules on their surface. MHC-II molecules are responsible for presenting antigens to T cells of the adaptive immune system, thereby initiating an immune response.

Classical monocytes are easily distinguishable from other monocyte subtypes based on their size, morphology, and CD14 expression profile. They are characterized by high expression levels of CD14, CD16, and MHC-II molecules. Additionally, these cells have a distinct gene expression profile, with several genes encoding immune-related molecules, such as cytokines and receptors, highly expressed.

MHC-II-positive classical monocytes play a pivotal role in the initiation and regulation of immune responses, particularly those involving T cells. These cells are primarily involved in presenting antigens to CD4+ T helper cells, which can differentiate into various effector cells depending on the antigen and the signaling molecules present. Additionally, these cells produce several cytokines, such as interleukin-1 beta (IL-1β), interleukin-6 (IL-6), and tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-α), which play a crucial role in regulating immune responses. Overall, MHC-II-positive classical monocytes are crucial players in the immune system and contribute to the immune response against a variety of pathogens.
CL:0002462:
Adipose dendritic cells (ADCs) are a subtype of dendritic cells (DCs) found in adipose tissue. As part of the immune system, their primary function is to recognize and initiate immune responses against pathogens. However, recent studies have suggested that ADCs play a role in metabolic regulation and the development of obesity-related inflammation.

One of the key features of ADCs is their ability to regulate adipose tissue inflammation in response to changes in energy balance. In lean individuals, ADCs are involved in the maintenance of adipose tissue homeostasis and contribute to the clearance of dead adipocytes. However, in obese individuals, ADCs have been shown to undergo phenotypic changes that impair their function, leading to the development of chronic inflammation and insulin resistance. Understanding the role of ADCs in obesity-related inflammation is of significant interest, as it may provide new targets for therapeutic intervention.

In addition to modulating inflammation and metabolic regulation, ADCs also play a critical role in antigen presentation and T-cell activation. Antigen-presenting cells such as dendritic cells are essential for generating adaptive immune responses against pathogens and cancer cells. ADCs are particularly efficient at driving CD8+ T-cell responses and are involved in the activation of other immune cells, such as natural killer (NK) cells. Overall, the unique properties of ADCs make them intriguing targets for the development of immune modulation and metabolic therapies.
CL:0002473:
MHC-II-high non-classical monocytes, also known as intermediate monocytes, are a unique population of monocytes that exhibit high expression levels of major histocompatibility complex class II (MHC-II) molecules. These cells are identified by their non-classical morphology, which includes a large size, convoluted nuclei and abundant cytoplasm. Intermediate monocytes represent a rare subset of circulating monocytes that account for approximately 2-10% of total monocyte population in human blood. 

These cells have been shown to play an important role in immune defense against various pathogens by acting as antigen-presenting cells to T cells. MHC-II molecules expressed on the surfaces of intermediate monocytes enable them to present peptides derived from phagocytosed pathogens to CD4+ T cells, which initiates a strong immune response against the invading pathogen. Additionally, MHC-II-high non-classical monocytes also produce cytokines and chemokines that assist in the recruitment and activation of other immune cells. These unique features of intermediate monocytes highlight their crucial role in orchestrating immune responses to bacterial, viral and parasitic infections.

Intermediate monocytes have also been recognized as potential biomarkers for various diseases including cardiovascular diseases, autoimmune disorders and cancer. Several studies have reported an elevated population of intermediate monocytes in patients with these diseases compared to healthy individuals. This suggests that intermediate monocytes could represent a promising diagnostic and prognostic indicator for these disorders. Overall, the study of MHC-II-high non-classical monocytes provides critical insights into the intricate mechanisms that govern immune defense and identifies potential therapeutic strategies for treating immune-related disorders.
CL:0002475:
Lymphoid MHC-II-negative non-classical monocytes represent a subset of monocytes that are involved in the innate immune system's response to pathogens and tissue damage. These monocytes derived from bone marrow differentiate into non-classical monocytes and circulate in the bloodstream until they are recruited to sites of inflammation. Unlike classical monocytes, lymphoid MHC-II-negative non-classical monocytes have a unique cell surface marker profile that includes the absence of MHC-II surface proteins.

Upon activation, lymphoid MHC-II-negative non-classical monocytes migrate to sites of inflammation and differentiate into specialized immune cells such as dendritic cells, macrophages, and monocyte-derived suppressor cells. These cells, particularly dendritic cells, are instrumental in presenting antigens to T-cells, which leads to the initiation of an adaptive immune response. Additionally, these cells have been shown to enhance wound healing and tissue regeneration via the production of growth factors and extracellular matrix components.

Lymphoid MHC-II-negative non-classical monocytes have also been implicated in the etiology of various inflammatory diseases, such as sepsis, rheumatoid arthritis, and atherosclerosis. In these conditions, the cells can promote inflammation and tissue damage via the secretion of pro-inflammatory cytokines. Overall, lymphoid MHC-II-negative non-classical monocytes are a diverse and functionally important group of immune cells that play a critical role in both the innate and adaptive immune responses to infection and tissue damage.
CL:0002495:
Fetal cardiomyocytes are specialized muscle cells that form the developing heart during fetal development. These cells are responsible for the mechanical contraction of the heart, which is essential for the circulation of blood throughout the body. Fetal cardiomyocytes are unique in that they are able to divide and differentiate into various cell types, allowing for the growth and development of the heart.

The function of fetal cardiomyocytes is critical for the development and functioning of the cardiovascular system. The cells work together to create a synchronized contraction of the heart, which allows for the proper beat of the heart. This contraction is controlled by specialized cells called pacemaker cells, which initiate the electrical impulses that cause the heart to contract rhythmically. Fetal cardiomyocytes also play a crucial role in responding to stress and injury, repairing and renewing damaged adult heart tissue.

Moreover, fetal cardiomyocytes have been implicated in various pathologies, such as congenital heart defects and heart failure. Understanding the molecular mechanisms of cardiomyocyte development and function is essential for developing new therapeutic interventions for these diseases. The research on fetal cardiomyocytes is vital to advance the field of cardiovascular biology, and may provide new insights into the diagnosis and treatment of heart diseases.
CL:0002486:
Strial intermediate cells, also known as intermediate cells of the cochlear stria vascularis, are specialized cells found in the cochlea of the inner ear. These cells play a vital role in maintaining the endocochlear potential, which is necessary for hearing. Strial intermediate cells are unique in their ability to secrete potassium ions, which are essential for the function of the hair cells in the organ of Corti. 

Strial intermediate cells are located in the lateral wall of the cochlea, where they form part of the stria vascularis. The stria vascularis is a strip of tissue that runs along the cochlear duct and is responsible for generating the endocochlear potential. This potential is created by the active transport of ions, specifically potassium ions, from the blood to the endolymph. Strial intermediate cells are responsible for secreting the potassium ions that are essential for this process. 

Due to their crucial role in maintaining the endocochlear potential, any damage to strial intermediate cells can lead to hearing loss. Studies have shown that age-related hearing loss is associated with a decrease in the number of strial intermediate cells, and noise-induced hearing loss can cause damage to these cells as well. Therefore, understanding the function and physiology of strial intermediate cells is essential for developing therapies to treat hearing loss.
CL:0002430:
CD4-intermediate, CD8-positive double-positive thymocytes are a subset of developing T cells that are found in the thymus gland. Unlike other thymocytes, which are either CD4+ or CD8+, double-positive thymocytes co-express both CD4 and CD8 co-receptor molecules on their cell surface while maintaining intermediate levels of T-cell receptor (TCR) expression. The expression of both CD4 and CD8 is crucial for the selection of appropriate T cells for self and non-self-recognition. Double-positive thymocytes go through positive and negative selection processes that help in determining whether they will be positively selected to become a CD4+ or CD8+ single-positive T cell, or undergo apoptosis-mediated negative selection.

Double-positive thymocytes carry out several functions during their development in the thymus. One of the most critical functions of double-positive thymocytes is to undergo positive and negative selection processes that lead to the selection of T cells that are self-tolerant and capable of recognizing foreign antigens. Positive selection helps in selecting thymocytes that can recognize self-antigens presented by major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules. Negative selection eliminates thymocytes that react to self-antigens with high affinity, while maintaining responsiveness to foreign antigens. Thymocytes that pass positive and negative selection give rise to mature T cells that play key roles in the immune response.

In summary, CD4-intermediate, CD8-positive double-positive thymocytes are a critical subset of developing T cells that undergo key selection processes in the thymus to ensure that the ensuing T cell population is self-tolerant and has the ability to recognize foreign antigens. The co-expression of both CD4 and CD8 co-receptors on the surface of these cells is crucial for their differentiation and selection processes. Understanding the functional characteristics of double-positive thymocytes is therefore important for the development of immunotherapeutic strategies aimed at enhancing immune function in pathological conditions such as autoimmune disorders and cancer.
CL:0002492:
The strial marginal cell is a specialized type of epithelial cell located in the cochlea of the inner ear. As part of the lateral wall of the cochlea, it plays a critical role in maintaining the ionic and fluid balance necessary for proper auditory function. In particular, the stria vascularis, which contains the strial marginal cells, generates the endocochlear potential (EP) that is necessary for hair cell transduction and hearing sensitivity.

Structurally, the strial marginal cells contain numerous mitochondria and transporters that assist in the production and secretion of potassium ions into the scala media. This process is essential for the maintenance of the EP, as well as the replenishment of the sensory hair cells' potassium. The stria vascularis also functions as a metabolic barrier between the blood supply and the scala media, protecting the delicate inner ear from toxins and other harmful substances.

Given its crucial role in maintaining cochlear homeostasis, dysfunction of the stria vascularis and its marginal cells can lead to a range of hearing disorders, including tinnitus, sensorineural hearing loss, and presbycusis. Research into the molecular and cellular mechanisms that underlie the function of the strial marginal cell is ongoing, and a greater understanding of this critical cell type could lead to new treatments for hearing-related disorders.
CL:0002449:
CD94-positive Ly49CI-positive natural killer (NK) cells are a subset of innate lymphoid cells found in mice. These cells express the CD94 receptor, which recognizes major histocompatibility complex class I molecules, and Ly49CI, which recognizes self-MHC class I molecules. This dual specificity enables CD94-positive Ly49CI-positive NK cells to distinguish between healthy, self cells and virally infected or cancerous cells that express altered or reduced levels of MHC class I molecules. 

Once activated, CD94-positive Ly49CI-positive NK cells rapidly produce and release cytotoxic granules, which contain perforin and granzymes, that induce apoptosis in the target cells. In addition to killing virally infected and tumor cells, these NK cells also produce cytokines, such as interferon-gamma and tumor necrosis factor-alpha, that stimulate the immune response and activate other immune cells. CD94-positive Ly49CI-positive NK cells thus play an important role in the early detection and elimination of infected and transformed cells, helping to safeguard the host against infectious diseases and cancer. 

Moreover, recent studies have also linked CD94-positive Ly49CI-positive NK cells to the maintenance of tissue homeostasis and the regulation of inflammatory responses. Specifically, these cells have been shown to interact with dendritic cells and regulate their activation and migration, as well as to modulate the development and function of other immune cells, such as T cells. Thus, CD94-positive Ly49CI-positive NK cells are emerging as a key player in the innate immune system that not only provides the first line of defense against infections and cancer, but also coordinates and regulates the subsequent adaptive immune response.
CL:0002481:
Peritubular myoid cells, also known as peritubular smooth muscle cells, are unique cells found surrounding the seminiferous tubules within the testes. These cells are known for their contractile abilities, allowing them to regulate blood flow through the testes and create a favorable environment for sperm maturation. Peritubular myoid cells achieve this by contracting and relaxing, thereby expelling remnants of the seminiferous epithelium that enter the lumen of the tubule, thus sweeping seminal fluid towards the epididymis.

In addition to contributing to the regulation of blood flow, peritubular myoid cells also play a crucial role in the process of spermatogenesis. They create the physical structure that separates and supports developing sperm during their maturation, ensuring their correct alignment within the seminiferous tubule. Peritubular myoid cells also provide a steady supply of nutrients to developing germ cells via their close proximity to the blood vessels.

Finally, these cells have been shown to play a critical role in the immune defense of the testes, serving as a barrier between circulating immune cells and the delicate seminiferous tubule. They do this by producing several cytokines and growth factors, which help regulate the immune response in the testes, preventing damage to developing germ cells and ensuring their complete development. In summary, the peritubular myoid cell is an intricate component of the male reproductive system that is essential for blood flow regulation, immune function and the support of spermatogenesis.
CL:0002472:
MHC-II-low non-classical monocytes are a distinct subset of monocytes circulating in the bloodstream, accounting for less than 10% of the total monocyte population. These cells are characterized by the low expression of major histocompatibility complex class II (MHC-II) molecules, which play a key role in the presentation of antigens to T cells. Instead, MHC-II-low non-classical monocytes express high levels of CD14 and CD16, and are therefore also referred to as CD14+CD16+ monocytes. 

Studies have shown that MHC-II-low non-classical monocytes play a crucial role in the immune response against viral infections, as well as in the resolution of inflammation. These cells are potent producers of antiviral cytokines, such as interferon-alpha (IFN-α), and are able to directly kill virus-infected cells through the release of cytotoxic granules. In addition, MHC-II-low non-classical monocytes have been shown to efficiently migrate to sites of inflammation and to phagocytose apoptotic cells, contributing to the resolution of tissue damage and preventing the development of chronic inflammation. 

Recent evidence suggests that MHC-II-low non-classical monocytes may also play a role in the pathogenesis of autoimmune and inflammatory disorders, such as rheumatoid arthritis and multiple sclerosis. Dysregulated activation of these cells has been associated with the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines and the exacerbation of tissue damage. Thus, a better understanding of the function of MHC-II-low non-classical monocytes may provide insights into the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of immune-mediated diseases.
CL:0002502:
Type M enteroendocrine cells are specialized cells found in the intestinal tissues of mammals and are involved in regulating various aspects of gut function. They are named after their ability to secrete motilin, a hormone that stimulates gastrointestinal contractions and is important for digestive motility. These cells also produce other hormone peptides, such as glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) and peptide YY (PYY), which help regulate glucose homeostasis and satiety.

Type M enteroendocrine cells are distributed along the length of the small intestine, with the highest concentration in the duodenum. They are linked to the nervous system through receptors for neuropeptides and neurotransmitters, which allows them to respond to changes in the gut environment. In addition to their role in hormone secretion, type M enteroendocrine cells also act as a sensor for luminal nutrients and microorganisms, providing an important link between the gut microbiota and host metabolism.

The alteration of type M enteroendocrine cell function has been associated with various gastrointestinal disorders, such as inflammatory bowel disease and irritable bowel syndrome. Therefore, understanding the biology of these cells may lead to the development of new therapeutics for the treatment of these conditions.
CL:0002484:
Epithelial melanocytes are specialized cells found in the skin and hair follicles that produce and distribute melanin, the pigment responsible for skin color. These cells are derived from the neural crest and migrate to the epidermis during development. In the skin, melanocytes are located in the bottom layer of the epidermis and along hair follicles, where they transfer melanin-containing vesicles to nearby keratinocytes.

The primary function of epithelial melanocytes is to protect the skin from damage caused by UV radiation. Melanin absorbs UV radiation and converts it into heat, preventing it from reaching and damaging DNA within skin cells. Melanocytes also play a role in regulating body temperature by increasing or decreasing the distribution of melanin in response to changes in environmental temperature.

Defects in melanocyte function can lead to diseases such as albinism, vitiligo, and melanoma. Albinism is a genetic condition characterized by a partial or complete lack of melanin, resulting in very light-colored skin, hair, and eyes. Vitiligo is a condition in which melanocytes are destroyed, leading to patches of depigmented skin. Melanoma is a form of skin cancer that arises from the transformation of melanocytes. Understanding the function and regulation of epithelial melanocytes is crucial to the development of treatments for these diseases.
CL:0002476:
Bone marrow macrophages are a type of immune cell that are derived from hematopoietic stem cells in the bone marrow. Macrophages are phagocytic, meaning that they can engulf and digest foreign particles, such as bacteria and cell debris. Specifically, bone marrow macrophages play a crucial role in the development and maintenance of the bone tissue microenvironment. 

One of the main functions of bone marrow macrophages is to regulate the activity of osteoclasts, cells that break down bone tissue during normal bone remodeling or in disease conditions such as osteoporosis. In this capacity, macrophages can release factors that promote osteoclastogenesis or inhibit its activity, depending on the bone tissue’s needs. Additionally, bone marrow macrophages also play a role in the formation of new bone tissue, also known as osteogenesis. Through complex signaling pathways that involve cytokines, growth factors, and extracellular matrix proteins, bone marrow macrophages can regulate the activity of osteoblasts, cells that build new bone tissue.

Moreover, bone marrow macrophages are key players in the immune system. They can recognize and respond to pathogenic microbes, damaged cells, or other foreign substances in the tissue, and recruit other immune cells to the site of infection or injury. Bone marrow macrophages also contribute to the clearance of old or dying cells, as well as the resolution of inflammation. Dysregulation of bone marrow macrophage function can lead to a variety of bone disorders and diseases, such as osteopetrosis and osteoarthritis.
CL:0002483:
A hair follicle melanocyte is a specialized type of cell that is found in the skin and is responsible for providing color to hair, skin and eyes. These cells are also known as pigment cells and are responsible for producing melanin, which gives color to the skin, hair and eyes. The melanocytes in hair follicles are located in the bulb of the hair follicle and are responsible for producing melanin, which is then transported to the hair shaft.

The function of hair follicle melanocytes is to protect the skin and hair from the harmful effects of the sun's ultraviolet (UV) rays. Melanin is produced in response to UV radiation, and its presence in the hair and skin helps to absorb and scatter UV light. This is important because exposure to UV radiation can lead to DNA damage and an increased risk of skin cancer. In addition to their protective function, hair follicle melanocytes also play a role in regulating skin and hair color, which is determined by the amount and type of melanin produced.

Studies have also suggested that hair follicle melanocytes may play a role in wound healing and inflammation. One study found that melanocytes can migrate to the site of a wound and may play a role in wound healing by producing growth factors that promote tissue regeneration. Other studies have suggested that hair follicle melanocytes may be involved in regulating immune responses in the skin and may play a role in protecting against infections. Overall, hair follicle melanocytes are an important cell type that plays a critical role in protecting the skin and regulating skin and hair color.
CL:0002506:
Liver CD103-positive dendritic cells (DCs) are immune cells found in the liver that play a crucial role in immune surveillance and tolerance. These cells are positive for the CD103 molecule, which is involved in cell adhesion and migration. Liver CD103-positive DCs are derived from monocytes and can present antigens to T cells, which helps initiate an adaptive immune response.

Liver CD103-positive DCs are specialized in inducing immune tolerance. They act as sentinels surveilling the liver's microenvironment and can interact with various immune and non-immune cells. One unique feature of these cells is their ability to induce the generation of T regulatory (Treg) cells, which help suppress unwanted immune responses. They are able to achieve this through various mechanisms, including the production of cytokines and chemokines that support Treg cell development.

Due to their important role in maintaining immune homeostasis, liver CD103-positive DCs have been implicated in the pathogenesis of various liver diseases, including viral hepatitis and autoimmune liver diseases. A better understanding of the functional characteristics and mechanisms of these cells could lead to new approaches in the diagnosis and treatment of liver diseases.
CL:2000000:
Epidermal melanocytes are a specialized type of cell located in the skin's epidermis responsible for the production of melanin, the pigment that gives skin, hair, and eyes their color. These cells are essential in protecting the skin from the harmful effects of the sun's ultraviolet radiation, as they are the primary cells that produce melanin. Melanin absorbs ultraviolet light and protects the skin from damage that can lead to skin cancer and premature skin aging. 

In addition to their role in producing melanin, epidermal melanocytes also play a crucial role in regulating the immune response in the skin. Melanocytes can directly interact with immune cells in the skin, such as T-cells, and activate them to mount an effective immune response against invading pathogens. Furthermore, melanocytes can produce a wide range of cytokines, growth factors, and other inflammatory mediators, all of which can modulate the local response to infection or other forms of tissue damage.

Finally, epidermal melanocytes also have a role in wound healing and tissue repair. Melanocytes can migrate to the site of injury and produce melanin to aid in the formation of a scar. They can also promote the proliferation and migration of other skin cells and, through the production of cytokines and growth factors, contribute to the remodeling of damaged tissue. Overall, epidermal melanocytes are a vital cell type in the skin that serves multiple essential functions in maintaining the health and integrity of the skin.
CL:1000458:
Melanocytes are specialized cells found in the skin that produce and distribute the pigment melanin, which plays a crucial role in the coloration of the skin, hair, and eyes. Melanocytes are located in the basal layer of the epidermis and are responsible for creating different shades of skin color, ranging from very dark to very light. The function of melanocytes is to protect the skin from damage caused by ultraviolet radiation from the sun by producing melanin, which absorbs the harmful radiation and prevents it from reaching the deeper layers of the skin.

Melanocytes use a complex biosynthetic pathway to create melanin, which is then transported to nearby keratinocytes (skin cells) via a process called melanosome transfer. The melanosome is a specialized organelle that contains the melanin pigment, and it is packaged and transported from the melanocyte to the keratinocyte. Once the melanin is inside the keratinocyte, it is spread evenly throughout the cell, providing protection from sun damage.

Melanocytes are also involved in the development of certain skin diseases, such as melanoma. This is a type of skin cancer that arises from the melanocytes and is one of the most aggressive types of cancer worldwide. Researchers are studying melanocytes to better understand the genetics and signaling pathways involved in the development of melanoma and other skin diseases, with the goal of developing new treatments and therapies that target these cells and their functions.
CL:0002498:
Secondary trophoblast giant cells are a specialized type of cell found in the placenta of rodents. These cells are typically located at the junction between the placental labyrinth and the junctional zone. Unlike other trophoblast cells, secondary trophoblast giant cells do not form a direct interface with fetal blood vessels, but instead interact with maternal decidual cells and the maternal blood supply.

One of the main functions of secondary trophoblast giant cells is the regulation of maternal blood flow. These cells produce and secrete factors that promote the invasion of maternal blood vessels by other placental cell types, such as the invasive trophoblast giant cells that make direct contact with fetal blood vessels. In addition, secondary trophoblast giant cells also secrete factors that promote the growth and development of the placenta, as well as the differentiation of other trophoblast cell types.

Interestingly, secondary trophoblast giant cells also play a role in modulating the maternal immune response to the developing fetus. These cells produce and secrete molecules that promote immune tolerance and prevent the maternal immune system from attacking the developing placenta. This immunomodulatory function is critical for the success of pregnancy, as rejection of the developing fetus by the maternal immune system can lead to miscarriage or fetal growth restriction.
CL:0002500:
P enteroendocrine cells, also known as EC cells, are specialized cells found in the gastrointestinal tract. These cells are responsible for producing and releasing hormones and peptides in response to various stimuli. The hormones and peptides secreted by enteroendocrine cells play important roles in regulating digestion, nutrient absorption, and metabolism.

Enteroendocrine cells have a characteristic shape and distribution throughout the gut lining. They are usually found scattered within the epithelial layer of the intestinal mucosa. Each cell typically contains a single large vesicle that stores and releases its hormonal cargo upon stimulation. These vesicles contain a variety of peptides and hormones, including cholecystokinin (CCK), gastrin, and glucagon-like peptide 1 (GLP-1).

The functions of these hormones are diverse and often interdependent. CCK, for example, is released from enteroendocrine cells in response to dietary fat and protein. It stimulates the release of pancreatic enzymes and bile, which aid in digestion and absorption of nutrients in the small intestine. GLP-1, on the other hand, is produced in response to glucose and promotes insulin secretion from pancreatic beta cells. This hormone helps regulate blood sugar levels and has been used as a therapeutic target for diabetes treatment. Overall, enteroendocrine cells play a critical role in maintaining gut homeostasis and metabolic health.
CL:0002505:
Liver CD103-negative dendritic cells (DCs) are a specialized class of immune cells that play a vital role in maintaining immune homeostasis in the liver. These cells are characterized by their expression of a variety of surface receptors such as CD11b and CD11c but lack the expression of CD103. They arise from bone marrow progenitor cells and are present in substantial numbers in the liver.

Liver CD103-negative DCs function as potent antigen-presenting cells that initiate and modulate adaptive immune responses against liver pathogens such as hepatitis C virus. These DCs play an essential role in the maintenance of immune tolerance by inducing regulatory T cell responses. They can induce liver-specific tolerance by selectively inducing apoptosis of effector T cells, thereby preventing liver damage. They also play a significant role in hepatic fibrosis by promoting the differentiation of collagen-producing fibroblasts.

Liver CD103-negative DCs are crucial components of the liver's immune system and play an essential role in maintaining hepatic immune homeostasis. These cells have unique functional properties that make them potential targets for the treatment of liver diseases such as hepatitis C and liver fibrosis. Further investigation into the biology of these cells will likely lead to the development of novel treatments for liver disease.
CL:0002471:
MHC-II-negative non-classical monocytes are a subtype of monocytes that lack the expression of major histocompatibility complex class II (MHC-II) molecules on their surface. These cells constitute a minor fraction of circulating monocytes but play a crucial role in immune surveillance and innate immune responses. MHC-II-negative non-classical monocytes are also known as patrolling monocytes because of their ability to survey the vascular endothelium and tissues for signs of damage, inflammation, or infection.

Studies have shown that MHC-II-negative non-classical monocytes differentiate from classical monocytes in response to specific chemokines and undergo a unique transcriptional program that endows them with distinct properties. Unlike classical monocytes, MHC-II-negative non-classical monocytes show increased expression of genes involved in phagocytosis, lipid metabolism, and the sensing of danger signals. Moreover, MHC-II-negative non-classical monocytes can rapidly respond to tissue injury or infection by migrating to affected sites and eliminating dead cells, debris, or invading pathogens. In this regard, MHC-II-negative non-classical monocytes are key players in maintaining tissue homeostasis and preventing chronic inflammation.

In summary, MHC-II-negative non-classical monocytes are a rare subset of monocytes that lack MHC-II molecules on their surface and have distinct immunological functions. These cells act as sentinels for peripheral tissues and respond to pathogen-associated molecular patterns or damage-associated molecular patterns by migrating to affected sites and exerting phagocytic and immunomodulatory activities. Understanding the biology of MHC-II-negative non-classical monocytes could pave the way for the development of new therapeutic strategies to target inflammatory diseases or antiviral/antibacterial immunity.
CL:0002499:
Spongiotrophoblast cells are specialized epithelial cells found in the placenta. They are responsible for the exchange of nutrients, waste products, and gases between the mother and the developing fetus. Spongiotrophoblast cells have a sponge-like appearance due to their numerous finger-like projections called microvilli, which increase their surface area for exchange. These cells also secrete hormones that play a crucial role in maintaining pregnancy, including human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) and human placental lactogen (hPL).

During early pregnancy, spongiotrophoblast cells rapidly proliferate and invade the uterine tissue to form the placenta. As the placenta develops, spongiotrophoblast cells differentiate into different subtypes with distinct functions. For example, the syncytiotrophoblast layer, which covers the surface of the placenta, is derived from spongiotrophoblast cells and is responsible for hormone secretion and nutrient transport. Spongiotrophoblast cells also play a role in immune tolerance, as they secrete factors that prevent the maternal immune system from attacking the developing fetus.

In summary, spongiotrophoblast cells are a crucial component of the placenta and play a key role in maintaining a healthy pregnancy. Their ability to exchange nutrients, hormones, and waste products between the mother and fetus, as well as modulate the maternal immune response, make them essential for fetal development and growth.
CL:0002468:
Gr1-low myeloid suppressor cells (GR1-low MDSCs) are a type of myeloid-derived suppressor cell (MDSC) that have been identified to play a crucial role in regulating the immune response in cancer and inflammation. These cells are characterized by low expression of GR1 surface marker, which distinguishes them from their GR1-high counterparts. The function of GR1-low MDSCs is to modulate the immune system by suppressing the activation and proliferation of T cells, B cells, and natural killer (NK) cells, thereby promoting tumor growth and increasing susceptibility to infections.

GR1-low MDSCs have been shown to have potent immunosuppressive abilities, which makes them attractive targets for cancer therapeutic strategies. These cells suppress the immune response through various mechanisms, such as producing high levels of arginase 1, reactive oxygen species (ROS), and nitric oxide (NO), which inhibit T cell proliferation and activity. Additionally, GR1-low MDSCs have been shown to secrete immunosuppressive cytokines such as interleukin (IL)-10 and transforming growth factor (TGF)-β, which further impair the function of effector immune cells.

In summary, GR1-low MDSCs are a subset of MDSCs that play a crucial role in immunoregulation in cancer and inflammation. Their ability to suppress immune cells and promote tumor growth make them an attractive target for cancer therapy. Understanding the function and mechanisms of GR1-low MDSCs will further our knowledge of immunomodulation and aid in the development of novel therapeutic strategies to combat cancer and other immune-related diseases.
CL:0002435:
CD69-positive, CD8-positive single-positive thymocytes are a unique subset of thymocytes that are critical for the development of a functional immune system. These cells undergo a complex process of differentiation within the thymus gland, where they are educated to recognize self- versus non-self-antigens. As CD8+ single-positive thymocytes mature, they acquire the ability to recognize and respond to specific pathogen-derived peptides presented by major histocompatibility complex class I (MHC-I) molecules. The expression of CD69, a type II C-type lectin that is upregulated upon stimulation, on CD8+ single-positive thymocytes is indicative of recent exposure to antigen and activation of the immune system.

Notably, CD69-positive, CD8-positive single-positive thymocytes are also known to undergo programmed cell death, or apoptosis, at a high rate. This is a hallmark of the negative selection process, where thymocytes that recognize self-antigens with high affinity are eliminated to prevent the development of autoimmune disorders. However, a small percentage of CD69-positive, CD8-positive single-positive thymocytes survive negative selection and exit the thymus as mature naïve CD8+ T cells, capable of mounting an adaptive immune response against specific pathogens.

In summary, CD69-positive, CD8-positive single-positive thymocytes are a vital part of the immune system, playing a critical role in the differentiation and negative selection of thymocytes within the thymus gland. These cells have the ability to recognize and respond to specific pathogen-derived peptides presented by MHC-I molecules, and a small subset of these cells survive negative selection to become mature naïve CD8+ T cells. Additionally, the expression of CD69 on these cells is indicative of recent activation of the immune system, making them an essential component of the adaptive immune response against pathogens.
CL:0002491:
Auditory epithelial cells, also known as hair cells, are specialized epithelial cells that play a crucial role in hearing. These cells are found in the cochlea of the inner ear and are responsible for transducing sound waves into electrical impulses that can be interpreted by the brain. There are two types of auditory epithelial cells: inner hair cells and outer hair cells.

Inner hair cells are responsible for the majority of sound transduction in the cochlea. These cells are arranged in a single row and each inner hair cell is directly connected to individual sensory neurons. When sound waves enter the cochlea, they cause the inner hair cells to vibrate, triggering ion channels to open and generate an electrical signal that is transmitted to the brain via the auditory nerve.

Outer hair cells, on the other hand, amplify and sharpen sound waves in order to improve hearing sensitivity and discrimination. These cells are arranged in three rows and are connected to surrounding supporting cells. When outer hair cells are stimulated by sound waves, they undergo rapid changes in shape that amplify and focus the incoming sound waves, enhancing the sensitivity of inner hair cells and improving the cochlea's ability to distinguish different frequencies of sound.

In summary, auditory epithelial cells are specialized cells found in the cochlea that are essential for hearing by transducing sound waves into electrical signals that can be interpreted by the brain. Inner hair cells are responsible for sound transduction, while outer hair cells amplify and sharpen sound waves to improve hearing sensitivity and discrimination.
CL:0002559:
Hair follicle cells are a group of diverse cells that contribute to the structure and function of hair follicles. The hair follicle is composed of several layers of cells, which include the hair shaft, inner and outer root sheath, dermal papilla, and bulb matrix cells. These cells work together to regulate hair growth and support the keratinocytes that form the hair shaft. 

One of the main functions of hair follicle cells is to regulate hair growth through a cyclical process of growth, regression, and rest. The dermal papilla cells, located at the base of the follicle, stimulate hair growth by sending signals to the stem cells in the bulb matrix that initiate hair growth. The inner and outer root sheath cells, on the other hand, support the hair shaft and provide a pathway for its growth. Together, these cells contribute to the regulation of hair growth and maintenance. 

Furthermore, hair follicle cells also have a role in skin homeostasis and wound healing. Follicular stem cells, located in the bulge region, can differentiate into various cell types, including keratinocytes and sebaceous gland cells, which contribute to the formation of the epidermis and secretion of sebum, respectively. Hair follicles also play a crucial role in skin regeneration and wound healing by providing a source of adult stem cells and releasing various growth factors that promote tissue repair. 

Overall, hair follicle cells are a diverse group of cells that contribute to the regulation of hair growth and skin homeostasis. Understanding the functions of these cells can provide insights into the mechanisms underlying hair loss and skin diseases and may lead to the development of new therapies for these conditions.
CL:0002487:
Cutaneous/subcutaneous mechanoreceptor cells are specialized cells found in the skin and subcutaneous tissue that are responsible for detecting mechanical stimuli such as pressure, touch, and vibrations. These sensory cells are essential for the perception of tactile sensations and play a critical role in our ability to recognize textures, shapes, and other physical properties of objects. 

There are several types of cutaneous/subcutaneous mechanoreceptor cells, including Merkel cells, Meissner's corpuscles, Pacinian corpuscles, and Ruffini endings. Each of these cells has a unique structure and responds to different types of mechanical stimuli. For example, Merkel cells are located in the epidermis and respond to sustained pressure, while Meissner's corpuscles are found in the dermis and are sensitive to light touch.

Cutaneous/subcutaneous mechanoreceptor cells are connected to sensory nerve fibers, which transmit information to the central nervous system. This information is then processed and interpreted by the brain, allowing us to perceive sensations such as pressure, texture, and vibrations. Dysfunction or loss of mechanoreceptor cells can lead to impaired tactile perception and sensory deficits, as seen in conditions such as neuropathy and peripheral nerve injury.

In summary, cutaneous/subcutaneous mechanoreceptor cells are specialized sensory cells that play a critical role in our ability to perceive touch, pressure, and other mechanical stimuli. These cells are found throughout the skin and subcutaneous tissue and are connected to sensory nerve fibers, which transmit information to the central nervous system for processing and interpretation. Understanding the function and structure of these cells is essential for developing treatments for sensory disorders and improving our understanding of the mechanisms underlying tactile perception.
CL:0002485:
Retinal melanocytes are specialized cells found in the retina of the eye. They possess pigment granules that are primarily responsible for providing the necessary protection against light damage. These pigments act as a filter that absorbs excessive light while allowing only the appropriate amount to enter the retinal cells to support vision. Additionally, retinal melanocytes are known to play a crucial role in the maintenance of the retinal environment through their effective regulation of ionic and molecular balance. Their function is essential in order to ensure proper neural signaling and photoreceptor health.

The primary function of retinal melanocytes is to provide a protective role against light damage. These cells are strategically located in the retinal epithelium and serve as a shield against excessive light from reaching the photoreceptors. Light that is absorbed by the pigment granules is converted into heat and then dissipated. This mechanism prevents phototoxicity caused by excessive light exposure and prevents damage to the retina, thereby maintaining normal vision. Additionally, the pigment granules of these cells contain specific melanin types that protects the eye from harmful ultraviolet radiation.

Retinal melanocytes also regulate the ionic and molecular balance in the retina. They create a unique environment that supports photoreceptor function and health. The melanin pigment in the cells sequesters specific ions, such as copper and iron, thereby reducing oxidative stress in the surrounding tissues. Furthermore, melanocytes provide a source of growth factors and cytokines that help to maintain a balanced inflammatory response in the retina. These functions together make retinal melanocytes an essential component of the retina that is responsible for both the protection and regulation of the retinal environment.
CL:0002493:
Strial basal cells are specialized cells located in the stria vascularis region of the cochlea in the inner ear. These cells are essential for maintaining the ionic composition of the endolymph, which is crucial for normal hearing. These cells are a part of the blood-labyrinth barrier, which separates the inner ear fluids from the rest of the body. This barrier is important for maintaining the unique composition of the endolymph, which is necessary for the transduction of sound waves into nerve impulses. 

The main function of strial basal cells is to support the production of endolymph by supplying potassium ions to the endolymphatic space. These cells have an abundance of mitochondria that produce ATP to drive the activity of the Na+/K+-ATPase pump, which pumps out sodium ions and brings in potassium ions. The high concentration of potassium ions in the endolymph is crucial for sound transduction in the cochlea. In addition, strial basal cells also produce and secrete several growth factors that are important for the maintenance of the organ of Corti, which consists of sensory hair cells and supporting cells that are responsible for detecting and transmitting sound signals. 

The dysfunction or loss of strial basal cells can result in a significant reduction in the endolymphatic potential, which can lead to hearing loss and balance disorders. Furthermore, the age-related decline in the number and function of strial basal cells has been implicated in presbyacusis or age-related hearing loss. Therefore, understanding the function and regulation of strial basal cells is crucial for the development of new therapies for hearing impairment and balance disorders.
CL:0002501:
Type D1 enteroendocrine cells are specialized cells found in the gastrointestinal tract that produce hormones and peptides in response to various stimuli, such as nutrients or neural signals. These cells are primarily located in the small intestine and colon, and have been shown to play important roles in regulating glucose homeostasis, appetite, and gut motility. The hormones produced by D1 cells include glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1), which stimulates insulin secretion and reduces appetite, and peptide YY (PYY), which inhibits gastric emptying and reduces food intake.

One of the unique characteristics of D1 cells is their ability to detect and respond to different types of stimuli, including nutrients, bacterial products, and neurotransmitters. For example, GLP-1 secretion is stimulated by the presence of glucose and other nutrients in the small intestine, while PYY secretion is stimulated by the presence of fat in the colon. These responses are mediated by specific receptors expressed on the surface of D1 cells, which activate intracellular signaling pathways to regulate hormone secretion.

Overall, the function of D1 enteroendocrine cells is to help regulate the digestive and metabolic processes in the body, through the secretion of hormones and peptides that act on various organs and tissues. In addition to their role in glucose homeostasis and appetite regulation, D1 cells have also been implicated in the control of gut motility, inflammation, and intestinal barrier function. Understanding the physiology of D1 cells may have important implications for the development of new therapies for metabolic and gastrointestinal disorders, such as diabetes, obesity, and inflammatory bowel disease.
CL:0002488:
Trophoblast giant cells (TGCs) are specialized cells found in the placenta that play a vital role in the development and maintenance of pregnancy. These cells are derived from the trophectoderm, a layer of cells that surround the blastocyst, and invade the maternal uterine tissue to establish a connection between the developing fetus and the mother. TGCs are characterized by their large size and the presence of multiple nuclei, which are a result of their ability to undergo endoreduplication, a process in which DNA replication occurs without subsequent cell division.

The primary function of TGCs is to facilitate the exchange of nutrients and oxygen between the maternal and fetal circulation. TGCs are involved in the construction of the placental labyrinth, a highly branched network of fetal blood vessels that interfaces with maternal blood vessels within the placenta. Through their invasive properties, TGCs promote the development of the labyrinth by modulating maternal blood vessels into forming the spiral arteries that feed the placenta. TGCs also secrete factors that promote the growth and differentiation of the fetal vasculature and support the function of the maternal immune system during pregnancy.

In addition to their essential role in placental development, TGCs have been implicated in various pregnancy-related pathologies, such as preeclampsia and fetal growth restriction. Dysregulation of TGC function and invasion has been associated with the development of these disorders, highlighting the importance of understanding the biology of TGCs in the context of pregnancy. Overall, TGCs are a critical cell type that ensures the proper growth and development of the fetus during pregnancy.
CL:0002507:
Langerin-positive lymph node dendritic cells (Langerin+ LN DCs) are a subtype of dendritic cells that play a crucial role in the initiation and regulation of adaptive immune responses. These cells are characterized by their expression of Langerin, a type II transmembrane C-type lectin receptor that is involved in antigen uptake, processing, and presentation.

Langerin+ LN DCs are mainly found in the lymph nodes, where they are strategically positioned to capture and transport antigens from peripheral tissues to the lymphoid organs for presentation to T cells. Upon encountering an antigen, Langerin+ LN DCs undergo a process of maturation that involves upregulation of co-stimulatory molecules and cytokine production, which enables them to efficiently activate T cells. Once activated, T cells differentiate into effector cells that can migrate to the site of infection or inflammation to eliminate pathogens or mediate immune responses.

In addition to their role in immunity, Langerin+ LN DCs have also been implicated in immune tolerance and the induction of peripheral tolerance. It has been shown that Langerin+ LN DCs can induce the differentiation of regulatory T cells (Tregs) that suppress immune responses and prevent autoimmunity. Therefore, understanding the biology of Langerin+ LN DCs is critical for the development of new immunotherapeutic strategies for the treatment of various infectious and autoimmune diseases.
CL:0002541:
Chorionic membrane mesenchymal stem cells (CMMSCs) are a type of stem cell found in the chorionic membrane, or placenta, of human fetuses. These cells have the remarkable ability to differentiate into a variety of cell types, including bone, cartilage, and adipose tissue, making them a valuable tool for regenerative medicine. 

In addition to their differentiation potential, CMMSCs also have unique immunomodulatory properties, allowing them to suppress the activity of immune cells and promote tissue repair. Studies have shown that CMMSCs can be used to treat a variety of diseases, including bone defects, heart disease, and autoimmune disorders.

Furthermore, CMMSCs are easily accessible and can be obtained non-invasively, making them a desirable source of stem cells for medical applications. Given their potential for differentiation and immunomodulation, CMMSCs hold great promise for the development of novel therapies for a range of diseases.
CL:0002503:
Adventitial cells are a type of stromal cell that are found in the outer layer of blood vessels, known as the adventitia. These cells play an important role in maintaining the structural integrity of blood vessels, as well as regulating cellular interactions with the surrounding tissue. Adventitial cells are thought to play a key role in the development of vascular diseases, such as atherosclerosis, as well as in the repair and remodeling of damaged vessels.

The primary function of adventitial cells is to provide structural support to the blood vessel wall. This is achieved through the secretion of extracellular matrix components, such as collagen, elastin, and fibronectin, which form the backbone of the vessel wall. Adventitial cells also supply nutrients and oxygen to the overlying layers of cells, including the endothelium, which lines the interior of the vessel, and the smooth muscle cells, which control vessel diameter.

In addition to their structural function, adventitial cells also play a critical role in maintaining the balance of inflammatory and immune cells within the tissue. These cells are thought to modulate the immune response to injury and infection, as well as regulate the migration and recruitment of various immune cells to the site of injury. As such, adventitial cells have been implicated in the pathophysiology of many vascular diseases, including atherosclerosis, thrombosis, and restenosis.
CL:0002510:
CD103-negative, langerin-positive lymph node dendritic cells (LNDCs) are a subset of immune cells that are found in lymph nodes and play a critical role in immune response regulation. These cells are known for their ability to recognize and capture antigens, which are then presented to T cells to activate an immune response. The presence of langerin, a protein found on the surface of these cells, helps to distinguish them from other dendritic cell subsets.

LNDCs lacking CD103 expression are believed to be involved in the initiation of immune responses. This is because they are able to effectively capture and present antigens to T cells, which are then activated to mount a specific immune response. Additionally, langerin expression on the surface of these cells enables them to recognize and capture antigens present on viruses, bacteria, and other invading pathogens. This makes CD103-negative, langerin-positive LNDCs important players in the early stages of an immune response.

In addition to their role in immune response regulation, CD103-negative, langerin-positive LNDCs are also thought to have a role in immune tolerance. This is because they are able to capture self-antigens, which can then be presented to T cells to promote immune tolerance and prevent autoimmune responses from developing. Overall, the presence of CD103-negative, langerin-positive LNDCs in lymph nodes is important for maintaining a balanced immune response, and understanding their function is critical for developing effective immunotherapies and vaccines.
CL:0002518:
Kidney epithelial cells are the basic functional unit of the kidneys and are responsible for carrying out the majority of kidney functions. These cells line the tubules and ducts within the kidneys and are involved in the filtration and reabsorption of various substances, such as salts, water, glucose, and amino acids, from the blood. They play a crucial role in maintaining electrolyte balance, removing waste and excess fluids from the body, and regulating blood pressure.

In addition to their filtration and reabsorption functions, kidney epithelial cells also participate in the secretion and reabsorption of hormones and other signaling molecules. For example, the cells of the adrenal cortex secrete aldosterone, which acts on the kidney epithelial cells to increase the reabsorption of sodium ions and the excretion of potassium ions. Kidney epithelial cells are also involved in the conversion of vitamin D into its active form, which is important for calcium absorption and bone health.

Kidney epithelial cells are highly specialized and have a unique structure that allows them to carry out their multifaceted functions. Because the kidneys play such a critical role in maintaining overall health and well-being, understanding the biology of kidney epithelial cells is crucial for developing effective treatments for kidney diseases and disorders, such as chronic kidney disease, kidney stones, and cystic kidney disease.
CL:0002524:
Disseminated nephrocytes are specialized cells found in the circulatory system of arthropods. These cells play a crucial role in filtering the hemolymph, which is the insect equivalent of blood. Disseminated nephrocytes serve a function similar to the glomerulus of mammalian kidneys. They are responsible for the elimination of waste products and the regulation of ion and water balance within the hemolymph.

In addition to their excretory function, disseminated nephrocytes also play a role in the immune response of insects. These cells are capable of recognizing and engulfing foreign particles, such as bacteria and viruses, that may be present in the hemolymph. Once engulfed, these particles are destroyed by lysosomal enzymes present within the disseminated nephrocytes.

Despite their important role in insect physiology, the function of disseminated nephrocytes is not well understood. Further research is needed to elucidate the complex mechanisms by which these cells carry out their excretory and immune functions. Nonetheless, disseminated nephrocytes are a fascinating example of the diversity of cell types found in nature and the intricate ways in which they contribute to the overall function of an organism.
CL:0002497:
Primary trophoblast giant cells are specialized, non-proliferative cells that arise from the trophectoderm layer of the blastocyst and form the outer layer of the placental labyrinth in rodents. These cells are essential for proper placental development and function, and they play a crucial role in facilitating communication between the maternal and fetal circulations. Primary trophoblast giant cells are defined by their unique morphology, with large, polyploid nuclei and abundant cytoplasm containing numerous organelles.

One of the primary functions of primary trophoblast giant cells is to secrete a variety of hormones and cytokines that regulate maternal-fetal communication and placental development. For example, these cells produce placental lactogens, which stimulate maternal mammary gland growth and milk production, and murine placental growth hormone, which regulates fetal growth and development.
