Endothelial cells of arterioles are a specialized type of endothelial cell that line the interior of small arteries known as arterioles. These cells play a crucial role in regulating blood pressure and blood flow throughout the body. They help to control the diameter of arterioles and therefore the amount of blood that flows through them. When the body requires more oxygen and nutrients, the endothelial cells of arterioles will dilate, allowing more blood to flow through and reach the tissues and organs that need it most.

In addition to their role in controlling blood flow, endothelial cells of arterioles also play a key role in maintaining the integrity of the blood vessel wall. They act as a barrier, preventing harmful substances from entering the bloodstream and protecting the tissues and organs from damage. These cells also produce a number of molecules that promote blood clotting and prevent excessive bleeding from injuries.

Diseases that affect the endothelial cells of arterioles can have serious consequences for cardiovascular health. For example, damage to these cells can lead to high blood pressure, as the arterioles are unable to dilate properly and regulate blood flow. This, in turn, can increase the risk of heart attack, stroke, and other serious complications. Understanding the function and structure of these specialized cells is therefore essential for developing effective treatments for cardiovascular diseases.
CL:1000373:
The transitional myocyte of the ventricular part of the atrioventricular (AV) bundle is a specialized cardiac muscle cell found in the heart's conduction system. Known for its critical function in regulating the heartbeat, the transitional myocyte is located in the electrical pathway of the heart between the atria and ventricles. These cells connect the AV node to the bundle branches and play a significant role in ensuring the coordinated contractions of the heart.

The transitional myocyte of the AV bundle is distinct from other cardiac muscle cells in terms of the arrangement of its sarcomeres and its electrical properties. These cells have a unique morphology, with a smaller diameter than regular cardiomyocytes, and fewer and shorter sarcomeres. They also have a lower number of T-tubules and a reduced sarcoplasmic reticulum compared to working cardiomyocytes. These adaptations allow them to conduct electrical signals quickly and efficiently, ensuring that the heart contracts in a coordinated manner.

The main function of the transitional myocyte is to facilitate the conduction of electrical impulses from the atria to the ventricles of the heart. These cells act as intermediary cells, connecting the AV node to the bundle branches and Purkinje fibers. By transmitting electrical impulses rapidly and effectively through their specialized conduction system, these cells allow the ventricles to contract in sync, enabling the heart to pump blood efficiently and effectively throughout the body. Dysfunction of the transitional myocyte can lead to a range of heart diseases, including AV block and bundle branch block, which can significantly impair heart function.
CL:1000419:
Myoepithelial cells of lactiferous duct are a specialized type of epithelial cells found in the mammary glands of mammals. These cells are located in the ducts that carry milk from the lobules to the nipple. Myoepithelial cells are responsible for the contraction of the lactiferous ducts, which helps to propel milk through the ducts during lactation. They are also involved in the production and secretion of milk by contracting around the alveoli, pushing the milk out of the gland and into the ducts.

In addition to their role in milk secretion, myoepithelial cells of lactiferous duct have other important functions. They are known to provide mechanical support to the mammary glands and prevent the formation of cysts by regulating the flow of fluids. Myoepithelial cells are also involved in the immune response of the mammary gland. They help to maintain the integrity of the gland by preventing pathogens and toxins from entering and causing infection.

In conclusion, myoepithelial cells of lactiferous duct play a vital role in milk production and secretion, as well as providing mechanical support and protecting the mammary gland from infection. Their unique contractile and immune functions make them an essential component of the mammary gland and important in the maintenance of lactation and overall health of the gland.
CL:2000046:
Ventricular cardiac muscle cells, also known as ventricular myocytes, are a type of muscle cell that is found specifically in the ventricles of the heart. These cells work together to generate the force required to pump blood out of the heart and into the circulatory system. Ventricular cardiac muscle cells are unique in their cellular structure and function, which allows for the efficient contraction and relaxation necessary for the heart to function properly. 

Ventricular cardiac muscle cells are highly specialized cells that have a distinct shape and structure. They are long and cylindrical in shape, with a single nucleus located towards one end of the cell. The cytoplasm of the cell is full of sarcomeres, the functional units responsible for muscle contraction. These sarcomeres contain filaments of actin and myosin, which slide past each other during muscle contraction, resulting in the shortening of the muscle cell. 

The function of ventricular cardiac muscle cells is essential to the overall function of the heart. When an electrical impulse, generated by the sinoatrial node, reaches the ventricles, it triggers a series of events that lead to the contraction of the ventricular cardiac muscle cells. This causes the ventricles to contract and blood to be pumped out of the heart and into the circulation. Ventricular cardiac muscle cells are able to contract forcefully, which is necessary to maintain adequate blood flow throughout the body. Additionally, these cells are able to rapidly and efficiently relax between contractions, allowing for the proper filling of the heart chambers before the next contraction occurs.
CL:1000418:
Myoepithelial cells of the lactiferous alveolus are a type of specialized epithelial cells that play a key role in the mammary gland. These cells are located between secretory epithelial cells and basal lamina in lactiferous alveoli, small sacs that produce milk during lactation. The main function of myoepithelial cells in lactiferous alveoli is to contract and squeeze milk out of the alveoli and into the ducts during breastfeeding.

Myoepithelial cells are characterized by their spindle-shaped morphology and the presence of myofilaments such as actin and myosin, which are the contractile machinery responsible for their function. In response to hormonal and neural signals, myoepithelial cells contract and surround the alveoli, forcing milk out into the mammary ducts. This process is critical for milk production and regulation during lactation.

Myoepithelial cells of the lactiferous alveolus also play an important role in the maintenance of the mammary gland architecture and composition. They provide structural support for the alveoli and help to maintain tissue organization and homeostasis. Dysregulation of myoepithelial cells has been implicated in breast cancer development and progression, highlighting their importance in mammary gland function and disease.
CL:1000420:
Myoepithelial cells of the terminal lactiferous duct are specialized cells found in the mammary gland. They are located in the outermost layer of the ducts and are responsible for contracting and relaxing the ducts, allowing milk to be expelled from the gland. Myoepithelial cells are categorized as smooth muscle cells and have similar contractile properties. These spindle-shaped cells have a large nucleus and abundant cytoplasm.

The primary function of myoepithelial cells of the terminal lactiferous duct is to assist in the milk ejection process during lactation. They contract in response to oxytocin, a hormone released during breastfeeding, and push the milk out of the gland and into the nipple. In addition, myoepithelial cells are also responsible for regulating the flow of milk by constricting or dilating the ducts, based on the need for milk delivery.

Myoepithelial cells of the terminal lactiferous duct are essential for normal lactation and the proper functioning of the mammary gland. These cells are also important in breast cancer research, as they are often involved in the development and progression of breast cancer. Studying the behavior and function of myoepithelial cells in breast cancer can lead to better understanding and treatments for this disease.
CL:1000397:
Endothelial cells are one of the most abundant cell types in the body and play a crucial role in maintaining the barrier between blood vessels and surrounding tissues. The endothelial cells of the venous sinus of red pulp of spleen are a unique subset of these cells found within the spleen. These cells line the walls of the venous sinus and are critical in maintaining the proper microenvironment for immune cell trafficking.

In the red pulp of the spleen, endothelial cells of the venous sinus are involved in the removal of aged and damaged erythrocytes from the circulation. These cells are able to recognize and phagocytose erythrocytes that are no longer viable, preventing them from accumulating within the spleen and causing damage. Additionally, the endothelial cells of the venous sinus play an important role in regulating the immune response within the spleen. These cells are able to present antigens to immune cells, helping to initiate an appropriate immune response to infection or other challenges.

Overall, the endothelial cells of the venous sinus of red pulp of spleen play a critical role in maintaining the proper function of the spleen. These cells are involved in the removal of damaged erythrocytes and in regulating the immune response within the spleen. Understanding the function of these cells is important for developing therapies to treat diseases that affect the spleen, such as splenomegaly and other immune disorders.

Microfold cells (M cells) are specialized epithelial cells located in the follicle-associated epithelium (FAE) of Peyer's patches and intestinal crypts, but they have also been identified in various other tissues such as the appendix. The microfold cell of epithelium proper of appendix, also known as the follicle-associated epithelium microfold cell of appendix, serves as a gateway for antigenic compounds and microorganisms from the lumen into the immune system. These cells lack the thick mucus layer and tight junctions that normally restrict antigenic particles in the intestines. Their apical surface forms a pocket-like structure overlying the underlying lymphoid follicle, with gaps between the cells that allow for direct contact with the immune cells. 

The immune system relies on microfold cells to sample the gut lumen of pathogens and foreign molecules through antigen uptake and transcytosis to deliver antigens to underlying lymphoid tissues to initiate the immune responses. This relays immune messages to dendritic cells, B and T lymphocytes, and macrophages, triggering the production of specific IgA antibodies which neutralize toxins and pathogens, eventually preventing the invasion of pathogens from the gut mucosa into the bloodstream. Microfold cells also provide a mechanism for the transfer of harmless antigens such as those from commensal flora or food across the epithelium to promote immune tolerance in the gut-associated lymphoid tissue.

In summary, microfold cells of epithelium proper of appendix are specialized cells found in the appendix that transport antigens and microbes from the gut lumen to the underlying lymphoid tissue to promote immune responses. These cells play a vital role in protecting the host against pathogenic invasion while also facilitating exposure to commensal flora and dietary antigens that induce tolerance and prevent inflammatory reactions.

Myoepithelial cells are specialized cells that are found in many glandular organs, including the mammary gland. Within the mammary gland, myoepithelial cells are found in the intralobular lactiferous ducts. These cells are responsible for the contraction of the ducts, which helps to move milk towards the nipple during lactation. Myoepithelial cells are essential for the proper function of the mammary gland, and abnormalities in their structure or function can lead to breast diseases.

Myoepithelial cells have a characteristic elongated shape and are located between the basement membrane and the luminal epithelial cells of the lactiferous ducts. They have contractile properties that are regulated by a variety of hormonal and signaling pathways. During lactation, myoepithelial cells contract to help propel milk towards the nipple, and they also contribute to the maintenance of the ductal architecture.

In addition to their role in milk secretion, myoepithelial cells are also thought to have a protective function. These cells have been shown to produce and secrete cytokines and growth factors that help to regulate the development and differentiation of the surrounding epithelial cells. Myoepithelial cells also help to maintain the integrity of the basement membrane and provide a physical barrier that can help to prevent the invasion of cancer cells into surrounding tissues. Overall, myoepithelial cells of the intralobular lactiferous duct play a crucial role in mammary gland function and their dysfunction has been implicated in various breast pathologies.

Mesothelial cells are a type of epithelial cell that covers the outer surface of organs and internal cavities. In the anterior chamber of the eye, these cells line the corneal endothelium and the iris. They are responsible for regulating the flow of fluid within the eye by secreting and absorbing aqueous humor. These cells also provide a physical barrier that protects the eye from harmful substances.

In addition to their role in regulating aqueous humor, mesothelial cells of the anterior chamber of the eye are involved in maintaining the transparency of the cornea. They form tight junctions that help to prevent the entry of foreign materials and protect the delicate structures of the eye. These cells also help maintain the shape of the eye by providing mechanical support to the endothelium and iris.

Mesothelial cells of the anterior chamber of the eye play an important role in the health of the eye. Any dysfunction or damage to these cells can result in vision loss and other eye disorders. Understanding the characteristics and function of these cells can aid in the diagnosis and treatment of conditions such as glaucoma and uveitis.

Transitional myocytes of atrial septal branch of anterior internodal tract are cells with distinct morphological and electrophysiological features that make them essential for the normal excitation-contraction coupling of the heart. These cells are located in the atrial septum, specifically in the anterior internodal tract, and play a crucial role in atrioventricular (AV) conduction, which is the process of transmitting electrical impulses from the atria to the ventricles.

The function of transitional myocytes of atrial septal branch of anterior internodal tract is to facilitate the conduction of electrical impulses from the sinoatrial node (SA node) to the AV node, which in turn induces ventricular contraction. These cells are unique because they possess both atrial and nodal-like properties, which allows them to serve as a bridge between the two nodes and modulate the electrical impulses as they travel through the heart. Additionally, transitional myocytes of atrial septal branch of anterior internodal tract play a significant role in maintaining the rhythm of the heart as they help prevent the formation of abnormal electrical pathways that could result in arrhythmias.

Overall, transitional myocytes of atrial septal branch of anterior internodal tract are an essential component of the cardiac conduction system. Their unique morphological and electrophysiological properties enable them to modulate the electrical impulses as they travel through the heart and maintain the appropriate rhythm and function of the heart. Dysfunction or damage to these cells can result in a range of cardiac arrhythmias, highlighting their crucial role in the proper functioning of the heart.

The transitional myocyte of the posterior division of the left branch of atrioventricular bundle is a specialized cardiac muscle cell that is essential for the proper conduction of electrical impulses throughout the heart. This cell type is important in regulating the rhythm of the heart and ensuring proper blood flow throughout the body. These cells have a unique structure and function that allows them to rapidly conduct electrical impulses in a coordinated manner.

The cells of the atrioventricular bundle are responsible for conducting the electrical impulses that allow for the contraction of the ventricles, which is essential for the proper functioning of the heart. The transitional myocytes of the posterior division of the left branch of atrioventricular bundle are responsible for transmitting electrical impulses from the atrioventricular node to the bundle branches. The rapid and coordinated conduction of these impulses is essential for maintaining normal heart rhythm and ensuring proper blood flow throughout the body.

In addition to their important role in the conduction of electrical impulses in the heart, the transitional myocytes of the posterior division of the left branch of atrioventricular bundle are also involved in regulating the contraction of the heart muscle. Overall, the transitional myocytes of the posterior division of the left branch of atrioventricular bundle are an essential component of the heart's electrical and mechanical systems, and their proper function is critical for maintaining normal heart rhythm and flow.

Type 1 vestibular sensory cells are a specialized type of sensory cell that are found in the epithelium of the macula of the utricle within the membranous labyrinth of the inner ear. These cells are important for detecting changes in head position and linear acceleration, which is critical for maintaining balance and stability of the body. Type 1 vestibular sensory cells have a unique structure, with a large cell body and a single, elongated stereocilium that extends from the apical surface of the cell.

The function of type 1 vestibular sensory cells is to detect movement of the otolithic membrane in the utricle, which is responsible for detecting changes in head position and linear acceleration. The stereocilia of the type 1 vestibular sensory cells are embedded in a gelatinous layer called the otolithic membrane, which contains microscopic crystals of calcium carbonate called otoliths. When the head moves, the otoliths move in response to changes in acceleration, and this movement causes the otolithic membrane to shear along the surface of the type 1 vestibular sensory cells. This shearing force causes the stereocilia to bend, which triggers an influx of calcium ions into the cell and initiates a nerve impulse that is transmitted to the brain.

Overall, type 1 vestibular sensory cells play a critical role in maintaining balance and spatial orientation of the body. Dysfunction of these cells can result in a variety of balance disorders, which can greatly impact an individual's quality of life. By understanding the function and structure of type 1 vestibular sensory cells, researchers hope to develop new treatments and therapies for individuals with balance disorders and other related conditions.

Epithelial cells of the nasolacrimal duct are a type of specialized cells that line the ducts carrying tears from the lacrimal gland to the nasal cavity. These cells provide a physical barrier between the body and the outside world and help regulate the fluid and electrolyte balance within the nasolacrimal system. 

One of the primary functions of the epithelial cells of nasolacrimal duct is to facilitate the movement of tears from the eye to the nasal cavity. These cells produce mucus, which helps lubricate the nasal cavity and allows tears to passively enter the nose. They also regulate the concentration of electrolytes, such as sodium and chloride, to create an osmotic gradient that drives fluid movement across the cell membrane. 

In addition to their transport functions, epithelial cells of the nasolacrimal duct also play a vital role in protecting the body from environmental damage and pathogens. These cells secrete enzymes and antimicrobial peptides that can neutralize harmful agents and prevent infection. They also provide a physical barrier that prevents toxins and pathogens from entering the body through the tear ducts. Overall, the epithelial cells of nasolacrimal duct maintain the proper function of the nasolacrimal system, which is critical for vision and eye health.
CL:1000383:
Type 2 vestibular sensory cells are specialized cells located in the epithelium of the macula of utricle in the membranous labyrinth of the inner ear. These cells are responsible for detecting changes in the position of the head with respect to gravity and linear acceleration. They are essential for maintaining balance and posture and play a crucial role in preventing falls and injuries.

Type 2 vestibular sensory cells contain hair-like protrusions called stereocilia that are embedded in a gel-like substance. The stereocilia are arranged in a polarized manner, with the tallest stereocilia pointing towards the kinocilium, a single, centrally-located cilium. The stereocilia are interconnected by fine filaments called tip links, which are sensitive to mechanical forces. When the head moves, the gel-like substance surrounding the stereocilia is displaced, causing the stereocilia to bend. This bending opens or closes tiny channels in the membrane of the cell, which triggers the release of neurotransmitters that signal the nervous system about the head's movement.

Type 2 vestibular sensory cells exhibit remarkable regenerative capabilities, even in adult organisms. These cells can differentiate into more than one cell type, including type 1 vestibular sensory cells and supporting cells, which are necessary for the functioning of the vestibular system. However, the regenerative capacity of type 2 vestibular sensory cells becomes limited with aging, leading to a decline in vestibular function and an increased risk for falls. Understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying type 2 vestibular sensory cell differentiation and regeneration has important implications for the treatment of balance disorders and age-related vestibular dysfunction.
CL:1000384:
The type 2 vestibular sensory cell of epithelium of macula of saccule of membranous labyrinth is a specialized cell found in the inner ear. These cells play a vital role in our ability to detect motion, acceleration, and gravity. Specifically, type 2 vestibular sensory cells are responsible for transducing mechanical stimuli into electrical signals that can be interpreted by the brain.

The epithelium of the macula of the saccule is specifically designed to respond to linear acceleration, such as the movement of your head in a straight line. Within this epithelium are two types of sensory cells: type 1 and type 2. While type 1 cells respond to both linear and angular acceleration, type 2 cells are only responsive to linear acceleration. Type 2 vestibular sensory cells have a unique structure that allows them to detect motion in a specific direction, making them critical to maintaining our balance and sense of spatial orientation.

In addition to their role in detecting motion, type 2 vestibular sensory cells are also responsible for supporting the surrounding epithelial cells and maintaining the structural integrity of the inner ear. Dysfunction or damage to these cells can result in balance disorders, dizziness, and vertigo. Understanding the function and structure of these cells is essential to developing treatments for these conditions and gaining a deeper understanding of the mechanics of the vestibular system.
CL:1000381:
Type 1 vestibular sensory cells are a specific cell type located in the epithelium of the crista of the ampulla of the semicircular duct of the membranous labyrinth in the inner ear. They play an important role in the detection of head movements and linear acceleration. These cells have a characteristic shape, with a large, flask-shaped cell body and a single, long, and thin hair-like structure called the kinocilium. Several shorter hair-like projections, known as stereocilia, surround the kinocilium. The stereocilia are organized in a staircase-like fashion, with the tallest one closest to the kinocilium and progressively shorter ones further away. The kinocilium is not embedded in the extracellular matrix but is anchored to the apex of the supporting cell.

Type 1 vestibular sensory cells are mechanoreceptors, meaning that they respond to mechanical forces such as the deflection of the stereocilia and the kinocilium in response to head movements. When these structures are deflected by a movement of the head, the cell depolarizes, and calcium ions flow into the cell, triggering the release of a neurotransmitter called glutamate. This neurotransmitter then activates the vestibular nerve fibers that carry the signal to the brain, allowing us to perceive and maintain our sense of balance and spatial orientation.

In summary, type 1 vestibular sensory cells are specialized mechanoreceptors located in the epithelium of the crista of the ampulla of the semicircular duct of the membranous labyrinth in the inner ear. They play a crucial role in detecting head movements and linear acceleration and contribute to our sense of balance and spatial orientation.
CL:1000410:
Myocytes of the atrioventricular node (AVN) are specialized cardiac cells located in the inferior interatrial septum near the opening of the coronary sinus. They are responsible for the electrical conduction between the atria and ventricles of the heart. Similar to other cardiomyocytes, they have a myofibrillar organization and are mainly composed of contractile proteins such as actin and myosin.

The function of AVN myocytes is critical to the coordinated contraction of the heart. These cells serve as the gatekeepers of the electrical impulse that travels from the atria to the ventricles. They are able to delay and filter the signal, giving the ventricles time to fill with blood before the contraction. This delay is necessary as it allows the atria to contract first and pump blood into the ventricles before the ventricles start contracting. Without this delay, the ventricles would contract at the same time as the atria, reducing the effectiveness of the cardiac output.

The unique properties of AVN myocytes make them particularly vulnerable to changes in the heart's electrical activity, which can result in defects such as atrioventricular block or bradycardia. Therefore, understanding the function and properties of these cells is essential for the diagnosis and treatment of various cardiac disorders.
CL:1000380:
Type 1 vestibular sensory cells are specialized epithelial cells found in the macula of the saccule within the membranous labyrinth of the inner ear. These cells play a crucial role in detecting linear acceleration and head position relative to gravity, providing us with information about our body's orientation and movement in space. The stereocilia of these cells extend into the otolithic membrane which is made up of calcium carbonate crystals known as otoconia. Changes in the movement of the head cause the otoconia to move and stimulate the stereocilia of the type 1 vestibular sensory cells, initiating an action potential that travels down the vestibular nerve to the brain.

Type 1 vestibular sensory cells are characterized by their large round cell bodies and distinctive synaptic contacts with afferent nerve fibers. These cells are not only responsible for detecting changes in linear acceleration and head position, but they also participate in the sensory processing and integration of these signals. This integration of vestibular signals allows us to maintain our balance and equilibrium, as well as adapt to changing environments. Disorders of the vestibular system and damage to type 1 vestibular sensory cells can cause vertigo, nausea, and loss of balance, highlighting the importance of these cells in sensory processing.

In conclusion, type 1 vestibular sensory cells are unique sensory receptors specialized for detecting linear acceleration and head position relative to gravity. These cells play a crucial role in sensory processing and contribute to our sense of balance and equilibrium. Understanding the function and properties of these cells is essential for the diagnosis and treatment of vestibular disorders and can provide insight into the complex mechanisms underlying sensory processing and integration in the inner ear.

Adrenal cortex chromaffin cells are specialized neuroendocrine cells that are present in the adrenal gland cortex. These cells play a critical role in the body's stress response. The adrenal gland is responsible for producing the hormones epinephrine and norepinephrine, which are essential for the body's fight or flight response. The adrenal cortex chromaffin cells are responsible for producing and secreting these hormones into the bloodstream when the body is under stress.

In addition to their role in the stress response, adrenal cortex chromaffin cells are also involved in regulating blood pressure and controlling the body's electrolyte balance. These cells are able to sense changes in blood pressure and electrolyte levels and respond accordingly by releasing hormones that help to maintain homeostasis. Specifically, they produce aldosterone, which is involved in regulating sodium and potassium levels in the blood, and cortisol, which is involved in regulating glucose metabolism in the body.

Overall, the function of adrenal cortex chromaffin cells is critical for maintaining the body's homeostasis in response to stress and changes in blood pressure and electrolyte levels. These cells play a vital role in regulating hormone production in the adrenal gland and are essential for ensuring that the body functions properly in response to external stressors.

Microfold cells (M cells) are a specialized type of epithelial cells found in the human small intestines, namely in the Peyer's patches. They are essential in gut immune surveillance, which plays a crucial role in defending against pathogenic microbes and antigens of dietary or microbial origin. M cells are involved in transporting luminal antigens and microbes across the epithelial barrier and delivering them to the underlying lymphoid tissue, also known as nerve bundles or dendritic cells. Consequently, M cells facilitate the initiation of immune responses, such as the production of IgA-secreting cells and T cell activation.

The microfold cell of epithelium proper of duodenum is a microfold cell that is present specifically in the duodenum region of the small intestine. The duodenum is located between the stomach and the jejunum, and it plays a critical role in the digestive process. The microfold cells in the duodenum are involved in sampling and transporting material from the intestinal lumen to the underlying lymphoid tissue, where immune responses are initiated. They are particularly important because the duodenum is a part of the body that is susceptible to pathogenic microbes, as microbes are not destroyed by the low gastric pH in this region. Therefore, the microfold cells of the duodenum form an important part of the gut immune system, providing an early defense mechanism against potentially harmful pathogens.

In summary, the microfold cell of epithelium proper of duodenum is a specialized cell type found in the small intestine that is involved in the transport of luminal antigens and microbes across the epithelial barrier to the underlying lymphoid tissue. This cell type plays a crucial role in the initiation of immune responses particularly in the duodenum region of the small intestine, where harmful pathogens can be found. The importance of microfold cells in mediating the body's innate immune system has been recognized as critical for gut health and homeostasis.

Conjunctival epithelial cells are a type of cell that forms the outermost surface of the conjunctiva, which is the thin, transparent, and moist tissue that covers the white part of the eye and the inside of the eyelids. These cells are flat, multi-layered, and tightly packed, forming a protective barrier that serves as the first line of defense against pathogens, allergens, and other irritants that may come into contact with the eye.

The main function of conjunctival epithelial cells is to prevent infections and inflammation in the eye by producing mucus and other substances that help trap and remove harmful particles and microorganisms. They also secrete tears that lubricate and nourish the eye, and contain enzymes and antibodies that help fight infections. Conjunctival epithelial cells are constantly renewed by cell division, which allows them to repair and replace damaged or dead cells.

In addition to their protective function, conjunctival epithelial cells are also involved in the production of cytokines and growth factors that regulate the immune response and promote tissue healing. They can interact with other cells in the conjunctiva, such as goblet cells, lymphocytes, and nerve cells, to coordinate the immune response and maintain homeostasis in the eye. Dysfunctional conjunctival epithelial cells can lead to various eye disorders, such as dry eye syndrome, allergic conjunctivitis, and viral or bacterial infections.

Type 2 vestibular sensory cells are a specialized type of sensory cell found in the epithelium of the crista of the ampulla of the semicircular duct of the membranous labyrinth. These cells play a crucial role in sensing changes in head movement and acceleration, which helps to maintain balance and spatial orientation. Type 2 vestibular sensory cells are bipolar neurons, meaning that they have two distinct processes: one dendrite and one axon. The dendrite of the cell extends into a gelatinous substance called the cupula, which is a crucial part of the vestibular apparatus responsible for detecting head movement.

The function of type 2 vestibular sensory cells is to transduce mechanical stimuli resulting from head movements into electrical signals that can be transmitted to the brainstem. These cells are structured in such a way that they can detect directional movement and the velocity of movement, helping to maintain proper balance during changes in head position. The cupula, which the dendrite of the cell extends into, is composed of a gelatinous substance that moves in response to changes in head movement. This movement causes the hair cells on the surface of the type 2 vestibular sensory cells to bend, which results in the generation of electrical signals that travel along the axon of the neuron.

Overall, type 2 vestibular sensory cells play a critical role in maintaining balance and spatial orientation in the body. These cells are highly specialized and are structured in a way that allows them to detect even the slightest changes in head movement and acceleration. While the structure and function of type 2 vestibular sensory cells are highly complex, they are essential for the proper functioning of the vestibular system and the maintenance of balance in the body.

Chromaffin cells of paraganglion are neuroendocrine cells found in the adrenal medulla and other sympathetic ganglia. These cells are responsible for secreting catecholamines, specifically adrenaline (epinephrine) and noradrenaline (norepinephrine), in response to stress or danger. Chromaffin cells are derived from the neural crest and are closely related to sympathetic ganglion neurons, sharing many of the same markers.

The secretion of catecholamines by chromaffin cells is an important component of the “fight-or-flight” response. When the body perceives a threat, the hypothalamus activates the sympathetic nervous system, triggering the release of adrenaline and noradrenaline. These hormones increase heart rate, blood pressure, and respiration in preparation for physical activity. In addition to their role in stress response, chromaffin cells also play a role in glucose homeostasis and have been implicated in certain disease states such as hypertension and pheochromocytoma.

Chromaffin cells have a unique morphology, featuring numerous secretory granules containing catecholamines. These granules are responsible for the rapid release of hormones in response to stress. Chromaffin cells also have specialized secretory machinery, allowing them to store and release large amounts of catecholamines quickly. The release of these hormones is tightly regulated by both neural and endocrine signals, ensuring that the body responds appropriately to stress. Overall, the function of chromaffin cells is critical for normal physiological responses to stress and maintaining homeostasis.

Purkinje myocytes of the interventricular septum are specialized cells that form the conduction system of the heart. They are located in the endocardium and are responsible for transmitting electrical impulses rapidly and efficiently through the ventricular myocardium, ensuring the coordinated contraction of the ventricles. These cells are large, with branching processes and abundant glycogen stores, allowing them to propagate electrical impulses quickly and with minimal energy usage.

The Purkinje myocytes of the interventricular septum function to coordinate the contraction of the ventricles, which is essential for the efficient pumping of blood through the circulatory system. The electrical impulses generated by the sinoatrial (SA) node travel through the atria and reach the atrioventricular (AV) node, where they are briefly delayed before being transmitted to the Purkinje fibers. The Purkinje fibers rapidly transmit the electrical impulse to the ventricular myocardium, causing it to contract and eject blood. The efficient transmission of electrical impulses by the Purkinje myocytes of the interventricular septum is critical for the proper functioning of the heart and the maintenance of cardiovascular health.

In summary, Purkinje myocytes of the interventricular septum are specialized cells that form an integral part of the conduction system of the heart. Their function is to rapidly and efficiently transmit electrical impulses through the ventricular myocardium, ensuring the coordinated contraction of the ventricles and efficient pumping of blood through the circulatory system. The proper function of these cells is critical for cardiovascular health, and disruptions in their activity can lead to a range of cardiovascular disorders, including arrhythmias, heart failure, and sudden cardiac death.

Transitional myocytes of the left branch of the atrioventricular bundle are specialized heart muscle cells that are responsible for the rapid conduction of impulses between the atrial the ventricular chambers of the heart. These cells are critical for the proper functioning of the cardiac electrical conduction system, which coordinates the rhythmic beating of the heart. The left bundle branch of the atrioventricular bundle is responsible for conducting electrical impulses from the left atrium to the left ventricle.

Transitional myocytes of the left branch of atrioventricular bundle, also known as Purkinje fibers, are larger and more elongated than typical cardiac muscle cells. They contain more mitochondria and less myofibrils than working cardiac muscle cells, making them suitable for fast conduction of impulses. The rapid conduction of impulses is facilitated by the presence of gap junctions between the myocytes, which enable the propagation of electrical signals from cell to cell. The rapid conduction of impulses through the Purkinje fibers ensures that the contraction of the ventricles is synchronized, leading to efficient pumping of blood through the body.

Disorders involving the left bundle branch block can lead to abnormalities in the conduction of electrical signals, resulting in a delay in or blockage of the electrical impulses within the left bundle branch. This can lead to a range of symptoms, including dizziness, faintness, and shortness of breath. In severe cases, left bundle branch block may lead to cardiac arrest or sudden cardiac death. Therefore, a better understanding of the physiology and function of transitional myocytes of the left branch of the atrioventricular bundle is critical for developing effective treatments for these conditions.

They are connected to the basement membrane of the sweat glands through hemidesmosomes and interact with the secretory epithelial cells via desmosomes.

The activation of myoepithelial cells results in the contraction of these cells, which helps to expel sweat from the lumen of the sweat gland into the duct. Moreover, myoepithelial cells of the sweat gland also provide structural support to the secretory epithelium and help to maintain the integrity of the glandular architecture. They also have phagocytic activity and are capable of removing wastes and debris from the glandular lumens.

In summary, myoepithelial cells of the sweat gland play a critical role in the process of sweat secretion and excretion. Overall, the myoepithelial cells of the sweat gland are a vital component of the sweat glandular system and are necessary for the maintenance of homeostasis in the human body.

Transitional myocytes of atrioventricular bundle, commonly referred to as TAVB cells, are specialized cells found in the atrioventricular (AV) node of the heart. TAVB cells also have a high density of gap junctions, which allow for the rapid spread of electrical impulses between neighboring cells. This unique structure and composition allow TAVB cells to act as a specialized pathway for the conduction of electrical signals from the atria to the ventricles.

They can respond to sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous system inputs, which can modulate their rate of depolarization and the strength of their electrical signals. This means that TAVB cells can adjust the rate at which electrical impulses are conducted through the AV node in response to changing physiological demands, ultimately leading to changes in heart rate. Overall, the specialized properties of TAVB cells play a critical role in coordinating proper electrical conduction and regulating heart rate, making them a key player in cardiovascular health.

They are also involved in the innate immune response by producing antimicrobial peptides that can help to protect the eyes from infection.

Conjunctival goblet cells are unique in their morphology and function. They are characterized by their large size and conspicuous secretory granules that contain mucins, the main component of mucus. Mucins are highly glycosylated proteins that form a hydrated gel and help to create a surface that is resistant to bacterial adhesion and epithelial damage. The secretion of mucins by goblet cells is regulated by a variety of factors, including inflammatory cytokines and mechanical stress.

In addition to their role in tear production, conjunctival goblet cells are also important in the diagnosis and treatment of various eye diseases. Changes in the number or function of these cells are associated with conditions such as dry eye syndrome and conjunctivitis, and they can serve as biomarkers for disease progression. Furthermore, there is potential for the use of goblet cell therapy to replace or augment lost or dysfunctional goblet cells in various ocular surface disorders.
CL:1000391:
Melanocytes of eyelid are pigment-producing cells found in the skin of the eyelids. These cells are responsible for the synthesis and deposition of melanin, a pigment that gives color to the skin and protects it from the harmful effects of ultraviolet radiation. Melanocytes of eyelid arise from the neural crest, a group of cells that give rise to a diverse range of cell types during embryonic development, and migrate to the skin where they differentiate into mature melanocytes.

The main function of melanocytes of eyelid is the production and regulation of melanin. Melanin synthesis and deposition in the skin is a complex process that involves a series of enzymatic reactions and cellular interactions. The melanin synthesized by melanocytes of eyelid is transferred to nearby keratinocytes, the most abundant cells in the epidermis, where it forms a protective barrier against ultraviolet radiation. Melanin also plays a role in skin pigmentation and contributes to the diversity of human skin colors.

In addition to their role in pigment production and regulation, melanocytes of eyelid have also been implicated in the development of skin diseases such as melanoma, a type of skin cancer. Understanding the molecular mechanisms that underlie melanocyte function and behavior is therefore important for the prevention and treatment of melanoma and other skin diseases. Melanocytes of eyelid represent an important cell type in the skin and their study is essential for advancing our knowledge of skin biology and pathology.
CL:1000424:
The chromaffin cell of the paraaortic body, also known as the chromaffin cell of Zuckerkandl, is a type of neuroendocrine cell that can be found within the adrenal gland or near the abdominal aorta. These cells produce and secrete a variety of hormones, including catecholamines such as adrenaline and noradrenaline, which play vital roles in modulating the body's fight or flight response. The secretion of these hormones is tightly regulated by the sympathetic nervous system, which stimulates the release of catecholamines in response to stress and other stimuli.

In addition to their role as endocrine cells, chromaffin cells of the paraaortic body also act as specialized sensory cells that monitor the levels of oxygen, glucose, and other important nutrients in the blood. By sensing changes in these parameters, chromaffin cells can modulate the secretion of catecholamines, which can affect a wide variety of physiological processes such as blood pressure, heart rate, and metabolism. Dysfunction of the chromaffin cells in the adrenal gland can lead to a number of disorders, including pheochromocytoma, a rare type of tumor that can cause high blood pressure and other symptoms.

Overall, the chromaffin cell of the paraaortic body plays a crucial role in the body's response to stress and helps to maintain proper physiological balance by modulating the secretion of hormones and sensing changes in important nutrients in the blood. Understanding the function and regulation of these cells can help to inform the development of new therapies for diseases related to adrenal gland dysfunction and may also shed light on the broader physiological pathways that govern the body's response to stress.
CL:1000471:
Myoepithelial cells of the secondary lactiferous duct are specialized contractile cells that line the ducts of the mammary gland. These cells play a crucial role in breast physiology by aiding in the expression of milk during lactation. The myoepithelial cells contract in response to hormonal and neurological signals, which generates the pressure needed to move the milk through the ducts and out of the nipple.

In addition to their role in milk expression, myoepithelial cells also function as a barrier between the glandular epithelium and the surrounding stroma. They create a physical barrier that helps to regulate the exchange of substances between the ductal lumen and the surrounding tissue. This barrier function is particularly important during times of lactation when there is increased risk of bacterial infection.

Finally, myoepithelial cells may also contribute to breast cancer development, as they are believed to be the site of origin for some types of breast tumors. They have been shown to have stem cell-like properties and may become transformed by mutations that lead to abnormal cell growth and division. Understanding the properties and functions of these cells is critical for developing effective treatments for breast cancer and other diseases of the mammary gland.
CL:1000435:
Epithelial cells of the lacrimal duct are a type of specialized cells which line the ducts of the lacrimal gland. These cells are crucial for maintaining the proper functioning of the tear system by producing, secreting and draining tears. These cells form a barrier that helps in regulating the flow and composition of the tear film. The tear film is responsible for keeping the eye moist and protecting it from foreign particles, bacteria, and other harmful agents.

Epithelial cells of the lacrimal duct achieve their functions through the production and secretion of various proteins, lipids, and other substances important for the tear film. These cells secrete a watery fluid called the aqueous layer, containing various nutrients, enzymes and proteins that keep the eye healthy. In addition, the epithelial cells of the lacrimal duct also secrete a mucin layer, which helps the tears adhere to the eye surface, facilitating lubrication and comfort. As the tears are being produced, the epithelial cells also help in draining the tears out of the eyes via the nasolacrimal ducts.

Malfunction of epithelial cells of the lacrimal duct can lead to various eye disorders such as dry eye syndrome, which results in a lack of moisture and comfort to the eye. Understanding the function and mechanisms of these cells is essential to developing new treatments for these conditions. Therefore, researchers continue to explore the underlying mechanisms of the epithelial cells of the lacrimal duct in order to develop new diagnostic tools and effective interventions to treat these and other related eye diseases.
CL:1000377:
Dense-core granulated cells (DCGCs) are specialized cells found in the epithelium of the trachea. These cells are easily recognizable due to their large, dense core granules, which contain a variety of signaling molecules such as peptides, neuropeptides and biogenic amines. DCGCs are regulated by the autonomic nervous system and are involved in the modulation of airway tone and smooth muscle activity. These cells play a crucial role in the regulation of the respiratory system and have been implicated in conditions such as asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

DCGCs of the trachea have been shown to be involved in mediating airway hyperresponsiveness, a hallmark feature of asthma. The release of peptides such as substance P and calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) from DCGCs stimulates the contraction of the surrounding airway smooth muscle, contributing to airway narrowing. Furthermore, studies have found that DCGCs may also play a role in airway inflammation, which is a key feature of asthma and COPD. DCGCs release cytokines and chemokines, which attract and activate immune cells to the site of inflammation.

In addition to their role in airway physiology and pathology, DCGCs have been linked to other physiological processes. For example, it has been suggested that DCGCs may play a role in nociception, as they contain neuropeptides involved in pain modulation. Through their complex signaling pathways, DCGCs of the epithelium of the trachea play a vital role in the regulation of the respiratory system and have been linked to numerous physiological and pathological processes.
CL:1000453:
Epithelial cells of intermediate tubule are a type of cell that occupies the intermediate segment of the renal tubule in the kidney. These cells are polarized and maintain a distinct apical and basal membrane that separates the lumen of the tubule from the interstitial space. They play a crucial role in the process of urine formation by selectively reabsorbing essential solutes and water from the filtrate. Additionally, these cells secrete waste and excess solutes into the tubular lumen to be excreted from the body.

The morphology of these cells varies depending on their location within the renal tubule, but they typically have a cuboidal shape with a central nucleus. They also have a high density of mitochondria, which provides the energy required for active transport of solutes across the epithelium. In addition to their involvement in ion and water transport, epithelial cells of intermediate tubule also participate in metabolic processes such as gluconeogenesis and the production of ammonia.

Overall, epithelial cells of intermediate tubule are critical for maintaining the balance of water and electrolytes in the body, as well as disposing of waste products. Dysfunctions in these cells can lead to a variety of renal disorders, including diabetes insipidus, renal tubular acidosis, and Fanconi syndrome. Further understanding of the physiology and molecular mechanisms of these cells may lead to the development of novel therapies for these diseases.
CL:1000470:
Myoepithelial cells are a specialized subset of epithelial cells that are found in the primary lactiferous ducts of mammals. These cells are characterized by the presence of contractile filaments that allow them to actively contract and move milk through the ducts. Myoepithelial cells are also involved in the regulation of milk production and secretion, through communication with the surrounding mammary gland tissue.

In addition to their role in milk secretion, myoepithelial cells also play a crucial role in the development and organization of the mammary gland. They are responsible for maintaining the structural integrity of the gland, as well as facilitating its branching and differentiation. Myoepithelial cells are also involved in the signaling pathways that mediate the interactions between the mammary gland and the surrounding cellular environment.

Overall, myoepithelial cells are a critical component of the mammary gland, playing an essential role in milk secretion, regulation, and development. Their unique contractile properties and interactions with the surrounding tissue make them an important target for the study and treatment of diseases associated with the mammary gland, such as breast cancer.
CL:1000482:
Myocardial endocrine cells of the interventricular septum, also known as intra-septal atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) cells, are specialized cells located in the heart's interventricular septum. These cells express and secrete ANP, a hormone that plays a crucial role in the cardiovascular system's regulation of blood volume and blood pressure. ANP acts as a vasodilator, causing blood vessels to widen, thereby reducing blood pressure.

In addition to their endocrine function, myocardial endocrine cells make up a small population of cardiac muscle cells and may have a role in regulating heart contractility. Studies have shown that ANP released by these cells can enhance cardiac contractility and improve heart function, making them potentially important therapeutic targets for heart disease.

Overall, myocardial endocrine cells of the interventricular septum play a critical role in regulating the cardiovascular system's function and maintaining homeostasis. Dysregulation of ANP secretion from these cells can lead to conditions such as hypertension, heart failure, and myocardial infarction, highlighting the importance of understanding their function and potential therapeutic applications.
CL:1000436:
An epithelial cell of the lacrimal sac is a specialized cell type found within the lacrimal sac. As a part of the ocular surface system, the lacrimal sac secretes aqueous fluid and mucus to lubricate the ocular surface and flush out debris. Epithelial cells of the lacrimal sac are responsible for maintaining the integrity of the lacrimal ducts, preventing the backflow of tears and other substances. 

These cells are polarized, meaning that their membrane domain facing the exterior of the lacrimal sac is different from the one close to the tear-filled lacrimal pathway. The apical membrane domain of these cells holds microvilli that function to increase the cell's surface area and boost its ability to absorb ions and other molecules. The cell's lateral domains and basolateral domain have intercellular junctions that collectively create the epithelial sheet component of the lacrimal sac. The junctions between the cells of the epithelial sheet enable the formation of a paracellular barrier that keeps tears from flowing back into the ducts. 

Moreover, these cells contain intracellular organelles such as lysosomes, endosomes, and mitochondria. These organelles work to maintain proper cell function, aid in signal transduction, and help in vesicular trafficking. Epithelial cells control the secretion of aqueous humor and other secretory mechanisms that serve lubricative and anti-inflammatory functions. Any malfunctioning of these cells can contribute to the clinical disorder known as dry eye, where the ocular surface lacks adequate lubrication and is susceptible to injury as a result.
CL:1000442:
Urothelial cells of trigone of urinary bladder are specialized cells that cover the inner lining of the urinary bladder, specifically the trigone region. These cells have unique morphology, with a flattened appearance when the bladder is empty and a stretched appearance when it is filled with urine. Urothelial cells are connected to each other with tight junctions, creating a tight barrier that prevents urine from leaking into surrounding tissues. They also have the ability to stretch and contract in response to the filling of the bladder, allowing the bladder to expand and contract without damage to the cells.

One of the most important functions of urothelial cells of trigone of urinary bladder is to act as a barrier and protect deeper layers of the bladder tissue from the toxic effects of urine. Urothelial cells actively transport ions and other substances out of the urine and into the bloodstream, helping to maintain the proper balance of electrolytes in the body. Additionally, urothelial cells of trigone of urinary bladder can also play a role in the sensation of fullness and the urge to urinate. They take part in the signaling pathway that lets the brain know when it is time to empty the bladder.

In summary, urothelial cells of trigone of urinary bladder comprise a specialized cell type that serves a crucial role in the protection and function of the urinary bladder. By maintaining a barrier and the proper electrolyte balance in the body, as well as signaling to the brain when it is time to urinate, urothelial cells help to ensure healthy urinary function.
CL:1000445:
Myoepithelial cells of dilator pupillae are a type of smooth muscle cell located in the iris of the eye. These cells are responsible for the dilation of the pupil, which allows more light to enter the eye. Myoepithelial cells of dilator pupillae contract in response to sympathetic nervous system stimulation. This stimulation results in the release of norepinephrine, which binds to alpha-adrenergic receptors on the myoepithelial cells, causing them to contract.

Myoepithelial cells of dilator pupillae are unique in that they not only contract but also express neuropeptides. Some of these neuropeptides, like VIP and PACAP, act as vasodilators and can increase blood flow to the eye, which is important for maintaining proper eye function. Myoepithelial cells of dilator pupillae also express other neurotransmitter receptors, such as acetylcholine receptors, which may play a role in controlling pupil size under different conditions.

In summary, myoepithelial cells of dilator pupillae are specialized smooth muscle cells found in the iris of the eye. These cells are responsible for the dilation of the pupil, which allows more light to enter the eye. They contract in response to sympathetic nervous system stimulation and also express neuropeptides and neurotransmitter receptors that may play a role in regulating pupil size and blood flow to the eye.
CL:1000447:
Epithelial cells of the stratum germinativum in the esophagus form the outermost layer of the esophageal tissue, which lines the hollow tube that carries food from the mouth to the stomach. These cells are responsible for the formation and maintenance of the esophageal epithelium. They are essential for the protection of the esophageal tissue against damage from ingested food, drink, and gastric acid reflux.

The epithelial cells of the stratum germinativum are specialized cells that replace the superficial squamous cells of the esophagus. They are responsible for the continuous replenishment of the esophageal epithelium by dividing repeatedly and producing new cells that differentiate into squamous cells. They play a critical role in the formation of the esophageal barrier, which contributes to the protection of the underlying tissue against physical, chemical and microbial damage.

Epithelial cells of the stratum germinativum are also involved in the synthesis and secretion of mucus, which aids in the lubrication and protection of the esophageal tissue against potentially harmful substances. These cells express a variety of membrane transporters that mediate the uptake of nutrients and ions from the luminal environment. They are also involved in the active transport of water and electrolytes across the esophageal epithelium, which contributes to the maintenance of fluid and electrolyte homeostasis.
CL:1000510:
Kidney glomerular epithelial cells, also known as podocytes, are specialized cells located in the glomerular tuft of the kidney. These cells have unique foot processes that wrap around the glomerular capillaries to form a filtration barrier known as the slit diaphragm. The primary function of podocytes is to maintain the glomerular filtration barrier, which is essential for proper kidney function.

Podocytes play a crucial role in the filtration process by preventing the loss of valuable proteins and other macromolecules from the blood into the urine. They achieve this through their intricate foot processes, which interdigitate with neighboring podocytes to form the slit diaphragm. The slit diaphragm acts as a size- and charge-selective barrier, allowing small molecules such as water and electrolytes to pass through while preventing larger molecules from getting filtered out. Therefore, any damage to podocytes or the slit diaphragm could lead to proteinuria and impaired kidney function.

Furthermore, podocytes are involved in the regulation of blood pressure and intraglomerular hemodynamics. They achieve this through their contractile properties, which help in maintaining the integrity of the glomerular capillaries and controlling the diameter of the capillaries. Thus, any dysfunction of these cells can result in hypertension and other renal disorders. In summary, kidney glomerular epithelial cells are essential for proper kidney function, and their dysfunction can lead to severe renal disorders.
CL:1000493:
Mesothelial cells are a specialized type of epithelial cell that form a protective membrane known as the mesothelium. The mesothelial cell of visceral pleura lines the surface of the lungs, providing a protective barrier between the lung tissue and the thoracic cavity. These cells are essential for maintaining the structural integrity of the lung tissue, as well as facilitating gas exchange during respiration.

In addition to their protective function, mesothelial cells of the visceral pleura are also involved in the regulation of inflammation within the lung tissue. These cells release a variety of cytokines and chemokines in response to injury or infection, which recruit immune cells to the site of inflammation and help to coordinate the immune response. Mesothelial cells also play a role in the removal of excess fluid and cellular debris from the pleural cavity, ensuring that the lung tissue remains free of unwanted material.

Overall, the mesothelial cell of visceral pleura plays an important role in the proper functioning of the lungs. This specialized cell type provides a protective barrier, regulates inflammation, and helps to maintain the structural integrity of the lung tissue.
CL:1000473:
Myoepithelial cells of the quaternary lactiferous duct are a specialized type of epithelial cell that have contractile properties. These cells are responsible for the secretion of milk and play a crucial role in the transportation of milk through the duct. Myoepithelial cells exhibit a spindle-shaped morphology that enables them to contract and relax, allowing for milk to be squeezed out of the duct and into the nipple. 

In addition to their contractile properties, myoepithelial cells also have the ability to synthesize and secrete extracellular matrix proteins, such as collagen and elastin. This function helps to maintain the structure and integrity of the ducts and ensures efficient milk transport. Myoepithelial cells are also involved in the regulation of luminal pressure and act as a barrier, preventing the invasion of pathogens. 

Alterations in myoepithelial cell function or morphology can lead to breast pathologies such as mammary gland tumors. Therefore, understanding the role of these cells is essential for developing a better understanding of the physiology of lactation and breast disease. Further research into the functions of myoepithelial cells of the quaternary lactiferous duct will continue to refine our understanding of lactation, breast development, and disease.
CL:1000382:
Type 2 vestibular sensory cells are specialized cells found in the stato-acoustic epithelium of the inner ear. Unlike their Type 1 counterparts, which form the majority of the sensory epithelium, Type 2 cells are fewer in number but are still crucial to the perception of head movement and orientation. These cells are notable for their long, slender, and microvilli-covered hair processes, which extend from the apical surface of the cell and are embedded in the gelatinous material called the cupula, which overlies the underlying sensory epithelium. Type 2 cells are innervated by the vestibular nerve and contribute to the afferent signaling pathway of the vestibular system. Their primary function is to transduce mechanical stimuli (i.e., head movement) into electrical signals that can be interpreted by the brain to provide an awareness of one's position relative to gravity and the spatial orientation of the head. 

In addition to their role in mechanotransduction, Type 2 vestibular sensory cells also play a critical role in fluid homeostasis within the inner ear. They are responsible for producing the endolymphatic potential and the K+ depletion potential, both of which are essential for maintaining the ion concentrations necessary for proper hair cell transduction. Additionally, Type 2 cells are involved in the regulation of basolateral ion channels, which are important for K+ recycling and the maintenance of proper endolymphatic potential. Dysfunctions in Type 2 vestibular sensory cells have been implicated in balance disorders and could play a role in hearing loss related to inner ear fluid homeostasis.

Overall, Type 2 vestibular sensory cells are a critical component of the inner ear's vestibular system, providing input about the head's spatial orientation and movement and playing a crucial role in fluid homeostasis. Despite being fewer in number than Type 1 cells, Type 2 cells are vital for healthy vestibular function, and disruptions in their function can have significant consequences for vestibular and auditory perception.
CL:1000434:
The epithelial cells of the external acoustic meatus are specialized cells that line the ear canal of the external ear. These cells play a crucial role in protecting the ear from external environmental damage and infection. The external acoustic meatus needs to be protected because its shape and characteristics make it vulnerable to infection, various types of injuries, and debris from the outside environment. 

The protective function of the epithelial cells of the external acoustic meatus is significant because they produce cerumen or earwax, and it plays an important role in protecting the ear from external factors. Earwax serves as a physical barrier trapping dust, debris, and foreign particles that might enter the ear canal. It also inhibits the growth of bacteria and other harmful microorganisms in the ear. Furthermore, it provides lubrication, which is essential to prevent the skin of the ear cannel from becoming dry and itchy. The production and secretion of earwax are a metabolic activity of the epithelial cells of this region.

The overall health and maintenance of the ear depend on the epithelial cells of the external acoustic meatus. For example, it is essential to avoid using cotton swabs or other objects in the ear because it can interfere with the production of earwax and damage the sensitive skin lining the ear canal. Additionally, exposure to loud sounds or physical trauma can result in damage or tearing of the epithelial cells leading to infections and complications. Therefore, a healthy lifestyle, including regular cleaning of the outer ear canal and hearing protection devices, is recommended to maintain the proper function of the epithelial cells of the external acoustic meatus.
CL:1000355:
Microfold cells, also known as M-cells, are specialized cells found in the epithelium of the small intestine. These cells are responsible for the transportation of antigens and microorganisms from the gut lumen to the underlying immune system. M-cells lack the thick layer of mucus and the brush border present on other epithelial cells, which allows them to interact directly with antigens and microorganisms.

M-cells have a unique internal structure that facilitates antigen uptake and transcytosis. Dense microvilli on the basal side of M-cells, known as the "filamentous actin brush," guide antigen uptake and transport. The antigens are engulfed by the cells and are then transported across the cell and released on the basal side, where they interact with underlying dendritic cells of the immune system. This transport of antigens across the epithelial barrier is an important aspect of mucosal immunity and helps to prevent infections in the gut.

The function of M-cells in the small intestine is critical to the proper functioning of the immune system. These cells play a key role in the initiation of adaptive immune responses by transporting antigens and microorganisms to the underlying lymphoid tissue. Additionally, M-cells are involved in the induction of oral tolerance, a process in which the immune system tolerates harmless antigens, thus preventing inflammatory responses against them. The unique properties of M-cells make them essential for the maintenance of intestinal homeostasis, and their dysfunction has been implicated in several gastrointestinal diseases.
CL:1000468:
Myoepithelial cells are specialized contractile cells found in various glands including the lactiferous gland. These cells have a spindle shape with elongated cytoplasmic processes that wrap around the secretory alveoli of the gland. Myoepithelial cells have a critical functional role in regulating glandular secretion and maintaining the structural integrity of the gland. These cells can contract in response to various stimuli and help to force the secretion out of the gland.

 In the lactiferous gland, myoepithelial cells of acinus surround secretory alveoli and play a critical role in regulating the secretion of milk. During lactation, myoepithelial cells contract in response to the hormone oxytocin, which is released in response to suckling. This contraction leads to the compression of adjacent alveoli and expulsion of milk into the ducts. Thus, the contraction of the myoepithelial cells in response to oxytocin is essential for the ejection of milk during lactation.

Overall, myoepithelial cells of acinus have a crucial functional role in the lactiferous gland. They enable the secretion of milk by contracting in response to oxytocin, which expels milk into the ducts. Understanding the structural and functional characteristics of these cells can help researchers better comprehend lactation, as well as develop new treatments for glandular-related disorders.
CL:1000456:
Mesothelial cells are the thin, flat cells that form the mesothelium, a specialized tissue that lines the body cavities and organs, including the parietal peritoneum. These cells are responsible for secreting a lubricating fluid that allows organs to move smoothly against each other and against the body wall. Mesothelial cells of the parietal peritoneum provide a protective barrier between the abdominal organs and the rest of the body, preventing potentially harmful molecules and pathogens from entering into the peritoneal cavity.

Mesothelial cells of the parietal peritoneum also play a key role in the host response to pathogens and injury. These cells are capable of recognizing and responding to microbial patterns and damage-associated signals, which activate a series of cellular processes that are critical for the initiation of an immune response. In addition, mesothelial cells can produce a range of cytokines, chemokines, and growth factors that orchestrate the recruitment of immune cells and the proliferation and repair of damaged tissues.

The dysfunction of mesothelial cells of the parietal peritoneum has been associated with various diseases, including peritoneal carcinomatosis, peritoneal mesothelioma, and peritonitis. In summary, mesothelial cells of the parietal peritoneum play a crucial role in the normal functioning of the peritoneal cavity as well as in the pathophysiology of various diseases affecting this tissue.
CL:1000490:
Mesothelial cells of peritoneum are a specialized type of epithelial cell that forms a single layer covering the peritoneum cavity. These cells are critical for the maintenance of the peritoneal membrane's integrity and function. They play an essential role in protecting the abdominal cavity and its contents from infection and mechanical stress.

The mesothelial cells of peritoneum perform various functions that include acting as a barrier between the abdominal organs, secreting and absorbing fluids, and forming a smooth surface to facilitate organ movement. They also help to remove and dispose of foreign particles, bacteria, and other potentially harmful substances from the peritoneal cavity. Mesothelial cells of peritoneum have a high level of plasticity and can transform into fibroblasts or inflammatory cells in response to injury or infection.

Diseases like peritoneal mesothelioma underline the importance of mesothelial cells and their role in the peritoneal cavity. Understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying the mesothelial cell-organ peritoneum interactions is crucial to develop new therapeutics against disorders involving these cells. Overall, mesothelial cells of peritoneum play a vital role in maintaining the peritoneal membrane's integrity and normal physiological functions, making them a crucial cell type in the abdominal cavity.
CL:1000548:
The kidney outer medulla collecting duct epithelial cell is a specialized cell that lines the collecting duct of the kidney. These cells are responsible for regulating the final concentration of urine by actively transporting solutes and water between the urine and the interstitium of the outer medulla. This process is essential for maintaining fluid balance and preventing dehydration or over-hydration of the body.

In addition to their role in regulating urine concentration, these cells also play an important role in maintaining the acid-base balance of the body. They are capable of reabsorbing bicarbonate ions, which helps to regulate the pH of the blood and prevent acidosis.

The kidney outer medulla collecting duct epithelial cell is also involved in the transport of various nutrients and waste products. They actively reabsorb nutrients such as glucose, amino acids, and ions, while also secreting waste products such as urea and creatinine into the urine. Dysfunction of these cells can lead to a variety of kidney disorders, including diabetes insipidus and renal tubular acidosis.
CL:1000546:
The kidney medulla collecting duct epithelial cell is a specialized cell type found in the medullary regions of the kidney. These cells are responsible for regulating the concentration of urine by controlling the reabsorption of water and solutes. The kidney medulla collecting duct epithelial cells are part of the renal tubule system and are involved in the final stage of urine formation.

The main function of the kidney medulla collecting duct epithelial cell is to reabsorb water and solutes from the urine that passes through it. This is important for maintaining a proper water balance in the body, as well as for eliminating waste products. Additionally, these cells can also secrete and absorb ions, which are important in the regulation of blood pressure and pH balance in the body.

The unique location and specialized function of the kidney medulla collecting duct epithelial cell make it an important cell type for maintaining proper kidney function. Dysfunction or damage to these cells can lead to a variety of kidney disorders, such as diabetes insipidus or renal salt wasting syndrome. Understanding the role and function of this cell type can aid in the development of treatments and therapies for these conditions.
CL:1000472:
Myoepithelial cells of the tertiary lactiferous duct are a specialized type of epithelial cell that is found in the mammary gland. These cells are responsible for the active contraction of the duct, which helps move milk through the mammary gland and towards the nipple. Myoepithelial cells are essential for the efficient release of milk from the gland, as they create the necessary force to move the milk through the duct.

In addition to their role in milk production, myoepithelial cells of the tertiary lactiferous duct also play a vital role in the prevention of breast cancer. These cells are known to have antiproliferative properties, meaning that they are able to prevent the growth and development of cancerous cells within the mammary gland. As a result, myoepithelial cells are essential in maintaining the overall health of the mammary gland and reducing the risk of breast cancer.

Overall, myoepithelial cells of the tertiary lactiferous duct are a critical component of the mammary gland. Their ability to contract and move milk through the duct, as well as their antiproliferative properties, make them essential for the efficient functioning and overall health of the gland.
CL:1000465:
Chromaffin cells of the ovary are neuroendocrine cells that secrete catecholamines, including epinephrine and norepinephrine. These cells are derived from neural crest cells and are found in the medulla of the ovary. The primary function of these cells is to modulate ovarian function by regulating blood flow and ovulation. 

Chromaffin cells of the ovary are stimulated by the sympathetic nervous system and are responsible for the release of catecholamines in response to stress. These hormones act on various tissues within the ovary, including the theca and granulosa cells, to regulate steroidogenesis and stimulate follicular development.
