Lateral ventricle glial cells, also known as ependymal cells, are specialized cells that line the lateral ventricles of the brain and play a crucial role in maintaining the homeostasis of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). These cells form a thin epithelial layer in the ventricular system that separates the CSF from the brain and other tissues. Their primary function is to regulate the flow of CSF by producing and secreting it into the ventricles, as well as absorbing excess CSF to prevent a buildup. 

In addition to their role in regulating CSF flow, lateral ventricle glial cells also serve as stem cells in the adult brain. They are capable of self-renewal and can differentiate into various cell types, including neurons and astrocytes. Recent studies have shown that these cells play a crucial role in the formation of new neurons in the adult brain, allowing for ongoing neurogenesis throughout life. 

Dysfunction of lateral ventricle glial cells has been associated with several neurological disorders, including hydrocephalus and gliomas. Hydrocephalus is a condition characterized by an accumulation of CSF in the brain, usually due to a blockage in the ventricular system. Gliomas are a type of brain tumor that can arise from glial cells. Understanding the function and regulation of lateral ventricle glial cells is therefore crucial for the development of new therapies for these conditions.
CL:2000027:
Cerebellum basket cells are inhibitory interneurons found in the cerebellum. These cells form synapses with Purkinje cells and play an important role in regulating the activity of these cells. Basket cells are named for their distinctive appearance, which resembles a woven basket due to the presence of a dense network of axons around the soma of Purkinje cells. 

Basket cells are characterized by their fast-spiking action potential and are known to play a role in cerebellar motor control and learning. Research has shown that these cells help regulate the activity of Purkinje cells during motor tasks, and that their activity is necessary for certain types of motor learning. Studies have also suggested that dysfunction of cerebellum basket cells could be involved in the development of certain neurological disorders, such as epilepsy and ataxia.

Overall, cerebellum basket cells are an essential component of cerebellar circuitry, functioning to modulate the activity of Purkinje cells and contribute to cerebellar motor control and learning.
CL:1001606:
Foreskin keratinocytes are a type of epithelial cell that are isolated from the outermost layer of the foreskin tissue. They are characterized by their ability to differentiate into keratin-filled cells that play a crucial role in forming the barrier function of the skin. Foreskin keratinocytes perform several essential functions in the human body. For example, they are involved in protecting the skin from environmental aggressors, including sunlight, chemicals, and microorganisms.

Foreskin keratinocytes are also involved in synthesizing and secreting cytokines and growth factors that regulate skin inflammation and wound healing. In particular, foreskin keratinocytes produce interleukins, tumor necrosis factor alpha, and transforming growth factors beta, which have been shown to play crucial roles in regulating the proliferation and differentiation of other skin cells, including fibroblasts and immune cells.

Additionally, foreskin keratinocytes are commonly used in research settings to develop new therapies for skin-related diseases such as psoriasis, eczema, and skin cancer. Recent studies have also shown that foreskin keratinocytes can be used to engineer skin grafts that can be transplanted onto patients with severe burns or other injuries, providing a promising regenerative therapy option for patients with skin wounds or defects.
CL:1001573:
Nasopharyngeal epithelial cells are specialized cells found in the lining of the nasopharynx, which is located at the back of the nasal cavity and above the soft palate. These cells play a crucial role in protecting the respiratory system from pathogens and other foreign particles that enter through the nose. The nasopharynx is constantly exposed to a variety of environmental irritants, including smoke, dust, and viruses, making the nasopharyngeal epithelial cells an essential component of the body's first line of defense against infection.

The nasopharyngeal epithelial cells are responsible for creating a barrier that prevents pathogens from entering the body. They have a tight junction complex that prevents the passage of large molecules and microorganisms. Additionally, nasopharyngeal epithelial cells produce mucus, which traps inhaled particles and pathogens. The mucus layer on the surface of the cells is constantly moved by cilia towards the pharynx, where it can be expelled from the body.

Furthermore, these cells also secrete immunoglobulins, which are antibodies that help to neutralize and eliminate pathogens. These antibodies bind to antigens on the surface of the pathogen, or the pathogen itself, and act as a signal to other immune cells to eliminate the invader. Overall, the nasopharyngeal epithelial cells are crucial for maintaining a healthy respiratory system, protecting against infections and irritants, and contributing to the body's overall immune defense.
CL:1001595:
Rectum glandular cells are a type of epithelial cell found in the mucosa of the rectum. These cells are responsible for the production and secretion of mucus and other substances that lubricate the rectum and aid in the passage of feces. The rectum glandular cells are a vital component of the gastrointestinal system as they help to protect the rectum from damage and infection.

The rectum glandular cells are characterized by their columnar shape, with a nucleus located near their base. These cells are highly specialized and have numerous microvilli on their apical surface, which increase their surface area for the secretion of mucus. The mucus secreted by these cells is composed of glycoproteins, lipids, and other molecules that aid in lubrication and provide a barrier against pathogens and toxins.

Abnormalities in rectum glandular cell function can lead to a range of gastrointestinal disorders, including inflammatory bowel disease, colorectal cancer, and hemorrhoids. Researchers continue to investigate the role of these cells in rectal health and disease, with the aim of developing new therapeutic approaches for these conditions. Overall, the rectum glandular cells play a critical role in maintaining the health and function of the rectum and the gastrointestinal system as a whole.
CL:2000030:
Hypothalamus cells are the fundamental cellular units of the hypothalamus, a brain region located in the ventral part of the brain. Hypothalamus cells play a crucial role in regulating vital metabolic processes such as thermoregulation, hunger, thirst, sleep, and circadian rhythms. Hypothalamus cells comprise an array of heterogeneous cell types that are involved in the regulation of the endocrine, autonomic, and behavioral responses that are necessary for homeostatic control of the body.

The two major types of hypothalamus cells are the neurons and glial cells. Neurons, also known as nerve cells, are responsible for the transmission of nerve impulses or signals, whereas glial cells provide support and insulation for neurons. The hypothalamus neurons are subdivided into different populations that each project to specific brain regions regulating different physiological functions. Some of the neurons are involved in controlling feeding behavior, while others are involved in controlling reproductive physiology.

Moreover, the hypothalamus cells are highly responsive to changes in nutrient availability and metabolic status, allowing them to dynamically adapt to changing energy requirements and maintain metabolic balance. They play a crucial role in processing signals from peripheral tissues and coordinating appropriate behavioral, metabolic, and endocrine responses to maintain physiological homeostasis. Therefore, understanding the cellular and molecular mechanisms that underlie hypothalamus cell function is critical for the development of effective therapeutic strategies for controlling metabolic disorders such as obesity, diabetes, and other metabolic diseases.
CL:1001577:
Tonsil squamous cells are a subset of epithelial cells that line the tonsils, which are part of the lymphoid system. These cells are characterized by their flattened shape and their ability to form a barrier that protects against harmful pathogens. Tonsil squamous cells play an important role in the immune response by producing a variety of cytokines, chemokines, and immunoglobulins.

One of the primary functions of tonsil squamous cells is to prevent the entry of foreign substances into the body. They do this by forming a physical barrier with tight junctions between adjacent cells. This barrier prevents the diffusion of molecules and pathogens across the epithelium. Tonsil squamous cells also produce a variety of antimicrobial peptides and enzymes that inhibit the growth of bacteria and viruses.

In addition to their barrier function, tonsil squamous cells also have a role in the immune response. They express a variety of toll-like receptors and pattern recognition receptors that recognize bacterial and viral components. When activated, tonsil squamous cells produce cytokines and chemokines that recruit other immune cells to the site of infection. Tonsil squamous cells also produce immunoglobulins, such as IgA, that help to neutralize pathogens and prevent their entry into the body.
CL:1001435:
Periglomerular cells are a subtype of interneurons found in the olfactory bulb of the brain. They are small, GABAergic cells that play a crucial role in regulating the activity of mitral and tufted cells in the olfactory glomeruli. These cells are classified into three main types: superficial periglomerular cells, middle periglomerular cells, and deep periglomerular cells. Each type has a distinct morphology and functional role in regulating olfactory signal processing.

Superficial periglomerular cells are the most abundant type of periglomerular cells. They are located in the outermost layer of the olfactory bulb and receive direct input from the olfactory receptors. These cells provide feedforward inhibition to mitral and tufted cells, which helps to sharpen the tuning of olfactory information. Middle periglomerular cells receive synaptic input from both superficial and deep periglomerular cells, and their inhibition can both sharpen or broaden the tuning of olfactory information. Deep periglomerular cells are located in the innermost layer of the olfactory bulb and receive input from the olfactory receptor neurons as well as mitral and tufted cells. These cells provide feedback inhibition to mitral and tufted cells, which can help to modulate the overall activity of the olfactory bulb.

Periglomerular cells are critical for regulating olfactory signal processing. Perturbing their activity can lead to disruptions in the ability to discern and distinguish between different odorants. These cells have also been implicated in modulating olfactory perception during different behavioral states, such as feeding or mating. Due to their role in olfactory signal processing, periglomerular cells have become an important target in developing therapies for olfactory dysfunction and neurodegenerative disorders.
CL:2000012:
Fibroblast of pedal digit skin is a type of skin cell that plays an integral role in maintaining the structural integrity of the skin. These cells are found in the skin of the toes and fingers and are responsible for synthesizing the extracellular matrix that provides support and stability to the tissue. They are also important for wound healing, as they can differentiate into myofibroblasts that contract and aid in the closure of the wound.

In addition to their structural and repair functions, fibroblasts of pedal digit skin are also involved in immune response and cytokine signaling. These cells help to coordinate the immune response to pathogens and are involved in the production and secretion of cytokines that aid in the recruitment of immune cells to the site of infection. Fibroblasts of pedal digit skin have also been shown to play a role in the development of skin cancer, as abnormalities in their proliferation and differentiation can lead to the formation of tumors.

Overall, fibroblasts of pedal digit skin are a highly specialized and important cell type that contribute to the structural integrity, repair, and immune response of the skin. Their diverse functions make them an important focus of research in a variety of fields, including dermatology, immunology, and oncology.
CL:2000006:
The tonsil germinal center B cell is a specialized cell type that is found within the germinal centers of the tonsils, which are located in the back of the throat. These B cells are responsible for initiating the process of antibody production in response to foreign antigens, such as those from bacteria or viruses. They do this by undergoing a process known as somatic hypermutation, which introduces random mutations into their immunoglobulin genes. This leads to the generation of a diverse population of B cells, each with a unique antigen receptor, that are capable of recognizing and binding to a wide range of pathogens.

In addition to their role in antibody production, tonsil germinal center B cells also play an important role in regulating the immune response. They do this by interacting with other immune cells, such as T cells and dendritic cells, to coordinate the appropriate immune response to a given antigen. This involves the secretion of cytokines and other signaling molecules that direct the activation and differentiation of other immune cell types.

Overall, tonsil germinal center B cells are a critical component of the adaptive immune system, playing an essential role in the recognition and elimination of pathogens. Their ability to generate a diverse population of B cells and to coordinate the immune response makes them an important target for the development of vaccines and other immunotherapeutic strategies.
CL:2000001:
Peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) are a diverse group of immune cells found in the blood that play a crucial role in the immune response. PBMCs primarily consist of lymphocytes such as T cells, B cells, and natural killer (NK) cells, as well as monocytes. These cells are essential for detecting and eliminating foreign pathogens and toxins in the human body, as well as for mounting an immune response after vaccination.

T cells, which account for a majority of PBMCs, recognize and eliminate virus-infected cells and cancer cells, as well as regulate other immune responses. B cells produce and secrete antibodies, which are specialized proteins that bind to and neutralize foreign substances in the body. NK cells play a critical role in detecting and destroying tumor cells and virus-infected cells. Finally, monocytes differentiate into macrophages, which are responsible for engulfing and digesting foreign invaders and cellular debris.

PBMCs are isolated from blood samples using a technique called density gradient centrifugation, which separates them from other blood components such as red blood cells and platelets. These cells are widely used in research to study the immune system, including immune responses to vaccines, infectious diseases, and cancer. PBMCs have also been used in adoptive immunotherapy, a cancer treatment in which immune cells are removed from the body, manipulated ex vivo, and then reintroduced to the patient to target cancer cells.
CL:2000018:
Endothelial cells of the coronary artery are a type of squamous epithelial cell that lines the inner surface of the coronary artery. They play a crucial role in the regulation of blood flow and the maintenance of vascular integrity. Specifically, these cells are responsible for the control of vasoconstriction and vasodilation, which are critical processes in the regulation of blood pressure and oxygen diffusion. The production of nitric oxide, a potent vasodilator, is one of these cells' most important functions.

In addition to their role in regulating blood flow, endothelial cells of the coronary artery also serve as a barrier to prevent circulating molecules and cells from penetrating into the vessel wall. They also produce a variety of cytokines, growth factors, and extracellular matrix proteins that are essential for maintaining the health and integrity of the arterial wall. Furthermore, these cells play a critical role in the development of atherosclerosis, an inflammatory disease that manifests in the coronary arteries.

Overall, endothelial cells of the coronary artery are a vital component of the cardiovascular system. Their function in regulating blood flow and maintaining vascular integrity is critical for human health, and the study of these cells is essential for further understanding the mechanisms of cardiovascular disease.
CL:1001582:
Lateral Ventricle Neurons are cells that make up a significant part of the nervous system in warm-blooded animals, including humans. These cells are located in the lateral ventricles of the brain and function as specialized nerve cells. Their primary function is to process information and relay signals to other neurons through a complex network of synaptic connections. 

Lateral Ventricle Neurons can be classified into two main types based on their morphology, i.e., pyramidal neurons and interneurons. Pyramidal neurons are large and have a triangular soma (cell body), while interneurons are smaller with a spherical soma. Pyramidal neurons have long axons, which allow them to send signals over long distances in the brain. In contrast, interneurons have short axons, which primarily connect local circuits within the brain.

The lateral ventricle neurons play critical roles in cognitive and emotional processes such as learning and memory. Specifically, pyramidal neurons in the hippocampus are involved in spatial navigation and the formation of new memories, while interneurons help maintain the balance between excitation and inhibition in neural circuits. Therefore, understanding the properties and functions of lateral ventricle neurons is essential for unraveling the complex mechanisms of neurological diseases that arise from the dysfunction of these cells.
CL:1001561:
Vomeronasal sensory neurons are specialized chemosensory cells located in the vomeronasal organ (VNO) within the nasal cavity. These cells are responsible for detecting pheromones, chemical signals that animals use for communication and mating behaviors. The VNO is found in many species of mammals, including rodents, carnivores, and ungulates, and is distinct from the main olfactory system that detects other odorants in the environment.

The vomeronasal sensory neurons have unique membrane proteins, called vomeronasal receptors, that allow them to bind to and detect pheromones with high specificity. The receptors are divided into two families: V1Rs and V2Rs. V1Rs are activated by small, volatile molecules such as male-derived pheromones, while V2Rs detect larger, protein-based pheromones from females such as those associated with pregnancy. Once activated, the VNO neurons project to the accessory olfactory bulb where further processing of pheromone signals occurs.

The detection of pheromones by vomeronasal sensory neurons has important behavioral implications for animals. For example, male rodents use pheromones detected by the VNO to identify females in estrus, distinguish between siblings and strangers, and establish social hierarchies. In addition, the VNO is also involved in the detection of predator odors and fear responses. The importance of the vomeronasal system in regulating social and reproductive behaviors is reflected in its preserved function across a wide range of mammalian species.
CL:1001517:
Stomach enteroendocrine cells (EECs) are specialized cells located in the gastric mucosa. These cells are responsible for the secretion of various hormones that regulate gastric motility, acid secretion, and nutrient uptake. EECs are one of the major endocrine cell types in the stomach constituting approximately 1% of the total cells. EECs are classified according to the hormone they secrete, which includes gastrin, ghrelin, somatostatin, and cholecystokinin.

Gastrin-secreting EECs are the most abundant cells in the stomach. They are located in the antrum region and control the secretion of gastric acid, pepsin, and mucus. Gastrin stimulates parietal cells in the stomach to produce hydrochloric acid and also stimulates the growth of the gastric mucosa. Ghrelin-secreting EECs are found mostly in the fundus and upper body of the stomach. Ghrelin is a hormone that stimulates appetite and regulates energy balance. It also promotes the release of growth hormone and plays a role in glucose metabolism.

Somatostatin-secreting EECs are located throughout the stomach, duodenum, and pancreas. Somatostatin regulates the secretion of other hormones, including gastrin, insulin, and glucagon. It also inhibits the secretion of gastric acid and pancreatic enzymes. Cholecystokinin-secreting EECs are located in the duodenum and control the release of bile from the gallbladder and pancreatic enzymes. Overall, stomach enteroendocrine cells play a crucial role in maintaining digestive homeostasis and regulating various physiological processes in the gastrointestinal tract.
CL:1001451:
Sensory neurons of dorsal root ganglia (DRG) are primary afferent neurons that innervate peripheral tissues and transmit sensory information from the body to the central nervous system (CNS). These neurons are pseudounipolar, meaning that they have a single process that divides into two branches: a peripheral process that detects stimuli in the periphery and a central process that synapses with second-order neurons in the spinal cord. Sensory DRG neurons can be classified based on the type of stimulus they detect, including mechanoreceptors, thermoreceptors, and nociceptors.

Mechanoreceptors are sensory neurons that respond to mechanical stimuli such as touch, pressure, or vibration. These neurons have specialized receptors on their peripheral processes that detect physical displacement of the receptor cells. Thermoreceptors detect changes in temperature and can be categorized as either warm- or cold-sensitive. Nociceptors are sensory neurons that respond to noxious stimuli, such as tissue damage, and are responsible for the sensation of pain. These neurons have specialized receptors on their peripheral processes that detect harmful stimuli and transduce this signal into an electrical impulse that is transmitted to the CNS.

The function of sensory DRG neurons is critical for normal sensation and movement, but perturbations in their activity can lead to symptoms such as chronic pain or sensory deficits. Dysfunction of mechanoreceptors can lead to disorders such as neuropathies or complex regional pain syndrome. Thermoreceptors and nociceptors are also involved in multiple pain disorders, including migraine and fibromyalgia. Understanding the function and pathology of sensory DRG neurons is essential for the development of treatments for these debilitating conditions.
CL:2000056:
Meynert cells are large neurons found specifically in the basal forebrain region of vertebrate brains. They are typically located in the nucleus basalis of Meynert, a part of the basal forebrain that is involved in the regulation of attention and memory. Meynert cells are characterized by their extensive axonal projections which release the neurotransmitter acetylcholine, a critical signaling molecule involved in cognitive processes.

Meynert cells receive input from other neurons in the basal forebrain region and project their axons widely throughout the cortex. Studies have shown that damage to the nucleus basalis of Meynert and subsequent loss of Meynert cells is strongly associated with cognitive impairment and dementia, particularly in diseases such as Alzheimer's disease. 

Research on Meynert cells has also indicated that they may be involved in regulating sleep-wake cycles, as well as modulating sensory processing and attention. Overall, Meynert cells play an important role in the regulation of cognitive and behavioral processes in the brain.
CL:2000014:
Fibroblast of upper leg skin is a type of connective tissue cell that is responsible for the synthesis and maintenance of the extracellular matrix (ECM) in the upper leg skin. These cells are roughly spindle-shaped and are spread throughout the dermis layer of the skin. Fibroblasts of upper leg skin play a crucial role in wound healing, tissue repair, and maintaining skin elasticity.

One of the main functions of fibroblasts is the synthesis of ECM, which is a complex network of proteins and carbohydrates that provide structural support for cells. Fibroblasts secrete a variety of ECM components, including collagen, elastin, and proteoglycans, all of which contribute to the strength and flexibility of the skin. In addition, fibroblasts also secrete growth factors and cytokines that regulate cell proliferation, differentiation, and migration during the healing process.

Fibroblasts of upper leg skin are also involved in the production and remodeling of scar tissue. After an injury or surgery, these cells proliferate and migrate to the site of tissue damage, where they synthesize a provisional matrix that is later replaced by ECM. Over time, fibroblasts continue to remodel the ECM, altering its composition and organization to improve tissue function and restore skin integrity. Overall, fibroblasts of upper leg skin play an essential role in maintaining the health and function of the skin and are critical for wound healing and tissue repair.
CL:2000028:
Cerebellum glutamatergic neurons are a type of neuron found in the cerebellum, a region of the brain responsible for coordinating movement and balance. These neurons use the neurotransmitter glutamate to communicate with other neurons, and their function is essential for proper cerebellar function. Cerebellum glutamatergic neurons receive input from various other parts of the brain, including the cerebral cortex, and process this information to regulate motor coordination.

The morphology and connectivity of cerebellum glutamatergic neurons are critical for their function. These neurons have a highly branched dendritic tree which allows them to receive input from numerous other neurons. They also have long axons that project to other parts of the cerebellum and the brainstem. The synapses formed by cerebellum glutamatergic neurons are essential for the precise coordination of movement and for the fine-tuning of motor commands.

Deficits in cerebellum glutamatergic neuron function have been linked to various neurological disorders, including ataxia, tremors, and motor coordination deficits. Researchers are actively investigating the role of these neurons and their circuits in disease pathogenesis to develop novel therapies that may help restore proper cerebellar function. Overall, cerebellum glutamatergic neurons play a crucial role in the regulation of movement and are fundamental for maintaining proper motor coordination.
CL:1001286:
The inner medulla vasa recta descending limb cell, also known as the vasa recta descending limb endothelial cell, is a specialized cell that lines the descending portion of the vasa recta in the renal medulla. The vasa recta is a network of capillaries that runs parallel to the renal tubules and is responsible for maintaining the osmotic equilibrium of the medulla. The inner medulla vasa recta descending limb cell plays a crucial role in this process as it serves as a barrier between the blood and the interstitial fluid and helps regulate the exchange of water and solutes.

One of the primary functions of the inner medulla vasa recta descending limb cell is to regulate the movement of water and solutes across the capillary wall. This is accomplished through a series of molecular transport mechanisms that allow for the selective movement of ions, water, and other molecules. Specifically, the cell uses specialized transport proteins, such as aquaporins and ion channels, to facilitate the movement of these molecules across the cell membrane. This process is critical for maintaining the osmotic balance of the renal medulla and preventing the buildup of water and solutes in the interstitial fluid.

In addition to its transport functions, the inner medulla vasa recta descending limb cell also plays an important role in regulating vascular tone and blood flow. The cell produces several vasoactive substances, such as nitric oxide and endothelin-1, which regulate the constriction and dilation of the vasa recta. This process is critical for maintaining proper blood flow and regulating the exchange of water and solutes between the capillaries and the interstitial fluid. Overall, the inner medulla vasa recta descending limb cell is a complex and specialized cell that plays a critical role in regulating the osmotic balance of the renal medulla and maintaining proper blood flow and vascular tone.
CL:2000017:
Fibroblasts of the peridontal ligament (PDL) are spindle-shaped cells that play a crucial role in maintaining the structural integrity of the periodontium. The PDL connects the cementum of the tooth root to the alveolar bone, acting as a cushion and allowing for shock absorption during mastication. Fibroblasts of the PDL are the most abundant cell type in the ligament and regulate its extracellular matrix.

The extracellular matrix of the PDL is composed of various types of collagen fibers, proteoglycans, and glycoproteins. Fibroblasts of the PDL secrete and organize these extracellular matrix components, contributing to the mechanical properties of the periodontium. Additionally, these cells actively remodel the extracellular matrix through the expression of matrix metalloproteinases and tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases.

Fibroblasts of the PDL also have immunomodulatory functions, producing cytokines and chemokines that regulate immune cell migration and activity in the periodontium. Dysfunction of PDL fibroblasts can lead to periodontal diseases such as periodontitis, where inflammation and degradation of the extracellular matrix result in tooth mobility and potential tooth loss. Overall, fibroblasts of the PDL play a crucial role in maintaining the structural and functional integrity of the periodontium through regulation of the extracellular matrix and immune response.
CL:2000020:
The inner cell mass (ICM) is a group of cells found within the blastocyst of early-stage embryos. ICM cells are pluripotent, meaning they have the ability to differentiate into any of the three primary germ layers: endoderm, mesoderm, and ectoderm. These layers go on to form the various tissues and organs of the body. ICM cells are also involved in the formation of the extra-embryonic membranes, which provide nutrients and support to the developing embryo. 

ICM cells have garnered considerable attention in the field of stem cell research because of their vast potential for therapeutic applications. Researchers are interested in their ability to differentiate into any cell type, which could be used to repair damaged tissues or organs. Scientists have also used ICM cells to create induced pluripotent stem (iPS) cells, which are adult cells that have been reprogrammed to have similar pluripotent capabilities as ICM cells. These cells have been used in disease modeling, drug discovery, and regenerative medicine.

ICM cells play a critical role in the development of the embryo and have vast potential in the field of stem cell research. Their ability to differentiate into any cell type makes them unique and valuable in applications such as regenerative medicine and disease modeling.
CL:2000041:
Dermis microvascular lymphatic vessel endothelial cells are a specialized type of cells that line the lymphatic vessels within the dermis, the second layer of the skin. These cells play a crucial role in maintaining fluid balance and immune function by facilitating the transport of lymph, a fluid that contains immune cells and waste products, from the skin to the lymph nodes.

These endothelial cells have unique structural and functional characteristics that make them highly specialized in their function. They have a complex network of intercellular junctions that form the lymphatic vessel walls and allow for the selective passage of fluids and immune cells, while preventing the entry of harmful pathogens. In addition, they express specific receptors that allow them to interact with immune cells and other signaling molecules in the lymphatic fluid.

The dermis microvascular lymphatic vessel endothelial cells work in conjunction with other cells in the immune system to provide a defense against infections and other foreign substances that enter the skin. They help to transport immune cells to the site of infection or injury and facilitate their communication with other immune cells. They also play a critical role in regulating the immune response by controlling the transport of antigens and cytokines, molecules that regulate immune cell activity. Overall, these cells are essential for maintaining the health and function of the skin and the immune system as a whole.
CL:1001590:
Epididymis glandular cells are a type of epithelial cell found in the epididymis, a coiled tube located behind the testes in male mammals. These cells are responsible for the secretion of a variety of proteins and other substances that facilitate sperm maturation and storage within the epididymis. Glandular cells are also involved in the secretion of fluid that contributes to the composition of semen.

One of the main functions of epididymis glandular cells is the production of proteins that make up a portion of the semen. These proteins help to protect and nourish sperm as they travel through the male reproductive tract, and may also play a role in sperm motility and capacitation. Additionally, glandular cells in the epididymis are responsible for the secretion of substances that regulate pH and ion balance within the epididymal fluid, which is crucial for the survival and proper function of sperm.

Another important function of epididymis glandular cells is the uptake of proteins and other substances from the lumen of the epididymis. This process, known as endocytosis, allows the cells to recycle and reutilize molecules that would otherwise be lost from the epididymal fluid. Some glandular cells may also be involved in the degradation of excess or damaged proteins, further contributing to the complex environment of the epididymal lumen. Overall, the complex functions of epididymis glandular cells are critical for the proper development, maturation, and transport of sperm through the male reproductive tract.
CL:2000034:
The anterior lateral line neuromast hair cell is a specialized type of mechanosensory cell found in fish and amphibians. These cells are located within the neuromasts of the anterior lateral line, which is a row of sensory organs that detect movement and vibration in the surrounding water. The hair cells are responsible for detecting changes in the water flow that occur as the result of nearby movements, such as those made by prey or predators. 

The hair cells are named for their unique morphology, which includes a bundle of hair-like projections that extend from the apical surface of the cell. These extensions, called stereocilia, are arranged in a graded fashion, with the longest at one end and the shortest at the other. When the stereocilia are bent due to fluid movement, they trigger a series of biochemical and electrical events that ultimately lead to the generation of an action potential in the nerve fibers that synapse with the hair cells. 

In addition to their crucial role in detecting prey and predators, the anterior lateral line neuromast hair cells also play a key role in maintaining balance and orientation in water. They are able to detect changes in the direction and flow rate of water, which allows the animal to detect changes in its own position relative to the surrounding environment. Dysfunction or loss of these cells can lead to a variety of problems, including difficulty swimming, reduced ability to feed, and increased vulnerability to predators.
CL:2000033:
Limb basal cells of epidermis are specialized cells found in the skin's outermost layer, also known as the epidermis. These cells play a vital role in skin homeostasis, serving as a source of new skin cells that constantly replenish the epidermis. Limb basal cells have the unique ability to self-renew and differentiate into various types of skin cells, including keratinocytes that make up the majority of the epidermis.

Limb basal cells are located in the basal layer of the epidermis and are in close proximity to the basement membrane that separates the epidermis from the underlying dermis. They are responsible for maintaining the integrity of the skin barrier, which serves as the first line of defense against environmental insults such as UV radiation, pathogens, and chemicals. In addition to their role in skin homeostasis, limb basal cells have also been implicated in skin tumorigenesis, where their abnormal proliferation and differentiation contribute to the development of skin cancers.

Overall, limb basal cells of epidermis are a critical component of the skin's barrier function and serve as a source of new skin cells that maintain the integrity of the epidermis. Their ability to self-renew and differentiate into different skin cell types highlights their importance in skin homeostasis and regeneration. Further understanding of the mechanisms regulating these cells may have implications for the development of new treatments for skin diseases and cancers.
CL:1001575:
Uterine cervix squamous cells are a type of stratified squamous epithelial cell that are found in the lining of the uterine cervix. These cells form a protective layer that helps to prevent infection, injury, and other types of damage. Uterine cervix squamous cells are unique in that they undergo a process known as squamous metaplasia, where they transform from columnar epithelial cells to the squamous cells that make up the lining of the cervix. 

The function of uterine cervix squamous cells is to provide a barrier between the vaginal canal and the uterus. These cells are responsible for preventing pathogens, such as bacteria and viruses, from entering the reproductive system and causing infection. Additionally, uterine cervix squamous cells play a critical role in maintaining the health and integrity of the cervix, which is necessary for successful pregnancy and childbirth. These cells are also responsible for the production of mucus that helps to lubricate the vaginal canal and facilitate the movement of sperm during sexual intercourse. 

Uterine cervix squamous cells can be affected by a variety of diseases and conditions, including human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, cervical cancer, and inflammation. Regular Pap smears and other screening tests are important for detecting any abnormalities or changes in these cells, as early detection and treatment can help to prevent serious health problems. Overall, uterine cervix squamous cells are a vital component of the female reproductive system, playing a critical role in protecting against infection and maintaining reproductive health.
CL:2000047:
Brainstem motor neurons are a group of cells that are involved in the control of voluntary and involuntary movements. These neurons are found in the brainstem, which is the region of the brain that controls many essential functions, including breathing, heart rate, and blood pressure. These neurons receive signals from different areas of the brain, such as the cerebral cortex, and send signals to muscles and glands throughout the body, allowing us to move and react to our environment.

Brainstem motor neurons are classified as either upper motor neurons or lower motor neurons.
